description: In 1967, a group of physicians toured the affluent society and what they found shocked the public: widespread hunger, malnutrition and even such horrible dietdeficiency diseases as marasmus and kwashiorkor, reminiscent of Biafra or Bangladesh. The physicians report, sponsored by the Field Foundation, helped set off a major Feaeral antihunger program. Now the foundation has taken another look at hunger America and its report shows that the national effort has been a resounding success.

title: Bangor Agrees To Stock Option
description: David W. Wallace, chairman and president of the Bangor Punta Corporation, said that the company had signed an agreement whereby the Bisping Capital Investment Company of Frankfurt would acquire a minority stock interest in Bangor Punta.

title: Male Breakthrough in Sports
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 1 (AP)  A Federal judge ruled today that a male high school senior had been unconstitutionally barred from the girls volleyball team at his school and ordered that he be allowed to play.

title: Angry Vietnam Veterans Form Group to Spur Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  A group of Vietnam War veterans, angered at the Carter Administration's policies toward them, have formed a national organization that seeks to spur employment, educational benefits and health care, as well as a broad debate, to come to terms With the reality of Vietnam and its lessons for us.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: A man with a strong background of administrative leadership in the chemical industry. Robed A., Schoellhorn, was named chief executive officer of Abbott Laboratories last month after barely six years with the company, which he joined as executive vice president for its hospital group. Before that he spent 26 years at the American Cyanamid Company, advancing from a chemist in a Philadelphia branch laboratory through the sales and management ranks to the presidency of its Lederle division.

title: Pact With Mobil Averts Walkout; Other Talks Set
description: A strike by drivers who deliver gasoline to service stations In the New York metropolitan area was apparently averted early yesterday when a tentative agreement was reached with Mobil, one of the six major companies that had been threatened with a walkout.

title: Radio
description: 8:159 WQXR. Symphony No. 9, Shostakovich; Don Quichotte: Pas de Deux, Minkus.

title: National Fights Merger Review
description: MIAMI, May 1 (AP)  National Airlines and two labor unions have asked a Federal court to halt the Civil Aeronautics Board's review of a merger proposal by Texas International Airlines, saving the review may be biased.

title: Jury Unable to Reach Verdict in Davis Murder Trial
description: The 11weeklong murder trial of Cleveland McKinley Davis, a reported leader of the Attica, N.Y., prison uprising who was accused of killing two police officers and a former fellow Attica inmate on a Brooklyn street last year, ended yesterday with the jury unable to agree on a verdict.

title: Legislator's Role Mulled By Starrett
description: The Starrett Housing Corporation disclosed yesterday that it would soon seek legal advice to determine whether it would be advisable for a Congressman or his family and friends to join the board of the huge housing company.

title: Man Is Awarded $1,600 a Month In Alimony. Case
description: Henry Durand Irwin yesterday was awarded $1,600 a month for life from his wife of 26 years, becoming the first man in New York State to win a major alimony award since the Supreme Court of the United States struck down all state laws prohibiting alimony payments to men.

title: Stage: Misanthrope
description: FROM time to time someone will make the argument that children waste their time studying an impractical language like French, and should be swotting up the tongues of crisis and profit such as Russian, Chinese or Arabic.

title: Economic Scene
description: INFLATION is heating up throughout the industrial world, even in the countries regarded as oases of price stability.

title: CHARLES TRYNIN
description: Charles Trynin, a lawyer who specialized in stockholder litigation, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 2 Fifth Avenue.

title: Chile Arrests Hundreds at Rallies
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 1 The police arrested hundreds of people trying to hold May Day rallies today while President Augusto Pinochet told proGovernment union delegates that he would not give way to internal or foreign pressures for political liberalization.

title: Vicente Geigel Polanco, 76, Dies; Puerto Rican Writer and Lawyer
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., May 1 (UPI)  Vicente Geigel Polanco, a Puerto Rican writer, lawyer and politician, died yesterday. Be was 76 years old.

title: Young Visits Papua New Guinea
description: PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea, May 1 (Reuters)  Andrew Young, the United States chief delegate to the United Nations, arrived here today for a threeday visit that will include talks with Prime Minister Michael Somare.

title: Dollar Advances Sharply In Active Tokyo Trading
description: TOKYO, May 1  The United States dollar rose sharply against the yen in heavy trading on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today, despite heavy intervention by the Bank of Japan.

title: Deatha
description: ARONHelene 5.74. of 19 East Wooley Lane, Great Neck, NY. Passed away in West Palm Beach, Florida. on Sunday APr 29, 1979. Survived by her beloved husband Lester of Great Neck and devoted sister Lucille Ross. Family will receive friends this evening (Wed. from 7:309:30pm) at Nassau North Chapel. Services will be held on Thursday, at 1pm, from the Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. NY. Interment will follow. Cedar Park Cemetery; Paramus. NJ.

title: Careers
description: Purchasing Agents Are In Demand

title: Australia Beats Canada In Federation Cup Tennis
description: MADRID, May 1 (AP)  Secondseeded Australia, led by Dianne From holtz and Wendy Turnbull, easily defeated Canada today and advanced to. the second round of the 32nation Federation Cup tennis tournament.

title: Study Suggests Readers Want Newspapers That Care
description: What do readers want to read in their newspapers?

title: The Context of College Cheating
description: A recent report by the Carnegie Commission on the ethical standards of college students, professors and administrators paints a depressing picture of cheating and other unethical practices. The commission offers useful suggestions for policing such conduct  but few insights info its causes.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Arkansas Power and Light Company, Little Rock, one of the five operating companies of Middle South Utilities Inc., has elected Jerry L. Maulden president and chief executive officer, succeeding Arch P. Prettit, who resigned.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, MAY 1, 1979

title: Sonics Top Suns in Western Opener, 10893
description: SEATTLE, May 1  John Johnson had heard all the talk. He knew that Walter Davis had led the Phoenix Suns easily through two playoff rounds, to the Western Conference final against the Seattle SunerSonics. He was con. stantly reminded how important it was to stop Davis, because everyone wanted to know how he was going to do it. So Johnson raised a point of his own.

title: State Senate Approves A DeathPenalty Bill
description: ALBANY, May 1A new attempt to restore the death penalty in New York State began today as the Senate Codes Committee approved a capital punishment bill slightly different from the legislation passed by the Assembly earlier this year.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Notes on People
description: It was Lewis Rudin C.B.E. yesterday after the realestate , developer and chairman of the Association for a Better New York became an honorary Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire, an honor one grade below that of knighthood.

title: CARDBOARD MAKERS TO PAY $300 MILLION TO END PRICING SUIT
description: Twentytwo manufacturers of corrugated cardboard have agreed to settle for $300 million a civil pricefixing suit brought by their customers. The settlement was reported to be the largest ever in a private antitrust suit.

title: Plum Island Scientists Discover Antiserums for a Feared Disease
description: Researchers at the Department of Agriculture's Animal Disease Center on Plum Island, N.Y., say they have successfully concluded their investigation of Rift Valley fever, a disease so destructive that Long Island officials had expressed alarm when they discovered that the work was being carried on there.

title: News of the Theater
description: THERE'S nothing new about making a film version of a Broadway play, but Louis La Russo's Knockout, opening Sunday at the Helen Hayes, will hit the silver screen with a different kind of punch. Thus, there will be none of the usual Hollywoodstyle suspense preceding the film: Who will star? How big is the deal? When is the release date? Instead, Bill Sargent, the producer, is taking Danny Aiello and the rest of the Broadway cast to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on May 27 and will film a performance of the play on the stage of the Opera House. Mr. Sargent plans to book the film into 600 movie theaters around the country for a threeweek run, starting Sept.7.

title: A Hot Line Grows Cold After the Business Day
description: BUCHANAN, N.Y.  Copies of an emergency plan that have been distributed at the Indian Point nuclear power generating station here contain an Albany telephone number designated as the hot line to report a serious nuclear mishap to the State Department of Health.

title: Carter and Ohira to Meet Today
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  American and Japanese officials said today that they expected the visit here of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira to result in the resumption of negotiations over Japanese Government procurement, an issue that has stirred Congressional resentment over Japan's trading practices.

title: China Is Said to Threaten Vietnam With New War Over Provocations
description: PEKING, May 1 Chinese leaders reportedly told Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today that Peking would carry out another military strike against Vietnam if Hanoi continues its provocations.

title: Chile Workers, Unable to Strike, May Quit
description: PUENTE ALTO, Chile, April 30  The 1,500 workers at the paper factory here, Chile's largest, have voted to quit their jobs May 8 unless they get a wage increase and costofliving bonus.

title: Canada Chess Meet Barring Korchnoi
description: MONTREAL  The richest tournament in chess history, the Man and his World Challenge Cup, has begun here, and the runnerup in last summer's world championship, Viktor Korchnoi, is the only one of the world's best players who is not present.

title: Yanks Score, 128, in 11th
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 1  With an incredible relief performance by Tommy John after the regular relief crew had again failed and a fiverun rally in the 11th inning, the Yankees defeated the California Angles by 128 tonight.

title: March Gain In Orders Leads 1979
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) New orders received by the nation's factories climbed 1.8 percent during March, the largest rise of 1979 and evidence the economy may still have some spark, the Commerce Department said today.

title: When a State Goes insane
description: To have known about the butchery in Idi Amin's Uganda, it turns out, was to know very little. Maybe 100,000 persons were murdered in eight years, maybe 300,000, out of 12 million. Mostly they disappeared, one at a .time, to be shot or starved, bludgeoned with car axles, sledgehammers and machetes, or thrown to crocodiles. When Tanzanians liberated the Kampala prisons two weeks ago, they found the underground cells packed with corpses; only a few skeletal figures had survived by drinking their own urine and eating the flesh of the dead.

title: Bridge:
description: In a club duplicate game, a player who takes a long time to play a particular deal will quickly find himself in trouble with the tournament director, since his extended thought inevitable delays several other players. More latitude is permitted in knockout team play, and within reasonable limits any player is entitled to take his time thinking about a difficult situation.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CLASS OF 79 One of the more serenely elegant musical vignettes in town is Joan St. James at her regular post, the piano of the Park Lane Hotel's restaurant, where she plays Tuesdays through Saturdays from 6 P.M. to midnight. Although the instrument used to be tucked just out of view from the adjacent cocktail lounge, the piano has now been moved closer to the connecting archway. With the highceiling accoustics, the music carries nicely into both rooms.

title: New Muse Museum To Honor 9 Blacks
description: An educator, a photographer, a dentist, a writer, a musician and political figures are among nine winners of the . New Muse Community Museum's annual prizes for black Brooklynites who have distinguished themselves in their chosen professions and through service to their fellow men.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: THE rangeoven combination in most kitchens is allelectric or allgas, which is too bad. Electricity and gas both have their advantage; and disadvantages, and when I think of an ideal kitchen I think of one with a gas range and an electric oven.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Negotiators to Settle All Arms Pact Issues Before a Summit Talk
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to settle all remaining issues in the strategic arms limitation treaty before President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, meet, a State Department official said today.

title: Car Production Lagged in April
description: DETROIT, May 1 (UPI)  Domestic car production, crippled by an 11day truckers strike, fell 18.3 percent in April, putting the year's output below last year's pace for the first time.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The House Commerce Committee rejected President Carter's request for standby authority to impose gasoline rationing, even though the President had called the measure imperative. The committee, which had also turned down the proposal last week, voted to send it to the House floor without any recommendation. Congressional sources said the measure faced a difficult fight. [Page D1.]

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Altered South Africa Union Laws Could Aid Blacks
description: CAPE TOWN, May 1A Governmentappointed commission today recommended cautious changes in South African labor laws that would grant union bargaining rights to blacks but maintain some other aspects of a union system that has been A pillar of apartheid.

title: Advertising
description: Magazine Is Digest Of Reading

title: They're Still Wild About Harry's
description: The Contessa is not at home, my Colonel, he said. They believe you might find her at Harry's.

title: Japan to Aid 4 U.S. Institutions
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  The Government of Japan will make a contribution of $1 million to each of four cultural and academic institutions in the United States, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the Embassy of Japan announced here today.

title: National Gallery, London, Admits Picasso, Matisse
description: LONDON (Reuters)  The National Gallery of London, Britain's most important museum of painting, has admitted Picasso and Matisse to its ranks of old masters.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS The Poisoned Shamrock
description: LONDON  At Dublin Castle last month, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Thomas P. ONeill Jr., reproached the British Government for using Northern Ireland as a political football. The British, however, know a form of football different from that known to Tip ONeill. Americans run with the ball; Europeans just keep on kicking it. The thought that reached the English may well not have been that which Mr. ONeill intended to convey.

title: Q&A
description: Q. on my last visit to France, we dined twice on a dish called raie au beurre noir. The raie, a kind of fish, was as tender and sweet as scallops. Does this fish exist in the United States, and how do you cook it?

title: Ohio Village Evacuated in Fire
description: ATLANTA, Ohio, May 1 (UPI)  A fire and explosion ripped through a fertilizer plant in this southcentral Ohio community of 150 persons today, releasing dangerous gases ana wrong me evacuation of the entire village. Danny Kirkpatrick, chief of the New Holland Fire Department, said that the blaze had started in the eaves of the Sohigro Company's plant. The company manager, James Wagner, put the loss at $400,000.

title: Moon Church Charged By S.E.C. in Bank Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the Unification Church International, founded by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, had violated fraud provisions of securities laws by secretly investing in the Diplomatic National Bank of Washington.

title: VANCE BIDS THE U.S. ADJUST TO NEW ERA
description: WASHINGTON. May 1  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the United States required a new kind of diplomacy to deal with what he called the ,deep and rapid change taking place in a world no longer dominated by traditional power centers.

title: Citicorp Notes Higher
description: Citicorp sold $100 million of 91day notes yesterday at an average rate of 10.125 percent, up from 9.838 percent last week. Bids accepted ranged from 10.04 percent to 10.14 percent, with $810.5 million submitted. The bankholding company, which owns Citibank, said it would sell $100 million of notes next Tuesday and would accept minimum bids of $200,000. Until now, the minimum had been $500,000.

title: Dow Jones Buys Out Information Service
description: Dow Jones & Company said it had bought the Bunker Ramo Corporation's half of a computerized news retrieval service formed as a joint venture by the two concerns in 1971. The price was not disclosed.

title: Sanjay Gandhi Arrested With Backers at Protest
description: NEW DELHI, May 1 Sanjay Gandhi, the son of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, and 388 young supporters were arrested today after a clash with the police in New Delhi's main shopping section

title: McEnroe Routs Alexander
description: DALLAS, May 1 (AP)  John McEnroe, after a feud with officials, trounced Australia's John Alexander, 64, 60, 62, in the opening match of the $260,000 World Championship Tennis eightman finals tonight.

title: Rangers Defeat Islanders by 31, Take 21 Edge
description: The Rangers were all Bobby Orrs and Rocket Richards last night at Madison Square Garden. That was what it took to turn back the Islanders, 31, and give the Rangers a 21 lead in their fourofsevengame National Hockey League semifinal series.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Seoul Will Buy Rice From U.S.
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 1 (AP) South Korea has decided to make an emergency purchase of 504,000 tons of rice from the United States, the Agriculture and Fishery Minister, Lee Heeil, said today.

title: Where Derby Favorite Was Born
description: VERSAILLES, Ky., May 1The 17th of February, 1976, was mild for that time of year with temperatures in the 50's, and although there were occasional showers the horses on Buck Pond Farm were out in the fields as they always are when weather permits. Two or three broodmares were getting close to their time and the foaling barn was being prepared for them when, at 8:25 A.M., somebody saw the 6yearold gray, Spectacular, lying down just beyond, the farm manager's cottage. About 11 months earlier Spectacular had had her first date, traveling over to Gainesway Farm near Lexington to meet a stallion named Bold Bidder. Sometimes mare's first delivery can be difficult, but by the time they got to Spectacular she already had her baby. Good, big. strone colt, Victor Heerman Jr. wrote in the foaling record. Shows quality.

title: Kennedy Broadens Truck Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  Senator Edward M. Kennedy is circulating a bill to lift regulations from the trucking industry in steps over the next four years, then abolish the Interstate Commerce Commission's authority over it.

title: Dow Up Slightly as Volume Expands
description: Takeover developments and earnings reports dominated interest in the stock market yesterday. Prices generally posted a token advance after declining for three sessions.

title: Song: Ann CarterCox
description: MOST song recitals, so called, actually are vocal athletic events, in which a famous voice must hurl itself out into an impossibly large hall, with results that can be exciting but hardly subtle or even remotely intimate. Now and then, however, the right singer and the right hall come together, and a wholly different esthetic experience is caught. That happened Monday night at Abraham Goodman House, on West 67th Street, where Ann CarterCox, a soprano not previously known to this listener, gave a genuine recital of English and American songs.

title: State Tax Investigator  Kills Robbery Suspect. In Shootout on a Roof
description: An investigator for the State Department of Taxation and Finance was enjoying his day off on a beautiful sunny afternoon yesterday. Within a 10minute period, he wound up in a shootout with two men who were apparently trying to rob a woman. One of the alleged robbers was killed.

title: Bush, With a Promise Of Candor, Declares His G.O.P. Candidacy
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  George Bush, former Director of Central Intelligence, announced his candidacy for the Presidency today as a lifelong Republican and pledged to support military strength, limited Federal spending and a new candor.

title: Basically Bach Fete Set for June 1122
description: A Basically Bach Festival will be presented for the first time by Musica Sacra at Avery Fisher Hall between June 11 and 22. Richard Westenburg, music director or tne organization, announced the plans, stating that this initial event would actually be allBach in content. He said that he expected the festival to become annual, in which case the repertory would be expanded beyond the music of Bach.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury sold 10year notes yesterday at an average yield of 9.37 percent, the highest rate on record for an issue of Government securities with that maturity.

title: Miller Calls Rate Actior No Switch
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)  The head of the Federal Reserve Board said today that if the agency pushed interest rates up further to slow the economy, no one should have been surprised.

title: Theater: An Antony In Spanish and English
description: ESTELLE PARSONS, who has directed Shakespeare's An tony and Cleopatra for The Interart Theater, has been quoted as saying about her production, I wanted it to be multiracial and mul tilingual, because I wanted to get away from the idea of just hearing Shake speare.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  The failure of a tower operator in Metuchen to switch a Wash. ingtonbound Metroliner onto an alternative southbound track led to the collision April 20 of a train and a railroad. repair vehicle that injured 73 persons and delayed train service for three hours, according to a preliminary in, vestigation by the Federal Railroad Administration..

title: Sale to Brazil to Be Studied
description: BRASILIA. May 1 (AP)  The Brazilian House of Representatives has approved the creation of a parliamentary committee to investigate the Government purchase Dec. 28 of a Brazilian subsidiary of Brascan Ltd.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Textron Inc. announced yesterday that it had reached preliminary agreement with the management and principal shareholders of Jacuzzi Brothers Inc., manufacturer of pumps and water systems, to acquire the privately owned company for $75 million in cash.

title: House Unit Rejects Gas Rationing
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  The House Commerce Commmittee rejected again today a request from President Carter for standby authority to impose gasoline rationing, even though the President asserted yesterday that the measure was imperative.

title: Curbs on Utilities' Advertising Upheld by State Court
description: Regulations limiting the advertising and promotion practices of electric companies were upheld yesterday by the New York Court of Appeals.

title: Sevareid: Days Of Reflection
description: MARSHALL, VA.

title: Kennecott to Pay CurtissWright
description: Shareholders of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, at the annual meeting yesterday in New York, approved the company's proposal to reimburse the CurtissWright Corporation for $1.8 million in outofpocket expenses CurtissWright incurred during last year's proxy contest for control of the Kennecott board.

title: Limited Participation Subject of Criticism
description: Last Friday, a worldclass swimmer, Kim Carlisle, filed suit in Cincinnati seeking to become eligible for her state high school swimming championships. She had been ruled ineligible because she had taken part in an international dual meet against West Germany as member of a United States team.

title: Smithtown G.O.P. Leader Is Arraigned
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 1  Nicholas Barbeto the Smithtown G.O.P. leader, was arraigned today on grand larceny and extortion charges for allegedly forcing the county's former insurance agent to pay him more than $100,000 $200 a week over a period of nearly 10 yearsIn return for the county business.

title: Personal Health
description: Hemorrhoids can be relieved by relatively simple treatments.

title: Califano Plans a Drive Against Problem Drinking
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  Joseph A. Califono Jr., Secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, disclosed plans today for a new antialcoholism drive whose goal is not prohibi tion, but prudence.

title: Samuel Orlinick, Scholar, Dealer In Rare Books and Manuscripts
description: Samuel Orlinick, an antiquarian book. dealer, Mozart scholar and proprietor of Scientific Library Service, died of cancer Monday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Raymond Bowers Dies At 51 in Fall Upstate; Was Cornell Professor
description: Raymond Bowers, a professor of physics at Cornell University, died Sunday following an accidental fall at Robert Treman State Park in Ithaca, N.Y. Ile was 51 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Felker's Losing Race With Red Ink at Esquire
description: More than a year and a half ago, Clay S. Felker set up editorial shop at Esquire magazine, still smarting from his loss of New York magazine to Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publishing magnate. He was amply primed by fi: nancing from an organization he had faith would stick by him for the long haul. He cheerfully promised that what happened at New York was not going to happen at Esquire.

title: Continental Oil
description: The Continental Oil Company, the nation's 21st largest industrial corporation, announced at its annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday that on July 1 it would change its name to Conoco Inc.. formally adopting what has long been its trademark and nickname.

title: Chess:
description: MONTREAL  Since Anatoly Karpov became world champion in 1975, his play has taken a turn toward a freer, more flexible approach to the openings and a greater reliance on tactics.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ON a crowded Fifth Avenue bus last week, writes Jack Hochhauser, the driver was fiercely trying to make up some of his running time by moving at a more than usual brisk pace.

title: News Summary
description: Islamic guerrillas killed an ayatollah  who was an important member of Iran's secret ruling Revolutionary Council. Ayatollah Morteza Motahari was shot in Teheran. Forghan, a new underground organization that recently declared its opposition to fanatic mullahs, took responsibility for the killing. [Page A1, Columns 23.]

title: Central Soya Purchase
description: The Central Soya Company, a leading soybean processor and grain merchandiser, announced yesterday that it had purchased 986,000 shares of its stock for 8135.3 million from the estate of Alvin B. Filbert, representing 6.4 percent of the shares outstanding. Mr. Filbert had been a director of the company following the acquisition of his company in 1972. The shares will be used for stock option plans, future acquisitions and or company needs.

title: Mr. Carter in Concrete
description: The current inflation rate of one percent a month can hardly be blamed on the President, for it was caused by uncontrollable explosions of oil and food prices and an unexpected orgy of consumer buying.

title: BUILDINGS WALKOUT IS OVER AND PICKUP OF GARBAGE STARTS
description: The strike by thousands of service employees at apartment houses and cooperatives throughout Manhattan ended yesterday as union and management officials accepted settlement terms recommended by Eric J. Schmertz, a special mediator.

title: Cluster of New Tory Stars Will Brighten Party's Future
description: BRISTOL, England, May I  Whether or not Margaret Thatcher wins Britain's general election Thursday, and some doubts about the outcome were raised today, by a new.opiniod poll, some of the brightest young Conservative politicians in years will be joining the House of Commons.

title: PIPE LEAKS TROUBLE 15 NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)  At least 15 nuclear power stations have problems with coolant water pipes that leak small amounts of radioactive water, government regulators said today.

title: Defense of Johnsons Keys Sonic Victory
description: SEATTLE, May 2  It was very easy for Dennis and John Johnson to get all the credit for Seattle's 10893 victory over Phoenix in the first game of the National Basketball Association Western Conference championship series last night. John Johnson held Walter Davis of the Suns to 13 points, his secondlowest total this season. Dennis Johnson held Paul Westphal to live baskets in 13 shots and 13 points, 11 fewer than his season average. That was how Johnson and Johnson became last night's heroes.

title: Carson Promises to Stay On Tonight Past Oct. 1
description: Johnny Carson said last night that he would remain as host of The Tonight Show on NBC beyond Oct. 1 and possibly into next year, but the 54yearold comedian left it unclear whether he would stay for the two years specified by his contract.

title: GREECE'S REENTRY INTO NATO SNAGGED
description: ATHENS, May 2  Efforts to reinstate Greece as a full member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which have been strongly backed by the United States and considered almost certain to succeed, are now floundering, according to Americkn and Greek diplomatic sources here.

title: TV. ABC Offers Ike, War Hem
description: FOR anyone who might remember Dwight David Eisenhower as an inarticulate, waffling, golfobsessed President of the United States, a sixhour television biography of the man would not appear to be the most promising of prospects.

title: Warriors Lucas Helping Driesell at Alma Mater
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., May 2 (AP)  Shorthanded after the loss Of his three assistants to other jobs, Lefty Driesell, the Maryland basketball coach, has hired John Lucas of Golden State as a graduate assistant.

title: Tarkenton to Call Plays for TV?
description: Fran Tarkenton will be on television during the next pro football season but he will probably be wearing the announcer's blazer of the one of the networks, ABC, CBS or NBC, rather than the uniform of the Minnesota Vikines.

title: Iraq Raises Oil Surcharge
description: Iraq raised the price of all grades of its oil yesterday, according to industry sources in New York. The move increases the pressure for another general price increase by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries on July 1, they said.

title: Designers Set Tables at Tiffany's
description: WE are in the process of reviving our traditions, said John Loring, Tiffany & Company's design director. And one of those traditions, missing since 1975, was the presentation of designer table settings. So 10 of the top talents in the business were invited to pick any of the store's china, silver and glass to include in their own minienvironments.

title: Piano: Teresa Compos's Beethoven
description: AT its best, Teresa Compos's playing in her recital in Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night had great charm. The pianist, who was giving her third annual recital in New York, is an uneven performer, but much that she did on this occasion was worth listening to. This included the opening piece, Beethoven's Farewell Sonata, which ranged from the thoughtful to the sparkling; it was serious without being weighty, was freely phrased with a genuine musicality, and offered a variety of colorful pianistic touches.

title: Prison Strike Optimism Is Not Apparent on S.I.
description: At 9 o'clock last night, seven New York State correction officers in windbreakers and jeans leaned dejectedly against a parked car and a sawhorse at the entrance to the Arthur Kill correctional facility on Staten Island.

title: Rangers: Revelation In Playoffs
description: The Rangers believe in themselves. That is why they fully expect to increase their 21 game advantage in tonight's fourth contest of their Stanley Cup semifinal playoffs.

title: Bend Me Mind, $13, Wins On the Grass at Aqueduct
description: Bend Me Mind, with Jorge Velasquez up, won his third turf race in a row by taking the $57,450 Hill Prince Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday before a crowd of 15,341. The Never Bend colt returned S13 to win.

title: Give Me That OldTime Darwin
description: Time was when conventional wisdom perceived the Darwin theory of natural selection as an article of faith. Chisled into stone was the truth that life ascended from lichens through reptiles to mammals and finally Homo sapiens. In this ordained order of aeveiopment, survival was reserved for the fittest. Those forms of life that could not change with the environment died out. The net result was progress.

title: Publisher of New Times Agrees to Refunds
description: Subscribers to New Times magazine, the proconsumer magazine that ceased publication in January, were never offered the option of a cash refund, even though the publisher had reportedly offered assurances that such a choice would be available, according to an assistant state attorney general who is conducting an inquiry.

title: The Art of the Furniture Maker
description: CABINETMAKING in the United States is not only alive and flourishing, it has become a highly innovative craft expressed in a dozen different ways by scores of artisans. This is the message of New Handmade Furniture: American Furniture Makers Working in Hardwood, a provocative exhibition of 36 designs opening today at the American Craft Museum, 44 West 53d Street. Much of the furniture selected is destined to make the furniture history books. As Paul J. Smith, director, put it, These pieces will become the heirlooms of tomorrow.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Greek Cypriot Prelate to Ask Diplomatic Aid in U.S.
description: ATHENS, May 2  When Archbishop Makarios of Cyprus died nearly two years ago, the political and religious powers that he and his predecessors had held for centuries were divided for the first time between two men.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: 4 Demonstrators Arrested at Georgia Wildlife Refuge
description: HARRIS NECK, Ga., May 2  Federal marshals arrested four black men unlawfully camped at the Harris Neck Wildlife Refuge this morning as they knelt in prayer. And scores of the demonstrators 'supporters  men, women and children gathered just outside the refuge's barbed wire fence  sang, cried and called on God and President Carter for help.

title: Ballet: A Cut Apollo
description: THE New York City Ballet opened its spring season Tuesday night at the New York State Theater with four of George Balanchine's ballets to music by Igor Stravinsky, including the most famous of them all, the 1928 Apollo.

title: Violin: Ronald Gorevic
description: THOUGHTFUL and reliable interpretations of the two violin and piano sonatas by Prokoviev, Bartok's First Rhapsody and Dvorak's Four Romantic Pieces were offered by Ronald Gorevic and Cary Lewis, assisting pianist, at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. The violinist, who has played in New York previously, teaches at the Cleveland Institute of Music.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: China Says Its Losses in Vietnam Were 20,000 Killed and Wounded
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  China said today that its army suffered 20,000 killed and wounded in the fourweek war with Vietnam in February and March.

title: Snow Falls on Europe In Frigid Start for May
description: PARIS, May 2 (Reuters)  Snow fell in France, the Netherlands and Britain today in the coldest start of May in Western Europe for years.

title: Notes on People
description: Sanitationmen's Changing Rooms to Get Face Lift

title: Surprises Hinted in N.F.L. Draft
description: Tom Cousineau, the 230  pound linebacker from Ohio State, plans to be present at draft headquarters at the WaldorfAstoria today, and he expects to hear Pete Rozelle, the National Foot ball League's commissioner, call out his name as the first player selected in the league's annual draft of college seniors.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amerace Corporation, a manufacturer of consumer products and components for the industrial, automotive and aerospace markets, has appointed C. Donald Caughey to the newly created position of vice presidentplanning and development.

title: 2 Publications Deny Tie to Esquire Sale
description: The American Lawyer magazine and The Soho Weekly News, both of which are largely owned by Associated Newspapers Ltd., said yesterday that the British conglomerate's sale of Esquire magazine this week would have no effect on them.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, May 2 (UPI)  Julius Kravitz, the grocery chain executive, died today of gunshot wounds sustained yesterday in a kidnapping by two men disguised as police officers.

title: Ousted Leader of Ghana Released From Custody
description: ACCRA, Ghana, May 2 (Reuters) I.K. Achearnpong, Ghana's deposed head of state, has been released from preventive custody but stripped of all military rank, the Ghana news agency reported today.

title: G.T.E. Is Cleared To Add Telenet
description: The Federal Communications Corn mission said it had approved the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation's plan to buy the Telenet Corporation, but only under certain conditions.

title: Execution Date Set for Two
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 2 (AP)  The Mississippi Supreme Court today set May 28 as the date for two convicted murderers to die in the gas chamber, but lawyers expected the courts to block the executions. The court reset the executions of Johnny Lewis Washington and John Buford Irving 3d after the United States Supreme Court refused to review their cases.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: Those who founded the United States two centuries ago, with their experience of tyranny, set out to prevent abuse of power by American Presidents. They relied on the counterpower of Congress, on a vigilant press and on the law: the Constitution itself, enforced by the courts.

title: 2 Schools Get $11.5 Million For Islamic Design Studies
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2 (AP) The Aga Khan. spiritual leader of 20 million Ismaili Moslems, has given $11.5 million to Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for the study of Islamic architecture.

title: 2 Drug Stocks Fall
description: Two prominent drug issues. SmithKline Corporation and Squibb Corporation, were the biggest losers on the active list of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in response to adverse news developments. Meanwhile, the number of declining stocks narrowly outnumbered advancing issues, as the general market closed virtually unchanged.

title: Advertising
description: MEANWHILE, back at New York magazine, founded by Clay S. Felker, 50 years old, the new, young management is riding the crest of a wave of optimism. And Joe Arm strong, age 3.5, chairman, president, editor in chief, publisher and half of the selfstyled dynamic duo, has turned his publisher's title over to Cathleen Black, 35, the former associate publisher and the other half of the duo.

title: Bomb in the Mail Kills An Official in South
description: BESSEMER, Ala., May 2 (AP)  A package bomb exploded in the Bessemer Police Commissioner's office today, killing the police lieutenant who was opening it, critically wounding the commissioner and injuring two other persons.

title: Rates Called Building Curb
description: High interest rates are beginning to have an impact on commercial property development, Citicorp Real Estate Inc. reported yesterday in its monthly survey of the mortgage market.

title: Illegal Refugee Exodus Increasing, but Hanoi Denies Encouraging It
description: SONGKLA, Thailand, May 1  Refugees from Vietnam are arriving on Southeast Asian shores in record numbers. Ethnic Chinese are estimated to make up twothirds to threequarters of the total. despite repeated denials by the Hanoi Government that it is abetting their departure.

title: CBS Radio Will Resume College Bowl on June 30
description: CBS Radio will resume weekly broadcasts of College Bowl, the quiz show that tests the erudition of undergraduate students, on June 30. The program, which originated on radio in 1953, also enjoyed an 11year run on television.

title: Rock Festival Set for Upstate
description: Another major summer rock festival is being planned for the Northeast. This one, to be called The Hamlet of Hurleyville, is scheduled for Aug. 2926 on the 290acre site of the former Columbia Hill Hotel in Sullivan County. N.Y.

title: Bonn's Trade Surplus Rises
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, May 2 (AP)  West Germany's March trade surplus was greater than the February surplus, but less than in March 1978, the Federal Statistics Offices said today.

title: Koch Reveals His Taxes With a Tale About Tails
description: By deducting, among other things, $116 for rental of formal attire for attendance at Pope's funeral in Rqme, Italy, Mayor Koch qualified for a refund on his 1978 income taxes.

title: China Warns of Love's Pitfalls
description: PEKING. May 2 (AP)  With love back as an approved subject in the Chinese press, a Shanghai newspaper has warned against love based on a pretty face, riches or property. With fame, wealth, position or beauty as the bonds for love, that kind of love is like straw, the newspaper, The Takong Daily, said yesterday. It burns fiercely, burns out quickly and in the end can bring suffering and remorse.

title: Home Beat
description: EIGHT years ago, a friend of Leslie Armstrong's, Annie Pfeiffer, complained that she couldn't find anyone to build a house that was worth living in, affordable, had some design integrity, and could be expanded when family and funds allowed. Mrs. Armstrong, left, an architect, and now a partner in the firm of Armstrong Childs Lang Associates, felt that she just couldn't afford to design simple, inexpensive houses for friends, and that her friendecouldn't afford the architectural fees I needed to break even. The two women decided to put something together to offer prospective house builders, plans for a house with a certain craftsmanship that would develop their own sense of detail, and allow them to participate in the design and construction processes. Nothing happened for years, until someone came along and thought it should be a book. With its publication, Mrs. Armstrong, who had never written a book before, said she has satisfied her evangelical need to introduce the terminology of architectural design to the layman. The Little House has just been published by Macmillan, simultaneously in hardcover ($14.95) and paperback ($8.95.)

title: Film: Japan's Animations
description: THE Film Forum's Japanese animation program is a catchall collection, which means it has the advantage of wide variety and the disadvantage of unevenness. But because the entire show lasts only 79 minutes, and because a quarter of that time is devoted to a single film of amazing mastery, the drawbacks of the set seem unimportant. Besides, even the less impressive short films on the bill reflect preoccupations with violence and overpopulation that, when presented in an animated format, become intriguingly bizarre.

title: World News Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 2 (UPI)  An American delegation flew to Uganda today to study the possibility of lifting the trade embargo that was imposed when President Idi Amin was President.

title: Fleetwood to Close 3 Vehicle Facilities
description: Fleetwood Enterprises Inc. announced yesterday that public concern over possible gasoline shortages had caused it to suspend operations at three of its recreationalvehicle plants that had only been marginally profitable in the past.

title: Murdoch Plans To Buy Papers
description: HOUSTON, May 2 (UPI)  K. Rupert Murdoch, owner of The New York Post and The San Antonio ExpressNews, plans to buy a chain of weekly newspapers in Texas, an official said today.

title: Technology
description: THE race to develop ever bigger magnetic bubble memories continues apace. For about a year the leadership in this oncearcane technology belonged to Texas Instruments Inc., the only company currently on the market, selling a device that stores up to 92,000 bits of computer language.

title: South Africa to Grant Union Rights to Many Blacks
description: CAPE TOWN, May 2  The South African Government announced today that it would grant full union rights to some of the country's seven million black workers. It will also permit companies to eliminate racial segregation in cafeterias, changing rooms and toilets, which has been mandated by law since the country was founded in 1910.

title: Connecticut Attorneys Will Drop Challenge To Schools Financing
description: HARTFORD, May 2  The two lawyers who succeeded in compelling the state to devise a new system of financing education unexpectedly announced today that they would not challenge the new school financingformula.

title: G.O.P. Leaders In Albany Make TaxCutting Bid
description: ALBANY, May 2  The Senate Republican Conference agreed today on a sevenpart taxreduction program that incorporates several elements included in Governor Carey's budget but rejected by the Legislature last month.

title: Three Doctors Rewarded For Research in Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  The first three annual awards by the General Motors Cancer Research Foundation were presented today to three doctors in recognition of their excellence and innovation in the field of cancer research.

title: Sound
description: FROM the bulging mailbag: Your column on car stereo (April 19) doesn't deal with my problem. I'm getting a new Buick, but I don't want the dashboard radio supplied by G.M. because I want to install a highquality carstereo system of my own. The dealer tells me I'd have to wait another six weeks for him to get a car without the radio. What can I do?

title: Doctors in China Are Said to Rebuild a Man's Hand
description: HONG KONG, May 2  Chinese doctors have successfully reconstructed a right hand for a man who lost both hands four years ago, according to the New China News Agency.

title: Stage: Long Goodbyes, ShowBusiness Musical
description: PEOPLE in Show Business Make Long Good Goodbyes is a mildewed tale about two innocent, eager young dancers who desperately want to break into show business. H. Jean Schaeffer's play, which opened last night at the Orpheum Theater, makes us look back with fondness at those Judy Garland vehicles such as Summer Stock. At least they had sentiment on their side.

title: Health Violations Laid To 40 Food Businesses
description: The New York City Department of Health yesterday released the names of 40 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also named one restaurant that had corrected earlier violations. It also cited three restaurants that had reopened after correcting earlier violations.

title: Jurist Faces Top Virginia Court in Rights Violations
description: NORFOLK. Va., May 2  Judge Joseph A. Jordan Jr., once a leading civil rights lawyer, must appear before the Virginia Supreme Court on June 5 to answer charges of violating the rights of defendants in his court.

title: Market Place
description: WHEN Beker Industries, the oncetroubled fertilizer company, released earnings on Monday, there was such a positive Wall Street response that trading on the New York Stock Exchange was halted for a time.

title: Newhall Land to Sell Amusement Park
description: The Newhall Land and Farming Company said it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its Magic Mountain amusement park in. Valencia, CaliL, for $53.2 million to the GSCSix Flags Corporation. The 260acre amusement park had revenues of $38.6 million in the year ended Feb. 28. Total attendance at the park exceeded 2.7 million for the year.

title: Kamerschen Will Lead Max Factor
description: In discussing its Max Factor cosmetics subsidiary about a year ago, David J. Mahoney, chairman of Norton Simon Inc., said that a disappointing United States performance will result in lower earnings for Max Factor & Company this year.

title: Screen: 'Age of Medici,' Trilogy by Rossellini:First Family of Florence
description: IN the very last scene of "The Age of the Medici," Roberto Rossellini's extraordinary trilogy about the great Florentine family of the Renaissance, Leon Battista Alberti, the architect, is lecturing the young Lorenzo de Medici, the grandson of Cosimo de Medici who would one day be known to history as Lorenzo the Magnificent. "Why do we live in such a marvelous time?" Alberti asks, and then answers, "Because we wish to be intelligent."I suspect that Alberti comes very close to being a spokesman for the Roberto Rossellini some of us came to know in the last years of his life when he was engaged in the production of a series of remarkable films for television designed to record, with as little artifice and editorial comment as possible, the ideas and the events that give direction to Western civilization. When he died three years ago, Rossellini had completed 40 hours of films in this series, two of which, "Socrates" and "The Rise of Louis XIV," have been commercially released in this country."The Age of the Medici," which consists (in chronological order) of "Cosimo de Medici," "The Power of Cosimo" and "Leon Battista Alberti: Humanism," is now being presented at Joseph Papp's Public Theater. "Cosimo de Medici" is playing through Sunday; "The Power of Cosimo," Tuesday through May 13, and "Leon Battista Alberti," May 15-20. My only quibble with the Public Theater's presentation is that it's not possible  should one wish it  to see the three films in a marathon (four hours and 12 minutes) screening, plus appropriate intermissions.The films are not difficult and certainly they are not ambiguous. However, their austere style, as well as Rossellini's total lack of concern for what might be called performance, take some getting used to. Yet once you've grasped the method and the rhythm of the films, they are a ravishingly beautiful experience that shouldn't be interrupted.More than "Socrates" and much more than "The Rise of Louis XIV," the Medici films speak most eleoquently of what was on Rossellini's mind when he turned away from the commercial cinema to what he called, for lack of any suitable euphemism, teaching films. In his book, "Un Esprit Libre," published in France the year he died, he devoted a chapter to what he saw as the need for "an integral education," meaning a kind of continuing, all-round education by which modern man would be freed from the terrible dangers of specialization, which he saw as as another form of ignorance. "We are neither ants, nor bees, nor spiders," he wrote, "and yet we have become regimented, stereotyped. . . ."Rossellini's impatience with contemporary education was founded on his belief that most educational systems have the effect of "fixing and maintaining" what is already established in a society. He also found ridiculous educational methods that fill brains with facts while suffocating all interest into the why's of life and the world.In "The Age of the Medici" Rossellini documents the explosion in the sciences and the arts in the Renaissance under the influence of the Medicis, the quintessential bourgeois family whose banking and business interests shaped the economic, political and social life of what became the modern world.In these films we see Cosimo wheeling and dealing to bring an end to a costly and foolish war, not because of moral reasons but because war is bad for business. Cosimo is not above bribery, conspiracy and murder in what he deems the public interest, which is also his. When necessary, the church is available to sanctify skulduggery. The arts are patronized, the past is examined for what it can yield to the present, and an unbiased science is a universal discipline.Though the trilogy takes the name of the Medicis, Leon Battista Alberti is its most important figure. Alberti is the true Renaissance man, an architect, scholar, humanist, a fellow who never stopped seeking, inquiring, speculating, someone, clearly, whom Rossellini could identify with.The visual style of "The Age of the Medici" is modestly elegant. Shot in color and 16 millimeter, mostly in and around Florence, the films have a form dictated by their function, which is to tell us as much as possible, as efficiently as possible, about the life and thought of the times.The actors make few attempts to act. They recite as they walk about magnificent locations, sounding and looking like ferociously gifted dress-extras. The talk has been rather flatly dubbed into English so that it's not always possible to tell who is speaking.Forget these problems, though. The film is about what is being said and what you can see around and behind these figures. When you connect with "The Age of the Medici," it has the effect of reducing every other film you've seen recently to the status of an ornament.

title: John Henry Willenbrok, 81, Dies; A Longtime Real Estate Lawyer
description: John Henry Willenbrok, a retired real estate lawyer and former partner in the Wall Street firm of Curtis, Mattet, Prevost, Colt & Mosle, died Tuesday at the Candlewood Valley Care Center in New Milford, Conn, after a brief illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Warren, Conn.

title: Ranger Blood in Me Now
description: At last, at 37 years old, Phil Esposito is a Ranger after more than three years of wishing he were not. Some athletes adjust to a trade quickly. They pack up and move and fit in with their new team without ever looking back. But after Phil Esposito joined the New York Rangers he kept looking back to Boston where he once scored 76 goals in a season, where he helped the Bruins win the Stanley Cup twice. Suddenly he had been traded with Carol Vadnais to the Rangers for Brad Park and Jean Ratelle on Nov. 7, 1975, a date that until now had lived in infamy in Ranger history. But now that trade does not look too bad. Now the Rangers hold a shocking 21 lead over the New York Islanders in the Stanley Cup semifinal that resumes at Madison Square Garden tonight. And now Phil Esposito has scored six goals in these playoffs, including the winning goal in Tuesday night's 31 victory. More importantly, Phil Esposito is looking ahead instead of looking back.

title: Seoul to Recheck Atom Plant
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 2 (AP) South Korea will again check its only operating nuclear power plant starting Monday. The Korea Electric Co. checked the plant at Kori, south of Seoul, only a month ago after the Three Mile Island accident in Pennsylvania. Now the builder, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, has advised another check because of the possibility of a malfunction.

title: $854,000 Award for a Navel Error
description: A 42yearold Poughkeepsie, N.Y., woman won an $854,000 judgment in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday against a plastic surgeon accused of accidentally moving her belly button off center.

title: Bonds Cracks 300th Home Run
description: CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP)  The 300th homer of Bobby Bonds's career provided the only Cleveland run tonight as the Indians were beaten by the Milwaukee Brewers, 61.

title: Delacorte Gives Gift to City
description: As water cascaded into the pink granite bowl and a band played Hey, Big Spender, George T. Delacorte yesterday gave a fountain in City Hall Park to the city and announced that he would build yet another one in Times Square.

title: Telco Ends Sports Bid
description: Telco Marketing Services Inc. said yesterday that it had terminated its cash offer of Ell a share to acquire up to 140,000 common shares of Outdoor Sports Industries Inc. Telco said the Securities and Exchange Commission had raised questions about the offer. Under terms of the bid, Telco is required to return all tendered shares.

title: Philharmonic Extends Mehta's Contract to 1986
description: Zubin Mehta, now completing his first season as music director of the New York Philharmonic, has had his contract extended to run through 1986. The announcement was made yesterday by Amyas Ames, chairman of the Philharmonic's board of directors. The extended contract calls for Mr. Mehra to conduct the orchestra at least 18 weeks each season, and he himself said that with tours and other concerts, his time with the Philharmonic would actually range from 20 to 22 weeks a season.

title: WILLIAM ELBERT JACKSON Jr.
description: William Elbert Jackson Jr. a retired lawyer, died Tuesday at a hospital in Hendersonville, N.C. He was 71 years old and lived in Etowah, N.C.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar continued mostly firmer in foreign exchange trading yesterday and hit a second consecutive high for the year against the Japanese yen in Tokyo.

title: The Wired Nation, Revisited
description: If enough New York fans want to see telecasts of Los Angeles Dodger games, or the San Francisco Opera, or conveniently timed reruns of Saturday Night Live, there is no technical obstacle. Distant telecasts can readily be beamed up to a communications satellite and then back down for distribution via cable television. The obstacle has been the Federal Communications Commission. For years, it has restricted cable television in the name of protecting the public's interest in free, locally operated broadcast television. But in truth, he F.C.C. has done more to protect the interests of broadcasters than of viewers.

title: Connors Subdues Mayer
description: DALLAS, May 2  Not hampered by a sore pinkie, Jimmy Connors took one set to decipher the style of Gene Mayer. then eliminated the New Yorker from the World Championship Tennis quarterfinals tonight, 67, 61, 64, 61.

title: COMIODMES
description: Prices of grain and soybean futures shot forward yesterday, ending a long period of relatively minor movements in these basic foodstuffs. At the final bell on the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat futures rose a stunning 9 to 17 cents a bushel; corn soared 4 to 2 cents, and soybeans advanced 8 to 12 cents on the day.

title: Deaths
description: AVONAnna. Dear wife of the late Arthur, loving mother of Jerry and Rita Feinberg, devoted grandmother of Michael, Alan, Melissa, Leslie and Gavin. Slipped away quietly on Wednesday, May 2. Survices will be held at the Schwartz Forest Park Chapel 76 Rd., Queens Blvd., Forest Hills at 10:30AM Friday. The family will observe Shivah Saturday evening & Sunday at Feinberg home, 4 Bobwhite Lane, West Nyack, N.Y.

title: Traffic Agents Unsnarl Jams on Radio Network
description: Portable fourfivefour to control, said Michael Owens, a traffic control agent, into his hand microphoneas his New York City Transportation Department car crawled through traffic on Central Park South.

title: ESSAY
description: This July will mark the tenth anniversary of man's historic walk on the moon. Mention that fact to a politician and his mind will instantly flash to the other newsmaking event of midsummer 1969: Ten years since Chappaquiddick? I wonder if the voters have forgotten ...

title: Israeli Culture Comes to 59th Street
description: BLOOMINGDALE'S is no longer content with its image as a purveyor of the latest in fashions, home furnishings and food. It also wants to be known as a purveyor of culture.

title: Bing Devine Switches To Football Cardinals
description: ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP)  Bing Devine, a baseball man for nearly 90 years, most of them with the St. Louis Cardinals, today was named vice president of the National Football League's St. Louis Cardinals.

title: CONNALLY WILL FILE DATA ON NET WORTH
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  John B. Connally, the former Texas Governor now seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, plans to file a personal financial statement this month under the new Ethics in Government Act despite his own reservations about such disclosures.

title: Problems Seen In Use of Coal
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (Reuters) The coal industry, a major factor in future American energy policy, will probably have a surplus of capacity for at least the next decade, a Congressional study said today.

title: Shipments Exceed Newsprint Output
description: Canadian newsprint shipments in March topped production, the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association announced yesterday. Newsprint production last month totaled 747,000 metric tons, up 10 percent from February but off threetenths of 1 percent from March 1978.

title: Key Official Stresses Iran's Backing of Palestinians
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 2  Foreign Minister Ibrahim Yazdi outlined a foreign policy for Iran today that stressed militant support of the Palestinian cause, an apparently conciliatory approach to the United States and a noncommittal attitude toward the Soviet Union.

title: Parley on Ginseng: Talk and BonePicking
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., May 2  A fastidious botanist from Missouri, the sort of public speaker who gives the lay name and the Latin name for a plant, then tracks the name on back to a time older than dirt while his listeners shift and scratch, was showing slides of his trip to the ginseng fields of China when he allowed that mice were a terrible problem there.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: ASTRIP of elecrical outlets is a useful addition to work areas where several electrical appliances are used. A kitchen, for instance, may have four or five appliances that are used regularly. With an outlet strip, these appliances would not need to be plugged and unplugged with every use. And while the strips do not provide extra power (one could not run four or five appliances at one time without blowing a fuse), they do provide the convenience of several readily available outlets.

title: Juror Was Questioned On Prejudging of Case In Davis Murder Trial
description: A juror on the panel that ended in a hung jury in the murder trial of Cleveland McKinley Davis in Brooklyn was questioned last week by the judge hearing the case concerning an assertion. which the juror denied. that the juror had judged the defendant not guilty before the jury began deliberations.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Army Chief With Perfect Career
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  Last Saturday morning, Lieut. Gen. Edward C. Meyer slipped into the White House for an unannounced 40minute meeting with President Carter. It was the first time that Mr. Carter had met the threestar Army veteran.

title: GDV Acquires 5.1% Of Stokely's Shares
description: GDV Inc., a subsidiary of the City Investing Company, disclosed yesterday that it had acquired 168,400 shares, or 5.1 percent, of StokelyVan Camp Inc., the Indianapolisbased marketer of canned and frozen fruits and vegetables, and that it intended to buy more.

title: Accord on Solar Energy
description: Energy Conversion Devices Inc., which has been working in the solar energy field, announced yesterday a product development and licensing agreement with the Atlantic Richfield Company, a major oil producer.

title: HOUSE REVIVES PLAN TO AID UNEMPLOYED
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  In an abrupt aboutface, the House resurrected today the program of additional Federal aid for cities with high unemployment and agreed to spend $200 million on it this year.

title: Disks : Rockabilly, Texas Style
description: IN England, where rockabilly music from the 50's has become something of a mania, dozens of new albums collecting vintage material are available. Almost none of the companies that recorded rockabilly in its prime has seen fit to release such collections in the United States, the notable exception being the Gusto label, owner of the catalogues of KingFederal and StardayDixie, two important independent record companies of the 50's.

title: Pension Law Curb Is Sought
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  A coalition of insurance companies, banks, major corporations and labor unions is lobbying intensively to limit the Government's ability to regulate pension fund transactions that are felt to pose conflicts of interest between funds and the insiders that handle or insure the funds.

title: Gulf of Mexico in Key Fuel Role
description: COGNAC PLATFORM, Gulf of Mexico  More than 1,000 feet above the floor of the Gulf, farther than the Empire State Building's observation deck is from 34th Street, Frank White's crew was drilling the seventh of 62 oil wells that are to be sunk into the sea bottom from this newest wonder of offshore oil technology, the biggest drilling platform in the world.

title: Quebec Near Asbestos Takeover
description: QUEBEC, May 2 (AP)  Negotiations for purchase of the Asbestos Corporation by the province of Quebec have broken down, and the Government will proceed with plans to expropriate the mineral producer controlled by the General Dynamics Corporation, the Quebec Finance Minister, Jacques Parizeau said today.

title: Ryan of Angels Beats Yanks, 10
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 2  The matchup was what everyone expected. The featured performers, Ron Guidry and Nolan Ryan, did not disappoint anyone, but Guidry and the Yankees were disappointed tonight because Ryan and the California Angels won, 10.

title: Pepsico Increases Quarterly Dividend
description: PURCHASE. N.Y. May 2  The board of directors of Pepsico Inc. announced today at the company's annual meeting an increase in the quarterly dividend to 28 cents a share from 25 cents. The dividend will be payable June 29 to shareholders of record June 8.

title: Carter Inquiry Witnesses Reportedly Are Asked to Forgo Public Comment
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  Unusual secrecy has been imposed on the Department of.Justice's investigation of President Carter's peanut warehouse, sources familiar with the case said today.

title: Creeping Democracy in South America
description: Ecuador's election, last Sunday, marks a watershed in South America's political life. For the first time in more than six years, one of that continent's military governments has allowed an election that will pass power to civilians.

title: Dome to Finance Share Bid Internally
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said it would finance internally its proposed $78 million purchase of up to 650,000 presplit shares of Dome Mines Ltd. at $120 a share. Dome Petroleum, as reported previously, plans to make the offer through the Toronto Stock Exchange next Monday.

title: Landslide in Indonesia Kills 82
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 2 (AP)  A landslide Monday on the 9,500foot Merapi volcano in western Sumatra killed 82 people, and 19 are still missing, a spokesman for the provincial office said today.

title: Stacks of Garbage Await Removal As Building Staffs Go Back on Job
description: Service workers in apartment buildings throughout Manhattan were back on the job yesterday after a weeklong strike  opening doors, hailing cabs, hauling trash, accepting deliveries and running elevators.

title: Televiion
description: Morning

title: U.S. SAYS 7 CONCERNS BILLED $1,7 BILLION OVER OILPRICE LIMIT
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  The Department of Energy accused seven large oil companies today of overcharging refiners by $1.7 billion in a sixyear period. The total is the largest amount in price violations the department has alleged so far in a single case.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday. May 2, 1979

title: U.S. Carrier Leaves Japan
description: TOKYO, May 2 (AP)  The United States aircraft carrier Ranger, which collided with a Liberianregistered tanker near Singapore April 5, sailed today from the American Navy base at Yokosuka, where it was repaired, for an undiclosed destination, the Japanese Maritime Safety Agency reported. The Ranger had reportedly been en route to replace the carrier Constellation in the Indian Ocean at the time of the collision.

title: Choosing a Crop And Getting It Right
description: ALL right, this is the year we don't grow summer squash or zucchini. It's not that we don't like them. Quite to the contrary, everyone in our family eats them with pleasure  for the first couple of months. But ye inevitably end up with enough to feed a hundred. And it there's one thing you can't give away to the neighbor, it's extra zucchini or summer squash. He's busy trying to give his away.

title: Piano: Richard Goode
description: RICHARD GOODE gave a curious piano recital Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y. Or maybe it was this reviewer's reaction that was curious, or that feaction in conjunction with that of the small but highly partisan audience. For his cult, Mr. Goode, who has been the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's pianist for several years, is an artist of the rarest musicality.

title: Trial Date Set for Illinois Official
description: CHICAGO, May 2 (UPI)  The trial of Attorney General William J. Scott of Illinois on income tax charges has been tentatively scheduled for Oct. 1. Federal District Judge John Powers Crowley set the date today. Mr. Scott was indicted April 9 by a Federal grand jury on charges of filing false income tax returns for 1972 through 1975 and a false amended 1974 return. He pleaded not guilty.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The Treasury yesterday sold an issue of bonds that will mature in 2009 at an average yield of 9.23 percent, the highest rate of return in history for longterm Government securities.

title: Editors Debate Support for Magazine on Bomb Article
description: One of the most troublesome questions facing the American Society of Newspaper Editors as it winds up its annual convention in New York City is whether to support The Progressive magazine in its fight against a Federal court order prohibiting it from publishing an article describing how to build a hydrogen bomb.

title: Boy's Body Found in Bay Ridge
description: The body of an unidentified teenaged boy, his hands locked behind his knees by thumbcuffs and dressed only in yellow undershorts, was discovered yesterday along the waterfront in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, about a half mile east of the VerrazanoNarrows Bridge. The police said the cause of death would have to be determined by the Medical Examiner.

title: A Shrine for English Gardeners
description: ENGLAND is said to be a nation of shopkeepers but it is actually a nation of gardeners. And to celebrate a millennium of British preoccupation with horticulture, this year has been declared The Year of the Garden. Exhibitions, competitions and garden tours have been feverishly organized to meet the occasion.

title: BankTakeover Bill Puts State Board in Control
description: All takeovers of banks in New York State will be subject to approval by the State Banking Board if Governor Carey signs a bill passed earlier this week by the Legislature.

title: Defective System Found At Reactor in Michigan
description: SOUTH HAVEN, Mich., May 2 (UPI)  A review of plans for replacing defective generators at the Consumer Power Company's Palisades nuclear plant disclosed a problem with two of the reactor's emergency cooling systems, a utility of ficial said today.

title: U.S. Tries to Stay Out of Dispute Between Egypt and Saudi Arabia
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  Seeking to preserve what it called its excellent relations with both Egypt and Saudi Arabia. the United States disassociated itself today from President Anwar elSadat's attack on the Saudi leadership.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Robert H. McKinney, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board since June 1977, resigned yesterday, effective June 1. He said that he was quitting for strictly personal reasons.

title: Foreign Reserves Decline in Britain
description: LONDON, May 2 (AP)  Britain's foreign currency reserves declined by $480 million in April after repayment of more than $1 billion to the International Monetary Fund, the Government announced today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: When the. School Is the Second Parent
description: ALICE DAVIS teaches a 20member class of 6 and 7yearolds at the City and Country School, a private school in Greenwich Village. Of 20 sets of parents, 17 are divorced or separated, and Miss Davis has been allocating more and more classrooin time for discussions with the children about what goes on at home  a family fight, a

title: Newest TV Sets Do Something More
description: THERE'S nothing like the electronics industry to let us know what kind of consumers we are. The introduction of video cassette recorders, which allow us to record television programs we can't be home to watch, and videodisk systems, which will allow us to build a library of readymade programs, type us as busy, working, afraidtomissanything people.

title: U.N. Assistance Asked In Korean Unification
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 2 (AP)  North Korean leaders told Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today that they were waging a vigorous struggle to expedite the cause of national reunification and expected the United Nations to help.

title: Experts, Though Split, Say Radiation Risk Is Small
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  Members of an expert committee of the National Academy of Sciences that has assessed the health effects of lowlevel radiation agreed today that the risks from manmade radiation were small, but they disagreed sharply over how small.

title: Pietro Lazzari, Painter, Sculptor and Researcher
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  Pietro Lazzari, a widely known painter, sculptor and researcher in art, died yesterday at a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 80 years old.

title: Prison Guards and New York State Appear Close to Pact to End Strike
description: ALBANY, Thursday, May 3  Negotiators for New York State and its 7,000 correction officers appeared to have reached agreement last night on the economic elements of a new labor contract that would end a twoweekold strike at the state's prisons. But they continued to negotiate into the morning over the last remaining snag, the issue of possible retaliation by the state against strikers after they returned to work.

title: Religious Coalition Calls for a Halt to Nuclear Power and Arms Race
description: Surrounded by posters that recalled the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island and the ravages of the atomic attack on Hiroshima, an interfaith coalition of religious leaders yesterday called for a suspension of nucleargenerated power and an end to the arms race.

title: France, U.S. Battle For Soccer Prestige
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May  When the national soccer teams of the United States and France met at Giants Stadium tonight, both coaches agreed that prestige was at stake more than anything else.

title: Santa Fe Feus RailPlan Loss
description: CHICAGO, May 2 (AP)  The Santa Fe Railway said today it would lose an estimated $58.7 million in gross revenue if the Interstate Commerce Commission approved the proposed acquisition of the Chicago. Rock Island & Pa cific. Railway trackage in the West by the St. Louis Southwestern Railway, a subsidiary of the Southern Pacific Company.

title: Movers Win Rate Increase
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission approved a 4.2 percent rate increase for the householdgoods moving industry today, despite an Administration request that it be denied as out of compliance with President Carter's price guidelines.

title: India Rejects Soviet APlant Offet
description: NEW DELHI, May 2  A Soviet offer to build a large atomic power plant for India has been rejected by the New Delhi Government.

title: Events
description: Theater

title: Calendar of Events: Energy and Antiques
description: Soft Energy Expo79, Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street, Newark, N.J.

title: Rubber Union Likely to Resume Bargaining Today With Uniroyal
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  Negotiators for Uniroyal and the United Rubber Workers are expected to return to the bargaining table tomorrow to resume master contract talks and attempt to avert a strike scheduled against the company at 12:01 A.M. Saturday.

title: Moynihan Seeks End of 70 Limit On Judges Ages
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has introduced a bill that would eliminate the age limitation of 70 for chief judges of Federal trial and appeals courts.

title: Talmadge Criticizes Senate Ethics Panel's Lawyers 1
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  Some of the 37,000 in excessive expense reimbursenents that Senator Herman E. Talmadge ellected could have been transferred to us personal bank account, one of his top udes told the Senate Select Committee on Ethics today.

title: . . .And Four Suburban Showhouses to See
description: FOR the next five weeks, those who get a vicarious pleasure from peeking into other people's homes and seeing how their lives are structured have a madetoorder opportunity. Four designer showcase houses, all within an hour of Manhattan, opened their doors during the past week  providing interior designers from New York and New Jersey, some prominent, others less wellknown, with a platform to display their work for charity.

title: OTB Contract Vote Confirmed
description: The showofhands vote that ended a threeweek strike of clerks for the New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation on April 16 has been confirmed by a secret mail ballot vote.

title: Auditors Approve Fuqua's 77 Results
description: Fuqua Industries disclosed in its annual report that its auditors, Ernst & Ernst, had lifted their qualification of the company's 1977 statements after Fuqua set up a reserve to cover possible damages resulting from an antitrust suit alleging a theater monopoly in Texas.

title: Auto Dispute Unresolved
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 2 (AP)  Efforts to resolve a dispute between the United States Auto Club and Championship Auto Racing Teams before tomorrow morning's Federal court hearing broke off tonight, said Dick King, president of USAC. The hearing is on motions to allow six dissident racing teams, representing 19 cars, to participate in the Indianapolis 500 May 27 and to participate in practice, which begins Saturday.

title: GOING OUT Gulde
description: HIS WORLD The public is invited to hear a distinguished Soviet poet read from his works at a Greenwich Village campus tonight at 8:15.

title: Design Notebook
