description: THERE is no public environment in the United States as squalid as the New York City subway. It is dirty, cramped, smelly, noisy and altogether lacking in amenities as basic as a place to sit down. It is efficient  that much can be said for it. But as an object of design, the subway is a lesson in what not to do. No other city has made for its citizens a public place as mean and unpleasant as New York City has made in its subways.

title: Truckers and Texaco Reach Tentative Pact
description: Negotiators for Texaco and the union representing drivers who deliver gasoline to metropolitanarea service stations reached a tentative agreement last night on a twoyear contract covering 80 drivers.

title: Cleveland Loses Big Convention; Science Unit Picks Atlantic City
description: CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP)  The city of Cleveland, already under severe financial strain, lost its largest annual convention today when the Pittsburgh Conference said it would go to Atlantic City for its 1980 session.

title: Insider Reports for Exchanges
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Houston Angels Win Title In Women's Basketball
description: HOUSTON, May 2 (AP)  Paula Mayo scored 36 points Tuesday night as the Houston Angels downed the Iowa Cornets, 111104, to win the first Women's Professional Basketball League championship in the final contest of a threeoffivegame series.

title: Ayatollah's Killing Sends Chill Through Iran Leaders
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 2  The reputed chairman of the secret, ruling Revolutionary Council, Ayatollah Morteza Motahari, was leaving a private meeting with Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan and other Cabinet members last night when an assassin cut him down with a single bullet, according to those in the building at the time.

title: New Sensors Tracked Cloud of Radioactivity
description: New York State scientists trapped and measured extremely low levels of a radioactive gas, xenon 133, as it passed over the Albany area last March 30 and 31 following the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania on March 28.

title: Mayor Formally Sends Legislative Package of 51 Bills to the City Council
description: Mayor Koch sent the City Council a 51measure program yesterday, believed by Council observers to mark the first time such a legislative package had been formally presented by a New York City Mayor to a Council.

title: U.S., Japan Urge Trade Harmony
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  President Carter and Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan, terming their countries ties the cornerstone of peace and stability in Asia, today instructed thbir negotiators to settle outstanding trade issues as soon as possible to prevent damaein2 political spillover.

title: Backgammon:
description: Backgammon strategy continues to evolve as new players enter the game and new theories are tested. The traditional approach to the game emphasized a safe, conservative style of play directed toward the running game. In the late 1960's a new style of play was introduced that radically altered the nature of the game. This style emphasized playing wide open, frequently leaving blots (exposed men) in order to rapidly bring men into play. As a result, more complicated games developed, with many men being sent back on each side. In the last year or two a new trend has emerged among some of the better young players. They have adopted a more structural approach  that is, making and holding key points to build solid formations. In general, they stress longterm positional gains over immediate tactical advantages.

title: Aristodimos Kaldis, 79, Is Dead; Artist Noted for His Landscapes
description: Aristodimos Kaldis, an artist who painted colorfilled landscapes of Greek mountains and New England scenes and whose robust personality and intellectual activities made him a wellknown figure in the New York art community, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Hers
description: IHAVE lived almost all of my life in a dripdry world, but I remember well the laundress who used to appear once a week in our kitchen and who spent much of her time in it steaming the place up. All other activity in the kitchen was suspended until 5 in the afternoon, when the laundress would depart, leaving behind her tall stacks of perfectly pressed and folded articles of clothing, table and bed linens. Because there were gasheated drying closets in our kitchen and in the basement of the apartment building we lived in, all of the work could be accomplished in the course of one day. I seem to remember that most of the washing was done in large tubs or in machines in the basement laundry room, but that the important things, the starching and the pressing, were done upstairs where I could and did watch from time to time.

title: Bus Strike in So Paulo
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 2 (UPI) Nearly 12,000 bus drivers and fare collectors demanding an 80 percent pay raise struck most bus lines today, stranding commuters in this city of 8 million people.

title: Posner Unit Buys Stake in Gypsum
description: Victor. Posner, president and chairman of the Pennsylvania Engineering Corporation, said that the company had bought 829,900 shares of the National Gypsum Company, or 5 percent of its outstanding common, for 512.8 million.

title: Ballet: Miss van Hamel As the Sleeping Beauty
description: THE American Ballet Theater offered its first Sleeping Beauty of the season Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. One of the triumphs of Russian Classicism, it is a splendid work that deserves splendid performances. Although there was much that was fine about the performance, there was little splendor. In part, certain deficiencies of the production accoimted for this. But it was also a matter of bad luck.

title: Edper's Bid is Criticized By Chairman of Brascan
description: TORONTO, May 2  J.H. Moore, chairman of Brascan Ltd., charged today that a successful takeover of control of Brascan by Edper Equities Ltd. would effectively disenfranchise Brascan's remaining tens of thousands of shareholders.

title: LATE BRITISH POLLS GIVE EDGE TO TORIES
description: CARDIFF, Wales, May 2  Concluding his campaign on a positive note despite strong signs that he has failed to overtake the Conservatives, Prime Minister James Callaghan asserted tonight that his Government had wrought an economic near miracle during its term of office.

title: Age of Consent in Jersey Expected to Revert to 16
description: TRENTON, May 2  Leaders of the New Jersey Assembly, responding to widespread fears about a new criminal code that lowers the age of sexual consent to 13 years, said today they expected the Assembly to pass a stopgap measure tomorrow to restore 16 as the age of consent. The legislators hope to allay fears that the state is endorsing sexual activity by teenagers.

title: Associatid Press
description: TAGGED ON NOSE: Atlanta's Jerry Royster sliding into tag by Pirates Phil Garner at third base during game last night. Royster was thrown out on steal attempt by Steve Nicosia, catcher, after Jeff Burroughs struck out. Pittsburgh won game, 102. Page 023.

title: Aid for Handicapped Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)  A White House panel today called for active Federal involvement on several fronts to improve health care for the nation's 30 million handicapped citizens. The White

title: Q &
description: Q. I want to remove white enamel paint from rough bricks. Can you tell me how to do this?  Mrs. J.W., Philadelphia.

title: Nuclear Haven Sought in New Hampshire
description: BRADFORD, N.H.  Tom and Woody Best's 12room country inn here is listed in the official Government evacuation plan as the site to receive 498 refugees.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Kentucky Miners to Vote Choice On Union Representation Today
description: STEARNS, Ky., May 2 (AP)  Miners will vote tomorrow on whether the United Mine Workers will represent employees of the Stearns Mining Company's Justus Mine, where the union has been on strike nearly three years.

title: Panel Narrowly Backs Agency on Education; House Battle Is Likely
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  A bill to create a new department of education squeezed through a House committee today by a onevote margin, but faced an uncertain fate on the House floor.

title: National Offer Raised By Pan Am
description: National Airlines announced yesterday that Pan American World Airways had increased its offer for National to $50 a share from $41 a sham, matching the high bid by Eastern Air Lines. The value of the new bid for National was estimated at $427 million.

title: Piano: Ashkenazy Plays With the Philharmonic
description: THE final weekend of New York Philharmonic concerts got .1tmdez way last night with a brilliant performance of the Piano Concerto No. 2 by Bela Bartok. Vladimir Ashkenazy was the soloist, with Zubin Idehta at the helm. The program,illso contained Schubert's Sym.phony No. 1 and the Tchaikovsky Fourth Symphony .

title: U.S. Wins in Water Polo
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 2 (AP)  The United States grabbed a 20 lead in the first period and went on to beat the Soviet Union, 63, today in the World Water Polo Cup tournament.

title: BEGIN SAYS ISRAELIS WILL STAY IN GOWN
description: JERUSALEM, May 2 (AP)  Israel today celebrated the 31st anniversary of its independence, the first at peace with Egypt, and Prime Minister Menachem Begin said his Government would consider no further major withdrawal from occupied lands in exchange for an overall Middle East settlement.

title: Companies List Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is fisted on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Sculptors Search For the Perfect Log
description: AN exhibition of sculpture in wood by Mark Lindquist and Bob Stocksdale. at the Elements Gallery, 766 Madison Avenue, through May 12, is as much a tribute to the art of nature as it is to the hand of man. For both craftsmen, material is as important as craftsmanship, and while the works of the two are different in spirit and intention, each searches for the perfect log with the care of a jeweler choosing his gem.

title: Stone &
description: The Stone & Webster Engineering Corporation announced yesterday that it had received a contract for the preliminary engineering of a pumped storage generating facility for the Salt River project, Arizona's largest public utility project. The site selected for the hydroelectric project is Alchesay Canyon, 50 miles northeast of Phoenix and near the Theodore Roosevelt Dam. The value of the contract was not disclosed.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH anyone who has ever used a hammer or a saw is familiar with plywood, there are still many doityourselfers who do not know the difference between the various types and grades available, and many who are not familiar with some basic working techniques that can simplify the cutting, assembling and finishing of this versatile material.

title: Judge Acquits Two Who Shouted At Deng During Washington Visit
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)  A judge today acquitted two persons who had been charged with disorderly conduct when they shouted at President Carter and Deng Xiaoping during White House welcoming ceremonies for the Chinese Deputy Prime Minister.

title: New Marine Chief Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)  The Senate today confirmed President Carter's nomination of Gen. Robert H. Barrow to become the next commandant of the Marine Corps.

title: A Glorious Day in May
description: With the sun shining and temperatures hovering in the lower 70's, many residents of the metropolitan area took the opportunity to relax and sunbathe yesterday. Here, two sun worshippers at the world's fairgrounds in Queens, stretch out before the Unisphere, the theme structure for The World of Tomorrow fair of 1964. Partly sunny skies are forecast for today with some showers likely tonight, and tomorrow.

title: 15 Designers In a Mansion
description: THEY are not in the least boggled by 16foot ceilings, massive marble fireplaces, gilt moldings and other such trappings that the celebrated architect Stanford White included in the palaces he wrought for the privileged citizens of New York around the turn of the century. On the contrary, they positively soar with the challenge.

title: Tunneling to Washington for Water
description: Mayor Koch is right to worry about New York City's water supply. The city's location, in an area usually served generously with rainfall, gives it a major advantage over other cities that boast about their sunshine yet need help from Washington to pay for huge waterworks. But New York will maintain that advantage only by continuing to invest in systems for water collection, transportation and distribution. The costs will be enormous; the price of neglect even greater.

title: MAYOR OF HOUSTON DEFENDS $6,000 LOAN
description: HOUSTON, May 2  Mayor James McConn has said that he told a Federal grand jury here Monday that a $6,000 loan arranged for him by the city's purchasing director to help cover his Las Vegas gambling debts was not related to a Justice Department investigation of alleged extortion from city contractors.

title: Cornell Hospital Gets $5 Million From Niarchosl
description: Stavros S. Niarchos, the Greek shipping magnate, has given $5 million to the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center.

title: Charlotte M. Mixsell, Prominent In Working for Philanthropies, 92
description: Charlotte Mallory Mixsell, who was active in philanthropic work and the widow of Dr. Harold Ruckman Mixsell, a pediatrician, died yesterday at her home in Locust Valley, L. I. She was 92 years old.

title: Wayne Has Operation For an Intestinal Block
description: LOS ANGELES, May 2 (AP)  John Wayne, the 72yearold veteran actor, has undergone surgery for the second time in five months, this time to relieve an intestinal obstruction found during a routine check of his cancer surgery in January, the U.C.L.A. Medical Center said today.

title: The City
description: Louis Werner. the only person indicted in connection with last December's $5.8 million Lufthansa cargo theft at Kennedy International Airport, went on trial yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: ULCER DRUG IS TIED TO A DROP IN SPERM
description: BOSTON, May 2 (AP)  Cimetidine, an ulcer medicine that is one of the nation's most widely prescribed drugs, can be expected to temporarily reduce the sperm count of most men and to cause temporary sterility in men who already have low sperm counts, according to doctors whose study involved seven men.

title: Spurs Eliminate 76ers by 111108
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 2 (AP) George Gervin and Larry Kenon combined for 60 points and Mike Green had 9 in the fourth period tonight as the San Antonio Spurs snapped a playoff jinx with a 111108 victory over Philadelphia in the decisive seventh game of a National Basketball Association Eastern Conference semifinal series.

title: The Region
description: Staff witnesses for the State Public Service Commission yesterday proposed to limit a New York Telephone Company rate increase to $90.1 million a year. The company is asking for a $240 million increase. The commission staff acts as a consumer advocate.

title: U.S. Lists Guidelines for Linking Rights Concern to Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher listed five guidelines today that he said were used by the Carter Administration in applying its concern for humanrights violations to the conduct of foreign policy.

title: Black Stage Fete Opens
description: THE fiveweeklong Black Theater Festival U. S. A. at Lincoln Center could not have begun more auspiciously than it did Tuesday evening with Vinnette Carroll's When Hell Freezes Over, I'll Skate, which Miss Carroll brought from her Urban Arts Corps downtown.

title: Pinochet in No Rush  I
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Power will be handed over when the time is ripe but I won't be rushed into this.

title: FosterCare Revisions Urged by 2
description: Changes to turn the fostercare system on its head were urged yesterday by City Council President Carol Bellamy and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Justice Dept. Seeks a Loosening Of Requirments on Speedy Trials
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)  The Justice Department asked today for a relaxation of speedy trial requirements but was accused of failing to try hard enough to comply with the existing law.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHY a biography of both Thomas and Heinrich Mann? Never mind Nigel Hamilton's somewhat fatuous observation that one may see in the brothers Mann the most significant literary brotherhood of all time.

title: Talking Business
description: The battle for control of National Airlines has been raging for the last nine months, but none of the three main suitors, Eastern Air Lines, Pan American World Airways and Texas International Airlines, has established a clear advantage.

title: EARNINGS
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd., the diversified Canadian transport company, reported yesterday a 42.8 percent profit increase to $96.8 million, or $1.34 a share, in the first three months of this year, from a restated $67.8 million, or 94 cents a share, for the corresponding 1978 quarter.

title: In Search of a Little Elephant That Wasn't
description: To Marie Filingeri, Abe Miller, Dick Coletti, Jose Feliciano and the others on the block in Bay Ridge, yesterday will live in history as the day all those lunatics from the city came elephanthunting in Brooklyn.

title: Rafshoon Gathers List of Carter Advocates
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  Gerald M. Rafshoon, President Carter's media adviser, has compiled a master list of prominent opinion makers inside and outside the Government who can be used to rebut editorial and public criticism of the President's policies on subjects from the strategic arms treaty to the 1980 budget.

title: Carter Picks 3 Judges, Including Miss Kearse Of Wall Street Firm
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)  Two women, one of them black, were among three new Federal appellate judges designated today by President Carter.

title: RECAN SEES A NEED TO RAISE HOUSING AID
description: ALBANY, May 2  New York's Urban Development Corporation may need almost twice as much money from the state as it projected it would to keep its housing projects from defaulting in the next decade, according to State Comptroller Edward V. Regan.

title: Mobil Opposes Decontrol
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  In a break with other major oil companies, the Mobil Oil Corporation plans to propose continued price controls on oil currently in production in return for freeing future oil discoveries from controls or special taxation, industry sources said today.

title: Bridge:
description: Crimes at the bridgetable, like those in real life, do not always receive their just punishment. If you overbid in a team match against expert opponents, reach a hopeless contract that can be defeated by top winners and then run into a bad trump break and a penalty double, you expect to, have to apologize to your teammates. But once in a while the ax does not tall, and no apology is necessary.

title: Thermostat Curb Passed By Senate
description: WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI)  The Senate today approved President Carter's plan to order public and commercial building thermostats set no lower than 80 degrees in summer or higher than 65 in winter, but refused to restrict outdoor advertising lights.

title: Screen King Trainer Sees Stretch Success
description: LOUISVILLE, KY., May 2  General Assembly had just stunned the clackers today with a fivefurlong workout of 57 2/5 seconds, but the trainer of Screen King was not impressed.

title: Letter: On the Beef Boycott
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS  Digest
description: Energy

title: For Octavio Paz, a Solitude of His Own as a Political Rebel
description: MEXICO CITY, May 2  At the age of 65, with his prestige as a poet never more secure, Mexico's most prominent writer, Octavio Paz, has opted for the lonely life of a political dissident.

title: Caesars World Splits Stock 3 for 1
description: Caesars World Inc. announced yesterday that its board of directors had declared a 3for1 stock split, payable June 5 to holders of record May14.

title: Hog Farmers Enjoying High Prices
description: KANEVILLE, Ill.  If hogs are Eldon Gould's line of business, why does the 37yearold farmer seem so pleased by the high prices cattlemen are getting?

title: Russians, Vermont Town Both Mind Own Business
description: CAVENDISH, Vt., May 3  There was a fuss when the first internationally famous Soviet dissident arrived, but now people here are taking things like that pretty much in stride, Tony Janowski was saying here this morning as he spread mayonnaise on white bread to make the sandwiches that the workers at the Mack Molding Company next door would want for lunch.

title: EDITORS JOIN APPEAL ON HBOMB ARTICLE
description: The board of directors of the American Society of Newspaper Editors voted unanimously yesterday to join in the appeal of The Progressive magazine against a Federal District Court order restraining it from publishing an article about the hydrogen bomb.

title: Art People
description: WHO'D have thought that the United States Custom House, that large and serious piece of marble business down on Bowling Green, would ever fall into the hands of ... artists? Yet, challenged by the grandiloquent spaces of the BeauxArts landmark, this wily group of infiltrators has had an eye on the structure ever since the Customs people decamped from it in 1973 for er quarters in the World Trade Center.

title: Poetry Festival Hails
description: You can't go home again says the common wisdom. But Allen Ginsberg, Paterson born and bred, returns tomorrow to the city on the Passaic River as the honored guest performer at the second annual William Carlos Williams Poetry Festival. It was Dr. Williams, a lifelong resident of nearby Rutherford, who enshrined the city in his major poem. In it he wrote, that a man is himself a city, beginning, seeking, achieving and concluding his life . . .

title: New National Gallery Post for Paul Mellon
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  The National Gallery of Art today announced the election of Paul Mellon as chairman of the board of trustees, John R. Stevenson as president of the gallery and Carlisle H. Humelsine as vice president, replacing John Hay Whitney, who has retired.

title: Failure to Enforce Oil Law Laid to Energy Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, May 4According to a General Accounting Office report requested by Senator John A. Durkin, the Department of Energy has consistently failed to enforce a Federal law regulating oil pricing, and as a result, he says, consumers have been subjected to billions of dollars in overcharges. The New Hampshire Democrat said the department was negligent in enforcing a 1973 law intended to prevent overpricing by the oil companies in the wake of the Arab oil embargo.

title: G.E. Akerson, ExTV Executive
description: George E. Akerson, a former top official of WHDHTV in Boston and past president of the Boston HeraldTraveler Corporation, died Tuesday in St. Luke's Hospital in New Bedford, Mass. Mr. Akerson, who lived on West Lake Farms in Westport, Mass., was 61 years old.

title: Broadway
description: Joshua Logan to direct West Side comedy.

title: Begin Offers a Plan for Palestinian Rule
description: JERUSALEM, May 3  In what amounts to a resumption of the Middle East peace negotiations by Israel, Prime Minister Menachem Begin today presented the Cabinet with his tough guidelines for Palestinian autonomy on the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: About Real Estate New MiddleIncome Housing in the Bronx
description: As Henry G. Waltemade sees it, there should be no new multifamily housing construction in the Bronx in the foreseeable future. But lowrise, lowdensity, owneroccupied housing that is something else again.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Secretary of State Vance made a quiet and thoughtful speech in Chicago the other day that deserves more attention than it received. Nothing unusual about this: For almost a generation, louder and more dramatic voices have overwhelmed Cyrus Vance's muted common sense, but he endures.

title: Auto Sales Down 13% In April
description: DETROIT, May 3 (UPI)  The Big Three auto makers reported today that domestic car sales fell 12.8 percent in late April and that the month's total sales were 13 percent below last year's levels.

title: Genuine Tory Taking Charge
description: LONDON, May 3  To Margaret Thatcher, free choice is ultimately what life is about, and she likes to illustrate what she means in political terms with this example: If somebody

title: '76 Triumph Holds Danger as Carter Returns to Iowa
description: DES MOINES, May 3  Iowa, which in 1976 gave Jimmy Carter, then a littleknown former Governor of Georgia, the initial victory that propelled him into the national spotlight, will welcome him back tomorrow in his second visit as President.

title: For the Retarded, Despair Is Lingering
description: They were the most profoundly retarded and severely handicapped patients ever assembled. You could work in this field for 90 years and never see anything like them. They were the hidden cases, the ones that no one ever wanted to see, the victims of years of neglect.

title: John Wilson Drye Jr., 78, Lawyer And a Director of 4 Corporations
description: John Wilson Drye Jr., senior partner of the law firm of Kelley, Drye & Warren, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Head of S.E.C. Defends Rules
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, May 3 (AP) Harold Williams, chairman of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that he was finding that stringent American disclosure laws were the primary barrier to attracting more foreign investment.

title: Afghans Said to Obtain Soviet Copter Gunships
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)  United States intelligence sources said today that the Soviet Union had supplied 12 rocketarmed helicopter gunships to Afghanistan and that Soviet pilots might be flying them.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, May 3,1979

title: For Children
description: CHILDREN'S CARNIVAL with entertainment, oames, and refreshments, Saturday, 11 A.M. to I P.M., at St. Michael's Mcritesscrl School, 221 West 991h Street. Admission: children, free; adults. $1.50. Games, 25 to 75 cents. Call 6630555.

title: National Football League College Draft Selections
description: Round 1

title: Yankee Relief Role Accepted by Beattie
description: Jim Beattie is refreshingly honest about why he was willing to forsake his startingpitching role for a relief role.

title: Russian in London Asks Asylum, Then Decides to Return to Soviet
description: MOSCOW, May 3 (Reuters  A Soviet journalist who flew back to Moscow yesterday just after British officials said he had been granted asylum in London may face disciplinary action by the Communist Party. Soviet sources said today.

title: Jets Move to Help Pass Rush
description: The New York Jets, who had one of the least effective pass rushes in the National Football League, took steps to alleviate that problem yesterday by drafting a pair of huge, quick defensive linemen in the first two rounds of the college draft.

title: Music: Sound of Calliope
description: THE idea of commissioning music for Renaissance instruments in the last quarter of the 20th century is a piquant one, but no more incongruous than the writing of new works for harpsichord, an activity that came to seem reasonable after Wanda Landowska came on the scene. It may be that groups such as Calliope, the quartet of Renaissance specialists that won the I975 Naumburg Chamber Music Award, will similarly fire the imagination of composers and set them writing for consorts of rebecs, viols and krummhorns. On Wednesday night at Abraham Goodman House, Calliope gave the first performance of the second of two pieces commissioned by the Naumburg Foundation, Alvin Brehm's A Pointe at His Pleasure, fivemovement dance suite that employed the old instruments, but filtered the antique sounds through a contemporary sensibility.

title: Benson Ford Cancels Meeting With Uncles
description: Benson Ford Jr., the Ford Motor Company heir who is striving to gain his late father's seat on the company's board of directors, attended an annual Ford family gathering in suburban Detroit yesterday but canceled a meeting scheduled for earlier in the day at which he had planned to talk with his uncles about his future in the company.

title: CALIFANO REASSESSES RADIATION HAZARDS
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Joseph Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that radiation exposure from the Three Mile Island reactor accident was higher than earlier measurements had indicated. As a result, he said, statistical probability indicates that at least one cancer death caused by radiation could be expected among the two million people living within 50 miles of the Pennsylvania power plant.

title: Shaker 'spirit Drawings at Hirschl &
description: ONE of the sweetest and most delicate forms of 19thcentury American folk art is the so called spirit drawing of the Shakers, and we are given an unusual opportunity to see sonie of the classic examples of this genre in the exhibition called The Gift of Inspiratioh Art of the Shakers, 183080, which has just opened at the Hirschl and Adler Galleries, 21 East 70th Street. The show, which draws heavily uporr the drawing collection of the Hancock Shaker Village, just outside Pittsfield, Mass., has been organized as a benefit for the village, which in recent years has been restored as a museum of Shaker art, ar chitecture and artifacts.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: House Study Sparks Debate
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 In a House investigative study released today, the National Endowment for the Arts was charged with conflicts of interest and a plethora of Shortcomings in its grants program, contract arrangements and Procedural processes.

title: Deaths
description: SOMMER  SigmundSincere con dolences to the bereaved family. From a dear friend, Michael J. Merkin

title: Draft: Time for Surprises
description: At the National Football League draft yesterday the Buffalo Bills and the Kansas City Chiefs, the first two teams to choose players from the pool of eligible college seniors, did what had been expected. The Bills selected Tom Cousineau, the Ohio State linebacker, and the Chiefs took Mike Bell, the defensive end from Colorado State. Then came the unexpected.

title: Army Planning to Shift 900 Bombs With Nerve Gas to a Base in Utah
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI)  The Army announced today that it would start moving about 900 Weteye bombs that contain more than 300,000 pounds of deadly nerve gas from a Denver arsenal to base in Utah in the near future.

title: Problem for Cosmos: Who Plays Offense?
description: TORONTO, May 3  The Cosmos will be short of offensive players in tomorrow night's North American Soccer League game against the Blizzard at National Exhibition Stadium.

title: N.Y.R.A.
description: Winsome, right, with Ruben Hernandez up, pulled away in stretch to win first race at Aqueduct yesterday

title: Bruins Down Canadiens, 43, to Tie Series
description: BOSTON, May 3  Thanks to Jean RateIle, the Boston Bruins are going back to Montreal for the fifth game of their Stanley Cup semifinal series all even with the Canadiens.

title: Striking Prison Guards and State Are Said to Reach Tentative Pact
description: ALBANY, Friday, May 4  After more than 38 hours of bargaining, negotiators were reported last night to have reached an agreement in principle on the issue of retaliation by the state against 7,000 striking correction officers, solving the last obstacle to a new contract agreement.

title: Deaths
description: ROSENFIELDBarbara. Of Teaneck, NJ. Formerly of Chicago. Beloved wife of Paul. Dear daughter at Marie and Bernard Barisal. Deyot. ad mother of Mark. Keith and Valerie. Laying sister of Harvey Barisal Services will be held at GuttermanMusicanfKreitzman caner Park and Passaic St, Hackensack, NJ on Friday May 4 at 1:00PM. The memorial period will be observed at the Rosenfield residence.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE NEW BARBARIANS invade Madison Square Garden next Monday night. If you haven't been paying close attention to the popmusic scene lately, you might wonder how a new group could hope to sell out this country's most prestigious indoor arena on its first tour. The answer is that the New Barbarians aren't a group at all, but an assortment of rock stars and semisuperstars (plus possible megasuperstar guests), assembled for a oneshot tour.

title: For the City's Bus Riders, It May Be Face Forward and Get More Room
E.C. Gathings
description: WEST MEMPHIS, Ark., May 3 (AP) Funeral services will be held tomorrow for former Representative E.C. Gathings, a staunch conservative who served 30 years in Congress.

title: Around the Nation
description: HARRIS NECK, Ga., May 3  The president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, the Rev. Dr. Joseph E. Lowery, committed his organization today to helping organize massive demonstrations that could lead to waves upon waves of arrests if the United States Government does not return the Harris Neck Wildlife Refuge to the black families that once owned it.

title: Mustering the Troops In Militia Day at Mystic
description: It is the 1840's, three decades after the last war with the British, in a small New England town. AU winter the village green lay frozen, and it was too cold to visit friends. But now the bustle of spring has come, and after the planting it is time for a little drill and mock battle on the green, a rollicking picnic with the neighbors, and then some serious card playing and rum drinking, in that periodic ritual called Militia Day.

title: A.M.C. Warranty To Allow Gasohol
description: The American Motors Corporation, smallest of the major United States auto producers, said yesterday that it planned to extend its warranty coverage on 1979 and some prior model years to include use of gasohol as a fuel if it contains 10 percent or less ethyl alcohol.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Rise of 16% In Business Outlay Due
description: Capital spending by American business this year will be 16 percent higher than last year's outlay  with a large part of the rise a result of inflation according to an annual survey reported yesterday by the McGrawHill Publications Company. The report noted that with adjustment for inflation, the real growth would be about 7 percent.

title: London Stocks Spurt Amid Voting
description: LONDON, May 3 (AP)  The London Stock Exchange soared today to its highest level as British voters seemed ready to shift to the right, toward the opposition Conser vatives, after five years of moderate socialism under the Labor Party Government.

title: Bally Foresees New York Casinos
description: CHICAGO, May 3  The Bally Manufacturing Company expects New York to follow the lead of New Jersey in legalizing casino gambling and anticipates operating casinos in the state.

title: Economic Scene
description: ZBIGNIEW BRZEZINSKI, President Carter's national security adviser, told the American Society of Newspaper Editors in New York this week that the United States can no longer confine itself to a primary preoccupation with EastWest problems, or even with NorthSouth problems. tie added, Nor can we pursue a Eurocentric, or even primarily trilateral, policy with Western Europe and Japan.

title: Philip Smith Is Elected a Shubert Officer
description: Philip J. Smith has been elected to the new post of executive vice president of the Shubert Organization, the largest owneroperator of legitimate theaters in the country.

title: Vanessa Redgrave Loses
description: LONDON, Friday, May 4 (UPI)  The actress Vanessa Redgrave polled only 225 votes for her Workers Revolutionary Party in the Moss Side constituency in Manchester yesterday. The Labor incumbent, G.M. Morton, won with 17,765 votes. T.E. Murphy, a Conservative, was second with 13,234.

title: Auto Imports in April
description: Auto imports in April were estimated at 222,000, compared with 178,900 for the same month last year. That meant that the importers improved their share of the market from 17 percent in April 1978 to 22.4 percent this year, slightly under their record share of 22.5 percent last month.

title: Mover's Fight for a National License
description: ST. LOUIS  Timothy Person is small fish in the householdgoods moving business, but when he filed last year to become a major mover, he stirred up the whales of the $1.5 billion industry. They opposed him solidly.

title: Events and Openings
description: A VOICE OF MY OWN. by Elinor Jones. Directed by Amy Seitz. Presented by the Acting Company, John Houseman, artistic director. At the Lion Theater, 422 West 42d Street, at&8

title: Vance Meets With Russian Envoy On Final Details of Weapons Pact
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union met again today to discuss the treaty to limit offensive nuclear weapons, and State Department spokesman said later that he hoped an announcement could be made next week that all issues had been resolved.

title: Ohira Warns Against US. Protectionism
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan told members of Ccogress today that Japan was acting visibly and decisively to contain trade problems with the United States and warned that a protectionist American response could trigger a catastrophic chain reaction.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: Ribicoff Sets Off A Political Rush In Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, May 3  The retirement announcement of Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, a pillar of Connecticut Democratic politics for more than 30 years, stunned politicians of both parties today and set off a chain reaction among a new generation of candidates eager to move up the political ladder.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: IN her splendid interview with Richard Locke in last Sunday's New York Times Book Review, Elizabeth Hardwick mentioned her admiration for Rainer Maria Rilke's The Notebook of Malte Laurids Brigge. She called it a miraculous, perfect work.

title: Theater. Bosoms and Neglect
description: APLAY may bury its meaning as deeply as it likes, or entangle it in as much complexity as it chooses; just as long as it generates an allure that will send us after it.

title: Don't Sell Alaska's Crown Jewels
description: The House of Representatives will soon decide whether to protect some of Alaska's prime wild lands from exploitation or open them to energy, mining and real estate interests  what Interior Secretary Andrus calls the rape, ruin and run boys. Two House committees have approved bills that the Carter Administration rightly finds wholly unacceptable; they would yield too much of this last unspoiled frontier to development. The bills need sweeping revision when the full House considers this most important conservation issue of the present generation.

title: Sportswear: Observing the Formalities
description: Sportswear has been the mainstream of fashion through most of the 1970's, signifying a casual attitude toward dress. Now the system is undergoing changes. More formality is coming in. Basic sportswear components, such as blazers and pants or skirts, are becoming more closely related, resembling suits rather than separates. Coats, not long ago mostly blankets or downlined ponchos, are being tailored once again. Evening clothes  not just set pieces for weddings and bar mitzvahs  are claiming more attention from designers.

title: The Region
description: Ignoring a request made a week ago by the State University board of trustees that it resume its search for a new president for the university branch at Stony Brook, the university council announced that it would resubmit the name of Dr. T. Alexander Pond as its choice for the presidency of the Long Island institution.

title: Jersey State Assembly Votes 71 to 2 to Keep 16 as Age of Consent
description: TRENTON, May 3  With a crowd of concerned parents nodding agreement from the balcony  and sometimes applauding, in violation of the rules  the State Assembly today voted 71 to 2 to keep the age of sexual consent at 16 years in New Jersey.

title: Business and the Law
description: SINCE the value of a name can be incalculable, business executives will go to great expense to protect their company's name. And Sambo's, the restaurant chain, after hiring highly talented legal and public relations specialists, appears to be winning its long legal battle over whether it will be allowed to remain Sambo's.

title: June Skylab Reentry Stirring New Worries, Officials at NASA Say
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (Reuters) After faltering in orbit for months, the Skylab space station is expected to plunge to earth in late June in a rain of debris that could bring unusual problems for the United States.

title: George V. T. Burgess, Transportation Expert
description: George Van Trump Burgess, a consulting engineer, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 76 years old.

title: Safety System Shuts Down Jersey Nuclear Power Plant
description: The Jersey Central Power and Light Company's 650megawatt Oyster Creek nuclear power plant at Forked River, N.J., was shut down automatically by its own safetymonitoring system Wednesday afternoon during a test of the reactor's pressurereading instruments, the utility and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission reported yesterday.

title: Giants Rout Falcone And Defeat Mets, 75
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3  The San Francisco Giants, whose bats had been subdued to almost a hush recently, suddenly exploded today. Three home runs in a fiverun fourth inning enabled them to register a 75 victory over the New York Mets.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, May 4 GUGLIELMO MARCONI (Italian Line Cruises International). Left St. Thomas April 30; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street,

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Despite a record 9.23 percent yield, the Treasury's new 30year bonds sagged in price yesterday as they began to trade in the secondary bond market, and they dragged down the rest of the credit markets.

title: Juantorena, Teammates Welcomed
description: LOS ANGELES, May 3  As the yellow Ford van pulled away from Los Angeles international Airport this afternoon, Alberto Juantorena studied the surroundings as if he were sizing up rivals for a race. But the California buildings differed considerably from the architecture in his native country, Cuba.

title: Auctions
description: THE 19thcentury and 20thcentury photography sales that begin today and continue through next week at three of New York's auction houses will offer a staggering number of classics and lessknown works by virtually every major figure from Ansel Adams to Edward Weston. Superlatives characterize the description by Christie, Manson & Woods of today's sale of more than 450 lots at Christie's East, 219 East 67th Street, taking place at 10:30 A.M. and 2 P.M. For starters, there is a halfplate portrait of Daniel Webster, done probably in 1851 by Albert Sands Southworth and Josiah Johnson Hawes. Dale Stulz, Christie's specialist, is describing this as the most significant American daguerreotype ever to appear at auction. The presale estimate is $8,000 to $12,000.

title: REPORTER'S MURDER GETS NEW ATTENTION
description: PHOENIX, ARIZ., May 3  Pressure to reopen the Don Bolles murder case is building here. A defense committee of more than 300 people, convinced there has been an injustice, has raised enough commotion to disturb even some of those who were responsible for convictions in the reporter's death.

title: GIULIO NATTA
description: BERGAMO, Italy, May 3 (AP)  Giulio Natta, an Italian chemist who shared the 1963 Nobel Prize with Karl Ziegler of West Germany, died yesterday at the age of 76. The two men won the prize for their contribution to macromolecular chemistry and for the development of new high polymers, an advance in synthetic materials.

title: Stage: Wilson's Talley's Folly
description: LANFORD WILSON'S eloquent new play, Talley's Folly, is, as the playwright promises in the opening scene, a waltz .. . a noholdsbarred romantic story. It deals with two particular people in a special time and place  beautifully played by Judd Hirsch and Trish Hawkins. In addition, through indirection, humor and stage poetry, Mr. Wilson has made them stand as paragons of truth and selffulfillment.

title: It's Simms of Morehead State
description: Giant fans. hoping to get Jack Thompson in yesterday's college draft of the National Football League, are now hoping they didn't get another Rocky Thompson instead.

title: Screen: Sophia Loren Starring in 'Firepower':A Tossed Salad
description: EQUIPPED only with an appreciation of Sophia Loren's dreaminess and a stopwatchthe kind that demands a car chase or a house afire every 10.6 minutesMichael Winner has thrown together "Firepower." Mr. Winner directs movies the way others toss salads, which means that "Firepower" is best appreciated at a kind of mental half-mast. A lot happens. None of it makes sense. It all takes place in the tropics, though, amid scenery almost as sensational looking as the leading lady. Well, things could be worse.The idea, foggy as it may be, is that Miss Loren is the wife of a chemist, who is blown up in the film's first minute or two, which makes her a widow. A Howard Hughes type ordered the murder of the chemist, or so Miss Loren thinks. So when the Federal Government, which would like to get its hooks on the Hughes figure, asks her to smoke him out of his Caribbean lair, she doesn't mind the prospect of sashaying magnificently around a couple of islands. James Coburn and O. J. Simpson are also enlisted. Since delicacy is not essential to their project, the first thing they do is set fire to the Hughes type's house.Mr. Coburn is supposed to be an expert gardener, which in a movie like this means he is once seen sitting in a flower bed, and once he remarks to his potential employer (Eli Wallach) that the "Ming aralias" in the man's office need watering. In another broad stroke of character establishing, Mr. Coburn is shown to have an identical twin brother, who is primed to play a crucial role in the story and is never mentioned again.Some of the performances Mr. Winner gets from his supporting players are rip-roaringly awful, as is Gato Barbieri's loud and schlocky score. However, there's a nice chemistry in the teaming of Miss Loren, Mr. Coburn and Mr. Simpson, each of whom has an unusually physical presence on the screen. Together, they generate an air of friendliness and cooperation, which makes up for the lack of romantic spark between Mr. Coburn and Miss Loren. The closest these two get to a love scene is when Miss Loren has to make a quick trip somewhere without her luggage, and Mr. Coburn gallantly shops for her once they get there. He is thoughtful enough to come up with an evening gown and about $12 million worth of diamonds."Firepower," which opens today at the Loew's State I and other theaters, includes enough violent episodes to have earned it an R rating. But the killings are perfunctory, and the blood-shed virtually nil, despite Mr. Winner's formidable reputation in that department ("Death Wish" is a notable example of the director at his goriest). Still, a message is in evidence, as when one character sneers "I've always noticed it's you rich, soft, pampered people who are so in love with violence. You've never experienced it. You just want to see it done."This time the emphasis is on sheer spectacle, as when Mr. Coburn drives a bulldozer through an entire house, reducing it to rubble. But the film's ingenuity in cooking up such episodes is disappointing. It should not be necessary, during various chase sequences, to see the actors upset a truck filled with oranges and a truck filled with bananas in the same movie.

title: Two Legislators Seek Bond Issue For Waste Sites
description: ALBANY, May 3  In an effort to avoid what they called future Love Canals, two state legislators today proposed a $150 million bond issue to build four centers in the state for the disposal of toxic wastes.

title: Islanders Victors In Overtime by 32
description: John Davidson, the Ranger goalie, is not a gambling man. Neither is Bob Nystrom, the Islander forward. But last night at Madison Square Garden with the fourth game of their Stanley Cup semifinal series in overtime, both men put the contest up for grabs over a loose puck.

title: Frances Stemhagen Gets Award for Golden Pond
description: Frances Stemhagen, who has received awards from her professional theater colleagues, yesterday won a rare one from a group of theatergoers.

title: Gerulaitis and Borg Gain Net Semifinals
description: DALLAS, May 3  Vitas Gerulaitis barely worked up a sweat tonight in his first match in the World Championship of Tennis eightman finals, beating Brian Gottfried 64 63 63.

title: Publishing: Jehan Sadat Coming to US. as Poet
description: AN unexpected addition to the roster of foreign poets to visit the United States is Jehan Sadat. The First Lady of Egypt will be presenting a program called The Poetry of Egypt in the spring of 1980 at the International Poetry Forum in Pittsburgh. It will be the first time Mrs. Sadat will be appearing in her own right in this country. The program will include a personally chosen anthology of poems translated from the Arabic. Mrs. Sadat has published poetry in Egyptian literary journals under a pseudonym and is completing a study of the influence of Shelley on modern Arabic literature. Samuel Hazo, director of the Poetry Fotum and himself a poet and novelist, could not give the exact date for her appeirance.

title: Uganda Refugees in Kenya Town Getting Red Cross and U.N. Aid
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 3 (Reuters) The Red Cross and the United Nations are providing blankets, medicine and food for 2,600 displaced Ugandans now in a camp at the western Kenyan town of Karamega, Charles Rubia, president of the Kenyan Red cross, said today.

title: Advertising
description: PROCTER & GAMBLE, besides being Cincinnati's silent Sphinx, is frequently a talisman for both its own products and those who manage them. It produces No. 1 brands and No. 1 people.

title: FRANCESCO MALGERI
description: ROME, May 3 (UPI)  Francesco Malgeri, former president of the Italian news agency Ansa, died Tuesday. He was 79 years old. Mr. Malgeri, who began his journalistic career at the age of 16, was director of various Italian newspapers before becoming the agency's president. He retired in 1976.

title: SchlumbergerRowan
description: Schlumberger Ltd. said yesterday it had acquired 727,400 additional shares of Rowan Companies Inc. at a price range of $21.81 to $23.40 a share between April 18 and 30. This brings its holdings to 2,077,200 shares, or about 20 percent of Rowan's 10 million shares outstanding.

title: Miss Daniel Shoots 70, Leads by 1
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., May 3  When Nancy Lopez was winning almost everything as a rookie on the women's golf tour last year, there were some people in this part of the country who said: You haven't seen anything yet. Just wait until Beth Daniel turns pro."

title: Firefighters in Birmingham Vote To Join PoliceSanitation Strike
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 3 (UPI) The city's firefighters joined 2,000 police and sanitation workers late today in their twoday strike over insurance coverage.

title: Neikrug to Play All Six Of Bach 's Cello Suites
description: One of the hardest tasks a cellist can set himself is to give a recital devoted to the six unaccompanied suites Bach wrote for the cello. The fact that a fair number of cellists accepts the challenge doesn't make it any easier; it merely indicates how fascinating the notion is.

title: Custom House Is Setting For a World Of New Arts
description: THE magnificent, BeauxArt United States Custom House on Bowling Green will once again be the site of an extended series of free avantgarde performances, residencies, installations and a visualarts exhibition. The whole project is called Custom and Culture, and the events get under way in earnest this weekend, continuing through June 17.

title: Maiden Is Surprise Kentucky Derby Entry
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3  A selfstyled breeding expert who reportedly has gone broke twice in the horse business startled the racing fraternity today by entering a nonwinner named Great Redeemer in Saturday's 105th Kentucky Derby.

title: The Editorial Notebook Remodel the Subway Remodeling Plan
description: Security and squalor are not unrelated. Beyond the disputed statistics about crime in the New York subways is the indisputable fact that their evident decay and sordid stations do nothing to make people feel safe.

title: Benefit for Dance Institute at Felt Forum
description: Professional musicians and dancers and more than 300 children from the metropolitan area will take part in a benefit performance for the National Dance Institute on Sunday at 8 P.M. at the Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue and 33dtreet.

title: TV: Global Village Festival and the Life of Molire
description: MUCH of the most interesting fare this weekend can be found in relatively outoftheway places  on cable television or in a village loft.

title: Elephant Hunt Turns Into Search for Owner
description: That elusive Brooklyn elephant is now believed to have been linked to an animal owner with many aliases and a long previous record of complaints involving animals, the director of the New York City Health Department's Bureau of Animal Affairs said yesterday.

title: Stock Show at the Waldorf
description: Perched on the 18th floor of the WaldorfAstoria, the Starlight Roof has been an elegant nightclub and ballroom for nearly half a century. Its crystal chandeliers were imported from Vienna, its wallpaper is an aviary of jadegreen songbirds. Glenn Miller's band played there and Rudy Vallee sang there. Ameha Earhart was honored there. Count Basie brought uptown jazz to Park Avenue there. One of its few links to sports occurred when Muhammad Ali and George Foreman scuffled on a dais there a few months before their Zaire rematch. But yesterday the National Football League conducted a stock show there, its annual draft of college beef. All of the

title: SENATE, 7712, VOTES MX MISSILE FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON. May 3 (AP)  The Senate voted today to authorize fullscale development of a mobile intercontinental ballistic missile that would be less vulnerable to surprise attack than existing landbased missiles.

title: Study Eases Concern On Contagious Nature Of Hodgkin's Disease
description: BOSTON, May3 (AP)  Hodgkin's disease, a form of cancer that will strike 6,900 Americans this year, is apparently not contagious, despite earlier reports saying that it was spread from person to person, according to a new study.

title: Bluegrass Contest Plays L.I. Reprise
description: The Brooklyn Union Grass aub is not a group of gardeners, and the Hen Cackle Sweet Serenaders are not a gaggle of poultry enthusiasts fresh off the farm.

title: Consumer Credit At Record
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI) American consumers obtained new credit at record levels during March but also paid off old debts at a faster pace than ever before, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Gracie Mansion May Get AlternativeEnergy Plant
description: Mayor Koch has offered the use of Gracie Mansion for a statesponsored solar energy and windmillpower demonstration project, and a threemonth, $40,000 study of the convertibility of the 1799 white frame Colonial structure on the East River and its 1963 Susan Wagner wing is under way.

title: Betty Blanc Glassbury, 78, Poet, LongTime Collector of Asian Art
description: Betty Blanc Glassbury, a poet and collector of Asian art, died Wednesday in Doctors Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, May 3  India is reviewing its defense position in view of reports that Pakistan is moving toward the ability to make nuclear weapons, a Government spokesman said in Parliament today. But later he said that his statement should not be construed as a move away from India's previous categorical renunciation of atomic weapons.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ENDS SOWETORIOTS TRIAL
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 3  A sevenmonth trial that became an inquisition into the Soweto riots ended here today with the prosecutor demanding severe deterrent punishment of the 11 black students convicted of sedition for their part in the upheaval. Some of the students, mostly teenagers at the time of the riots, are likely to receive heavy jail terms when sentences are handed down May 11.

title: Settlements By Grumman
description: The Grumman Corporation has agreed to payments that could total $16.3 million in the settlement of three separate lawsuits brought against it by agents involved in the sale of 80 F14 interceptor planes to Iran.

title: Carter Seeking to Retain TaxFree Housing Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  The White House is trying to develop a program that would, at limited cost to the Government, permit cities to continue issuing taxexempt bonds to finance mortgages on singlefamily houses and apartments.

title: Ametek to Buy Metalloy
description: Ametek Inc., a maker of marine motors and other precision equipment, said yesterday it planned to buy Metalby Inc. of Houston for an undisclosed amount of cash. The purchase will be completed in June. Metalloy has an annual sales volume of about $3 million, according to Ametek.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times yesterday was edited to state that The Progressive magazine had been prohibited from publishing an article describing how to build a hydrogen bomb. That is the Government's contention in its court action; the magazine says the article does not contain such information. A further report on the case appears today on page A19.

title: Restaurants
description: ALTHOUGH it takes on some of the less attractive attributes of Coney Island in summer, right now City Island is one of New York's more beguiling attractions. With all the charm of a resort out of season, this casual, comfortably worn island, which is officially part of the Bronx, has the raffish colorfulness of a fishing marina, with its boatyards, its pleasantly ramshackle summer houses and a main street that is being rejuvenated with antiques stores and crafts shops. For the most part, seafood restaurants on this island are operated by Italians, and the food they offer is a lusty combination of simple American fish and shellfish preparations along with Neapolitan specialties.

title: Terrorists Bomb the Rome Offices Of the Christian Democratic Party
description: ROME, May 3  A group of urban guerrillas raided the Rome area headquarters of Italy's dominant Christian Democratic Party today, wrecked two floors with bombs, killed one policeman, wounded two others and escaped.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday announced that it had developed a new family of experimental computer circuits that operate so quickly they approach limits imposed by the speed of light.

title: CONSERVATIVES WIN BRITISH VOTE; MARGARET THATCHER FIRST WOMAN TO HEAD A EUROPEAN GOVERNMENT
description: LONDON, Friday, May 4  Margaret Thatcher and the Conservative Party won a decisive victory in Britain's general election yesterday.

title: For Children of Holocaust Survivors, an Affectionate Gathering
description: I saw things I knew no little girl should see. Blood and shattered glass. Piles of skeletons and blackened barbwire with bits of flesh stuck to it ... Hills of suitcases, mountains of children's shoes. Whips, pistols, boots, knives and needles.

title: Plant to Convert Garbage to Fuel Set for the Bronx
description: A $100 million facility designed to convert 3,000 tons of garbage daily into a fuel that could substitute for oil will be financed and built in the South Bronx by a private concern with the assistance of the State Urban Development Corporaton, U.D.C. officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Mausoleum for Mao Is Reopened in Peking
description: HONG KONG, May 3  China reopened Mao Zedong's mausoleum today for the first time since December, the latest sign that he is making something of a posthumous comeback.

title: Companies List Their Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American E xchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Two Drums of Caustic Chemicals Are Found in Ontario Town Dump
description: TORONTO, May 3 (AP)  An official of the Ontario Environment Ministry said today that two drums of caustic chemicals had been discovered at a Fort Erie dump that is described as hazardous in ministry records.

title: Market Place
description: BROKERS on the New York Stock Exchange have become increasingly restless with a computerized display system that purports to give uptotheminute prices, but sometimes, when trades are actually made, turns out to be outofdate.

title: Several Concerns Raise Dividends
description: Good news in the form of higher dividends was announced to shareholders at a number of meetings around the country yesterday.

title: Spying on Americans
description: We've got to get off the back of the . . . C.I.A., says George Bush, the newest Republican Presidential candidate  and former C.I.A. director. He is not alone. There are many who regard the effort to prevent the abuses and horror stories of recent years as just so much wallowing in Watergate, and harmful wallowing

title: Waldheim, Fetediavishly by North Koreans, Heads for Talks in Seoul
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 3 After two days of dazzling pageantry and entertainment, Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations concluded a visit to North Korea today, saying he Was going to South Korea tomorrow with several new elements for discussion.

title: Concert: Gottschalk Extravaganza
description: EUGENE LIST, a pianist who has done as much as anyone to win posthumous fame for Louis Moreau Gottschalk, presided at a threehour monster concert in Gottschalk's memory Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall. It was a glorious idea, but it didn't quite come off.

title: The Rev. Leo Barrows, 63, Dies; Professor at St. Peter's College
description: The Rev. Leo Branch Barrows, a professor of theology and former dean of the evening sessions at St. Peter's College, died Tuesday at St. Francis Community Health Center in Jersey City, N.J., after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

title: Ribicoff Decides He Won't Seek A Fourth Term
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut announced today that he would retire from the Senate after his current term of office  his third expires next year.

title: Chrysler Posts Loss For Quarter
description: DETROIT, May 3  The Chrysler Corporation, the nation's thirdlargest passenger car manufacturer, reported today a firstquarter loss of $53.8 million, less than half what it lost in last year's first quarter but significantly more than what investmentmarket analysts had anticipated.

title: Crafts in Richmondtown
description: The Richmondtown Restoration on Staten Island will open for the season Sunday with its annual Yankee Peddler Day. Demonstrations of weaving, printing, basketmaking and leather tanning will take place at the restoration, which provides examples of life in American villages during the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries. The 96acre site, run by the Staten Island Historical Society. is at 441 Clark Avenue. For more information, call 3511611.

title: House Defeats Proposal to Balance Budget and Cut Taxes $10 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  The House today defeated a Republican financial plan that its sponsors said would have balanced the Federal budget in 1980 and permitted a $10 billion tax cut at the same time.

title: S.E.C. Halts Brascan Trading 10 Days
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday a 10day suspension of trading in the securities of Brascan Ltd., the Canadian holding company that is trying to take over the F.W. Woolworth Company.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Up on Mergers, CasinoStock Gains
description: Casino stocks moved higher yesterday as takeover developments shared the limelight in Wall Street. The general market, continuing its weeklong pattern of showing slight changes, posted a small advance.

title: Horoscopes, by Computer
description: One out of four Americans regularly reads an astrology column. Seventysix percent of all Americans know what sign they were born under. So says a recent Gallup survey.

title: At the Movies
description: Michael Ritchie denies romantic film was his Affair.

title: Trade Deficit Cut; Smallest in 2 Years
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) An increase in overall exports more than offset an 8 percent rise in oil imports and helped lower the nation's trade deficit to $6.2 billion in the first three months of the year, the Commerce Department said today. It was the smallest quarterly deficit in more than two years.

title: Art: Tony Smith, SculptorHumorist
description: TONY SMITH'S new show at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, consists of two works only: a 10part piece that fills the entire upper floor of the gallery and a big single piece called Throwback, which comfortably fills one of the rooms below. They are there through June 9, and between them they have a lot to tell us about the current ambitions of one of our stranger and more provocative artists.

title: Ayatollah's Funeral Becomes AntiCommunist Rally
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 3 Hundreds of thousands of chanting, weeping mourners turned the funeral procession for Ayatollah Morteza Motahari, the slain reputed chief of the Revolutionary Council, into an antiCommunist rally today.

title: Rubber Union Ties Court Order On Pay Rules to Delaying Strike
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  The United Rubber Workers has offered to rescind its 12:01 A.M. Saturday strike deadline against Uniroyal Inc. if a Federal judge will issue a temporary order prohibiting Carter Administration officials from interfering in the rubber industry's labor negotiations.

title: Gulf and Truckers Reach Accord
description: Negotiators for the Gulf Oil Corporation and drivers who deliver gasoline to service stations in the New York metropolitan area reached a tentative agreement on a twoyear contract late last night in Woodbridge, N.J., leaving only settlments with Amoco and Getty oustanding in the effort to avert threatened walkouts. The union's president, Richard Lewicki, said he expected difficulty in the Getty talks.

title: Chase Lifts Prime Rate To 1%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank raised its prime rate yesterday to 11 percent from 11 percent, and Citibank indicated it might increase its prime rate today, underscoring the general trend to higher borrowing costs for corporations. The prime is the rate banks charge their most creditworthy corporate customers.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Here is a story for those who urge newspapers. to print good news rather than the usual gloom and doom:

title: Chris Evert Triumphs In Federation Cup Play
description: MADRID, May 3 (AP)  Chris Evert, rejoining tennis competition 16 days after her wedding to John Lloyd, the British Davis Cup player, beat Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, 69, 62, today to send the topseeded United States team to a 30 victory and into the quarterfinals of the $110,000 Federation Cup tournament.

title: Mount Vernon's Auxiliary Police Force Dismissed
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 3This city's 40member auxiliary police force was dismissed last night by the city's Civil Defense Director for refusing to report to work last weekend.

title: Traveling President Unable to Shun Trappings of Power
description: DES MOINES, May 3  At precisely 11:05 A.M. tomorrow, according to the plan, Air Force One will touch down at the Air National Guard facility here and taxi to a halt near a ramp next to a white telephone on a blue, plastic pedestal.

title: In Her Own Words
description: Comments by Margaret Thatcher since taking the party leadership in 1975:

title: Chile's Chicago Pill  II
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Under photographs of Mahatma Gandhi and Marttn Luther. King Jr. on the wall of shabby office almost next door to Santiago's cathedral, two secretaries are busy answering the phone, typing documents and trying to respond to constant stream of visitors to the Vicariate of Solidarity. This is the socialaction arm of the Roman Catholic Church, run until recently by a dynamic young priest in civilian clothes, Msgr. Cristian Precht.

title: Shades of the Medici on Park Avenue
description: GENEVA HELM has dyed her hair a fiery red to play Queen Elizabeth I. Minstrels and troubadours are donning doublets of velvet, satin and silk, entwined with pearls and threads of silver and gold. Musicians are tuning up sacbut and viola da gamba, pipe and tabor. The minions of Lorenzo, the Magnificent Medici, are brewing foaming mead and beakers of blushful hippocrene. The Ananda Dancers are gliding to the stately measures of pavane and gavotte. And the Incredible Merlin the Magician is preparing for his joust with Feste, the fireeating fool, by making beauteous damsels levitate and disappear.

title: Movie: 'Last Embrace,' a Hero-Besieged Thriller:The Game Is Deadly
description: HARRY HANNAN (Roy Scheider) thinks someone is out to kill him. Hannan, who works for a top-secret government bureau that may or may not be the Central Intelligence Agency, goes to Mexico to meet a contact in a cantina just over the border from El Paso and, instead, meets an ambush in which his wife is assassinated. Is somebody trying to tell him something?His suspicions are further reinforced when, after a stay in a Connecticut sanitarium, he is standing in a suburban railroad station and is almost pushed into the path of an incoming train. Is he simply high strung and nervous? Later he receives a letter that is definitely not junk mail. It's a note written in ancient Hebrew and signed "Avenger of Blood." Is Harry mad?If you know your movies, you can be sure he isn't. The principal pleasure of Jonathan Demme's "Last Embrace" is noting the way the director is able to keep this very slim tale moving forward without totally alienating common sense. The secret is impeccable casting.More than any other new director Mr. Demme recognizes good actors and knows how to use them. As the besieged Harry Hannan, Mr. Scheider is like an uncertainly delicate watch spring. You can never be sure if one more turn of the screw will be smooth or if it will result in a total crackup. No other leading actor can create so much tension out of such modest material. As the young woman who befriends Harry Hannan, Janet Margolin is unexpectedly fine, but it's the sort of role that offers a good deal more than is originally promised.The supporting cast is made up of some of the best actors available in New York and Hollywood, including Sam Levene, John Glover, the Oscar-winning Christopher Walken, David Margulies and Lou Gilbert, as well as Charles Napier and Marcia Rodd, who were so memorably lunatic in Mr. Demme's "Handle With Care.""Last Embrace," which opens today at the Paramount, Beekman, Murray Hill and other theaters, is never quite so entertaining as its parts, but I've no idea whether this is because of some lack in David Shaber's screenplay or because Mr. Demme's handling of it is more conventional than need be. The material is the sort that might be liberated by the imagination of Alfred Hitchcock. In only two sequences does the film rise to its baroque needs.In one, a "john" meets his death at the hands of a lady of the evening, but in midafternoon, and in the other, a climactic chase at Niagara Falls, the pursuer is momentarily stumped at the edge of the falls because all of the sightseers have suddenly donned identical rain slickers. This image of what appears to be an innocent group of yellow penguins is very, very funny. No other moment in the movie matches it.

title: Mobil President Urges Controls
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 3  At the annual meeting of stockholders held here today, William P. Tavoulareas, president of the Mobil Corporation, called, as had been expected, for a continuation of price controls on existing oil in the United States, and full decontrol of new oil.

title: Touring the Town for Tiffany Windows
description: The quality and quantity of Louis Comfort Tiffany's stainedglass windows between Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn and Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx is staggering. Now, after

title: Bridge:
description: All tournament players are familiar with the negative double, in which doubles of overcalls, within limits prescribed by partnership preference, are for takeout rather than penalty, suggesting length in any unbid major suit. But very few are familiar with the negative redouble, which has recently become popular among the experts.

title: EARNINGS
description: Gimbel Brothers Inc., parent of one of New York's oldest retailers, reported yesterday that its earnings in the 13 weeks to Dec. 30 were up 14.6 percent on a sales gain of 9.2 percent. A spokesman for the retailer said the results reflected the largest Christmas business in the company's I37year history.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: B. Altman & Company, the New York departmentstore chain, has elected Richard J. Mullin a vice president.

title: ASEAN's Members Start to Speak With One Voice
description: SINGAPORE, May 3  Their collective name, ASEAN, still looks more like misspelled word than an acronym for the Association of South East Asian Nations. Their professed goal of achieving regional economic integration has gone virtually nowhere.

title: President Creates 2 Panels to Rid Government of Fraud and Waste
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)  President Carter established two highlevel panels today to combat fraud, waste and inefficiency in the Government, which his advisers say cost taxpayers billions of dollars each year.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MAY 4, 1979

title: Adela Holzer Is Given 2to6Year Sentence For Investment Fraud
description: Declaring that Adela Holzer, the former Broadway producer, was motivated by simple greed, Justice Richard G. Denzer of State Supreme Court in Manhattan sentenced her yesterday to two to six years for defrauding scores of investors of their life savings.

title: Whetting The Soviet Appetite
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  What are they up to? That was the reaction of staff member of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry even before the announcement that the Russians had released two Jewish, one Baptist, one Ukrainian and one Orthodox dissident in a Spectacular exchange for two spies. A few days earlier, five Jews were let out of prison and allowed to emigrate in fact. Jewish emigration at the current monthly rate may reach 50,000 a year. Then, too, a Yiddish rockopera group, after having been confined to performances in Siberia, was unexpectedly authorized to appear in Moscow. The Russians certainly are up to something.

title: Reading Mr. Miller's Smoke Signals
description: Just as we were urging last weekend that the Federal Reserve Board's Chairman Miller hold interest rates steady and ignore the Administration's clamor for higher rates, the Fed took action that many read as a surrender to the White House. After a week of trying to figure it out, we are still unsure about where the Fed is headed. There is reason to hope, therefore, that Mr. Miller remains wary of more restrictive monetary policies and is still seeking a period of slow growth to shake down doubledigit inflation without recession.

title: Mauritania Backs Talks With Sahara Guerrillas
description: PARIS, May 3 (AP)  Mauritania accepts selfdetermination for residents of the former Spanish Sahara and is willing to start talks with the Polisario guerrilla movement, Prime Minister Ahmed OuId Bouceif said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP BY 0.9% FOR APRIL; FOOD DOWN A LITTLE
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Producer prices rose by ninetenths of 1 percent in April, and, despite a slight slowing from March, signs pointed to at least another month of substantial increases, according to Labor Department figures released today.

title: Move to Draft KennedyEndorsed By Cleveland Democratic Leaders
description: CLEVELAND. May 3  Cleveland's Democratic Party moved tonight toward urging Senator Edward M. Kennedy to run for President in 1980, despite what the party chairman called a, pro forma request from the Senator's office to block the move.

title: Uniroyal's Big Peril in a Strike
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 2  Uniroyal Inc., the target singled out by the United Rubber Workers, could be severely hurt in a strike threatened for Friday midnight.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Music: Giulini's Beethoven Night
description: CARLO MARIA GIULINI and the Los Angeles Philharmonic came to town last night bearng the Beethoven Ninth Symphony. It was the first of three concerts that they will be giving in Carnegie Hall on three consecutive nights. These concerts are in the nature of a celebration. The Los Angeles Philharmonic is celebrating its 60th anniversary season, and it has a new conductor as part of the festivities. Mr. Giulini took corn mand of the orchestra when Zubin Mehta left it for New York.

title: Deaths
description: ALTSHULERMel on May 2, 1979 in his tittyseaind year. We record with scram the death of a cherished, courageous friend, he waged a noble battle.

title: Memo Suggests Talmadge Failed To Report Campaign Gifts in '74
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Evidence presented to the Senate ethics committee today indicated that Senator Herman E. Talmadge, with the help of a top aide, may have received several campaign gifts that were deliberately not reported.

title: Arab League ExAides Remove $250,000 From New York Bank
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 3 Two Egyptian former employees of the Arab League office in New York have retaliated for the suspension of Egypt from league membership by withdrawing at least $250,000 from a Manhattan bank for transfer to the organization's headquarters in Cairo.

title: The City
description: Council Panel Acts On Rent Hearings

title: Enslaving and Torture of Indians Charged by Missionary in Brazil
description: BRASILIA, May 3 (Reuters) Catholic missionary has accused some officials of virtually enslaving an Indian tribe in remote western Brazil and of torturing them, church sources said today.

title: Notes on People
