description: Metropolitan Opera Guild Getting Its 10th President

title: 77th St. &rine Fair Set
description: Handicrafts, ethnic foods., cakes and children's rides will be available tomorrow on 77th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, as part of Mayfair, a spring fundraismg festival sponsored by the Parents Association of Public School 87. The event is scheduled to begin at noon and an until 6 P.M. Rain date is the following Saturday.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: As Mike Mansfield said, There is a time to slay and a time to go. I've watched them come and go, and I have admiration for the men who know how to go out at the top of their careers. A person who's been in power a long lane should know how to step (Aside and open Up the political process.  Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff. [A1:1:1]

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: For the last 14 years, Lester Pollack has been a close associate of Laurence A. Tisch and Preston Robert Tisch In the management of the Loews Corporation, where he rose to executive vice president. In some quarters, he was called the third brother because of his close professional and personal relationship with the Tisches at the widely diversified company.

title: For Central Park Bird Watchers, Thrills Take Flight Every Spring
description: Why don't bird watchers get warblers neck in Central Park? Why does the Police Department assign a patrolman to watch the bird watchers? And have you ever seen a rock dove?

title: Poll Finds Increasing Concern Over Threats to Privacy
description: Two out of three Americans polled in a recent national survey expressed concern that Government agencies such as the Internal Revenue Service and private organizations such as finance companies were violating their privacy.

title: Dance: Ailey Tribute to Miingus
description: ASASSY new production, the kind thabt used to be banned in Boston, highlighted the opening gala of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Wednesday night at the City Center35th Street Theater. But there was more besides.

title: Report on Foster Care Provides a Blueprint for Reforms
description: Early on a soft May evening, after most of the people who work near City Hall had left their offices and while three young men in shirtsleeves and ties threw a softball around in the park just outside the Mayor's office. City Council President Carol Bellamy sat at a desk on the other side of the building explaining how her office's use of new social science technologies might help her and Controller Har

title: Study Criticizes State Dept. On Handling of Jonestown
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  A Government report on the Jonestown tragedy in Guyana charges the State Department with errors and lapses in handling and evaluating information about the People's Temple before the mass murders and suicides of last Nov. 18.

title: Operetta: Vagabond King
description: THIS year marks the centennial of the birth of Rudolf Friml, and to mark the anniversary the Village Light Opera Group has revived The Vagabond King, a hit operetta of 1925 that gave us three memorable songs  Only a Rose, Some Day and song of me vagabonds  in a score of remarkable strength throughout.

title: Sales at Chains Rise, But Sears Lists Drop
description: Several of the nation's largest retail chains reported substantial sales gains for April and the first 13 weeks of this year, compared with the corresponding periods a year ago, but Sears, Roebtick & Company, the nation's biggest general merchandise and catalogue retailer, was not among them.

title: Conference on Arms Pact Elicits Views From the Heart of Texas
description: AMARILLO. Tex., May 2  The morning had been full of speeches and slogans, calls to arms, and calls for arms control. Strange terms  MIRV's and Backfires and ICBM's  had hurtled around the room, and now it was time for lunch and reflection.

title: U.S. Charges 18 With Operating 2 Big Narcotics Rings
description: Eighteen defendants were charged yesterday with operating two major narcotics rings  one regarded as the largest heroin supplier in New York City for almost a year and one allegedly run from prison by a convicted narcotics dealer.

title: CHARLES ANGOFF, WRITER, DIES AT 77
description: Charles Angoff, a literary figure for more than half a century and author of a series of autobiographical novels that have run to 11 volumes, died yesterday morning at New York Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: NEW YORK NUMBERS FEWER UNEMPLOYED
description: The unemployment rate declined in New York City and New York State last month, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Government, and New Jersey showed a significant improvement, with its unemployment rate falling below 6 percent for the first time in nearly five years.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, May 5

title: E.P.A. Is Pressed to Drop Tougher Emission Rules for CoalFired Plants
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  Under pressure from the coal industry and Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, the Environmental Protection Agency may decide to scrap its plans to toughen air pollution standards for new coalfired power and industrial plants.

title: Moves Across Country Of Radioactive Sludge Stir Ire in Some States
description: Flatbed trailers carrying casks of radioactive sludge from Pennsylvania's crippled Three Mile Island nuclear reactor to Richland, Wash., have been making their way across America on Interstate 80 in recent weeks.

title: Maurice FremontSmith, Internist
description: MELROSE, Mass., May 4 (AP) Maurice FremontSmith, the physician who popularized the Pap smear test for the detection of cervical cancer, died today in the MelroseWakefield Hospital after a short illness. He was 88 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: The odds against two expert players going astray in similar fashion in the play of the same deal are very high indeed, but it happened last Sunday in the final of the New York Grand National Team Championship in Manhattan. At both tables, four spades was reached, but by different routes.

title: Rosen Criticizes Yanks After Loss
description: The Yankees were rocked last night by their eighth loss in 12 games, an 115 drubbing by the Oakland A's. Then they were put on warning after the sorry showing, which included four errors, that complacency will not take over.

title: Rate Fears Send Dow Down 10.05
description: The stock market, confronted with investor concern over rising interest rates, declined along a broad front yes terday. The Dow Jones industrial aver age fell 10.05 points to 897.54.

title: Cosmos Win by 10 On Seninho's Goal
description: TORONTO, May 4  The Cosmos got a goal by Seninho in the 17th minute and withstood a fierce Toronto attack the rest of the way to come away with a 10 victory tonight over the Blizzard at Exhibition Stadium.

title: Mayor Declares Emergency Near Jersey Chemical Plant
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., May 4  Mayor Thomas G. Dunn declared a state of emergency in this Union County industrial community today and restricted pedestrian and vehicular traffic within half a mile of a chemical plant where hazardous materials are stored.

title: 500 Moved Out After Tank Cars Derail
description: All 500 residents of Sunset Bay, N.Y., were ordered out of the Lake Erie shorefront community 30 miles southwest of Buffalo yesterday after the derailment of 21 cars of a Conrail freight train, including two tank cars of highly flammable, potentially explosive vinyl chloride. The cars were jackknifed into an inverted V on a trestle bridge.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation
description: LOS ANGELES, May 4 (AP)  Doctors said today that they had found more cancer in John Wayne, the 71yearold movie actor.

title: Four in Crane Presidential Drive Resign After Ouster of Manager
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP)  Four top aides in Representative Philip M. Crane's drive for the Republican Presidential nomination resigned today after the abrupt ouster of the campaign mann per Richard S. Williamson.

title: Prison Officials and Striking Guards Wait for Normalcy
description: Ronald Bertrand stood on the threshold of the Arthur Kill Correctional Facility on Staten Island yesterday afternoon, peered past a huge parking lot in the direction of some men who were playing hall or lounging in the sunshine and said:

title: Prices for Gasoline Rise 4% in France
description: PARIS, May 4 (AP)  Gasoline prices will rise about 4 percent in France today and will be among the highest in Europe. sources at the Ministry of Economy said. At current exchange rates, regular gasoline will cost the equivalent of $2.29 a gallon.

title: News Summary
description: Margaret Thatcher took office as Prime Minister of Britain after the Conservative Party's solid victory in Thursday's election. She is the first woman to be Prime Minister of a European country. The British seemed somewhat surprised that a woman would head the government, even though Mrs. Thatcher's victory had been anticipated. Her party will have a majority of 93 seats in the House of Commons. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Again, a New York Traffic Plan
description: Like many other cities, New York has spent the better part of a decade evading the Federal cleanair requirements that impinge on its auto traffic patterns. Mayor Lindsay, with help from the state administration of Nelson Rockefeller, offered a plan in 1973 to reduce Manhattan's congestion by charging tolls on the East River bridges but it riled too many commuters and merchants. The city was then hauled into court, where new promises were made, and broken. Mayor Beame mostly stalled, because he thought compliance with many of the cleanair standards would injure the city's business. A few measures to limit parking were finally adopted but they are far from enough. Now the legal burden weighs on Mayor Koch.

title: World Gold
description: FRIDAY, MAY 4, 1979

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, May 4, 1979

title: I.R.S. Rule on Tenants Assailed
description: Two Bronx officials began a petition campaign yesterday to overturn a ruling by the Internal Revenue Service that denies tenants the right to deduct a portion of their building's realestate taxes.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, Avery Fisher Hall, 8:30.

title: A Meteorite Hunt Makes a Splash Around Barnegat Bay
description: LANOICA HARBOR, N.J.  About 9:45 o'clock on the evening of April 18, while Frank Forka was walking the family dogs along the beach, the dogs  a brown Labrador and a black and brown mixed beagle and retriever  began barking turiously in the direction of Barnegat Bay.

title: Striking Port Authority Officers Stage a Protest in Bus Terminal
description: More than 100 Port Authority police officers, chanting slogans and carrying signs demanding a new contract, picketed inside the Port Authority Bus Terminal during the evening rush hour yesterday.

title: Nystrom's Winner: A Goal to Remember
description: The Islanders Bob Nystrom can go on calling his overtime goal that won Thursday night's game the most important of his career. And the Islanders and Rangers, tied at two games apiece in their Stanley Cup semifinal series, can go on saying it's like starting all over again tonight when they play the fifth contest of their fourofsevengame series at Nassau Coliseum.

title: May and May Alone Brings Out the Gypsy in Me!
description: The month of May again! I am strolling down a thoroughfare in lower Manhattan on my way to Orchard Street, and I am holding a tornup coat in my hands. The west wind knocks my hat off. I pick up my hat.

title: Dance: Detroit, Rod Rodgers Troupes
description: The Detroit City Dance Company and the Rod Rodgers Dance Company of New York shared the first dance concert presented by the Black Theater Festival U.S.A. Thursday night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater.

title: Bullets Trounced By Spurs
description: LANDOVER, Md., May 4  The Washington Bullets did not play like the defending National Basketball Association champions tonight, and they were battered by the San Antonio Spurs, 11897,in the opening game or the Eastern Conference championship before a capacity crowd of 19,035 at the Capital Centre. The second game of the fourofsevengame series will be played here Sunday afternoon.

title: Giants Run in 8th Edges Mets
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 4  A towering drive to deep center field by Roger Metzger with one out in the eighth off Skip Lockwood set the stage tonight for a 43 victory by the Giants over the New York Mets before 19.275 fans.

title: Estimate Board Acts to Improve City Foster Care
description: Broad changes were voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate in New York City's $300millionayear program that provides foster care through voluntary agencies for 26.000 children.

title: Smith Role in New Regime Is Big Question in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 30 With the election over and Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa preparing to take over as Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith is in his last weeks at the pinnacle of authority here.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Federated's Profit Is Up; Problems of A.&S. Cited
description: Abraham & Straus still experienced a poor year in 1978 despite its efforts to resolve operating problems that are holding down profits, its parent, Federated Department Stores Inc., said yesterday in a financial report.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PORTER WITH HART The mention of Broadway's Jubilee, the 1935 musical, usually suggests th??e Cole Porter classics, Begin the Beguine, Just One of Those Things and Why Shouldn't I?

title: Books of The Times Princess in the Closet
description: ANYONE'S DAUGHTER. By Shana Alexander. 562 pages. Viking. $14.95.

title: MARGARET THATCHER ASSUMES HER OFFICE AS PRIME MINISTER
description: LONDON, May 4  Margaret Thatcher, who lived above her father's smalltown grocery store for the first 18 years of her life, took office today as the Prime Minister of Britain.

title: Californians Doubt Presidential Visit Can Hurt Brown
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 4  Even though his fellow Democratic officehold ers tend to think of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., as being as slippery as an eel and as eccentric as a hummingbird's flight, they doubt that President Carter can shake Mr. Brown's grip on California with a visit that began today.

title: HOTEL REPORTS LOAN TO HOUSTON'S MAYOR
description: HOUSTON, May 4  A $6,000 loan to cover gambling losses incurred by Mayor Jim McCorm on a Las Vegas convention trip last January came from the funds of the MGM Grand Hotel, a representative of the hotel disclosed today.

title: Money
description: THURSDAY, MAY 3, 1979

title: Comsat Asks for Rate Cut of 15%
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation said it had asked the Federal Communications Commission for a 15 percent reduction in the rate it charges for international satellite service.

title: Mine Union in Kentucky Strike Rejected in Election
description: STEARNS, Ky., May 4 (AP)  The United Mine Workers was rejected yes. terday as bargaining agent at the Stearns Mining Company's embattled Justus mine, but the election is far from settled.

title: State of Emergency Declared at Jersey Chemical Plant
description: In Elizabeth, N.J., workers for the State Department of Environmental Protection wore respirators yesterday on the site of the Chemical Control Corporation facility at 23 South Front Street. Earlier, Mayor Thomas G. Dunn declared an emergency within a halfmile radius after discovery of potentially explosive chemicals, including nitroglycerin and picric acid crystals. Page 26.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: FLASH FLOODS HIT TENNESSEE: In Nashville, vehi cles were pushed off road by rising waters of Mill Creek after up to seven Inches of rain fell yesterday. High winds accompanied the driving rain that lashed central Tennessee, washing out roads and bridges and forcing more than 1,600 persons in four counties to flee their homes.

title: Sports Today
description: National championship sprint races, at Terre Haute, Ind. (Television  Channel 7, 4 P.M., finals at 6 P.M. following Kentucky Derby wrapup.)

title: New York Prison Guards End Their 16Day Strike
description: The state's prison guards ratified a new threeyear contract last night and began returning to work early today, ending a 16day strike that had incurred heavy fines and forced the state to call National Guardsmen and state troopers to tend 21,000 inmates.

title: U.S.Chinese Business Deals Lag As Peking Reviews Growth Plan
description: HONG KONG, May 4  Some of the deals that American companies negotiated with Peking are running into uncertainties as a result of China's current reappraisal of its modernization program, interviews with businessmen indicate. Other transactions, however, are going ahead, albeit more slowly.

title: Patents
description: Insulating Spacecraft From Heat

title: Draddy Captures Mile Rur At 14th New York Relays
description: Vince Draddy won, Billy Pearson could have won, and Vern Dye thought he won but was disqualified yesterday on the opening day of the 14th annual New York Relays at Downing Stadium on Ranch'Ils Island.

title: McEnroe, Borg in Final
description: DALLAS, May 4  John McEnroe broke down the mental barrier that had separated him from success against Jimmy Connors in impressive fashion tonight, eliminating Connors, 61, 64, 64, in the semifinals of the World Chamoionship of Tennis.

title: U.S. Warns City It May Withhold Revenue Sharing
description: The Treasury Department has warned New York City that $300 million in Federal revenuesharing funds may be withheld on the basis of a February court finding that the city discriminated against black and Hispanic police officers.

title: Deaths
description: AVINSSuzanne, beloved wife of the late William, devoted mother of Jeremiah, Styra ElsInger and Dr. Nora Klein, loving grandmother, gear gig. ter of Berte Brown, Annette Chiland and Georgette Osnowitz. Services Sunday 12 noon at Bronx Riverside, 179 St & Grand Concourse

title: Zahringer Pacing Field In Richardson Memorial
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 4 George Zahringer, a 26yearold stockbroker, disproved an observation that he has everything but consistency by leading the way today into the semifinal round of the William B. Richardson memorial golf tournament.

title: Deaths
description: RUFFHyman. Beloved husband of Frieda. Devoted father of Jackie Levy, Leslie Mathias, and Michael. Dear brother of Nettle Alterman and Robert. Loving grandfather of Lisa. Nicole, and Pamela. Services at Schwartz Brothers, Queens Blvd at 76 Road, Forest Hills 11:15 AM Sunday.

title: Senate Group Blocks Aid Grant to Turkey; Backs a Loan Instead
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  The Carter Administration, which has sought to set an example for other nations in providing Turkey with economic and military aid, suffered a setback yesterday when a Senate committee voted to lend Turkey money instead of providing it with an outright grant.

title: About Huntington
description: HUNTINGTON, May 3  They had arrived in the suburbs, chosen a good frame house and settled into a daily antlike routine  eat and run, eat and run  until the men from Fumex came this week and killed them.

title: 200 Starving Cambodians Facing Expulsion by Thailand and Death
description: BAN LAEM, Thailand, May 4  Huddled under makeshift shelters around a simple pagoda in this impoverished village on the Cambodian border, hungry and ill, about 200 Cambodian refugees are awaiting what they and their guards believe is nearly certain death within seven days.

title: Official Rejects Charges Of Shipyard Vote Fraud
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., May 4  An administrative law judge of the National Labor Relations Board has recommended dismissal of voting fraud charges arising froth the union representation election at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company 15 months ago.

title: Dance: Two Pairs of Stars Offer Beauty
description: The Princess Aurora is the focus of The Sleeping Beauty, that treasure of Classical ballet. Cynthia Gregory. and Eleanor D'Antuono, seen in the role at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively, are two of the American Ballet Theater's more dependable ballerinas. In their clear approach to the choreography, they are textbook examples of how to dance the role. Miss D'Antuono could pass, in fact, for a bit of living dance notation, so correctly does she perform Aurora. But the old dear Ballet Theater's production of The Sleeping Beauty, that is  is looking distinctly like a victim of neglect or inattention these days, and neither Miss Gregory nor Miss D'Antuono rescued it, though for the record, both balanced without a quaver in that famous balletic test of nerves, the Rose Adagio.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear an Page 21.

title: H.E.W. Finds That Equal Access for Handicapped Begins at Home
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  They agreed to lower the elevator controls so that a person in a wheelchair could reach the emergency button. They agreed to lower the urinals, lower some of the pay telephones by six Indies, reduce the pressure needed to open doors to eight pounds or less and even redesign the condiment counter in the cafeteria to make it accessible to the handicapped.

title: Erin O'BrienMoore, 77, Is Dead; Actress of Stage, Screen and TV
description: Erin O'BrienMoore, a stage and screen actress of the 1930's whose promising career was hampered by injuries suffered in a restaurant fire, died Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 77 years old.

title: Asian Bank Realigns Aid
description: MANILA, May 4  Sidestepping ideological differences among some of its member countries, the Asian Development Bank endorsed new ways to fight underdevelopment at its 12th annual meeting, which ended today.

title: Citibank Raises Prime to 11%
description: Citibank, which had been the only major bank with an 11% percent prime rate, moved back into line yesterday when it raised its prime to 11 percent. The prime is the rate banks charge their most creditworthy corporate customers.

title: EastWest Battle Looms for 105th Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4 There's no doubt this horse of mine is great, says Bud Delp, the fasttalking trainer of Spectacular Bid. How great, I don't know. Maybe we'll find out tomorrow.

title: Panicky California Drivers Form Lines at Gas Stations
description: LOS ANGELES, May 4  It's hornble; it's jast like it was five years ago, Beverly Lyons, whose Buick was mired 32d in a queue of more than 60 cars outside a Mobil station, said shortly after 8 o'clock this morning.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Pennsylvania Engineering Corporation, whose chairman is Victor Posner, said yesterday that it had bought about 5 percent of the common stock of the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation for $2.5 million.

title: Reins on New Prime Minister
description: LONDON, May 4  Margaret Thatcher, who rose to power on pledges of a drastic change in the strategy for reviving Britain's listless economy, is expected to step cautiously toward her goals

title: Spielvogel Resigns At Interpublic Group
description: In a surprise move, Carl Spielvo. gel, one of the bestknown advertising executives, resigned yesterday as chairman of the executive committee and vice chairman of the board of the Interpublic Group of Companies, the largest communications marketing corporation in the world.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A wide band of heavy cloudiness can be seen extending from the New England area Into the lake region and southwesterly to the western Gulf Coast A band of frontal clouds are apparent across the Cascades and the Pacific Northwest while scattered clouds are visible over the Northern Plain States.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: DR. IRWIN LANGEL

title: Bus Drivers Get A Tentative Pact In School Strike
description: The threemonth strike by schoolbus drivers, which has kept 16,000 handicapped children away from classes, was tentatively settled yesterday with an agreement that would preserve job security for at least some of the striking bus drivers and matrons.

title: Minority Business Aid Faulted
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  Government policies to give members of minority groups a substantial stake in the economy over the last decade have mostly failed and sweeping changes are necessary, according to a new study made in the Commerce Department.

title: Election Expected to Change British Ties to Continent
description: BRUSSELS, May 4  European diplomats in Brussels said today that the Conservative Party's victory in Britain was likely to lead to a shift in political relations within Western Europe that would have important implications for the United States.

title: U.S. Sees Little Foreign Policy Shift Under the New British Government
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  Carter Administration officials said today that they expected no immediate changes in foreign policy under the new British government and that they would be in touch to arrange highlevel talks on a range of issues, including the key problem of finding a common approach on Rhodesia and its newly elected government.

title: U.S. AGENCY REPORTS RISE IN JOBHOLDERS HALTED LAST MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  The sharp and steady rise in the number of jobholders that has characterized the economy in recent months ground to a halt in April, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: COVERUP TIE DENIED BY ROMERO BARCELO
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., May 3 Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo, under pressure from the Puerto Rican press and rival political parties, went on television tonight to denounce reports seeking to link his office with a coverup of events that led to the shooting deaths last year of two suspected terrorists.

title: Lebanese Draw Up a New Program To Seek Reconciliation of Factions
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 4  With the current decrease in the volume of violence, Lebanese leaders are again striving to find a political solution to the problems plaguing this country since the 197576 civil war.

title: Conoco Chief Backs Coal Ties
description: Ralph E. Bailey has more than the usual oilman's interest in the Carter Administration's renewed concern over ownership of coal by oil companies. Mr. Bailey is the new chairman of the Continental Oil Company, which owns the Consolidation Coal Company, the nation's secondlargest coal producer.

title: EARNINGS Grumman's Profits Drop 83.1%
description: The Grumman Corporation, a leading supplier of military aircraft for the Navy and a maker of diversified industrial products, reported yesterday an MA percent plunge in firstquarter profits on a sales decline of 13.6 percent.

title: Guerrillas Attack Police in Soweto
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 4 (AP) Three black guerrillas stormed a police station in the township of Soweto on the outskirts of Johannesburg last night, killing a black officer and injuring two other officers and three civilians before setting the building ablaze and fleeing.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on Page 28.

title: Mrs. Thatcher, the Conservative Hope
description: Margaret Thatcher, who led Britain's Conservative Party to victory on Thursday, is not only the first woman elected to head a major Western government. She is also the most successful of the contemporary conservatives who want to call a halt to the welfare politics of most of those governments. Her victory will give heart to such kindred American spirits as Ronald Reagan and Philip Crane.

title: 4 Blacks Are Sentenced to 30 Days In Dispute Over Refuge Ownership
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., May 4 A Federal judge today sentenced four black men to 30 days in jail for criminal contempt after their arrest Wednesday for refusing to leave the Harris Neck Wildlife Refuge, which blacks say they rightfully own.

title: Your Money
description: Lure of Bonds For Long Term

title: The Region
description: FORKED RIVER, N.J.  Tests of the coolant water surrounding the reactor at the Jersey Central Power and Light Company's nuclear generating plant on Oyster Creek indicated yesterday that there was no damage to the reactor and no abnormal release of radioactivity as the result of an automatic shutdown on Wednesday, according to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Economists Studying Mininum Pay And Effects on Jobless TeenAgers
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  The minimum wage, long considered a protector of the poor, may do more harm than good, at least for teenagers, a growing number of economists believe.

title: Radio
description: 89 A.M., WNCN. Abu Hassan, Overture, Weber; Sonatine for Mandolin and Harpsichord in C, Beethoven; Gala Cakewalk, Gottschalk; Tancredi. Overture, Rossini; Concerto in D, Sinfonia. Bach.

title: ExWife of Talmadge Portrayed By Aide as Sometimes Irrational
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  Senator Herman E. Talmadge's former wife, Betty, one of the main accusers in the Georgia Democrat's Senate ethics hearing, was portrayed today by a top Talmadge aide as a woman capable of irrational statements and acts, including violence.

title: U.N. Stormed by Stamp Buyers; Some Turn Philately Into Cash
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 4 Maria Zimmerer left her home in Morris Plains, N.J., at 5 A.M., caught the bus and by 7 was standing outside the locked iron gates of the United Nations. Beside her in the line, which had begun to form at 1:30 A.M., were William Patty, his wife and three children from Lake Ronkonkoma,, L.I. They were all waiting to buy the United Nations stamps issued today honoring the International Year of the Child.

title: N.A.A.C.P.'s Charges On City Hospital Plan To Be Studied by U.S.
description: The Federal Government will look into a charge that the planned reduction of hospital facilities in New York City constitutes discrimination against blacks and Hispanic people and thus violates Federal civilrights laws, Representative Charles B. Rangel was told yesterday by the Carter Administration.

title: GOV. BROWN OFFERS EMERGENCY GAS PLAN
description: SACRAMENTO, May 4  Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. today announced an emergency plan for dealing with the long lines that California motorists have encountered at gasoline service stations in recent days.

title: Readers Reply to Thomas Sowell's Articles On the Implications of Black Leaders Atypical Origins
description: To the Editor:

title: Financier in San Diego Convicted Of a Second Tax Evasion Charge
description: SAN DIEGO, May 4 (UPI)  A jury convicted financier C. Arnholt Smith, an 80yearold San Diego financier, of a second count of state income tax evasion today and indicated that it was very close to reaching a decision on five other felony counts against him.

title: Malaysian Military Jet Crashes
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 4 (AP)  A Malaysian Air Force F5. jet crashed today 120 miles east of here, killing one of two crewmen, the Air Force said.

title: Young Hands Refurbish France's Past
description: ARGY, France  Noses running and hands reddened with cold, a dozen young people confronted a daunting pile of 17thcentury beams stacked outside the Chateau d'Argy, then cheerfully carted them off to a site threequarters of a mile away. Another group chipped, scraped and painted, while others installed electrical wiring and repaired roofing on a 17thcentury farm.

title: Jets Are Enthusiastic About Draft Choices
description: The oldest and most optimistic Jet of them all, Randy Rasmussen, regarded the end of the college football draft yesterday and concluded: I felt we had people last year that we could go a long way with. This draft could push us over the top.

title: Piano: Bradford Gowen Specializes in U.S. Music
description: This country has produced a number of pianists who specialize honorably and effectively in modern American music and, on the basis of his recital Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, Bradford Gowen can be added to the list. Mr. Gowen's program selection and playing weren't beyond reproach, but they were intelligent and commanding at best.

title: Companies List Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: 3 Women Tied for Golf Lead
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., May 4  Jane Blalock claims she is not on a streak, even though she has won the last two Ladies Professional Golf Association tournaments.

title: Japanese Premier Presents $1 Million Each to Metropolitan Museum and Asia Society
description: The Prime Minister of Japan, Masayoshi Ohira, yesterday presented the Asia Society and the Metropolitan Museum of Art with gifts of $1 million each from the Government of Japan.

title: The City
description: Bail Request Denied In Holzer Case

title: Dance: New Fire Sermon Keeps Ailey Fans Guessing
description: Whatever the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater meant to convey Thursday night with its latest premiere at the City Center55th Street Theater is anybody's guess, and there was plenty of guessing to go around.

title: Rubber Union Rebuffed by Court, But It Postpones Strike at Uniroyal
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  A court move by organized labor to bar Government involvement in the rubber industry's contract negotiations was dealt a technical setback today. Yet the union representing rubber workers postponed a strike against Uniroyal that had been scheduled for 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Woodward Denies It Had Macy Talks
description: Edwin K. Hoffman, chairman of Woodward & Lothrop, the Washingtonarea department store chain, denied yesterday the retail trade reports that the company had recently held informal but inconclusive merger talks with R.H. Macy & Company.

title: For 12 Executives, 78 Was a $1 Million Year
description: Chalk it up to inflation, but at least 12 American industrial executives had incomes exceeding $1 million last year.

title: Worcester Workers Plan Strike
description: WORCESTER, Mass. (UPI)  City employees, including sanitation workers, city airport crash crews, nurses, secretaries and mechanics, overwhelmingly voted yesterday to authorize a strike to begin next week.

title: Theater: Victim, Mario Fratti's Slightly Macabre 3Character Thriller, at the Quaigh
description: In the midst of a telephone conversation with her lover, a woman looks up to find an intruder, a young man with a slightly menacing air, in the house. How did you get in? she asks. The door was open. And what do you want? I'm the gas man, he tells her, come to fix the stove. It turns out soon enough that the door was not open and he's not the gas man. After a little sparring, he admits that he found her wallet in the street, became infatuated with her picture and he's there to take her to bed. Impossible, she says rather haughtily. We'll see, he says, settling in.

title: ClassAction Suit Filed
description: In New York yesterday, Harry Lewis, an owner of 120 shares of Brascan, filed a classaction suit in United States Court for the Southern District of New York alleging that Edper and officers of Edper had denied accurate and full information to shareholders about their plans to seek control of Brascan shares. He asked the court to enjoin Edper from acquiring any more Brascan shares and asked for exemplary damages.

title: JAMES S. ROSEN
description: James S. Rosen, who had been since 1975 a vice president with Johnson & Higgins, a Wall Street insurance concern, died Thursday at the Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Haworth, N.J.

title: From Veils to Padded Shoulders: A Fashion Mosaic
description: The model's head and most of her body were wrapped in white chiffon, brilliantly bathed in color, like an abstract painting or, as Mary McFadden would prefer to say, a mosaic. The models stalking the stage of the Circle in the Square  Miss McFadden would say fiercely  as more than 1,000 spectators watched, riveted, were contemporary embodiments of the Mongolian hordes. You know, Genghis Khan and all that.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Agriculture U.S.A.

title: Letter: On Gun Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Literary Lunch Breaks
description: New Yorkers were out in force yesterday to enjoy the last day of a mostly sunny spring week, and many of them brought their favorite reading. Benjamin G. Benno, left, was oblivious to the activity around him in Washington Square Park. Third graders at P.S. 41 studied their lessons through lunch. And Steve Katz, a New York cabbie, curled up with a book on the hood of his taxi while waiting for a fare.

title: 372,000 Cadillacs Are Recalled
description: DETROIT, May 4 (AP)  The Cadillac division of the General Motors Corporation recalled 372,000 cars today to fix faulty accelerator pedals linked to accidents in which three persons died and 96 were injured. The pedals have a rubber extension at the bottom that could be inadvertently repositioned by the floor mat and wedged under the pedal, G.M. said. Recalled were Coupe de Villes, Sedan de Villes, Broughams and limousines of the 1977 and early 1978 model years. Models with fuel injection were not affected.

title: Deaths
description: KIRSCHMarvin. 1700 NE 105 St, Miami Shores Fkrlda.Forrner VP & Publisher of Radio & TV Daily died May 3, 1979 In Florida.Surylved by wife, Bertha, daughters Mrs. Shirley Rice New York, Mrs. Joan Solewak & son Edward, Florida, sisters Mrs Ruth Schwartz Massachusetts, Mrs Anna Greenberg, California 8 grandchildren & 1 orandchild.Servites Sunday at Wintter Kirby Funeral Chapels, Hollywood Florida.

title: Cabaret Thelma Carpenter Sinks
description: Thelma Carpenter is a singer whose bubbling, buoyant personality is tied in with a pliant, flexible voice and a polished sense of showmanship. And yet, while all these qualities were evident in her performance on Thursday evening at Reno Sweeney, where she is appearing through next week, they were accompanied by a sense of uncertainty, of vagueness, that drained some of the sparkle and flu from Miss Carpenter's normally positive projection.

title: At Duke Zeibert's: Politics And Wit
description: WASHINGTON  Through the lunchtime crowd he strides, a FalstaffIan figure in houndstooth jacket, openneck polo shirt, black slacks and a tan that hints more of the sunshine and gaming tables of Las Vegas than the pale legislative pursuits of Washington. This is the man who talked bool

title: Stage: Equity Theater Revives Clear Day
description: ON A CLEAR DAY YOU CAN SEE FOREVER, musical, with book and lyrics by Alan Jay Lerner; music by Burton Lane. Directed by Richard Mogavero; musical direction by Paul Ford: choreography by Ed Brazo; setting by Richard Harmon; lighting by Norma Coates; costumes by Kenneth M. Yount and Jack Peyron; Production stage manager. Susan K. Butcher. Presented by the Equity Library Theater, 103d Street and Riverside Drive. through May 27.

title: Barbara W. Lynch, U.P. Reporter Formerly at City Hall, Dead at 59
description: Barbara Washburn Lynch, who covered City Hall for The United Press during the administrations of Mayors William O'Dwyer and Vincent R. Impellitteri, died yesterday of cancer at Mt. Sinai Hospital. Mrs. Lynch, who lived in Upper Montclair, N. J., was 59 years old.

title: Egypt Suggests Islamic Leaders Meet on Jerusalem
description: CAIRO, May 4  In a diplomatic counterattack against Arab critics, Egypt has called for an Islamic summit conference to discuss liberation of the Arab sector of Jerusalem, which was annexed by Israel after its 1967 war with the Arabs.

title: City Gets Court Order Telling Moran Towing To Transport Garbage
description: New York City's Corporation Counsel obtained a court order yesterday directing the Moran Towing and Transportation Corporation to carry out its obligations under its contract with the Department of Sanitation or provide three tug boats with sufficient supervisory employees so that the city could transport garbage by water to a Staten Island landfill.

title: Brascan Fights Bid In Canada
description: TORONTO, May 4  Brascan Ltd. filed complaints with the Ontario Securities Commission and Canadian fed eral authorities today asking them to investigate the purchase of 6.7 million Brascan shares by Edper Equities Ltd. earlier this week, thus shifting the focus of the threeway battle between Brascan, Edper and F.W. Woolworth back here from the United States.

title: Prosecution Doubted for Ford Aides
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  It now seems likely that no top officer of the Ford Motor Company will be prosecuted in connection with a Federal grand jury investigation here into a plan to pay a bribe in Indonesia in 1975, according to people familiar with the investigation.

title: Notes on People
description: Koch, at Harvard, Dubious on His Political Longevity

title: Rock Against Racism In Park Today
description: An allday festival called Rock Against Racism will present 17 newwave rock bands in concert today at the Central Park bandshell. The music, which will be interspersed with political speeches by Flo Kennedy, William Kunstler and others, will begin at 11:30 A.M. and continue into the evening.

title: Sonics Triumph, Lead, 20
description: SEATTLE, May 4  It was as if the first game never happened. The Phoenix Suns were embarrassed in the first game of their Western Conference final series with the Seattle SuperSonics, but Paul Westphal of the Suns pointed out that the series was still as close as it could be after one game.

title: Henry Ford's Nephew Is Barred From Board
description: Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, informed his nephew, Benson Ford Jr., by letter yesterday that the committee that selects new members for the company's board of directors has unanimously declined to recommend your nomination to the hnard.

title: Vincent Carberry Dies; Was Business Executive
description: Vincent A. Carberry, director of advertising and public relations for the Precision Valve Corporation of Yonkers, died Wednesday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital after a brief illness. He lived in Leonia, N.J.. and was 68 years old.

title: World News Briefs
description: SAN SALVADOR, Saturday, May 5 (AP)  Persons described by the Government as heavily armed terrorists. seized the French and Costa Rican Embassies yesterday, seriously injuring a French Embassy guard, and took 30 hostages, including the Ambassadors of both countries.

title: Giants Defend Value in Choice of Simms
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 4  He didn't say anything when he looked up and saw the empty 76,000seat stadium, but Phil Simms (who only yesterday was Phil Who?) was impressed. Phil Simms, in his four losing seasons at Morehead State, had never played before more than 25,000 spectators.

title: About 5,000 Soviet Jews Emigrate In April, Setting 2d Straight Record
description: MOSCOW, May 4  The number of Soviet Jews allowed to emigrate broke record in April for the second straight month as about 5,000 left for the main transit point in Vienna, a senior Western envoy said today.

title: SPRING RACING MEETINGS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 20. This was Derby Day, and the weather was very favorable. The crowds that flocked to the Jockey Club's course were very large. Today's sport was exciting. No one could predict the winners in a bunch, although the Derby favorite had been agreed upon by a majority. It was estimated that there were fully 20,000 persons in the stands and in the field, which was free to all, as it always is when the Jockey Derby is run.

title: Two Daddies And One Maiden
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., May 4  The favorite's sire is a middleaged rake who still dates 60 females a year. His name is Bold Bidder. He lives in thes second room on the right as you enter the Lshaped stallion barn on Gainesway Farm just off the Paris Pike, the same barn where he and Queen Sucree conceived Cannonade, who won the 100th Kentucky Derby in 1974 with Queen Elizabeth II looking on from the steepled stands of Churchill Downs. In March of 1975, a gray mare named Spectacular came over the Versailles Pike for a tryst with Bold Bidder, and the product of that encounter, Spectacular Bid, is expected to attract the liveliest support in the mutuels when the field for the 105th Derby goes to the post tomorrow afternoon.

title: Previous Drafts Successful
description: The Jets have had extraordinarily successful drafts in recent years, leading to last season's 88 wonlost mark following three consecutive 311 cam

title: Economic Issues Are Tempting Austrians to Vote for Conservatives
description: VIENNA, May 4  Gustaf Feykus plans to vote conservative for the first time in his life in Sunday's national elections.

title: Coal's Time of Frustration
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  If there is silver lining to the nuclear power industry's cloud of troubles, the coal industry has yet to find it.

title: PBS to Carry Antinuclear March
description: A number of Public Broadcasting. Service television stations throughout the nation will carry live tomorrow's antinuclear demonstration from Washington  the first time that the PBS satellite will be used to allow independent producers to feed a live publicaffairs program to PBS stations.

title: Carter Politicks in Iowa, Assailing Foes
description: DES MOINES, May 4 President Carter brought his unannounced Presidential campaign to this politically strategic Corn Belt state today, joked about his problems with Iowa Democrats and talked about enemy and inflation.

title: Public Management for New Jersey's Buses
description: After three months, the New Jersey Legislature still seems reluctant to approve Governor Byrne's plan to end a costly and controversial bus subsidy program. The Governor wants the state. to take over and run what are now private bus lines, but the lawmakers question whether the state can do a better job. We're pretty sure it can.

title: Bow Stock Negotiations
description: Bow Valley Industries Ltd. said that it was negotiating for the private placement with Canadian financial institutions of up to one million common shares. No further details were given. Bow Valley explores for oil, gas, coal and uranium.

title: Turn Right at the French Fries
description: DON'T let anyone tell you fastfood restaurants are no good. I count on them seven days a week. Do I hate to cook? No, I just couldn't find my way around the Island without them.

title: Engagements SUCHWALDBRODSKY
description: Dr.and Mrs. Julius Buchwald are happy to amounce the engagement of their daughter, Lynne to Dr.Norman Brodsky. son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis I. Brodsky of New Haven. Com & Petach Tikvah, Israel.

title: Guidry Puts Himself In Yankee Bull Pen
description: Ron Guidry, last year's Cy Young Award winner in the American League after having captured 25 of 28 decisions, will try something different for a couple of months.

title: Preserving Dances In Print
description: The time may one day come when a dance lover will be able to tell a friend, I don't think I'll go out tonight. I want to stay home and read dance.

title: TRIAL NEARS AN END IN SILKWOOD DEATH
description: OKLAHOMA CITY. May 5  This trial is a microcosm of the whole nuclear issue, said Gerry Spence, a lawyer representing the family of Karen Gay Silkwood in an $11.5 million damage suit against the KerrMcGee Corporation and the KerrMcGee Nuclear Corporation.

title: Surgeon Tried a Second Time, Is Acquittedby a Manhattan jury in Wife's 1977 Death
description: Dr. Arsenio Favor, a surgeon tried for the second time on charges that he murdered his wife, was found not guilty yesterday by a State Supreme Court jury in Manhattan.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: It's true that blind people have trouble finding apartments [A House for the Blind, Feb. 25], but for persons using wheelchairs finding suitable living accommodations is almost impossible.

title: Clubhouse Access: Reaction Is Mixed
description: Melissa Ludtke Lincoln, the reporter for Sports Illustrated, wrote this page (Locker Rooms: Equality With Integrity, April 15) that editors who assign female journalists to the clubhouse merely to report on environment are engaging in a ludicrous approach. Yet, such was my assignment on April 5, opening day of the baseball season at Boston's Fenwav Park.

title: Troy AT A GLANCE
description: In 1609 a longboat from Henry Hudson's Half Moon explored as far north as the plains of Troy. The area was included as part of a patroonship granted by the Dutch West India Company to Kiliaen Van Rensselaer shortly thereafter, and it remained farmland until 1786, when it was laid out as a city. It was given the name Troy three years later. As the center of river and barge traffic in the early 1800's, Troy thrived as a major steel and manufacturing center until Andrew Carnegie started his steel mill in Pittsburgh in 1873. The detachable collar for men's shirts was invented in Troy in 1825 and since then the city has been a major producer of men's shirts, with the sobriquet The Collar City.

title: Calendars
description: Today  Eastern Motor Racing Association relay race, at Bridgehampton Race Circuit. Registration: 9 A.M.; race P.M.

title: Joan Vanderbeck Married to Michael Taylor
description: Joan Diane Vanderbeck and Michael Scallon Taylor were married yesterday in the clubhouse of the Junior League of New York. The Rev. Gary F. Glogg of the Epiphany Anglican Church in Ozone Park, Queens, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: The New York Times / Paul Hosefros
description: SPRING STROLL DOWN BOULEVARD IN BLOOM: Two visitors to Brooklyn Botanic Garden lingered for closer look and savored the aroma of the blossoms of one of many Japanese cherry trees in full bloom there yesterday. Temperatures reached upper 60's under sunny skies yesterday. Today is expected to be mild and partly sunny.

title: Janet Ann Hobbs Is Married
description: Janet Ann Hobbs, a book designer for Allyne & Bacon, publishers in Boston, was married yesterday to John R. Hixson, a transportation planner for Cambridge, Mass. The ceremony was performed in St. James's Episcopal Church in Cambridge by the rector, the Rev. Russell Way. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Hobbs of Worcester, Mass. Her husband's parents are Mrs. John Brand of Carmel, N.Y., and Joseph R. Hixson of Milan, N.Y.

title: Notes: Suggestions for the Summer Vacationer
description: With the peak summer travel season just around the corner, vacationers will find the tourist calendar chock full of fascinating things to do in the months ahead. Here are some that you might not have thought of.

title: Pick One: S.A.T. Coaching Is [Is Not] Fair to Students; Eduration; Students are coached for the Law Aptitude Test.
description: In Stanley H. Kaplan's Manhattan office is a map of the United States with 84 pins marking the locations of the centers Mr. Kaplan has established coach students preparing to jump the hurdles of the Scholastic Aptitude Test, the Medical College Admissions Test, the Law School Admissions Test and other obstacles to the good life.

title: Cardinals Bypassed as Delegates To 80 Synod of Bishops in Rome
description: CHICAGO, May 3  For the first time since the international Synod of Bishops was begun in 1967, no cardinals will represent the Roman Catholic Church in the United States at next year's mieeting in Rome.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Kenneth Rinker, a former dancer with Twyla Tharp's company, won critical acclaim as a choreographer with his Forty Second / 42d Street Variations, which had its premiere at the American Theater Laboratory in March  The Times's Jenniter Dunning described the piece as a richly inventive, multilayered hour of dance  unfailingly witty. The work, which revolves around members of a chorus line in a Broadway rehearsal room, with Mr. Rinker as their frenetic director, has an original score by Sergio Cervetti taking off from the Al Dubin and Henry Warren song from Busby Berkeley's 1933 film. 42d Street returns to the American Theater Laboratory for a special fiveday engagement starting Thursday. (See Dance)

title: HOME CLINIC
description: NOW THAT the heating season is behind us for a few months, most homeowners stop thinking about the need for adding the extra insulation that the house may still need.the plaster on these walls before I repaper. It has been suggested that I squeegee a joint cement over the surface. Is this of any value, or is there some other way that I can strengthen the wall surfaces?  S.B., Mountain Lakes, N.J.

title: Lilco Expects Larger Rate Increase
description: CUSTOMERS of the Long Island Lighting Company have been spared an immediate 18.5 percent increase in electricity bills, but the victory may prove to be a hollow one because, Lilco says, the increase will have to come later and, when it does, it will be even larger.

title: Unlikely Heroines
description: ANJO is a 34yearold woman with an I.Q. of 30. A victim of Down's syndrome, she has lived all her life with her parents, who are now aging and in poor health, flattened by the daily catas. trophes of losing Sanjo on shopping trips, strug.

title: Recommendations Last Week Had Two Aims: Concessions but Control
description: CAPE TOWN  For South African blacks, there is no easy path to freedom. When nationalist leader Nelson Mandela coined that phrase nearly 20 years ago, most militants envisioned the overthrow of white rule within their lifetimes. Today, Mr. Mandela and many of his associates are growing old in jail and the prospect of their followers seizing power seems remote.

title: THE CITY'S MOST EXCLUSIVE CLUB
description: The unprepossessing l0story building at 30 West 47th Street resembles its neighbors in most respects. Shop windows on the street level bristle with diamonds, and the sidewalk in front is alive with the mysterious trading of diamond dealers, many of them Hasidic Jews. Yet this drab structure that blends so comfortably into the grimy trappings of the Street is the home of one of the most powerful, exclusive and compulsively secretive clubs in the world, the Diamond Dealers Club.

title: A Tiny, Remote Island Spawns Dynasties of Greek Shipowners
description: OINOUSA, Greece  This tiny, remote Greek island, about the size of Central Park, lies in the Aegean within swimming distance of Turkey. It has produced half a dozen great shipping clans, numbering about 30 millionaire shipping families. The largest merchant fleet in the world, 45 million tons, is in the hands of Greeks, and a quarter of those Greeks are Oinousans.

title: PartTime Jobs For Teenagers Are in Demand
description: Before the school year began, Dennis Taylor, a Bushwick High School senior, was considering a career as a lawyer. Now, after working part time in a Man hattan law firm, he is certain of his plans.

title: Westchester Resists
description: WESTCHESTER County officials fired the latest salvo in a border war with Connecticut last week, contending that Hartford's sofar successful pressure to have Albany set stiffer pollution regulations for Westchester waters that flow across the state boundary would have an adverse economic impact on the county's northern communities.

title: PRISON STRIKE ENDS; GUARDSMEN CO HOME
description: Thousandg of National Guardsmen who had been on temporary emergency duty inside Nei,/ York State prisons withdrew yesterday ahead of schedule, as correction officers who had been on a 17day strike returned to work after ratifying a new threeyear contract.

title: Margaret McColgan Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McColgan of Maplewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Mary McColgan, to John Hamilton Martinson of Ringwood, N.J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond A. Martinson of Wyckoff, N.J. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Editors' Choice
description: DUBIN'S LIVES, by Bernard Malarnud. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.) Winter brings discontent and temptation to a biographer of D. H. Lawrence in a realistic, risktaking novel.

title: The Nation
description: Uncertainty seemed last week to have become a leading byproduct of nuclear power, affecting not only public bombarded with sometimes conflicting data on radiation hazards, but also those who produce the data.

title: ART
description: HEMPSTEAD ALTHOUGH the 20th century has broadened our artistic vision, it has also limited it. Its disproportionate emphasis on an artforart'ssake attitude has amplified our appreciation of art as an esthetic experience, but lessened our appreciation of art as a cultural embodiment. We seek out the formal beauties of art with more facility and understanding, but pay considerably less attention to the climate that fostered the creation of the art work.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: It takes the Boston Women's Health Book Collective a while to turn out a new volume, but the group's patience seems to pay off: Both of its books have quickly become best sellers on the trade paperback list: The collective's first book.

title: Gregory Museum Earth Science Center in Hicksville Is Looking for Someone to Help Keep It Operating
description: HICKSVILLE, L.I.  On the eve of its 15th anniversary, the financially strapped Gregory Museum, the Long Island Earth Science Center, is looking for somebody to keep it going.

title: Topics At What Age?; A Special Case
description: In his performance as Watergate Special Prosecutor  and even in his ditmissal by Richard Nixon  Archibald Cox personified public rectitude. In his performafice in the 1960's as the Solicitor General, the Federal Government's chief appellate lawyer, he personified wise public policy and legal skill. He would be, many people have long thought, the ideal Federal appellate, judge. And now he has been propoSed to fill a new position on the United States Court of Appeals in New England. Indeed, he is the unanimous first choice of the commission appointed to recommend candidates. And yet months have gone by; the Department of Justice still won't act on the recommendation. He is, the department believes, too old.

title: Fear of Domino Effect in Public
description: PLAINVIEW FEAR that their homes will decrease in value, with a growing sentiment that their community has become a dumping ground for public facilities, has led a group of residents to protest the selection of Plainview as the site for a Planned lowincome housing oroiect.

title: Westchester/ ThisWeek
description: ELMSFORD  Funny Girl. Tonight and Tuesday through next Sunday. Opens 6:15, buffet at 7, show at 8:30. Sundays one hour earlier. $18.15 to $20.35. Reservations. An Evening Dinner Theater, 11 Clearbrook Rd. 592.

title: Wittner New Pace Coach
description: Stu Wittner, 23 years old, has been named the head basketball coach at Pace University, replacing Gene Westmoreland. In eight years at Pace, Westmoreland compiled an 8594 wonlost record. Last season, when Wittner was an assistant coach, the record was 1115.

title: Paring Prices, Naming Names
description: For months now President Carter and his inflation fighters have been promising to start embarrassing companies that ignore the Administration's voluntary guidelines in setting new prices. Last week, with inflationary pressure as strong as ever, they finally did so.

title: Wendy Burch Becomes Bride In Wilton of Michael Jackson
description: Sarah Wendelin Burch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Kent Burch of Wilton, Conn., was married there yesterday to Michael Earl Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Virgil Luther Jackson of Newport News, Va. The ceremony was performed in the Wilton Congregational Church by the Rev. Zdenek F. Bednar.

title: In His Broadway Debut, Director Has Smash Hit
description: Jack Hofsiss is 28 years old, darkly handsome, somewhat intense and, in his first time out on Broadway as a director, he has a smash hit in The Elephant Man, a new play with 21 scenes that could easily be a director's despair were it not, as in this case, a director's delight.

title: What They're Saying
description: Wilt Chamberlain, at his induction into the Basketball Hall of Fame Springfield, Mass.: I feel I wouldn't have been a great basketball player if I hadn't been brought up in Philadelphia.

title: Gasoline: Long, Dry Summer?
description: A shortage of gasoline, threatening since the Iranian revolution, has finally reached the gas pumps. Many service stations are limiting sales to something less than a tankful and others are closing on weekends. In California, where lines at service stations have been lengthening, the state announced an emergency plan under which counties could limit motorists to gasoline sales on alternate days.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Fears of escalating interest rates and uncertainties about the future course of the economy burdened Wall Street last week. The American Stock Exchange's market value index, marching to its own drummer, reached a new high. But the Dow Jones industrials, weakening Friday, fell 9.10 points for the week to 847.54. its lowest close since March 15.

title: Birthdays: Sunday Afternoon Fever
description: Lisa Schottenfeld turned 8 years old last Sunday and of course she had a party. This year, she didn't wear her pastel party dress and Mary Janes; she had a very sophisticated black number with sequins around the neck and a skirt that was all fringe. Her friend, Alison Friedman, came in an orchid camisole with jeweled straps and a slinky skirt and with her long lashes beautifully mascaraed. If you're discoing at New YorkNew York, you pester your mother for something grownup just this once.

title: Troy Gets New Shopping Mall as It Tries to Halt Decline
description: TROY, N.Y. Ten years after it was first proposed, the Uncle Sam Atrium, a redbrick and glass shopping mall with a large, skylighted, terraced interior, has just opened in the heart of downtown Troy, filling a cityblocksize hole that had been there for years.

title: Country Club Fights Conversion to a Jail
description: WOODBURY THE Woodbury Country Club, this city's upperregister social institution, was a place where serenity prevailed from its founding in 1897 until just a few weeks am.

title: Lafleur Paces 51 Rout of Bruins
description: MONTREAL, May 5  The Montreal Canadiens looked like the Canadiens of old tonight in the Forum as, led by Guy Lafleur's two goals within a 25second span of the first period, they routed the Boston Bruins, 51, before a crowd of 17,593 fans.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: 249 in Primary Races
description: TRENTON AN ACTIVE but relatively noncombative primary election for 80 State Assembly seats will be held June 5, with  at last count 199 Republican and Democratic candidates, plus 50 independents, in the 40 legislative district contests.

title: Fidrych Starts, Goes 4 Innings
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 5 (UPI)  Mark Fidrych allowed four hits and two runs over four innings in his first appearance in more than a year and Rusty Staub drove in three runs with a pair of doubles today as the Detroit Tigers scored an 89 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: Dance: City Ballet Offers 'Agon,' 'Concerto Barocco'
description: Ask dancegoers to list their favorite works by George Balanchine and many will surely name Concerto Barocco and Agora, two of the three ballets by Mr. Balanchine presented Friday night by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater. Each in its own way is as near perfection as ballet can be in this imperfect world.

title: CRIME
description: Most of the action in THE EIGHTH DWARF by Ross Thomas (Simon and Schuster, $9.95) takes place in Germany, but this is not the fairytale Germany of Snow White and the seven dwarfs. It is the battered, desperate Germany just after World War II: the Germany in which a carton of cigarettes means wealth, where Nazis are burrowing underground and hiding, where intelligence services jockey for position.

title: Writers Are Boning Up on Laverne and Shirley 101
description: Television is using up so much'inaterial these days in the scramble for ratings that even the Olythpicsized pool of scriptwriters in Hollywood is becoming insufficient. In pioneering move to tap more of the creative potential of the East, Columbia Pictures Television has been holding free classes at its midManhattan screening room to teach professional New York writers the art of the situationcomedy halfhour, the actionadventure hour, the madeforTV movie and the miniseries. Quipsters in the class have called it Laverne and Shirley 101, but take it dead seriously. There were 400 requests for admission to the first series of eight classes that ended in early March, and places for only 76. The rejected were so disappointed that a new cycle of classes has been scheduled for consecutive Wednesdays from 6 to 8 P.M., beginning this week.

title: A New Type of Magnolia Is Born
description: WITH winter's retreat and the gradual northward advance of spring through Westchester's hills and plains, comes the spectacle of the county's famous flowering trees  cherry, apple, dogwood and, earliest of all, the magnolia. This ancient tree has already begun to decorate the county's landscape with white and purple blossoms, but few magnolia species can evoke a sense of vernal wonder as much as a new hybrid recently propogated by scientists at the Kitchawan Research Station in Ossining.

title: A New Orient Express Goes Out to Hong Kong
description: LONDON (AP)  Passengers for Paris, Berlin, Warsaw, Moscow, Irkutsk, Peking, Nanking, Shanghai, Canton and Hong Kong; please go to Platform 1.

title: CASES ARE LAID OUT IN LUFTHANSA TRIAL
description: The Lufthansa cargo agent accused of having been the inside man in the $5.8 million robbery of the airline's cargo building last December admitted a role in the robbery to three persons, according to the prosecutor in the case.

title: Don't Surrender And Other Tips for Island's Growth
description: IGREW up on Long Island when inflation was 2 percent, unemployment 4 percent, mortgage rates 5 percent and the voting age 21. Today only one of those numbers is lower, and about the only thipg that is still 5 percent is the weekly increase in easoline prices.

title: More Proof: Each Vote Counts
description: ANYONE of voting age is familiar with political campaign efforts that intensify as an Election Day approaches. For time, we seem besieged by political messages extolling the virtues of particular candidate, reciting the shortcomings of the opponent, and reminding us that every vote counts.

title: CORRECTION
description: In The Times last Sunday, a photograph of William J. Stack, a lawyer in New Jersey for the Exxon Corporation, was wrongly identified as a picture of William J. Stack Jr., the Atlanta lawyer quoted in the accompanying article on President Carter's 1976 campaign.

title: Plan to Close Ft. Dix Spawns New Protest
description: WASHINGTON T'E Army's plan to close its basictraining center at Fort Dix magnifies a regional bias in Department of Defense policy that already costs New Jersey hundreds of millions of dollars a year, according to a new protest by members of Congress from the Northeast and Middle West.

title: Bronfmans, Brascan, Woolworth (Cont)
description: For the sake of clarity, imagine four companies, A, B, C, and D.

title: Rub Softly On a Cheek
description: Facial hair can mean many things: it is often necessary for acceptance and status in a social group; it may signify identification with role models and leaders; or it may symbolically be used to reject the status quo.

title: Cleveland's City Council Weighs Bill to Limit Commercial Fishing
description: CLEVELAND. May 5  Members of the Cleveland Police Department's Harbor Patrol may have some new duties this summer  keeping commercial fishing boats away from the Lake Erie shore.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Susan Teicher, a young pianist with bachelor's and master's degrees from Juilliard, made her New York recital debut last Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The program consisted of Beethoven's Sonata No. 7 in D (Op. 10, No. 3), Bartok's Sonata and Schumann's Kreisleriana.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Stephen Garnett keeps his pets in the bedroom. Nothing unusual about that, except that his pets are snakes 18 of them. Mr. Garnett is an officer of the New York Herpetological Society, and with his father, Gordon, he has traveled all over Westchester in behalf of his hobby and the much maligned reptile species.

title: Ann Fernandez Bride of Jacques R. Wiegert
description: Margaret Ann Somerville Fernandez, daughter of Mollie D. Somerville of Washington and James William Somerville of Alexandria, Va., and Center Harbor, N.H., was married yesterday morning to Jacques Raymond Wieeert. He is the son of Mrs. Rene LeBas of Nice, France, and the late Isidore Leon Wiegert of Turkheim, France.

title: Food
description: One of the most remarkable, refined and eminently edible sauces in the entire French repertory is also one of the easiest to prepare. It is beurre blanc, or butter sauce, a simple, noble creation to grace poached lobsters, baked oysters, poached fish and grilled prawns or shrimp.

title: Health Center Links Most Tornado Deaths to Cars
description: ATLANTA. May 5 (AP)  Residents of Wichita Falls, Tex., who took to their cars to escape a series of tornadoes last month would have been safer to seek shelter indoors, according to the Center for Disease Control.

title: ART
description: MONTCLAIR COLLAGE has become such an integral part of the art scene that we take it for granted as an art form. And yet it is not very old, having made its appearance in a serious way only in the early decades of this century.

title: Consumers to Pay for Shutdown
description: AUGUSTA, Me., May 5 (AP)  The state Public Utilities Commission ruled tonight that utilities can pass on to consumers the cost of a safetyshutdcnvn of the Maine Yankee nuclear power plant. The utilities were ordered to spread out the charges over a 12month period in billing consumers for replacement fuel, mainly for oilfired generators.

title: Ribicoff Packs It In, After 40 Years
description: Senator Abraham A. Ribicoft of Connecticut was once asked to name the most important thing in politics. Luck, he replied. Being at the right place at the right time.

title: Asian Nations Tourist Facilities Strained by Boom
description: SINGAPORE, May 5  After waiting in lines for two hours to get out of Muang Airport at Bangkok a week ago, an Australian businessman arrived in Singapore without a hotel reservation. He said he phoned eight hotels and found them all full, so he flew on to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, for the weekend. Arriving again on Monday, he found a room  for Wednesday. In the meantime he stayed with friends.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Anyone who wants to think well of our city and can't for the moment think of a good reason should go once to the NewYork Historical Society and stay there till closing time. It will be a day well spent delightful surroundings and among people who have a great deal to show and are happy to share it with others. By 5 P.M. we are convinced that New York has past to be proud of, a present that has its mitigating features, and a future that is worth working for.

title: Nancy Lynn Parssinen, Wed to Michael Vespoli
description: Nancy Lynn Parssinen, daughter of Claire B. Parssinen of Westerly. R.I., was married yesterday in the Weekapaug (R.I.) Chapel to Michael L. Vespoli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Vespoli of Orange, Conn. The Rev. George K. Dreher of the Mystic (Conn.) Congregational Church performed the ceremony.

title: Ideas Were
description: For me, iarold's death was the conclusion of a series, which began with Heinrich Bluecher, went on with Philip Rahv, Nicola Chiaromonte, Edmund Wilson, Hannah Arendt, and finishes with him. He was the last tall pine in the forest to go down. There is no tree left standing in that noble array to look up to or mourn for; the axe has fallen on a generation, mine, of intellectuals and bold thinkers; consummatum est. And reviewing the scene through the present flat perspective, I cannot help feeling that in those days there were giants in the earth.

title: EFFECT OF CRITICISM ON JUDGES ASSESSED
description: Civil libertarians and some criminal defense lawyers say that attacks by elected officials on Judge Bruce McM. Wright of Criminal Courtand a subsequent controversy over a sentencing offer made by another judge  may have a chilling effect on the entire judiciary, in the words of one lawyer.

title: Hale Woodruff Looks Back on Lifetime of Painting
description: Hale A. Woodruff, who at the age of 79 is one of America's oldest living black artists, says that, when he was coming up, there was no such thing as a black esthetic.

title: Lisa Beth Wahl Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Lisa Beth Wahl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Wahl of New York, to Michael I. Rosenstock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Rosenstock, son of Ellenville, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents. Miss Wahl, an alumna of George Washington University, received a master's in child development from Yeshiva University. Her fianc graduated from the University of Florida.

title: Corsaro Weighs In With a New Play
description: Earlier this season, the successful revival of Whoopee!, the madcap 1928 musical set on dude ranch in Arizona, opened at the ANTA Theater. Tonight, Knockout, a new boxing drama by Louis La Russo 2d, set in a brokendown gymnasium in Hoboken in 1948, opens at the Helen Hayes. These thoroughly dissimilar theatrical properties have one thing in common: They were both staged by the same man, Frank Corsaro, a director whose name in recent years has been linked primarily  and sometimes sensationally  with opera.

title: House Committee Approves Use Of Mirex Pesticide on Fire Ants
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)  A week after the Environmental Protection Agency approved use of another chemical against fire ants, the House Agriculture Committee has adopted a bill that would lift a ban on the pesticide Mires that farmers apparently prefer.

title: Caldwell Sets Sights On a New Firehouse
description: CALDWELL TWICE a week like clockwork, and several more times a week with something less than clockwork, Richard Cannone yanks the gasoline hoses out of his customers tanks and orders the cars out of his Gulf station at Roseland and Westville Avenues.

title: Lynne M. Dryzga Wed to Keith Venn
description: The marriage of Lynne Marie Dryzga, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Dryzga of Bogota, N.J., and Oxford, Me., to Keith Edward Venn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Venn of Loughton, England, took place yesterday at the Inwood Manor in Teaneck, N.J. Mayor Eugene Brophy of Bogota performed the ceremony.

title: A Keyhole View of St. Peter's
description: To the Editor: John Ferris's article on the Spanish Steps entitled A Contemplator on the Steps of Rome (Travel Section, April 8) brought to mind our visit to the nearby Sovrano Militare Ordine di Malta, one of the most fascinating institutions in Rome.

title: Indictment in Miami Depicts Rise and Fall of NarcoticsSmuggling Gang
description: MIAMI, May 5  Early one morning about two years ago, the owner of a fortresslike suburban home here was awakened by a telephone c,all. Look out of the window, said the caller, who did not identify himself. Do you see a helicopter hovering around? Aboard there is a 50gallon drum of gasoline and a fuse. If you and your family don't want to fry, you'd better come to terms with youknowwho. You have 30 seconds to decide.

title: Ecuador Goes Civilian and More Prepare To Follow
description: QUITO, Ecuador The military in this tiny nation took a significant step in its planned retreat from governmental responsibility last week and earned the right to head up the column of brass hats in eight countries who are heading back to the barracks.

title: Siting Nuclear Reactors Once Seemed Simple and Safe
description: WASHINGTON  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, as part of its legal responsibility to ensure the safe operation of nuclear reactors, has final authority over where reactors may be located. Yet in the last 20 years, utility companies have so often been permitted to build nuclear plants in heavily populated areas that more than million Americans now live within 30 miles of a reactor, and 10 million live within 20 miles.

title: A FatherSons Canoe Trip on the Saco
description: Four days in a canoe with your teenage sons could produce either of these results: It could persuade you that adolescent boys are irresponsible monsters who belong military school, and it could persuade them that your grouchiness is amphibious. Or it could remind all of you that the love you share for clear water, quiet camp fires, shootJig stars and each other will be around long after adolescent battles are over.

title: Fadden The Everywhere Dress
description: The American woman who has little patience with clothes unless they are comfortable, need minimum care, and, preferably, have more than one function, is always on the lookout for a dress to suit her requirements.

title: Where the Youngsters Step Out
description: New YorkNew York  A special musical show (Discoella) on Saturday and Sunday afternoon makes this a favorite birthday party spot. Lunch (hamburgers, french fries and soda) is served at noon, show from 1 to 2 P.M., dancing from 3 to 5 P.M. Charge for all three is $11.20; show and dancing only, $7.95; dancing only, 35.95 (fees apply to both children and adults). Reservations are necessary. Call 7598207. The address is 33 West 52d Street.

title: How New Jersey Merged Its Statehood
description: NOT too many of us in New Jersey realize that our lives as well as the lives of New York and Connecticut residents  are directly affected by a superstructure body called the Tristate Regional Planning Commission.

title: Dr. Margery Buck, Dr. Robert Brenner Plan June 30 Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Calvin Buck of Morristown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Margery Buck to Dr. Robert Roland Brenner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Angus LeJaren Brenner of Rydal, Pa., and Melvin Village. N.H.

title: Baseball at Seton Hall Is a Family Affair
description: SOUTH ORANGE THEY will converge from all corners of the state, filled with fond memories and nostalgia. They will be older and a little slower, but just as enthusiastic as they were when they played years earlier.

title: Motorists Vent Anger On Higher Gas Prices In Hot Line to Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  American motorists are sending a message to Washington 500 times a day and, boiled down, it says: We're mad as blazes and we won't take it any more.

title: McEnroe Is at Peak For Duel With Borg
description: DALLAS, May 5  Overflowing with confidence, 20yearold John McEnroe of Douglaston, Queens, will play the second major tournament final of his career tomorrow, knowing he has solid chance of beating No. 1ranked Bjorn Borg.

title: MUSIC
description: HEARD any good sheitholts lately? Would you put a serpent in your mouth?
