Frederick Philipse, the wealthy Dutch landlord of Philipsburg Manor, and most of his cultured friends in the 18th century might very well have said yes to both questions, since the scheitholt is a zitherlike instrument popularized by the Pennsylvania Dutch settlers, and the serpent, musicologically speaking, is a kind of bass cornet, a military instrument of the 18th century so named because of its twisting shape. Unfortunately (for him), Meinheer Philipse bet on the wrong side in the American Revolution, and like many another Tory in those difficult days, saw his lands confiscated and was exiled to England. Fortunately (for us), some of the buildings on his 90,000acre estate are still maintained as living museums of history and art.

title: Brass Plate of Drake Called Probable Hoax
description: BERKELEY, Calif., May 6 (AP)The famous Plate of Brass, once accepted as proof that Sir Francis Drake visited near San Francisco 400 years ago, is probably bogus, according to a publication of the University a Calilornia Bancroft Library.

title: TREASURE FROM THE KREMLIN
description: Just once in a while there is an exhibition whose title has exotic and sinister overtones. Such an exhibition is Treasures From the Kremlin, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art from May 19 through Sept. 2.

title: Other Ideas & Trends
description: Ten years ago, abortion was the most common method of birth control. Last week the Population Crisis Committee reported that the method had dropped to third place, after sterilization and the pill. But on the average, one of every four pregnancies around the world is still terminated by abortion. The rate is even higher  more than 1 in 2  in Austria, Italy, Japan, Portugal, the Soviet Union and Uruguay, where the most effective methods of contraception are not generally available. In all, 40 million abortions are performed every year, more than half of them illegally.

title: U.S. Official Will Fly To Turkey to Discuss Economy and Unrest
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher will fly to Ankara tomorrow for two days of discussions with Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit and other Turkish officials, the State Department announced today.

title: House Agrees, by a 236.18 Vote, To Preservation of Alaska Lands
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI)  The House voted tentatively yesterday to preserve more than 100 million acres of still untouched Alaskan lands for future generations but put off a decision over exactly which lands would be included.

title: Koch Sees No Possibility Of Losing $300 Million
description: A threat by Washington to withhold $300 million in revenuesharing funds from Mew York City was termed unjustified yesterday by Mayor Koch, who said there was no real possibility that the city would ultimately lose the money.

title: HardLine Arabs Fear Soviet Is Wavering on Mideast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 5  Concern is growing among some Arabs over what they regard as equivocal Soviet policy in the Middle East since Egypt and Israel signed a peace treaty in March.

title: Music: The Contiguglias, Duo Pianists
description: John and Richard Contiguglia, the excellent two piano team, closed off the ConcertParty series at the new St. Peter's Church on Friday night with a generally pleasing program of works for two pianos that almost miraculously contained not one single hack transcription.

title: 6 ExPolicewomen Win $100,000 In Suit Challenging Boise Firings
description: BOISE, Idaho, May 6 (AP)  Six former Boise policewomen dismissed by the city in 1977 for alleged homosexual activity have been awarded more than $103,000 in back pay, tax payments and attorneys fees.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Time trials for the Indianapolis 500 will be held Saturday at Indianapolis Speedway to determine the pole position for the May 27 race.

title: POLITICS
description: I T is a riddle, wrapped in a mystery, inside an enigma, said Winston Churchill in 1939 of the apparent uncertainty of Soviet help for the Allies on the eve of World War II. The oftrepeated observation had a local application last week as a judge pondered the strictly legal riddle of what is done in the case of a tie vote in the April 24 village trustee elections in Port Chester and the mystery of the validity of a particular absentee ballot that could break that tie.

title: The Best Of the Beans
description: There is an old song with words to the effect that the Navy gets the gravy but the Army gets the beans. Considering the enormous variety of beans  from limas to soys to garbanzos to all of the green and wax beans  and their tremendous nutritional value, the Army got much the better deal!

title: At Home: A Store Is a Memory Bank
description: ASTORE failed in our town and my wife and I were shocked and saddened. The signs in the store's windows announcing bank sale affected us like handwriting on the wall.

title: Fashion View American Designers Come of Age
description: The fashion business and show business have more than a few things in common. They are full of richness and pageantry, giving even the casual viewer something interesting to watch. They're each a gambier's business; everyone takes a risk, every time out, with the hope that the public will likeand buy  the product. There is big money involved. It can cost more to produce a fashion collection than to mount a musical and, if a collection is a success, it makes a large return on investment. Flops can be professionally fatal. Both depend on creative people and sell that ephemeral quality called talent; the result is that  even for seasoned professionals  a performance can be brilliant, controversial, uneven, merely competent or, alas, inadequate. Occasionally, there is a heartwarming comeback, and there are always talented newcomers on the way up.

title: Lydia Snel, Student, And John Brenner Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. Herbert Snel of Reston, Va., formerly of Amersfoort, the Netherlands, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lydia Snel, to John Finn Brenner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore E. Brenner of Rumson. N.J.

title: A Different Death Squad Haunts Iran
description: Anger of God Comes Out Of The Rifle Barrel, proclaims a banner at an automobile factory outside Teheran. Since the revolution, most of that righteous revenge has been aimed by the new Islamic authorities against helpmates of the Shah. Now it appears that the mullahs and ayatollahs have rival for the role of Islamic executioner and the target is them.

title: Rangers Beat Islanders by 43, Lead Series
description: UNIONDALE; LI., May 5  The swarming Rangers and their $600,000ayear import, Anders Hedberg, moved one step closer to making plane reservations for a Stanley Cup final series by halting the Islanders, 43, tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Mabel Coyle and Lee Gerkin, Bankers, Wed
description: Mabel Brady Coyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Coyle of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Lee Merrill Gerkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Merrill C. Gerkin of Santa Fe, N.M. The ceremony was performed in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Vincent O'Connor of Riverside, Conn.

title: The Renaissance Sculptor for Roosevelt Memorial
description: VENICE, Calif.  The young nude model revolves on an electric turntable as the sculptor Robert Graham shoots away with a video camera. He catches her in a variety of views and poses front, side, threequarters, hand on hip and stretching her arms behind her. And later he plays the finished tape for a visitor with an exultant air of discovery.

title: Compost Ring for Tomatoes
description: Afew years ago, a neighbor returned from a Florida vacation with a fascinating tale of a backyard gardener who had harvested over 200 pounds of tomatoes from four plants. thought he was exaggerating.

title: Design
description: Ward Bennett is something of an anachronism  he is not a furniture designer or an interior designer or an industrial designer or a product designer, but has chosen, despite this age of specialization, to be all of these things. He Still spare, Ward Bennett's recent renovation of his Dakota gable is more soft and sensual. brings a similar esthetic to a remarkably varied body of work, ranging from apartment interiors to chairs to silverware, in what could be described as a search to simplify traditional design.

title: SOCIALISTS IN ITALY SEEKING NEW IMAGE
description: ROME, May 5  The campaign for Italy's national elections on June 3 and is featuring a new theme, a new symbol and a new protagonist.

title: The Region; In Summary; Prison Guards Back on the Job, Cautiously; Three New Faces On Utility Authority; Odds Grow Longer On N.Y. Casinos; Atlantic City Infiltrated?; Age of Consent To Stay at 16 in N.J.; Murdoch Reveals An Old Talent
description: Six thousand prison guards returned to work last week  only to face disgruntled prisoners who had behaved like pussycats during the 16day walkout. The inmates tried to prove that the prisons of New York State were better without the oldline guards and, to a man, in 28 institutions, they acted like model citizens under the interim control of 7,000 National Guardsmen.The Carey Administration will retain some Guardsmen to keep the prisoners, the guards and their nonstriking colleagues from each others throats. In addition, Corrections Commissioner Richard D. Hongisto has emergency power to reassign guards to less explosive posts.

title: MARGARET THATCHER NAMES HER CABINET; A BALANCE OF PARTY
description: LONDON, May 5  On her first full day in office, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher named a Cabinet today that is carefully balanced between rightwingers like herself and moderates.

title: HELP FOR ARTHRITICS BY INDUSTRY SOUGHT
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 4  Improved industrial health programs could make work more productive and less painful for many among the millions of American workers suffering from arthritis and could benefit their employers as well, experts said at a symposium here.

title: Alicia Mary Haines Betrothed
description: Mrs. Charles Haines of Manhasset, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Alicia Mary Haines, to Lawrence J. Ragonese, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sebastian Ragonese of West Milford, N.J. The future bride is the daughter also of the late Mr. Haines. A wedding is planned for September.

title: Where They Are
description: At the 48 sites described below are the 70 licensed nuclear reactors used commercially generate electricity. Where there Is more than one reactor at a given site, at Indian Point for ample, the number is shown in parenthesis next to the name of the plant. The name of the town given underneath the site is the nearest settlement, regardless of population.

title: Scything the Meadow at 95
description: IF one were to pick a single person to represent the counterculture, it would not be a young Californian living in a hollow redwood tree, or a Columbia dropout now part of an urban commune. It would be a 95yearold man named Scott Nearing. But one would immediately have to add his wife, Helen, who is still under 80. The two of them joined, almost founded the counterculture a little under 50 years ago. He, at least, was already at an age when most people are starting to take things easy.

title: Miss Buechner Becomes Bride Of J.W. Mullen
description: Katherine Ann Buechner. daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Frederick Buechner of Rupert, Vt., was married at her home yesterday afternoon to John W. Mullen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Mullen of San Diego. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Hal C. Miller, minister of the United Church of Christ in Dorset, Vt.

title: Racial Violence Again a Threat To Sri Lankans
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  Racial violence again threatens the seeming serenity of this beautiful island.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: So goes the riddle that handsome Prince Tuzn must solve if he is to win the hand of the daughter of the king of Tizapn.

title: LivePerformance
description: The Massenet revival continues. Presently at hand are the first complete recordings of Cendrillon and Le Jongleur de NotreDame, joining Manon, Thais, Werther,

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: A FEW weeks ago three separate moving trucks drew up at the Victorian home of Marguerite and Paul Burnham, an elderly New Haven couple. One truck was to head for their new apartment in the nearby Whitney Center for the aging. Another truck would take excess, yet stillcherished, family possessions back to the original Burnham family home In Massachusetts. A third truckload was destined for auction.

title: Meet Jane Bull
description: LONDONA panel of voters interviewed after Thursday's general election ranked no foreign policy question among the five most important issues. But a whole spectrum of such questions lies before Margaret Thatcher this weekend as she settles into 10 Downing Street, where her portrait will soon hang alongside those of her male predecessors stretching back to Robert Walpole, who took office in 1721.

title: The Difference a Year Makes
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5  One year ago tomorrow, an 18year old apprentice jockey named Ronald Joseph Franklin sat in the home of Grover Delp in Laurel, Md., and watched on television while Alydar strove in vain to catch Affirmed in the Kentucky Derby. Three months earlier, Franklin had ridden the first race of his life on a mare named Pioneer Patty and she had won easily at Bowie. Things had none well for the kid since then, but Churchill Downs on the first Saturday in May is light years removed from the thickets of Maryland. On May 6, 1978, Ron couldn't have imagined where h would be on May 5. 1979.

title: Deaths
description: GRANDJANYGeorgette on May 3, 1919. Beloved wife of the late Mar. cel. Dear mother of Bernard. Sister of the late Emily Boulanger. Reposino at the Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W 72 St. Mass of Chrisfian Burial, Blessed Sacrament Church, Monday 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: At Home: A Bulwark Crumbles
description: FAIRFIELD ASTORE failed in our town and my wife and I were shocked and saddened. The signs. in the store's windows announcing bank sale affected us like handwriting on the wall.

title: Harvard: A RealLife Case Study
description: The Case of the Business School

title: Nancy Rees, Nurse, Philip Mark Read Engaged to Many
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest H. Rees of Vernon, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ann Rees, to Philip Mark Read, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Read 3d of Clifton.

title: Problems at Kent State Called Severe After 70
description: KENT, Ohio, May 5 (AP)  A Kent State University professor said yesterday that the financial problems that befell the school in the wake of the May 4, 1970, slaying of four students were so severe that it had been a struggle just to keen the university mine.

title: List of Candidates in the June 5 Primary
description: Following is a list of Assembly candidates, as compiled by The Associated Press. Incumbents are denoted by an asterisk (*).

title: IN THE NATION A Meat Ax Over Amtrak
description: Too little public attention is being paid to the fact that sometime this month Congress must decide whether to accede to Carter Administration proposals to cut Amtrak rail passenger service by 43 percent.

title: PUERTO RICAN FUND MARKS ITS VICTORIES
description: When Federal officials recently charged the city with discriminating against Hispanic welfare applicants and ordered immediate corrective measures, a small but influential organization marked another victory in its campaign to make the law meet the needs of the Hispanic community.

title: National Football League 1979 Draft
description: Don Smith, de, Miami; Pat Howell, op, Southern California; James Mayberry, rb, Colorado; William Andrews, rb, Auburn; Lynn Cain, rb, Southern California; Charles Johnson, db, Grambling; Mike Zele, dt, Kent State; Mike Moroski, qb, CalDavis; Roger Westiund, ot, WashIngtonl Dave Parkin, db, Utah State; Bruce Beekley, ib, Oregon; Bill Leer, c, Coloredo State; Stuart Walker, lb, Colorado.

title: High School Students Set Aside Their Books To Help Cornbat Fires
description: GRANITE FALLS, Wash. (AP) When the bell rings, seven Granite Falls high school students respond quickly. But instead of recess, the bell signals trouble in this community of 750 in western Washington.

title: F. C. C. to Decide On Easier Rules For Broadcasters
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  In its first attempt to relax regulatory control over the broadcasting industry, the Federal Communications Commission plans to make decision next week on proposals to allow radio stations in major markets to ignore many programming requirements.

title: Plans for GarbagetoFuel Plants Encounter Support and Skepticism
description: Borough and community leaders voiced support in some cases but concern in others in reaction to state and city plans to build plants in the Bronx and Brooklyn that would dispose of thousands of tons of garbage daily by converting it to energy.

title: MUSIC
description: ACOUPLE of weeks ago, I ran into Hugh Ross, the eminent choral conductor, who was bursting with excitement about a concert that will bring full circle a project he helped start nearly 90 years ago.

title: DINING OUT
description: EVIEWING Chinese restaurants is as chancy as I Ching. Each year produces new crop of restaurants and new hope for the Chinese enthusiast. And yet, in a recent sampling of three new places within a 25mile area, found only one that was solidly good and two that were merely tpir.

title: NATO Mediterranean Exercise
description: NAPLES, May 5 (AP)  Eight nations will take part in a 12.day NATO military exercise in the Mediterranean starting next Saturday. The emphasis in the maneuvers will be on keeping naval corn. municatlon channels open. Units from Britain, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, Turkey and the United States will participate.

title: Associated Press
description: From Mystic to Washington: Solarheating system; made with the help of the Southwest Regional Vocational High School in Groton, is installed at the White House. Page 3.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: NEW YORK JEW, by Alfred Kazin. (Vintage, $4.95.) The literary critic who chronicled his early years in Walker in the City and Starting Out in the Thirties carries his story into the 1970's. He recalls his experiences as a college teacher and magazine editor, his relationships with great and neargreat cultural figures, his loves and marriages and his coming to terms with his own Jewish heritage. Our reviewer Mordecai Richter particularly relished the book's illuminating anecdotes  that should give pleasure to anyone interested in the literary history of our times.

title: Ways to Improve Transportation In New York at Low Cost Given
description: A nonprofit environmental group has proposed five ways to improve transportation in New York City without making large capital outlays.

title: Prior Disappointments
description: WASHINGTON  National health insurance was first was discussed as a serious political issue at the Bull Moose convention in 1912, but was never more than discussed until 1934, when President Franklin D. Roosevelt's Committee on Economic Security endorsed a compulsory national health program  in principle. The idea was dropped because of fears that its inclusion in the Social Security Act of 1935 would endanger passage of that landmark legislation.

title: Pope Names Cardinal As Presiding Official For Vote on Successor
description: ROME, May 5  Pope John Paul II today appointed Paolo Cardinal Bertoli, a prestigious pontifical diplomat, as Camerlengo, or chamberlain, of the Roman Catholic Church, the prelate who acts as interim head of the ecclesiastical government in the Vatican between the death of a pontiff and the election of his successor.

title: Around the World in 80 Dishes; What do both women do in their spare time? They cook.
description: EAST may be East and West West, but the twain actuallxdo meet frequently these days when the partners, of a new catering business, The Moveable Feast, get together to discuss menus.

title: South African Whites Pleased by the Victory Of Margaret Thatcher
description: CAPE TOWN, May 5  Outside the Conservative Party itself, the accession of Margaret Thatcher as Prime Minister of Britain has probably won its greatest acclaim among whites in southern Africa, who hope that the Thatcher Government will look more sympathetically on their problems than did the outgoing Labor administration.

title: The 5Foot Painting Had to Stay at Home
description: NORTHPORT WHEN she finished high school, Pamela Long Nolan was recalling the other day, she decided to study English in college instead of her first love, art, because she knew that would probably have led her to commercial art and, she said, I knew I couldn't work at someone's corn; mand.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: NOW THAT the heating season is behind us for a few months, most homeowners stop thinking about the need fOr adding the extra insulation that the house may still need.

title: South Korea Grants Paroles
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 5 (AP)Just over 1,000 exemplary prisoners were paroled this week in commemoration of Buddha's birthday. Among them are five serving life terms and five foe mer students convicted under President Park Chung Hee's emergency decree of. 1975 forbidding open opposition.

title: Lake Placid Facilities Plagued by Disputes
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y. May 5  Almost 10 months before the opening of the 1980 Winter Olympic Games here construction of new facilities is nearing completion, plagued by continuing controversy.

title: Alabama Auto Race Indicates Good Year
description: While other forms of bigleague auto racing are plagued by a variety of problems, the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing continues to ramble toward what is likely to be another banner season.

title: Sketches of the Men Margaret Thatcher Has Named to the Key Cabinet Posts in Britain
description: The 60yearold Home Secretary and Deputy Prime Minister is one of the most experienced Cabinet ministers and one of the bestknown faces in Parliament  His hulking figure and striking round face are a gift to cartoonists, and even his friends call him Oyster Eyes  He speaks in public like a commanding officer addressing recruits  Was rival of Mrs. Thatcher in the battle for party leadership in 1975 but since then has supported her  They have worked closely together, and in the Commons he was the party's spokesman on home affairs  He stands for tougher treatment of criminals but not for the reintroduction of capital punishment. The stunningly frightening fact is that today about half of all the burglaries are committed by people under the age of 16, he said recently  He entered the House of Commons in 1955 Held several junior ministerial posts and was majority leader in the House in 1972. That year, when direct rule from London was imposed on Northern Ireland, he was named Secretary for Northern Ireland. Later, he was Secretary for EmployFrom hisbounds of protocol he was instantly slapped down but with impeccable courtesy. seems he intends to apply controls on nonwhite immigration strictly and to stand firmly by the police in their efforts tocombat crime and disorder.

title: Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1,400 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: Nematode Rule Bugs Farmers
description: EAST End farmers and Federal and state officials have been fighting the golden nematode, considered to be the world's most serious potato pest, for more than four decades here in what has essentially been a cooperative effort. This spring, however, they are fighting one another, rather than the nematode.

title: Television This Week
description: Today 2 P.M. (7) 1901ITHE YEAR TIME CHANGED. A pictorial essay focusing on life in turnofthecentury America, including rarely seen film clips from that period; narrated by Alexander Scourby.

title: Star de Naskra Wins As Alydar is Second
description: Alydar, last year's perpetual runnerup to Affirmed, may be starting to think he was born to finish second. That was where he ended up yesterday as Star de Naskra won the 79th running of the Carter Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: Around the Nation
description: LIVERMORE, Calif., May 5  About 4,000 demonstrators gathered in intermit. tent rain today to urge that the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory be converted from nuclear weapons development to solar energy research.

title: Biological Musings
description: THE human body  both to our peril and our enlightenment  has been an inevitable source for analogy in our attempt to understand larger systems. We still speak of the body politic, and we nave not strayed so far as we like to think from ancient notions of the human body as a microcosm, a complete abridgement of the whole universe (macrocosm) a living emblem and hieroglyph of eternity and time as the German mystic Jakob Boehme wrote 1622.

title: A Trial for Cameras in the Courtroom
description: HACKENSACK WEARING a vested chocolatebrown suit and opennecked beige shirt, William Tomaras came to court here last Wednesday to defend himself against a murder charge. Sartorially, he seemed a satisfactory subject for the two newspaper photographers assigned to take pictures of him.

title: A Silver Lining in the Genes
description: MOST people would imagine that, on any given day, the possibility that something astounding and delightful will happen to them is roughly equal to the alternative possibility, that disaster will strike. But such a view may be, as Danter Kahneman and Amos Tversky, psychologists, noted in one of their elegant papers on biases in human thinking, a falsely overoptimistic one. For the very good things that might happen to a person are actually limited in number, but the awful things exist in sumptuous and generous variety. To name the first few that spring to mind: One could step off a curb and be hit by a car, or die in an airplane accident or in a fire because of faulty wiring. But what are the range of overwhelmingly wonderful events that  would be as lifeshakingly good as these bad things would be bad? Inheriting a million dollars? Winning the Nobel Prize? But we humans don't tend to scan our personal probabilities in so coldeyed and dismal a fashion. We work, fall in love, raise our children, struggle, and somehow, throughout much or most of the turmoil, we continue to hope for the best, cast our thoughts toward a future that will be rosier, better, happier. Such an inborn cognitive bias is, according to Prof. Lionel Tiger, the anthropologist, actually programmed into the human species.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Except in mathematics, absolute proof is more often an ideal to be sought than a goal to be reached, a fact the courts recognize by setting varying standards of proof for different kinds of cases. Most civil suits are decided on the basis of a preponderance of the evidence. In criminal law, the standard is higher, requiring proof beyond a reasonable doubt.

title: Jane Strassberg, Ph.D. Student, Fiancee Of James King Hall 3d, Financial Analyst
description: The engagement of Jane Lisa Strassberg to James King Hall 3d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Strassberg of Forest Hills, Queens, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Hall Jr. of New Hope. Va.

title: Iranian Exiles Trying to Buy Homes Find New Troubles
description: Many wealthy refugees from the recent government turnover in Iran are having trouble closing contracts on new homes in the metropolitan area because their personal assets continue to be blocked in Iran.

title: Robinson to Be Among 36 Water Polo Inductees
description: LOS ANGELES, May 5  The new Water Polo Hall of Fame will induct 36 former players, coaches, contributors and referees on May 14. They include John Robinson, the Englishman who introduced the sport to the United States in 1888 as coach of the Boston Athletic Association.

title: GARDENING
description: THE huge bulldozer stood at the bottom of the grade while the women worked quickly with their trowels and baskets. They were digging  rescuing is a better word  a stand of red trillium that stood in the oath of the huge machine.

title: Wide Disparity Found in Control Of Pesticides Around the Nation
description: Nearly two decades after Rachel Carson's book Silent Spring sounded an alarm about pesticides, their use and the harm they may do are still surrounded by vagueness and imprecision.

title: Charlotte Louise Merriam Is Bride of Laurence Shevland
description: Charlotte Louise Merriam and Laurence Michael Shevland were married yesterday in the chapel of the Presbyterian Church of Tenafly, N.J. The Rev. Harry E. Chase, the minister, and the Rev. Joseph Wallroth, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Art
description: New York at that time was full of tenacious characters who didn't intend to get stuck with any one particular identification. One such was Robert Fulton (17651815). That Fulton was a very good watercolorist we know from his portrait of Charlotte Villette in the present exhibition: Lasting reputations have been made with less. But Fulton was also a designer and an inventor for whom no task was too daunting. He designed, for instance, the first steamboat to run successfully (in 1807) from New York to Albany. He designed ropemaking machine, and a house to go with it. He published a treatise on Torpedo War and Submarine Explosions. All these activities are documented in the present show, as is the look of Fulton himself as he was portrayed by John Vanderlyn. Energy is life was Fulton's message us all, and he certainly lived up to it.

title: Connecticut And the County Fight Over Water
description: COUNTY officials fired the latest salvo in a border war with Connecticut lastweek, contending that Hartford's sofarsuccessful pressure to have Albany set stiffer pollution regulations for Westchester waters that flow across the state boundary would have an adverse economic impact on Westchester's northern communities.

title: Council Panel Honors 2 Women
description: A City Council committee yesterday approved bills that would name a small park and a square in memory of two worldfamous women who died last year.

title: Thackeray's Thackeray
description: THACKERAY firmly told his daughters, When I drop there is to be no life written of me, mind this. Both his modesty and his concern for privacy led him to anticipate Lytton Strachey's dislike for the funereal barbarism of the official biography. In his lectures on the English humorists, Mackeray had praised fiction above autobiography or his tory for its vivid rendering of life and manners.

title: Miss Lane Is Bride Of Carlo Tomberli, Market Supervisor
description: Elizabeth Richardson Lane, daughter of Dr. George F. Lane 2d of Plainfield, N.J., and the late Ada Childers Lane, was married yesterday to Carlo Tomberli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aldo Tomberli of Florence.

title: Caucus to Look At Women's Needs
description: WASHINGTON  With generous contributions from both business and labor  including some firms involved in recent sex discrimination cases  the Congresswomen's Caucus will launch an expanded research and education program this sorine to focus on the needs and problems of women.

title: City Hospital's Revival Is Possible
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation is making preparations to open the new Woodhull Hospital in Brooklyn after failing to give it away or to persuade the United States Department of Justice to turn it into a Federal detention center, high corporation officials said last week.

title: One Killed and 6 Hurt in Shooting After a Dispute at a Kansas Park
description: ATCHISON, Kan., May 5 (AP)  Gunmen fired into a group of about 20 persons following a barbecue at a park early today, killing one man and injuring six others, the police said.

title: Susan R. Beck To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Beck of Boca Raton, Fla., and Danville, Ky., formerly of Garden City, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ruth Beck, to Clinton B. Davis 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil B. Davis of Orlando, Fla. An Aug. 4 wedding is planned at the Duke University Chattel in Durham. N.C.

title: How Oil Glut on Coast Became a Shortage
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 5  When the various spokesmen are asked how it is that the Alaska pipeline supposedly brought a glut of oil to California but that California has been hit by the first gasoline shortage panic since 1974, they begin by describing the answer as very complicated.

title: Bob Hope: More Than A Gagster?
description: James Agee once characterized Bob Hope as a good radio comedian with a pleasing presence, but not much else, on the screen. This has been conventional wisdom among scholars and critics of film for the past two decades. It is therefore a great satisfaction for adinirers of Mr. Hope that the Film Society of Lincoln Center is presenting a tribute to him tomorrow night at Avery Fisher Hall  a tribute that, it should be noted, is being held by a film, not a radio, society.

title: Health THE RUNAWAY USE OF ANTIBIOTICS
description: Over the past 30 years, antibiotics have permitted a control of infectious disease that would have been considered miraculous by earlier generations. And until recent years.

title: A Dream Bogs Down For Orlando Ballet
description: HUNTINGTO IN an attempt to execute a gram. leap to a stage of its own, the Or lando Ballet Company may fall short of landing on its feet.

title: P.L.O. Aide Buoyed by U.S. Trip
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 5  There has been no new opening by the United States toward the Palestine Liberation Organization but there is increasing recognition in America that the two should start talking, the director of the P.L.O.'s office here said after a visit to the United States.

title: GARDENING An Abandoned Site Is Now a Prizewinner
description: IN recent years, boardedup supermarkets and discount stores with rubbishstrewn parking lots have become an all too frequent sight on the Island. And abandoned gas stations often present a warravaged appearance. But one sbch sight  an abandoned supermarket on Montauk Highway in East Islip  has recently undergone a transformation that might well serve as an example for the reclamation of others.

title: A Nonprofit Theater
description: MILLBURN I WONDER how many people realize, Angelo Del Rossi commented with a note of pride, that the Paper Mill Playhouse is the only nonprofit theater in the United States that has been in continuous operation for 40 years.

title: A HighLevel Discussion Has Been Going On in Peking for Weeks
description: PEKING  American car manufacturers would be envious. The Peking Automobile Factory, China's largest maker of jeeps, has managed to triple its production over the past decade, gradually reducing both its costs and the selling price of its vehicles.

title: Nostalgia Is No Longer Enough for Good Works Overseas
description: WASHINGTON  Before Vietnam, before inflation, before the energy crisis and distrust in Government, when America seemed young and invincible, there was a program that for one brief moment captured the nation's enthusiasm  the Peace Corps, which seemed to rise above narrow political ideology, appealing to the country's best instincts. Yet from its beginning 18 years ago, it has been shadowed by politics. What was it really all about? How did it fit in with America's goals abroad and other countries views of America? Once again those issues are being raised in a miasma of politics, nostalgia, personalities and philosophies.

title: Bowling's Summer Tour Worth $800,000 in Purses
description: AKRON, Ohio (AP)  Joe Antenora, the commissioner of the Professional Bowlers Association, says the 12tournament P.B.A. summer tour will total more than $800,000 in prize money. The first prize for each televised summer event will be at least $8,000.

title: Modern Settings
description: ROM the first trace of blood in the emergency room of MidIsland Hospital, you know you are in the hands of a master practitioner of medical fiction. Multiple fractures, bullet wounds, openheart surgery, a hepatitis epidemic, bilname, anorexia nervosa, allergic shock, dengue fever  the novel's itinerary takes you through the heart of the Merck Manual of medical diagnosis. The healers who respond to these ills are the children of Jack and Meg Derry, who run an unsuccessful pharmacy on Long Island's South Shore.

title: Music Notes: Life With a Harpsichord
description: I first saw a harpsichord when was a sophomore at Brandeis University, Elaine Comparone said the other day. I came from a family that loved music and played a lot. I had grown up playing the piano, organ, violin and flute, even singing. But I'd never had any predilection for Bach. His music never moved me, and I didn't know what a harpsiThe statement was a surprising one to come from a musician who has established herself as an accomplished artist on that instrument, who thinks the second book of Bach's The WellTempered Clavier is the greatest music there is and who will give her next recital in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night. Equally surprising was her following remark that she had really only studied the harpsichord for about a year and a half. The rest of her training on the instrument had been on her own. But then it might be said of her, as it has of many musicians, that she Would have been good in whatever  musical path she pursued.

title: Skipper's Necessity: Getting a Good Crew
description: Offshore yachts were to hit the starting line at noon today on Long Island Sound as the sixmonth racing season opens with the Riverside tuneup race. For some skippers, though, the start of the season means the beginning of frantic phone calls trying to complete crews.

title: Wood, Field and Stream The Eerie Howl of the Coyote Is Heard Nationwide
description: The eerie cry of the coyote, a marvelously adaptable and sagacious animal, is heard throughout most of the United States today.

title: A Doctor's Rx For Medical Training
description: WE train our doctors now, essentially, to wait until people get sick and attempt to cure them, said Dr. Steven Jonas. For people who have illnesses and diseases for which known effective treatments are available, this is very important.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BRIDGEPORT  Allied Sculptors and Painters exhibit oils, watercolors, collage, wall sculptures, through May 31. Also Polish folk art. Library, 925 Broad St. 576.7413.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 5 (AP)  Firing squads executed four more of Shah Mo. hammed Rim Pahlevi's supporters early today, the newspaper Kayhan reported.

title: L.I. in Albany: Getting Ahead By Staying Even
description: ALBANY THE State Legislature has come up with few new projects and has provided little new money for the Island thus far this year. But considering what might have been, the Island might just be out ahead.

title: The Young, Bright Prokofiev
description: MEMOIRS are almost always carefully gilded documents, at least as fascinating for what they obscure as for what they illuminate. The memoirs of composers are no different. Typically, we find a chapter of preluding, in which family origins are poked at in a gingerly way, and where we read how the infant crawled to the piano at the age of 2 to tap out a Chopin Nocturne. Then, on about page 10, there begins the chronicle of compositions and the history of struggles and triumphs. If the child is father to the titan, we are left to guess how.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: HOME CLINIC
description: NOW THAT the heating season is behind us for a few months, most homeowners stop thinking about the need for adding the extra insulation that the house may still need.

title: Backers of Coastal Bill Urged to Look at Shore
description: WHEN I was a student at the University of Massachusetts some years back, several of my fellow student waiters in the dining hall concocted a diabolical scheme. We would select a rugged blocking back or a slugging outfielder as our victim and, at intervals, three of us would comment to him that he looked flushed and feverish. We wondered if he was feeling well.

title: Arithmetic Wasn't The Only Change
description: CONNECTICUT'S state government recently completed a journey down a very long road with the enactment of legislation dramatically changing the way we finance and oversee local public schools.

title: A Year's Ban on Access to Plant
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)  Federal regulators said today that it would be at least a year before workers could enter the containment building at the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear power plant to determine the extent of damage to the reactor core. The oneyear estimate was given to the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission by executives of the General Public Utilities Corporation, parent company of the utility that owns the Three Mile Island plant near Harrisburg, Pa. The utility has estimated that will take at least two to three years to decontaminate the plant as a result of the accident March 28.

title: Joan Brennan Sets September Bridal
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Vincent P. Brennan of Bronxville, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Joan Irene Brennan, to William S. Hearst, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hearst of Atlantic Beach, Li. A September wedding is planned. miss tsrennan and her fiance are with Bloomingdale's. She is a floor supervisor in the Manhattan store, and he is operations manager of the White Plains store.

title: ANTIQUES
description: WYCKOFF  WHEN we first moved in six years ago, they were still holding services in the other half of the church, Joseph Villano was saying. It gave you kind of a funny feeling.

title: On Language Sweet Land of Euphemism
description: The art of euphemism refusing to use painful words like dying  has not passed away.

title: Closing of ViolenceRidden Prison Seen as Far Off
description: ATLANTA, May 5 (AP) A year after a Federal study group recommended that the 77yearold, fortresslike Atlanta Federal Penitentiary be shut down, Federal prison officials say 1985 is the latest target date for closing the ??? eurity facility.

title: O.A. Petty 3d Weds Laurene 0. Thomas
description: Laurene Orcutt Thomas and 0. Anderson Petty 3d were married yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Andrew Mullins performed the ceremony.

title: $15 Million Higher Loss Seen for City's Hospitals
description: New York City's 17 municipal hospitals will run up a deficit in the current fiscal year $15 million higher than anticipated by the Koch administration, Sidney Schwartz, the state monitor of the city's fiscal affairs, said yesterday.

title: DINING OUT; Here It Pays to Be the Demanding One; China Garden
description: CONSISTENCY is the keen doubleedged standard of the Chinese kitchen, both in the food and in the attitude toward the customer. Does too much cornstarch destroy delicacy of flavor? Does a Chinese customer get different food than does an Occidental? This latter question may be answered by the nonChinese customer who shows sincere interest in the unusual or by ordering something special in advance.

title: Camps Where Old People Can Vacation
description: Since my arrival in New York more than 50 years ago from the Middle West, I have loved the city. I have enjoyed the crowds, the feverish vitality and the many stimulating opportunities. Recently, though, one part of the year has come to depress me  the long, hot, lonely summer, especially the protracted long holiday weekends when the city is closed uo tight.

title: ANTIQUES
description: WILTON BEFORE computers and tape recorders became familiar classroom tools, many generations of schoolchildren learned the rules of arithmetic and English grammar by heart, as New Englanders used to say. To help in practice and memorization, they also often made their own exercise and copy books from sheets of fairly heavy rag paper purchased at the local stationer's or newspaper office, folded to about 9 by 11inch pages, and stitched together with linen thread.

title: Montclair Violinist A Big Hit in Japan
description: MONTCLAIR WHEN Oscar Ravine finished playing the first piece on his violinrecital program in Japan, he thought he had done something wrong because there was no applause. It was only at the end that he discovered the reason.

title: 201 Winner for Cauthen
description: NEWMARKET, England, May 5 (AP)  Steve Cauthen rode Tap on Wood to victory in the 2,000 Guineas Classic today in his most brilliant ride in Britain.

title: Gale Munson Plans To Be Wed June 30
description: Gale Munson and Acheson Hamilton Callaghan Jr., alumni of the Harvard Law School and partners in the Boston law firm of Palmer & Dodge, plan to be married June 30.

title: More and More, the Courts Are Called On to Be Mind Readers
description: As a matter of logic and experience more than of law, chances are that a person who has told a lie, when asked about that lie, will probably tell another lie. Does it do any good to ask? Last month the Supreme Court said such inquiries into the wrongdoer's state of mind would presumably elicit selfserving responses. Nonetheless, the Court Puled in a 6to3 libel decision, there is no harm in asking.

title: Yugoslav Resorts After the Quakes
description: If you come to the Yugoslav Adriatic coast this summer, you will find crazyquilt pattern of damage left by the Easter Sunday earthquake. From Dubrovnik north through Split, Zadar and the Istrian Peninsula and the Italian border, the northern coast has been virtually untouched by the tremors that continue to shake portions of the southern Adriatic. But south of Herceg Novi, the oldtown areas of Kotor, Budva, Bar and Ulcinj have been so devastated, their architectural treasures, some dating back a thousand years, so shattered, that they may never be fully restored. In this area  the earthquake zone from Herceg Novi on the north to Ulcinj and the Albanian border on the south  road communications, food supplies, municipal services, accommodations and air connections have all to some degree been disrupted.

title: Old Buildings Get New Life
description: ADAPTIVE usage is a new phrase, one that rapidly catching on. But its meaning  converting a building from its original use to different one  is not new. And the process, like the phrase, is catching on as an effective, economical and practical way to put fresh life into a deteriorating neighborhood without bulldozing half the communitv.

title: U.S. Weighs Halting MX Missile, Shifting to a Submarine Weapon
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  The Carter Administration, nearing a crucial decision on how to deploy a new intercontinental missile, is considering a possiblity of scrapping the controversial weapon altogether and building instead a more deadly submarinelaunched missile, White House and Defense Department officials said today.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: BONN The involvement of West German banks in this country's industrial companies is in some ways similar to the activities of the Cheshire cat in Alice's wonderland. Somewhat mysterious, unquestionably secretive, the banks, like the cat, have a way of popping up in unusual ways in unexpected places. It has been that way for years, but perhaps not for many more.

title: Follow Up on the News
description: The staff of the New York State Public Service Commission reported in September 1977 that chronic exposure to 765,000volt electric transmission lines probably would cause biological effects in humans. What kind of effects it didn't say. It did recommend that a 550footwide protective zone be mandated under such lines to guard against undue exposure to the electrical and magnetic fields.

title: Authors Plan Campaign For Lending Royalties
description: American writers groups are planning a campaign for a doctrine that would provide a form of royalty pay. ments for books borrowed from public libraries. The proposal is expected to arouse strong opposition from librarians.

title: That Luxury, The Tomato
description: RIVERHEAD ANYONE who enjoys a ripe, scarlet tomato brimming with rich flavor and juice knows that the yearround run of the supermarket version can't compare with the Island's summer crop. What the local chapters of the tomato appreciation society may not realize, however, is that it is possible to get a jump on the season with Long Island hothouse tomatoes. Some markets carry them between now and July.

title: Dance: Faison's Tilt, in Disco Idiom, at the Ailey
description: For about its first two thirds, Tilt is great but rather ordinary fun. The new work by George Faison, performed Friday by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at the City Center55th Street Theater, is a workout for three mugging, mannequin disco dancers. Dressed in earish elitterand dancing through the funniest and most delectably tasteless stage decor of the season, all designed by Mr. Faison, the three women strut, bob and generally shake it up in an unvarnished disco idiom that reveals the numbing lack of invention in our newest American art form.

title: Allies Become Enemies in War Against Potato Pest
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I.  East End farmers and Federal and state officials have been fighting the golden nematode, considered to be the world's most serious potato pest, for more than four decades here in what has essentially been a cooperative effort. This spring, however, they are fighting one another, rather than thenematode.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: I felt it necessary to write in reference to your.April 15 article A Macaroon Called Sarah Bernhardt in order to enlighten readers to the fact that Stanley Shear, owner of Jespersen's pastry shop in Scarsdale, is not the only baker in Westchester who still makes Sarah Bernhardts by hand. Edelweiss Pastries in Bedford, where am employed, produces these same confections. Each week the pastry chefs at Edelweiss and their assistants labor over hundreds of Sarahs, all of this fine work being done by hand. Sarah Bernhardts are without a doubt one of the most delicious confections to be found anywhere, and I was pleased to see them spotlighted.

title: Peking Surveys Students and Finds They Lack Zeal for Communism
description: HONG KONG, May 5  When a high school in Peking recently tested students on the difference between Marxist Socialism and capitalism, a large number could not explain the difference or expound on the advantages of the Marxist system. Even more disturbing, said a report in The Liberation Army Daily, when asked what they most wanted in life, some students replied, Good work and high wages.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  Cold Storage, in an Actor's Cafe:Theater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through May 26). $3.5045.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Congress Is Expected to Decide 3Way Bolivian Race
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 29  The three major candidates for Bolivia's presidency are campaigning heavily in the provinces for an election that appears headed for final decision in Congress.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY. May

title: Radioactive Leak Reported
description: ATHENS, Ala., May 5 (AP) A small amount of radioactivity was released into the Tennessee River as a result of a leak in a generating unit's cooling system at the Browns Ferry nuclear plant, the Tennessee Valley Authority said today.

title: Taxing the Hilt, Too
description: LONDON  Very few nations or individuals regard themselves as liable to pay too little tax. Many people, at least subconsciously, are convinced that they pay more tax than the next man and that a great portion of what they do pay is misappropriated by bureaucracy.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: In his acceptance speech as winner of the 1979 Capezio Dance Award the other day, Alvin Ailey hit close to the bone before an audience of figures from the dance world. Not very dignified, is it, he said, to see all the dance companies scrambling for foundation funds. It was also the remark in Mr' Ailey's talk that elicited the most applause.

title: HEALTH, EXERCISE, BEAUTY, DIET
description: Many of this year's health and beauty books seem to have been developed, or thickened, or bloated, from ideas that should have been (and probably were) magazine articles. Others began with encyclopedic intentions, but emerged thin. Either approach is annoying to the reader, who in both cases gets too little for his or her money. However, there are some exceptions, books that define health and beauty more generously than last year's cosmeticcellulite sevendaydiet crop.

title: Questions/Answers
description: We have had an extended border of scillas, both, blue and white, for years. They have bloomed beautifully every year until this spring. Although the leaves were plentiful, not one of the bulbs flowered. Could it have been the February cold? Will they bloom again? Mrs. S. F.S., Hightstown, N.J.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Melvin Simon couldn't be confused with Jack Warner, say, or Sam Goldwyn. He lives in Indianapolis, for one thing, and he spends most of his time building shopping centers. But Melvin Simon is a bona fide movie mogul as well. He is the moneyman behind the dark horse hit of the year, Love at First Bite.

title: Deaths
description: SELTZERRuth, beloved wife of the late William, loving sister of Jack Jankelowitz. Louis. Philip and Abraham Jan', cherished aunt. Services at BoulevardPark West 1901 Flatbush Ave (at Ave L Brooklyn, 11AM, Sunday.

title: Shows and Events
description: Today  Antiques Fair, Urban Farms Shopping Center, High Mountain and Franklin Lakes Roads, Franklin Lakes. Donation: $1. Proceeds will benefit the Franklin Lakes Volunteer Ambulance Corps. Hours: 10 A.M.5 P.M.

title: Poor Big Rich Man
description: ONE of the myths that Americans cherish concerns the man of great wealth and power whom fate does in. He can buy anything, except relief from personal misery. He controls politicians, enjoys the favors of beautiful women and seems immune to the laws and limitations that govern other mortals; but in the end he falls from grace. The public feeds on his exploits, but takes satisfaction in the demise of someone who has strayed too far from the average. The myth has several variants. In its literary guise, we have a figure such as Sinclair Lewis, Nobel Prize winner, the most successful writer of his time, who died an unhappy, burntout alcoholic. In its entrepreneurial variant, we have Citizen Kane, based on William Randolph Hearst, whose triumphs as a newspaper magnate never quite managed to heal the wound of a miserable childhood.

title: Advice for Students Going Abroad This Summer
description: They pour out of their ivory towers, from behind ivied and red brick walls, searching for adventure, excitement and maybe a course credit or two.

title: Real French Bread, Made in U.S.A.
description: Do you have to be French to bake the best French bread? The French themselves have always thought so, naturellement, but now a French company is trying to persuade Americans of it, too.

title: Tarrytown Takes To Preservation
description: PRESERVING the past is the wave of the future. That is the message that the Historical Society of the Tarrytowns wants to sell to other communities.

title: A Manual for CarPoolers
description: BEFORE long, car pooling may be as familiar in suburbia as jogging. It will be discussed, analyzed, criticized and possibly found wanting. But as gasoline prices continue to rise and should gas rationing become a reality, car pooling will inevitably become for many the mode of transportation to and from work.

title: KOCH'S BUDGET PLAN WILL FACE HEARINGS
description: At a series of public hearings over the next 10 days, Mayor Koch's proposed $12.8 billion budget for the coming fiscal year will be called an outrage, a rank injustice and a complete disaster.

title: Union Head Pleads Guilty in a Compensation Case
description: Edward Yule, who was elected general chairman of the biggest union on the Long Island Rail Road last year with a campaign that charged his predecessor with improprieties while in office, has pleaded guilty to a charge that he solicited a payment from a trainman in 1977 in return for getting him an increased iniurvenmnensation award.

title: Byrd Denies Tvine Arms Treaty Vote to Coat Rule
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, confirmed today that he had talked to the Environmental Protection Agency about its proposed pollution standards for coal. fired power plants, but he strongly denied reports that he had linked his support for a new treaty to limit strategic arms to relaxation of those proposl.

title: CAMERA
description: Although today's sophisticated cameras loaded with a high speed film such as Kodak TriX or Ilford HP5 enables anyone to shoot portraits in ordinary room light, or to shoot scenes at dawn or dusk and even indoor sports and stage events without flash or auxiliary lighting. most photographers are sooner or later tempted to wring even more speed out of these ASA 400 films by pushing that is, by deliberately using a higher exposure index (E.1.).

title: ROCKEFELLER FUND ANNOUNCES AWARDS
description: The Rockefeller Foundation has announced 41 winners of its Fellowship in the Humanities.

title: 2 Homosexuals Living Together Not a Legal Family, Judge Rules
description: Two homosexuals who live together, no matter how close or prolonged their relationship, do not legally constitute an immediate family, according to a ruling by a judge in New York City Housing Court.

title: ART VIEW
description: In the great exhibition of Michelangelo and His World, With Drawings From the British Museum, now resplendently installed at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street (through July 28), there is one drawing that for many people will stand out above all others. This is the red chalk drawing that bears the title Studies of a Reclining Male Nude. It is one of the 41 drawings by Michelangelo on temporary loan to the Morgan Library from the collection of the British Museum  the largest number of the master's drawings ever to be seen here  and it is the one in which we instantly recognize one of the classic images of Western art.

title: M. T. Pyne to Wed Shyamoli Sen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sudhir Sen of New York and Calcutta, India, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Shyamoli Sen, to Moses Taylor Pyne, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Pyne of Far Hills, N.J.

title: Government TV Link May Get a Reprieve
description: The closedcircuit television system that links municipal. offices in the region for discussionand employeetraining purposes may get ariextension of financing that will enable it to continue for at least two more months. On Tuesday, the board of directors of the Metropolitan Regional Councit Inc., private organization that operates the network, requested the Tristate Regional Planning Commission, an official planning agency that provides about half the council's annual budget expense, to grant the extension.

title: DINING OUT; Seafood in a Railway Station; The Shell Station
description: STRATFORD THE Shell Station in Stratford is not a competitor of the Mobil Corporation or of Conrail. the shells distributed are seashells, and the station in question is an old railroad sfation. You might think that in exurbia the last place commuter would want to eat and spend an evening would be a railway station. But judging by that crowds that frequent this yearold restaurant that seeminelv no deterrent.

title: March on Capitol Planned
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)  As many as 25,000 protesters are expected to march to the Capitol tomorrow to demonstrate opposition to nuclear power in an attempt to spur national interest in the issue.

title: The ABC's of When and What to Tip
description: Sometimes the fare is $1.15 and they give me $1.50, Charles Zingman said. But sometimes the fare is $1.95 and they give me $2, so I give them back nickel and tell them, Keep it, you need it more than I do.Mr. Zingman has been driving a taxicab in New York City for more than 20 years. In response to a recent passenger's questions, he attempted to clarify the oftenbefuddling problem: How much is an appropriate tip for each service performed?

title: A Zany Logic Lends
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y. ALAN Ayckbourn, Britain's answer to Neil Simon, is currently represented on Broadway by Bedroom Farce and is remembered for Absurd Person Singular. Relatively Speaking is earlier Ayckbourn, and thanks to the final production of this Westchester Regional Theater season, the New York area can have a look at it. And it is play worth looking at.

title: Two Men Slain in Bar After $1,500 Holdup In Greenwich Village
description: An employee of a Greenwich Village bar and discotheque was stabbed fatally and a second man was shot to death early yesterday morning by two robbers who fled with $1.500. the police reported.

title: Springtime in Paris
description: IT has been a cold spring in Paris, the chilliest and wettest since the French started keeping records over a century ago. So far, only the heartiest souls or the most intrepid tourists have ventured to sit at the tables outside the Deux Magots in St. Germain des Pres, unfortunately no longer the rendezvous of the intellectual elite, as its menu claims. But this is only one of the many inevitable signs of change on the Left Bank today. The garish Tour Montparnasse, a very New York skyscraper, is as visible as the Eiffel Tower in this part of town, and much less appealing. And within the French publishing community that is largely housed in the warren of little streets that make up this fashionable quartier, developments are in the air that may signal permanent changes in a profession still largely dominated by small, family owned and operated firms.

title: Joan Morse Is Betrothed To Prof. Donald Gordon
description: Joan B. Morse of New York City and Canaan, N.Y., widow of Arthur D. Morse, will be married next September to Donald E. Gordon, professor of art history at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Poor Little Rich Girl
description: EVEN now, at five years distance, it is not clear whether the wispy girl attached to the semiautomatic rifle in the San Francisco bank was a masquerading media princess abducted by a terrorist gang and forced to participate out of fear for her life, or a revolutionary adventuress making her debut, out to avenge a childhood of privileged repression by defaming her family and everything it stood for. That Patricia Hearst, not yet 20 years old, might have been both was far too complex a notion for the press. But that is the figure that finally takes form in Shana Alexander's perplexing portrait.

title: The Anatomy Of a Zoning Case
description: ORDINARILY, a local zoning board deals with matters that can be decided after a single meeting. On Wednesday, for example, the agenda of the Bedford Zoning Board of Appeals included re quests to allow construction of a pond, a new rightofway, an addition to a barn and a relaxation of restrictions on two commercial signs.

title: Two Who Make Fresh Air Fund Campers Happy
description: Pete Pascale is happy to see his kids go off to camp for the summer. So is Eleanore Minus. Sometimes it takes no encouragement at all to get the kids to go. Occasionally it does.

title: The Young, Bad Brecht
description: WHEN Brecht kept these diaries, in his early 20's, he was not only going all out to establish himself as a poet, playwright, filmscript writer, journalist and balladeer, but was also working on an image of himself as an entirely new type of German writer. This image is familiar to readers of his famous selfportrait in verse, Of Poor B.B. It is the writer not as a dreamer of exemplary dreams but as the manabouttown, cynical, uptodate, hardbitten, hardliving, deliberately coarse and brash. In the diaries, as in the poem, this image is not so much a face as a mask that Brecht is trying on, trying to live up to, with a good deal of swagger and exaggeration  his response to conventions with which he felt it necessary to break.

title: MargaretMary Stuart Married to C. J. Williams
description: MargaretMary Stuart and Charles James Williams were married yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by Msgr. John A. Ruvo.

title: HOW 60 MINUTES MAKES NEWS
description: Toward the front of the thick black idea file known around the 60 Minutes office as the Blue Sheets is a page marked 925. MEET THE BEATLES. Over the next few months, it reads, '60 Minutes will try to convince Messrs. Lennon, McCartney, Harrison and Starr to sit down together for a discussion, 10 years after their breakup. When they agree, Mike Wallace will interview.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: FIRST it came to Greenwich and now it's in Westport, a diabolical new regulatory weapon that could be even more maddening to errant car owners than having their vehicles impounded. If it's any consolation, they can blame Denver  or maybe France.

title: Black and White and Middleman
description: THE African soul is a blank slate on which anything can be written, onto which any fantasy can be transposed, writes Shiva Naipaul halfway through his narrative of travels in East Africa. The quotation is out of context. Mr. Naipaul. a ??? novelist and the brother of V.S. Naipaul, is really musing eloquently on how it was that Kenya's majestic highlands stimulated the outmoded and frustrated aristocratic longings of the white settlers, and how it is that Tanzania's preaching and wordheavy socialism holds such appeal for European idealists, who are, he suggests, equally outmoded. But the dictum of Africa as a repository for the foreigner's fantasies goes a long way toward explaining the peculiar deficiencies of his own book.

title: In Jail, the Innocent Also Suffer
description: THERE are 27 county jails, workhouses or correctional institutions in New Jersey's 21 counties, and more than half the inmates in those facilities are legally innocent; that is, they have not been found guilty of a crime.

title: Track Goes Metric, Endangers Mile Run
description: The mile may always be the glamour event in American track and field, but its future impact may never rival the 25 years that have passed since Roger Bannister's first subfourminute race.

title: Energy Proposals Still Going Uphill
description: Opposition to President Carter's decontrol of domestic oil prices crystallized last week around political and regional objections, while his standby gasoline rationing plan barely survived a committee vote. In both cases, liberal Democrats led, the opposition.

title: Events Today
description: BIKOAThor for United Cerebral Patios,: 5,000 bicKliStS to raise money; 10 A.M.; Central Park, Fifth Avenue and 72d Street, and Midland Beach Promenade, Seaside Boulevard and Lincoln Avenue, Midland Beach, S.1. (For information call 6777400.)

title: SPEAKING PERSONALY
description: IWAS taken aback  not somewhat aback, just aback  the other day by a display ad run by one of the better men's stores in New York. The store, which also sells clothing and other apparel for boys and women, was advertising navy blazers for boys, and its pitch read, in part:

title: Reassurance About Radiation
description: The antinuclear demonstrators who will gather today in Washington and other cities are understandably jittery about radiation. Not only were there accidental radibactive releases at Three Mile Island but also revelations that the people in Utah were dangerously exposed to fallout from atomic tests in the 1950's.

title: One Artist's Life After SpOrts
description: While 330 rookies were chosen in the National Football League draft last week, 10 paintings by Ernie Barnes were put on display at the Spectrum Fine Arts Gallery on West 57th Street for the next two weeks. There's a connection. All those rookies hope to make it in the N.F.L. when the games begin. But the biggest game, Ernie Barnes says, is adjusting to life after sports. Ernie Barnes knows. In the loneliness of his adjustment, this 6foot3inch 260pound artist often wept. But now he is better known than he was as an offensive lineman in the American Football League and he makes better money  nearly $100,000 annually.

title: Westport Looks Frankly At a Delicate Subject
description: THE scene is Staples High School, Westport, and the class is Human Sexuality, a new program in the humanrelations department.

title: OPERA
description: In 1974, the Metropolitan Opera's board of directors, having decided that the ship was foundering under the captaincy of Schuyler Chapin, the general manager, put aboard one of its own members, Anthony A. Bliss, with orders to make things shipshape. Mr. Bliss, who had served as the Metropolitan's unsalaried president in the Bing years, took on the salaried position of executive director and soon put Mr. Chapin ashore. He subsequently divided authority three ways, sharing it with two Chapin appointees, James Levine as music director and John Dexter as production director, and set out to put the company on an even keel both artistically and financially. It was Mr. Bliss's belief  though not, to be sure, Mr. Chapin's  that drastic shakeups and shapeups were necessary in both areas if the company were to survive.

title: Lab Battles the Consequences of Aging
description: A NEW research laboratory is opening at the Burke Rehabilitation Center in White Plains, dedicated to the simple proposition that although growing old is inevitable, some of its more fearful consequences are not.

title: Meadowlands Aide Predicts Tax Bonanza
description: SECAUCUS THE Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission has predicted that property values in the 14 towns that share ownership of the land will soar from about $500 million to $7.3 billion by the time all construction is completed. But no date was given for full development of the vast marshland.

title: Gunners From the South: Saving Esquire and the Male Ego
description: Out of Knoxville; Tenn., they came: two littleknown publishers who call themselves the fastest draws in the South. Last week they strode into the nation's publishing capital and bagged prestigious old Esquire Magazine.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Low level clouds are visible over New England. A band of frontal clouds can be seen tending from the Mid Atlantic States across the Texas gulf coast. Heavy clouds cover the lake region and the intermountain region. Heavy cloud cover can also be seen over Cascades and the Pacific Northwest and the Central Pacific States.

title: LATIN CHURCH IN SIEGE
description: On the afternoon of March 12, 1977, Father Rutilio Grande was driving two local peasants along the dusty road from Aguilares, El Salvador, where he was the parish priest, to celebrate mass at Ei Paisnal, three miles away. Father Grande's life had been threatened several times because of his efforts to inspire the deeply impoverished peasants of this region to demand improvements in their lives. But he had refused to flee. We have to hope that the cassock protects us, he had told me a few months earlier. They have never killed a priest.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: Cover: St. John the Evangelist; detail Of a 16thcentury Russian ecclesiastical veil. Photographed by Sheldan Collins / Picture credits, Page 112

title: Sorrel, a Leafy Taste Treat From France
description: French or Normandy sorrel (Rumex scutatus) is an herbvegetable which has only recently been discovered by Americans. This leafy green lemon tastetreat has been a classic of French cuisine since the days of the Bourbons. The memorable soup potage germiny served at the Ritz Hotel in Paris contains a sorrel base. Less elegantly produced, as sourgrass soup and Schav, middle and Eastern European Christians and Jews have known it well for centuries.

title: Second Case of Polio Confirmed In an Amish Area in Pennsylvania
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 5 (AP)The second case of polio within two days was confirmed in a rural Amish settlement yesterday, and a health official warned that unless the Amish agreed to mass immunizations they could experience up to 20 cases of the crippling disease this summer.

title: Guest Observer
description: A few years ago I was the proprietor of a flowering terrace that made a nice U around three sides of a small apartment on East 57th Street in Manhattan. It was windy up there and it was dry, but by patience and fortitude and money I became one of the great authorities on what would die in the sky.

title: Spending and Priorities Are at the Heart of the CarterKennedy Dispute
description: WASHINGTONThe latest clash between President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy involves more than oil and windfall profit taxes. Underlying last week's free use of the term baloney  first by Mr. Carter in response to the Senator's attacks on his oil price and tax policy, then by a group of Democrats in Cleveland whose leadership voted start a draftKennedy movement  are deeply felt differences over the direction of the party.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: ON two recent Saturdays, motor ists who pulled into the Exxon station on Hamilton Avenue in White Plains were greeted by a cardboard sign on the pump for regular fuel that read No Gas. Reports that some stations in the county were closing shop early and limiting the amount of gasoline customers could purchase had some residents worried to the point of waiting on line on Friday afternoons to fuel up for the weekend.

title: INTERVIEW A Lawyer Who Opts To Stress the Present
description: PRINCETON AS A Deputy State Attorney General in 1968, William J. Brennan 3d caused some eyes to open in New Jersey when he said that organized crime had infiltrated every facet of public life in the state except the church.

title: U.S. in Cup Final
description: MADRID, May 5 (UPI)  The United States beat the Soviet Union and Australia defeated Czechoslovakia today in the semifinals of the women's Federation Cup tennis tournament.

title: CHESS
description: The prospects are bright that the United States, which already has 13 active grandmasters, may not be long in getting another one. Yasser Seirawan of Seattle, 18 years old, achieved the grandmaster norm in the Louis D. Statham International Tournament in Lone Pine, Calif., and even though it did not count  he had to use it in obtaining the international master title  it clearly indicates what he can do.

title: Commuter Project Offers Safe, Registered Hitchhiking
description: NOVATO, Calif., May 4  In another energysaving attempt to pry Americans out of their automobiles, an experimental program was begun here to encourage commuters from this small suburban community to hitchhike to their jobs in San Francisco and back.

title: Budget Forecast: Mostly Cloudy
description: HARTFORD INFLATION is going to raise the state's costs more than it will increase revenues next year, and according leaders of both parties the result will be a politically painful conflict between the desire to avoid a tax rise and the reluctance to cut services and lay off state employees.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: AN 18yearold student, Geoffrey Kors, who has been in the Great Neck educational system since kindergarten, is seeking one of two trustee posts on the Great Neck Board of Education.

title: ART
description: BETHPAGE IN the 1930's, American art was challenged as never before to prove itself relevant to a people preoccupied with belttightening and bread lines. In response to the national identity crisis, artists were motivated to seek out and objectify America's latent strength. Some looked to the rural values of rugged individualism and selfsufficiency, while others turned to symbols of urban vitality.

title: Nixon, in Affidavit, Says Diaries Are Confidential
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI)  Former President Richard M. Nixon has filed an affidavit in Federal District Court in his battle to keep recordings of his innermost thoughts and feelings, diaries he contends contain no discussion of official business.

title: Rock: Tin Huey, a Sextet From Ohio, at Mudd Club
description: Ohio has been a fertile force for newwave rock bands of late, what with Devo, Pere Ubu, Rachel Sweet and more. And now the principal fount of Ohio rock bands, Akron, has presented us with yet another interesting new group, which calls itself Tin Huey. The sextet has been playing here and there in Manhattan last week, and was at the Mudd Club on Thursday night.

title: U.S. Steel Walks While Competitors Run
description: PITTSBURGH  Edgar B. Speer was known for his ability to hang tough, for his tendency to take the longrange view, for his bold and independent approach to the steel business. His style was reflected in the daring $3.8 billion capital spending strategy that the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel manufacturer, pursued throughout one of the worst downturns in the industry's history, Which began in 1975 and lasted well into 1977.

title: Unbeaten Harvard Winner on Severn
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 5  Harvard's unbeaten varsity heavyweight crew, with one eye on next Sunday's Eastern sprint championships, won the 43d Adams Cup against Navy and Pennsylvania today.

title: An Equestrian Journey to the Great Pyramids of Sakkara
description: Few are the visitors to Egypt who do not make the pilgrimage to the Great Pyramids of Giza, the last survivors of the Seven Wonders of the ancient world. But the impact is lost when the tourist is chauffeured up in an airconditioned bus and, upon emerging, is promptly set upon by persistent camel drivers, souvenir hawkers and softdrink peddlers  a hustle that has soured the trip for more than a few travelers.

title: WireHaired Pointer BestinShow Choice
description: ERWYNNA, Pa., May 5  Patricia Laurans's German wirehaired pointer, Ch. Laurwyn's Banner, was the surprise choice for the bestinshow award in the final at the 38th Bucks County Kennel Club show in Tinicum Park on the banks of the Delaware today.

title: Waldheim Opens Link Between the Koreas
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 5  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations said today that his talks here and in Pyongyang in the last week have opened a new channel of communication between North and South Korea that he hopes will be productive.

title: NEWS ANALYSIS
description: RONALD REAGAN is still confusing and confounding some New Jersey Republicans. First, he comes into the state for a fundraising dinner at the invitation of Noel Gross, a national committdewoman. This event angered Anthony Statile, the Bergen County G.O.P. chairman, who had nothing to say or do when Mr. Reagan entered his turf.

title: County Group Aids
description: IN Westchester there is a group of people who write letters to protest labor camps, torture and the deprivation of human rights.
