Their letters concern people in other parts of the world whom they have adopted, otherwise forgotten individuals whose expressions of conscience brought them Imprisonment and oppression.

title: Feared Leak in a Chemical Truck Slows Traffic in the Beacon Area
description: BEACON, N.Y., May 5 (AP) Traffic slowed to a near halt on Route 84 for almost two hours this morning near the NewburghBeacon Bridge in Dutchess County when a driver stopped his truck because he feared there was a leak of toxic chemicals he was transporting, the state police said.

title: Opposition Grows On Plan to Limit Parking in City
description: To comply with a Federal cpurt order on the reduction of air pollution, New York City has drafted amendments to its zoning regulations that would significantly limit the number of new offstreet parking facilities.

title: Marriner Conducts The Big Ones Now
description: Neville Marriner, who conducts the New York Philharmonic in its Music in May Series this week, is known to. the American public as a chamberorchestra man. This is primanly because of his many superb recordings with the Academy of St. MartinintheFields, the London chamber ensemble he has led since its founding in 1957. But other musiclovers also know of his work with the Los Angeles Chamber Orchestra, which he's conducted throughout the 1970's.

title: Roy D. Grossman Fiance Of Robin Leslie Friedman
description: The engagement of Robin Leslie Friedman to Roy. Douglas Grossman has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Friedman of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the bridetobe. Mr. Grossman is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Grossman of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Marriage Planned By Miss Lindenthal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Lindenthal of Short Hills, N.J., and Meriden, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, MaryElizabeth Lindenthal, to George Davenport Jones 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones of Concord and Wianno, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: To Israel: A Love Story
description: BY Zionist credo, Israel remains committed to the mission of gathering Jews from all the lands of the dispersion, with special attention directed to the six millionstrong American Jewish community. To encourage a sizable Aliya (the term for immigration to Israel, literally meaning to ascend) from America, Israel sends out special emissaries, stationing them in every urban center in the United States with a significant Jewish community. With all the effort, however, only about 30,000 American Jews have settled permanently in Israel since the creation of the state, whereas 10 times that number of Israeli Jews have passed the other way to take up residence in North America. The situation is regarded as nothing short of a national disgrace and the subject of heated ideological debate on what is to be done to reverse the trend.

title: U.S. Defoliant Is Linked to Liver Cancer in Vietnam
description: BERKELEY, Calif May 5  A highranking Vietnamese public health official strongly suspects that dioxin, an ingredient Of Agent Orange, the defoliant used by the United States in the Vietnam War, is responsible for an explosion in the incidence of liver cancer in what was formerly South Vietnam.

title: Bills at noted schools expected to reach $10,000 next year
description: FOR highschool seniors, the mailbox patrol is over. Armed with acceptances and waitinglist status, those who have won the admissions battle are planning their strategies for college next fall. For their parents, though, the battle is just beginning  the battle with inflation and the dizzying cost of postsecondary education.

title: Environmentalists Fear Development of L.I. Preserve
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L.I.  One of the.largest tracts of privately owned undeveloped land in the northeast, a 2,039acre wildlife preserve on this small and rustic island, is about to lose the club that manages it, and environmentalists are concerned that the property may be on the verge of realestate development.

title: 'scared Straight! Film a. Part of Life for Many Students in One Town
description: RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., May 5In one of the student skits in the spring variety show at Ridgefield Park High School last week, half a dozen students playing the roles of stern administrators ushered a dozen or so other youngsters depicting troublemakers into the auditorium and berated them about gum chewing, tardiness and inattentiveness in class.

title: HOME CLINICIC
description: NOW THAT the hearing season is behind us tor a few months, most homeowners stop thinking about the need for adding the extra insulation that the house may still need.

title: MediumSize Airports to Receive New Radar SyStem to Aid Safety
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 2 (AP)The Federal Aviation Administration has exhibited a radar system for mediumsize airports here, describing it as a major step toward safer flights and improved air traffic control.

title: Judge, With Injunction, Reinstates CART for 500
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 5 (AP) Federal judge, citing possible severe hardships to some of the biggest names in auto racing, granted a temporary injunction tonight and ordered that six Championship Auto Raoing Teams barred from the Indianapolis 500 by the United States Auto Club be reinstated.

title: Zielinski, in Office a Year, Grants Meager Rate Increases
description: Soon after Charles A. Zielinski was appointed chairman of New York State's Public Service Commission a year ago, he upbraided the state's utilities for what he said was a gross lack of foresight in planning for the future. There is justifiable indignation over certain areas of utility operations, he told a reporter. There's been very little innovation in the power field.

title: School Desegregation Dispute in Milwaukee Is Settled After 14 Years
description: MILWAUKEE, May 5  A school desegregation case that has divided Milwaukee for 14 years has apparently been ended with the approval of an outofcourt settlement yesterday by Federal Judge John W. Reynolds.

title: Band With 150 Songs and No Dictator
description: FREEPOR DESPITE this country's rela tively short history, it has spawned an impressive range of popular music genres That are simply bursting at The seams with attractive, wellconstrutted tunes. Montage, a fiveyearold, fivemember band that is bookeol for six nights a week through September and has a performing repertory of some 150 songs, draws  as its name suggests  from an unusually large number of these genres for material and inspiration.

title: Mailbox: Casey Stengel's Mets Recreated
description: To the Sports Editor: It is a shame that today's Mets fans refuse to enjoy their team as they did in the early 1960's. The comparison beokeen Casey Stengel's team and the one led by Joe Torre grows more favorable each day.

title: Deaths
description: DeMER ITTBromley. Former Vice President at the New York Office of the Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection & Insurance Co. died Sunday. April 29 at Hilton Head, So. Carolina. He was 70 years old. A graduate of Exeter Academy & Yale Univ.. Mr. DeMeritt Joined Hartford Steam Boiler in 1937 at the St. Louis Branch office. Subsequently, he was named manager at New York in 1952, and elected vice president, remaining In that capacity until his retirment in 1971. He served as president of the Casualty & Surety Club of N.Y. and other local meantzations. He was a former resident of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. He leaves his wife Olive & 2 sons Bromley Jr. and John Peter, and two grandchildren.

title: E.C.A.C. Hockey Playoffs Slated for Boston Garden
description: CENTERVILLE, Mass. (UPI) The Eastern College Athletic Confer. ence says its annual Division I hockey semifinal and final playoffs will return to Boston Garden for the next three years.

title: Michaels Praises Buffalo's Draft
description: Walt Michaels, the New York Jets coach, believes the Buffalo Bills had the best college draft of any National Football League team. If that turns out to be the. case, the competitive aspects of the'Jets division  the American Conference East  will further increase. And it is a difficult enough division now with the Baltimore Colts, the Miami Dolphins and the New England Patriots having produced playoff teams within the last two years.

title: Kennedy Assails U.S. Paperwork
description: WASHINGTON, Max 5  In a speech that he labeled nonpolitical, Senator Edward M. Kennedy today told an audience of about 2,000 medical scientists many things such an audience would want to hear.

title: U.S.Soviet Swap Improved the Diplomatic Climate but Basic Attitudes Remain Unchanged
description: WASHINGTON Like all important Soviet actions, the carefully workedout exchange last weekend of political prisoners for Soviet spies convicted by American courts was being combed over for both tactical and longerrange policy implications. The exchange raised the question of whether a softening of Moscow's attitudes should be seen in the release from Soviet prisons of two Jewish activists, a Ukrainian nationalist, a Baptist pastor and a leader of the watchdog group set up to monitor Soviet compliance with the Helsinki accords on human rights.

title: The World
description: Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa, the Prime Ministerdesignate of RhodesiaZimbabwe, warned last week that if Western help were not forthcoming, he would get it from anywhere, even the Devil, by which he meant South Africa. It was a telling and potentially suicidal threat. Nothing could boost African and Marxist support for the guerrillas like South African intervention in Rhodesia's war  unless it was a decision by the United States or Britain's new Conservative Government to lift economic sanctions against Salisbury. So while the United Nations Security Council last week declared the elections illegal and insisted that the sanctions be maintained, the countries that really matter to Rhodesia  the United States and Britain abstained.

title: Realty News Elliman in New Post After Dismissal
description: Edward S. Elliman, who was dismissed in February as the president of Douglas EllimanGibbons & Ives Inc., one of the city's leading realestate management concerns, has joined SulzbergerRolfe Inc. as a senior vice president and vice chairman of the executive committee.

title: Nancy B. Gentzler To Be Wed June 17
description: Nancy Byron Gentzler and Peter Richard Chaffetz, New York lawyers, will be married June 17 in Westport, Conn. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Gentzler's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John A. Gentzler of Washineton.

title: Shortages Where Have All the Small Cars Gone?
description: Two months ago, 50 new Hondas sat on John Ellena's car lot in Lawrence, Kan., waiting for buyers. He had so many that he turned down Honda's offers for more shipments, for fear that he could not sell the ones he had on hand.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Holly Friant, Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Olin Chester Friant Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Holly Melinda Friant, to Paul Mulholland Butler Jr., son of Mrs. Butler of South Bend, Ind., and the late Mr. Butler, a chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Film: 'Teresa the Thief,' A Comedy From Italy:The Cast
description: Imagine Barbra Streisand starring in a happy-go-lucky comic version of "Seven Beauties." and you get the tenor of "Teresa the Thief," a raffish Italian comedy that shows off Monica Vitti to marvelous advantage. Miss Vitti, who bore a very strong resemblance to Miss Streisand at the time (1974) when "Teresa the Thief" was shot, also has a Streisand-like ability to make herself adorable at will.In addition, and perhaps of no lesser importance, Miss Vitti can wolf down a meal more avidly than anyone else in movies these days. Because Teresa, the heroine here, is very often down on her luck and starving, this gift of Miss Vitti's comes in handy. She lends an ecstatic energy to the film's every frame, even to the sequences that aspire, not very successfully, to sobriety."Teresa the Thief" takes the form of a rambling memoir, a long string of vignettes that lead nowhere in particular but are often individually charming. Raised by the strict father of her large, earthy family, Teresa turns into a burglar during World War II, and is jailed for her crimes. Later, when the Allied forces conquer Italy, she pleads for clemency, explaining that she broke a bust of Mussolini in the apartment she was caught robbing.She becomes a pickpocket later on, operating with a female accomplice during the film's most delightful chapter. Together, they operate by picking up a strange man with whom the accomplice can neck in a movie theater, until she finds his wallet and passes it to Teresa in the next seat. Unfortunately, they always seem to attempt this stunt in theaters showing "Waterloo Bridge." And Teresa, who has no real talent for crime, likes the movie so much that she invariably loses track of her job.Miss Vitti, the only real star of the film, helps unify its many episodes by playing them with an imperturbable buoyancy. But even her performance can't quite compensate for the movie's lack of dramatic emphasis, or for its tendency to meander. The loose ends never tie up, and no interlude seems to have any more weight than any other. The passage of time often goes unremarked on, except in the English voice-overs  the rest of the film is subtitled  delivered by Miss Vitti in an accent that makes already-funny lines even funnier."Teresa the Thief" is the first film to be directed by Carlo Di Palma, who has long worked as a cinematographer, most notably for Michelangelo Antonioni. It is handsome and well played, but a little bit fluffier than Mr. Di Palma seems to want it to be, and somewhat lacking in momentum.

title: WASHINGTON The Power Of a Woman
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  Every time the British have a national election, Washington seems a little envious and goes through a spasm of election reform. The British, to use their own word, seem so tidy. Their elections, are suddendeath affairs. After a threeweek campaign, it's all over, and the moving vans are at the door of No. 10 Downing Street.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: One year the temperature was 93 degrees at Easter, and last year's ice storms inhibited normal growth, but the spectacular pink and white blooms of 30,000 trees are expected to coincide perfectly with the 43d Annual Fairfield Dogwood Festival from Saturday to May 19.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Rebel PoliTechs
description: LONDON  Is modern technology beginning to turn against tyranny?

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: There can never be too many books on this subject, so even if you've read Edwin Newman, read Donna Woolfolk Cross. Word Abuse goes through the familiar litany of political double talk, advertising tricks, bureaucratic jargon, speech laziness, cliches and so forth, but Mrs. Cross's approach is fresh and witty (perhaps at times a trifle too colloquial to be comfortable), and her examples are wonderfully apt.

title: Charles Eric de Carbonnel Will Marry Katrina Vanderlip on Aug. 4 in California
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Kelvin Cox Vanderlip of Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., of the engagement of her daughter, Katrina Vanderlip, to Charles Eric de Carbonnel, son of Use de Carbonnel of Paris and the late Eric de Carbonnel.

title: Carolyn Schreiner Sets Autumn Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Agnew Schreiner Jr. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Cort Schreiner, to Scott Calder of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Calder of Oyster Bay, L.1. An autumn wedding is planned.

title: Satellite's Orbit Seen as Perfect
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May (UPI) The latest in a series of military communications satellitep designed to provide jamproof radio links with the nation's warships, planes and troops was reported in perfect preliminary orbit today.

title: DoortoDoor Voter Registration
description: HARTFORD IF someone knocks on your door sometime next year and asks whether you would like to register to vote, chances are it won't be the opening gambit of a person trying to sell you a magazine subscription.

title: Municipal TV Link in Trouble
description: FIVE years ago, a closedcircuit television network that was designed to improve communication among municipalities in the New YorkNew JerseyConnecticut region was put into operation amid high hopes. It is a system that is still regarded as one with great potential by those who operate it and by almost everyone else associated with it, but it is also one that appears to be in trouble.

title: P.U.C.A. ShakeUp Leaves Uncertainty
description: HARTFORD IN the most sweeping change since the Public Utilities Control Authority was created in 1975 Governor Grasso has moved to replace a majority of the fivemember panel, but what effect the action will have on the state's consumers or its utilities remains unclear.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WELL, maybe not poems. Maybe it's just plain doggerel, like the lines above, for which this columnist takes full blame. But whatever it is they write, Gladys Phillips and Maxine (Mickey) Karpen have become the poetslaureate of the crisisbirthday set, from Long Island and into the heartlands.

title: Brenda Jane Arsenault Plans To Become Bride on June 16
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Edward Arsenault of Bethlehem, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Brenda Jane Arsenault, to Jeffery Walters Simon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Raymond Simon of Huntington, L.I. A June 16 wedding Is planned.

title: L'Appartement Means the French Have Landed
description: If things work out the way Jacques Teze hopes, Pappartement will become as familiar a word in New York as Perrier.

title: Bomb Detoxification Supported
description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 5 (AP)  Gov. Scott M. Matheson said today that the Army's decision to delay transfer of 900 deadly nervegas bombs from Colorado to Utah until they are inspected for leakage supported his argument that the bombs should be detoxified where they sit. Three of the bombs were discovered to have leaks in an inspection last summer, halting the planned transfer.

title: STAMPS
description: Architecture of enduring classic beauty, representative of the treasured structures of the early decades of thisnation, is depicted on a new block of four commemoratives in tribute to American Architecture.

title: FILM VIEW
description: In 1973 Luis Builuel made one of his rare visits to Hollywood, where he was feted by some of the community's leading film directors on the occasion of his having won an Oscar for his The Discreet. Charm of the Bourgeoisie. Bur'mei had worked briefly in Hollywood in the mid1940's supervising the dubbing of Spanishlanguage versions of Hollywood films, but never as the director of his own films. Several weeks after his Hollywood visit, when he passed through New York on his way back to Europe, it was obvious that he had been invigorated and touched by the directors tributes. He rattled off the names of the people who had turned out for him, the first being Billy Wilder's. At the time I didn't think to ask him about Wilder  whether Wilder was a friend, or whether Buiiuel had a particular feeling for Wilder's films. We talked about other things.

title: A Lefthanded Third Baseman
description: OU'VE got to attend closely to Jerome Charyn. He's ambitious, daring, but quietly so. The Seventh Babe starts out as a fairly conventional baseball novel but modulates into something more strange and wonderful and decidedly southoftheborder.

title: Beauty Being a Gym-Dandy
description: There are tough workouts, long and short workouts, fun workouts, machine workouts and even a workout done flat on the back. And, despite one.

title: Klein in a Quandary Over Barbato Case
description: IT was 1971, and John V. N. Klein was a Suffolk County Legislator from Smithtown about to embark on his first campaign for County Executive. His campaign manager was Nicholas Barbato, the Smithtown Republican leader.

title: Nuclear Nonsense
description: MARGARET MAXEY'S defense of nuclear power as an energy source ['Despite Emotional Fallout, Atomic Energy Resource Safest, Opinion Page, April 22] contains so many fallacies, errors in logic and wrongheaded assumptions that it must not go unchallenged.

title: The Real Threats to America
description: It is not normally news when an American Administration looks around the world and pronounces the United States strong and wise. Nor is it remarkable that our foreign policy managers, facing strong political challenge, should be reaching for a catch phrase give a strategic shape to their tactical exertions abroad. Our diplomacy usually pretends to be architecture, building alliances or communities, erecting frameworks and protecting structures of peace. By. this rhetorical standard, the recent major speeches of President Carter, Secretary Vance and Counselor Brzezinski have been routine.

title: Armadillo Race More Scrabble Than Dash
description: NAHUNTA, Ga., May 5  Before 300odd sweltering spectators, 23 unwilling competitors set world records yesterday in the Brantley County Armadillo Olympics, touted by its sponsors as the first in the world.

title: Candace Collamore Wed To Scott George Paine
description: Candace Huston Collamore, daughter of Joy Ericson Collamore of New Canaan, Conn., and Wallace Rowe Collamore of Avon, Conn., was married yesterday to Scott George Paine, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Paine of Middletown, N.J. The Rev. W. Wallace Spiegel performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Your April 11 editorial How to Make Railroads Solvent is a timely discussion of a serious problem. The industry has financial troubles, which are serious in and of themselves. But they are even more serious when viewed as symptoms of a deeper problem  the failure of the industry to cope with the rise of competition from other modes and the shifting nature of the demand for railroad service since World War II. But the solution which you have advanced embraces a fallacy that has caused much of the railroads problems today.

title: Other National Events
description: A legal charter of do's and dont's for United States intelligence agen. cies, begun by the Carter Administration in 1977, has proved to be a slow and delicate undertaking. Last week, the White House announced that the second of seven sections, this one affecting the Centtal Intelligence Agency, had been finished and presented to the Senate Intelligence Committee. One aim of the bill is to free the agency from the need for Presidential approval of small clandestine operations, a requirement that some White House officials regard as clumsy. A potentially more controversial proposal, however, would give the C.I.A. authority under certain circumstances to spy on American citizens abroad.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: Prof. Edmund S. Morgan has written an odd (and to me distressing) review of my book The First Frontier (March 4). The conflict of the English settlers with the Indians seems to be the theme intended to hold the book together, he writes, and then proceeds to criticize it for omitting certain nativesettler conflicts, for failing to deal with nonbellicose relationships between the two groups, for neglecting to discuss the making and breaking of treaties, for paying scant attention to Indian cultures, etc. Fair enough. Except that the theme of my book is not Indiansettler relations or conflicts. (This is the reason that the longest and final chapter in the book is not concerned with Indian wars at all  a fact that seems to puzzle Professor Morgan, as though I had failed to remember what I was writing.

title: John Lloyd, 78, Worked For 40 Years With A.P.
description: LONDON, May 5 (AP)  John Lloyd, former Associated Press general executive for Europe, the Middle East and Africa, died at his home near London today. He was 78 years old.

title: Connie Schott Wed To Dean Phypers
description: In the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, Conn., yesterday, Mary Conway Pendleton Schott, chief staff editor for Bayard Publications. trade journal and book publishers in Stamford, Conn., was married to Dean Pinney Phypers, vice president of finance and planning for the International Business Machines Corporation. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Marrero Is Seelszing Broader Support in Bronx Race
description: Trying to put together a broad coalition, Victor Marrero has lined up several wellknown Democrats to support his bid for the Democratic nomination for Bronx Borough President.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: With last week's concerts, the New York Philharmonic brought its season to a close, and with it the first season of Zubin Mehta as musical director of the orchestra. For him must have been a satisfactory eieht months. Audiences have responded to his dynamic approach music, and so far there have not been any rumblings within the orchestra. When the New York Philharmonic does not like a conductor, the whole world immediately knows about it.

title: A Shop for RockandRoll Rarities
description: AS he goes through the bins one record at a time or points to the sleeves on the wall, Bob Caruso has a personal recollection about each. It soon becomes apparent that each item has special meaning and that he is involved in more than just another business. His feeling for records is akin to a love affair.

title: GARDENING
description: THE huge bulldozer stood at the bottom of the grade while the women worked quickly with their trowels and baskets. They were digging  rescuing is a better word  a stand of red trillium that stood in the path of the huge machine.

title: SHOP TALK
description: LOCUST VALLEY LOCUST VALLEY has a quiet, rural atmosphere that belies its proximity to New York City. Shopping here is neither trendy nor chic, but It is interesting because of the variety of small convenience stores in the downtown area. And there are several picturesque antiques shops, most of which are open during the week and on Saturdays by chance or appointment.

title: Grand Jury Investigations Are Linking Political Figures With Contractors
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I.  Suffolk County politicians who have pushed the controversial $920 million Southwest Sewer District used to brush off critics by pointing out that none of a dozen investigations at the troubled project had resulted Man indictment.

title: Bartram High Takes 2 Events at Relays
description: The senior prom for Bartram High of Philadelphia was held Friday night and many of its track athletes, including Rod Wilson, did not get home until the early hours of yesterday morning. Yesterday afternoon, although tired, they had a good time again at the 19th annual New York Relays at Downing Stadium on Randall's Island.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: LABOR unions representing about half of the state government's 70,000 fulltime employees are threatening wholesale strikes this summer unless the state offers bigger raises. The current contracts expire on June 30.$1,000 fine and a 30day suspension to Dr. Wel Reele, a Roselle Park veterinarinan, for endangering the lives of two cats. When Dr. Reele was preparing to anesthesize the cats before spaying and declawing them, the board said, he estimated their weight by holding them in his hands instead of weighing them.

title: Noisy Vibration Detected in Nuclear Plant Shut Down 2 Weeks Ago
description: CHARLEVOIX, Mich., May 5  The Big Rock Point nuclear power plant has a noisy vibration coming from its reactor vessel, in addition to a leak of radioactive water that forced it into a cold shutdown two weeks ago.

title: INVESTING
description: PARIS  French stock prices jumped an average of 44 percent last year, giving investors on the Paris Bourse their biggest bonanza ever. No one is expecting a repeat performance in 1979. But brokers and analysts are remarkably united in predicting a further, more modest advance, probably in the 15 to 20 percent range this year.

title: KlanRobed Man Shot by Blacks Says His Initiation Was a Ruse
description: DECATUR, Ala., May 5  A 24yearold unemployed Alabama welder, shot twice earlier this week while wearing a Ku Klux Klan robe in an allblack neighborhood, said yesterday that be had thought he was being initiated into the Klan.

title: Dance: Three in Debuts In Ballet Theater Works
description: Desir, a pas de deux by John Neumeier that was to have had its New York premiere with American Ballet Theater's Natalia Makarova and Asthony Dowell, was taken off the program Friday night when the management reported an injury to Miss MaltaOra.

title: Students Are Unexcited By Draft Registration Bill
description: The possibility of military registration for male ISyearolds, raised by a House subcommittee last week, has met with muted responses on college campuses. So far, there has not been much reaction in the nation's high schools.

title: TREATER
description: ALAN AYCKBOURN, Britain's answer to Neil Simon, is currently represented on Broadway,by Bedroom Farce and is remembered for Absurd Person Singular. Relatively Speaking is earlier Ayckbourn and thanks to the final production of this Westchester Regional Theater season, the New York area can have a look at it. And it is a play worth looking at.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Your April 11 editorial How to Make Railroads Solvent is a timely discussion of a serious problem. The industry has financial troubles, which are serious in and of themselves. But they are even more serious when viewed as symptoms of a deeper problem  the failure of the industry to cope with the rise of competition from other modes and the shifting nature of the demand for railroad service since World War II. But the solution which you have advanced embraces a fallacy that has caused much of the railroads problems today.

title: Beth Heiden, Speed Skater, Leads Voting for Award
description: Beth Heiden, a world speed skating champion from Madison, Wis., has been named winner of the firstquarter balloting for the Pinch woman athlete of the world award.

title: Drama: The Sound Of Music in Millburn
description: MILLBURN IN CASE you've forgotten, The Sound of Music will be 20 years old this Nov. 16. It opened at the LuntFontanne Theater in New York in 1959 and became Rodgers and Hammerstein's third longestrunning Broadway show, surpassed only by their Oklahoma! and South Pacific.

title: Crime Figure Wins Court Fight To Avoid a PerjuryCount Term
description: Vincent Aloi, a reputed leader of organized crime, has won a long court fight to avoid serving a prison sentence for a perjury conviction that grew out of the 1972 murder of Joseph Gallo, a rival gangster who was shot to death in a restaurant in lower Manhattan.

title: Oklahoma to Force Divestitures Of Land Owned in State by Aliens
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, May 5 (AP) Oklahoma's constitution prohibits foreign nationals from owning land in the state, and Jan Eric Cartwright, the Attorney General, has said that he will move to enforce the law.

title: New, Varied Prescriptions Push a National Health Plan
description: WASHINGTON  For two generations, the men in the White House have called for the enactment of a national health insurance program. And for two generations, the legislators down Pennsylvania Avenue have produced generally liberal and activist records  but no health plan. This year, as is well known, the electorate has sent timid, conservative group to Capitol Hill, one that shies away from even talking about sweeping new Federal programs, especially expensive ones. Yet this donothing, tightfisted 96th Congress just might vote on a national health insurance bill this year. What is more, such a bill has a 5050 chance of passing, at least in the Senate.

title: Nancy Friedman Betrothed To Dr. Edward J. Seidmon
description: The engagement of Nancy Friedman to Dr. Edward James Seidmon has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Friedman of Forest Hills, Queens. The bridegroomtobe is a son of Dorothy Goldman of New York and the late Dr. Edward E. Seidmon, a pediatrician and allergist in Plainfield, N.J. The wedding is planned for Nov. 11.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: The skies over Sunken Meadow State Park will be bustling with activity today, but pity the poor bird that wanders by. For from 10 A.M. to 3:30 P.M., the area will be taken over by the Long Island AeroRadio Society for a Radio Controlled Model Aircraft Show, giving the earthbound ;pilots a chance to go through their pates as they engage in combat maneuvers, stage some stunt and precision flying or just show how glider or laterelease planes get off the ground  and stay up. There will also be a display of scale models. Sunken Meadow is in Kings Park. Admission is free. 6691000, Ext. 247.

title: Lois D. Mann Is Betrothed To Physician
description: Announcement has been made by Jeanne Douglass Mann of Alexandria, Va., and Capt. Stephen Stafford Mann Jr., U.S.N., retired, of Punta Gorda, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Lois Douglass Mann, to Dr. Allen Bryant Nichols. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Doveton Nichols of Charlottesville, Va.

title: Robert Shearer to Wed Linda M. Smith May 20
description: Linda Mairs Smith, an officer with the merchant banking group of Citibank, and Robert Roe Shearer, an investment banker, will be married May 20 in New York.

title: Richard Carlson Fianc Of Laura A. DeAngelis
description: Laura Ann DeAngelis, who expects to graduate next month from Sarah Lawrence College, and Richard Andrew Carlson of New York, an associate with the New York law firm of Lord, Day & Lord, plan to be married in October in New Haven, where Mr. and Mrs. Daniel DeAngelis have announced their daughter's engegement.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS
description: EAST FARMINGDALE JULES FEIFFER'S plays stage cartoons may be a likelier description  are so animated, so chaotic that the stage can hardly contain them. It seems as though the theater form has provided a release from the stircraziness inflicted upon characters too long impaneled. On stage, they go veritably berserk, indulging in farcical antics that are the most logical accompanimentto illogical situations. Mr. Feiffer exploits all stage resources and stretches limits of space and imagination  to wild effect.

title: Rafshoon Says Agency Lent Funds to Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI)  Gerald M. Rafshoon, President Carter's media adviser, says his former Atlanta advertising agency extended credit to the Carter Presidential campaign in 1975 and 1976 in the normal course of business but did nothing improper. mr. Katsnoon said in an interview yesterday that he was confident that an audit would show that no illegal financing was funneled to the campaign through his agency and that the campaign paid back all the debts.

title: How the U.S. Could Stand Up to OPEC
description: President Carter's new energy program  to eliminate price controls on domestic crude oil, impose a tax on the extra profits the oil companies will earn as a result and employ those tax revenues in energy research and mass transportation  confuses the issue of energy with the issue of equity. And it does nothing to attack the root of the problem,  the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries monopoly control over world oil prices.

title: Susan Silver, Museum Aide, Fiancee of Dr. Glenn Brown
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Silver of Bonita, Calif., and Delmar, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Meredith Silver, to Dr. Glenn H. Brown, son of Mrs. Matthew Schoenwald of New York and the late Marvin L. Brown.

title: L.P.G.A. Jealousy Is Denied
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., May 5  Recent reports that many of the players on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour are jealous of Nancy Lopez and have expressed their feelings by openly cheering against her were denied today by veteran members of the L.P.G.A.

title: Jane Austen: By a Lady
description: THIS is not a feminist pronouncement but a characteristic touch of Jane Austen's irony: The pen was now in her hand, and the warning not to trust books necessarily recoils on the text in which it is inscribed. At the Yes, yes, if you please, no reference to exam pies in books. Men have had every advantage of us in telling their own story. Education has been theirs in so much higher a degree; the pen has been in their hands. I will not allow books to prove anything. same time Jane Austen is, of course, making a serious point. The pen had been mainly in the man's hand: It was the male who effectively owned and controlled the discourses within which the woman had to move and have (or fail to have) her being. So when the woman took up the pen, she was, in a certain sense, venturing into a maledominated realm, engaging in an activity traditionally reserved for males (except for letters and other kinds of private documents). Men held the pen, and  with a few exceptionsonly men published. Hence, partly, the degree of anonymity and the extensive use of pseudonyms employed by women writers in the 19th century. It is as though part of them felt that they were engaging in an unfeminine activity  or recognized that men would not always welcome the intrusion of women into their privileged realm.

title: 9 Try to Devise Computer to Predict Arson Targets
description: BOSTON May 5 (AP)  Four floors above Milk Street in the oldest section of Boston, nine persons are struggling to devise a computer that would help the nation's cities predict whether a building was likely to be intentionally burned.

title: More Police Assigned to Madrid
description: MADRID, May 4 (AP)  The Government has assigned 3,000 extra national policemen to the capital to help counter recent increase in political violence, officials announced today.

title: Cheaper Crude or No More Food Is a Heartland Hit
description: In the past 10 days this jingoistic message, sung with Johnny Cashstyle fervor to the accompaniment of fleet banjo and untempo country band, has become a new national ahem for heartland America  even Wore the record's actual release to the public.

title: Compact Tripods Are Worth Carrying Along
description: Carrying a tripod on a trip seems like a good idea until you have to decide whether to leave it in the car or hotel room, or haul it along when walkingitiound the streets or in the country. Many fine pictures have been missed because a tripod was consciously left behind  especially in situations where exposures will be longer than I / 30th of a second.

title: The Princeton Poll:
description: PRINCETON WHEN a campus newspaper at Princeton University published a poll two weeks ago purporting to show that more than a third of the students had cheated at least once on an inclass examination, the reactions were concerned more with fraud in polling techniques than with fraud in unproctored exam rooms.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: All Of a sudden we are cheerfully serious, an odd state of mind for the theater to be in. There we were, from September until April, watching the theater lumber its way from one disappointment to another (with a few exceptions), baffled and wondering where its recent promise had gone. We knew we were trapped in a paradox, an irony we might well have done without. On the one hand, during the past four or five years, Broadway and the outlying stages that have become its principal source of nourishment had together built up an audience larger than any in living memory, an audience eager to break house records with the least hint of encouragement. And, on the other hand, no one was able to supply it with the pleasures it was so passionately demanding. Curiously, the forms normally thought to be most popular were in the direst straits. Musicals, for instance, took a terrible drubbing this year: King of Hearts, Carmelina, Ballroom, Zoot Suit, and Grand Tour virtually tripped over one another's heels in their eagerness to depart. But effective comedies were in short supply, too. All those theatergoers, and what were they to go to? (They went to last year's shows, and holdovers from the few years before that, which means that Variety's boxoffice figures for the season will probably remain high; but present shortage means future shrinkage, and confidence was beginning to.

title: News Summary
description: Britain's new Cabinet was announced by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who sought a balance between rightwingers and moderates. There was no job among the 22 posts for former Prime Minister Edward Heath, who had campaigned unusually hard for the Tories and had hoped to be included. Mr. Heath was an obvious candidate for Foreign Secretary, but that job was given to Lord Carrington, considered one his party's ablest administrators. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: MAILBAG
description: The Boston Athenaeum's proposed sale to the Na tional Portrait Gallery of Gilbert Stuart's portraits of George and Martha Washington has clearly touched a number of particularly sensitive nerves in Massachusetts, and in other parts of the country as well. Editorial writers, columnists, cartoonists and even humorists have eagerly entered the fray espousing the claims not only of Boston and Washington, but of New York and Philadelphia, 400. When The Times's William Safi lightheartedly imagined a celestial debate over the issue between Jefferson and Hamilton (April 9), he was actually getting very close to the crux of the matter, for this episode has tapped very deep feelings about the proper relations be. tween the capital city and the rest of the country, between the Federal Government and the states and cities of America.

title: Long Island Is Getting Very Little New Money From Albany, but Sometimes Standing Still Is Progress
description: ALBANY  The Legislature has come up with few new projects and has provided little new money for Long Island thus far this year. But considering what might have been, the Island might just be out ahead.

title: Franklin: My Horse Looked Him in Eye
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5  They were racing down the backstetch of the 105th Kentucky Derby when the confrontation arose, about half a mile from home: Spectacular Bid on the outside in fourth place, Flying Paster on the inside in third place, and everybody elso waiting for the clash.

title: Nuclear Agency ReEvaluating Tests
description: WASHINGTON WHEN six new operators were licensed last November to work at the Salem nuclear generating plant in southern New Jersey, their employer  the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark  did not know that five of them had failed a section of the licensing examination testing their knowledge of systems that protect a reactor during emergencies.

title: A LONG LIFE IN THE THEATER; In his 55year career, Harold Clurman has directedwith passion  more than 40 plays, and written some of the finest dramatic criticism of our age. Now (fittingly) a theater has been named after him.
description: Tonight some 600 people, including many of the most famous names in the American theater, will gather to celebrate a phenomenon called Harold Clurman. At 77, Mr. Clurman is the grand young man of the American theater. He is both a figure in theatrical history and a vital contemporary force, a fact illustrated by the location of tonight's homage  the Harold Clurman Theater, a new stage on a onceseedy stretch of far West 42d Street. No glittering Broadway marquee for him, but Off Off Broadway and a youthfully enterprising company run by his friend, director Jack Garfein. Paying tribute to Mr. Clurman will be such notables as Elia Kazan, Arthur Miller, Walter Matthau, Julie Harris, Kim Stanley and Maureen Stapleton. All of these people owe the progress of their careers at some point to the perspicacity of Mr. Clurman. In his 55 years in the theater, Mr. CI urman has been marked by his frankness, audacity, persistence and conviction. Recently in an article he summed up the theater as indestructible and incorrigible, two adjectives that might also be applied to him.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: When I was a college freshman, I wrote a long paper on William Randolph Hearst, Shana Alexander said. I got an A  in Hearst. Now, I'm waiting to see what mark I get on the book. The book is Anyone's Daughter, about the times and trials of Patty Hearst; it's published this month by The Viking Press, and a review appears on page 3 of this issue. The book is also designed to tell something of the life, times and ideas of Shana Alexander.

title: Deaths
description: KLEIMANJoan. Beloved wile of Sidney. Devoted mother of Dr. Bet. tr. Dr. Devra Eisenberg, Ilene Elbourn and Charles. Loving grandmother of Russel?. Michael, Robert, Anya. Jake, Carl and Elise. Servi. cos today 2 PM at Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: BROADCASTING VIEW
description: For most people, radio is some form of music or news surrounded by commercials. For many, those aging hordes who grew up before the onslaught of television, radio represents a vast collection of fond memories, encompassing everything from Fibber McGee and Molly to Edward R. Murrow's World War H reports out of Londpn. Those were the Golden Years. Contrary to general impressions, though, the television boom did not completely cripple radio. Over the years, the older medium has steadily recovered its quota of listeners. Today, radio a flourishing business, transmitting its products into cars, kitchens, expensive stereo equipment, and those giant portable boxes lugged around by bopping teenagers. And, at least occasionally, radio can venture beyond the familiar borders of music and news. One rather stunning example provided by Wings, one of the most acclaimed dramas the current Broadway season. The Arthur Kopit play began as a project written specifically for radici.

title: Mild Earthquake Jolts Tokyo
description: TOKYO, May 5 (AP)  A mild earthquake jolted western Tokyo today but there were no reports of injuries or damage, officials said. The quake registered 4.5 on the Richter scale, according to the Japanese Meteorological Agency. This the level above which damage results. In Alaska, the Tsunami Warning Center reported a mild earthquake last night in a remote area near Mt. McKinley Park.

title: Can Mrs. Thatcher Avoid the Beartraps That Caught Heath?
description: For the past five years, Britons have been ruled by a Labor Government that looked more and more like a Tory one. Last week, voters swapped it for the genuine article. In an election dominated by economic issues, they turned the pursestrings over to Margaret Thatcher, a rightwing Conservative who has promised to face down the unions, cut income taxes and Government spending and revive British capitalism.

title: Susan Battles, G. B. Andrews Set June Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Battles of Andover, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Battles, to Gregory B. Andrews, son of Mrs. Larry Andrews of Mankato, Minn., and the late Mr. Andrews.

title: The First 4Minute Mile, 25 Years Later
description: On May 6, 1954  25 years ago today  Roger Bannister, an English medical student, became the first person to run a mile in under four minutes. It was one of history's great sports achievements and, to some people of that era, one of humanity's great accomplishments.

title: Radio
description: 77:40 A.M., WBLS: Tenant iurviv)al Program.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING The Lure of Lengthy Commuting
description: BARNEGAT WHAT with the continuing increases in gasoline prices and hints of shortages, it might be reasonable to conclude that New Jerseyans would think twice before moving to home in a location that would mean a long ride to work.

title: Maine Island Considers Central Electricity
description: MONHEGA1J ISLAND, Me., May 5 (AP)  While people across the nation are worried about the rising rates for electricity and the dangers of nuclear power, residents of this island are debating whether they should turn to centralized electricity for the first time.

title: SPORTS
description: DARIEN ONCE upon time in Persia, or maybe it was Tibet, a gang of bored cavalry soldiers began dragging a dead goat back and forth across the plains. With a whoop and a holler, another troop charged out on horseback and speared the goat away. Naturally, they were chased. As quick as you can say polo!  a new game was born.

title: Gretchen White Married to John F. Maloney
description: In St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in Chestnut Hill, Mass., yesterday, Gretchen Anne White, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank X. White Jr. of Wilmette, Ill., was married to John Frederick Maloney, son of Dr. and Mrs. James Henry Maloney of Waban and North Scituate, Mass. The Rev. John McCarthy performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. John Caulfield.

title: Inflation News Remains Unhappy
description: Most of the principal figures in last week's episode of Waiting for the Slowdown could be read several ways. Except, of course, for inflation, in the form of the Producer Price Index for Anril. which showed another unambiguous and unhealthy increase, 0.9 percent, for a compound annual rate this year of 13.1 percent. And although Administration officials were relieved by a slight abatement in food price increases (more rapidly  and noticeably  passed on to the consumer price level than other wholesale rises), there was a new worry. Recent energy price hikes have begun to filter through to other products. Plastics, for instance, were up 4 percent.

title: Rudolph P. Kunett, 85
description: Rudolph P. Kunett, founder of the country's first domestic vodka distillery, died Wednesday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 85 years old.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Finish pruning overgrown forsythia and rosebushes. Snap seedpods off earlyflowering tulips and daffodils to prevent them from developing but do not cut down the foliage; it must ripen to renew bulbs for next spring's bloom. Apply crabgrass controls to lawn. Last call to patch seed lawn bare spots.. Plant hardy annuals but wait to set out tender ones.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10:30 A.M. (Channel 2) For Our Times: social and ethical effects of the United States 67year involvement in Nicaragua.

title: Headliners
description: Nobody is perfect, but threestar generals are usually almost perfect. Lieut. Gen. Edward C. Meyer has had command and staff jobs, served in Europe, Korea and Vietnam, jogs four miles a day, and is described by his colleagues as cool, very smart, a thinker, aggressive and extremely articulate. President Carter met General Meyer for the first time a week ago yesterday. Mr. Carter was so impressed that last week he chose General Meyer to be Army Chief of Staff, jumping him over 18 more senior threeandfourstar generals to the highest job in the Army.

title: Fostering Venture Capital: A Tax Credit
description: The reduction in the capital gains tax rate from a maximum of 48 percent to 28 percent was hailed by Government officials and members of the investment community as a significant stimulus to capital investment, yet fails to deal with the root of the problem facing the capital markets today.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR; To the Boy Scouts, Who Sold the Schiff Estate; anyway.; Mendham; What Qualifies Someone To Teach Writing Course?; Highland Park; About the Lack of Parking For the Rutgers Museum; very disappointed.; Flemington
description: The Boy Scouts of America, who are supposed to be so concerned about preserving nature, getting back to the woods, protecting wildlife and being good neighbors, have sure made a spectacle of yourselves.

title: Letters: Sikkim-On Top of the World
description: To the Editor: My heart leaped when I read Grace Lichtenstein's article, Himalayan Adventure in Sikkim (Travel Section, April 15). It is indeed one of the most fascinating corners of the globe.

title: Rural China Women to Visit U.S
description: WASHINGTON May 5 (AP)  Women who live in the countryside of the United States and their counterparts in China will assemble here later this month to discuss mutual problems, according to an organization representing rural American women. Jane Threatt, president of Rural American Women Inc., said today that the Chinese delegation would observe the conditions affecting American women living in rural areas.

title: Law and Order in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  It's a cleaner, more subtle, more intelligent type of repression, said the former minister who had once served in the Cabinet of Christian Democratic President Eduardo Frei Montalva when Chile was still a fully functioning democracy a decade ago. It's true that nobody has disappeared or been murdered for political reasons for at least a year. The new secret police are less brutal than the old. They're also more sophisticated. Theres a change in the nature of the operation  but the basic structure remains the same.

title: Outside, Scalper Was the Star
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. May 5  His name was Arnie. He had come to Nassau Coliseum tonight about two hours before the start of the fifth game between the Islanders and the Rangers.

title: United Press International
description: HAMBURG BIRTHDAY FETE: An estimated 100,000 people watched the training ship Gorch Fock sail into the harbor yesterday as part of the celebration of the 790th anniversary of the West German city.

title: Carter Visits Hospital And Sees John Wayne
description: LOS ANGELES, May 5 (AP) President Carter visited John Wayne at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center today to tell him he had the love, affection and prayers of not only everybody in our own nation, but of millions of persons around the world.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: CEDARHURST  Photography exhibition; 10:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. tomorrow, Wednesday through Saturday; Loring Gallery, 661 Central Ave.

title: What's Doing on FIRE ISLAND
description: BARRIER BEACH  Fire Island is one of the best known and most widely misunderstood barrier beaches along the Atlantic Seaboard. The misunderstanding begins with the name; no one is quite sure how it developed. One theory is that an early printer set the type wrong or a clerk misread the name and converted Five Islands to Fire Island. The theory is backed by the fact that four inlets once divided what is now a 32milelong island. A more romantic explanation is that preRevolutionary residents built fires on the beach to lure passing boats to the shoals where they would flounder and could then be looted. Another version has the fires serving as a warning beacon to mariners, and yet another version ascribes the name to fires that were supposed to have burned to render oil from harpooned whales.

title: ANTIQUES
description: The booming Islamic art market has gone bust in some areas, has reached a plateau in others and is still inching upwards in manuscripts and miniatures. This mixed picture emerged following the Islamic art sales in late April at the London galleries of Sotheby Parke Bernet and Christie, Manson & Woods, auctions that served as the first fullscale test of this segment of the art market since the fall of the Shah's government.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Will Hold Convention In Miami Beach Despite Boycott
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 5 (AP)  The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will hold its 1980 national convention here, despite a boycott against Florida and other states that have not ratified the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: BRIDGE
description: Among the handful of American experts who are legitimate candidates for the title of best player of all time is B. Jay Becker of New York. who celebrated his 75th birthday yesterday. He does not have the public recognition of Charles Goren, the flamboyant personality of an Oswald Jacoby, or the convention creativity of a Sam Stayman. But his peers know that in the 47 years since he won a national title in his first year of tournament play he has made fewer mistakes in each 100 deals than any of his rivals. And it is accuracy that wins titles and tournaments, not deceptive bidding and exotic plays.

title: Both Sides in SchoolBus Drivers Strike Claim Victory
description: Each side in the threemonth strike by schoolbus drivers claimed success in the tentative settlement yesterday, with the Board of Education saying it had preserved the principle of open, competitive bidding and the Amalgamated Transit Union saying it had won job security provisions for its membership.

title: An Artistic Celebration of Paper in Rockland
description: THE art world used to be much simpler. Oils and acrylics were used for canvases, and ink, charcoal, lead and watercolor were used for paper. But the art world has become much more complex. It no longer observes such neat, clearcut distinctions. Now it is not uncommon to see oil or acrylic or both on paper and drawing materials on canvas. The art media no longer know their place.

title: F.B.I. Assailed by U.S. Court in Black Panther Case
description: CHICAGO, April 29  The Federal Bureau of Investigation and attorneys representing it have been strongly criticized by a Federal appeals court here that also said the agency should be sanctioned for its refusal to turn over documents ordered by a trial court in a $47 million suit against four of its agents and state law enforcement officials.

title: $1.7 Billion Overcharge, the Biggest Yet, Laid to Oil Concerns
description: Seven large oil companies were accused by the Department of Energy last week of overcharging rermers by $1.7 billion over six years. The figure represents the biggest alleged violation ever of Federal ceilings on crude oil prices.

title: Drive on Delinquency In Support Payments
description: MEN who have agreed to support their families through courtordered payments are beginning to hear a new message in Westchester County: There may be warrants awaiting them if they don't pay on time.

title: God We Trust Motto Opposed on U.S. Coins
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 4 (UPI) Madalyn Murray O'Hair, the atheist leader, and her son have asked the United States Supreme Court to order removal of the phrase In God We Trust from coins and currency.

title: Letter TO THE EDITOR
description: Bravo Richard J. Barnet! Challenging the Myths of National Security (April 1) should be required reading for everyone, particularly members of Congress and, of course, all members of the executive branch.

title: Deson C. Sze, Retired From Brokerage Firm; Son of an Ambassador
description: Deson Chungyuan Sze, retired vice president of Smith Barney Harris Upham & Company, the brokerage house, died Friday at Beth Israel Hospital at the age of 66. He had lived in Manhattan.

title: James Brown Leads Penn Track Victory
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 5 James Brown of the University of Pennsylvania finished his four years of Heptagonal track and field competition with a flourish today. Brown led his teammates to Penn's seventh Heptagonal team championship in the last eight years with victories in the 100meter dash and the long jump, as Penn scored 62 points to 50 for Cornell, the defending champion, and 97 for Army.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Howard Ruff hates to write. The author of How to Prosper During the Coming Bad Years describes a previous book as lousy. Such demurrers aside, the 48yearold selfdescribed economic ecologist has hit the best seller list with an impressive bang and has two more advice books on the way.

title: Bill Lucas of Braves Dead at 43; Highest Black Official in Baseball
description: ATLANTA, May 5 (UPI)  Bill Lucas, vice president of the Atlanta Braves and the highestranking black official in professional baseball, died today as the result of a massive brain hemorrhage suffered last Wednesday. He was 43 years old.

title: Helen Ann Thomas Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Randolph Hopkins of Harwood, Md., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Helen Ann Thomas, to Jonathan Eber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Eber of Clifton, N.J. A July wedding is planned. The future bride is the adopted daughter of Mr Hopkins.

title: MEXICO LIBERALIZES RULES FOR CAMPAIGN
description: MEXICO CITY, May 5 All over Mexico, walls are suddenly sprouting names that are unknown to most of the public. And, in a few weeks, just as suddenly, the names will return to obscurity as the walls are whitewashed and posters taken down.

title: North Korean Woman Loses Table Tennis Title
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea, May 5 (AP)  Pak Yong Sun of North Korea, the twotime defending champion, lost her women's title in thd World Table Tennis Championships today as fifthseeded Tong Ling, a 16yearold Chinese, scored an 821, 2022, 2115, 2116, 2115 upset.

title: Procedure at the 87th Precinct
description: HE first of Ed McBain's 87th Precinct stories, Cop Hater, appeared in 1956, and for a while he published two or three tales about the Precinct each year. The pace has slackened, so that they are now annuals, and perhaps in part because of this slackening the standard remains remarkably high. Mr. McBain did not invent the police procedural story, in which the investigation of a crime is shown as it is handled by a police department, but his books are among the best in the field.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: After reading the recent article Marriage Groups Encountering Criticism, we felt compelled to write in support of the Marriage Encounter program.

title: BIG STAFF REFLECTS KENNEDY INFLUENCE
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  When the subject of radiation exploded into public awareness recently, investigators for Senator Edward M. Kennedy's staff uncovered documents disclosing a coverup of the dangers posed by nuclear testing. After the Senator publicized the documents at a Congressional hearing, they made frontDaze news.

title: Hicksville Museum Is Up for Grabs
description: HICKSVILLE ON the eve of its 15th anniversary, the financially strapped Gregory Museum, the Long Island Earth Science Center, is up for grabs.

title: Cambodia Needs Food From Abroad to Avoid Mass Starvation
description: BANGKOK, Thailand  Cambodians are once more addressing a mute question to the world, and the answer, for now, is silence. The question: Who will feed a nation whose food has been largely destroyed by war and whose future food supply can hardly be planted while fighting continues?

title: Spectacular Bid Takes Kentucky Derby by 2 Lengths
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5  When Ron Franklin wants Spectacular Bid to turn it on, he just chirps to him and says, Let's go, daddy.

title: Greek Public Servants Strike
description: ATHENS, May 4 (Reuters)  About 120,000 teachers and civil servants went on a twoday strike in Greece today to press demands for more pay and better conditions. Schools will be kept open by teachers who have refused to join the strike, an official spokesman said.

title: GARDENING Corn: How Sweet It Can Be in the Summer
description: MAIZE is the only grain that Americans call corn, and its origins are somewhere in the remote past.

title: A Stargazer For Baseball
description: THE players didn't know it, but they were being judged. As each batter stepped up to home plate, one of the spectators was looking him up and down, checking his size, stance and swing. If he connected with the ball, the same man surreptiously consulted a stopwatch and timed his run to first base. When a fielder threw, caught, or even moved toward a ball, that, too, was noted by the unobtrusive observer.

title: MAYOR'S CETA PLAN PUZZLES SOME AIDES
description: Mayor Koch's plan to shift some jobs now paid under the federally financed Comprehensive Employment and Training Act back to the city payroll has caused some confusion among city officials who must deal with it.

title: United Press International
description: SPECTACULAR BID WINS KENTUCKY DERBY: Ron Franklin guiding favorite to finish of the 105th running at Churchill Downs yesterday. Section 5.

title: Music: Ravel and Debussy by Los Angeles Philharmonic
description: Music by Ravel and Debussy made up the second of the three programs being given currently in Carnegie Hall by the Los Angeles Philharmonic under its new music director, Carlo Maria Giulini. Played on Friday night. it ineluded the Mother Goose suite and Sheherazade of Ravel, with Frederica von Stade as soloist in the latter. Debussy was represented by the Prelude a d'un fame and La Mer.

title: ARTA
description: NEW HAVEN KENNETH MARTIN enjoys considerable renown in England for his Constructivist art and, in 1975, was honored by a major retrospective at the Tate Gallery. He is now receiving fullscale exposure here  long overdue  at the Yale Center for British Art, where 128 of his sculptures, paintings, drawings and screenprints may be seen through June 17.

title: The Tour Bus may of Seeing Castles in Spain
description: A retired United States Air Force general who lives near the walled city of Avila, which is about 70 miles northwest of Madrid, told.me that the Marquis of Santo Domingo owns a house built right into the 11thcentury battlements. He not only owns the house but also 14 neighboring stone towers and the intervening walls. The general asked the Marquis why he did not leave it to the city to maintain hiS towers and walls. What, the Marquis protested, and have my privacy invaded?

title: Cosmos Meet Hurricane Today
description: The Cosmos returned from their 10 victory over the Toronto Blizzard Friday night to prepare for a game with the Houston Hurricane at Giants Stadium this afternoon.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor: In his article, What the Army Learned From Business, (April 15) Professor Gabriel makes an important distinction between managers and leaders. His observations in this regard are apt food for thought for any organization or institution that attempts to accomplish its purposes through people.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY Look What You've Done Now, OPEC
description: AS IF the escalating costs of gasoline and home heating oil aren't enough, OPEC had to go and cause one of my storm windows to be bent a few weeks ago.

title: Other World Events
description: Terrorizing civilians to strike at their own dictatorial regime, Salvadoran guerrillas last week seized the French and Costa Rican embassies and a Roman Catholic cathedral, demanding the release of three guerrilla leaders. The attackers, members of the Popular Revolutionary Bloc leftist trade union and peasant groups, killed two policemen and a private guard. They were holding 30 hostages, including the French and Costa Rican ambassadors.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Amystery coin, a disowned dollar that may be worth upwards of half a million dollars, will soon be displayed at selected museums and shows around the country. It is the only overt specimen of the silver dollar of 1866 that does not carry the motto: In God We Trust.

title: Deaths
description: ADLERBecky. The Officers and Members of the Nettie Peckler Auxiliary P.J.C.S. are deeply sorrowed by the passing of the beloved mother of our esteemed members Lillian Bernstein, Selma Goldfine and Lee Kanter. Heartfelt condolences to her husband Joseph Adler.

title: Carter, on Coast, Promises to Protect Human Rights of Illegal Aliens
description: LOS ANGELES, May 5  President Carter pledged today to protect the basic human rights of illegal aliens but found both his policies and intentions questioned by leaders of the MexicanAmerican community.

title: Susan L. Buck Is Betrothed To Christopher Grant Jr.
description: Susan Louise Buck and Christopher Grant Jr., alumni of Williams College, will be married in September. Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Buck Jr. of Storrs, Conn., parents of the future bride, have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Grant of Dedham, Mass.

title: 5 Jersey Teamster Officers Guilty Of a Kickback Plot With 9 Banks
description: CAMDEN, N.J., May 5 (UPI)  After the longest jury deliberation in the history of the Federal Court here, five Paterson teamster officers have been found guilty of charges of depositing union. funds in nine state banks in return for kickbacks and loans.

title: School Press, With More Articles on Controversial Topics, Is Under Increasing Attack
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 I don't think Mr. Rivadue would allow that, said Kevin Cloherty, listening, impressed but dubious, to a speaker at the recent convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association.

title: Spurs Keep Bullets in a Rut
description: The highscoring Phoenix Sun guard made that assessment midway through the National Basketball Association season and there were few who would argue with him. It was also correct to assume when the playoffs began almost a month ago that the Bullets had an excellent chance to become the first team to repeat as champions since the 1969 Boston Celtics.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: A program of songs and dances based on poems written by children interned at the Terezin Concentration Camp in Czechoslovakia will be performed by the Wendy Osserman Dance Company at the Y.M.Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey in West Orange. through Terezin on their way to Auschwitz, only 100 survived. I Never Saw Another Butterfly is based on the poems and pictures they left behind. Miss Osserman, who has choreographed the fulllength piece, with music by Peter Schlosser, is on the dance faculty of Rutgers University. Admission to the performance, which starts at 3 P.M., is $5. The Y is at 760 Northfield Avenue, West Orange. Telephone: (201) 7363200.

title: Births DANSON
description: Wayne and Jill (nee Davis) Joyfully announce the birth of Erik's brother. Michael Evan, on April 17, 1979.

title: Englewood Beset  By Racial Dispute
description: ENGLEWOOD BLACK leaders in this comfortable Bergen County community have begun a concerted voterregistration drive in the predominantly black Fourth Ward, and in so doing, the leaders  most of whom are Democrats are taking aim at their own party.

title: SchoolAid Tangle
description: As is often the case with highly controversial issues, most of the noise over state schoolaid formulas has been and will be heard in the Legislature, but the solutions will probably come in the state's courts.

title: Deaths
description: PILOFRobert G.. beloved husband of Dolores, devoted father of Ellen Iris Finkelstein and Judith Pilot, devoted brother of Theresa Greenberg, Helen Eiancio, Esther Horowitz, Bertha Strassner and Harold Pilot. Services today. 12 noon, Garlick's. Coney Island Ave at Ave N. Brooklyn.

title: 'superman as the Marathon Man
description: NOT every member of the Suburban Roadrunners Club wears a Superman outfit. Most content themselves with more traditional sweatshirts and running shoes while practicing at dawn and dusk in their neighborhoods in Westchester. But the president of the yearold club, created for the weekend athlete who enters races more for fun than glory, has attracted approximately 1,500 members by running in garb that Lois Lane might mistake for the real thing.

title: On a Sunday Built for Bicycles
description: WANT to ride your bike for 10 miles on a smooth, wide road in Westchester without dodging cars, trucks, buses or dogs? You can do it on the Bronx River Parkway on Sunday from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. The fivemile stretch of the parkway between the Harney Road exit and the County Center will be offlimits to all cars, motorcycles and motor bikes for Westchester's first Bicycle Sunday of the year.

title: Europe's Big Festival Season
description: At probably no other time in history have more musical riches been available to the traveler than right now. New works are proliferating. Older works are being revived, and lost or hitherto unperformed works are being discovered. Keeping up with the trend, music festivals are growing in number and size to provide an ever increasing choice, ranging from the ancient to the contemporary in the classics, and from folk music to jazz and rock in the popular field.

title: Tennis Reflects Life, Gerulaitis Sr. Finds
description: KINGS POINT HIS eyes lighting up with humor, Vitas Gerulaitis Sr. put down the telephone and said: Some people just don't understand what it takes to make a good tennis player. They think it can happen overnight with iust a few tins.

title: DINING OUT
description: RISTORANTE MARANGOLA in Sayville is a small place, vaguely English pub in style, what with its leaded glass windows and lights and dark, halftimbered and woodpaneled walls. While the setting is rather incongruous for an Italian restaurant, the dining rooms are comfortable and the tables nicely appointed.

title: What Is Ahead For Channel 13?
description: LITTLE has been heard so far about a recent Federal Communications Commission decision regarding WNET (Channel 13) in Newark. On or before May 19, WNET will have to make known to the F.C.C. the plans it has to build a full studio facility and offices in its city of license (Newark).

title: kID BY COAST GUARD IN TOWING GARBAGE ORDERED BY CARTER
description: Responding to appeals from Mayor Koch and Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel, the Carter Administration yesterday directed the Coast Guard to help New York City haul garbage aboard sanitation barges immobilized by the 35dayold tugboat strike.

title: World News Briefs
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, May 6 (UPI) Tanzanianled Government forces completed their takeover of most of northeast Uganda today and moved into the northwest, where troops loyal to Idi Amin were reportedly planning a last stand.

title: Friars Toast Carson, Entertainer of Year
description: Months before Johnny Carson turned into one of the news stories of the year, the Friars Club of New York had picked him, unannounced, as Entertainer of the Year. Last night, riding the crest in both roles, the host of The Tonight Show was saluted, needled and embraced at the club's 75th anniversary dinner for nearly 1,500 guests at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: A StarStudded Party Honors Harold Clurman
description: Harold Clurman, wearing a red velvet suit to set the place on fire, arrived at the theater bearing his name last night, stared up at his name in lights, and announced: IBIS tneater nas a very noose name mine. Then he giggled devilishly.

title: Jet Noise: Senate Passes Easier Rules
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  Legislation that passed the Senate last week virtually unnoticed and that may be taken up in the House this week would soften rules against airplane noise, even though many airlines have been complying with them.

title: Food Price Rise Seen Slowing
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) Food prices will rise at the slowest pace of the year at least through May, a Government report said.

title: Jazz: Arthur Blyth and Quintet
description: ARTHUR BLYTH who was at the Public Theater over the weekend leading one of his adventuresome quintets, has a new album out, his first for Columbia Records. For seriously exploratory artist like Mr. Blyth, recording for Columbia is something of a career milestone, and the company seems justifiably proud of both the artist and the record.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON MORE trouble may be in store for the Administration's price standard. Officials at the Council on Wage and Price Stability are worrying that their original goal of designing guidelines that would lead to a deceleration in the rate of price increases may be in jeopardy as a result of large increases in business costs that are not controlled by the program, principally those of energy and other commodities.

title: Bees Endangered by Insecticide Resembling Pollen
description: The honeybee, steadily declining in recent years because of urbanization and the use of pesticides, is facing an even greater hazard  a relatively new kind of insecticide that resembles grains of pollen.

title: Notes on People
description: In Paris, Roman Polanski offered no timetable, but he said he definitely planned to return to the United States for sentencing on his guilty plea to having had unlawful sexual relations with a 13yearold girl. The film director has been living in an apartment on the Right Bank of Paris since he fled California on Feb. 1,1978, the day before he was be sentenced by a judge in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Expos: Serious Contenders at Last
description: WARREN CROMARTIE, the 25yearold Montreal Expo left fielder, enjoys telling this story: It was our first home game of the season.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: KHUDOZHNIK REPIN (Baltatlantic LineNorton Lilly). Rotterdam May 21. Bremerhaven 22. Hamburg 23, Tilbury, ZS and Letlavre 26; sails from Port Elizabeth N.J.

title: New Relay for Voice of America
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)  The Voice of America radio network today inaugurated a new satellite relay system that it said would enable millions of listeners in the Far East and South Asia to receive a clearer signal.

title: Remembering Dr. King
description: A youngster in the crowd joined parade along Fifth Avenue yesterday carrying a portrait of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Occasion was the 12th annual Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Parade, originally known as the 369th Veterans Association Mgmorial Parade. After the death of the civil rights leader, the organizers renamed ale event in his memory.

title: Chess:
description: MONTREAL, May 6  Anatoly Karpov, the world chess champion, and Mikhail Tal, a former champion, both of the Soviet Union, shared first prize in the Man and His World Chess Challenge Cup international tournament here in the Maison du Quebec. They each won $21,500.

title: Sharp Rise in Success For Heart Transplants Is Hailed by Specialist
description: CHICAGO, May 6 (AP)  Seventy percent of the recipients of heart transplants live at least a year after the operation, indicating that the procedure can be considered clinically effective, a Stanford University heart specialist says.

title: AUSTRIAN SOCIALISTS INCREASE MAJORITY
description: VIENNA, May 6  Austria's governing Socialist Party increased its narrow majority in Parliament in national elections today.

title: 2 Walk Away From Plane Crash After Trying to Land on Thruway
description: MONSEY, N.Y. (UPI)  A small private plane crashed into an overpass while attempting to make an emergency landing yesterday afternoon on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in this Rockland County community, but the pilot and a passenger suffered only minor injuries, authorities said.

title: Theater: Knockout, La Russo's Ring Drama
description: NEVER having been to a prize fight, I have no real grounds to judge the stage bout that serves as a climax to the play Knockout. For what it is. worth, it seemed a soso affair to me. with lots of boxingglove per square blow.

title: Martha Cooksey Wins
description: SPRINGDALE, Ohio, May 6 (AP)Martha Cooksey breezed to victory today in the women's national Amateur Athletic Union 30kilometer (18mile) race in 1 hour 53.06 minutes. The Californian broke clear of the pack at the 12mile mark and, after taking the lead at 13 miles, was never challenged. Kris Banks of Reading, Pa., was second, 1:09 behind.

title: Letters
