description: To the Editor: The Administration's program to abate the continuing unchecked inflation has been met with but limited compliance. The longer this evil inflation continues, the more difficult will be the return to a stable economy.

title: TERRORISM IN ITALY BECOMES VOTE ISSUE
description: ROME, May 6  Political terrorism has begun to overshadow the Italian election campaign, which officially got under way Friday when the parties posted their lists of 10,000 candidates for 315 seats in the Senate and 630 seats in the Chamber of Deputies.

title: KHOMEINI ORGANIZES A NEW ARMED FORCE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 6  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has ordered the formation of a special armed force, responsible only to the secret religious Revolutionary Couticil, to protect the Islamic revolution.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles. (TelevisionCablevision, 10:25 P.M. RadioWMCA, WGBB, 10:25 P.M.)

title: Deaths
description: POLLITTLeanore Levine. Our deepest expression of sympathy to Basil and Kettle PoHitt. Belle and Joseph Levine and Zeena Kassel, wife of our President, on the testimely death of Lee, beloved wife, mother, daughter, and sister. To the family we extend our heartfelt condolences.

title: Outdoors Taking Your Child Along With You
description: IF you are moved to introduce your youngstering to the delights of fishing, camping, canoeing or hiking proceed with sensitivity, realizing, particularly if you area passionate devotee of the outdoor life, that what is a rewarding, relaxing day to you may soon become boring to your offspring.

title: Music: Bach Cello Suites by Neikrug
description: AT this late date it seems hardly imperative to remark that Bach's solo sonatas, partitas and suites for violin and cello represent some sort of apex of Western musical creativity. But when someone comes along and offers them to us  as George Neikrug did Saturday afternoon with the complete cello suites at Alice Tully Hall  one is struck once again at how remarkable this music is.

title: Mrs. Thatcher's Uphill Task
description: LONDON, May 6  Not quite a decade ago, a new Conservative Prime Minister came to power in Bntain, determined to make a clean break with collectivism, to cut income taxes, to trim Government spending and to restore tree collective bargaining.

title: Deaths
description: JACOBSBeatrice Edith Moore, passed away at State University Hospital of Downstate Medical Center, Saturday, May 5, 1979. A solemn Mass of the Resurrection in thanksgiving of her life will be offered at St. Augustine's Episcopal Church, 20 Madison St. Brooklyn on Tuesday, May 8 at 10AM. She was the wife of the Reverend W. G. Henson Jacobs, Rector. St. Augustine's Episcopal Parish, Brcoklyn. and is survived by her three sons Rithard of Trinidad. Godfrey of Washington. D.C. Ian of Jamaica and her two daughters Mary Nelson of New Brunswick, NJ, Monica Murphy of Brooklyn, NY and their families. She Is also survived by her two sisters and five grandchildren. Remains will lie in state 1 to 9. Monday at House of Hills. 406 Rogers Ave.

title: Who Will Regulate U.S. Trade?
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  An interagency battle has broken out over how to reorganize foreign trade responsibilities in the Federal bureaucracy as a result of impending new international agreements.

title: In Hartford, $5 Buys Priceless View
description: HARTFORD, May 4  The neighbors of the oldest statehouse in the country have decided that a window on history is worth paying for, and they have come up with a 200yearold idea that will help preserve the Revolutionera building.

title: Sundstrand Halts Sale
description: The Sundstrand Corporation said that the previously announced negotiations to sell its compressor division to the Jard Company of Bennington, Vt., had been terminated. No reason was given. Last month, Sundstrand said it had signed an agreement in principle to sell the division for about $18 million in cash and notes and to lease certain assets to Jard.

title: Waggling Hand in a Car Leads to Arrest of Three
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 6 (AP)  A human hand waggling for help from the trunk of a car led a reporter and a photographer for The Birmingham News on a 30minute chase yesterday.

title: Susan J. Douglas Is Bride of Student
description: Susan Jeanne Douglas, daughter of Col. Harry Vincent Douglas, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Douglas of South River, N.J., was married yesterday to Taylor Randolph Durham Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Durham of Webster Groves, Mo. The ceremony was performed in Glen Manor House in Portsmouth, R.I., by the Rev. Hamilton Brown of the Potomac Valley United Church of Christ in Washington.

title: GOING OUTGuide
description: SCORES Some prestigious names in literature and music will be heard from in two free events in the auditorium of the City University Graduate Center, 33 \Vest 42d Street.

title: Advertising
description: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS, an international advertising agency whose London office has been servicing British Airways in Britain since 1948, has just become the agency for the airline worldwide. That raises the billings to $30 million from $9 million.

title: Deaths
description: AHRENSJane M.. on Sunday, May 6, 1979. beloved wife of the late Walter. devoted mother of Diane N. Marino, Mary J. Hibbard, the late Dennis M., Ellen E., Anne F. Deignan, J. Eileen Zone and Lucy L. Ahrens. Loving sister of James G. Murray. Also survived by 14 grandchildren. Reposing at the Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Ave., Rockville Centre, N.Y. Mass of the Resurrection St. Agnes Cathedral, Tuesday, May 8, 8 PM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. Westbury, N.Y., private. Family will receive friends Monday, 25 and 7.9 PM, and Tuesday, 25 PM.

title: Col. Robert Heinl Jr.; Columnist and Author Of History of Marines
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  Robert D. Heinl Jr., a retired colonel in the United States Marine Corps and a former syndicated columnist and author, died of a heart attack yesterday in Saint Barthelemy, a Caribbean Island. He was 62 years old..

title: Woman College Student Found Slain in Bathtub
description: A 24yearold Brooklyn woman was found stabbed to death last night in the bathtub of her apartment in the Fort. Greene Housing Project, the police reported.

title: Iran Receives Oil Payments
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 6 (UPI) Iran has received $600 million in the first payments for resumed oil exports and hopes to earn $1.4 billion a month from oil sales, Mohammad Ali Mowlawi, governor of the central bank, said.

title: Television.
description: 5:55(4)Coping with Inflation

title: 25 Bus Shelters On City Streets Found Smashed
description: At least 25 bus shelters in midtown Manhattan were smashed early yesterday morning, causing several thousands of dollars in damage and littering the streets with millions of chunks of fiberglass.

title: Califano Orders Steps Toward Halting Sales Of Many Sleep. Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)  Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that the Government would act quickly to remove many wellknown nonprescription sleeping aids from the market because of the risk that an ingredient, methapyrilene. caused cancer.

title: One Youth Problem at a Time
description: We and others have occasionally toyed with the idea of a national service corps that would alleviate such domestic ills as teenage unemployment, young people's disaffection, the decline of community services and the lack of Artily volunteers. Now the idea has been endorsed by a diligent study committee, led by Jacqueline Wexler, the outgoing president of Hunter College, and Harris Wofford, former president of Bryn Mawr. The panel proposes a corps of a million young volunteers aged 16 to 25 that would cost $8 billion year. The idea is still appealing but it does not seem practical in the foreseeable future.

title: McEnroe Overcomes a Tired Borg
description: DALLAS, May 6  The fastestrising star in tennis, John McEnroe of Douglaston, Queens, won his second major title in tour months today, defeating topranked Bjorn Borg in the World Championship Tennis final, 75, 46, 62, 76.

title: Highway Suit Filed by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)  The Government is suing eight Chicagoarea corporations and six of their officials today for damages in an alleged highway construction bidrigging conspiracy.

title: Sports News Briefs.
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6 (AP)  The University of California, Los Angeles, capped a perfect season last night, defeating its crosstown rival, Southern California, 1215, 1512, 1511, 157, to win the National Collegiate volleyball championship.

title: Cincinnati Policeman Killed
description: CINCINNATI, May 6 (UPI)  A policeman was shot and killed yesterday by a suspect he chased into an alley. The officer, Melvin Henze, 28 years old, is the fourth Cincinnati policeman shot and killed while on duty in the last year. The police said Officer Henze, on patrol alone in his car, sighted and followed a man wanted for allegedly pointing a gun at a resident earlier. lie drove the car into an alley, where the suspect apparently shot him. Other officers captured the suspect, whose identity was withheld.

title: Hatcher, Seeking 4th Term as Gary's Mayor, Faces Primary Contest
description: GARY, Ind., May 6 (AP)  Mayor Richard G. Hatcher, seeking a fourth fouryear term, is facing his toughest challenge since upsetting the whitedominated Democratic Party machine in 1967.

title: Bridge:
description: The concluding stages of the Grand National Teams in New York are tougher than anywhere else in the country. The caliber of the play and the intensity of the players resemble a national knockout team championship final.

title: Rash of Racial Violence To Be Investigated by F.B.I.
description: DECATUR, Ala., May 6  The Federal Bureau of Investigation tomorrow is to begin looking into a shooting this weekend into a house owned by a black family in a white neighborhood. The police here said that 12 shots were fired from a highpowered rifle, narrowly missing several children. No one was injured.

title: Most Unions' Leaders Still Favor Building Atom Plants to Get Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  At its last meeting, the executive council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations voted to press for accelerated development of nuclear power, with only William Winpisinger, president of the machinists' union, voting no.

title: Nehemiah Smashes World Mark
description: LOS ANGELES, May 6  A meeting in the 110meter high hurdles that began with hot words and controversy ended today in a worldrecord performance by Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah.

title: Rock: Irish Boomtown Rats Appear
description: FIRST there were the Good Rats, the fine Long Island rock band, and then there was the Rat, Boston's premier newwave rock club. But for the moment. at least.

title: POOR NATIONS PRESS RICH TO CLOSE CAP
description: MANILA. May 6  Delegates from 159 nations open a threeweek conference here tomorrow to measure the chasm between rich and poor countries and debate ways of bridging it.

title: Auto Crush Poses Problems in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., May 3  The road to the American dream in this century for Puerto Ricans has been filled with struggle and cultural contradictions. For many, that road today is also filled with traffic congestion, the stifling smell of exhaust fumes and the high cost of operating a car.

title: Cabaret: Jonathan Schwartz
description: JONATHAN SCHWARTZ is a disk jockey and a novelist. He is also the son of Arthur Schwartz, who has written such songs as Dancing in the Dark, Alone Together and I Guess I'll Have to Change My Plan. So when he turns to singing, as he is doing at Michael's Pub through Saturday, he brings to his performance a background and approach that are a bit different from those of a singer who is primarily a singer.

title: Right of Women to SelfDefense Gaining in Battered Wife Cases
description: It was the most brutal act in recent history, said David Berg, the lawyer who defended Diana Cervantes Barson in her trial for the murder of her commonlaw husband in Houstoh. And it took the jury only one hour and 40 Minutes to acquit her.

title: ABC News Establishes Jayne Fellowship Program
description: ABC News has established a fellowship program at Columbia University in memory of David W. Jayne 3d, a senior producer who was killed in a 1977 plane crash while on assignment in Jordan.

title: Busy Week in Municipals
description: Taxexempt financing activity will pick up some speed this week as more than $1 billion of new notes and bonds come to market for the first time in month.

title: Houston Hearin Told of MexicanAmerican Fears on '80 Census
description: HOUSTON, May 6  Representatives of a variety of MexicanAmerican groups are expressing strong fears that next year's nationwide census will again pass many of them by, with a resulting loss of jobs, federally financed programs and, perhaps most important, influence at the polls over the decade to come.

title: DOROTHY BARKO
description: Dorothy Barko, a New York City attorney who specialized in trusts and estates, died Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. Miss Barko, who lived in Manhattan, was 79 years old.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON, May 6  There has been same American concern that a British Government under Margaret Thatcher would raise problems for U.S. foreign policy. The Carter Administration, it was said, might find it hard to work with so ideological a Conservative  especially on the tough issues of southern Africa, where her sympathies were with the white minorities.

title: Pacific Coast Highway Reopens After 24 Days
description: MALIBU, Calif., May 6 (AP)  The Pacific Coast Highway was reopened today, 24 days after sliding rock and dirt covered a 500foot stretch of the road and threatened to destroy homes on the hill sloping down from the road. At one point the landslide had threatened six $500,000 homes below the highway.

title: 65,000 DEMONSTRATE AT CAPITOL TO HALT ATOMIC POWER UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  More than 65,000 people marched peacefully from the White House to the Capitol today in the largest demonstration against nuclear Dower the country has seen.

title: Cosmos Top Hurricane, 30
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May  The Cosmos reduced the Houston Hurricane to a spring shower at Giants Stadium this afternoon, defeating the visitors. 30.

title: New Vogue for Critic of Keynes
description: FREIBURG, West Germany, May  Friedrich A. von Hayek, one, of the strongest, and at times one of the few, economic voices advocating the reduction of government's role in the economy, is finally finding himself in the position of a Cassandra who suddenly that discovers people are listening. On the eve of his 80th birthday, the Nobel laureate is back in fashion.

title: 12 Injured as Train and Engine Collide at Penn Station
description: A fourcar Amtrak passenger train was sideswiped by a switch engine just outside Pennsylvania Station yesterday afternoon, derailing both locomotives and injuring 12 of the 150 persons aboard.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: As the telephone industry gears for an era of less Federal regulation, the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation has moved one of its veteran executives into the slot with primary responsibility for telephone operations.

title: In Defense Of My Executed Brother
description: Mr. Prime Minister, I cannot hide it; the recent murder of my brother has deeply shocked and revolted me. And should I stress the word murder, it is simply because no other word can be used for the kind of mock justice he was subjected to in the dead of night in front of masked judges!

title: Whalers Win, Tie Series, 33
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 6 (AP)  The New England Whalers, led by John McKenzie and Dave Keon, escaped elimination from the World Hockey Association playoffs tonight by defeating the Edmonton Oilers, 84.

title: Recital: Horowitz At Fisher
description: THERE were several things worthy of notice about Vladimir Horowitz's concert yesterday afternoon, outside of the fact that he played beautifully, which should occasion nosurprise. For one thing, he played in Avery Fisher Hall for the first time. For another, almost everything on the program was being played by him for the first time in New York. In this respect Mr. Horowitz is different from most veteran pianists, who coast for years on much the same repertory. Every time that Mr. Horowitz gives a New York recital he manages to get on it a piece that either is new to him or that he has not played for many years.

title: Cards Win
description: Shortly after the season started, 39yearold Lou Brock, the major league career leader in stolen bases, announced that this would be his last year. He said he wanted only to reach one more milestone  3,000 hits. He started the season, his 19th, with 2,900.

title: A Typical Day in Israel: 40,000 on Strike, Raids on Lebanon and Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM, May 6  The day began with a general strike by 40,000 civil service workers that gave the country the aura of a Sabbath. Early this morning, the armed forces announced that an air raid had been carried out against suspected Palestinian guerrilla positions in northern Lebanon.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Over the short run, bond yields may have risen about as far as they are going to. For the long run, the outlook for the credit markets remains as olnorriv es ever.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Fishermen who have avoided walking into a stream because of the discomfort in wearing heavy, cumbersome waders now have reason to chance their minds. Royal Red Ball has added an inflatable air cham ber, sealed around the chest, and this not only keeps water from flowing freely over the top of the wader but also adds buoyancy, helping the fisherman stay afloat when he loses his footing or steps off into a deep spot. The air chamber can be inflated while the boot worn: simply blow through a valve in the inside pouch. This new wader is called the Flyweight, is available five sizes and can be ordered for $59 a pair, plus $2 for postage, from Sporting GoodsSuppliers, 541 Bishop Street NW, Atlanta 30318, (404) 3521600.

title: COURTS STILL VEXED BY DELAYS IN TRIALS
description: ST. LOUIS, May 5  Because the pace of justice is slow here, 500 defendants await trial in a facility that was designed to house convicted felons.

title: TV: Close to Home, About a Bitter Strike
description: CLOSE to Home, produced by Philip Garvin for Boston station WGBHTV, is a portrait of a bitter strike and its disruptive effects on a quiet Detroit suburb. Narrated by Jim Lehrer, the thoughtful, remarkably evenhanded documentary can be seen tonight at o'clock on publictelevision Channels 13 and 21.

title: Help for Cities: BudgetCutting Making Impact
description: On March 27, 1978, President Carter announced what his Administration has called the nation's first explicit and unified urban policy. Thirteen months later, at the end of last month, the Mayors of Pittsburgh, Newark, Waltham, Mass.; York, Pa., and Toledo, Ohio, left the White House after a legislative strategy session and piled into a gray Chevrolet van.

title: Korean Art Show Begins TwoYear Tour of U.S.
description: The largest collection of Korean art treasures ever displayed in the United States has begun a twoyear, sevenmuseum tour in San Francisco, where the exhibition, 5,000 Years of Korean Art is on display at the Asian Art Museurri.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: China is making major readjustments in economic development priorities, Li Qiang, Minister of Foreign Trade, confirmed. But it has not abandoned its fundamental goal of modernization. He made the statement at a dinner for Juanita M. Kreps, the American Commerce Secretary, who is in Peking. [Page D1.]

title: Henrietfe Schnitzer, 84, Long in Yiddish Theater
description: Henriette Schnitzer, a Yiddish actress who began her stage career at the age of in her native Rumania, died Friday in Miami Beach. She was 84 years old.

title: Israeli Planes Kill 7 During Strikes On Village and Camp in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, May 6  Israeli jets attacked a Palestinian camp and a neighboring village in northern Lebanon today, killing seven and wounding 90, according to Palestinians, Lebanese and the staterun Lebanese radio.

title: Experiment Expanded For VoiceOnlyBoxes Calling In Fire Alarms
description: The New York City Fire Department will expand today its successful fivemonth drive to cut down on costly and potentially disastrous responses to false alarms by answering alarms from voiceoperated boxes only when a voice is actually heard requesting help.

title: Abducted Chicago Baby Found
description: CHICAGO, May 6 (UPI)  A teenager allegedly kidnapped a 5monthold baby from a suburban couple for three days, then abandoned the infant in the back yard of a South Side home, the police said. The baby, Stevie Joy Newtoff, was in good condition at Holy Cross Hospital. The police said Richard and Sharon Newtoff of Hickory Hills reported Wednesday that a 14yearold girl living with them had abducted their baby. Walter Wayrnar found the baby yesterday in his yard.

title: Dance: Ballet Hispanico Presents New Chaaa
description: SATURDAY night's concert by the Ballet Hispanico of New York at the Symphony Space was always lively, yet not always very interesting. Although new works had been scheduled by Lois Bewley and the company's director, Tina Ramirez, Miss Ramirez's piece had to be postponed. That left Miss Bewley's Chaaa as the evening's novelty. Like the program in general, it was lively, but not really very interesting.

title: Event of the Year for Aspiring Young Dance Students
description: Christopher d'Amboise, center, leading rehearsal of dance number with members of a class of hearingimpaired students who were part of The Event of the Year last night at Madison Square Garden. The program, at the Felt Forum, was conceived by his father, Jacques d'Amboise, the dancer and choreographer, who was for 30 years principal dancer with the New York City Ballet. Hundreds of children from dance schools in the metropolitan area participated with Mikhail Baryshnikov and Patricia McBride in a show sponsored by the National Dance Institute.

title: Gadfly Monthly Makes a Mark
description: SAN FRANCISCO  What would I do if Mother Jones wanted to interview me? asks an executive at a fairly large corporation who has not yet gotten a request. I would tell them I was out of town, and there's be no telling if I'd be coming back. You know those people are coming in with their cannons smoking, and you know they'll shake the closets until they've got some scalps.

title: Learning JobSafety and Health From Europe
description: WASHINGTON  While there is argument over the dimensions of the occupational safety and health problem in American industry, there can be little disagreement that employers alone have been unable to keep our workplaces safe.

title: Metzenbaum Says Oil Companies Hold Up Supply Until Prices Rise
description: CAMBRIDGE, Ohio, May 6 (UPl) Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio. accused major oil companies yesterday of holding their product from the market until the Government allows Drices to rise next month.

title: Excerpts From the Wall Poster Describing How Detainees Are Treated
description: HONG KONG, May 6  Following are excerpts from a translation for The New York Times of a Chinese wall poster written by Wei Jingsheng, printed in mimeographed form and dated March 3,1979:

title: Newark Airport Sets a Record For Growth in Passenger Traffic
description: NEWARK, May 6 (UPI)  Newark International Airport has proved to be the fastestgrowing metropolitan airport, with record passengertraffic figures for the first quarter of this year, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Events
description: BESSE WELSH, flutist, Alice Tully Hall, 8.

title: On the Rural Coast of Georgia, Activist Blacks Pray and Plot Strategy in Land Dispute
description: HARRIS NECK, Ga., May 5  It was in July 1942 and I used to fish for crabs and shrimp in the river, and I had a good crop of corn, sweet potatoes and tomatoes, and along about then these white men came along  surveying up and down and cutting down trees and they said I would have to move in two days, because they needed my land for the war.

title: Commodities
description: THE longdormant markets for corn, wheat and soybeans, the most essential foodstuffs, suddenly came to life last week as unseasonably cold and wet weather continued to delay spring plantings in North America, the Soviet Union and China.

title: U.S. 2d in Water Polo
description: RIJEKA, Yugoslavia, May 6 (UPI)  Kevin Robertson scored three goals to help the United States defeat Italy, 94, and gain the silver medal in the eightnation Water Polo Cup. The American team won five matches and lost two. Hungary clinched the gold medal last night by beating the United States, 43

title: Rebounding Suns Beat Sonics, 113103
description: PHOENIX, May 6  Every rebound makes a big difference, said Joel Kramer, former accounting student, son of two accountants and rookie forward with the Phoenix Suns. Especially with us.

title: De Gustibus: A Peacock On the Table, A Peahen On the Porch
description: The world is, apparently, more full of peacock, peahen or peafowl fanciers than most cooks ever dreamed. It all began when someone asked if they were edible. I replied that I'd never sampled peacock and the thought of that roast bird did not excite my appetite. Peacock, according to one informant, is not only eaten in the 20th century but is available in certain markets in Manhattan. Another reader stated that it was served at her wedding.

title: Dance: City Ballet Offers Cage And Other Dances by Robbins
description: PERFORMED consecutively, as they were by the New York City Ballet on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater, Jerome Robbins's The Cage and his Other Dances offer an intriguing view of two sides of the same coin. In The Cage, still vividly nightmarish after 28 years, woman is the engulfer and man her prey. The relationship is painted in allegorical terms, of course, with two male intruders stomped to death by lethal female insects.

title: Nature Books for Children
description: Today's parents with a desire to lead their children into an understanding of the natural world have a great advantage over those of yesteryear.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  By electing a Con. servative Parliament headed by Margaret Thatcher, the British voter has at last arrested Robin Hood: The no torious brigand of Sherwood Forest, Nottinghamshire, has been something of a hero in EnglishAmerican folklore ever since his mention in the 14thcentury Piers Plowman. That is because Mr. Hood and his motley crew of early Socialists  Little John, Friar Tuck, AllanaDale, and Maid Marian (the Jane Fonda of her day) robbed from the rich and gave to the poor. Tha,t is now called income redistribution and has had a good. press for five centuries.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. The Flying Dutthman, Spinning Chorus, WagnerLiszt; Mouvement Perpetuel No. 1, Poulenc; Mona. Prelude, Parker.

title: Popularity Is Not the Lawyer's Special Duty
description: HOUSTON  Nothing in our system of justice is as widely misunderstood by the layman and as frequently neglected by the lawyer as the rights of an unpopular accused when involved in the judicial process.

title: Volunteers Make Waiting for the Railroad Easier
description: Carrying rags and brooms, detergent and trash bags, residents in the neighborhood of the Lynbrook station the Long Island Rail,Road descended upon its vandalized waiting room yesterday to help restore it. The railroad's facilities have been increasingly affected by vandalism in recent months, particularly at the station waiting rooms.

title: Rubber Workers and Uniroyal Toughen Positions
description: DETROIT, May 6  The bargaining positions of the United Rubber Workers and Uniroyal Inc., whose onagain, offagain contract negotiations were to resume tomorrow morning in New York City, appeared to be hardening today, and the prospects of a strike against the tire manufacturer remained strong.

title: U.S. Team Retains Federation Cup
description: MADRID, May 6 (AP) The United States won its fourth consecutive Federation Cup today as Chris Evert squeezed by Australia's Dianne Fromholtz, 26, 63, 86, in one of the longest, closest matches of the American's career.

title: Pakistanis Sentence 2 Robbers To Amputation of Hand and Foot
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, May 6 (Reuters) Two bank robbers have been sentenced to have their right hands and left feet amputated in the first such decision since the introduction of strict Islamic law, the Associated Press of Pakistan said today..

title: Next Stop, Preakness
description: LOUISVILLE, KY. RON Franklin stepped into his blue jeans, pulled sweater over his white Tshirt and started out of the jockeys quarters at Churchill Downs to go tell the press how he and Spectacular Bid had won the Kentucky Derby. He was at the door when Angel Corder) Jr. popped out of a shower and called him back.

title: A Hasty Assault on Triple Damages
description: Should a foreign government which thinks it has been cheated by the pricefixing of an American company be entitled to its day in court? Two years ago, the Supreme Court said yes, ruling that India, Iran and other countries could sue a number of American drug firms in a case involving antibiotics. But now Congress is being asked to overturn that decision without even the benefit of hearings. We urge it to delay for reflection.

title: Supplementary OTC Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Wil Hartog Victor In Motorcycle Race
description: HOCKENHEIM, West Germany, May 6 (AP)  Wil Hartog of the Netherlands, riding a Suzuki, won the 500 ccm class of an international motorcycle competition today. He was timed in 42 minutes 33.9 seconds for a speed of 113 miles per hour.

title: Gas Shortages Give Drivers a Sense of Foreboding but Not Panic
description: The Sunday closings and other signs of a tight supply of gasoline at America's pumps, while causing turmoil in California. do not appear to be panicking the rest of the nation's motorists. But among many there is a sense of a gathering storm.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Special committee on the nonuse of force10:30 A.M.

title: New U.S. Agency for ForeignAid Loans Is Urged
description: Primary responsibility for the position of the United States on individual loans made by the multilateral development banks, which currently dispense the largest single part of American foreign aid, should be taken from the Treasury Department and given to a new agency, according to a Senate staff study.

title: Inside a Prison: Concern In Wake of Guard Strike
description: WALLKILL, N.Y., May 6  I wish they'd stayed out longer, Raymond Mathias said at lunch today in the New York State Correctional Facility here. He paused, then added: I enjoyed waking up to no confrontation, no hassles. We all felt relieved when they walked out. But now they're back, and who knows what's going to happen?

title: New Arrival at Bronx Zoo is Lucky 13
description: An American bison calf struggling to its feet to greet its mother shortly after birth yesterday at the Bronx Zoo. The calf, a member of a native species which almost became extinct, became the 13th member of the zoo's herd.

title: Levi Posts 63 and 71 To Win by 2 Shots
description: HOUSTON, May 6 (AP)  Wayne Levi took command with a courserecord 63 in the morning and then posted a twostroke victory with a closing 71 today in the doubleround windup of the Houston open golf tournament.

title: Sudan Trying 45 in Alleged Plot
description: KHARTOUM, the SUdan, May 6 (AP)  Fortyfive persons, most of them military men, go on trial before a state security court this week on charges of plotting to overthrow President Gaafar alNimeiry, the Sudanese press agency reported. The agency gave no details of the alleged plot, but said the defendants included 23 military men, six policemen and 11 civilians.

title: Canadiens Bolstered By Return of Shutt
description: MONTREAL, May 6  The Montreal Canadiens, faced with a mustwin situation in the Forum last night, reasserted their dominance as, they routed the Boston Bruins, 51, and took a 32 lead in the Stanley Cup semifinal series.

title: Scientists Examine Tiny Viruses For Messages From Outer Space
description: A search for messages from other worlds is focusing not on the heavens but on certain bacterial viruses.

title: Madison Ave. Residents Mourn A Sculpture Ruined by Vandals
description: For seven months a massive granite sculpture valued at $80,000 presided on the sidewalk outside an art gallery at 77th Street and Madison Avenue, where it became a favorite of many neighborhood residents. Early yesterday, unknown vandals pulled it from its pedestal and left it smashed in pieces on the sidewalk.

title: Doctors Wives: Many Report Marriage Is a Disappointment
description: For many it was the American dream, female version: marry a nice young doctor and live happily and prosperously ever after, while he does noble work and she devotes herself to him, his career and his children.

title: The Man Nobody Wants
description: SOMEHOW Alice Cooper was overlooked in the football draft. He would have made an ideal receiver for June Jones of the Falcons. Turned out Alice Cooper had as much chance in the N.F.L. as George Allen. George Allen, remember him? Never had much use for the draft, course. A couple of years ago he was trying to trade his Redskin choices for 1980. His future, as he always proclaimed, was now. Now he qualifies as one of those people he used to covet a veteran, a winner and nobody wants him.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Jimmy Connors failed to appear at the presentation ceremony of the Wimbledon centennial, hi 1977, and so the medal that he was to have received as a former Wimbledon champion was denied him. Has Connors ever received that medal, or are the officials of the world's most prestigious tennis tournament continuing to withhold it?

title: $11 Billion Spent in 77 For Public Environment
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI)  Government spending for environmental quality control reached almost $11 billion in the fiscal year 1977, with about 70 percent going for water cleanup projects, the Census Bureau said today. me spending level was up FM million, or 7.6 percent, over the fiscal year 1976, the bureau said. Its figures are the latest available on the subject.

title: After 5 Years, Harlem FamilyCare Center Is to Open
description: The building stood unused in West Harlem for five years, its gleaming glass facade unable to hide the shiny chromeandsteel medical equipment that filled its four floors.

title: Yale Crew Takes Goldthwaite Cup
description: DERBY, Conn., May 6  Yale's lightweight varsity crew ended a 28year drought today when it beat Harvard and Princeton to win the Goldthwaite Cup. The Yale eight covered the 2,000 meters in 6 minutes 10 seconds, 1 lengths ahead of the Crimson. Princeton was another length and half back.

title: Guidry, in Relief, Wins for Yanks
description: The Yankees unveiled their newest relief pitcher yesterday and the slim lefthander showed definite promise. One day after announcing that he was forsaking his starting spot to join the bull pen, Ron Guidry went to work at his new job.

title: Y. & R. Wins Car Dealer Groups
description: Young & Rubicam, which recently won the $75 million LincolnMercury national advertising account, has just been picked by two of its dealer associations, which have combined billings of $5.5 million. They are two of the 18 associa= Lions in the country. Y.&R. has 16 pitches yet to make.

title: TaxPaid Campaigns Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)  More than twothirds of votingage Americans oppose the use of tax money to finance Congressional campaigns, according to nationwide survey by Civic Service Inc., a St. Louisbased political research firm. The survey of 1,659 persons, conducted in March, showed 31.8 percent disapproved and 36.1 percent strongly disapproved of the practice. Only 5.1 percent strongly app appoved and 16.7 percent approved.

title: Carey May Soon Choose A New Commerce Chief
description: ALBANY, May 5  Governor Carey is close to taking care of several problems at once by naming William D. Bassett, a Republican businessman from Buffalo, to be the state's new Commerce Commissioner. aides say.

title: Charter, a Winner Before, Is Gambling on Oil Again
description: Raymond K. Mason, chairman of the Charter Company, called on his good friend, Edward Ball, chairman of the St. Joe Paper Company, a few months ago and invited him to the Bahamas to look at a refinery.

title: Delp: Never a Derby Doubt
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6  Bud Delp could have said it, but he didn't.

title: Mets Beat Giants On 4 in 8th, 54
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 The New York Mets, just when it seemed they were destined to leave this city of high winds and low gasoline supplies without posting a victory in four games, scored four runs in the eighth inning today to register a 54 triumph over the San Francisco Giants.

title: CHILEANS, IN CHANGE, OPPOSE BIRTH CURBS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 6  A steady decline in Chile's birth rate during the last five years of economic hardship has resulted in a campaign against birth control.

title: City Hopes Coast Guard Can Haul a Third of Garbage
description: New York City officials expressed hope yesterday that, with Coast Guard help, about a third of the usual load of 10,000 tons a day of city refuse would be hauled by barge to the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island.

title: Opera: Luke's Medea Has Premiere in Boston
description: BOSTON IN at least one respect, Ray Luke's new opera Medea is a winner. Given its premiere by the New England Conservatory of Music at the Boston University Theater on Thursday. Friday and Saturday niehts. the opera took first prize in a contest sponsored jointly by the Rockefeller Foundation and the New England Conservatory. Mr. Luke's reward was the opportunity of seeing his opera per formed and a cash prize of $5,000.

title: Miss Lopez Gains 3d Tour Victory
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., May 6  Nancy Lopez played one of the strongest rounds of her twoyear professional career today and won the fourth annual Women's International golf tournament by three shots. With the victory she moved ahead of the record pace she set during her rookie season.

title: Steel Mill Closing Denied
description: PITTSBURGH, May 6 (AP)  The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation disputed a report that it had decided to close a large portion of its Youngstown, Ohio, works at the end of the year. At a meeting with union representatives March 30, J.&L. committed itself to continue operations at the Brier Hill Works at least through the end of 1979 and beyond, depending on market Conditions, the company said late last week, adding that that position had not changed.

title: Italian Bank Reinstates Aide
description: ROME, May 6 (AP)  The Bank of Italy's deputy director, Mario Sarcinel1i, who spent more than a week in jail late in March on charges of misusing his power to cover up a financial scandal, was reinstated in his office after a monthlong suspension.

title: Ecuador Raises Oil Price
description: QUITO, Ecuador; May 6 (UPI) Ecuador's state petroleum company yesterday raised oil prices 6 percent to 520.36 a barrel, retroactive to May 1. Ecuador exports 150,000 barrels of oil a day, mostly to the United States, Trinidad, Jamaica, Chile and Colombia. Some 62.5 percent of the oil is sold by the state company and the rest by Texaco Inc.

title: Suit Casts New Light on Land Deals in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 4  Documents in a lawsuit filed in New Jersey Superior Court here this week contend that a company headed by a Toronto developer, Antonio Montemarano, has contracted to buy 17.9 acres of land in Brigantine, an Atlantic City suburb, from that town's Mayor, John A. Rogge, for $3 million.

title: Sports World Specials
description: The head athletic trainer at Yale University supervises a staff of six fulltime and numerous parttime trainers, and oversees facilities for all of Yale's 37 varsity sports. Recently the head trainer became Daphne Benas, a 27yearold physical therapist and certified athletic trainer, who had been the interim chief since Jim Wall left the university last fall because of illness. Miss Benas, a graduate of the University of Connecticut, is the first woman to hold the position at a Division school of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Truck Drivers Accept New 2Year Contracts With 5 Gas Concerns
description: A strike by truck drivers who %deliver gasoline to service stations in New York City, Long Island, Westchester County and northern New Jersey was averted yesterday when the drivers voted approval of new contracts with five major gasoline companies.

title: 100th Birthday Is Nostalgic At Madison Square Garden
description: They're calling it Madison Square Garden's 100th birthday, and throughout this year there will be parties, television specials, an overall face lifting of its interior, a specially created medallion, a book, magazine supplements, even hotair balloons and a Goodyear blimp.

title: The Region
description: The 500 residents of Sunset Bay, N.Y., who were evacuated Friday after the derailment of two tank cars loaded with toxic, flammable vinyl chloride, returned to their community on the shore of Lake Erie 30 miles southwest of Buffalo yesterday after the removal of the potentially explosive tank cars.

title: Green of Queens Star in Track Meet
description: Paul Green, a Queens College sophomore, scored in 10 events, but his performance was not enough to lead the Knights to the City University of New York track and field championship.

title: World's Atom Energy Lags In Meeting Needs for Power
description: PARIS, May 6  Since 1953, when President Eisenhower started the Atoms for Peace program that helped promote the nuclear generation of electricity, industrial and developing countries have made a major commitment to harnessing the power of the atom to meet future energy needs.

title: 26 Argentines Reported Detained For Violating a Ban on Politics
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 6 (Reuters) The Argentine police detained 26 politicians here and in the northern city of Resistencla for violating a ban on political activities. party sources said today.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: The Rangers, Something Happens to Us Inside
description: ASK any two Rangers what's going on in this semifinal series, and you get two different answers. Fair enough. But ask six others, and you get six more. Perhaps the explanation closest to the mark comes from Dave Maloney, the captain, who was asked to draw a diagram of any particular technique that he felt had given the Rangers the edge.

title: The Last Offer Answer to Police Strikes
description: There have been no police or firemen's strikes in New York State for five years, largely because a state law, not applicable in New York City, requires local governments to submit public safety disputes to binding arbitration. The arbitration requirement will lapse on June 30, however, and some mayors and county executives are urging Albany not to renew it. Their view is shortsighted. Binding arbitration does, to some extent, dilute official responsibiity for local budgets. But it is the only procedure that offers a realistic alternative to strikes endangering public safety.

title: Smashes and Cheers Mark Table Tennis
description: The following article was written by Alice Green of Great Neck, L.I., a member of the United States team that competed in the world table tennis championships in North Korea.

title: Ohio Slaying Suspect Returned
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, May 6 (AP)  Michael G. Levine was returned to Ohio yesterday to face charges in the slaying of Julius Kravitz, the supermarket executive, and the abduction of Mr. Kravitz's wife, Georgene. Mr. Levine, 35 years old, surrendered Thursday at Arlington County, Va. He and John A. File, 26, who surrendered Wednesday, are charged with aggravated murder, attempted aggravated murder and kidnapping in last Tuesday's abduction and slaying.

title: Bullets Down Spurs, 11595
description: LANDOVER. Md., May 6 Wes Unseld's muscle and 11 seasons of experience paved the way for the Washington Bullets 115.95 victory over the San Antonio Spurs today before a capacity crowd of 19,035 at the Capital Centre. Unseld's 26 points and 22 rebounds enabled the Bullets to tie the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference chamoionshiD series at 11.

title: Vornado Sues to Block Votes
description: Vornado Inc., which operates the Two Guys discountstore chain, filed suit in Federal Court in New York last Friday in an effort to enjoin Interstate Properties from soliciting proxies or voting its Vornado shares at the retailer's annual meeting on May 22.

title: SRI LANKA PLANNING 25,000 NEW VILLAGES
description: UDARAGAMA, Sri Lanka  Life for the ricegrowing Podihamy family has just undergone a metamorphosis that promises new hope for the poor in the mean villages of the lush interior.

title: TV: Playboy Celebrates Its 25th Anniversary
description: H. L. MENCKEN'S term for this country's blinkered middle class of the 20's, the booboisie, leaps to mind in considering Playboy's 25th Anniversary Celebration. The program will be seen from 10 to 11 o'clock tonight on ABCTV.

title: Memorial to Dr. King Discussed
description: ATLANTA, May 6 (UPI)  Officials of the National Parks Service have been discussing with the widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. the possibility of a national memorial or shrine to the memory of the slain civil rights leader. Coretta King heads the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Social Change on Auburn Avenue.

title: South Africa Tells Its Conditions For U.N.Run Voting in Namibia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 6 South Africa has told officials here that it is prepared to proceed with United Nationssupervised elections in SouthWest Africa, but only on the condition that they do not involve setting up temporary military bases for guerrillas inside the territory.

title: The City
description: The General Services Administration has recommended the construction of a $92 million office building in Jamaica, Queens, to house the Social Security Administration's regional payment operations, a spokesman for Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said last night.

title: China Cites New Policy On Growth
description: PEKING, May 6  Li Qiang, China's Minister of Foreign Trade, acknowledged tonight that his country was undergoing a major readjustment in its economic development program, which will involve retrenchments in heavyindustry imports of capital goods in the period immediately ahead.

title: Market Place
description: THE gambling stocks continue to dominate speculative market action, throwing off healthy profits for some investors and even larger losses for others.

title: News Summary
description: A Peking poster told of imprisonment of many top Chinese political prisoners in an inconspicuous walled complex in a Peking suburb, where they are often tortured, deprived of food and forbidden visits by relatives. It was dated March 3, andwas written by a leading Chinese dissident, Wei Jingsheng, who was arrested a few weeks after the poster appeared. He has reportedly been charged with being a counterrevolutionary, which carries the death penalty. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: Experts Assert Children on Laps Are in Danger in Auto Accidents
description: WASHINGTON, May 6 (UPI) Highway safety experts said today that there was ample proof that babies or young children were in peril in a car when held by adults but that car seats or belts could save their lives.

title: Ballet: Premiere of Tudor's Tiller
description: ANY new work by a great ballet choreographer is of interest, and Antony Tudor's The Tiller in the Fields is no exception. You might even say it packs a double wallop. Or so it did at its Metropolitan Opera House premiere Saturday night when American Ballet Theater presented Gelsey Kirkland and Patrick Bissell in this coup de theatre.

title: Letter: On Rhodesia's Elections
description: To the Editor: With regard to your April 26 editorial Rhodesia Passes the Wrong Test, please consider the following:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ABC Inc. has appointed Martin Greenberg president of the ABCowned FM radio stations, succeeding Allen B. Shaw Jr., who has resigned.

title: HENRY SCHULTZ DIES; HEADED CIVIC GROUP
description: Henry E. Schultz, a retired national chairman of the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith and a former member of the New York City Board of Higher Education, died Saturday at the Miami Heart Institute in Miami. He was 72 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: TV SPORTS
description: 4:00 (31)German soccer (tape)

title: MARY LOUISE GILLERAN
description: Mary Louise Gilleran, an administrative assistant to the Metropolitan New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, died Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital at the age of 61.

title: Says They Are Beaten and Deprived of Food in a Secret Complex
description: HONG KONG, May 6  Many of China's highlevel political prisoners over the last decade have been kept in an inconspicuous walled complex in a scenic Peking suburb, where they are often tortured and deprived of food and visits from relatives, according to a wall poster written by a leadine Chinese dissident.

title: Mixed Media: Anderson and Sahl
description: BETH ANDERSON and Michael Sahl called their Saturday evening program at the Kitchen Romantic Allusions for Instruments, Machines and People. It included new works in a number of media, from pianoaccompanied songs to textsound to jazz to tape, but it was mostly tonal and positively rhapsodic.

title: Bernard Leach, 92, Noted Potter; Briton Learned From Japanese
description: LONDON, May 6 Bernard Leach, an internationally renowned potter, died at his home in St. Ives, Cornwall, today. He was 92 years old.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Suddenly, a New Look for Carter
description: WASHINGTON, May 6  What's got into Jimmy Carter lately?

title: Books of TheTimes
description: DONT BUY A CAR MADE ON MONDAY. By Vance Muse. 145 pages. Times Books. $8.95. LEMONS are more likely to roll off the assembly line on Friday and Monday than any other days of the week, writes Vance Muse under the alphabetically listed heading, CARS MANUFACTURED ON FRIDAY AND MONDAY. No surprises here: The spirit of TGIF, Monday hangovers, and the resulting absenteeism on both days result in factory failures and endangered motorists.

title: Concert: Giulini Ends Visit
description: CRLO MARIA GIULINI, as most concertgoers are well aware, is a conductor of high =aical principle. His program with the Los Angeles Philharmonic in Carnegie Hall Saturday night, the orchestra's third and final concert of its New York visit, was typical in its uncompromising earnestness: Mozart's Don Giovanni Overture, Hindemith's Mathis der Maler Symphony and Beethoven's Eroica Symphony.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: An eastwest band of heavy clouds extends from Southern New England across the lake region to the intermountain region. Patches of low level clouds and fog are visible over the Southern Atlantic States and the Mississippi Valley. Considerable cloudiness can be seen over the Pacific Northwest and the Central Pacific States.

title: Janice Ellen Cooper Wed To William Grey Schaffer
description: Janice Ellen Cooper and William Grey Schaffer, Washington lawyers, were married yesterday at their home in Washington by Judge Frederick B. Weisberg of the District of Columbia Superior Court.

title: Frosty Skater Big A Victor
description: Frosty Skater, a bay filly, extended her winning streak to five yesterday when she scored an easy victory in the $55,400 Vagrancy Handicap at Aqueduct. Taking control on the turn for home, Frosty Skater finished 1 lengths ahead of the lateclosing Hagany. Skipat, the 85 choice who carried 126 pounds, was third, 4 lengths behind Hagany.

title: About New York
description: When she was good, the little girl in the brown beanie was very, very good  good enough to sell 1,148 boxes of Girl Scout cookies and, now, to be proclaimed the best cookie seller in Manhattan for 1979. And when she was bad, the worst she did was interrupt an interview to try and sell more Girl Scout cookies.

title: Sunday BusShelter Damage Spree Called Work of Organized Vandals
description: The heads of two companies competing for the city's busshelter franchise agreed yesterday that damage to as many as 27 shelters in Manhattan early Sunday was the work of organized vandals.

title: Sir George Bendel at 90; Former British Diplomat
description: LONDON, May 7 (AP)  Sir George William Rendel, a former diplomat who survived two World War 11 assassination attempts attributed to Hitler's Gestapo, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home here, his family announced today. He was 90 years old.

title: Boeing Earnings Double On 75% Advance in Sales
description: The Boeing Company reported yesterday that net income more than doubled in the first quarter to $108.1 million, or $1.69 a share, from $45.2 million, or 71 cents a share, in the first auarter of 1978.

title: Teheran Executes 21, Including 3 Officials In Shah's Government
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Tuesday, May 8 Revolutionary courts this morning executed 21 people, including two former Cabinet ministers and the speaker of the Parliament, bringing the number of executions since the revolution that overthrew Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi to nearly 200.

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI Petition for an Arrangement Filed by

title: Notes on People
description: To be sure, there are ample precedents for such changes in lines of work. Therefore it was not too surprising when Steve Garvey, who makes his living with his admirable playing at first base for the Los Angeles Dodgers, said he had been thinking about a future in politics. Specifically, Mr. Garvey has in mind the United States Senate, which recently acquired another figure from the sports world, Bill Bradley, who comes from New Jersey by way of Madison Square Garden.

title: MiddleIncome Housing Endangered by New Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  The New York State and New York City plan to save $450 million worth of troubled housing projects has been thrown into jeopardy by a new bill in Congress designed to curtail the ability of state and local governments to finance and constrixt middleincome housing.

title: Abnormal Form of Interferon Linked to Some Diseases
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  A probablyharmful aspect of the antivirus substance Interferon has been discovered, linking it to some serious diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis.

title: Boat People Find Jobs and Fellow Asians in Iowa
description: DES MOINES, May 7  Tran Vinh Kiet, slender and earnest, spoke slowly and with some amazement, in the English he had polished working with Americans in Saigon, about the wondrous ways of Iowa.

title: Bill Would End Research Using Unclaimed Pets
description: ALBANY, May 7  The State Senate voted today to repeal a controversial law that forces animal shelters to yield dogs and cats to scientific research institutions for experimentation.

title: Juantorena: Soul Is Key To Success
description: LOS ANGELES, May 7  Alberto Juantorena had a wonderful time on his first trip to the United States. The weather was warm and sunny, he went sightseeing and ate well, saw the Dodgers play, smiled a lot and socialized.

title: Science Watch
description: Neither science nor philosophy has ever explained satisfactorily just how the human brain defines beauty. Now, however, a psychologist at Stanford University says that he believes he has found a clue in visual experiences that some people occasionally have just as they wake up.

title: For Old Law, A New Attack
description: WASHINGTON, May 7This seems to be the business community's year to flex its muscle on Capitol Hill, and a major fight that it has picked involves a 48yearold law that regulates the pay of construction workers on federally funded projects.

title: BEGIN OFFERS TALKS WITH THE LEBANESE
description: JERUSALEM, May 7  Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel proposed today that Lebanon and Israel sign a peace treaty, but he vowed to continue attacking Palestinian guerrilla positions on Lebanese territory.

title: SeaFloor Geysers May Be Key to Ore Deposits
description: WHAT the diving scientists saw as they looked out the small portholes of their pressure sphere was almost unbelievable. It was like Pittsburgh in 1925, with all those blast furnaces going full tilt, said Dr. Roger L. Larson. Simply mindboggling, said Dr. Robert D. Ballard. turned from a series of submarine dives onto the East Pacific Rise where, for the first time, they and others witnessed eruptions from the bottom of extremely hot, metalladen water. When a temperature sensor in the submarine's remotecontrolled arm was placed over one vent, its plastic components melted, and Dr. Larson believes water temperatures may reach 600 to 800 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Hazards Cited in Widely Used Art Supplies
description: FOR a year and a half, Bruce Beasley, a California sculptor, ran a lowgrade fever and broke out in shakes and sweats every time he climbed the stairs. A doctor finally traced his illness to the arsenic compound Mr. Beasley was using to color his aluminum sculptures, but it was another year and a half before he regained his health.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Defying the experts, a technological supertoy broke at Three Mile Island. But even the experts agree that another supertoy, Skylab, will fall and break this summer, and it may make whopping mess.

title: World Gold
description: By the Associated Press

title: Justice Dept., in Civil Complaint, Seeking $149,000 From Eilberg
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP) Department of Justice announced that it had filed a civil complaint seeking more than $149,000 from former Representative Joshua Eilberg.

title: The Region
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan dismissed an $11.5 million breachofcontract suit brought by a Long Island man who asserted he had been discharged from his bank job for exposing a $75,000 embezzlement.

title: FAULTY CAR REPAIRS FOUND WIDESPREAD
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Undercover investigators for the Department of Transportation found in a survey of 62 automobile repair shops in seven cities that 53 cents of each service dollar was wasted tin needless repairs.

title: House Votes to Strike $2.3 Billion For Revenue Sharing From Budget
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  The House upheld today a committee decision to strike from President Carter's budget for the fiscal year 1980 all $2.3 billion designated for revenuesharing with the states.

title: The City
description: Some Consolidated Edison Company equipment, dating to the turn of the century, will become museum pieces, requested by the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

title: OBSERVER
description: Everybody must have a list of certain things not worth mastering. In my case it includes things like growing hybrid tea roses, calculus, buying automobile tires and learning the anatomy of the horse.

title: Waldheim, Opening Conference, Urges Rich Nations to Raise Aid
description: MANILA, May 7  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim opened the fifth United Nations Conference on Trade and Development here today by urging wealthy nations not to let the current economic malaise prevent them from doing more to help developing nations.

title: Producers Cut Copper Price Again
description: In a continuing decline of copper prices, major producers announced yesterday the second round of cuts in a little more than a month  an average reduction of three cents a pound, to level of 91 to 92 cents.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M. National Occamc and Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: TV: Film of an Affair, Anatomy of a Seduction
description: THE phenomenon might have been plucked from a NoOl Coward lyric. Stars do it. Housewives do it. Even ladies leading gray soapopera lives do it. The fashion of the older woman's having an affair with a younger man is unon the land.

title: Stocks Fall To Low for 2 Months
description: Heavy selling hit the stock market yesterday amid continued fears of rising interest rates.

title: Congressman Discloses Move to Draft Kennedy
description: ST. PAUL, May 7 (AP)  Representative Richard M. Nolan announced today that he would lead a nationwide effort to draft Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts as the Democratic Party's 1980 Presidential candidate because President Carter had abandoned the party.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ROYAL VIKING SEA (Home). Lett Montego Bay May 4; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: West German Reporter Is Beaten And Robbed in Moscow, He Says
description: MOSCOW, May 7 (Reuters)  A West German newspaper correspondent said today that he was assaulted and robbed of about $900 after entering a taxi outside central Moscow's Intourist Hotel at midnight on Friday.

title: Tennessee High Court Overturns State's Stiff Antiobscenity Law
description: NASHVILLE, May 7 (AP)  A tough antiobscenity law passed by the Tennessee Legislature last year that outlawed everything from topless waitresses to written articles about sex was overturned today by the State's Supreme Court.

title: Dr. Joseph Mahoney Dies at 58; Obstetrician on L.I. for 25 Years
description: Dr. Joseph P. Mahoney, an obstetrician and gynecologist at North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., died of cancer there yesterday. He was 58 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Phillies 11, Padres 6
description: SAN DIEGO, May 7 (AP)  Bake McBride drove in four runs to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to an 116 triumph over the San Diego Padres tonight. McBride had a runscoring single in the Phillies threerun fourth inning and basesloaded triple in the seventh. The Phillies Steve Carlton (34) pitched six innings, giving up one run on five hits while striking out six. The decision snapped Carlton's threegame losing streak and gave him the most victories  133  by a lefthander in Phillies history.

title: EDWIN LEE DOREE
description: Edwin Lee Doree, a teacher at the High School of Art and Design in New York City, died of a heart attack Sunday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. He was 52 years old and lived in Englewood, N.J. Mr. Doree was an advertising art director for many years at the William Douglas McAdams Agency, among others, before leaving the field to teach. He is survived by his wife, the former Lucille Freidenreich, and two daughters, Susan and Elizabeth. He is also survived by a sister, Dr. Ellen Rosen of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Mayes Army Captain
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., May 6 (UPI)George Mayes, a threeyear letterman and an East Coast Athletic Conference allstar for tw,o seasons at middle guard, was named captain of the 1979 Army football team today.

title: Letter: On NoFault Auto Insurance.
description: To the Editor: Your recent editorial on auto nofault recommended that New Jersey follow New York's example and replace the present dollar threshold with a verbal threshold. Under the present law, $200 in medical bills entitles the victim to sue for injuries. Under a verbal threshold, suit is permitted only for victims in very serious cases: death, loss of use of a bodily organ, or four months of a serious nonpermanent injury.

title: City's Bonds Still Rated Only at B With Moody's
description: Saying that the city's overall credit outlook remains. highly uncertain,, Moody's Investor Services yesterday left unchanged the highly speculative B rating it had given New York City bonds in May 1977.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4)Coping with Inflation

title: U.S. Losing Education Official
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)  Patricia Albjerg Graham is resigning as director of the National Institute of Education of the Department, of Health, Education and Welfare to return to a teaching post at Harvard University's Graduate School of Education. Mrs. Graham will leave the post June 15 to become a professor in the history of education at Harvard. She formerly taught there and was a vice president of Radcliffe College.

title: New York's Assembly Approves Bill Barring PublicArea Smoking
description: ALBANY, May 7  After hours of debate, the Assembly today passed a bill that would ban smoking in virtually all public places except in certain designated areas. The action, by a vote of 79 to 58, marked the first time either house of the Legislature had approved such a ban.

title: News Summary
description: The U.S. intensified efforts to conclude negotiations this week with the Soviet Union for a strategic arms limitation treaty. Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin met twice, in the morning and briefly in the afternoon after Mr. Vance had conferred with President Carter. Mr. Vance annnounced that he would go to London May 20 for talks with members of the new Conservative Government on coordinating British and American policy on issues of mutual interest. [Page A1, Columns 34.]

title: Curiosity Sidesteps Follow the Leader
description: As Deidre Chiocarelli's firstgrade class trooped outdoors for exercises  in single file, marching in time  at Epiphany School on East 22d Street yesterday, one young fellow sneaked a peek through a window next door. Small wonder that his attention wandered as thoughts of summer vacation distracted even the most studious in balmy sunshine and temperatures in the mid 70's. Forecast is for more of the same today.

title: ALBANY ACTS TO CUT MANDATORY TERMS IN NARCOTICS CASES
description: ALBANY, May 7  After six years of controversy, negotiators for legislative leaders and Governor Carey have agreed to eliminate some of the mandatory prison sentences for illegal sale and possession of small amounts of narcotics required by the socalled Rockefeller Drug Law, principals in the negotiations said today.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Contrasts in Asia
description: MANILA, May 7  Peking, Hanoi and Pyongyang all are capitals of Asian Communist countries, but to a visitor they seem in different worlds. Peking is relaxed and bustling, Hanoi appears Spartan and Pyongyang is like an architect's model, sparkling new but devoid of people.

title: Motor Home Sales Skid On Fear of Gas Shortage
description: The motor home industry is suffering from its third gasolineinduced financial headache in recent years. Manufacturers of the selfpropelled vehicles have seen sales plummet for several months because of public concern over possible gasoline shortages. The recreational vehicles provide selfcontained living facilities for both camping and highway use.

title: Benson Ford Seeks to Bar Judge
description: DETROIT, May 7  On the eve of key court hearing on Benson Ford Jr.'s attempt to change his father's will, his attorney filed a motion in Probate Court here today asking that Judge Ira O. Kaufman, who has presided over the case. be disoualified.

title: OddEven Gasoline Ration Plan To Start in California Tomorrow
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7  An oddevenday gasoline rationing plan designed to meet the gasoline shortage that has resulted in halfmilelong lines of motorists at service stations in some areas of California will go into effect on spotty basis at 12:01 A.M. Wednesday, officials announced today.

title: William Ross Proctor Dies at 85; ExPartner in Brokerage Concern
description: William Ross Proctor, a former senior partner in the brokerage concern of Abbott, Proctor & Paine, died Friday in the Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, N.J., after a brief illness. He was 85 years old and lived in Pittstown, N.J., and Eldred, N.Y.

title: Dratils
description: AGERMilton. We record with deep sorrow the death of our beloved member & colleague Milton Ayer in CaIkenia on May 6.1979. Stanley Adams.

title: Bridge:
description: The negative inferences that can be derived from the fact that an opponent has not bid are quite common, but are sometimes overlooked by experts in the heat of battle. Consider, for example, the diagramed deal that capped a private individual tournament last week, honoring the 75th birthday of one of the world's great players, B. Jay Becker.

title: Two Carter Aides.Leaving
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI)  Two men constantly seen around President Carter are leaving soon for other assignments. Lieut. Comdr. Paul Reason, the President's naval aide, Will become the No. 2 officer aboard the Mississippi, a nuclearnowered shin with a crew of 600. John Simpson, the Secret Service's agent in charge of the President's detail, is being promoted to assistant director of the service in charge of all protection.

title: Associated Press
description: HOSTAGES IN EL SALVADOR: Peering from a barred window in the French Embassy in San Salvador were Ambassador Georges Paul Dondentle, left, and his first secretary, Jean Duffaud. They have been held for four days by leftists demanding the release of jailed union leaders. Costa Rican diplomats, including the ambassador, who were also being held hostage at their embassy, were released by the militants late last night.

title: United Cancels More Flights
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI)  United Airlines announced today the cancellation of all scheduled flights through May 19 because of the fiveweekold strike by mechanics and other ground crew workers. The airline said it was accepting reservations for travel on June 8 and thereafter, subject to resumption of service. The strike by the Machinists and Aerospace Workers union has grounded the nation's largest airline, which carries 160,000 passengers daily. Negotiations broke off last month and no new talks were scheduled.

title: Yankees Gamble With Ron Guidry
description: Soon after Ron Guidry changed his address from the rotation to the bull pen, Reggie Jackson told him, You're showing me a lot. Ron Guidry is showing all his Yankee teammates a lot, mostly a lot of class. He put an old word back in the Yankees vocabulary  volunteer. And he revised an old ohrase  sacrifice for the team  Last year thpv helped me win the Cy Young Award, he says of his 253 wonlost record last season. This year maybe it's me who owes them something. He does not owe them anything. of course.

title: Advertising
description: AMID all the plastic geegaws and tinny gimcracks, the oil paintings on black velvet, and the gaudy baseball caps adorned with product names, Saks Fifth Avenue, understated and chic, made its debut as an exhibitor at the 4fst annual Premium Show.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GOLDEN ECHOES You can have a jolly good time in Greenwich Village at the Blue Parrot, a nicely atmospheric night oasis for drinks, food and dancing to the nostalgic sounds of the Widespread Depression Band, Tuesdays and Thursdays from 9:30 P.M. to midnight. Prices are reasonable and the young eightmember orchestra is simply marvelous.

title: Talking Business
description: The impact of inflation on the American public so important to the Carter Administration that the President's chances for reelection next year could well depend largely on the performance of the Consumer Price Index.

title: 10 Die in Argentine Crash
description: CORDOBA, Argentina (AP)  An Argentine Air Force helicopter crashed near the city of San Francisco, 300 miles northwest of Buenos Aires, last night, killing 10 of the 16 people aboard, the authorities reported.

title: Theater: Tribute to Langston Hughes
description: CLEVELAND'S Karamu House is the oldest black theater company in America, which means that for 64 years it has been a source of new theatrical talent. Suitably, Karamu House was represented last weekend at the Black Theater Festival U.S.A. at Lincoln Center with show called Langston, an affectionate tribute to Langston Hughes, the celebrated pott and playwright.

title: PANEL REJECTS PLAN ON POSTAL CLOSINGS
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)  Plans of the Postal Service to save cash by closing some rural post offices that have been losing money ran into a ruling today that may make it more difficult to achieve savines.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION Wave of Censors Hits the Schools
description: FUNDAMENTALISTS in Iowa, calling themselves Scientific Creationists, are rekindling opposition to the Darwinian theory of evolution, and school librarians are girding themselves for a new round in the battle of the books. The public schools have never enjoyed more than brief periods of ceasefire with the censors. Whenever the national mood is angry, frustrated or conservative, the bluepencil brigade mobilizes, and the National Council for Teachers of English says that is happening now.

title: Islanders, Facing Elimination, Change Lines, Power Play to Thwart Rangers
description: The Rangers, one victory from moving into the Stanley Cup final, are in trouble.

title: For Bruins, Main Goal Again Is to Stop Lafleur
description: BOSTON, May 7 With spring in the air outside Boston Garden and spring in their steps inside the arena, the Boston Bruins sought to stave off elimination in the Stanley Cup semifinals with a furious. hour's nractice today.

title: Yields on Bills Up at Treasury
description: Yields rose on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and the 182day maturities. ine average rate for the threemonth bill was 9.621 percent, up from 9.998 percent for the preceding week. The average rate for the sixmonth bill was 9.617 percent, up from 9.570 percent for the week earlier.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 7 (AP) The Westinghouse Electric Corpora. don has agreed to a $17 million settlement of a uranium suit with the Wisconsin Electric Power Company.

title: Jim Walter Plans Aluminum Mill
description: Plans to build a $27 million rolling mill to produce aluminum sheet and foil has been announced by the Jim Walter Corporation of Tampa, Fla. It will be completed in 1981 at a site somewhere in the Southeast, the company said.

title: Fidelcor Sets Credit Agreement
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 7  Fidelcor Inc., the parent corporation of the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia, announced yesterday that it had reached a $105 million revolving credit agreement with 19 major American banks, led by Chase Manhattan.

title: Pope Gives a New Job To Greek Churchman Once Jailed by Israelis
description: ROME, May 7  Bishop Hilarion Capucci, a Greek Catholic of the Melkite rite known for his militant Palestinian stance, was received by Pope John Paul II today and appointed inspector of Melkite communities in Western Europe. His last post had been that of Inspector of Melkite communities in Latin America.

title: Millon of M.I.T. to Head Unit at National Gallery
description: In a longawaited appointment, the National Gallery of Art in Washington has named Henry Armand Millon, an architectural historian who is professor of history and architecture at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to head its new Center for Advanced Studies in the Visual Arts.

title: Bennington to Mark 50 Years
description: Bennington College will mark its 50th anniversary with a Pioneers Weekend on Saturday and Sunday at which participants in the college's historical summer dance school of the 1930's will reunite for two days of panels and performance, with films and photograph exhibits. Participants will include Martha Hill, Wi!Rani Bales, Ben Belitt, Ray Green, Gertrude Shurr and May O'Donnell. The May O'Donnell Dance Company will perform on Sunday at o'clock. Information may be obtained from Bennington College, Bennington, Vt. 05201 (8024425401).

title: Pierre VianssonPonte, Top Le Monde Editor And de Gaulle Expert
description: PARIS, May 7  Pierre VianssonPonte of Le Monde, a prominent French journalist and an internationally known chronicler of the de Gaulle era, died here today. He was 58 years old and had long been a cancer patient.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 3 P.M.

title: Astaire, Nearing 80, Is Still a Very Private Person
description: LOS ANGELES, May 7  On Thursday, Fred Astaire will be 80 years old. Although he will still occasionally get up and move around with some music hear on television, he has not really danced for almost eight years.

title: Big Board Specialist Suspended for a Year
description: Imposing its most severe penalty ever on an exchange specialist, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday suspended Irwin Schloss, the president of the brokerdealer firm of Marcus Schloss & Company, from any dealings on the exchange for one year.

title: IN THE NATION
description: While the world has been watching the Rhodesian elections, the United Nations plan for the independence of SouthWest. Africa (Namibia) has fallen into stalemate. Now it seems likely that there, too, an independent government without international approval may soon come into existence.

title: Market Place
description: ASUCCESSFUL money manager in Philadelphia has also had personal success in the stock market in a way that would appall many professionals.

title: Money
description: MONDAY, MAY 7, 1979

title: Asia Find Indicates Origin Of Apes
description: rOSSILS recently discovered in Burma have led scientists to suggest that, in a major step in evolution toward human beings, anthropoids may have originated more than 40 million years ago in Southeast Asia.

title: Student Elections in Chile Result In Victory for Foes of the Regime
description: SANTIAGO. Chile, May 7  The first elections for student delegates in Chilean universities under the present military regime have given candidates opposed to the authorities a clear victory.

title: Building Products In 39% Profit Rise
description: The surge in homebuilding activity in 1978 produced an average profit rise of 39 percent for building products manufacturers, an advance the industry will be hardpressed to match in the coming year, according to the F.W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill CornPan Y.

title: Ethics Inquiry on Talmadge Gets Conflicting Polygraph Assertions
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  A veteran polygraph examiner told the Senate ethics committee today that Daniel Minchew, a former aide to Senator Herman E. Talmadge, had told the truth when he asserted that he had given the Senator campaign and office funds that had been laundered through a secret bank account.

title: Sears Is Innovating With Radio
description: Remember the squeaking door on Inner Sanctum? Or when Lux presented Hollywood? Or Howard Duff as Sam Spade, private eye? All three were popular radio dramas of yesteryear. But everybody knows that radio drama disappeared long ago, when television made explicit what previously could only be imagined.
