title: An Overdue Electric Bill: Symbol of West Bank Ills
description: RAMALLAH, IsraeliOccUpied West Bank  This is such a small story, apologized Fuad Shihadeh, a Palestinian lawyer for the East Jerusalem Electric Company. But it may have some significance as an example of what happened, what happens and what is likely to happen on the West Bank after we get autonomy.

title: U.S. Steel Sees Need for Greater Profitability in 79
description: HOUSTON, May 7 (UPI)  William R. Roesch, president of the United States Steel Corporation, told stockholders today that the company must generate greatly improved profitability to be able to streamline its operations and successfully compete in contemporary markets. But, he added that U.S. Steel expects to do well in 1979 despite an expected economic downturn in the fourth fiscal quarter.

title: Small Lacrosse Powers Obtain Byes for Playoffs
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association announced the championship tournament lineup for lacrosse teams playing in Division IIIll yesterday. It will release the alignment for Division I next week.

title: Productivity Rate Causes Worry
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Economists, businessmen and Government officials have become concerned about a marked drop in the nation's productivity growth rate, a development they fear will reduce economic growth and increase inflation and unemployment.

title: Peter Orth Named Winner Of Naumburg Competition
description: Peter Orth was named winner yesterday of the William Kapell International Piano Competition sponsored by the Naumbura Foundation.

title: 8 Judges Are Nominated To Two Courts by Koch
description: Eight new judges have been nominated by Mayor Koch, six for the Criminal Court and two for the Family Court.

title: EAST GERMAN TELLS OF NEW CRACKDOWN
description: EAST BERLIN, May 6  East Germany appears to have started a cam. paign of repression against its leading internal critics that is described by a writer naw facing possible criminal charges as a revival of Stalinism.

title: Surf Rock: Jan and Dean
description: SURF music never seemed very substantial as a rockandroll subgenre; it was all frothy vocal harmonies and bleachedout Chuck Berry guitar riffs. But its influence has endured, and a now a second generation of performers is coming along to shore up the continuing efforts of the music's originators.

title: CARTER ALTERS PLAN TO RATION GASOLINE IN BID TO RESCUE IT
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  President Carter amended his proposed standby gasoline rationing plan today in a lastminute attempt to keep it alive and meet the objections of members of Congress from Western states and rural areas.

title: Florida Hires Randolph
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., May 7 (AP)John Randolph, head coach at Army since 1976, was hired today as track coach at the University of Florida.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles. (TelevisionCablevision, 10:25 P.M. RadioWMCA, WGBB, 10:25 P.M.)

title: Carter Tells Protesters Closing All Nuclear Plants Is Out of the Question
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  President Carter told a group of nuclear power opponents today that shutting down all the nation's nuclear generating plants was out of the question. But he said his Administration was trying to minimize the requirement for nuclear power through the use of alternative energy sources and strict conservation.

title: A's 5, Orioles 3
description: BALTIMORE, May 7 (UPI)  Jeff Newman belted his third home run of the season, and the Oakland A's pulled off a triple play to back the sevenhit pitching of Rick Langford tonight and snap the Baltimore Orioles sixgame winning streak with a 53 triumph.

title: Vance and Dobrynin Meet Twice, Looking to Arms Pact This Week
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance met twice today with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union in an effort to conclude negotiations this week for a treaty limiting each side's offensive strategic arms.

title: Senate, Acting on Amin Ouster, Votes to Resume Uganda Trade
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)  The Senate, in effect recognizing the deposition of President Id Amin, voted today to lift economic sanctions that had been applied against Uganda.

title: SchoolBus Pact Put in Jeopardy Over Hiring List
description: The tentative agreement between the New York City Board of Education and the union representing striking bus drivers was described by both sides as in jeopardy last night after a new dispute developed over job security.

title: Music: The Arioso Trio
description: CONSIDERING the large amount of good music available to small chamber ensembles with piano, not many such groups gain international standing and hold together for significant periods. certainty, despite the presence on the scene of the Beaux Arts Trio and a few others, there is plenty of room for piano trios of talent and ambition. Three excellent musicians known as the Arioso Trio played a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night that suggested they aspire to help fill the vacuum.

title: 10. 75% Ceiling For Mortgages Voted in Jersey
description: TRENTON, May 7 Both houses of the New Jersey Legislature today approved a 10.75 percent maximum interest rate on home mortgages in New Jersey, breaking a sixweek deadlock.

title: Commodity Tables Explained
description: Next to each commodity in the table is a key to the exchange on which It is traded, the minimum contract size and the monetary units represented by the figures in the table. Open interest is the number of contracts outstanding each month and not liquidated by delivery of the commodity or by an offsetting contract. The exchange keys are:

title: Free Met Operas in Parks To Be Given June 12 to 23
description: The Metropolitan Opera's 13th season of free concert performances in the city parks will run from June 12 to 23. Four performances each of Verdi's Aida and La Traviata will be given. Both operas will be sung in Central Park's Sheen Meadow. Aida will also be done in Marine Park, Brooklyn; Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, and Eisenhower Park, Nassau County. Traviata will be heard in Clove Lake Park, Staten Island; Cunningham Park, Queens, and Prospect Park, Brooklyn. Casts will be announced later.

title: Judge Says Radar Is Too Inexact To Be Sole Evidence in Speeding
description: MIAMI, May 7  A Miami judge ruled today that radar is an inexact and often unreliable instrument of law enforcement.

title: Red Sox Get Six in First, Rout Angels, Ryan by 94
description: BOSTON, May 7 (AP)  A sixrun first inning, highlighted by Butch Hobson's threerun double off Nolan Ryan, lifted the Boston Red Sox and Mike Torrez to a 94 victory over the California Angels tonight.

title: Car Ban, a Spring Ritual, Gives Park Roads to the People
description: Speeding over a small rise near the Sheep Meadow, Francisco Ortiz rolled down the southbound roadway in Central Park the other morning on fireenginered roller skates.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Slides in Tokyo; Gold Prices Up in Europe
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, May 8 (AP)  The dollar opened more than three yen lower on the Tokyo foreignexchange market today  at 213.30 yen, compared with the previous day's close of 216.90and slid to 212.

title: J. Homer Platten, 85
description: J. Homer Platten, a retired business executive who served as an economic adviser to the United States Government during World Wars I and II, died last Saturday at his home in Sheffield, Mass., after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Koch to Reopen Public Library On Thursdays
description: Despite library cuts totaling more than $1.2 million in his budget for the 1980 fiscal year, Mayor Koch pledged yesterday to reopen the New York Public Library on Thursdays at a cost of $350,000.

title: Radioactive Wastes Found in Jersey Where Nitroglycerin Was Uncovered
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., May 7  Containers of radioactive chemicals were found today in the loft of a wastedisposal company warehouse where potentially explosive and potentially lethal nitroglycerin and bacteriological wastes were uncovered last week.

title: Wenner to Run Look as Monthly
description: Jann Wenner, editor and publisher of Rolling Stone magazine, said yesterday that he will also run Look magazine, replacing Robert Gutwillie. editor and resident.

title: 8 Judges Are Nominated To Two Courts by Koch
description: Eight new judges have been nominated by Mayor Koch, six for the Criminal Court and two for the Family Court.

title: Nicklaus Selected Athlete of Decade
description: Jack Nicklaus, who was named yesterday as athlete of the decade for the period 19691979, said there were no more mountains he aspired to climb  he just wanted to build a bigger mountain.

title: Pirates 4. Braves 2
description: ATLANTA, May 7 (AP)  Bill Robinson's tiebreaking home run in the sixth inning helped the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 42 triumph over the Atlanta Braves tonight. The Braves, who have now lost five in a row, had tied the score, 22, on a tworun homer by Gary Matthews in the fifth before Robinson connected off Atlanta's Mickey Mahler for his fifth home run of the season.

title: Permanent Teeth in the OilProfits Tax
description: Senator Kennedy thinks the President's decision to decontrol oil prices, and to ask Congress to recapture part of the profit with a new tax, amounts to a sellout to the oil companies. Why, then, has Mobil Oil, no fan the Senator's energy policies, also come out against the Administration's proposals? Part of the answer probably lies in the specific technical problems that decontrol poses for Mobil. But the larger answer lies deeper. Mobil understands what Congressional liberals do not: the windfall tax will cut sharply into future oil company revenues.

title: Chorale: Brahms's Requiem
description: ALTHOUGH it was probably a coincidence, the Collegiate Chorale's performance of the Brahms German Requiem in Carnegie Hall Sunday night fell one day before the composer's r46th birthday. Whether by design or not, it was a suitable way to mark the occasion because the Requiem is one of Brahms's most popular and moving works.

title: ROSEMARY LA PLANCHE
description: HOLLYWOOD, May 7 (UPI)  Rosemary La Planche, a screen actress during the 1940's and the Miss America of 1941, died yesterday at the age of 56.

title: TV: Thriller Hanging by a Thread on Channel
description: NSTRAINED by television's tight budgets, Irwin Allen, the Jovian producer of The Poseidon Adventure, The Towering Inferno and other bigscreen cataclysms. groves to be merely mortal.

title: Dividends
description: PeStk pay riod Rate record able

title: An Elegant End to the New York Showings
description: Just how far sportswear has progressed since its plebeian, origin in the Depression years was shown by the Calvin Klein fall collection, which brought the formal fashion openings in New York to an elegant conclusion.

title: PHILADELPHIA SEEN APATHETIC ON VOTE
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 7  There's apathy out there so thick, said Albert V. Gaudiosi, who was a candidate for Mayor here when he made the remark, that you could cut it with a knife. Last week, Mr. Gaudiosi removed himself from the race for the Democratic nomination, which will be decided by the voters in a primary May 15.

title: Beech Aircraft to Build 4 New Planes For Entry Into Commuter Market
description: WICHITA, Kan., May 7  Officials of the Beech Aircraft Corporation announced today that the company would build four turboprop planes in a fullscale entry into the commuter aircraft market.

title: Energy Use Up Only 2% in 1978
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI) American energy consumption was up 2 percent in 1978, the smallest increase in three years, the Energy Department said today.

title: U.S. Supports 4 Savings Plans
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI)  The Administration announced today for the first time its support of four plans that would allow small savers to take advantage of higher interest rates.

title: JAPANESE RENEWING APLANT RESISTANCE
description: KUCHO, Japan, May 2  Fusaichi Hirono led the way down the steep mountain path. It was a warm spring day and nightingales sang in the bamboos. The slopes above the village were covered with tangerine trees and vegetable plots.

title: James A. Burden Is Dead at 81; RollerBearing Concern ExHead
description: Mr. Burden, who retired in 1969, was the greatgrandson of Cornelius Vanderbilt and the grandson of Emily V. Vanderbilt. With his cousin, Harold S. Vanderbilt, who founded the game, he was an expert amateur contractbridge player. He was also the greatgrandson of Henry Burden, founder of the Burden Iron Works, Troy, N.Y., which became the largest horseshoe and nailproducing concern in the world.

title: Sikorsky Sued for $65 Million Over Copter Crashes
description: New York Airways, which suspended its flights in the city after a fatal Sikorsky S61 accident at Newark International Airport on April 18, has gone to court seeking damages from Sikorsky Aircraft for that crash as well as for the S61 accident atop the Pan Am Building on May 16, 1977.

title: The New York Times/Neal Boenzi
description: Coast Guard tugboats began to haul incinerated garbage by barge yesterday from Manhattan transfer terminals to the Fresh Kills lan.afill on Staten Island as negotiations in the 37dayold tug strike continued.

title: Canadian Union Leader Is Jailed
description: OTTAWA, May 7 (Reuters)  A court today jailed JeanClaude Parrot, head of Canada's postal union, for three months for defying a backtowork order rushed through Parliament to end a postal strike last October. In addition he was put on 18 months probation.

title: Q&A
description: Q Why is adrenaline administered  in cases of severe wasp and bee stings?

title: Rhodesia's Parliament Convenes, Boycotted by Sithole
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 7 (Reuters)  Rhodesia's blackdominated Parliament met for the first time today, with the end of 90 years of white supremacy symbolized by the sight of Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa, who will become the new Prime Minister, seated at the center of the front bench.

title: Town Is Worried by a Leaky Silo Containing AtomicBomb Waste
description: LEWISTON, N.Y.  A concrete watersilo, 165 feet high and filled with 1,757 tons of uranium and and radiumrich wastes left over from the Manhattan Project the development of the atomic bomb in World War II  is leaking small amounts of radiation and worrying some citizens of this suburb of Niagara Falls.

title: Marriage Is Good for Health and Longevity, Studies Say
description: CHARILE and Josephine were so devoted that they had been inseparable for nearly 10 years. Then one midwinter day, in a senseless act of violence so typical of our times, Charlie was fatally shot M a melee with the police.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter amended his proposed gasoline rationing plan in what was seen as an attempt to meet the objections of Western and rural members of Congress. A key provision of the ammendment would limit each household to three cars for which they could receive rationed gasoline. In addition., states would receive a monthly gasoline allotment equal to half of the historic amount they are used receiving. [Page A1.]

title: Thugs Renew Terrorizing of Naples And Mimic Tactics of Red Brigades
description: NAPLES  Most of the bombs that go off here at night are not planted by the Red Brigades or other extremist groups. Instead they mark an alarming comeback of the Camorra.

title: Milton Ager, 85, Composer, Dies
description: Milton Ager, who composed hundreds of popular songs and contributed scores to Broadway shows and motion pictures, died Sunday in Centinela Hospital in Inglewood, a suburb of Los Angeles. He was 85 years old. One of his songs, Happy Days Are Here Again, became the theme song of Franklin D. Roosevelt's Presidential campaigns, and is still played at Democratic conventions.

title: Sweeney and Elephant Lead Tony Nominations
description: Sweeney Todd, the new Stephen SondheimHarold Prince musical, has been nominated for nine of this year's Antoinette Perry (Tony) Awards, leading all other musical candidates. Bernard Pomerance's The Elegbant Man placed first among stright nlays with seven nominations.

title: Lag in Reporting Reactor Damage Laid to Experts
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., May 7  A technician from the Three Mile Island nuclear plant told visiting Congressmen today that control room personnel and Federal inspectors knew that the plant's fuel core was seriously damaged two days before the damage was formally reported and the seriousness of the accident made public.

title: Bob Hope Honored at Film Society Gala
description: Although he has never won an Oscar, and he makes sure everybody knows it, Bob Hope was honored last night for his film career by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. A crowd of 2,700 trouped to Avery Fisher Hall to thank him for the memories.

title: Concert: The American Symphony
description: FOR its last concert of the season in Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon, the American Symphony Orchestra offered a solid, traditional program with one minor exception. That was the opening work, an Overture in D by one Charles Hommann, who flourished, if that is the right word for so obscure a figure, in Philadelphia around the middle of the 19th century. The piece made a pleasantenough impression, skillfully composed in the Viennese Classical style that was the accepted fashion in American musical establishment circles during those days.

title: Events
description: NATIONAL ORCHESTRAL ASSOCIATION, Carnegie Hall, 8.

title: Cancer Victim's Son Tells of Lost Data
description: LEWISTON, N.Y.  James Charles Schmidt, who is 40 years old, put down his haunch of roasted rabbit and, in the tired voice of a much older man, explained why his father, James Sweet Schmidt, had not complained publicly about the dose of radiation he said he had received at the Lake Ontario Ordnance Works.

title: Dance: Star Joins Youngsters
description: ONE of the most charming events of this and probably many more dance seasons occurred Sunday at the Felt Forum where Mikhail Baryshnikov showed up to lead what looked like several thousand youngsters through a zippy little disco routine. The occasion Avery Sommers, who has appeared in Platinum and Sancocho, will join the cast of Ain't Misbehavin',  playing at the Plymouth Theater, next Monday. Miss Sommers will replace Nell Carter, who will pursue concert and nightclub engagements before joining the national company of Ain't Misbehavin  in Los Angeles this fall.

title: Decisive Point In Sahara War
description: ALGIERS, May 3  Overshadowed by other conflicts on the African Continent, the Western Sahara war appears to be entering a phase that could be decisive for Morocco. Algeria and Mauritania.

title: Services Held for Henry Schultz
description: Funeral services for Henry E. Schultz, a retired national chairman of the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith who died last Saturday in Miami at the age of 72, were held Sunday at the Riverside Memorial Chapel in Miami Beach. Mr. Schultz is survived by his wife, the former Rose Yellin; two sons, Roger A. of North Woodmere, LI., and Michael E. of New York City; a daughter, Jane Ellen Bloom of Hauppauge, LI., and eight grandchildren.

title: Around the Nation
description: CATLETTSBURG, Ky., May 7 (UPI)  Judge H. David Hermansdorfer of Federal District Court today upheld the constitutionality of an amendment to the Clean Air Act that would allow President Carter to force Ohio's electric utilities to burn coal mined in that state.

title: Rubber Talks End in an Impasse; Strike Deadline of Tomorrow Set
description: Contract talks between the United Rubber Workers union and Uniroyal Inc. ended here yesterday with union leaders setting a firm deadline of noon tomorrow for a strike against the nation's No. tire maker unless the company signs an aereement by then.

title: Music: CelloPiano Duo
description: THE ClarkSchuldmann Duo is husbandandwife cellopiano team that made its New York debut in 1979 and has performed here with some frequency since. Sunday afternoon the pair was at the 92d Street Y, and offered a competent set of performances that didn't really add up to a very telling or memorable occasion.

title: New Offer On Fairchild
description: Gould Inc., rebuffed on its $298 million offer to buy the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation, bounced back yesterday with an offer of $315 million.

title: Program Attacks Inability to Learn
description: VER the years, there have been private efforts to assist children with learning disorders, but now New York City has begun its own widescale attempt. The Board of Education's program, which will cost $7 million, is designed to help such youngsters without the stigma of separation from normal Glasswork.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  The Iranian Foreign Ministry has appointed a new charg d'affaires to head its embassy here in a move that seems to have soothed the factionalism that beset the mission since the Revolution.

title: U.S. Publishers Say Peking Weighs a Copyright. Law
description: HONG KONG, May 5  Because Mao Zedong once said that knowledge belongs to the people, Chinese authors have not been allowed to earn royalties. As part of the modernization program, the Government is now considering a copyright law, a delegation of American Publishers was told in Peking.

title: Mr. Small To Mr. Big
description: The text of the following correspondence was forwarded to The New York Times by Lewis S. [baps, vice president of the Palmer Asphalt Company. a small manufacturing firm in Bayonne, N.J.

title: Treasury Loan Bill Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  The House unexpectedly rejected today, 195 to 175, a bill to renew the Treasury's lapsed authority to cover brief shortfalls of cash by borrowing directly from Federal Reserve banks.

title: Moynihan Charges on C.I.A. Aid Stir Call for Inquiry in New Delhi
description: NEW DELHI. May 7  Allegations in a took by Daniel Patrick Moynihan that the Central Intelligence Agency contributed money to an Indian political party. in one instance making the payment directly to Indira Gandhi, brought demands for an investigation during an angry fourhour parliamentary debate today.

title: Twins 6, Blue Jays 1
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 7 (UPI)  Butch Wynegar had three hits, including his fifth homer of the season, and Rob Wilfong singled home two runs to cap a fourrun fourth inning tonight as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 61.

title: Tigers 5, White Sox 4
description: DETROIT, May 7 (AP)  The Detroit Tigers rallied for two runs in the eighth inning on runscoring singles by Jason Thompson and Lance Parrish to gain a 54 victory tonight over the Chicago White Sox.

title: Radio
description: WQXR: Piano Personalties. Martha Argerich. Mazurkas. Nos. 1, 2 and 3, Chopin; Sonatine, Piano Concerto in p, Ravel.

title: Skaggs Obtains 45% Of American Stores
description: Skaggs Companies announced that it had acquired 2.4 million shares of the American Stores Company under its recent tender offer.

title: Understanding Mrs. Mendoza
description: When Gloria Mendoza, one of many New York Hispanic citizens who understand only Spanish, applied for welfare, shabrought along a sister who speaks a little English. Nonetheless, they were unable to explain the Department of Social Services that Mrs. Mendoza was unemployed, divorced, had four young children and needed help. A welfare worker so thoroughly misunderstood a comment that Mrs. Mendoza was suffering from a bad cold that the worker concluded she was disabled. Hence, Mrs. Mendoza applied for disability assistance instead of Aid to Dependent Children. It took three weeks and a legal service lawyer to straighten things out.

title: Australia to Take Refugees
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 7 (AP)  Australia's Immigration Minister, Michael J. R. MacKellar, said today that Australia would accept 12,000 Indochinese refugees in the next 12 months, including 7,500 Vietnamese from Malaysian camps. Mr. MacKellar was here for talks with Home Affairs Minister Mohammed Ghazali bin Shafie about the future of 65,000 Vietnamese refugees in Malaysian camps.

title: Piano: Sonatas by Frank
description: CLAUDE FRANK, one of the most distinguished Beethoven pianists around, was presented by the Beethoven Society on Sunday at Hunter College in the second installment of a Beethoven sonata cycle. On this occasion, the sonatas were Opus 10, No. 1; Opus 28 (the Pastoral), Opus 53 (the Waldstein) and Opus 90, and listening to Mr. Frank play them was like attending a master class in interpretation.

title: PennwaltMexico Link
description: The Pennwalt Corporation said yesterday that it had sold enough stock in Mexico to increase Mexican ownership of the company's chemical operations there to the required 51 percent. In making the announcement, Edwin E. Tuttle, Pennwalt chairman, called the Mexicanization of the chemical facilities there complete. He also said the. stock sale would add about 20 percent a share to 1979 earnings.

title: Johncamp Offer
description: Johncamp Realty Inc. said that it had acquired 2.4 million shares, or 73.4 percent, of the Prudent Real Estate Trust as a result of its recent tender offer.

title: Senate.Approves Health Warnings On Liquor Bottles
description: WASHINGTON, May 7.(UPI)  The Senate voted today to require a health warning label on all bottles of hard liquor. The warning would be similar to the one on cigarette packages.

title: Jets Taking an Offseason Look at Veterans
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 7  The New York Jets began taking inventory today.

title: N.Y.R.A.
description: LEADING ALL THE WAY: Swift Poppy, second from right, led the field at the clubhouse turn in the running of the race at Aqueduct. The filly, with Eddie Maple aboard, went on to win the 1 Mrmile contest.

title: The Senator, the Darter and the Dam
description: Last year, he proudly cosponsored legislation make the Endangered Species Act more flexible. He was righlty concerned that the act allowed valuable Federal public works to be stopped cold if they threatened to extinguish even obscure plants and animals no known value. In particular, Mr. Baker was upset that the substantially completed Tellico Dam in his home state was being held up lest it destroy the habitat of the snail darter, a tiny fish.

title: EARNINGS
description: The CocaCola Company, the world's largest softdrink producer, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del., that its profits had risen 13.4 percent in the first quarter on a 16.7 percent sales gain.

title: COMMODITIES Dry Weather Depresses Grain, Soybean Prices
description: Warm dry weather swept the Middle West Farm Belt late in the weekend, shriveling prices of grain and soybean futures. As farmers rushed to complete their spring plantings, long delayed by uncommonly cold and wet weather this season, overseas reports indicated improved sowing conditions in the Soviet Union and in China as well.

title: Fire Damages Bridge on Jersey Shore
description: A fireman running across the burning Grassy. Sound Bridge near West Wildwood, N.J. yesterday after bridge accidently caught fire while a welder was repairing the guardrail. The fire severely damaged the wooden structure and caused a gas line explosion. One fireman was injured before the fire was brought under control.

title: N.B.A. Delays Decision on Jazz Move.
description: CHICAGO, May 7  The National Basketball Association owners delayed today an attempt by the New Orleans Jazz to become the Utah Saints. Instead, the 22 owners gave their eightmember advisory and finance committee 21 days to investigate the issues. utter the sway is completea me enure board of governors will be called together eight days later to act on the recommendation.

title: Pleas for Sewers, Roofs and Tables Blossom in Spring Budget Hearings
description: Jorgelina Centeno wanted Mayor Koch to know that if he did not find the money for a new roof for her tiny museum, she would have to continue taking the paintings off the wall every time it rained.

title: New Theory Disputes Old in Geographical Distribution of Species
description: TWO schools of thought, one new and one old, have come into basic conflict over a biological question that has long puzzled scientists: Why are similar species of birds, mammals, fishes and insects found in areas separated by thousands of miles, by vast mountain ranges and sometimes even by oceans?

title: Columbia Pictures Profits Fall 26.7%
description: Columbia Pictures Industries reported yesterday a 26.7 percent drop in net income for the March quarter to $11.8 million, or $1.22 a share, from $16.1 million, or $1.75 a share, in the comparable quarter last year, when Close Encounters of the Third Kind enhanced results. Revenues of $184.5 were up 13.5 oercent from $162.5 million.

title: CREDIT MARKETS North Carolina Power Yields 7%
description: In a financing affected by opposition to nuclear power, the North Carolina Municipal Power Agency is borrowing $150 million this week at a cost that is estimated to be onequarter of 1 percentage point higher than it would otherwise have been.

title: Books: Photography Critic's Views
description: A. D. COLEMAN is a photography critic who has written for many publications, including this one. The period covered by this book, 196878, was a time of radical reappraisal by photographers of their medium. The body of work that emerged represented as much a break with the past as the efforts of the photosecessionists who, led by Alfred Stieglitx in 1902, denounced controlled printing processes such as gum bichromate, which enabled photographers to omit details, change tone values, and by a great variety of manipulations to modify the photograph to such an extent that it became the result of handwork far removed from the original camera image. The results were more like paintings than photographs.

title: Mariners Trounce Yanks, 124, Meyer. Clouts Slam, Drives in 7
description: Guidry, who has become the No. 1 short, or lateinning, reliever in place of the injured Rich Gossage, could have come in handy last night, when the Yankee bull pen faltered early in the game and New York fell to the Seattle Mariners, 129.

title: Homosexual Couples: Therapy for Problems of Living Together
description: When they spoke of interfering inlaws or communication problems or squabbles about money, they sounded much like a group of conventional middleclass couples in marriage counseling. I don't like doing all the housework, said a woman in her mid40's. A 30yearold salesman said: I'm not capable of being faithful to one person for ever and ever.

title: G.M. Payout Rises To $1.65 a Share
description: The General Motors Corporation raised its regular quarterly dividend on common stock yesterday to $1.15 a share from the previous payment of $1. Directors also declared a special dividend of 50 cents, the same amount as the special dividend paid in the 1978 second quarter. The latest dividends, totaling $1.65 a share, are payable June 9 to stockholders of record May 17.

title: Suit Accuses Procter & Gamble Of Bias Against Female Workers
description: CINCINNATI, May 7 (AP)  The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed suit today against the Procter & Gamble Company, charging sex discrimination in employment practices.

title: Dodgers Beat Mets, Falcone, 52
description: LOS ANGELES, May 7  The floundering Dodgers, who had been held scoreless for 21 innings. and beaten in six of their seven previous starts, found the New York Mets just in time tonight. With the score tied at 11 after four innings, the Mets helped the Dodgers to a fourrun fifth inning that lifted Los Angeles to a 52 victory.

title: Home Loan Rates Rise In Purchase
description: Interest rates on home mortgage continued to rise yesterday in the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation's weekly purchase of conventional housing loans. The volume of mortgages offered for sale declined for the fourth week in a row.

title: Paul Blair, Former Yank, Is Signed by the Reds
description: CINCINNATI, May 7 (UPI)  Paul Blair, the veteran American League outfielder, was signed as a free agent today by the Cincinnati Reds. The 35yearold righthanded hitter was to join the Reds in Chicago tomorrow.

title: T.V.A. MAY RESTRAIN ITS NUCLEAR EFFORT
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 7  The chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, the nation's largest producer of electricity, said today that public opinion may force the utiltty to accept a containment policy entailing a 20 to 30year moratorium on the construction of nuclear Dower Wants.

title: Air Force Secretary Said To Resign in Frustration
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI)  In the second resignation of a high Pentagon official in two months, Air Force Secretary John Stetson is leaving his post because of frustrations in his job, defense sources said today.

title: NBC's Slippage in Ratings Spurs Defection by Affiliates to ABC
description: What had started out to be, earlier this season, another year of disappointing ratings for NBC in the prunetime audiencepopularity sweepstakes has escalated into serious slippages of viewing in daytime, earlymorning television and the evening news, as well. And it threatens still to spread to the lucrative latenight period if Johnny Carson should quit The Tonight Show before the expiration of his contract, which has two years to go.

title: Fire Damages Rome Opera
description: ROME, May 7 (UPI)  A threealarm, fire caused extensive damage to the Rome Opera House today. Officials said it started when a backdrop curtain fell on a light reflector. There was a minor fire in the building yesterday.

title: SENATE DEFERS VOTE ON NEW CARTER BID TO RATION GASOLINE
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  After a day of spirited and sometimes testy political struggle, President Carter's heavily amended standby plan to ration gasoline in an emergency reached the Senate floor tonight but faced an uncertain future tomorrow.

title: New York Retailers Had Big Sales Gains in April
description: Retail business in New York City soared last month, buoyed by this year's later Easter and warm weather favorable to shopping.

title: Interest Rates: A Survey
description: Here's what the survey of 76 thrift institutions by the city's Consumer Affairs Departmentshowed:

title: Company Fined for Phone Tap
description: MINEOLA, L.I., May 8  A buildingmanagement concern was fined $10,000 today for putting a tap on one of its own phone lines in efforts to discover who was making unauthorized longdistance calls.

title: Tilling Acquisition Of Ramteck Is Set
description: Thomas Tilling Ltd. announced in London that it had agreed to acquire Ramteck Industries of Houston for $24.2 million. Ramteck manufactures oil and gas industrial equipment. The acquisition is subject to the consent of the Bank of England and regulatory and other approvals in the United States, Tilling said.

title: It Means: (B)ruised (M)auled (T)ransit.
description: Survivors of rushhour subway rides, fresh from being leaned on, stepped on and breathed on and from sharing uninvited intimacy with our fellow New Yorkers, often speak of the cattlecar conditions on the trains.

title: Dodgers Subdue Mets, 32
description: LOS ANGELES, May 8  The New York Mets started off well tonight. They dominated the Dodgers in the early stages, outhit them, 5 to 1, in the first three innings and moved to a 20 lead. But the outcome was the same as it had been a night earlier  a triumph for Los Angeles, 32.

title: NAMIBIA IS PROMISED ITS OWN LEGISLATURE
description: CAPE TOWN, May 8  The South Ain. can Government announced today that has agreed to establish an assembly with legislative authority in SouthWest Africa, but it denied that the step constituted a move toward Rhodesianstyle independence for the disputed territory.

title: Lufthansa Trial Witness Tells of an Earlier Theft
description: Peter Gruenewald says that he remembers taking a cardboard box bearing Lufthansa sticker  a box filled with $22.000 in foreign currency  and, in the dark of night, hiding it in a garbage dump near his home in Levittown, L.I.

title: Deadline for Nuclear Waste Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Senator Gary Hart, chairman of a Senate nuclear regulatory subcommittee, today called for fiveyear deadline for the Administration and the nuclear industry to come up with an acceptable plan for nuclear waste disnosal.

title: Loews Holders Hear Earnings Report
description: Stockholders of the Loews Corporation were told at the company's annual meeting yesterday that earnings might be affected by some unfavorable un derwriting results of its affiliate, the CNA Financial Corporation, a large property and casualty insurer. we get percent 01 our earnings out of the insurance business. It is bound to have an effect, Lawrence Tisch, chairman, said at the annual meeting here. He also told shareholders that CNA's loss at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant would be in the $(3. million ranee.

title: Are Small Savers Being Shortchanged?
description: AFTER his 86yearold father-inlaw died last year, Albert B. Lewis of Brooklyn was settling  the estate when he detected a puzzling discrepancy. Accord- ing to his calculations, at the 514 percent standard annual interest rate there should have been more money than there was in the savings account at the Equitable Federal Savings and Loan Association in Bensonhurst. He figured it through again and again and kept coming up short.

title: Navy Officer Is Given The Legion of Merit For Counterspy Feat
description: LAKEHURST, NI., May 8  The American penchant for littering was used to advantage by Russian spies in their contacts with Arthur E. Lindberg, a retired Navy officer who received the Legion of Merit today for his successful performance as a double agent.

title: Student Editor Backed By Judge After Ouster
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8 (AP) Federal judge said today that the dismissal of the editor of the University of Louisville student newspaper because of a controversial April Fool edition violated the editor's constitutional riehts.

title: Monte F. Boudaily, 85, Headed Globe Syndicate
description: Monte Ferris Bourjaily, president of the Globe Syndicate, which he founded in 1937, died Sunday at the Palms of Pasadena Hospital, Pasadena, Fla. He was 85 years old and lived in South Pasadena.

description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 8 (AP) Assistant Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher Jr. left for Washington today after two days of talks with Turkish leaders on economic and military aid.

title: Food CompanyLifts Net 14.8%

The Houstonbased company, which gets 97 percent of its domestic sales from food and related products, reported sales of $278.4 million for the latest quarter, up 14.9 percent.

title: 2 Lie Detector Examiners Differ On Tests of a Talmadge Accuser
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Private and Government polygraph examiners gave conflicting testimony today to the Senate Select Committee on Ethics about whether Senator Herman E. Talmadge knew of a secret bank account through which office and campaign funds were laundered for his personal use.

title: Sun Worshipers on Long Island, Warm Faces and Cool Feet

Yesterday the temperature rose to 81 degrees with southerly breezes. Today the promise Is for more weather in the 80's and clear skies. At the shore, it will be a bit cooler.

description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Representative Lionel Van Deerlin, Democrat of California, said today that his bill to reshape Federal communications law might have to be toughened so that competitors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company were better protected against the giant monopoly.

title: MAJOR ARMS ISSUES REPORTED SETTLED BY U.S. AND SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The United States and the Soviet Union were reported today to have resolved the key issues holding up a new treaty limiting offensive missiles and bombers.

title: Greyhound Cites Shortage of Buses
description: PHOENIX, May 8 (AP)  Bus travel has risen su rapidly in the last month because of the gasoline shortage that we are now short of buses, the Greyhound Corporation chairman, Gerald H. Trautman, told the company's annual meetiQ today.

description: WASHINGTON. May 8  The Federal Communications Commission moved closer today to easing program requirements on the radio broadcasting industry in large and small communities.

title: South Leads the Country In School Desegregation
description: ATLANTA, May 8  This month, 25 years after the highest court in the land declared separate schools for blacks and whites inherently unequal and thus constitutionally unlawful, the public schools of the 11 states of the Old Confederacy are the least segregated in the country.

description: Add to the list of the luckless and deprived the lovers of zubrovka. Zubrovka is vodka flavored with buffalo grass. It is popular in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union and has a small but loyal coterie of enthusiasts in this country.

title: Former Police Officer Is Held In City Hall Bombing in Alabama
description: BESSEMER. Ala. May 8 (UPI)  The authorities said tonight that they were holding a former Bessemer police sergeant as a material witness in the city hall bombing that killed a police lieutenant and injured the police commissioner last week.

title: California Begins Permitting Gasoline Purchases Only on Alternate Days
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8  An oddeven gasoline distribution plan beginning at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow was written into state law by Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. today when he signed a proclamation of emergency in a ceremony at his office in the State Building here.

title: Careers
description: MORE than 50 of the nation's leading graduate and undergraduate schools of business are searching for deans  not assistant deans or associate deans, but deans.

title: Senator Ribicoff's Surprise
description: Abraham Ribicoff's retirement announcement, coming at the peak of his influence, caught Washington and Connecticut quite by surprise. He will not retire until his present Senate term ends next year. But make his intention clear now reflects the balance and sensibility that have marked his tenure in Congress.

title: Tight Gasoline Supplies Foreseen;  Shortage Possible at Memorial Day
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Gasoline supplies are sure to be tighter this month than they were in April and motorists are likely to find them particularly short over the Memorial Day weekend, according to industry and government officials.

description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today by a vote of 9 to 8 an antitrust bill that is emerging as one of the most controversial pieces of business legislation of the year.

title: U.S. Files Suit Against Beneficial
description: The Justice Department tiled a civil suit in the United States District Court in Newark against the Beneficial Corporation and its UIT Beneficial Management Corporation charging that the company's consumer loan operations have discriminated against credit applicants because of their age and marital status.

title: Boris N. Moralev. 62, of Soviet; Official of the Central Committee
description: MOSCOW, May 8 (UPI)  The Soviet press today reported the death on Sunday of Boris N. Moralev, an official of the Comm'nist Party's Central Committee. He was 62 years old.

A spokesman for the brokerage and investment banking firm said that no successor had been named because there would be a restructuring of the office.

Woolworth Company would provide the funds necessary to continue the development of the Woolworth business as well as our oil and gas exploration program.

title: Mayor Hatcher of Gary Defeats Former Ally in Democratic Primary
description: GARY. Ind., May 8  Mayor Richard I G. Hatcher. challenged in a bitter campaign by a former friend. political ally and fellow black. Jesse E. Bell. easily wor renomination in today's Democratic primary election.

title: Atom Plant Held Sabotage Target
description: RICHMOND, May 8 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating a report of attempted sabotage of nuclear power plant, an official of the Virginia Electric and Power Company said today.

title: WOMEN'S PANEL PICK SAID TO BE MRS. ROBB
description: WASHINGTON. May 8 (AP)  President Carter has decided to appoint Lynda Bird Robb. daughter of the late President Lyndon B. Johnson. as chairman of the Nationa! Advisory Committee for Women. it was learned today.

title: William S. Shea, 66, State Justice And Former Republican Leader
description: William Stephen Shea, a New York City and state judge for the last 19 years, died yesterday at Horton Memorial Hospital in Middletown, N.Y., at the age of 66. He lived in Monroe, N.Y., where he had moved from New York City a few years aeo.

title: World Gold

title: Thorpe and 3 Others Go on Trial In Britain in Alleged Murder Plot
description: LONDON, May 8  Jeremy Thorpe, who just a few years ago was a major figure on the British political scene, went on trial today on charges of having conspired to murder a man who says the two once had a sexual relationship.

title: Coffee Traders Sue Exchange
description: The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange has been named as one of 13 defendants in a second lawsuit arising from a coffee futures contract that the exchange forced traders to liquidate, the exchange said yesterday. Tho first :::smissed.

title: Mrs. Kreps, in Peking, Signs 4 Science Accords
description: PEKING, May 8 (UPI)  The United States and China signed four agreements on science and technology today.

title: Koch Backs Off on His Urgent Call To Permit More Discretion on Bail
description: Backing off from his earlier intention to seek a change in bail procedure at the current session of the New York State Legislature, Mayor Koch proposed yesterday that the legislators study a proposal to give judges wider discretion in jailing before trial defendants charged with serious crimes.

title: Real Estate
description: WALTER LANGER, the founder and chief executive officer of Evyan Perfumes Inc., is often to be found in a white robe surrounded by baroque furnishings, fine paintings and sweet scents at 350 East 35th Street.

title: Meteorologists Elect Dane
description: GENEVA, May 8  Prof. Aksel WiinNielsen of Denmark was elected today to a fouryear term as Secretary General of the World Meteorological Organization, United Nations specialized agency. lie was elected by the 149nation organization's congress in a threeway contest with David A. Davies of Britain, the holder of the post since 1955, and Drujo Radinovic of Yugoslavia. Professor WiinNielsen is director of the European Center for Medium Range Weather Forecasts at Reading, Britain.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Yield Raised on Nuclear Issue
description: While the credit markets generally moved insignificantly yesterday, yields were increased on the North Carolina Municipal Power Agency's $150 million bond issue, scheduled for sale tomorrow. This issue is the first allnuclear financing since the Three Mile Island accident in Pennsylvania.

title: I.M.F. Loan For Egypt Seen Vital
description: CAIRO, May 8  Egypt, having failed twice in the last five months to get its second installment of a loan from the International Monetary Fund, is anxiously awaiting the outcome of review of its economic situation scheduled by the fund's board of directors in June.

title: Salvadoran Police Fire on Crowd; 18 Demonstrators Reported Slain
description: SAN SALVADOR, May 8 (AP)  The police fired on demonstrators outside the Metropolitan Cathedral in downtown San Salvador today and Red Cross sources reported that 18 demonstrators had been killed and at least 37 wounded.

title: Soviet Gives U.S. New Ideas on Europe Troop Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The Soviet Union, in an effort to break the deadlock in EastWest talks on troop reductions in Central Europe, has offered new ideas in recent weeks in secret conversations with the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: Seatrain, Citing Brooklyn Loss, Lays Off 1,300
description: Thirteen hundred workers were laid off yesterday by the Seatrain Shipbuilding Corporation at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard. The company said it was discontinuing the construction of new vessels there because of what it called the Federal Government's lack of a cohesive maritime policy and an inability to compete with subsidized foreign shipbuilders.

title: Lo, the Poor Chicken
description: SAN DIEGO, May 8 (AP)  A controversy over who owns rights to eightfoot feathered chicken costume has San Diego in a stew.

title: Another Department?
description: WASHINGTON  The House Cornmittee on Government Operations recently voted 2019 in favor of a bill to establish a Cabinetlevel Department of Education. The full Senate has already passed a similar measure, and the full House may vote on it by the end of May.

title: Wayne to Get New Treatment
description: LOS ANGELES, May 8 (AP)  John Wayne was reported in stable condition today as doctors at C.C.L.A. Medical Center prepared to start experimental treatments for a cancer that has invaded the actor's intestines.

title: Notes on People
description: Mother's Day Myth Exploded by Brooklyn Professor

title: The Premature Talk of a Draft
description: The growing problems of the volunteer Army have finally been conceded at the Pentagon and some remedies are being discussed. Nothing beyond standby registration of 18-year-old men is likely to pass Congress in the next two years, but it is time to face the problem and to sort out the proposals. These range from an emergency draft to comprehensive national service for men and women. The proposals must be weighed against the cost of recruiting volunteers, not only in money but also in the size and quality of the resulting force.

title: Purchase Of Bodcaw Planned
description: The International Paper Company, using the tax laws as a bargaining tool, announced yesterday that it would buy the Bodcaw Company of Dallas for $610 million in preferred stock  a taxfree deal for Bodcaw shareholders.

title: Right-to-Work
description: AUGUSTA, Me., May 8  The State Senate, by a vote of 21 to 9, today killed righttowork bill that would have prohibited compulsory union membership as a condition of employment.

title: Deaths
description: GOLD I EArthur G. Beloved husband of Beverly, devoted father of JerYI and Dennis Katz, Frances and Irene. Cherished grandfather of 5abrine. Stephanie, Jonathan and Burton. Dear brother of Harry. Services today. 9:30 AM Temple Hiliel. 1030 Rosedale Road, Valley Stream, L.I.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Rejecting SALT: A Hazard
description: Since the ancients settled disputes over sacrificial meals in which salt was the universal preservative, a covenant of salt came to mean an enduring bargain. Unfortunately, for the makers of acronyms, the Romans later used with a grain of salt to denote skepticism. This latter attitude marks the current uproar over the impending SALT treaty.

title: CRACOW'S CATHOLICS HONOR THEIR SAINT
description: CRACOW, Poland, May 8  Nine hundred years ago today, Stanislaus Szczepanski, Bishop of Cracow, was executed, legend says, at the altar of his, church by King Boleslaus the Bold, whom he had for years defied. Tonight.

title: Late Rally Lifts Stocks 1.47 Points to 834.89
description: Strength in bluechip issues helped give the stock market a better tone yesterday. Still there were still nearly twice as many stocks down as up.

title: GERMANS HARD HIT BY TV HOLOCAUST
description: BONN, May 8  A public opinion survey measuring the effect of Holocaust on West Germany has suggested that the American television series on the Nazi persecution of the Jews deeply touched large segments of the population, changing attitudes and providing a simplified but unique history lesson.

title: Fairchild Rejects Gould Bid Again
description: The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation, as expected. rejected yesterday for the second time multimilliondollar takeover bid from Gould Inc.

title: Mrs. Carter to Address Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)  Rosalynn Carter is scheduled to address meeting of the American Psychiatric Association in Chicago on May 16, the White House said today. The President's wife will receive an award for her work on the President's Commission on Mental Health.

title: Carter Proclaims Flag Week
description: WASHINGTON. May 8 (UPI)  Complying with a 1949 resolution by Congress. President Carter today proclaimed the week of June 10 as National Flag Week and June 14 as Flag Day.

title: Suns Beat Sonics
description: PHOENIX, May 8  The :earn that John Johnson thought would not play better game has done just that. Wher the Seattle SuperSonics took a twogame lead over Phoenix in the four-ofsevengame National Basketball Association Western conference final series. Johnson said he would be surprised if the Suns played a better game. When the Suns won on Sunday. Johnsor. said they had not played better. The Suns wor tonight. 10091. Johnson has no argument.

title: CalifanoTellsW.H.O. To Keep Itself Aloof From Mideast Dispute
description: GENEVA, May 8  The United States sought today to head off an attempt by the hardline Arab countries to inject their quarrel with Egypt into the World Health Organization's annual assembly here.

title: Bronfman Case Figure Loses Appeal to Upset Extortion Conviction
description: ALBANY. May 8 (AP)  The state's highest court.today upheld the $2.3 million extortion conviction of Dominic Byrne in the 1975 kidnapping plot involvine Samuel Bronfman 2d.

title: End of School Bus Strike Is Set Under New Accord
description: A tentative settlement in the strike by schoolbus drivers was reached last night after an earlier accord to end the threemonthold wildcat walkout collapsed over the key issue of Mb security.

title: Ramada Casino Plan For Jersey Rejected
description: Monotonous was a key word used yesterday when the New Jersey Casino Control Commission unanimously rejected a plan offered by Ramada Inns to reconstruct the former Ambassador Hotel into a gambling casino-convention hallhotel complex.

title: TV: Once a Daughter
description: ONCE a Daughter, an hourlong program on Channel 13 tonight at 10, is part of series with the silly title of Non Fiction Television. This panic- ular documentary includes scenes from three plays, making the use of nonfiction even more pointless.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: Slicing Knives

title: U.S. Testing Workers for Effects Of 13 Years Amid Atomic Waste
description: ARGONNE, Ill., May 7  This is boring, said Vaughn Crile, a robust, 47yearold machine shop operator from Pennsylvania, as he reclined in. disposable paper pajamas in a leadlined underground vault here.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administratior ;Up

title: Bra*
description: HAHNHerman. on Sunday. May 6, 1979. Beloved husband of Lorraine (nee Ryder). Fond brother of Wit. (lam, Lawrence. Mrs. Warren Hub. schman and Eleanor Emery. Religious services at the Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home. 149.20 Northern Blvd, Flushing NY on Wednesday, May 9 at 1:15PM. Interment St. Michael's Cemetery.

title: TwiceDaily Robbery Keeps Police Sharp
description: There is a bank in the Bronx that has been herd Up at east twice each day since it opened Apri: 23. The robberies have taker place in full view of more than 200 armed police officers.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IT has been noted before that there are numerous precooked foods supermarkets and grocery stores that can be both palatable and timesaver. I do not, naturally, mean frozen dinners, since most, not all, are beyond repair even if smothered with truffles and foie Bras.

title: British Food Journal Shows Its Erudition
description: LONDON

title: Around the Nation
description: Tornadoes Hit MidFlorida; 6 Killed and Dozens Injured

title: Guide
description: NO MALLET, NICE TOUCH Dan Edwards's piano provides a soothing background for table dining at Hurlingham's, an elegant new restaurant on the 53d Street side of the New York Hilton Hotel, on the Avenue of the Americas. The selections are popular standards of the day and back when, and the pianist has a light style that seems to sprinkle the melodies into the atmosphere. It beats Muzak.

title: Beatrice Foods Sued by Stockholder
description: The Beatrice Foods Company announced that it had been sued in the United States District Court in Chicago by a stockholder who alleged that Beatrice's proxy statement was inadecuate.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Cabaret: Joe Williams
description: JOE WILLIAMS is a singer of such persuasive charm and ability that he can usually surmount even uninspired backing for his performances. At Marty's this week. he has no such problems because with the sensitive and lively accompaniment of Norman Simmons at the piano, Paul West on bass and David Lee on drums, the musical setting for his singing poses no difficulties.

title: Federal Judge Upholds Fishing Rights of Indians in Michigan Waters
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 8 (UPI)  In what was regarded as an important ruling on Indian rights, a Federal judge held today held that two 19thcentury treaties give Indians unlimited fishing rights that cannot be limited by the state.

title: Piedmont to Sell Unit
description: The Piedmont Management Company announced yesterday in Los Angeles that it entered into an agreement to sell a wholly owned subsidiary. the Pacific Fidelity Life Insurance Company, to a unit of Life Investors Inc. of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, for $15 million. Half of the $15 million would be paid in cash, with the rest in the form of a 10year promissory note.

title: Shelter Inquiry Uncovers Check Paid to Bronston
description: Former State Senator Jack E. Bronston, who has repeatedly denied receiving any compensation for representing the Convenience and Safety Corporation, received a $12,500 check from the compa ny's chairman on June 28, 1978, according to officials close to the Federal investigation of the city's bus shelter franchise.

title: Topics
description: Perspectives

title: The World Behind High School Walls
description: At John Jay High School, in the Par Slope section of Brooklyn. time measured out by buzzers and bells in chunks of 40 minutes each. The big men and women on campus wear sweatshirts inscribed with a double J. Status is a fresh pair of Puma sneakers, a date with a member of the basketball team. a part in the spring play. Discipline is meted out with pink slips and telephone calls to parents.

title: Japan's Opposition Is Rebuffed on Scandal Inquiry
description: TOKYO, May 8  After months of political agitation. Japan's ruling conservative party today turned down a request by opposition parties that former Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi testify before Parliament on his role in the biggest aircraft payoff scandal to erupt here since the Lockheed affair in the mid1970's.

title: Q8A
description: Q. Last week 1 spent an hour and walked 12 blocks trying to find quart of buttermilk to use in a recipe. I finally gave up in desperation and did without.Is there any substitute for buttermilk?

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: ABC Buys Reddy Special
description: LOS ANGELES, May 8 (AP)  ABCTV has purchased The Helen Reddy Special, the hourlong variety show the singer bought back from NBC in dispute last month.

title: WASHINGTON The New Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The Carter Administration is now trying to adjust to the newpolitical leaders in the world  in China, Japan and Britain, as well as in Rhodesia and elsewhere in Africa, Asia and Latin America. At the same time it must deal with the old leaders in Moscow and the Middle East. Do the leaders make a difference, or do events still dominate world politics?

title: Hawthorne Lee, 70, Businessman
description: Hawthorne E. Lee, a New York realestate agent and businessman, died Monday at his home in New York City following a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Sadat Assures U.S. Business
description: CAIRO, May 8  President Anwar elSadat assured visiting American businessmen today that it would. be profitable to invest in Egypt despite attempts by other Arab states to isolate Egypt politically and econom ira 11v

title: Heinicke Is Named In S.E.C. Complaint
description: MIAMI, May 8  The Securities. and Exchange Commission has accused Florida corporation of having violated antifraud provisions of the Federal securities laws in connection with its sales of aircraft parts manufactured from allegedly misappropriated blueprints designed by another company.

title: The Region
description: Murder Trial Ends With Little Notice

title: Warsaw Pact Calls Meeting
description: MOSCOW, May 8 (AP)  The foreign ministers of all Warsaw Pact countries will meet in Budapest in midMay, the Soviet pressagency Tass reported today.

title: Economic Scene
description: PEKING WAKING before dawn in the Nationalities Hotel here, a visitor switched on his transistor radio and heard English spoken. It was the daily English lesson, presented in the form of a play about an old woman who was traveling by train to visit her son, serving in an army unit Inner Mongolia. But when the woman got off the train, her son was not there. She had got off at the wrong station and had lost his letter. She called and called his name, weeping. A factory worker, seeing her plight, took the old mother home with him to his wife and little daughter, who quickly came to love granny.
