Tarken ton Joins Television Team
description: ATLANTA, May 8 (AP) Fran Tarkenton, holder of most major National Football League passing records, officially quit pro football today to become a television commentator with American Broadcasting Companies.

title: Iranian Jew Executed For Links With Israel; Six Others Also Shot
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Wednesday, May 9 (UPI)  Two multimillionaires, including a Jew sentenced to death partly for his connections with Israel, were executed along with five other people today by Islamic firing squads.

title: Tremor Rocks Yugoslav City
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 8 (Reuter)  An earth tremor of medium strength shook the southern Yugoslav City of Skopije today but there were no reports of casualties or damage, officials In 1963, Skoplje was devastated by an earthquake that killed more than I,000 people.

title: House Votes to grid a Tax Break Given to Domestic Oil Companies
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  The House today voted overwhelmingly to abolish a special tax advantage enjoyed by domestic oil companies and thus reduce the 1980 deficit by an amount variously estimated at $300 million to 51.7 billion. The vote was 355 to 66.

title: 33 Food Outlets Called Violators of Health Law
description: The New York City Department of Health yesterday released the names of 33 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also named seven restaurants that had corrected earlier violations and two that had been closed for failing to do so.

title: Twins Win FightFilled Game
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 8 (AP)  Ken Landreaux drove in five runs, and Roy Smalley and Bombo Rivera knocked irifour apiece as the Minnesota TwinS routed the Toronto Blue Jays, 166; in a fightfilled contest tonight.

title: Rock: New Barbarians
description: WELL, all the heavy-breathing rumors proved false. The New Barbarians, the ad hoc rock band supporting Ron Wood's new record. came and went at Madison Square Garden Monday night and not one single guest star appeared. The crowd hung around long after the lights had come up, disbelievingly  teased on by an empty stage, microphone stand with three mikes and even a roadie setting up the drum kit again. But nobody showed.

title: Concert: National Orchestral Group
description: AS music director and principal conductor of the New York City Ballet, Robert Irving is heard much more than lle is seen by the public. Last night in Carnegie Hall, he made one of his infrequent appearances on the concert platform, leading the season's final concert by the National Orchestral Association. His wellbalanced program included one unfamiliar contemporary piece, Benjamin Lees's Passacaglia for Orchestra (1975) in its New York premiere; one unfamiliar old piece, Moritz Moszkowski's Violin Concerto, with Charles Treger as soloist, and the very familiar but always welcome Enigma Variations of Sir Edward Elgar.

title: Wildensteins
description: The Wildenstein family collection of palacequality French 18thcentury furnishings is up for sale at auction again. The collection, valued at more tnan pG.million, is described by Sotheby Parke Bernet, which will disperse the 200 examples in Monaco on June 25 and 26, as the finest assemblage of French furniture to be auctioned in a century.

title: Best Buys
description: AS rising food prices force shoppers to stretch their imaginations, manufacturers have begun showing a bit of resourcefulness, too.

title: Deaths
description: SCHWEIZERWalter Lewis devoted son of Jacob and Pearl Schweizer, cherished brother of Paul Schweizer. Services Thursday. 17:15 onl at The Riverside 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Suit Filed on Testing Chemicals
description: The Natural Resources Defense Council filed a suit in Manhattan yesterday seeking to compel the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to require private manufacturers to test highrisk chemicals. The suit contends that the agency is several months behind in imposing regulations to require the testing under a Federal law for the control of dangerous chemicals in commercial production.

title: Stokely to Monitor City Investing Link
description: Alfred J. Stokely, board chairman of StokelyVan Camp Inc.. the food company. told stockholders in a letter today that it would continue to monitor stock purchases by the City Investing Company and keep you informed. He said he did not know City Investinn's ultimate intentions.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article on the Style page April 28, Marietta Tree was incorrectly described as the first woman to serve as chief United States delegate to the United Nations. She has never held that post; in 196465 she served as delegate to the Trusteeship Council, with the rank of ambassador.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCELOINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, May 8, 1979

title: A Good Way to Close a Tax Loophole
description: The latest idea for beating the high cost of living the taxexempt housing bond. It has allowed thousands of middle- and upperincome families to obtain home mortgages at about 2 percentage points below the going interest rate. The catch is that someone has pay the 2 percent  and the someone in this case the rest of us. That is why legislation to close the loophole, introduced last week by House Ways and Means Chairman Al Ullman, deserves support.

title: Futures License Indictments
description: Twenty persons were indicted in Manhattan yesterday for allegedly making false statements on their applications for licenses to buy and tell commodity futures.

title: Court Says Priest's Confidentiality Is Limited to Talks With Penitent
description: ALBANY, May 8  The Court of Appeals, New York State's highest court, ruled today that the confidentiality of talks between a priest and a penitent did not extend to conversations with other people that were a result of the privileged talks.

title: News of the Theater Van Dyke Ending 20Year Absence
description: IN Dick Van Dyke's opinion, &performer has two choices: You can do television and films, which L mn the entertainment industry, or you can go on the stage  which is the Teal show business. After a long, succeSsful career in the entertainment- industry, Mr. Van Dyke has opted for the real thing. He has just signed to 'star in Lawrence Roman's new play, Tragedies/A Comedy, which will bring him back to Broadway for the first time in almost 20 years.

title: Chess:
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Alitalia Seeks DC10's
description: Italy's air carrier, Alitalia, announced that it hoped to purchase six DCI0 jet airliners from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for $310 million. The first three of the airliners will be added to the passenger fleet between June 1981 and May 1982. In St. Louis, McDonnell Douglas said that negotiations with Alitalia were under way, but that the sale had not been made final.

title: Women's Interclub Golf
description: FINAL STANDINGS

title: Minnesota Gas Refund
description: The Minnesota Gas Company said yesterday that it had filed with the Minnesota Public Service Commission a proposed plan to refund $13 million to its customers in the form of a line of credit on current bills. The refunds represent the disallowed portion of a $16.5 million general rate rise put into effect by the utility in January 1978.

title: Citicorp Sells Notes
description: Citicorp sold $100 million of its 91day notes yesterday at an average rate of 10.180 percent, up from 10.125 percent last week and its highest rate since late February. Accepted bids ranged from 10.151 to 10.190 percent with $649.8 million submitted. Fortysix percent of the bids at the high rate were accepted.

title: Murdoch, Greschner Get Goals
description: Under a flashing scoreboard that predicted, WE CAN DO IT, the Rangers did it last night, cruising into the Stanley Cup final by ending their dramatic series against the Islanders with a 21 victory.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ON Easter Sunday, Jack Greenberg was walking his dog when he observed a man releasing the air from the tire of an automobile. As I passed. he writes. he looked up me and asked, I bet you wonder why I'm letting the air out of this tire. I told him I did.

title: Energy Agency Asks Data Hunt In Cancer Death
description: The Department of Energy has requested a subsidiary of the Atlantic Richfield Oil Company to search old employee , medical records to see if a former worker received notice that he had absorbed an unusually large dose of radiation while on a storage site for radioactive waste in i Lewiston. N.Y.

title: Flour for Displaced Vietnamese
description: ROME, May 8 (AP)  The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization has approved an emergency grant of $5.4 million to ship almost 19,000 tons of wheat flour to Vietnamese displaced by the recent war between China and Vietnam.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ExChrysler Official Up for DeLorean Job
description: When Eugene A. Cafiero resigned two months ago as vice chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, he said that he wanted to pursue other business interests. Now the 52-year-old executive is negotiating to become president of the DeLorean Motor Company, established by John Z. DeLorean, a former top executive of the General Motors Corporation.

title: ,Electricity Rates To Rise by 15% Con Edison Says
description: Average Bill for Summer Put at $32.34 a Month

title: Private Lives
description: IT MUST have been a Wednesday, because he wasn't typing, and so he was willing to answer the telephone. When he is typing, be can't stand to be interrupted; thus be is always sitting down when the alarm clock of the outside world goes off. When, however, he is merely thinking, any excuse to stop is welcome. Every Wednesday, ready or not, he is obliged to think, and he looks upon the telephone as a sort of friendly parrot.

title: Soviet Beats U.S. Five
description: MOSCOW. May 8 (UPI) The Soviet Union beat the United States. 9177. today in an Intercontinental Cup basketball game at Kiev, the Tass press agency reported. The Russians led. 4338. at halftime.

title: Brazil Stresses Farming and Enrolls Its Miracle
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The new Government of Brazil has decided that its top economic priority will be the expansion of agriculture, and to lead the effort has named the man who crafted the socalled economic miracle a decade ago.

title: Rubber Union Is Due To Call Strike Today At Uniroyal's Plants1
description: A strike at noon today by nearly 8,500 workers at Uniroyal Inc. was expected after talks between the tire maker and Federal mediators failed yesterday afternoon to make any progress toward negotiating a new contract with the United Rubber Workers union.

title: Benson Ford Said To Coerce
description: DETROIT, May 8  Attorneys for Edith McNaughton Ford said in court papers presented here today that her son Benson Ford Jr. tried to coerce an agreement from her to turn over to him control of a trust of $7.5 million in Class B Ford stock left for his benefit.

title: Steel Dumping Laid to Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)  The International Trade Commission ruled today that the United States steel industry was being injured by unfairly low prices charged for imported carbon steel plate from Taiwan.

title: The New York Times /Larry C. Morris
description: The impossible happened last night at Madison Square Garden. The improbable will have to come later. With their 21 victory over the Islanders, the Rangers captured a semifinal series that no one, including themselves, had dared dream when the National Hockey League playoffs started.

title: Regulation Foe Atop the F.C.C.
description: He had had no experience before it the entrenched Federal administrative bureaucracy. but he had a reputation in the offices of Congress for being fast and decisive when a problem needed solving.

title: State Democratic Group Adopts Resolution Criticizing President
description: ALBANY, May 8  Discontent with President Carter emerged today at meeting of the Democratic State Committee when members approved a resolution questioning Mr. Carter's urban policy and heard a Democratic legislative leader heavily criticize the Democratic President.

title: Scope of Investigation at NBC Widens
description: The Federal investigation into financial irregularities within the Nationa: Broadcasting Company's unit-manager system has moved beyond that department and now includes not only unit managers and supervisors. but aiso some programming and financia: executives. sources close to the investigation report.

title: MOSCOW SEES PERIL IN OLYMPICS INFLUX
description: MOSCOW, May 8  The head of the Moscow city party committee warned citizens today against succumbing to ideological contamination when thousands of foreigners pour into the Soviet capital for the Olympic Games next year.

title: France Said to Pledge to Replace IraqBound Reactor
description: PARIS, May 8  France has formally assured Iraq that it will replace the sophisticated research reactor destroyed by saboteurs here shortly before it was to have been shipped to Baghdad and that the replacement will be the same as the original, French officials have said.

title: MARGARET THATCHER TO REPLACE ENVOYS
description: LONDON. May 8  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has decided not to reappoint Peter Jay as Ambassador to the United States or Ivor Richard as chief representative at the United Nations, the Foreign Office disclosed today.

title: RICHARD M. KLEBERG, HEAD OF KING RANCH
description: KINGSVILLE, Tex., May 8 (AP) Richard M. Kleberg Jr., board chairman of King Ranch Inc., and one of the most powerful men in Texas ranching, died today. He was 62 nears old.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: BUSINESS Digest

title: The Escargot: A Quick Course
description: A CULINARY wag once observed that the eminent appeal of snails to most epicures was as a preeminent excuse to eat great quantities of butter and garlic without apology. While that observation may be trifle wide of the mark, the appetite of Americans for that curious food has become increasingly evident over the past few years. They dine on escargots stuffed in the shells, mushroom caps and in ceramic pots, with an enthusiasm almost equal to that once reserved for shrimp cocktails and clams on the half shell.

title: Letters
description: Reducing Jury Selection to a Lottery

title: Welfare Board Splits a Poor, Rural Family
description: MARENGO, Ind., May 7  People who live in dire poverty. as most people do here in Crawford County, the poorest of Indiana's 92 counties, seldom raise their voices on any issue. When you earn less than $4,000 a year, which is the lot of many among the 9,000 Crawford residents, nothing matters much outside family, food and shelter. Tamper with any of these. though, and the people will be heard.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: THERE was a sense of exquisite timing about the recent strike of apartment house employees. It was, at once, long enough to avoid being categorized as a mere pimple of irritation, and short enough to preclude development into a serious rash.

title: G.E. and 2 Unions Hold Talks
description: The General Electric Company and two large unions held their first full day of contract negotiations yesterday with the aim of reaching accords before pact expirations at the end of next month.

title: Jonathan Logan And F.T.C. Settle
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) One of the nation's biggest suppliers of women's apparel agreed today to a Federal Trade Commission order against fixing prices of its products.

title: Carter Names Atherton As New Envoy to Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (Reuters) President Carter today nominated Alfred L. Atherton Jr., a senior diplomat and Middle East expert, as the new United States Ambassador to Eevot.

title: Advertising
description: ACHANGE of key executives was announced yesterday by the Interpublic Group of Companies, helping to explain why Carl Spielvogel resigned as chairman of the executive committee and vice chairman of the board.

title: Pentagon to Produce New Tank Despite Call for Additional Tests
description: WASHINGTON. May 8 (AP)  Defense Secretary Harold Brown announced today that the Defense Department would go ahead with immediate production of the nation's newest generation of tanks. although Congressiona7 investigators had urged that further tests and design changes be made.

title: Castro May Visit U.N. in the Fall
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.,May 8 President Fidel Castro of Cuba intends to visit the United Nations in September in an attempt to demonstrate what Havana regards as its increasing prominence as a leader in the third world, according to wellplaced diplomats.

title: Suddenly Orioles Take Flight
description: BALTIMORE, May 8  While public attention was being monopolized by horses named Spectacular Bid, Flying Paster and General Assembly, a flock of birds took startling flight recently. The birds bear names like Singleton, Martinez, Palmer, Dauer and Roenicke and they play baseball under the beni en direction of Earl Weaver.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, May 9,1979

title: Flood Retrial Begins June 4
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)  The retrial of Representative Daniel J. Flood, Democrat of Pennsylvania, will begin as scheduled June 4, a Federal district judge said today. Judge Oliver Gasch also said he hoped that Mr. Flood's trial on bribery, perjury and conspiracy charges could be completed within three weeks. The first trial for the ailing, 76yearold Congressman ended in a hung jury in February.

title: Three Mile Shadow on G.P.U. Meeting
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., May 9  Stockholders of the General Public Utilities Corporation today got their first chance to challenge management since an accident crippled the company's Three Mile Island nuclear power plant last March 28.

title: Senate in New Hampshire Votes To Raise the Drinking Age to 20
description: CONCORD, N.H., May 9 (AP)  The Senate voted yesterday to raise the state's drinking age from 18 years to 20 to match the new higher age in Massachusetts.

title: Iran Plans 3.5% Rise In Oil Prices
description: In a move that is expected to lead to another escalation in world oil prices, Iran has started to notify oil companies that, on May 15, it will raise the price of all grades of its oil by 60 cents a barrel or about 3.5 percent, according to industry sources in New York.

title: Panel Blocks Baker Move to Revive Dam in Tennessee
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate Republican leader and a Presidential pmspect, today called an endangered, twoinch species of perch the bane of my existence and the nemesis of what I fondly hoped would be my onbien years.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Crocker Mortgage Rise
description: The Crocker Bank announced yesterday in San Francisco that it was increasing its prime home mortgage rate to 10 7/8 percent from 10 3/4 percent, effective today. The rise reflects increases in moneymarket rates, the bank said.

title: Deaths
description: LEVEEPolly Annenber g, The United Jewish AopealFederation of Jewish Philanthropies Joint Camonion records with profound sadness the oassing of a gracious and generous woman, who was a most thoughtful supporter of our Women's Campaign throughout the years and whose family has long been identified with the cause of human need in our home community. In Israel and in nations in all parts of the world. She will be deed, missed, and we offer heartfelt sympathy to the members of her family. LAURENCE A. TISCH, President MILDREDGEIGER,

title: Crying MEOW?
description: The public has long refused to believe there is an energy crisis or even an oil shortage, passing off each call to action as just another cry of wolf  or MEOW, Russell Baker's term for Jimmy Carter's declaring the moral equivalent of war. But Congress ought to know better, especially now when agitated Californians pull guns and beat un pregnant women at the gas pump

title: Vornado Letter On Proxy Fight
description: The management of Vornado Inc., facing a proxy fight from Interstate Properties, issued a letter yesterday to Vornado shareholders charging that Interstate had started the proxy contest after failing to buy a number of Vornado stores below the original cost and below their replacement value.

title: I.T.T. Net Up 31.2% in Quarter
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday that its firstquarter consolidated net income climbed 31.2 percent to a record $209.1 million, or $1.47 a share, from $159.4 million, or $1.12 a share. a year earlier.

title: POLLY ANNENBERG LEVEE
description: Polly Annenberg Levee, a philanthropist and sister of Walter Annenberg, publisher and former Ambassador to Britain, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital following a long illness. She was 73 years old and lived at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Crown Heights Gets Hot Line To Avert Crises
description: The new Crown Heights Coalition of black and Jewish leaders in the Brooklyn community announced yesterday its intention to establish a hot line between the two groups. It also said it would set up an ombudsman's office in an effort to avoid the hostilities that upset the community last summer.

title: United Press International
description: CALIFORNIA LANDSLIDES REMAIN A DANGER: A boulder falling on the Pacific Coast Highway near Malibu yesterday. Officials there said that the artery would remain closed at least for the rest of the week.

title: Parimutuel Clerks End Strike at Coast Tracks
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 9 (UPI) Labor peace came to California race tracks today with the end of a 28day strike by parimutuel clerks and other union members.

title: Chinese Trade Pact With U.S. Unsettled
description: PEKING, May 9  The chances that Commerce Secretary Juanita M. Kreps will leave China with an initialed trade agreement appeared to be fading today.

title: New Owners For NABC
description: The Nordic American Banking Corporation, which has headquarters in New York, said yesterday that its ownership would undergo a chanee.

title: Thorpe Trial Is Told He Planned a Murder To Protect His Career
description: LONDON, May 9  Jeremy Thorpe was portrayed tpday as a desperate and anxious man, drWen to plotting a murder to protect his increasingly successful political career.

title: Ben Bella, Held 14 Years in Algeria, May Be Freed Soon
description: EL ASNAM, Algeria  Ahmed Ben Bella, independent Algeria's first President and for 14 years a prisoner in his homeland, could soon be given the beginning of his freedom in this dusty crossroads town on the main highway between Algiers and Oran.

title: A Party Full Of Bill Biasses
description: IT'S a class act, Helen Holler ith said, summing up the party Lord & Taylor gave the other night for Bill Blass, whiner of store's Creative Design Award for 1979.

title: ABC Stations Contented
description: LOS ANGELES, May 9  Our biggest problem, said Jim Tighe, manager of the ABCTV station in El Dorado, Ark., is whether it's going to rain tonight and spoil the party.

title: Houston City Official Indicted in Extortions Involving Contractors
description: HOUSTON, May 9  A Federal grand jury returned a sixcount indictment against Jack Douglas Key, director of the Houston Purchasing Department, today on charges of obstructing interstate commerce and extorting $42,500 from contractors doing business with the city.

title: $745,000 in Paintings Reported Stolen Here
description: Six paintings said to be worth a total of $745,000 were reported stolen from truck making deliveries to art galleries on the East Side yesterday afternoon, the police said. Among the paintings were works by Pierre Bonnard, John Singleton Copley and Mary Cassatt.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Energy

title: Debate on Energy: Anger and Confusion
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The voice of the angry consumer, protesting higher gasoline prices, longer waiting lines and larger oil company profits, is intruding into the debate over energy policy on Capitol Hill. As Representa- tive James L. Oberstar, Democrat of Minnesota, put it: People are really hot on this issue. They stand up at town meetings and boil over.

title: Eddie Jefferson, 60, Jazz Lyricist, Slain After Leaving Detroit Club
description: DETROIT, May 9 (AP)  Eddie Jefferson, the vocalist regarded by critics as one of the great innovators of modern jazz, was shot to death early today as he left a popular nightclub where he had just finished an opening engagement.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON, May 9  We resent bureaucracy and the mechanization of life. That feeling is almost universal among Americans, cutting across differences of age and politics. But most of the complaining is directed at government, when in truth the bureaucracy of private institutions can be just as oppressive. Herewith a personal example.

title: Getty Talks With Drivers Put Off
description: Negotiations between Getty Oil and its truck drivers who deliver gasoline, originally scheduled for today, have been postponed until 9 A. M. tomorrow at the Howard Johnson's Motor Lodge at Kennedy International Airport, Hubert Robinson, a Federal mediator announced. The Petroleum Trades Employ- ees Union, representing 116 Getty drivels in New York and New Jersey, is seeking settlement with Getty, the last contract to be settled with the six oil companies with which the union negotiates.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION.

title: Cabaret: Hildegarde
description: HILDEGARDE, who admits, somewhat obliquely, to be 73 or 74 years old, has ventured down to SoHo from her old midtown Manhattan haunts to play farewell engagement this week and next at the Ballroom.

title: Union Pacific Wins
description: The Union Pacific Corporation which for many years has been a major landowner in the area of its railroad operations in the West, won a round in court yesterday over the mineral rights on some land sold to predecessors of the Guild Trust in Uinta County, Wyo United States District Judge EwingT. Kerr said that, in selling the land, Union Pacific had reserved to itself rights to all coal and other minerals.

title: Policeman Slain After He Takes Shot at His Wife.
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 9  An offDuty New York City policeman was shot and killed by a Westchester deputy sheriff after he tried to shoot his estranged wife in a crowded waiting room in Family Court here and critically wounded a woman bystander instead.

title: Anton Dolin to Perform At Ballet Contest in South
description: The first annual U.S.A. International Ballet Competition, to take place June 1829 in Jackson, Miss., has announced that the English dancer, choreographer and anecdotalist Anton Dolin will appear on June 27 in his oneman show, Conversations With Diaghilev.

title: Yankees Conquer Mariners, 50
description: The bull pen telephone did not ring in Yankee Stadium last night and that was fine with Ron Guidry, who sat and watched while Ed Figueroa pitched the New York Yankees to a 50 victory over the Seattle Mariners.

title: Votes by Senate on Gas Rationing
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)  Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate approved President Carter's basic changes in his standby gasoline rationing proposal, clearing the way for final Senate action on the measure:

title: House Rejects Two G.O.P. Attempts to Cut Budget
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The House today rejected two major Republican attempts to trim the Democratic version of the 1980 budget that would have lowered Government spending and reduced the prospective deficit.

title: Deaths
description: RACHLINJerry, beloved husband of Martha, devoted fattier of Barton & Phyllis Rachlin. Loving grandfather. Dear brother of David Rachlin and Dora Ullman. Services at BoulevardPark West 115 West 79 St, N YC Friday at 10:15 am.

title: Geothermal Power Supplies Detailed
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) The United States Geological Survey reported today that America could tap as much energy from underground heat sources as current oil consumption would supply in 162 years.

title: Cement Company Cited As PriceGuide Violator
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The Carter Administration today cited one of the nation's largest cement manufacturers, Ideal Basic Industries Inc., as out of compliance with the President's trice guidelines.

title: COMMODITIES Soviet Purchase of Corn Propels Wheat Futures
description: A powerful rally carried wheat futures to new season's highs yesterday on speculation that the Soviet Union will buy more United States grain and fears that 1979 will be a poor crop year.

title: SONDRA FARBER ISAAC
description: Sondra Farber Isaac, an assistant professor at Queensborough Community College, died of cancer Monday at the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City. She was 3R years old and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Rock: Matthews Sings
description: IAN MATTHEWS has been around for a long time, as an original member of Fairport Convention, the pioneering English electric folkrock band, and then as leader of Matthews Southern Comfort, which won the hearts of critics for its tasteful country-folk-rock. More recently he has actually manages a nit single, Shake It, and Tuesday night he was at the Lone Star Cafe as part of a tour.

title: Dancemobile Plays At Symphony Space
description: The Harlem Cultural Council's Dancemobile is completing its 12th season with performances through May 19 at the Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway. Eighteen jazz, African and modern dance companies are appearing.

title: Around the Nation
description: MIAMI, May 9  Antismoking activists, defeated in one of the most narrow referendum votes in local history, vowed today to make another effort to curtail smoking in public places in the Miami area.

title: VICTOR SAVILLE, 83, FILM PRODUCER, DIES
description: Victor Saville, the British director and producer whose credits during a 40year film career in London and Hollywood included Goodbye, Mr. Chips, Evergreen, the landmark British musical comedy, and the panoramic Green Dolphin Street, died in London on Tuesday. He was 83 years old.

title: House Approves Measure Urging Bonn to Extend Nazi Prosecution
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI)  The House of Representatives approved resolution today urging West Germany to extend its time limit for prosecuting Nazi war criminals.

title: MAX J, SHULMAN
description: Dr. Max J. Shulman, who had practiced general medicine in the Bronx for 35 years until his retirement in 1969, died Tuesday in Hallandale, Fla. He was 81 years old.

title: The City
description: Stiffer penalties for taxicab drivers found guilty of overcharging have been proposed by the Taxi and Limousine Commission at the behest of Mayor Koch. The new regulations could be put into effect within six weeks, following receipt of public comment by the commission.

title: $37 Million in Damage
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 9 (UPI) An atomic fuel expert for General Public Utilities Corporation said today that the accident at Three Mile Island resulted in $37 million worth of damage to the No. 2 reactor's fuel core, valued at $40 million. Vincent Zodiaco, nuclear fuels manager for the company, told the Public Utility Commission that the damaged core must be considered as waste material.

title: NBC's White Paper To Be Revived in Fall
description: NBCTV's White Paper documentary series, which went off the air in 1974, will be revived next season, beginning with a twohour program in September focusing on American foreign policy.

title: Guitar: Bach Suite By Corey
description: PETER COREY is a 21yearold guitarist who made his New York debut four years ago as the youngest artist ever to be a winner in the Concert Artists Guild auditions. Tuesday night, he performed at the 92d Street Y, this time under the auspices of the Pro Musicis Foundation.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: William R. Grant. a former president of Smith Barney & Company, has been named president of the MacKayShields Financial Corporation, an independent moneymanagement firm with about $1.5 billion under management. Gilbert MacKay, the 69-year-old cofounder of MacKayShields in 1938, continues as chairman.

title: Egypt Preparing SelfRule Plan
description: CAIRO, May 9  Egypt is preparing plan that is intended to broaden the definition of Palestinian selfrule in coming negotiations with Israel dealing with the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Those Irresistible Rangers
description: Until now, hockey has always been strange sport to many New Yorkers. They either could not or would not try to understand it. Nurtured on baseball, football and basketball, they considered hockey an unregistered alien from Canada, an intruder on the other seasons. Oh, enough people have been in- terested in hockey to fill Madison

Devoted brother of Arthur and Dr. David B. Services Fri 17:30 at the Westchester Riverside 21 West Broad St, Mt Vernon NY.

title: Texts of Vance and Brown Remarks on Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) lowilig are the texts of statements today at the White House by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Secretary of Defense Harold Brown announcing general agreement with the Soviet Union on a new treaty to limit strategic arms:

title: The City That Hires Now, Pays Later
description: The more one considers Mayor Koch's proposal to add 4,200 workers to the New York City payroll in fiscal 1980, the more perverse it seems. The Mayor envisions a balanced 1980 budget only because $285 million in expenses continue to be misclassified as capital improvements to be paid with borrowed money. A gap of at least $405 million looms in 1981 and it will be closed only by reducing the work force. Adding new employees appears to be taking everyone in the wrong direction.

title: Sound
description: JtOYCE MAYNARD, a graceful writer who sometimes shares these pages, often lets us in on bits and pieces of her home life. The other day she recalled: In our household, the sport was, conversation, and it was a source of sadness to us all, think, that words  spoken into the air evaporate, rather than, like laundry, collect in nice tangible piles. So, often, we turned on a tape recorder underneath the dinner table as we sat down to eat. Only in adult life did I come to realize how odd this was.

title: A Rockefeller Gift: Folk Art in Virginia
description: WILLIAMSBURG, VA. THEY lived surrounded by house museums in a home that was anything but. Bassett Hall, the 18thcentury manor that Abby Aldrich and John D. Rockefeller Jr. restored to serve as their residence here, is the antithesis of its more formally decorated neighbors. The rooms where the Rockefellers ate, slept and entertained are downright homey and full of the sort of exuberant mix of furnishings that curators abhor but people adore.

title: Former Nepal Premier Is Released in a Move To Halt Rising Unrest
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 9  Bisheswar Prasad Koirala, the former Prime Minister and now a leading dissident, was freed from house arrest early today in an apparent bid by King Birendra's Government to curb civil disorders in this undevelneed hut strategic Himalayan state.

title: Modern Wings On Old Houses: Risk and Reward
description: AMODERN wing on an old house, like a MayDecember marriage, can be magnetic union of opposing styles and traditions. For the matchmaking architect, however, the pairing of opposite designs is fraught with failure, as indicated by the innumerable odd couples found in most older communities.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES LIMITS ON APLANTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  A House committee today approved a sixmonth moratorium on construction permits for nuclear reactors and a ban on the operation of new reactors until the Federal Government has developed a plan to deal with nuclear accidents.

description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The draft treaty limiting Soviet and American heavy bombers and intercontinental missiles is the most detailed and complex arms.control agreement ever negotiated by the two nuclear superpowers.

title: FIRING SQUADS KILL 2 IRAN BUSINESSIVIEN
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 9  Two multimillionaire businessmen, one a prominent Jewish supporter of Israel, were killed along with several others by revolutionary firing squads early this morning, bringing the total number of dead at the hands of revolutionary courts to 200.

description: A measure that makes drinking alcoholic beverages on the streets of New York City illegal was signed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: U.S., Citing Bacteria, Recalls 2 Nasal Sprays Of SmithKline Corp.
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)  The Government today announced the recall of virtually all Contac Nasal Mist and SineOff OnceADay Sinus Spray on the market because of possible bacterial contamination.

The former star  super- star?  of Saturday Night Live is back on NBCTV, tonight at 9 o'clock, with another special: The Chevy Chase National Humor Test. On scale of 100, he rates about 16.

description: Jeremy Brown, English pianist who was to have made his debut in Alice Tully Hall tonight, has canceled his appearance because of tendinitis. His place will be taken by Patricia MichaeHan. Tickets for the Brown recital will be honored.

title: HolmesShavers Set For Giants Stadium
description: Larry Holmes will defend his World Boxing Council heavyweight title against Earnie Shavers Sept. 14 on the first boxing show to be held at Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands, ABCTV announced yesterday.

title: Con Ed Found Guilty Of Gross Negligence For Blackout in 1977
description: A supermarket chain won a 340,500 judgment against the Consolidated Edison Company in State Supreme Court in the Bronx yesterday after a jury found the utility guilty of gross negligence for the blackout that began on the evening of July 13.1977.

title: Albert Glick, 59, Once Was Warden in Queens
description: Albert Glick, a former warden for the New York City Department of Correction, was pronounced dead Saturday night at Community General Hospital in Monticello, N.Y., following a heart attack. He was 59 years old and lived in Levittown, L.I.

title: Jersey Projects $10 Million. Cost For Cleaning Up a Toxic Dump
description: TRENTON, May 9  State officials said today that it would cost $10 million to 315 million to clean up the 16 million pounds of toxic and hazardous wastes stored at an Elizabeth waste disposal warehouse, and 34 million just to inventory the materials.

description: In Aug. 20. 1975, Edgard Lang Sacasa. son of Federico Lang. a wealthy Nicaraguan businessman and longtime ally of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle, left his home to join the country's leftist guerrilla movement. the Sandinist National Liberation Front. title: A's Norris and Phils
description: BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP)  Mike Norris allowed one hit  Gary Roenicke's seventhinning double  and Mario Guerrero and Jeff Newman drove in ninthinning runs as the Oakland A's posted a 42 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

description: WESTBURY, L. I., May 9  The suburban bubble was burst last night by a slap shot that brought a yowl of pleasure from a small army of fistshaking intruders who had come from out of the setting sun, from New York City.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET COMPLETE STRATEGIC ARMS TREATY; SENATE BATTLE FORECAST
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The United States announced today that it had reached basic agreement with the Soviet Union on a new treaty limiting longrange missiles and bombers.

title: Stainless Steel Flatware Comes Out of the Kitchen
description: NOT too long ago, stainless steel flatware was sterling silver's poor relation. Relegated to the kitchen table for family meals, or taken on picnics before the advent of plastic, stainless steel was rarely seen on the dining room table in the company of the good china and crystal. Recently though, stainless steel flatware has become the Cinderella of cutlery.

description: LOS ANGELES, May 9  Restrictions on gasoline sales, the first in the nation since 1979, were carried out by 10 California counties today.

description: THE stock market sinking spell that has carried the Dow Jones industrial average into the low 800's  it closed yesterday at 838.62. up 3.73may have further to go.

title: Trial by Anonymous Jury
description: Has criminal justice in this country become so turbulent as to require trial by anonymous jury? Not long ago, such an idea would have been inconceivable but that's just what a divided Federal Court of Appeals has decided in upholding the conviction and life sentence Leroy (Nickv) Barnes. the Harlem narcotics kingpin. The jurors identities were kept secret not only from the press and public but from the prosecution and defense as well. The court said the practice was warranted by legitimate concern for the jurors safety, privacy and ability to decide the case impartially. Those dangers are real ; but the decision is disturbing.

title: Backgammon:
description: The American Stock Exchange Annual Tournament, under the direction of Susan Bender, was completed recently after several months of elimination rounds. First place went to zsyearoia Michael Rosenberg, a talented young Scotsman from Glasgow, who took up backgammon seriously just a year ago when he moved to New York City. A natural games player, he had previously gained international recognition as a bridge expert and member of the British Bridge Team. The runnerup was Charles Silverman: semi- finalists were Robin Katz and Mel Weiss.

title: More Funds Are Sought In Food Stamp Program
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)  The Carter Administration warned Congress today that unless it approved new funds to allow the food stamp program to keep up with steadily rising prices, benefits for poor families mieht be curtailed.

title: Ax Wins Fisher Prize
description: The Avery Fisher Prize, one of the most prestigious in the concert world, has been given this year to the pianist Emanuel Ax. Awarded annually to an American instrumentalist in recognition of outstanding achievement, it includes a cash stipend of $5,000 and ap. pearances with the New York Philharmonic during its regular season, with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, the Mostly Mozart Festival and the Great Performers series in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: MONTREAL, May 9  The Asbestos Corporation, the General Dynamics Corporation's subsidiary that is under a threat of expropriation by the Government of Quebec, has proposed as an alternative that the company and the Government undertake new manufacturing and mining projects designed to increase employment in Quebec's asbestos industry, company officials said today.

title: Mrs. Carter Visits Factory
description: GRUYERES, Switzerland, May 9 (Reuters)  Rosalyn Carter and her daughter, Amy, visited a Swiss cheese factory and Alpine farm today at the end of a fourday stay in Switzerland. Mrs. Carter, who arrived in the country Sunday to attend the opening of the World Health Organization's annual assembly, told reporters: We have enjoyed our stay here very much. It is a beautiful village.

title: State Seeks Children With Links to DES
description: ALBANY. May 9  The New York State Health Department announced today a major campaign to find the children of an estimated 100,000 New York women who took the drug DES during their pregnancies.

title: New Head of Carter's Advisory Panel on Women
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  She has been the perfect political daughter, the perfect political wife, raising neither conflicts nor controversy.

title: Dance: City Ballet's Toes Tap at Pops
description: YOU can put the wiggle into the danseur noble but you can't take the danseur noble out of the wiggle. That about sums up Peter Martins's hilarious debut as the rumbamad sailor from Fancy Free in the New York City Ballet's special program Tuesday night at the State Theater. It was that kind of an evening.

title: Miss Siebert Assailed on Midland Bid
description: The proposal of the Hongkong & Shanghai Banking Corporation to gain control of the Marine Midland Bank has set off some fireworks in Albany particularly between the New York State Banking Commissioner, Muriel Siebert, and John S. Dyson, Commissionerof Commerce.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY MAY 10, 1979

title: Rock: All Stars Quintet
description: AT one time there may have been more to San Francisco rock than directionless, self-indulgent jamming, the most shameless white blues cliche, and the assturiptiou that the higher the volume, the more profound the psychedelic experience. The writer remembers liking the. Jefferson Airplane at first and being willing to put up with the Grateful Dead's cosmic meanderings once or twice. Presumably, his lack of enthusiasm for the genre brands him as a biased observer; all the more reason to forgive him for walking out of the Bottom 1,ine on Tuesday night after threeand-a-half numbers by the San Fran. cisco All Stars.

title: Italy Gains Semifinals In Nations Cup Tennis
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, May 9 (UPI)  Italy beat Argentina, 21, and became the first team to reach the semifinals of the $250,000 Nations Cup men's tennis tournament today. The United States faces West Germany tomorrow.

title: The International Side Effects
description: MOSCOW, May 9  Negotiations for the arms treaty announced today have been as much political as military, and are likely to have continuing political ef-

title: Mrs. Page, Carding a 78, Is L.I. Senior Golf Victor
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 9 Sara Sage of Piping Rock birdied the final hole at The Creek Club for a 78 and captured the Marian Holland Trophy in the annual Women's Long Island Golf Association senior championship today.

title: China Dismisses New Arms Pact As Only a Game of Hide and Seek
description: HONG KONG, May 9 (Reuters) China dismissed the new treaty to limit strategic arms today as a hideandseek game between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Home Beat
description: EILEEN MAYO, far left, and Adele Heller Zasloff met when Mrs. Mayo was a freelance fabric designer and Mrs. Zasloff a decorator. About a year ago, Mrs. Mayo went on a sabbatical and returned with the beginnings of a new textile collection. The two women started gNU 2, opening a small to-the-trade showroom at 150 East 58th Street. The firm offers wallpapers and fabrics that are, according to Mrs. Zasloff, a contemporary or country. Some of their 100 percent cotton fabrics, handscreened in Brooklyn, are shown at left. In the background is Infinity, a fourscreen, 46-inch-wide fabric that lists for $37.50 per yard. Infinity Diamond, in the foreground (46 inches wide, $24 list a yard), is one of its variations. The three other patterns, from left to right, are Going Baroque (47 inches wide, $45 list per yard), Stripe I (46 inches wide, $37.50 list per yard) and Grapetree (461/2 inches wide, $30 list per yard). These three are in the Bloomingdale's model rooms and can be ordered through the store's interior design department.

title: Canadien Home Ice: Will It Be Thin Ice?
description: BOSTON, May 9  Stan Jonathan, the scrappy left wing of the Boston Bruins, missed 44 games during the regular season because of a fractured right wrist and a dislocated right shoulder that will require surgery in the summer.

title: TOP POP RECORDS
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates a specially fast-selling record.

title: Dr. Joseph Rabacky, 82, LegalMedicine Expert
description: Dr. Joseph F. A. Rubacky, who combined a medical and legal practice for more than 40 years, died Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 82 years old and had lived there since his retirement in 1969.

title: Marinho In Cosmos Doghouse
description: EAST R1UTTIERFORD, N'.J., May 9  It was only 17 days ago that Francisco Marinho, whom the Cosmos coach, Eddie Firmani, calls Glamour Boy, scored three goals in a league game before 72,342 fans at Giants Stadium here. Today, Marinho played with the team's reserves in remote Piscataway, N.J., before fewer than 200 fans.

title: The Chinese Gulag
description: Sometimes the worst kind of news can be heartening, if only for the fact that it becomes known. So it with the account of life in a Chinese political prison that appeared briefly on a Peking wall poster last March. The report, augmented by others, has been passed to the world through Hong Kong, and its author, Wei Jingsheng, may now be suffering the agonies he described.

title: Economic Advisers
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  Through the cruel lens of hindsight, history seems likely to fault President Carter's Council of Economic Advisers for underestimating the strength of the economy two years running and for underestimating the virulence of an inflation that has accelerated to a doubledigit oace.

title: Stage: Poet and Rent
description: DVID MAMET'S The Poet and the Rent at the Circle Repertory is a children's play about an artist with a rental block: he must pay the rent, he can't pay the rent. In the closing minutes of the show, his girlfriend comes to his rescue, a reverse switch on the old routine  the day is saved by my heroine instead of my hem.

title: AllPurpose Computers to Lure $1 Bettor
description: A system of computerized racetrack wagering that has infected much of the country is about to break out in New York, taking from the $2 bettor more than his wager.

title: Spurs Triumph, 116114, Lead Series
description: SAN ANTONIO, May 9 (UPI) Washington's Charles Johnson missed a jump shot at the buzzer tonight and San Antonio posted a 116114 victory over the Bullets, giving the Spurs a 21 lead in their Eastern Conference championship series.

title: Author Faces Contempt Hearing
description: A hearing is scheduled for next Tuesday on a move to hold an author in contempt of court for refusing to disclose the source of a critical comment about Roman Catholic priest made in a book that became the subiect of a libel suit. The priest, the Rev. Sean McManus, sued the author, Russell Warren Howe, for $1 million. Mr. Howe refused again yesterday to disclose a confidential source of information about Father McManus, despite an order by Judge Edward Weinfeld in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HIGHLAND FLING The village pf Brigadoon, in the musical classic Of the same name, comes to life for day every century. Fortunately for the tnany fans of the show, the tuneful, picturesque stage offering, which started on Broadway in 1947, is usually revived locally every springtime. And the delightful story in a Scottish setting by Alan Jay Lerner, his lyrics and the music of Frederick Loewe usually provide an apt seasonal tonic, if the revival troupe is capable.

title: Dr. Otto Deutschberger, 75, Dies; ExRadiologist in New York City
description: Dr. Otto Deutschberger, former director of radiology at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary in New York City, died of cancer May 2 at Hollywood Hospital in Florida after a brief illness. He was 75 years old and had lived in Portugal since his retirement.

title: W.H.O. to Study Moving Egypt Office
description: GENEVA, May 9  The World Health Organization's Assembly agreed today to gxamine a demand by hardline Arab countries that the agency's regional office for the nations of the eastern Mediterranean be transferred from Alexandria, Egypt.

title: ITALY TO USE ARMY AGAINST TERRORISTS
description: ROME, May 9  Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti's caretaker Government decided today to try to stem the growing tide of political violence in Italy by calling in the regular army to aid the police in the fight against terrorists.

title: Big French Loan Pact With China
description: PARIS, May 9  A group of major French banks signed an agreement today to lend China $7 billion, believed to be by far the largest foreign loan accord China has ever negotiated. The pact, negotiated within the framework of a trade agreement France and China

title: Buyers to Get Refunds on Worthless Land in Colorado
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  In the brochures it all looked alluringly beautiful: homesites nestled among mountains, with clear trout streams and ski slopes nearby. And it sounded like an easy way to turn a fast buck.

title: Some Pointers for Your Potato Patch
description: IT'S true you can't go home again, but at least they may still grow real potatoes there. When my family returned to Sweden for visit last year, we went down into my uncle's basement, where one whole wall was lined with bins. In the bins were 20 varieties Of potatoes: red ones, yellow ones, blue ones, white ones. For a week, we ate potatoes.

title: Camco in Soviet Deal
description: Camco Inc. of Houston said it, had completed arrangements for its British subsidiary to provide $36 million of wellcompletion equipment to the Soviet Union for its Siberian oilfields.

title: Militants in El Salvador Undeterred by the Death of 22
description: SAN SALVADOR, May 9  A militant peasantlabor organization vowed today to continue its fivedayold occupation of the Metropolitan Cathedral here despite yesterday's attack on antiGovernment demonstrators by security forces during which at least 22 people were killed.

title: L.I.R.R. Drops Plans to Cut Off Bar Service to Its Drinking Dans
description: The Long Island Rail Road has decided against getting rid of its bar cars, so commuters will be able to continue drowning their sorrows, many of which they feel are rooted in the railroad itself.

title: GARDENING
description: MARSH marigolds, bloodroots, trout lilies, Dutchman'sbreeches, white trilliums, hepaticas. Mention of these early spring wildflowers brings to mind the special places in woodlands and parklands and the banks along streams where they grow. The last of them are lingering in the colder northern regions; you can see them if you burry.

title: Glossary of Technical Terms in the Talks
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  The arms limitation agreement between  the Soviet Union and the United States follows years of talks that involved technical vocabulary and acronymic Jargon. Here are some of the wouls used in the negotiations:

title: Red Tape Snarls Project to Keep Lake George Clean
description: LAKE GEORGE, N.Y.  A problem has developed in the plan to build sewage system to stop the pollution in Lake George  the Federal Government now says it will not approve any work until the local governments conduct a $50,000 study of something they say state law specifically forbids them to do.

title: Martin Joseph McHate, Former Yankee Pitcher
description: HEMPSTEAD LI., April 9  Martin Joseph (Marty) McHale, a former pitcher with the Boston Red Sox, New York Yankees and Cleveland Indians and a vaudeville performer, died at his home Monday night. He was 90 years old.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON. May 9  The indictment of Bert Lance. nearly two years after his bamboozling of the Senate Government Operations Committee in the summer of 1977. is expected during the third week of May.

title: Big Banks Report Increase in Loans
description: The nation's major banks those with assets of $750 million and more  reported $140.27 billion in commercial and industrial loans for the week ended May 2. This total was $1.45 billion higher than in the previous week and more than $18 billion higher than for the same week a year earlier.

title: Medical Care Pact
description: National Medical Care Inc. has acquired for about $2 million cash and notes the Consolidated Medical Care Company, a privately owned Kansas City, Mo., concern in the respiratory therapy equipment field. Dr. C.L. Hampers, chairman of National Medical, said its new acquisition had revenues of $4.7 million in the fiscal year ended Feb. 28, which resulted in net income of $300,000.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 9  Seven South Korean reporters were convicted here today of privately publishing and circulating news items banned under 1975 emergency decree that outlaws criticizing the Government and spreading rumors harmful to it. They were sentenced to terms ranging from 18 months to two and a half years.

title: Technology
description: NEW ORLEANS YOU could call them the sand people. a society built around silicon. These are the leaders of the $6 billion semiconductor industry, and when they met recently in this city of crayfish, camellias and Mardi eras, the occasion was as much a chance for a closetip look at the culture of this hightechnology environment, as it was for a look at the industry's prospects.

title: Stage: Walcott's Remembrance,
description: ALL those island ceremonials in. the 1950's  bagpipe bands, the Governor in starched whites, the British flag lowered as the flag of the new state was raisedwere a beginning disguised as an ending.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: How to Grow Your Own
description: For more information on growing wildflowers, the following books are suggested:

title: Iberia Cancels Some Flights
description: MADRID, May 9 (UPI)  A pilot dispute forced Spain's national airline, Iberia, to cancel seven flights today and to announce more cancellations for the end of the week. The cancellations affect only domestic routes.

title: New America's Cup Yacht Takes First Sail Today
description: Freedom, a new 12Meter yacht built for the 23d defense of the America's Cup next year, was commissioned yesterday at Fort Schuyler on Throgs Neck in the Bronx. Dennis Conner, her probable skipper, intends to take the vessel for her first sail today on Long Island Sound.

title: Rabbi Leizer Garelik, 83, Headed A Religious Court in New Haven
description: Rabbi Leizer Garelik, an Orthodox rabbi in New Haven for 45 years, died Tuesday at his home following a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Blue Chips Lead Market Higher
description: The stock market, buoyed by strength in the bluechip issues, posted a moderate advance yesterday in slower trading.

title: Creating Tenant Power
description: New York City's Rent Guidelines Board. which defines landlords rent boosts for 872.000 rentstabilized apartments. needs a rationale for its latest rulings  bad ones  allowing those amounts to soar by as much as 100 percent. The board's actions raise questions about the fairness ot the city's housing policies. They underscore the need for tenants to establish a single, citywide group to pay closer attention to an important agency that few really understand.

title: City Is Caught in Morass as 'slumlord
description: The dark basement reeked of sewage, which was not surprising because there were puddles. of it everywhere. In one spot, a little sump pump being used to dry out thy, imps ed area was nearly submerged in several feet of water. More was dripping from the pipes and down the walls every minute, and the pump was clogged.

title: Bridge:
description: Those who competed in the National Championships played in New York City four years ago will recall a brilliantly conceived and executed musical show, with famous lyrics suitably modified for the occasion, entitled Bridge to Broadway.

title: 9 Persons Are Seized As Hostages at Prison In Washington State
description: WALLA WALLA, Wash., 9 (UPI)  Inmates took nine persons hostage today in a building within the main compound at Washington State Penitentiary.

title: U.S. Gasoline Stocks Increase in Week
description: The nation's gasoline inventories increased last week for the first time in nearly three months, the American Petroleum Institute reoorted yesterday. The trade association's weekly statistical report showed that the industry's stocks of gasoline stood at 232.1 million barrels as of May 4. Although that is nearly 17 million fewer barrels than the industry had on hand at this time a year ago, it is 400,000 barrels more than what the A.P.I. reported last week.

title: New Jobless Claims Down
description: Initial claims for regular state unemploymentinsurance benefits nationwide fell in the week ended April 28 to a seasonally adjusted 374,000 from 421,000 in the preceding week, the Department of Labor announced yesterday.

title: The PostMortem: Islanders Fell Flat
description: It was almost 6 o'clock yesterday morning when Bill Torrey stopped replaying the television tape of the Islanders 21 loss to the Rangers hours earlier. The loss had eliminated his team from the Stanley Cup playoffs and sent the Rangers to the final round.

title: Good News in Maine: No More Bad News Expected
description: PRESQUE ISLE, Me., May 9 Things always seem to be going from bad to worse here in the depressed northernmost part of Maine, so it was no great surprise this spring when things went from just plain worse to terrible.

title: THRILLER OR FARCE, HOUSTON IN RESCUE
description: BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, May 9 Ten days ago, William A. Spradley says, he landed his small airplane on a beach; here and was set upon by bandits. The next thing he remembers, according to the Houston fireman, is waking up under; arresttin a hospital with a bullet in his back.

title: RUTH GAST GREEN
description: Ruth Gast Green, a former officer of the Jewish Guild for the Blind, and the wife of Monroe Green, former vice president of The New York Times, died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla., after a long illness. She was 67 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: 10 Are Chosen by Columbia As First New York Fellows
description: Standing opposite three lifeless and deteriorating buildings that housed Unity Hospital until it closed last year, the Rev. Edmond G. O'Brien spun out a vision of older people living comfortably in new cooperative apartments that  if go his  will be coaxed,out of sturdy old structures in Brooklyn's Crown Heights section.

title: Deaths
description: FINKLESTEINSadie on Wed. May 9, 1979, of W. Orange, NJ, formerly of Bklyn. beloved wife of the late Max Finklesteln, devoted mother of Or. Howard Finklestein, M.D. and Mrs. Rita Bauman. dear sister of Solomon Finklestein, loving grandmother of 6 grandchildren and seven great grandchildren. Funeral services conducted from The Men. orah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd. N.J. on Thursday, May 10, 1979 at 1:00PM. Interment New Mantellore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I. Period of mourning will be observed at the residence of Mr. 8 Mrs. Moe Bauman, 3 Stonewall Dr. Livingston, N.J.

title: Parking Rules Resume In Manhattan to Give Cleanup Crews Room
description: Alternate-side-of-the-street parking rules will be back in effect in Manhattan today to permit the Sanitation Department to resume street sweeping and to clean up trash that has accumulated in gutters during the 39-day-old tue strike.

title: Q&A
description: Q I have read about the advisability of adding insulation to basement walls down to about 24 inches below ground level. My basement walls go about 12 inches below the grade level, then, from that point down, thicken out by an additional six inches. Would it be enough to apply insulation just down to the point where the wall forms. this 6inch shelf?  M.D., Brooklyn.

title: How Allotments of Gas Would Be Set
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)  If the standby gasoline rationing plan approved by the Senate today is adopted, the basis for determining allotments would be a list compiled by the Department of Energy of the average monthly consumption of gasoline per vehicle for each state.

title: Milwaukee Line Is Offered Aid
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) Transportation Secretary Brock Adams said today he had offered a $20 million Government loan guarantee to keep the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad in operation until a solution of its financial problems was worked out.

title: ISLAMIC CONFERENCE SUSPENDS EGYPTIANS
description: FEZ, Morocco, May 9 (AP)  Foreign ministers of Moslem countries suspended Egypt from the 43member Islamic Conference today, excluding it from all activities and aid money of the group until further decision.

title: New York City Swelters in 94 , A May 9 Record
description: Yesterday's 94degree temperature topped by 2 degrees a record for May 9 set in 1936, and the sunny day filled the city's parks and benches, and caused a surge in icecream sales.

title: Books of The Times
description: THIS is the way Abeba, the hero. ine of Ellease Southerland's fine first novel, thinks and talks: God has plans which mortals don't understand. He rests in

title: Home Improvement
description: AS more people get involved with home repairs and home improvement projects, their need for additional knowledge and up-to-date information keeps growing. Book publishers have been turning out a steady stream of new volumes designed to answer this need  some Rood, and some not so good.

title: Stainless Steel Comes Out
description: The New York Times/Robert Levin

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Airwick Professional Products Division of Atrwick Industries has appointed John Updegraph Jr. president.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather al a P.M.: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administralion/UPI Clear skies can be seen across New England while broken clouds are scattered over Southeast. Clouds blanket the lake region, the intermountian region, the Cascades and the Northern Plain States. Patches of cloudiness are visible over the Rockies and part the Texas gulf coast.

title: Music: By Eduard Lieber
description: TRYING to guess at the seriousness and sincerity of a creator on the sole basis of his or her creations is always a tricky business. This writer's immediate reaction to Edvard Lieber's evening of three selfcomposed world premieres Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall was that the works themselves were ludicrously naive and their presentation absurdly theatrical. Whether these comments can apply directly to Mr. Lieber is another matter. And, to be sure, they might have been said about the young Richard Wagner. Mr. Lieber is probably no Wagner, but still...

title: Dodgers Set Back Mets, 72
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10  The sinking New York Mets gave the Dodgers another opportunity to surge in the National League standings tonight by bowing to them for the third straight time.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Helping Women To Buy Property
description: WASHINGTON

title: Entertainment Events
description: A FLEA IN HER EAR (La Puce a l'OrellIe), by Fey deau; performed by the Comedle Francalse; di rected by Jean Laurent Cochet, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, 7.

title: Richard III
description: Richard III, starring AI Pacino, which was scheduled to open May 20 at the Cort Theater, will open instead on June 10. The production will begin previews there tonight. Mr. Pacino, whose previous Broadway appearance two years ago, in The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel, won him a Tony award, heads a cast of 27.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times on Tuesday reported erroneously that Samuel H. Lovejoy once blew up a 500foot meteorological tower in Massachusetts as a protest against nuclear power. Mr. Lovejoy, an organizer of last weekend's antinuclear rally in Washington, used no explosives. He toppled the tower by loosening guy wires.

title: BRITAIN'S LABORITES REELECT CALLAGHAN
description: LONDON, May 9  James Callaghan, whose Government was ousted by Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party in the British general election last Thursday, was reelected leader of the Labor Party by acclamation this afternoon.

title: UNIROYAL IS STRUCK BY RUBBER WORKERS
description: DETROIT, May 9  Uniroyal Inc., the nation's third largest manufacturer of tires, was struck at noon today by the United Rubber Workers. The strike, af-

title: CREDIT MARKETS Yields Rise on TaxFree Bonds
description: Yields on taxexempt state bonds with the highest credit rating rose moderately yesterday as New Hampshire borrowed $40.5 million for capital improvements and its turnpike. The benchmark financing took place as the credit markets generally moved a little more definitely toward higher fixed-income prices and lower interest rates.

title: Air France Orders 14 Airbus Planes
description: Officials of Mr France, the French Governmentowned airline, have signed an agreement in Paris for 14 twinengine Airbus medium range airliners, produced by the European Airbus Industrie Consortium, The price is estimated at $942 million.

title: SENATE, BY 58 TO 39, BACKS CARTER PLAN TO RATION GASOLINE
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  After another long day of maneuver and compromise, the Senate today approved President Carter's standby plan for gasoline rationing in the event of a national emergency.

title: Congress Worried Over Soviet
description: Probably not since the Senate rejected Woodrow Wilson's bid to join the League of Nations in 1919 has a President confronted so precarious a struggle in Congress on foreign policy as Jimmy Carter faces over the strategicarms agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: Corporate Earnings Are Reported for the Quarter
Waldheim Confers With Suharto In Jakarta on Vietnam Refugees
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 9 (Reuters)  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations and President Suharto of Indonesia met today for talks on the Vietnamese refugees pouring into many Southeast Asian countries.

title: $111,000 Diamond Ring Stolen
description: GENEVA, May 9 (UPI)  Christie's said today that a diamond ring valued at $111,000 was, stolen and replaced by an imitation just before the company's spring jewelry sale, apparently during shoving for the trade. In November, diamond valued at $585,000 was stolen in the same manner.

title: Mexico Planning To Lift Oil Output
description: MEXICO CITY, May 9 (UPI) Mexico is planning to produce an additional quarter of a million barrels of crude oil a day above the 2.25 million figure originally projected for the end of 1980, a high Government official said today.

title: Applicants for Tuition Aid Cheat State of $5.3 Million
description: ALBANY, May 9  More than 23,500 students or their families cheated the state out of $5.3 million last year by understating their incomes when applying for awards under the Tuition Assistance Program, according to an official state memorandum.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY  Governor Carey asked the Legislature for additional money in excess of $6 million  for special compensation for employees who provided essential services during the 16 day strike by correction officers.

title: Blumenthal Wary on Oil Output Rise
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal conceded under questioning today that President Carter's plan to remove price controls from domestic crude oil would not, necessarily guarantee greater production within the United States.

title: Highlights of the Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  Following are highlights of the projected SovietAmerican strategic arms limitation treaty:

title: PRESS GROUPS ASSAIL REPORT FOR UNESCO
description: U.S. Publishers and Editors Object to Proposals They Say Could Curb Free Flow of News

title: Israelis Cease Attacks in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 10 (UPI)  Israeli jets reportedly flew over Palestinian camps near the southern Lebanese port of Tyre today and Israeli gunboats were offshore. But for the first time in five days there were no Israeli attacks, the stateoperated Beirut radio retorted.

title: Federal Reserve
description: In millions

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, May 10To President Leonid Brezhnev of the Soviet Union from mythical agent Pavel Nitzekoff.

title: IN THE NATION
description: President Carter was only speaking common sense the other day when he told organizers of the big Washington antinuclear rally that closing all operating nuclear plants was out of the question.

title: April Spending: Smaller Rise
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)  The Government reported today that consumer spending rose by fivetenths of 1 percent last month, half the March gain, another sign that economic growth was slowing. Stripped of the effects of inflation, the April performance would probably show no growth at all.

title: New York Policeman, Father of 8 Children, Is Slain in Queens Bar
description: An offduty New York City police officer was shot and killed yesterday in a bar in Queens by a man with a shotgun who then fled in a van, the police reported.

title: P.S.A. Sets Up SelfRegulation
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, Va., May 10The Public Securities Association, which represents 250 banks, brokers and dealers that underwrite and trade state and local government securities, today approved the formation of a voluntary, selfregulatory organization at a meeting at the Greenbrir resort here.

title: Paris Staging the Entire Erik Satie Body of Work
description: PARIS, May 10The entire eclectic, eccentric oeuvre of the French composer Erik Satie is being performed here this month in two sixhourlong alternating evenings through May 16 at the Opra Comique. A sort of seamless, surrealistic happening, Intgrale

title: Advertising
description: PERRIER has opened a new world for everybody and nobody has found the limit, said an excited Robert H. Schmidt, president of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Planler & Beaver. He was speaking with the particular interest of an insider in the big bottled water boom because last October his agency was retained by Sangemini International of New Haven, the new subsidiary of dell'Acqua Minerale di Sangemini of Rome. The company, run by the Violati family for more than 100 years, bottles Ferra relle water, from a spring that has been in use since 82 B.C., a great year for water.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Energy

title: Heinz, Campbell Settle Feud
description: PITTSBURGH, May 10 (AP)  A corporate feud between the H.J. Heinz Company and the Campbell Soup Company, which saw the companies trade antitrust charges, ended today in an outofcourt settiement and dismissal of suits that the two food processing giants have filed against each other since 1978.

title: Opera: Two From Shakespeare
description: Those whose tastes run to Shakespeare and opera are in luck this weekend. Tomorrow night, Verdi's familiar Falstaff will be performed by Opera New England at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., and on Sunday night, Bellini's infrequently heard version of Romeo and Juliet (I Capuletti ed i Montecchi) will be given in concert form by the Opera Orchestra of New York at Carnegie Hall.

title: TV Weekend
description: ANY movie starring both Bette Davis and Gana Rowlands is bound to command attention. And in the case of Strangers: The Story of a Mother and Daughter, on CBS this Sunday at 9 P.M., the attention is justified.

title: Publishing: Mr. Kaplan and Walt Whitman
description: THERE was a narrative problem I couldn't quite solve, Justin Kaplan was saying the other day about his virtually completed life of Walt Whitman. There was the young man with the fuzzy and shady background who suddenly turned up with Leaves of Grass and the famous old man whose every conversation was carefully taken down.

title: Witness Asserts Talmadge Aide Did Not Act Alone on Expenses
description: WASHINGTON. May 10 (AP)  Senator Herman E. Talmadge's principal accuser did not act alone in obtaining Senate expense funds that the Senator is accused of turning to his personal use, a Federal documents examiner testified today.

title: Jewish Group Asks Interfaith Talks With Moslems
description: Noting the rise in the nation's Moslem population, the American Jewish Cornmittee yesterday called for interfaith talks among Jews, Christians and followers of Islam.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE Roches are playing in New York next week  at the Bottom Line on Tuesday and Wednesday  and ordinarily that wouldn't seem like such a big deal. They live in New York, they've played often in the city, and they've even played the Bottom Line.

title: Broadway
description: FEW black musicals have been based on plays written by blacks: Purlie and Raisin, and what else? Now, however, there will be Daddy Goodness, which has been adapted from the play by the late Richard Wright. Wright, in turn, had based it on a French play by Louis Sapin the genealogy is complicated. Daddy Goodness has a book by Ron Miller and Shauneille Perry. lyrics by Mr. Miller and music by Ken Hirsch. The director is Israel Hicks, the choreographer is Louis Johnson. the set designer is Santo Loquasto, the lighting designer is Jennifer Tipton, the producer is Ashton Springer, and the budget is $1 million. Motown Records liked the score and gave Mr. Springer a large part of the $1 million; the Shubert Organization liked the book and gave him something, too. Daddy Goodness is to open at the Winter Garden on Oct. 10.

title: Woman Ordered Held As a Material Witness In the Lufthansa Case
description: The girlfriend of Louis Werner  the Lufthansa cargo agent now on trial for allegedly setting up the $5.8 million robbery of the airline last December  was arrested yesterday as a material witness for the prosecution after she apparently feigned illness to avoid having to testify.

title: 1,300 Seatrain Workers Gather for a Final Payday

Authorities said there was no danger of a radiation leak, since the reactor at the Hunterston B nuclear power station on the Ayrshire coast was shut down two years ago when sea water leaked into it. No one was injured.

description: After weeks of relative stability, prices for both crude oil and refined products have suddenly started soaring on the open market again, adding greatly to mounting pressure on oil producing countries to raise prices sharply across the board.

Coast Guard tugboats moved garbage to the Fresh Kills landfill, and the city, which made test runs with three chartered tugs using cityemployed crews, hoped to begin transporting garbage on Monday. Bargaining talks in the 40day old strike continued. No progress was reported.

White vice presidentfinancial management development, Robert J. Sullivan vice presidentcorporate development and John R. Laird controller.
