title: Joseph Pinckney, 81; Former Assemblyman Leda Harlem District
description: Joseph Pinckney, a retired lawyer, former State Assemblyman and Democratic district leader in Harlem, died Tuesday at La Guardia Hospital in Queens after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived at 503365th Street in Woodside. Queens.

title: About Real Estate Rent Limit Squeezes Manhattan Landlord
description: In the cities of the Northeast and North Central states, a costrevenue squeeze is eroding the quality of most rental housing and in many neighborhoods is threatening its very survival. In New York, the decline of multifamily housing has affected tenants and owners, mortgage lenders and the city government, neighboring homeowners and small businesses, and the character and quality of entire residential districts.

title: BARBIERS TO TRADE DEBATED IN MANILA
description: MANILA, May 10  Barriers to free trade, by which nations keep out competitive foreign products, have emerged as the chief villains threatening international economic cooperation in the eyes of representatives to the fifth United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, which opened here this week.

title: Court Bars Touche Bid On S.E.C.
description: A decision strongly supporting the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission to discipline accountants was issued yesterday by a Federal appeals court in Manhattan.

title: Finally a Treaty, and a Question
description: The yearlong discussion of SALT II, before the treaty was actually completed, has put many carts before the horse. And it left us with the impression that many of the treaty's critics are not really interested in the animal. They seem to be worried not about the terms of the pact but about the adequacy of the weapons that the United States intends to acquire with or without a treaty. At times, they do not even seem to be saying that the accord will deny the nation necessary new missiles but only that it might lull the country into a false sense of security and cause us to deny ourselves. So they want not more or better arms control within the treaty, but the promise of a more energetic arms buildup outside of it.

title: Play: Tunnel Fever
description: WHEN I saw Jonathan Reynolds's Yanks 3 Detroit 0 Top of the Seventh and Rubbers four years ago, I found them amusing, but don't remember much else about them. At the time. I was differently employed and not wearing the round and intrvsive reviewer's stare.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: DALLAS, May 10 (AP)  Larry Nelson, off to the best start in his fiveyear career, oneputted eight greens today and shot a five-under-par 65 to take the firstround lead in the rainplagued $300,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic. But Tom Watson was six under par with a hole to go before play was suspended.

title: GoodGovernment Groups Seeking to Expand Their Influence
description: New York City's goodgovernment groups-whose praise politicians always seek but whose practicality they sometimes question  are heading into uncharted territory.

title: Washington State Prison Inmates Release 10 Hostages and Surrender
description: WALLA WALLA, Wash., May 10 (AP) Three state prison inmates who took 10 people hostage to dramatize their grievances surrendered early today after being given a chance to voice their complaints to reporters.

title: Dodgers Drub Mets, 141, to Sweep Series
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10  Anxious to stem the series of misfortunes that have been hounding his Mets during their current road trip to the Pacific Coast cities, Manager Joe Torre shutfled his line up drastically tonight as New York closed its series with the Dodgers.

title: Ballet: Robbins's Noces
description: DANCEGOERS fond of paradoxes would have been intrigued by American Ballet Theater's Wednesday evening performance at the Metropolitan Opera House. The program included a work in which massiveness is unexpectedly allied with rapidity and the season's first performance of a ballet so beautiful that it's boring.

title: Jury Trial Due in Berlin Hijacking
description: WEST BERLIN, May 10  An East German accused of having hijacked a Polish plane to West Berlin was ordered today to be tried in a special American court by a German jury.

title: SecondHand Smoke
description: The New York State Assembly has finally summoned enough nerve to approve a bill to discourage smoking in public places. It is now prohibited in public transportation, libraries, museums, theaters and, in some localities, elevators. The new bill would apply as well to restaurants, offices, retail stores, schools, arenas and other public meeting places. Only bars, small restaurants and offices, restrooms, lobbies and factories would be exempt. The bill is long overdue; it deserves support by the State Senate as well.

title: Screen: Elliott Gould Stars in Daryl Duke's Thriller, 'The Silent Partner':Locked in Combat
description: DARYL DUKE, fondly remembered in some quarters as the director of "Payday," has at last made another feature film, and it's a fine one. "The Silent partner" is about a Toronto bank teller who is given an unexpected chance to rob his own bank, which might seem to place it at a considerable remove from "Payday," a movie that took an acerbic look at the world of a country music star. But both the singer and the bank teller are escape artists, busy extricating themselves from the workaday world. And Mr. Duke, in addition to being a brisk and suspenseful story teller, has a talent for depicting the life they'd like to get away from in exquisitely damning detail.So the backdrop for "The Silent Partner," which opens today at neighbor, hood theaters, is a series of office parties, on-the-job friendships and afterwork assignations. At the center of all this curiously half-hearted activity is one particular teller, played by Elliott Gould and immediately identified as a man whose ambitions are small. He lives alone. He flirts, ineffectually, with a co-worker (Susannah York) who is more than his match. He works out chess problems and collects tropical fish. He robs his bank only because a fluke of an opportunity presents itself. But what an opportunity it is!The teller, who may be drab but is certainly no fool, spots someone getting ready to commit a robbery. So when the thief (Christopher Plummer) comes to his window and demands money, the teller pockets the loot himself and trips off an alarm. Only the thief, who escapes, knows where the money really went. Unfortunately for the teller, the thief is a foul-tempered psychopath who doesn't like wise guys.Beginning with a marvelous confrontation scene in which Mr. Plummer scares the daylights out of Mr. Could by telephoning him from a phone booth just outside his window and delivering some very convincing threats, the film follows the sparring match between these two characters. But Mr. Duke never lets this particular round of cat-and-mousing run away with his story, which is still as much a tale of mundane mores as it is a thriller. The film's romantic interludes are at least as full of gamesmanship as the episodes involving the robbery.Just as he did with "Payday," Mr. Duke has put together a dense, quirky, uncommonly interesting movie, this time with a high quotient of suspense. He develops his characters firmly and fast, and populates the story with a lot of them, weighed down by the monotony of their lives but still, senselessly, always on the go. When Mr. Plummet's fiercely vibrant thief bursts into Mr. Gould's life, he seems almost to be a creature of another species.Mr. Plummer makes a terrific heavy, especially in an early scene in which his destructive potential seems to know no bounds. Unfortunately, the screenplay never makes full use of the maniacal power of his performance, nor does it allow the thief enough ingenuity to make his tricks really surprising. He does behead another character during the course of one quarrel, it's true. But for the most part, his antics are tamer than what is initially promised. And the film has to struggle a bit to make an audience believe that the thief and the teller really are inextricably locked in combat, since there's nothing to keep Mr. Plummer from robbing a different bank, or Mr. Gould, who has hidden the money where no one can find it, from going to the police.One of the most impressive things about "Payday" was its central performance, from Rip Torn. Mr. Duke needed a performance of similar intensity from Elliott Gould to hold "The Silent Partner" together, and from that point of view Mr. Gould is disappointing. Too often, he recites his lines as if he were explaining things to a small child with a hearing problem, exaggerating the teller's dullness to an almost insufferable degree. And too often, he makes a mockery of the character's old-maidishness, even though the audience needs to believe that this man's co-workers take him entirely at face value.

title: Stage: Eclectic Martha Schlamme
description: MARTHA SCHLAMME is at Theater East, singing songs and reciting poetry in A Woman without a man is ... This suggests she will tell us about struggling, coping, or both, and it is true that some of her songs are lamentations. Mostly, however, Miss Schlamme is charming, and even though she was born in Vienna the charm is not just sacker torte. You want to introduce Miss Schlamme to your children.

title: U.S. Tops West Germany
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, May 10 (UPI)  Arthur Ashe and Stan Smith routed Andreas Maurer and Werner Zirngibl, 60, 63, today to give the United States a 21 victory over West Germany in the $250,000 Nations Cup tennis tourney.

title: CARTER WILL MEET BREZHNEV JUNE 15
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Senate leaders opened an informal debate today on the new strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union by stressing its importance and listing questions that they said had to be answered satisfactorily to insure ratification.

title: Taiwan Adapts to Break by U.S.; Economic Signs All Pointing Up
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 10  After an initial bout of antiAmericanism, Taiwan appears to have adjusted with surprising ease to President Carter's decision to break off diplomatic relations.

title: Two Black Students at Amherst Are Suspended in Cross Burning
description: AMHERST, Mass., May 10 (AP) Two black students have been suspended from Amherst College for burning a cross on campus April 16.

title: New York Sings Siren Song to Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  With a chorus that had just sung I Love New York at his side, Mayor Koch today beseeched the Democratic Party to return to Madison Square Garden for its 1980 National Convention.

title: HOUSE VOTES DOWN WHITE HOUSE PLAN FOR GAS RATIONING
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  The House of Representatives tonight voted down President Carter's standby plan for gasoline rationing, handing the President stunning defeat in his energy program.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Discusses Her Aims With Schmidt
description: LONDON, May 10 (UPI)  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, in the first foreign policy discussions of her six days in office, conferred with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany today and pledged her Government's commitment to NATO and the Common Market.

title: Chesebrough-Pond's: Growth via Market Control
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  ChesebroughPond's has no shortage of names. The maker of such vintage products as Pond's cold cream and Vaseline and a dozen other topflight brands, the big consumer products company is large enough and select enough to turn away several hundred wouldbe acquisitions a year. It is, by some accounts, the poor man's Procter & Gamble.

title: Ida Wallner, a Founder Of a Refugee Group, 78
description: Ida Herman Waliner, a founding member of the Parents Committee for Jewish Refugees, died Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital, following a long illness. She was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan, Mrs. Wallner and 10 other women formed the committee in 1940 to raise funds for children whose parents had been killed in Nazi concentration camps.

description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Denis Thatcher Quietly Easing Into New Role
description: LONDON, May 10Through most of their 27 years of married life, Denis Thatcher has had to share his wife with her absorbing outside interests.

title: Cyrus Eaton, Industrialist, 95, Dies
description: Cyrus S. Eaton Sr., a multimillionaire industrialist who strongly advocated friendly relations with the Communist world, died Wednesday night at his home, Acadia Farm, near Cleveland. He was 95 years old.

title: Court in Michigan Holds 2 Indian Treaties Invalid
description: LANSING, Mich., May 10 (UPI) The Michigan Court of Appeals ruled today that Indians did not have unrestricted fishing rights in the Great Lakes despite a Federal court decision that says two treaties gave them that guarantee.

title: 4 Are Murdered On Two Estates At Bedford Hills
description: Dr. Charles Frankel, a former Assistant Secretary of State, and his wife and the 21-year-old son of a Wall Street broker and his elderly governess were found shot to death yesterday on two neighboring Westchester County estates. All were the annarent victims of nighttime robbers.

title: No Tax on Windfall Profits, Please . . .
description: DALLAS  A few years ago, thenPresident Ford proposed taxation of socalled excess profits by the nation's oil companies. Despite a change in Administration from Republican to Democratic, politicians still are demanding that oil producers be punished for windfall profits.

title: Kris Messenger Captures $25,000 Pace at Roosevelt
description: WESTBURY, L.I., May 10  Kris Messenger extended her winning streak to seven tonight as she scored a 2length victory over Viper in the $25,000 Petticoat pacing series for threeyearold fillies at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Sambo's in Accord With Japanese Chain
description: Sambo's Restaurants Inc. announced that it had signed a licensing agreement with a Japanese restaurant chain, Skylark K.K. MushashinoShi of Tokyo. It would be Sambo's first entry into overseas markets.

title: 1981 Goal: A Budget Surplus
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  Administration budget planners calculate that, with luck, President Carter could send Congress next January a budget that will be in the black and also offer the country a small tax cut for 1981, according to knowledgeable officials.

title: Mrs. Carter and Amy Received In Private Audience by the Pope
description: ROME, May 10 (Reuters)  Rosalyn Carter and her 11yearold daughter, Amy, were received in a private 30minute audience today by Pope John Paul II.

description: MADRAS, India  India is looking to the sun to bring prosperity to its predominantly rural copulation.

title: Suspect Is Arraigned in Slaying Of Eddie Jefferson, Jazz Vocalist
description: DETROIT, May 10 (AP)  A 41yearold unemployed factory worker was arraigned today on charges of murder and possession of a firearm in the killing of Eddie Jefferson, the jazz vocalist.

title: Assembly Speaker Bars New State Tax Cut
description: ALBANY, May 10  Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink ruled out today any new tax cuts beyond a reduction in the state's maximum income tax, putting himself at odds with both Governor Carey and the Senate's Republican majority. At the same time, he proposed an additional $35 million in education aid to the state's poorer school districts.

title: Gas Station Holds Line  At 99.9c for Gallon
description: As prices for gasoline in the New York continue to rise, one station in Manhattan has managed to maintain the same price for a gallon of premium gas for the last 30 days. Last month, the Texaco station on the corner of 37th Street and First Avenue was charging 99.9 cents for a gallon of premium gasoline  the highest price in the city.

description: Art Dealers Offer To Repair Ubatuba

description: WASHINGTON  President Carter's proposal for a windfallprofits tax to be used in an Energy Security Trust Fund is one of the most critical legislative proposals the Congress has considered in many years, because it offers real hope of energy security for Americans.

title: Leading Black College Faces Aid Loss
description: DALLAS  A widening financial scandal at a small black college here that is unable to account for as much as $2.8 million in Federal student aid funds has threatened the existence of the school and placed the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in a sensitive position.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  The New Jersey Assembly gave final legislative approval yesterday to the proposed $4.6 billion 197980 state budget and sent the measure to Governor Byrne for his signature. The vote, 50 to 24, broke across party lines, but with only two Republicans among the measure's supporters.

title: Market Place
description: THE troubles of RCA's National Broadcasting Company have been making headlines for weeks. As a result, the underlying strength of the electronics giant has been softpedaled. At least that's the point of view of John S. Reidy, senior broadcast analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert. He says in a recent report that significant progress is being made under the present management team.

title: Stolen Stadivarius Is Recovere
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, May (Reuters)  A stolen Stradivarius viol valued at over $200.000, has been ma ered from a secondhand dealer who pz $30 for it, the police said today. The vio was taken yesterday from the home o musician, Olive McKenzie.

title: Wayne Strolls in Hospital
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10 (AP)  John Wayne has taken his first steps, outside his hospital room since undergoing surgery in which cancerous cells were discovered in his .intestiries, officials said. The 71yearold novie actor walked in the hall outside his room briefly yesterday. He just walked down the hall and back for a little ways, said Bernard Strohm, administrator of the Medical Center of the University of California at.Los Angeles.

title: Restaurants
description: ALTHOUGH it is doubtful that Greece would be represented on a list of the world's great cuisines, there are some interesting and savory specialties within that national culinary repertory. Grilled fish, a few salads and lamb dishes are among the more noteworthy features, and so is the mezedakia course of appetizers similar to those of Armenia and the Middle East. The eightmonthold Xenia, on First Avenue, between 98th and 49th Streets, is a bright, friendly and colorfully folkloric setting, with a small, cheerful garden, and some pleasant and satisfying Greek food is served at lunch and dinner.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CHICAGO, May 10  The McDonald's Corporation today announced an increase in its dividend and said it would move into eightto10 new foreign markets this year. The company will add 165 units outside the United States, up from 134 opened in 1978.

description: CAIRO, May 10Kuwait has informed Cairo that it wants to withdraw the more than $1 billion it has on deposit in Egyptian banks, according to knowledgeable sources here. Egypt has so far ignored the request.

description: ELAINE COMPARONE'S harpsichord recital Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall was a delight, and this despite a few pieces in which there were more wrong notes than one might have expected although why wrong notes on the harpsichord are more prevalent or more noticeable than on the piano is a question worth considering.

title: Gen. Gabriel Ramanantsoa, 73, Former President of Madagascar
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar, May 10 (AP)Maj. Gen. Gabriel Ramanantsoa, former President of Madagascar, died in a military hospital in Paris last night, the Government announced here. He was 73.

title: 94 Makes It 2d Record in a Row: Some Hate It and Some Like It Hot
description: New York City suffered and celebrated through the second recordbreaking day of a heat wave that dragged its weight over the city's windowsills and shimmered on the streets like a premature August. The athletic and the leisurely loved it, but those who had to go to work took less delight in it.

title: Democratic Chiefs Lose Control Of House Debate on Budget Cut
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  House Democratic leaders lost control of the budget debate today for the first time is two weeks of floor maneuvering, and the consequences, while not fatal, could be very Serious.

description: Early this week an African revolutionary who works in New York encountered a friend in the street and was queried on why he had carefully filled out the Metropolitan Transportation Authority inquiry card he was carrying in his hand The

title: USAC's Troubles MountAs King Offers to Resign
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 10  Dick King, president of the United States Auto Club, said today he would offer his resignation tomorrow to the board of the racing group in the wake of a disclosure that in 1957 he served nine months in prison for grand larceny.

title: It's Apple Blossom Time in the Hudson Valley
description: A blanket of pink and white blossoms has spread over the apple orchards of the Hudson Valley, transforming the fruitgrowing area into a springtime wonderland of visual delight.

title: Philharmonic: Music in May Begins
description: BETWEEN the closing of the New York Philharmonic's subscription season and the opening of the Mostly Mozart Festival there is a gap that in the past was partly filled by the orchestra's Promenades, popularpriced programs for which half the seats in Avery Fisher Hall were removed so that tables and champagne coolers could be installed. Last year, however, the Philharmonic decided to leave all the seats in place and inaugurate a series called Music in May, in hopes of increasing offseason revenues. And, in the first season of the series, the plan seemed to work. Promenades, popularpriced programs for which half the seats in Avery Fisher Hall were removed so that tables and champagne coolers could be installed. Last year, however, the Philharmonic decided to leave all the seats in place and inaugurate a series called Music in May, in hopes of increasing offseason revenues. And, in the first season of the series, the plan seemed to work.

title: School Bus Mechanics at Work
description: Schoolbus mechanics in New York City went back to work yesterday for the l first time in 84 days, to start repairing and cleaning up hundreds of idled buses to transport 130.000 students to classes. One bus company in the Bronx announced plans to resume regular service Friday for 9,000 children. Thousands of other pupils in the city, particularly 30,000 who are handicapped, may have to wait as long as two weeks. The strike of schoolbus drivers and matrons ended Wednesday night.

title: Ark: Kenneth Martin Opens Yale Center
description: ENNETH MARTIN. the 74 yearold English painter and sculptor, though well known to followers of the international Constructivist movement, is not exactly a familiar figure on this side of the. Atlantic. So it comes as somethine of a surprise that Mr. Martin's recent workshould be the subject of the first exhibition to be devoted to a living artist at the Center for British Art at Yale University in New Haven. But what a happy surprise, for the most part, it is! This exhibition, organized by Andrew Forge, dean of the Yale School of Art, will be a little astonishing, I think, even to people who know Mr. Martin's work, and it serves as an excellent introduction to those who do not.

title: A Jersey Couple Ordered to Trial In Drinking Suit
description: A New Jersey appeals court yesterday ordered a civil trial for a couple accused in a lawsuit of contributing to the death of two juveniles by permitting them to consume alcoholic beverages in their home even though they knew, or should have known, that one of them would be driving a car afterward.

title: Charles Frankel Resigned a Post Under Johnson
description: Dr. Charles Frankel, who was among four persons found murdered yesterday in the Westchester County community of Bedford Hills, gained national attention in 1967 when, after serving two years as an Assistant Secretary of State, he resigned in protest against the Vietnam War.

title: Czech Dissident Sentenced
description: VIENNA, May 10 (Reuters)  A Czechoslovak dissident, Jaroslav Sabata, who is in jail for insulting a policeman, was ordered by a Prague court today to serve 18 more months in prison. The term represents the unexpired part of a six, andayear sentence for dissident activities. Dr. Sabata was released In 1976 after serving five years, with 18 months suspended on condition of good behavior.

title: Brascan Disputes Woolworth
description: Brascan Ltd., seeking to take over the F.W. Woolworth Company, yesterday denied charges by Woolworth that it had access to confidential bank records of that company.

title: Arms Pact and Its Effect on U.S. Security
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  The new strategic arms treaty is the most farreaching arms control step ever taken by the United States and the Soviet Union, yet a key question in the emerging debate News Analysis is whether it will enhance American security.

title: Ford: Birthright, Bluntness and Hard Work
description: DETROIT, May 10  There is no other quite like him on the American scene  no one who combines the heritage with the power and has held them so long. Henry Ford 2d has spent 34 years as we top man at the Ford Motor Company, piloting his organization through the storms that have buffeted the United States since the end of

title: Winnebago Offers Fuel Option
description: Winnebago Industries Inc. announced yesterday that it wouldoffer a new factoryinstalled option allowing operation of its motor homes on either liquefied petroleum gas or regular gasoline.

title: Music: Elizabeth Fogle
description: ELIZABETH FOGLE, a clarinetist who appeared in New York earlier this season in a solo recital, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night to play clarinetcentered chamber music concert with Steven Lubin, pianist; Myron Lutzice, cellist, and Louise Schulman, violist. The program consisted of Mozart's Trio in Eflat (K.198), Ferdinand Ries's Trio (Op. 28) and Brahms's Trio in A minor (Op. 114).

title: Money Supply Dips; Business Loans Rise
description: The key measures of the nation's money supply declined in the week ended May 2, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: 20,000 in San Salvador Mourn Slain Demonstrators
description: SAN SALVADOR, May 10  Chanting antiGovernment slogans and carrying flowers and banners, 20,000 Salvadorans walked in the funeral procession today for 17 of the 23 persons killed when policemen and soldiers opened fire on a peaceful demonstration outside the cathedral here Tuesday.

title: Phillies, Espinosa Win, 32
description: SAN DIEGO, May 10 (UPI)  Nino Espinosa and Ron Reed combined on a sevenhitter today, leading Philadelphia to its seventh straight victory, 32 triumph over the San Diego Padres.

title: Bank SuspendsAPlant Loans
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 10  The Bank of America said today that it had suspended the granting of new loans for nuclear construction and for utility purchases of nuclear fuel pending Federal and industry reviews of the accident at the Three M11e Island reactor.

title: IND Derailing Is Traced To Setting of Hand Brake
description: The cause of an IND subway derailment last Dec. 12 that resulted in 22 injuries and $667,500 in train and track damage was the setting of a hand brake on one car by a person unknown that led to overheating and the breaking of wheels, according to a report by the American Public Transit Association submitted at a Federal hearing yesterday.

title: GoldmanSteps UpFutures Bid
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company took two important steps yesterday toward becoming the nation's first top investment banking house to offer a full commodity futures brokerage service.

title: Anaconda Back in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 10  The Anaconda Company, which lost its big Chuquicamata mine through expropriation in 1971, returned to copper mining in Chile today with purchase of an important ore property, Los Pelambres.

title: Student
description: His face pale, his hands clenching the rail in front of him, Arnold Barry Moskowitz waited yesterday in a Brooklyn courtroom for a judge to sentence him for his conviction in a $229,000 bank robbery, the largest in the city in a decade. When he heard the sentence, the 23yearold college student collapsed with relief.

title: Hot String jazz of the 1930's Makes a Comeback
description: The Quintet of the Hot Club of France, the nearlegendary, allstring jazz group of the 1930's that began the international fame of the guitarist Django Reinhardt and the violinist Stephan Grappelli, was never heard in the United States except on records. Mr. Reinhardt appeared in this country as a soloist immediately after World War II, and during the 1970's Mr. Grappelli has played here frequently, also as a soloist. But the group never performed as a unit in this country.

title: Topics
description: It has hardly been a social secret that alcohol can be hazardous. We would imagine that's just what people mean when they name their poison or warn about old debbil rum. Not for nothing, are the cartoon jugs labeled X X X. But to the United States Senate, such folk warnings do not suffice. It has voted to require that all hard liquor bottles now carry a further label Caution: Consumption of alcoholic beverages may be hazardous to your health.

title: For Children
description: FROM SUNRISE TO SUNRISE, the 36th Annual Children's Art Exhibition of the Board of Jewish Education of Greater New York, featuring artwork of students 3 to 17, Sunday through Thursday, noon to 5 P.M., (through June 10) at the board's art gallery, 476 West 58th Street. Free. Call 2458200.

title: PAYMENT PACT SET, U.S. AND CHINA NEAR p TRAUE AGREEMENT
description: PEKING, Friday, May 11 China and the United States have paved the way for a trade agreement between the two countries by agreeing to an accord covering both American claims on China and assets blocked in the United States.

title: Race Against Multiple Sclerosis
description: You should be warned, perhaps, that horse auctions are hypnotic, Joe Palmer wrote during a race meeting at Saratoga. Couple of years ago a friend of mine, who had no more idea of buying a horse than a steam calliope and not much more use for one, suddenly heard himself make the successful bid on a broodmare with a foal at foot. He seemed somewhat dazed afterward but his wife was well ahead of him in that respect. What will we do with them? she asked me, with the accumulated sadness of all the daughters of Eve.

title: Queens Couple Held In Starvation Deaths Of Two Young Sons
description: A Queens couple described by authorities as adherents of a strict diet of fruits, vegetables and seaweed were arrested yesterday and held in bail of $25,000 each on charges of criminally negligent homicide and manslaughter in the alleged starvation deaths of their two infant sons, one in 1976 and the other last March.

title: Drivers Worried About Cas Shift to Buses and Trains!
description: Longdistance travelers, fearing that they will not have enough gasoline for their cars, are switching to trains and buses and swamping telephone reservations lines throughout the country.

title: Sunless April, Strikeless May
description: Things are looking up. April in New York this year meant gloomy weather and six major labor disputes. But now, in May, skies have turned bright and hot, and four and fivesixths of the strikes have been settled. Of the strikes by tugboat crews, drivers of school buses and milk trucks, apartment employees, and prison guards, only the tug strike remains. Gasoline truck drivers have not struck but are still threatening.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: California to Get More Gasoline, Energy Dept. Says
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  Officials of the Department of Energy assured California Congressmen today that gasoline supplies in their state would increase slightly in the rest of May.

title: Philip Caldwell: New Breed of Ford Leader
description: He was occasionally referred to as the prince within the company because of his close ties with the chairman and the aura of the anointed that clung to him. So when Philip Caldwell was named yesterday to succeed Henry Ford 2d as head of the Ford Motor Company, not many were surprised.

title: He'll Resign as Chief, But Remain Chairman
description: DETROIT, May 10  Henry Ford 2d, for 34 years the undisputed master of one of the world's largest companies and perhaps America's bestknown executive, today announced his retirement as chief executive officer of the Ford Motor Company, effective Oct. 1.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: MANHATTAN

title: Art People
description: LEONARDO DAVINCI staged river pageants and Henri Rousseau held soirees in his studio. The Futurists acted out their antiestablishment feelings in theaters and the streets; the Dadaists carried on in cabaret divertissements. A spate of happenings occurred in the 1960's and in th 70's the provocative phenomenon known as performance has spawned such multimedia spectaculars as Robert Wilson's Einstein on the Beach.

title: French in Bitter European Vote Campaign
description: PARIS, May 10  The election of a European Assembly next month has provoked a fierce domestic political campaign in France, deepening trie splits between parties on both sides of the divide between Government and opposition.

title: Oil Anxieties Send Dow Tumbling 9.70
description: Investor concern over gasoline shortages and crudeoil supplies dealt another blow to the stock market yesterday. With the volatile gambling issues sustaining particularly large losses, it was the market's third sharp setback within a week.

title: Marathon Entries Accepted June 1
description: Requests for entry forms for the 10th New York City Marathon will be accepted starting June 1. Requests should include a selfaddressed, stamped No. 10 envelope. All entrants for the fall event must be members of the Amateur Athletic Union.

title: Student Accused of Taking Homer's Idea, Bank's Gold
description: MIAMI, May 10  The police have accused a University of Miami Law School student of robbing a bank with a technique borrowed from Homer.

title: Jerome R. White, 75, A WellKnown Figure In Construction Field
description: Jerome R. White, a prominent figure in the construction industry, died Wednesday in Cranbury, N.J., where he made his home. He was 75 years old.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Ends Tokyo Slide After Gains in New York
description: TOKYO, Friday, May 11 (Reuters)  The dollar ended a fiveday retreat on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today, opening a full three yen higher than yesterday's close.The dollar traded at 216 yen, up from 213 at the close yesterday. It soon eased to 215.35 in moderate trading, according to dealers, who said the dollar's initial firmness reflected its strength against the yen yesterday in New York following reports that Iran will raise oil prices.

title: Minister Who Defied Grand Jury Is Released After 4 Months in Jail
description: CINCINNATI, May 10 (AP)  The Rev. Maurice McCrackin was freed today after spending nearly four months in jail for refusing to answer a grand jury's questions about his alleged abduction by two escaped inmates.

title: Rangers Eager to Fill the Cup
description: Although each of them was already $13,200 richer for just making it to the final round of the National Hockey League championship, the Rangers tried to put the past out of their minds yesterday to concentrate on the future.

title: At the Movies
description: CARCELY a day passes when she's not making a movie herself, Monica Vitti was saying, that she doesn't also spend the afternoon or evening watching one. The theater is so big and dark and private, she said. Nobody knows that I am there. I am relaxed. I forget completely I am an actress. I laugh, I applaud, I cry.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: After slipping early yesterday, prices in the credit markets recovered most of their small losses late in the afternoon after the Federal Reserve disclosed that the nation's basic money supply had declined $1.9 billion in the week ended May 2.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: EVANS THREE ON FOURTH ST.

title: New President Of Algeria Acts For Eased Rule
description: ALGIERS, May 5  After three months in office, President Chadli Benjedid has subtly changed and opened up the style of government in Algeria, which was tightly ruled for 13 years by Houari Boumediene, the austere revolutionary who died in December.

title: Indian Prime Minister Plans Visit To Soviet Union Starting June 10
description: NEW DELHI, May 10  Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai is scheduled to visit four Communist countries beginning with the Soviet Union next month, the Foreign Ministry said here today.

title: Labor Official Says Geneva Trade Accord .Would Harm U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  A spokesman for organized labor said today that a new international trade liberalization pact could do an immense amount of damage to the American economy and called on the Carter Administration to renegotiate the agreement in Geneva.

title: Architecture: Works Of Michael Graves
description: THE current fashion among architects for alluding to older styles has led to a lot of rather facile work. Sensible in its intent, it has nonetheless tended to encourage a certain simplistic, easy aping of the past, with architectural quotations being tossed oft asiightly as bons mots at a cocktail party. But the work of Michael Graves, which has just gone on exhibition at the Max Protetch Gallery, 37 West 57th Street, stands as a notable exception to this trend. And it confirms that Mr. Graves is now an architect of major stature.

title: Notes on People
description: Ripples of discontent have spread across the University of Chicago campus, where later this month a 125,000 cash prize will be given to Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank. The award, named after the late Albert Pick Jr., who headed a hotel chain, honors outstanding contributions to international understanding. What bothers faculty members who've made their displeasure public is Mr. McNamara's role in shaping Vietnam War policies as Secretary of Defense in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a review of the Derek Walcott play Remembrance in The Times yesterday, the name of the director was incorrect. He is Charles Turner.

title: When Past Is Present A Tale of Manhattan
description: A horse pulling a carriage and a taxi tried to turn left from Seventh Avenue into 52d Street at the same time early yesterday. Cab cut the horse off, leaving horse's hoof stuck fast in its rear bumper. Here a fire rescue unit works sucessfully to extricate the horse, which remained unperturbed throughout. The police could give neither the name of the cabby nor the carriage driver. It was just one of those unusual street happenings, the police said.

title: Two From Houston Arrive in Colombia Seeking Release of FiremanPilot
description: BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, May 10  A highranking rescue squad from the Houston Fire Department arrived here today to begin working for the release of William A. Spradley, a Houston firefighter who has been under arrest in a nearby hospital since the aircraft he was piloting landed here illegally 11 days ago. The delegation was headed by V.E. Rogers, the Houston fire chief, who like Mr. Spradley is a pilot and who himself was held prisoner in a Colombian jail seven years ago. That was a result of a dispute over an import permit for a cargo of chemicals he had ferried here from the United States.

title: Bridge:
description: In recent years the World Team Championship for the Bermuda Bowl has included representatives of five continental zones: Europe, North America, South America, the Far East and Australasia. This year. in Rio de Janeiro in October, there is likely tor the first time to be a sixth contender. The World Bridge Federation is expected to approve the inclusion of the Central American and Caribbean champions.

title: Commuters Beset by Gas Prices Find Mass Transit Lacks Space
description: With the price of gasoline heading toward $1 a gallon, many commuters in the New York metropolitan area who used to drive to work are turning to mass transit, but they are not finding enough seats on trains and buses.

title: Theater: Welfare Indicts Bureaucracy
description: THE frustration of trying to deal with a demeaning and oppressive bureaucracy is the basis of Marcia Haufrecht's Welfare at the Ensemble Studio Theater. As Miss Haufrecht, who is an actress as well as a playwright, sees it. welfare is misguided. It is something that is supposed to be ameliorative, but is as ephemeral as cotton candy.

title: Oliver R. Peterson, 75; Expert in Labor Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  Oliver R. Peterson, a specialist in labor affairs and the husband of Esther Peterson, President Carter's Special Assistant for Consumer Affairs, died today in a hospital in Brattleboro, Vt. He was 75 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: TO begin with, we have the hero of Jake's Thing, Kingsley Amis's 13th and most accomplished novel in some time. He is Jaques Cecil Richardson  known to his intimates as Jake  a 59yearold Reader in Early Mediterranean History at Oxford and a Fellow of Comyns College, though not too much should be made of his scholarly interests, because he regards them with all the passionate intensity that a blind man brings to crossword puzzles.

title: Visiting Bristol Team Is Victor in Rugby Here
description: The Bristol Football Club, one of Britain's leading rugby teams, defeated an allstar Metropolitan Rugby Union side, 2113, Wednesday night at Randalls Island.

title: Business and the Law
description: Marblehead, Mass.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 10  Senator Edward M. Kennedy said in an interview with The Belfast Telegraph today that he believed the United States would provide cash support for a political settlement in Northern Ireland.

title: Oscar E. Schoeffler Is Dead at 80; Was Fashion Director of Esquire
description: Oscar E. Schoeffler, former vice president and fashion director of Esquire magazine, died Sunday in a nursing home in Sarasota, Fla., following a brief illness. He was 80 years old and had lived in Sarasota since his retirement in 1972.

title: Fairfield's Dogwood Show Begins
description: Echoes of the 18th century are visible in assorted corners of Connecticut, but nowhere in the state is the evidence of that era so alive as on Greenfield Hill this weekend.

title: Judge Is Upheld In Barring Press From a Pretrial
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court voted narrowly yesterday to uphold the decision of a Bronx judge who had excluded the press from a pretrial hearing on a murder charge against a 13yearold boy. The state is seeking to try the boy as an adult.

title: Collections Harking Back to the Trash Can School
description: The Gina Zucker Collection of Cigarette Filters is not included in an exhibition entitled Unusual Children's Collections, now on view at the 80 Washington Square East Galleries. Gina's mother inadvertently threw it in the garbage.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: DEATS

title: Giants Test Simms in A Workout
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 10  Phil Simms, already being called Prince Valiant by his new teammates, was entering Giants Stadium today just as Joe Pisarcik was leaving.

title: PEOPLE IN BUSINESS
description: The proposed acquisition of a controlling interest in Marine Midland Banks Inc. by the Hongkong & Shanghai Banking Corporation has apparently become a New York State political issue, pitting Banking Superintendent Muriel Siebert against Commerce Commissioner John S. Dyson. One result of this dispute within the administration of Governor Carey is that Edward W. Duffy, chairman and chief executive officer of Marine Midland, is probably facing more public attention these days than ever before in his career.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: PARKING RULES BACK ON
description: Alternateside parking regulations will be in effect in Manhattan today so that street trash built up during the tugboat strike can be removed. The rules will later be reapplied in the other boroughs, in rotttion.

title: Panel Votes Restrictions On Plants
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  The Senate Environment and Public Works Committee voted today to revoke the licenses of all nuclear reactors operating in states that do not develop federally approved emergency evacuation plans within six months.

title: Foreign Service Wives: Many Are Choosing to Remain Behind
description: Ever adaptable, never complaining, she moves from one end of the world to the other with the ease of a nomad and the efficiency of a computer.

title: Panel Backs Draft Registration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)  The House Armed Services Committee today approved a proposal to resume registration of 18yearold men for possible military service. The decision insures a debate and vote on the issue by the entire House of Representatives.

title: Drug Raids Are Staged in 6 States
description: MIAMI, May 10  Suspected drug smugglers from Florida to upstate New York were being rounded up today as a result of an undercover police operation that videotaped cargoes of marijuana being flown in and out of landing strips in the Miami area.

title: I.R.A, Leader Reported Shot
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 10 (UPI)  Gunmen shot and seriously wounded William Davidson, 39 years old, a leading member of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Provisional Irish Republican Army, in his grocery store in Belfast today, witnesses reported.

title: U.S. Group Backs Rhodesia Vote
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  Freedom House, a New Yorkbased private organi zation that observed the Rhodesian elec tions last month, said today that they were a relatively free expression of the will of the people and should result in an alteration of American policy.

title: Schultze Defends 7% Pay Limit
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, today defended the Administration's voluntary limit on pay increases of 7 percent, despite predictions by Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal of an inflation rate this near of 8.5 percent.

title: U. of Houston Seeks Dismissal of Its Nobel Chemist
description: HOUSTON, May 10  The University of Houston, a sprawling cement and glass commuter college that aspires in its every nerve and fiber to join the first rank of American universities someday, is trying to get rid of the only Nobel Laureate it has ever managed to attract.

title: Panamanian Reassured By Carter on Canal Pact
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI) President Carter told President Aristides Royo of Panama today that he would oppose any attempt by Congress to weaken Panama's canal treaty rights when it approves legislation to carry out the pacts.

title: Auctions
description: THE spring art auctions are upon us with a vengeance. Beginning today and ending next Friday, art collectors and dealers will be shuttling between Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, and Christie, Manson & Woods, Park Avenue at 59th Street, to view and bid on what may well be the largest number of paintings, watercolors, drawings and sculptures of the 19th and 20th centuries ever auctioned anywhere in so short a time. At Sotheby's, six sales in eight sessions will disperse 945 works of art, estimated to sell for a total of about $12 million. At Christie's, 567 works of art will be auctioned at three sales occupying five sessions and are expected to realize at least $10 million.

title: Art: Tom Wesselmann Sticks to the Same Last
description: IN the paintings of Tom Wesselmann the world looks the way a winter garden looks to a white fly that has somehow evaded the insect killer. It looks enormous. in otherwords, and it is seen from very close to, and the forms are wrenched this way and thit. The scale of the work is not our human scale, and although our passions are reflected in it they somehow come out upside down: monumental and ridiculous at one and the same time.

title: Foreign Concerns Expanding in U.S.
description: Foreign companies continued last year's rapid pace of investments in the United States in the first quarter of 1979, according to the Conference Board.

title: West Coast Commuters Try Mass Transit
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10  The Route 813 bus left the hilly Palos Verdes peninsula shortly after 7 o'clock this morning bound for downtown Los Angeles, 30 miles away. Normally, half of its seats would have been empty; today, the seats were filled and a dozen people were standing in the aisles.

title: 2 American Students Ordered Out by Israel For a Stoning Attack
description: JERUSALEM, June 10  Israel today ordered the deportation of two American students on the ground that they had taken part in proPalestinian rockthrow ing demonstrations in the occupied West Rank territory. American officials here said they could not recall any previous instance of United States citizens being expelled by Israel. The American Embassy in Tel Aviv said it had been informed of the case but had no comment.

title: U.S. Lifting Bond Rate To 6%
description: The Government will raise the interest rate on its Savings Bonds half a percentage point, to 61 percent, starting June 1, the Treasury disclosed yesterday. The increase, however, will still leave the rate far below yields on other Government notes and bonds that are sold in larger denominations.

title: Tenure Over, U.S. Envoy in Cairo Fears for Fate of Peace
description: CAIRO, May 10  Through the ups and downs of Egypt's tortuous peace negotiations with Israel, few men have been as close to the moods and reasoning of President Anwar elSadat as the American Ambassador to Cairo, Hermann F. Eilts.

title: Terrorists in Turkey Kill American In NATO Unit and Wound Second
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, May II (AP) Terrorists shot two United States servicemen in a suburb here today, killing one and wounding the other.

title: Cup Tickets Priced at $600
description: LONDON, May 11 (AP)  Tickets for Saturday's English Cup soccer final between Manchester United and Arsenal are being sold for up to $600 each by scalpers. The normal price for a good seat is $24, but standingroom tickets are bringing prices of $80. The match is sold out.

title: Watson Holds Lead As Rain Delays Golf
description: DALLAS, May 11 (AP)  Tom. Watson battled miserable playing conditions and struggled to a twooverpar 72 today to take the 36hole lead in the weatherplagued $300,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic. Darkness halted play with almost onethird of the field still on the course.

title: OBSERVER
description: It was a spring in the future and young Alvin's thoughts turned to love when he saw Gloria board the plane, then turned to despair when he saw her go to the rear.

title: Spurs Rout Bullets As Gervin Scores 42
description: SAN ANTONIO, May 11 (UPI) George Gervin scored 18 consecutive points in the third quarter and 42 points over all, carrying the San Antonio Spurs to a 118102 triumph over the Washington Bullets tonight. The victory gave San Antonio a 31 advantage in their National Basketball Association Eastern Conference championship series.

title: Woman Testifies A Friend Denied Lufthansa Theft
description: The girlfriend of the airline cargo agent on trial for last December's $5.8 million robbery of Lufthansa German Airlines was released yesterday after she collapsed three times in court and at one point responded to questioning while laying on a spectators bench with a psychiatrist sittine at her side.

title: General Haig Speaks Of 'serious Questions Regarding Arms Pact
description: PARIS, May 11  Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., commander of both NATO and United States forces in Europe, has serious questions about the treaty to limit strategic arms and feels that the Western defense position now is one of declining deterrence.

title: Uncharitable Rivalry Among Charities
description: As inflation shrinks the charity dollar, the competition is heating up  and the giant United Way has been playing too rough. Bad enough that it has been unresponsive to newer, nontraditional causes like neighborhood associations; it has also tried to blackball their efforts to raise money from corporations. The United Way is a valuable instrument of philanthropy and deserves continued support. But it should direct some of its energies toward new needs, rather than thwart those already working to meet them.

title: Mrs. Kreps Hopeful on Accord
description: SHANGHAI, May 11Although Chinese and United States negotiating teams are still struggling in Peking to resolve a host of outstanding issues on a full ChineseAmerican trade agreement. Secretary of Commerce Juanita M. Kreps said today that she hoped to initial it before leaving China Tuesday.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the obituary of Cyrus S. Eaton Sr. in The Times yesterday, the date of his marriage to Anne Kinder Jones was incorrect. He married her in 1957.

title: Banker's 2 Sons Kept From Him As Mother Dies
description: Two young boys whose Polishimmigrant mother died of cancer in apparent poverty a week ago have been spirited into hiding somewhere have In New York by a Polish Mend of the family, evidently to block custody by their father, an EgyptianAmerican banker. The father was divorced from the boys mother two years ago and has returned from abroad to claim them.

title: American Record Set
description: EUGENE, Ore., May 11 (AP) Rudy Chapa, a junior at the University of Oregon, set an American record in the 3,000meter run yesterday at the university's annual twilight track and field meet. Chapa's time was 7 minutes 37.7 seconds.

title: Services for Dr. Charles Frankel
description: Funeral services for Dr. Charles Frankel, a Columbia University professor of history and former Assistant Secretary of State who was slain with his wife Thursday night at their Bedford Hills,N.Y., estate, have been tentatively scheduled for next Tuesday at 9:30 P.M. in St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia campus.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON

title: 9 Stars to Vie in New Dream Mile Tonight
description: The curiosity has been building for months. How fast can Don Paige run a mile? Is he really a successor to Jim Ryun, in dynamic racing style and tailored demeanor, or is he simply another talented, young American trying to climb a crowded ladder?

title: Dodgers Win by 70 On Rau's OneHitter
description: LOS ANGELES, May 11 (AP) Doug Rau stymied Montreal on one hit  a single by Chris Speier in the eighth inning  as the resurgent Los Angeles Dodgers routed the Expos tonight, 70.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SHANGRILA SPECIAL The Big Apple's Tibetan community is a proud but small ethnic unit numbering 40 residents. Most of them will serve as attendants today from 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. at the spring bazaar of the Tibet Center, 114 East 28th Street.

title: VENEIIEIAA EMBASSY SEIZED IN SALVADOR
description: SAN SALVADOR, May 11A militant peasantworker organization that has held the French Embassy and the Metropolitan Cathedral here for a week seized the Venezuelan Embassy today to press for the freedom of several jailed labor leaders.

title: Rona Jaffe's View Of the Single Life
description: Flashback: The year was 1958, and Rana Jaffe was the toast of the town. She was young (26), single. Radcliffeeducated and very photogenic (big brown waif's eyes), and she had just written The Best of Everything,  the bestselling novel about New York career girls trying to sleep and claw their way out of the steno pool.

title: Lester Flatt, Singer and Guitarist In Duo With Earl Scruggs, Dies
description: Lester Flatt, the veteran singer and guitarist who performed for 25 years with the bluegrass duo of Flatt and Scruggs, died at a hospital in Nashville yesterday of heart failure following a long illness. He was 64 years old. Surviviors include three brothers and three sisters.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Pennsylvania Engineering Corporation, whose chairman is Victor Posner, has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it bought 286,076 shares, or about 5 percent, of the common stock of Bliss & Laughlin Industries Inc., a steel manufacturer, for 59.1 million.

title: Burger Plans to Continue Policy On Curbing TV at Appearances
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger declared today that he intends no change in his policy of refusing to allow his public appearances to be televised unless the conditions meet his approval.

title: Scores of Rats Are Found at Site Where They Attacked a Woman
description: Scores of rats have been discovered at an excavated lot near City Hall, prompting authorities to undertake what they say is an intensive effort to eliminate the rat population in the area.rats, also known as brown rats. They have also been called super rats because of their apparent ability to develop resistances to most rodenticides. The adults are up to 12 inches long and weigh nearly a pound.

title: Companies List Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: French Verve Clings to Robust Ivory Coast
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  Abidjan is very nice, the cynics here like to say, and very convenient to Africa.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Yanks Lose, 41; Kaat Purchased
description: The New York Yankees bought 44 yearold Jim Kaat from the Philadelphia Phililes yesterday, but neither Kaat nor Ron Guidry nor anybody else could save the Yankees from a 41 defeat by the California Angels.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS Southern District

title: PARKING RULES
description: Alternateside parking regulations will again be in effect in Manhattan today so that trash accumulated during the tugboat strike can be removed. The rules will later be applied in the other boroughs, in rotation.

title: Miss Siebert Said to Bar Midland Bid
description: ALBANY, May 11  New York State's Banking Superintendent, Muriel F. Siebert, has sent a draft report to the Attorney General stating that she intends to reject a proposed takeover of Marine Midland Banks Inc. of Buffalo by the Hongkong & Shanghai Banking Corporation.

title: Shearson And Loeb May Merge
description: Two of the largest firms in the brokerage business  Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. and Loeb Rhoades, Homblower & Company  are discussing a possible merger, a spokesman for Loeb Rhoades said last night.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Albany Warned On Bills to Raise State School Aid
description: ALBANY, May 11  Top Carey administration officials said today that legislative initiatives to increase state aid to school districts by $35 million to $50 million were not financially responsible and that Mr. Carey would veto anything that is not financially responsible.

title: Rubinstein Sale Talks Terminated
description: The ColgatePalmolive Company and Japan's Kao Soap Company announced yesterday that they had terminated negotiations for the sale to Kao of Helena Rubinstein Inc., a Colgate. subsidiary.

title: U.S hIBRARY IS SHUT TO REVIEW SECRETS
description: The library of the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, which is normally open to the public, was suddenly closed Thursday afternoon after a researcher for the American Civil Liberties Union began examining unclassified material on nuclear weapons.

title: General Dynamics Fails In Quebec Asbestos Bid
description: MONTREAL, May 11  A compromise bidby the General Dynamics Corporation.of St. Louis to head off expropriation of its majority holding in the Asbestos Corporation, has been rejected by the Quebec government.

title: Johnson's Magic Act Is Moving to N.B.A.
description: EarvinIohnson, the Michigan State basketball star who answers to the nickname of Magic, is turning pro and the Los Angeles Lakers have first crack at him.

title: CARTER CASTIGATES HOUSE ON REJECTION OF GASRATION PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  President Carter accused the House of Representatives today of political timidity and said he was shocked and embarrassed for our nation's Government after the rejection by the House of his standby gasoline rationing plan.

title: Formidable Task for Randers
description: MONTREAL, May 11  They have met before  about 300 times since 1926  but when the Rangers face off against the Canadiens at the Forum on Sunday it will mark their first clash in the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Sidewalk Sculpture Symbolizes Faith in City
description: Accord, a 20-foot-high, fiveton, painted steel sculpture by Alexander Liberman after it was unveiled yesterday in front of Connaught Tower at 300 East 59th Street. Despite the recent destruction of a sidewalk sculpture Madison Avenue at 77th Street, the owners of the Connaught building decided to mount the work on the street as an affirmation of faith in the city

title: British Inflation In Double Digits
description: LONDON, May 11 (AP)  The annual inflation rate in Britain moved into double figures in April for the first time since December 1977, the Department of Employment announced today. The department said the rise in retail prices on a yeartoyear basis stood at 10.1 percent in April, compared with 9.8 percent in March.

title: Deaths
description: ABEREMary P. (nee Bruton) on May 10, 1979, beloved wife of George J., devoted mother of George J. Jr., and Kenneth James Abet, loving grandmother of Kenneth Jr., Geoffrey, and Douglas. Reposing Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 10333 Lefferts Blvd. Richmond Hill. Funeral Monday at 9:15 AM, Mass at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church. 9:45 AM. Interment St. John's Camefery.

title: Around the Nation
description: BALTIMORE, May 11 (AP)  Nine more persons were indicted today in the multimilliondollar General Services Administration scandal, including the highestranking Government official charged so tar.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: INTENSIVE DISCUSSION WITH MOSCOW IS DUE BEFORE PACT SIGNING
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  Administration officials said today that they expected to hold intensive discussions with Soviet officials in the next five weeks so that as many outstanding issues as possible could be resolved before President Carter's threeday meeting next month with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader.

title: A Wild Week For Oil Buyers
description: Oil prices on the open market surged higher once again yesterday, capping one of the wildest weeks buyers have ever seen. According to the editor of Oil Buyers Guide an industry newsletter, home heating oil sold for 91 cents a gallon in New York Harbor, up a staggering 10 cents a gallon from the day before. Unleaded gasoline went for 92 cents a gallon, he said, up 7 cents from the Thursday level.

title: Machines Ready for Dollar Coin
description: A quartermillion vending machines, newly revamped after a twoyear effort and a $25 million investment, stand ready to swallow the 400,000 new Susan B. Anthony dollar coins that are to pour into the American economy on July 2.

title: Higher Oil Tax To Be Studied
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) Under pressure from liberal. members of the House, Charles L. Schultze, President Carter's chief economic adviser, promised today that the Administration would seriously consider toughening a proposed windfall profits tax on the oil industry.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 22.

title: 3Alarm Fire Damages Buildings
description: A threealarm fire burned out of control for almost two hours last night on the Avenue of the Americans at 27th Street causing heavy damage to three buildings. The Fire Department reported that the fire broke out at 792 Avenue of the Americas in a flower store and two other stores in the ground floors of the threestory buildings.

title: Townley Is Sentenced In Letelier Murder Plot
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)  Michael Vernon Townley, a former Chilean agent, was sentenced today to serve between 90 months and 10 years in prison for planting the car bomb that killed the former Chilean ambassador Orlando Letelier and an aide.

title: King, U.S.A.C. President, Given Vote of Confidence
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 11 (AP) The United States Auto Club board of directors gave its embattled president, Dick King, an overwhelming vote of confidence today and then appointed him chairman of the board.

title: Greene Calls Profile of Him In New Yorker Inaccurate
description: Graham Greene, the British novelist, has complained that a profile written about him in The New Yorker was inaccurate. The article, which appeared in the. March 25 issue, was written Dy Penelope Gillian, who serves as movie critic of The New Yorker six months every year, a task she shared with Pauline Kael, who recently left her critical duties to produce movies.

title: Notes on People
description: Ballet lovers yesterday were given the dispiriting word that Antoinette Sibley, one of Britain's greatest ballerinas, must retire because of a knee injury. My leg has been giving way throughout rehearsals, and now my doctor tells me that my knee will never be strong enough again, said the 90yearold star of the Royal Ballet. Miss Sibley joined the ballet company in 1956 and created 12 roles.

title: Test of New Pact. Rein on Atom Technology and Strength
description: The new agreement on strategic weapons is an attempt to stabilize and constrain the nucleararms race between the Soviet Union and the United States. Its adequacy will be judged as much by the provisions intended to restrain technolog

title: Witness Says Thorpe Spoke to Him About Murder
description: LONDON, May 11 A former member of Parliament testified today that 10 years ago he and Jeremy Thorpe held two conversations in a House of Commons office about the possibility of murdering the young man who said he had been Mr. Thorpe's lover.

title: Letter. On Cogenerating Power The Benefits of Doing It Yourself
description: As the first New York City manufacturer to opt for saving energy and dollars by cogenerating, I find your April 24 editorial The Catch in DoItYourself Power full of misstatements and factual inaccuracies.

title: Letters
description: In his OpEd page article of April 29, George Ball admonishes the Europeans to build a political structure on a continentwide basis... In suggesting this notnew and seemingly natural idea he seems to overlook a basic and difficult question: Just what is a European?

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 19.

title: U.S. Sees Violations of Trust Act if Gas Stations Close
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  The Justice Department declared today that concerted action by gasoline retailers to shut down filling stations across the country on the weekend of May 1720 would violate the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: Serkin Cancels Recital
description: Rudolf Serkin has canceled his recital at the 92d Street Y next Wednesday because of illness. The pianist will be replaced by Isaac Stern, violinist; Jaime Laredo, violist; Leonard Rose, cellist, and David Golub, pianist. Tickets for the Serkin concert will be honored for the replacement concert or refunds will be made at the box office.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A band of frontal clouds extends from the lake region to Texas. Heavy thunderstorm acirity is visible over the Ohio Valley, the lower Missouri Valley, and Texas. Scattered clouds patches can be seen over sections of Hew England and the Atlantic. States. clouds are also visible over the northern Rockies. Mostly clear skies prevail elsewhere.

title: Coast Car Lines Stretch On
description: LOS ANGELES, May 11 (AP) Gasoline lines spilled onto freeways and caused traffic backups as long as eight miles today as California's new gasolinerestriction plan was tested in the rush preceding the weekend.

title: For a Select 400, Society's Bouquet
description: The 400 has a new meaning this week. It's the select group of socially prominent New Yorkers who were invited to attend the annual Spring Party at the New York Botanical Garden:,

title: Trudeau Tries to Spur Campaign
description: MONTREAL, May 11 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has sought to revive his flagging election campaign by presenting a plan to end a long stalemate over the Canadian constitution.

title: Nehemiah, HandTimed, Wins at 110 Meters in 12.8
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 11 (AP)  Renaldo Nehemiah, despite being unnerved by meet officials indecision over whether to disqualify Alejandro Casanas of Cuba, ran a handtimed 12.8second 110meter hurdles race tonirht at the Norman Manley Games.

title: About New York
description: Esther Shulamit Molloy lived from April 29,1962, until Feb. 5,1978, and two days before she died she told her mother how angry she was that everything was ending for her.

title: Pop: Perfect Miss Dearie In Club Date
description: Blossom Dearie is not, as some of her more adamant enthusiasts insist, perfect, She opened her program on Thursday evening at Reno Sweeney, where she is singing and playing piano through next Saturday, by forgetting theboenine lines of Sheldon Harnick's The Ballad of the Shape of Things to Come, which she has been singing for years. Then, conceding that she could not remember the rest of the words, she cleared the air and started all over by singing something else.

title: Deaf Players Guide Lists 35 Professionals
description: Listing 12 actresses and 23 actors, the first edition of the Deaf Players Guide for 197980 has been published by the National Theater of the Deaf, which is affilated with the Eugene ONeill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn.

title: Police Link 4 Slayings in Bedford Hills to Same Burglars
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., May 11 The four murders discovered yesterday on two neighboring estates in this affluent Westchester community were apparently the work of the same intruders, the county prosecutor said today. But he said he was at a loss to explain the senseless, wanton and brutal manner of the killings.

title: Market Up Slightly On Light Trading
description: The stock market produced a modest recovery yesterday after its sharp setback on Thursday. Analysts noted, however, that the low trading volume and token gains continued to reflect worries over gasoline shortages and the possibility of higher interest rates.

title: Your Money
description: AT 4 oclock in the morning on the final day of the last Congress, two bills dealing with plastic money cards came up for consideration.

title: What Term for Presidents?
description: When President Carter remarked the other day that he would like just by the stroke of a pen to change the Constitution to limit Presidents to one sixyear term, he embraced an idea that has found its champions in every generation. The idea of sparing Presidents from political ambition  and calculation has been particularly attractive to Presidents.

title: Broker Is Given 10 Years in Jail
description: A 10year prison sentence was imposed yesterday on a Wall Street broker who admitted defrauding 1,200 people in 45 states of $6 million in the sale of London commodity options, commodity pools and cold contracts.

title: Theater: La Puce  l'Oreille by Comdie Franaise
description: Having put such a winged foot forward with its performance of Molire's Le Misanthrope, the comdie Fnow follows with a more earth eas o nd version of the Feydeau farce, La Puce  lOreille.

title: Movie: Beneath the Valley of Ultra vixens
description: When pornographic films became legal. I thought that the market would disappear for Russ Meyer's very particular brand of supersoftcore pornography  wildly farcical and sometimes wildly violent films that feature a breed of rapacious women who look to have overdosed on silicone. I was appatently wrong, probably because didn't see the forest for the trees, if may use such a mild figure of speech in such gaudy circumstances.

title: Mother's Day, 1945
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y.  It was a beautiful, balmy morning in April 1945, when I entered Major Adams makeshift office in Farsieben, a small town in Germany, to offer my services as an interpreter. It made me feel good that I could show, in a small way, the gratitude I felt for the 9th American Army, which had liberated us as we were being transported from BergenBelsen concentration camp.

title: Dividends
description: REGUUIR

title: On the Auction Block, Couture's Classic Lines
description: Cathy Hardwick was so pleased, she went around hugging people. It's my lucky day, the designer kept saying. I got two Fortunys. Someday I'll give them to the museum, but I'm going to wear them first. Miss Hardwick's two dresses set her back $4,600.

title: St. Patrick's to Mark 100th Birthday Today
description: It is the most famous church In the country. Pope Paul VI celebrated mass there, tourists take pictures there, parades and politicians consistently find their way to its steps, and today St. Patrick's Cathedral will celebrate its 100th birthday.

title: Thermostat Curbs Seen After July 1
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  Administration officials said today that temperature controls on most commercial and government buildings would not go into effect until July 1 at the earliest, even though President Carter had asserted that he would invoke the controls as soon as he won the authority to do so.

title: Robert Thom, Writer Of Plays, Screenplays, Novels and Poems, 49
description: Robert Thom, playwright, poet, screenwriter and author, died Tuesday at a motel in Malibu, Calif., apparently of a heart attack. lie was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Court Upholds Reporter's Jailing for Balking on Notes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 11 (AP)  The State Supreme Court yesterday refused to overturn the jail sentence imposed on a reporter for refusing to turn over tapes and notes wanted by the defense in a murder case.

title: 329 Doctors Fined for Striking
description: Staff doctors who struck municipal hospitals last Jan. 17 to protest the threatened closing of some of the hospitals were fined one day's pay yesterday under the provisions of the state's Taylor Law, which prohibits strikes by government employees. Joseph C. Hoffman, the president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, said 329 staff doctors were fined a total of $21,000, which was deducted from their paychecks. A similar amount had been deducted from their checks on March 2.

title: Film Festival Opens in Cannes
description: CANNES, France, May 11 (AP)  In a setting of hype and celebration, the 32d International Film Festival opened yesterday in this Mediterranean resort city brimming with tourists and film representatives.

title: Recital: Simca Heled Plays Cello
description: Simca Heled, until 1973 the principal cellist of the Israel Philharmonic and currently a member of the Yuval Trio, has been branching out into the solo repertory more frequently over the last five years. On Thursday night at the 92d Street Y, he made a further gesture in that direction with a meaty program of sonatas in which he was accompanied by Jonathan Feldman, the pianist.

title: Ben Weber, 62, Tonal Composer
description: Ben Weber, the composer, was found dead Wednesday evening in his apartment at 418 Central Park West. The death was attributed to a coronary attack. He was 62 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: BERNARD BERENSON: The Making of a Connoisseur. By Ernest Samuels. Illustrated. 471 pages. Belknap. $15.

title: Jorge Gomez, Worked 22 Years For New York Attorney General
description: Jorge Gomez, an assistant state attorney general in New York for 22 years who specialized in cases involving workmen's compensation and labor appeals, died Wedneday at his daughter's home in Cherry Hill, N.J. Mr. Gomez, who lived in Manhattan, was 68 years old.

title: Arms Treaty Assurances Are Asked by Moynihan
description: WASHINGTON. May 11  Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. Democrat of New York, has reiterated that he wants to support the new strategic arms treaty, but in a speech last night he said he needed assurances from the Administration that will enable me to do so.

title: A.T.&T. Sets China Talks
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)  Officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that a delegation would visit China next month to discuss plans for expanding communications with that country. A company official said there had been a 300 percent increase in United States calls to China in the first three months of this year.

title: Cabbie Is Held in Killing of a Fare
description: A 37yearold taxicab driver struck and killed an unidentified male passenger last night as they stood before a desk sergeant in an East Side police station discussing a dispute over a $13 fare. The driver was taken into custody and charged with manslaughter in the first degree.

title: Jazz: Dave Liebman Is Leading a Different Quintet
description: The quintet that Dave Liebman has been leading this week  playing. through tonight  at Fat Tuesdays, Third Avenue and 17th Street, is, aside from Richie Beirach, the pianist, not his regular group, Lookout Farm. It is. as Mr. Liebman describes it, a band that gets together every once in while. Which can be interpreted as meaning a group that enjoys playing together, but does not do it so often that they become casual.

title: Sentences for 11 in Soweto Riots Are Relatively Light
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 11  Eleven black students received relatively light sentences today for their part in organizing protests that erupted into riots in the black ehetto of Soweto in 1976 and 1977.

title: Limiting C.I.A. and Oversight
description: It was not so many months ago that the public was first astonished and then angered by disclosure of covert operations by the Central Intelligence Agency in Chile, Laos, Angola and elsewhere. So it seems odd that the Carter Administration now proposes to ease present controls over C.I.A. dirty tricks. But the proposal is neither odd nor hastily permissive. It responds to practical necessity.

title: Edper Head Questions Brascan's Woolworth Bid
description: Patrick Keenan, president of Edper Equities Ltd., told a public hearing in New York yesterday that if his company acquired control of Brascan Ltd., after Brascan took over the F.W. Woolworth Company, Edper would sell off Woolworth assets to rid itself of the financial burdens imposed by the takeover of the retailer.

title: TheCity
description: Adela Holzer, who was sentenced to from two to six years in prison for defratding Scores of investors, was freed on $50,00tbond yesterday after spending eight days in jail.

title: Mets, Behind Kobel, Defeat Padres by 40
description: SAN DIEGO, May 11  Suddenly everything worked for the Mets tonight. They got pitching  eight scoreless innings from Kevin Kobel and another from Skip Lockwood  and they got the long ball  home runs by John Stearns and Steve Henderson. The result was a 40 triumph over the San Diego Padres.
