title: Benson Ford Says Talk With Uncle Yielded Little
description: DETROIT, May 11  Benson Ford Jr. said in an interview here today that he and his uncle Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, met privately for about an hour on Wednesday and found no common ground on which to begin to iron out their differences.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 11. (Reuters) Aleksandr Ginzburg said today that his recent release from Soviet imprisonment did not signify an improvement in Moscow's policiet on human rights.

title: 6 Killed in Philadelphia Explosion
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP)  Six persons were killed and three others were seriously injured this afternoon in a gas explosion and fire that destroyed a tavern and a rowhouse, fire officials said.

title: How Officials Are Tackling The Bedford Hills Murders
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., May 11 The last time Thomas A. Facelle, the chief assistant district attorney of Westchester County, and Peter Liverzani, a New York state police captain, worked together was in the March 1977 killings of two Lewisboro housewives who had interrupted burglars in a house just about 10 miles north of here. That case ended a year later when three Connecticut men were convicted and sentenced to long prison terms.

title: Transit Budget For 80 Passed; A Deficit Looms
description: The Transit Authority's directors yesterday approved a $1.08 billion financial plan for running the city's subway and bus system in the next fiscal year, but acknowledged that an almost certain wage increase in a new labor contract next April would create a deficit in the final quarter.

title: Algerians Recall Rebellion, But Days Needs Are First
description: ALGIERS, May 5  The audience at the premiere of El Moufid, the latest Technicolor accomplishment of the infant Algerian film industry, was respectful, applauding hard at the end.

title: Nuclear Power Opposed By Council of Churches
description: SAN ANTONIO, May 11 (AP)  The National Council of Churches, by a vote of 120 to 26, urged the United States today to end its dependence on nuclear energy and to focus on such renewable energy resources as solar, wind and water power.

title: Director Will Retire at Carnegie Museum
description: PITTSBURGH, May 11  Leon A. Arkus will retire as director of the Museum of Art, Carnegie Institute, on June 1, 1980, it was announced today. Mr. Arkus assumed the position in April, 1968, succeeding Gustave van Groschwitz.

title: A Flower for the Occasion
description: MONTREAL, May 11 In or out of sports, it's known as rising to the occasion. Muhammad Ali, the Yankees and Jack Nicklaus do it. Laurence Olivier and Baryshnikov do it. And in hockey, the Montreal Canadiens do it. In their glorious history, they have won the Stanley Cup a record 21 times, including each of the last three years and 15 of the last 26 years.

title: Taiwan's Lifeblood Is Trade
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 11  While Americans press Japan to reduce its huge trade surplus with the United States, Taiwan's $2.6 billion surplus with the United States has escaped similar attention, even though the Taiwanese balance is proportionately much larger than Japan's surplus of $11.6 billion, considering Taiwan's population of 17 million and Japan's 113 million.

title: Police Officer Is Suspended
description: A New York City police officer was suspended yesterday after admitting he had wounded himself in a suicide attempt and had not been shot by a mugger, as he had first reported, the police said. They said the officer, Alphonso De La Vega, 33 years old, of Babylon, L.I., had been admitted to Kings County Hospital with a gunshot wound of the thigh.

title: Key West, When the World Was New
description: Whenever asked ta list place of birth, I mention Key West, Florida. You're a conch.

title: Stanley Cup Schedule
description: Sunday, May 13 at Montreal, 4 P.M.

title: PARADE TODAY
description: The 29th Annual Armed Forces Day Parade will begin at noon today. The parade, which honors American servicemen, will start at 26th Street, proceed up Fifth Avenue to 59th Street and turn east, ending at Third Avenue.

title: Hearing Set On Satellite Consortium
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  The Federal Communications Commission and the Satellite Business Systems today won a full hearing before an appeals court on the right of the threecompany consortium to enter the satellite business.

title: Suspect, 22, Held in Rape of 10 Women
description: A 22yearold man was accused by the police yesterday of raping and robbing 10 elderly women in a series of assaults in the West Bronx in recent months. The suspect was arrested Thursday.

title: Cicadas Warm Up for Their 17Year Song
description: An invertebrate animal that has long puzzled scientists is about to be heard in the land. It is the world's longestlived insect, known to entomologists as the periodic cicada, and more often incorrectly called the 17year locust by laymen.

title: Long Wait Nearly Over for Kin of Jonestown Dead
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 11  For Freddie L. Lewis, the long, emotionally exhausting wait was almost over.

title: Webster Settlement Upheld
description: Telford Taylor, the special master appointed to rule on any disputes arising from the Oscar Robertson settlement, refused yesterday to overrule the compensation awarded to the Seattle SuperSonics by Larry O'Brien, the National Basketball Associatiion commissioner, for the Knicks signing of Marvin Webster.

title: A New Sense of the Vulnerable in Bedford
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y. May 11 The door to St. Matthew's, a church constructed with financial help from John Jay and consecrated in 1810, is seldom locked, a tribute to the old values of the graceful hamlets of Bedford. But should a stranger park close to the door and leave the engine running, Tom Reilly, the sexton, comes quickly and anxiously from his nearby house.

title: U.S. Tactic In A.T.& T. Suit at Issue
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  Federal Judge Harold Greene expressed doubt today about the workability of a Justice Department proposal trial Now. 1 on background start sof the Government's civil antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Democrats to Journey To Four Cities in Hunt For a Convention Site
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  Democratic leaders decided today to tour all four cities still in the running as sites for the party's 1980 convention before making a final selection late next month.

title: MoreDistant Trumpets
description: As recently as World War II and the early postwar period, the international airwaves and front pages of the world press were monopolized by the stirring rhetoric of American and British statesmen.

title: Deaths
description: HYMANEdgar C. Beloved husband of the late Theresa M. Hyman. Devoted father of Dorothy H. Roberts. Loving grandfather of Lym and Steven. Founder and former Board Chairman of Echo Scarfs, InCorporeted. Death came at age 88. Friday, May 11th in a Miami nursing hone. Services to be held Monday 10AM at Campbell's, 81st Street and Madison Avenue, New York. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to e favorite charity.

title: The Region
description: ELIZABETH, N.I. Two police officers were slightly injured here after a 55gallon drum of acid ruptured, sending caustic fumes into the air at the Chemical Control Corporation dump site, where more than 45,000 drums of potentially hazardous chemicals are stored.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Rikers Guard Among 17 Indicted in Narcotics Case
description: An indictment charging 17 defendants with a conspiracy to sell massive amounts of heroin and cocaine in Manhattan was announced yesterday by Federal prosecutors, who said one defendant was a Rikers Island prison guard accused of delivering narcotics in the House of Detention for Men.

title: Carey, Yielding to Republicans, To Dismiss Seiff as Investigator
description: Under pressure from Republican legislative leaders, Governor Carey has decided to dismiss Eric A. Seiff as chairman of the State Commission of Investigation. Mr. Seiff will be replaced by Adam Walinsky, now a member of the commission, aides to the Governor said.

title: Reported CarterAssassination Plot Given Credibility by New Evidence
description: LOS ANGELES, May 11 (UPI)  Investigators have found evidence, including a gun case, ammunition and corroborative testimony, that adds credibility to a reported plot to assassinate President Carter, originally dismissed as a tale spun by an intoxicated man.

title: Bridge:
description: A distinguished field will sit down in Manhattan today and tomorrow to contest the fifth annual Cavendish Club invitational pair championship, one of the two strongest events of its type in the world. Among the 80 players are 15 who have won world titles and 26 who have won North American titles.

title: N.L.R.B. Office Backs Charge by The Times; Calls the Guild Unfair
description: A complaint charging unfair labor practices has been made by the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board against the Newspaper Guild of New York. The complaint is based on disciplinary actions the guild took against some employees of The New York Times.

title: Oil Rig With 34 Collapses in Gulf, Divers Press a Search for 8 Missing
description: GALVESTON, Tex., May 11  An offshore oildrilling platform unaccountably collapsed in the Gulf of Mexico about 12 miles southeast of here last night, plunging into sevenfoot waves 60 feet above the sea floor with 34 men aboard. Today divers were searching for eight who remained missing.

title: 2 Rival Jewish Factions In Scuffle on West Bank
description: BETHLEHEM, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, May 11  Fist fights broke out near here today between two Jewish groups  one promoting understanding with the Arabs and the other demanding the creation of new Jewish settlements among the Arabs in the West Bank territory. Israeli sotaters mtervenea to separate the battling groups.

title: Dr. Teller Tested in Hospital
description: LOS ANGELES, May 11 (Reuters) Dr. Edward Teller, sometimes referred to as father of the hydrogen bomb, was undergoing tests at a hospital here after telling doctors he felt ill, a hospital spokesman said yesterday. A spokesman at CedarsSinai Hospital did not disclose the nature of the 71yearold scientist's illness but said his general condition was good.

title: Tests in an Alabama Town Seek to Trace DDT's Effects on Humans
description: TRIANA, Ala., May 11  A 12member medical team from the Federal Center for Disease Control set up a makeshift clinic here today and examined the first of more than 500 residents from this small community in the most extensive inquiry to date into the effects of longterm consumption of food contaminated with high levels of DDT.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M. (Television  Channel 11, P.M. Radio  WINS, 2 P.M.)

title: Wheat Stability Sought
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  The four major wheatexporting countries agreed yesterday to cooperate in stabilizing world wheat prices but did not even discuss the possibility of forming a wheat cartel, Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland said today.

title: Milwaukee Road Aid
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  The Interstate Commerce Commission, bracing for a possible decision next week that could leave many Middle Western cornmunities without rail service, voted 4 to 2 today to direct other railroad companies to serve threefourths of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad's area.

title: News Summary
description: Soviet and American officials will meet for intensive talks within the next few weeks in an attempt to resolve beforehand the issues that will be on the agenda when President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, sign the treaty to limit strategic arms treaty in Vienna next month. [Page 1, Column 4.]

title: Inventories Up by 1.3%
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) American business built up inventories at an accelerated rate in March,but sales also surged to relieve possible stockpilingproblems if the economy slows down sharply, new Government figures indicated today.

title: SHARP REFUGEE RISE WORRIES HONG KONG
description: HONG KONG, May 11 Discriminatory measures against the Chinese minority in the north of Vietnam have dramatically increased the flow of refugees to Hong Kong, making this British colony a principal port of asylum for people fleeing Indochina.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter accused the House of political timidity in rejecting his gasoline rationing proposal and challenged it to develop its own program. The President said there was no purpose in his submitting another plan. [Page 1.]

title: Food Stamps: A Way of Life In Puerto Rico
description: PONCE, P. R.  On any Saturday morning, the Pueblo supermarket in the Centro de Sur shopping mall looks like a typical supermarket anywhere in Amer ica.

title: A Nation of Sheep
description: Flying over the snowfields

title: Mahwah Linking Homes and Offices
description: MAHWAH

title: Teamsters Plan an Organizing Drive in Chinatown
description: Local 868 of the teamsters has announced its intention to organize the Chinatown restaurant and garment industries, where, according to the local's president, employees have no overtime or health benefits and often work long hours for less than Federal minimum wages.

title: Performing Artists Find Stimulation in the Capital
description: WASHINGTON  New York City is unlikely to lose its place as mecca for the performing artist.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE Connecticut Falcons of the International Women's Professional Softball Association embark tomorrow on what may be the longest road trip in Connecticut sports history. The Falcons will leave San Francisco for a nineday visit to China, where the team will play six games in Lanchow and Peking and also conduct a number of clinics.

title: HONE CLINIC Important Steps for Ladder Safety
description: THIS is the time of year when many homeowners tackle such jobs as painting the outside of their homes, repairing gutters or doing similar outdoor chores that call for the use of a tall extension ladder.

title: Births
description: BASSIN

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: ART
description: MANY photographs taken in China in recent years make the Chinese look sullen and their surroundings drab. We have got the impression that the Chinese are melancholic or al ways serious and that their life is outrageously tedious. The revolution appears to have homogenized not only the people, but also their landscape into a sober, humdrum uniformity.

title: Mideast Peace A Lot Like War
description: Since Israel refuses to recognize the Palestine Liberation Organization (and viceversa), there was a certain logic to Prime Minister Menachem Begin's offer last week to talk peace with the Lebanese Government of President Elias Sarkis while Israeli troops were attacking the Palestinians again on Lebanese turf. That Mr. Sarkis refused the offer was hardly surprising, since the Syrians control most of Lebanon except for the south, where the Palestinians seem to answer to no oneleast of all Mr. Sarkis.

title: A Walk Unlike Any Other
description: MY father left me at Heckscher State Park at 6 A.M. At 4 P.M. I was soaking my feet in the kitchen, eyes glazed, unable to answer questions, express what the day had been.

title: No Complaints, Mom
description: YOU can't fool me. I know what stands behind all those sentimental Mother's Day cards, bouquets of roses and busy telephone circuits today. It's crass commercialism. I am aware of the glittering dollar signs that form a garland around the day, but I am trapped by one inescapable truth: I have an extraordinary mother.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Pippin. Thursday to Saturday at 8 P.M., Sundays at 2 P.M. Through June 3.55.50 to $7.50. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Route 6.6281169.

title: Anne Emmons Is Betrothed To Alexander K. Buck Jr.
description: Anne MacDougall Emmons, who expects to gradute May 25 from Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., plans to be married in October to Alexander Knapp Buck Jr., an English and history teacher and sports coach at the Shore Country Day School in Beverly, Mass.

title: Yonkers Project's Shining Promise Called Tarnished
description: YONKERS  When it opened in 1974, Whitney Young Manor was expected to represent a kept promise of the state's Urban Development Corporation to provide low and moderateincome housing.

title: Coastal Bill A Balancing Act
description: IN a move to protect the beauty and fragility of the Connecticut shoreline, local, state and Federal officials have spent nearly five years trying to put together a coastal management package that would strike a healthy balance between development and preservation.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IS there a possibility that Westchester may lose its only major airline, Allegheny? According to the State Transportation Department, there is. The state agency has mentioned the possibility in a background paper circulated to business associations in the state  groups that are being asked by the agency to participate in a survey of airservice needs in the state.

title: Padres Defeat Mets On Bevacqua Hit, 21
description: SAN DIEGO, May 12  The Mets winning streak came to an end at one game tonight.

title: In Praise of John Culver
description: WHENEVER they haven't got anything better to think about, taxpayers must wonder what, besides messing things up, a member of Congress does for $57,500 plus perquisites. To satisfy that curiosity, several books of a semidiary or journal variety have been written in recent years by our Federal politicians, usually with the help of one or more literate collaborators; for example, former Representative Donald Riegle's 0 Congress, written with Trevor Armbrister. But they are almost always very selectively pieced together from the liveliest episodes that occurred over a period of many months. One easily gets the impression from them that national politicians skip merrily from peak to peak. eral politicians, usually with the help of one or more literate collaborators; for example, former Representative Donald Riegle's 0 Congress, written with Trevor Armbrister. But they are almost always very selectively pieced together from the liveliest episodes that occurred over a period of many months. One easily gets the impression from them that national politicians skip merrily from peak to peak.

title: Greg Herzog Runs 4:10.5 For Loucks Mile Record
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 12  Greg Herzog, who had been having a disappointing outdoor season, atoned for it today before hometown fans by winning the onemile run at the 12th annual Glenn Loucks Games in the meet record time of 4 minutes 10.5 seconds.

title: Mary Riley Married. To David Dearborn
description: Mary Scott Riley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Drinker Riley of Reading, Vt., was married yesterday afternocin to David Dearborn, son of Pauline M. Nickerson of Wenham, Mass., and the:late Frederick M. Dearborn Jr. The rector, the Rev. J. Mark Dyer, performed the ceremony in the chapel of Christ Episcopal Church in Hamilton, Mass.

title: Pamela J. Steiniger To Be Wed in Fall
description: The engagement of Pamela Joan Steiniger to Michel Huard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Huard of Pads, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Steiniger of New York and Shelter Island, L.I. A fall wedding is planned.

title: The Philharmonic Finds New Soloists In Its Own Ranks
description: When he needs three superb solo violinists, Zubin Mehta, like King Cole, can find them in his own court.

title: Roller Skates: 300,000 Pairs a Month
description: Perhaps it was the proliferation of discos or a reaction to the hazards of skateboarding. Perhaps it was newspaper photos of New Yorkers rollerskating in Central Park or of singer Linda Ronstadt wheeling off for a luncheon date with Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California. Lately, maybe, it's the gasoline scare.

title: Brewers 3, Tigers 2
description: DETROIT, May 12 (AP)  Jim WohHord and Charlie Moore hit consecutive doubles with two out in the ninth inning today to give the Milwaukee Brewers a 32 triumph over the Detroit Tigers.

title: Hollins, Lock Haven Win
description: HOLLINS, Va., May 12 (AP)Leslie Blankin scored seven goals and led topseeded Hollins to a 92 romp over Cortland State, and secondseeded Lock Haven State defeated Loyola of Baltimore by 84 today in the semifinals of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association Division II tournament. The final is tomorrow

title: L.I. Symphony Ends On Discordant Note
description: THE Long Island Symphony came to a rancorous end this weekend with the cancellation of the orchestra's final pair of subscription concerts and with continued feuding between musicians and management.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: An Appreciation: The Tarkenton Legacy
description: After Fran Tarkenton announced last week that he was through playing football the Chicago Bears best linebacker, Doug Buffone, who had been toying with his own retirement, mused that he might now extend his career well into the 1980's. Buffone contended that no linebacker in the National Football League was sorry to see Tarkenton bow out although he had one personal regret.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: Clifton Fadiman, one of the important literary arbiters of our time, observes two events this month: his 75th birthday on Tuesday and his 35th year as the quintessential BookoftheMonth Club judge, as Ed Fitzgerald, president of B.O.M.C. calls him. That offered two reasons to ring him at his Santa Barbara, Calif., home. He was between monthly visits to New York to sit down with his fellow judges at the most exclusive lunch club in town (the long table in the B.O.M.C. office) and pick the club's main choice. I asked him: How has the novel changed since 1999? visits to New York to sit down with his fellow judges at the most exclusive lunch club in town (the long table in the B.O.M.C. office) and pick the club's main choice. I asked him: How has the novel changed since 1999?

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: In recent years, a great deal has been written about opera production. The cry has gone up that directors are usurping the place of the composers; that in their stagings they are playing fast and loose with what the composer intended; that they are on ego trips that leave the music far behind. Horrible examples are cited one of the most recent being what JeanPierre Ponnelle did to the Flying Dutchman when the Metropolitan Opera staged it last season.

title: CONNECTICUT HOUSING
description: NEW BRITAIN TEN o'clock at the New Britain Courthouse. Visitors gallery is packed. On a row of chairs just in front of this gallery, lawyers sit with neat files laid on their knees as as they await the imminent arrival of Judge Arthur L. Spada.

title: Winning and Losing at Texas Instruments
description: DALLAS  Like its neighbors, the Dallas Cowboys, Texas Instruments is welldrilled and tightly controlled. It has excellent recruiting, depth at every position, and its offense runs like the proverbial clock. But the Cowboys don't always win, nor does Texas Instruments.

title: Births
description: RUBIN

title: You Can't Take It With You Alms for Fresh Laughs on TV
description: HOLLYWOOD Director Paul Bogart grimaced and cupped his hands protectively over his ears as explosives boomed man alley outsidc Stage Eight in Hollywood's Television Studios shattering the quiet April afternoon Man. that's some racket! Mr. Bogar said, rubbing his trim gray heard and smiling approvingly a,: the specialeffects man. Where on earth did you ever get firecrackers like that?

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: There would appear to be a continuing interest in the subject of religious communities. The nun, secluded from the world by some orders, living according to ancient rules and unbreakable vows, is still a mystery.

title: In North Salem, a Planning Quandary
description: NORTH SALEM SOME planners and business people who have dealt with this northern Westchester town in the last six or seven years have described its planning policies as mercurial in the approach and avoidance of more intensive and diversified development.

title: U.S.CHINESE ACCORD ON TRADE REPORTED SET FOR INITIALING
description: GUILIN, China, May 12  An oral agreement has been reached between the United States and China to initial a trade treaty, according to sources within touring American delegation headed by Commerce Secretary Juanita M. Kreps.

title: Airline Economics Determine Frills
description: Anyone who has flown a lot snows that on highly competitive routes there are two main lures to attract passengers: bargain fares and increased frills. The degree to which airlines offer one or the other or a combination of both is commonly governed by the degree of competition.

title: The CostSaving, SteelFrame Solution
description: MT. PLEASANT, N.Y.  The familiar hammering sounds of a suburban construction job were missing recently as. workmen began framing up twostory home at 290 Hardscrabble Road. Only the creaking of a crane lifting steel frames into place and the whoosh of an acetylene torch broke the silence of the treeshaded site.

title: THE ISLAND
description: To the charge that Charles Williams wrote potboilers, T. S. Eliot once replied, yes, but he

title: The Cicadas Song Is
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE cicadas are coming! The cicadas are coming! Any day now, like their parents in 1962, their grandparents in 1945 and their ancestors as far back as anyone remembers or knows, the insects will emerge, their 17 years of quiet growth underground ended.

title: The Region
description: When state legislatures limit the interest that lenders can charge for home mortgage loans, it's usually done in the name of protecting the consumer. The theory is that banks and other institutions shouldn't be able to profit on their loans at a much greater margin than the interest they are returning to their depositors. But when the lenders of money, and the builders of houses, see their competitors elsewhere prospering on doubledigit interest, legislators come under intense pressure to loosen the limit.

title: Inflation Has Thrown the MitchellLama Program Into Turmoil but the Democrats May Have a Way
description: ALBANY  After years of trying, Governor Carey and his Democratic allies in the Assembly seem on the verge making New York's troubled MitchellLama middleincome housing program a bipartisan problem. They have done this by coming to terms with each other on a longrange plan for the deficitridden program, a necessary preliminary pressuring the Republicancontrolled Senate to join them a bipartisan solution  not the one the Democrats adopted last month, most likely, but something.

title: Deaths
description: JACKSONSidney L. Kept, Ohio, May 8. Dr. Sidney L. Jackson, a native of Brooklyn & professor of Ubrary Science at Kenf State Unlvesity, died in his sleep at his home Ise Tuesday. He was 64. His other. Julie Jackson. resides in Manhattan. Flowing cremation, services were held in Kew on Theuiday Evening. (Bissier Funeral Home. 7:30pmm) with interment in Queens the following week. A blend of historian 8 librarian, and a strong advocate of socipl lustice, Dr. Jackson authored The Struggle for Free Schools in 1943, and Libraries & Librarianship in the west, a brief history. published by McGraw Hill In 1974. He had traveled widely in Europe. His PHD was earned at Columbia. Born Sept. 12. 1914, he lived in New York City, with brief stays in Buffalo & Washington D.C. unfit 1959 when he Mined the Kent State faculty. During his 20 ream ther. he served on the Faculty Senate and as faculty advisor to the May 4 Task Force. He was active in professional organizations and in the NAACP. Dr. Jackson is also survived by his wife, Clara. a member of the Kent State Library School faculty, son Joseph and daughter Miriam (Mim). Both of Kent and brother Gabriel of LaJolia,Calif.

title: Women Together: Facing the Risks Of White Water
description: Two miles south of Vallecito, on Parrot's Ferry Road, we pull into the dirt driveway of the American River Touring Association headquarters. We straggle in by twos, on this spring morning, mothers and daughters, gathering for a twoday weekend rafting trip down northern California's Stanislaus River.

title: Senator Kennedy's Antitrust Bill Passed One Obstacle Last Week; Many More Lie Ahead
description: WASHINGTON  From Adam Smith's. Wealth of Nations, through the Founding Fathers, up to Teddy Roosevelt's zealous enforcement of the Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890, and on into the midcentury, opponents of monopoly have also tended, more or less, to be adherents of the philosophy that big is bad. Yet despite President Carter's populist convictions, his Administration has been coyly dancing away from taking a position on a pending bill that would write that proposition into antitrust law.

title: Expertise of Physicists at Brookhaven Laboratory Illustrated After Three Mile Island Nuclear Mishap
description: YAPHANK, L.I.  By 1 P.M. of the day that the name Three Mile Island began to become synonymous with a nuclear accident, a unit of health physicists from the Brookhaven National Laboratory here were on the scene in Pennsylvania, beginning to determine how much radioactive iodine had leaked out into the air.

title: ART
description: RIDGEFIELD AMUSEUM that takes its didactic responsibility very seriously, the Aldrich is conducting small survey of minimal art.

title: ART An Exhibition in Praise of Paper
description: WEST NYACK, N.Y. THE art world used to be much simpler. Oils and acrylics were used for canvases. and ink, charcoal. lead and water colors were used for paper.

title: He Smiles When He Says Cheese
description: I THINK we are the epitome of a familyowned private business, said William Dorman. He knows whereof he speaks, for he is executive vice president of N. Dorman & Company, the Syossetbased cheese company that millions of people associate with Endecobrand cheeses and the slogan The cheese with the paper between the slices.

title: 25 Years After Brown
description: WASHINGTON  The awful vice of the 1896 Supreme Court decision in Plessy v. Ferguson, which established the separatebutequal doctrine, was that it tolerated the use of governmental power to support and enforce the notion that people with dark skins were inherently and inescapably inferior to those with white skins. That notion is deeply rooted in our culture and, indeed, was written into the Constitution. The Civil War Amendments cleansed the Constitution (if not men's hearts), but Plessy sullied it again.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: When last heard from in midMarch, Jove Publications was about to move in permanently with Berkley Publishing Corporation yet retain its own name. This arrangement was the result of the acquisition by MCA, Berkley's owner, of Jove from Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title: Sailing Gets a Corporate Look
description: Unlike many American sports, sailing has resisted corporate sponsorship  until now. In a move that will set a new course for sail boat racing, the United States Yacht Racing Union, which sanctions American competition, is on the verge of entering into an agreement with Michelob beer to sponsor the United States and Ton championship regattas this year.

title: On a Pony Trek in the Welsh Hills
description: My wife and I chose to ponytrek at Builth Wells, Wales, for no particular reason. Its name sounded interesting and it was on the way back to England, about 15 miles from the border as the crow flies, twice that as the road meanders. We were returning from a visit to Laugharne, the timeless, mild, beguiling island of a town that is Dylan Thomas's final restingplace and to St. David's with its rugged coast and splendid purple stone cathedral, both in southern Wales. And we had always wanted to go ponytrekking.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: There was no small cause for celebration in the offices of Farrar, Straus & Giroux in June 1976 when A Party of Animals arrived, an epic stack of 2,000 manuscript pages soon to be published as Harold Brodkey's longanticipated first novel.

title: A Challenge in Africa for Conservatives
description: American and British policy for southern Africa is approaching another turn and many hands are lunging for the wheel. Washington and London have obviously failed to reach their recent objectives. That does not, however, justify the conclusion that they have been traveling the wrong road altogether.

title: Connecticut /This Week
description: DANBURY  The Seat of American Invention: exhibition of antique and unusual chairs, through May 30, Library, 170 Main St. 7920280.

title: Ganga's Secrets
description: FOR more than five years I had dreamed of a new adventure. There hardly could be a more enticing opening line, especially when its author is Sir Edmund Hillary, conqueror of Mount Everest, and it begins the account of his latest expedition to the Himalayas. Surely what follows will be an epic tale of courageous men challenging the wilderness and themselves.

title: Goose's Demise on Back Nine Ruffles Feathers
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  This much is known: One Canada goose died near the 17th hole of the Congressional Country Club in Bethesda, Md., a week ago Thursday.

title: The Nuclear Inquest Proliferates Too
description: Members of Congress, squeezed between pleas to keep atomic reactors going and demands to shut em down, seemed inclined last week to put them on hold.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: How Writer Got Secrets Of U.S. Cambodian Acts
description: It would be impossible to write this kind of book in England, William Shawcross said. And it probably would have been impossible to write the book had the Republicans won in 76.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  Cold Storage, in an Actor's CafeTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through May 26). $3.5$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$4.50. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: About Cars: G.M.'s XBodies
description: THE specifics of General Motors new Xbody cars  the Chevy Citation, Pontiac Phoenix, Oldsmobile Omega and Buick Skylark  are available almost everywhere these days. thanks to

title: Tracy Austin Ends Miss Evert's Streak
description: ROME, May 12 (UPI)  Tracy Austin upset Chris Evert, 64, 26, 76, today and gained the final of the $100,000 Halian women's tennis tournament against another upset winner, Sylvia Hanika of West Germany. Miss Hanika, unseeded, toppled Evonne Goolagong, 75, 36, 75.

title: Talking With Thinkers
description: THIS book is an edited version of a very successful BBC television series of 15 interviews with contemporary British and American philosophers. Each interview was introduced and conducted by Bryan Magee, who studied philosophy at Oxford and is an experienced broadcaster. The originai is talks were uneven in quality, but the best of them were outstandingly interesting and informative, and they make excellent written dialogues in this revised form. Three of them present tersely, and with authority, original ideas. These are the interviews with Noam Chomsky, W.V. Quine and Iris Murdoch. In addition, Sir Isaiah Berlin, Bernard Williams, Ronald Dworkin, Sir Alfred Ayer and John Searle all produce excellent summaries of contemporary work, which cannot easily be found in such an agreeable and readable form elsewhere. The proportion of success is doubly remarkable when one considers the limits naturally set on the dissemination of philosophical ideas by television, as opposed to radio. Unavoidably there are aspects of contemporary philosophy that are neglected. Recent developments in logic and the philosophy of mathematics have had a very great influence on philosophy in recent decades, as they always must have; but they are not subjects that can easily be presented to a large audience on television.

title: McCarter Gets a New Artistic Director
description: PRINCETON ONCE Nagle Jackson settles in as artistic director of the McCarter Theater, he promises to add his own innovative touch to drama in New Jersey. It will be something that the McCarter has never had before: a resident acting ensemble.

title: Leters T0 THE EDIT0R
description: In Man on the Spot (April 8) Christopher Wren refers to King Hussein as a moderate. Mr. Wren must have paid scant attention to the King's own remarks. When asked if he saw a way of coexisting with Israel, the Jordanian monarch replied, in a slightly roundabout manner, No. He did not say, Yes, if Israel will surrender the West Bank, or Yes, if Israel will return to the 1947 United Nations Partition borders. He said, No. Oh, he wrapped it in flowery phrases  there are some ingredients missing to make Arabs and Israelis living together a reality but his meaning was still quite clear: The Jewish State must be eliminated.

title: The Claim Now Is That the Drivers Got What They Wanted All Along
description: When the threemonthlong wildcat walkout by public school bus drivers was settled last week, parents of children unable to get to school for most of the spring semester wondered whether their children had been the pawns in a battle that had little to do with transoortation or education.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING Teaneck: Its Trump Card Is Charm
description: TEANECK THE I Love New York people have nothing on the folks in Teaneck. This quiet, sixsquaremile Bergen County community has plenty of what Rori Kanter, a longtime resident, calls its cheerleaders  official and otherwise. Their chief rallying cry is the variety and quality of Teaneck's housing.

title: Linda Ann Pollard Is Married
description: Linda Ann Pollard and Maurice K.C. Wilcox, 1977 alumni of the Hastings College of the Law, were married yesterday at the Yosemite Chapel in Yosemite Valley, Calif. The Rev. John Davis of the United Methodist Church performed the ceremony. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Spencer Pollard of Burns Lakes, British Columbia, is an editor of the lawbook publishing concern of Matthew Bender & Company in San Francisco, where her husband is an associate with the law firm of Morrison & Foerster. His parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Wilcox, have homes in San Francisco and Shelter Island, L.I.

title: J.W. Paris 2d Weds Belinda Winpenny
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday, Belinda Randall Winpenny, promotion coordinator for Business Week magazine, was married to John Wright Paris 2d, a senior consultant with People Management Inc. in Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. H. Lawrence Scott, assisted by the Rev. Robert O. Weeks, performed the ceremony.

title: The Have It All Now Generation
description: THE generation gap in style, music, dancing and social mores has been explored and exploited ever since Elvis Presley first burst on the scene. but the economic generation gap has been largely ignored by social scientists, although it could be the most pervasive force in our society today.

title: ZIONIST WARNS IRAN ABOUT HARM TO JEWS
description: The execution of a top Jewish community leader in Iran by Islamic revolutionaries has created a very dangerous situation, arousing alarm among Jews everywhere, according to the chairman of the World Zionist Organization and head of the Jewish Agency, speaking here.

title: Concert: Organ Pairs By Dessoff
description: The Dessoff Choirs and Anthony Newman combined for an unusual, most effective concert Friday night at Alice Tully Hall. The idea was to pair a solo organ piece Dy Mr. Newman with a complementary choral work, accompanied by him with a greater or lesser freedom of line.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: Morocco's intervention in the Western Sahara could soon widen into war with Algeria. That prospect is aggravated by the Carter Administration's proposal nearly to double arms sales to Morocco, from $55 million in fiscal 1979 to $105 million in 1980.

title: Massachusetts Governor Backs Plan to Curb Taxes
description: BOSTON, May 12  Gov. Edward J. King has given up his fight for an absolute freeze on local property tax increases and announced instead that he will sign a 4 percent tax cap plan substituted by the State Legislature.

title: INVESTING
description: Salomon Brothers tracks the yields of a range of investments from Chinese ceramics to diamonds to paintings for its institutional clients.

title: Radio
description: 77:30 A.M., WBLS: Tenant Survival Program.

title: 4 NEW LAWS AFFECT SMALLCLAIMS COURT
description: ALBANY, May 11  Aggrieved consumers should have an easier time taking action in the state's smallclaims courts under four bills signed into law by Governor Carey this week.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: If the sight of a deer bounding off the trail or the distant throbbing of a ruffed grouse drumming in the deep woods appeals to you, and if, above all, you crave solitude when angling for trout, New Hampshire's remote pond system may be for you.

title: Parsons on Himself
description: In 1970 Talcott Parsons wrote an essay called On Building Social System Theory: A Personal History. Some excerpts: Two related images of my role in American social science have emerged. One is that  largely, I presume, by contrast with solid empirical research contributors  I have been held to be primarily a talented and stimulating essayist, writing on a variety of topics but without any genuine continuity or solidity of any kindone might suggest an esoterically academic kind of journalist. The second is the attribution to me of a kind of schizophrenic dual professional personality  on the one hand this kind of journalism, on the other hand a wholly unrealistic abstract kind of formalized theorizing, with the strong implication if not assertion that the two personalities had nothing substantive to do with each other....

title: Fear of Gasoline Shortage Causing Changes in Vacation Travel Plans
description: The summer travel plans of millions of American motorists are being thrown into turmoil by growing uncertainties over the availability of gasoline. Fears of shortages and service station shutdowns are also clouding prospects for the nation's $100billionayear vacation and travel industry.

title: Speaking Personally: A Child Dies
description: RUMMAGING through my files during spring cleaning, I find a few folders of memorabilia from my pediatrics internship in Connecticut. A Kodacolor photograph slips out. A child I will call Bobby Gammer, 4 years old, sits in front of the family Christmas tree, hands loosely clasped around a fluffy white blanket. He beams at me with bright brown eyes, full dimpled cheeks and an inviting curl at the edges of his lips. His shiny brown hair is trimmed with bangs lying neatly over his forehead. In his flowered shirt, check ered pants and navy blue vest, he is decked out as lustrously as the tree behind him.

title: Joe Louis Is 65 Today And Not a Forgotten Hero
description: JOE LOUIS is 65 years old today and there is going to be a party at his home in Las Vegas, Nev., for 100 friends. There will b champagne and birthday cake, ham and chicken, and Frank Sinatra ham probably be there. Martha Louis said she hoped the weather would be nice so she can move some of the furniture outside for her guests.

title: Pamela Smith, Teacher, Wed
description: In Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston yesterday afternoon, Pamela Macy Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Procter Smith Jr. of Montclair, N.J., and West Chop, Mass., became the bride of John Biddle Brock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Brock of Oyster Bay. L.I., and Annisquam, Mass:The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ed.. ward Oehler Miller.

title: Lake Placid: Tickets First, Rooms Later
description: The last time Lake Placid played host to the Winter Olympics  in the longago world of 1932  there were no television cameras to poke their noses at the athletes and send out pictures to people who did not want to shiver in the snow and watch.

title: The Fourth World Wants Help With Its Bootstraps
description: MANILA  It has been 24 years since the phrase, Third World, was coined to identify the countries containing the impoverished majority of the world, years since 77 of those countries, emboldened by the success of the oil exporters embargo, demanded nothing less than the redistribution of wealth and economic power from the rich nations to the poor. This Group of 77 has now grown to nearly 120. But last week, assessing their progress in a speech keynoting the fifth session of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, Philippines President Ferdinand E. Marcos used the word impotent four times.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: SLOUCHING TOWARDS BETHLEHEM and PLAY IT AS IT LAYS. By Joan Didion. (Simon & Schuster/ Touchstone. 2 vols., $3.95 each.) As the time approaches to reassess the legacies of the 1960's, these two works by one of the keenest observers and most talented writers of that decade take on a particular value. Slouching Towards Bethlehem (1968) is collection of magazine pieces that capture the look and feel of such places as New York City, Las Vegas, Hollywood and HaightAshbury. Play It As It Lays (1970), a novel, chronicles the case of Maria, separated from her movie director husband, whose cruise about Tinseltown becomes a microcosm of the society of that time and place, rife with divorce, adultery, ennui and

title: Olympia: Echoes of the Ancient Games
description: When the modern Olympic Games were inaugurated in Athens in 1896, a Greek postman named Spiridon Louis won the world's first marathon race with a time of 2 hours 58 minutes 20 seconds. For his victory photograph, Louis posed in a fierce mustache and the white woolen stockings and skirt of an evzone. Second place was taken by another Greek, Harilaos Vasilakos, who apparently competed in checkered knickers, matching spats, a bow tie and cummerbund. Years later, Louis turned up again at the Olympics as honorary head of the Greek team. He led the athletes in the ceremonial opening parade. If he watched any track events on that occasion, he must have seen another runner better known in the United States: Jesse Owens. That was Berlin, 1936.

title: Mission To Mayo
description: He stench of history is overpowering, Thomas Pakenham has written of Ireland. That stench is still poisoning the wells of good will on that island today. One of the sources of poison is the memory of the suppression of the rebellion of the United Irish

title: Can Battlestar Ride the SciFi Wave?
description: HOLLYWOOD An experienced Universal Studio employee shakes his head in bewilderment: That buck Rogers of ours is bringing in just piles of money. I don't know why  there are good films around that aren't making dime. And the studio is expecting Battlestar Galactica to do as well as `Buck Rogers.

title: CALIFANO SUPPORTED ON ATOMIC ACCIDENT
description: WASHINGTON. May 12  A team of Government scientists has repeated earlier assertions that the nuclear reactor accident at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania has posed only a minimal health risk and can be expected to cause approximately one additional cancer death among the 2,164,000 people living within 50 miles of the reactor.

title: U.S. Gives Ways to Avoid ManjuanaParaquat Danger
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  The State Department has been forced by lawsuit filed by a small organization favoring legalized marijuana to consider how to mitigate the harmful effects of the herbicide paraquat that sometimes contaminates marijuana.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The article Pinball: Nassau's Big Zero [April 8] failed to give proper recognition to the Tax Reduction Action Committee (TRAC) for its efforts in exposing this travesty. It also did not discuss how the county leadership sees fit to raise bath the sales tax and the property tax, in addition to laying off county employees; while this same leadership, since 1977, has ignored the enforcement of a law that would have produced desperately needed revenues. TRAC board members have brought suit to have the county collect these delinquent taxes.

title: The Meter Haters Begin to Rally
description: Seaver Leslie is five feet, 10 and a half inches tall, and hopes to stay that way till he dies. Mr. Leslie, an artist, head of Americans for Customary Weight and Measure, an organization dedicated to preserving this country from the inhumane, imprecise and costly metric system. Yesterday, Mr. Leslie and the likeminded rallied in Central Park for Weight and Measure Festival to celebrate foot and inch, gallon and gill, fathom and furlong.

title: At Arms Length
description: WASHINGTON  Since early last year, they've been saying it couldn't be done as President Carter sent one difficult foreign policy measure after another to Congress. Now, with the new strategic arms limitation treaty, he tackling the most difficult of them all.

title: Finally, Agreement On Treaty and Long Debate Opens
description: The Administration jumped the gun last week on the longawaited SovietAmerican treaty to limit longrange nuclear missiles and bombers, announcing basic agreement before final details were complete. President Carter thereby got a running start in an uphill struggle for public understanding and support and Senate ratification. The vote is expected early next year, extending the lengthy debate over the complicated set of ceilings on landbased and submarine launchers, multiple warheads, lowflying cruise missiles and new missile systems into the 1980 Presidential campaign.

title: Dialectical Comics
description: WHEN it comes to understanding Marx, the problem is where to begin. What is wanted is an introduction that takes Marx seriously, yet refrains from mystification. Unfortunately, this is not easily had.

title: STAMPS
description: The past. the present and the future are being observed philateltally. The past is the 200th running of the venerable and most prestigious of all horse races. the English Derby at Epsom. The present. less significant but immediate. is the second item of United States postal stationery for the year. an embossed stamped envelope (described below). The future is in the commemoratves for the imminent reality of a concept few would have believed would ever come into being European Parliament.

title: How Arbitration And Caps Conflict
description: WHEN the State Legislature enacted the caps law in the summer of 1976, New Jersey became the precursor of a national movement to limit the growth of government spending. Like Proposition 13 in California, the caps law was designed to place rigid controls on the rate of increase in municipal and county budgets, with the principal purpose of stabilizing local property tax rates.

title: Sampling the Life on a Farm Without Getting Calluses
description: It all sounded good. Fresh country air, lush fields with crops growing, lake and land teeming with life  pickerel, perch, bluegills, catfish, ducks, roosters, chickens, rabbits and cows. Sports: swimming, tennis, boating and hiking. And, best of all, the smell of home cooking wafting through the air. My husband and I decided to spend weekend getting back to nature on a resort farm.

title: Pate 4Putt Gives Lead To Watson
description: DALLAS, May 12 (AP)  Tom Watson benefited from Jerry Pate's fourputt collapse on the final green today and took a oneshot lead after 54 holes of the $300,000 Byron Nelson Golf Classic.

title: The World
description: Some enlightened Latin military regimes are making tenuous moves toward political and social reform. Not in El Salvador, where the policy under Gen. Carlos Humberto Romero has been to shoot first, talk rarely.

title: Demme's Newest Film Sets a Recordof Sorts
description: In a business ordinarily fraught with risks, Jonathan Demme has been in the unusual position of being guaranteed that his latest film, Last Embrace, would do better business than the one before, Once Last Embrace  which opened a week ago Friday  had played in theaters across the country for a single weekend, it broke the longevity record established by Mr. Demme's widely praised and amazingly illfated Handle With Care.

title: GasAlcohol Fuel to Go on Sale Tomorrow
description: Gasohol is coming East. The mixture of alcohol and gasoline that has proved popular with motorists in the Middle West will be on sale tomorrow at an independent filling station in Shirley, L.I. And that, apparently is only the beginning.

title: Toxic Waste: Costly Health Hazard
description: TRENTON IN 1977, toxic waste  1,343 barrels of it  was found abandoned in a shed on the docks in Jersey City. The authorities hired the Chemical Control Corporation of Elizabeth to dispose of it.

title: The Life and Death of a Store
description: ASTORE failed in our town and my wife and I were shocked and saddened. The signs in the store's windows announcing bank sale affected us like handwriting on the wall.

title: SignLanguage Use Thrives at Wesleyan
description: MIDDLETOWN AHUSH seems at times to have descended on parts of the Wesleyan University campus. veryone is talking about it in sign language.

title: The Lives Of Women
description: IN the second paragraph of Reinventing Womanhood, Carolyn Heilbrun declares that in setting out to name those strictures not wholly societal or cultural that inhibit women from the full formation of a self she possessed a unique qualification: I felt that, unlike so many of the women I had read or known personally, I had been born a feminist and never wavered from that position. What a remarkable statement! Are special diets and exercises required to give birth to a feminist, as opposed to a socialist or a capitalist? Can a judiciously administered test measure one's Feminist Quotient? I do not mean, of course, Professor Heilbrun continues, that I expressed feminist views in the dreary masculinist years after World War H. But I never denied the pain to myself nor lied about my anger. In which case she is no different from any Dumber of women who became feminists by joining private feelings to a set of political and philosophical principles that have been extant and evolving for  well, let us take Mary Wollstonecraft as a starting pointnearly two centuries. This unsettling practice of draping an oftstated notion or simple observation in the garments of radical originality pervades the book.

title: Camila Sarmiento Wed to Architect
description: Camila Sarmiento, daughter of Dario Sarmiento of Bogot, Colombia, and New York, and the late Flor Acosta de Sarmiento, was married yesterday afternoon to Jrge Alonso Restrepo of Rio de Janeiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jairo Restrepo of Paris. The Rev. James G. Blewett performed the ceremony in St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Carter Is Urged Not to Abandon Standby Plan for Rationing Gas
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, urged President Carter today not to close the door on submitting a new standby gasoline rationing plan, despite the resounding defeat of his first proposal.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Leslie Howard's New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night was unusual for at least two reasons. First, Mr. Howard, a 31yearold pianist from Australia, is not exactly a novice musician, having performed and recorded fairly extensively in England and Europe.

title: May 26 Selected For a 7th Game
description: If a seventh game of the RangersCanadiens Stanley Cup championship series is necessary, it will be played in Montreal Saturday, May 26, at 4 P.M. and be televised by ABCTV (Channel 7 in New York).

title: MOM SILLS AND BUBBLY: TWO LIVES IN TUNE
description: All of us daughters are reflections of our mothers, says Beverly Sills, at breakfast, in her apartment on upper Central Park West. If I'm a carbon copy of my mother, I'm damn lucky! You know, I've been called a cheerful woman. I have a reputation for looking at the very bright side of things. If so, I learned it from her. God will take care of it, my mother taught me. He has bigger shoulders than we do. It's not a religion, it's a philosophy.

title: Car of Tomorrow Runs Well Today
description: THE specifics of the new Xbody cars from General Motors  the Chevrolet Citation, Pontiac Phoenix, Oldsmobile Omega and Buick Skylarkare available almost everywhere these days, thanks to G.M.'s $100 million advertising campaign. But there is one thing that you can't get from the ads, and that is the feel of these family cars of the 1980's.

title: Feds Want A Closer Look At How Cities Keep Books
description: WASHINGTON  Last year, state and local governments sold to the public more than $48 billion in bonds, roughly 10 times the number of issues in the corporate securities market. But while Congress passed strict regulations for the private sector 45 years ago, the municipal securities market continues to underwrite bonds with no effective disclosure standards.

title: Rep. Fenwick: Basics Her Forte
description: WASHINGTON YOU'VE got to concentrate on the basics of living, says Representative Millicent Fenwick, thirdterm Republican from Bernardsville, andplop  another Fenwick bill on sensitive consumer issue lands in the hopper.

title: Folks at Home Stall Gas Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Last Wednesday night, after the Senate had approved President Carter's standby gasoline rationing plan, a high Administration official was chatting with friends at a political dinner. It looked, he said, as Congress would overcome local protests against the gas rationing bill and vote in the national interest.

title: U.S. to Move Against Fishermen Who Kill Porpoises Above Quota
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  Some tuna fishermen are killing more porpoises than quotas allow and the Federal Government says it will move against violators with heavy fines and possible seizures of catches.

title: France's Communists Shifting Back to Orthodoxy
description: PARIS, May 12  The French Communist Party's shift back toward orthodoxy and tightened discipline was confirmed yesterday as debates continued at its 23d party congress at SaintOuen, in the suburban red belt of Paris.

title: How 'swing Senators Cope With Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  On Thursday morning, Senator Joseph R. Biden, Jr. spent three hours in a secure, soundproof room on Capitol Hill listening to a secret briefing from Senate staff members. The subject was one that concerns a lot of people here these days  whether the United States has the ability to monitor a strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: GARDENING
description: MAY belongs to the dogwoods. The beautiful display of this splendid native tree will be with us everywhere for the next few weeks. Itgraces lawns, woodlands, even highways  especially the Merritt and Taconic Parkways. graces lawns, woodlands, even highways  especially the Merritt and Taconic Parkways.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: BILL passed by the State Legislature last week will do more than fix the age of sexual consent at 16. It will make petting between a 15 and a 16yearold fourthdegree crime, and heavy petting between them punishable by 10 years in prison for the 16yearold.

title: WASHINGTON Who's To Blame?
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  Scapegoating is now the biggest game in Washington. Nobody here seems to know how to allocate gas but everybody knows how to allocate blame.

title: Coast Guard Crew Wins
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 12  It was not until the last race of the afternoon that the United States Coast Guard Academy heavyweight crews could win a race, but the wait proved worthwhile today as the varsity crew captured the featured race of the 41st annual Dad Vail Regatta.

title: Editors Choice
description: DUBIN'S LIVES, by Bernard Malamud. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.) Winter brings discontent and temptation to a biographer of D. H. Lawrence in a realistic, risktaking novel.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Theater Opening This Week

title: Buy One, Get One Free: Cars, i.e.
description: ONCE upon a time, you could lick a Popsicle and hope the stick would say Free. Now comes the ultimate giveaway: Buy a MercedesBenz and they'll toss in a fully loaded Dodge.

title: Point, Counterpoint: A Legacy of Horror
description: AS I read an article about Yad Vashem, the holocaust memorial in Israel  the article had been given to me by a Jewish coworker  I felt what I usually feel whenever I read of the Jewish holocaust: sadness, fear, morbid fascination, guilt and a vague sense of dj vu.

title: INTERVIEW For Her, the Lottery Is the Game's Name
description: TRENTON DESPITE the pinch of inflation, the New Jersey Lottery continuing to prosper and grow, according to Gloria A. Decker, executive director of the state's Division of Lottery.

title: Tatiana Brandt Becomes Bride In Delaware
description: Tatiana Brandt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril A. Brandt of Palma de Majorca, Algiers and San Francisco, was married to Gerret van Sweringen Copeland yesterday in Wilmington, Del. The bridegroom is a son of Lammot du Pont Copeland, former president and chairman of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, and Mrs. Copeland of Greenville, Del., and a descendant of Eleuthre Irne du Pont, founder of Du Pont. The Rev. Jerry D. Rassias performed the ceremony in Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church.

title: When Home Values Don't Go Up
description: CORAM GREENBROOK, as name suggests, appears to be an idyllic community. It is seven years old and has approximately 150 contemporarystyle homes, all set on generous plots. Its streets are broad and winding, and the woodlands surrounding it add a bucolic touch. There is even a swimming poolclubhouse complex run by a homeowners association, where club membership costs just $60 a year.

title: Koosman Beats Indians for No. 6
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 12 (AP)  Glenn Adams slugged a threerun home run and unbeaten Jerry Koosman won his sixth game of the year today as': the Minnesota Twins downed the Cleveland Indians, 40, for their fifth straight victory.

title: PARKING RULES
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations will be suspended throughout the city today and in all boroughs except Brooklyn tomorrow. They will be in effect in Brooklyn then so that trash accumulated during the tugboat strike can be removed. The rules will later be applied to the other boroughs, in rotation.

title: Nancy Armstrong And James F. Bolt Of Xerox to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wakefield Armstrong of Stamford, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Lee Armstrong, to James Francis Bolt, son of Mr. and Mrs. James N. Bolt of Herndon, Va. A September wedding is planned.

title: Uncovering 1792 Behind the Plaster In Old State House
description: HARTFORD

title: HOME CLINIC Important Steps for Ladder Safety
description: THIS is the time of year when many homeowners tackle such jobs as painting the outside of their homes, repairing gutters or doing similar outdoor chores that call for the use of a tall extension ladder.

title: A Texaco Dealer Tries Living With Cutbacks
description: BAYVILLE, L.I.  It's not even the middle of the month and I've already used up nearly half my gasoline allocation for May, said Eddie Burke, who as operator of the corner Texaco station here has, at one time or another, pumped gas into the car of nearly every resident of this small village on the north shore of Lone Island.

title: TV MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: Reynolds on Guidry: Saving Yanks a Career Shortener
description: WHEN I first heard about Ron Guidry volunteering to get out of the starting rotadon and go into the bull pen I could appreciate it from a personal standpoint. Basically, he felt the same way I felt when I did the same thing. It was also a little bit differeM from the image we have of the average ballplayer today. With all the problems you read about athletes, you hear people say, Boy, they don't know how lucky they are.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the folfowing events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.

title: Munich Atom Laboratory Burns
description: GARCHING, West Germany, May 12 (AP)  A fire swept a nuclear research laboratory outside Munich early today, but firemen prevented the flames from reaching radioactive materials and a nearby experimental reactor, authorities said.

title: DINING OUT Tasty Food If You Have the Time
description: TUCKED alongside the railroad station Wantagh is Hakone, a small, new Japanese restaurant. The cheerful, carved and paneled wood interior evokes an almost rustic feeling. The food is good and authentically Japanese. The menu also goes more than halfway to accommodate healthfood enthusiasts with brown rice, herb teas and fresh fruit juices.

title: Tenants Oppose Economic Mix, Study Finds
description: A Federal study has concluded that tenants in governmentsubsidized housing are happier without the integration of different social, economic and cultural groups, and it has recommended that such integration be avoided.

title: A Conspiracy to Block the Perfect Roach Killer?
description: Nobody knows whether cockroaches have any notion of Armageddon, but a California inventorentrepreneur believes that the time for a battle to the last bug is at hand. There's no question  you can eliminate roaches, says Alan Brite, holder of 15 patents and owner of the tiny Copper Brite Corporation in Los Angeles, for 30 years the producer of a household cleaner. This is the end of the roach.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The name of the game in architecture right now Can You Top This? And the master of the game, hands and pediments down, is Philip Johnson, whose firm, Johnson /Burgee, has produced the vastly overpublicized, unceasingly controversial, Chippendaletopped AT&T Building for New York, a design that raises passions equally in learned symposia and on the cocktail circuit. The appearance of that gargantuan broken pediment with its buckeye bow to the Baroque in a world of flattopped, nononsense skyscrapers succeeded in doing what mere masterpieces have failed to pull off: It put architecture on the front pages of newspapers and on the cover of Time  a neat trick for a building that is still a hole in the ground.

title: Dance: The Nutcracker
description: American Ballet Theater must believe that Christmas can come at any time, for on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House it offered its first Nutcracker of the season.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in The Times last Sunday incorrectly identified the designer of the Uncle Sam Atrium in Troy, N.Y. The designer and architect is Elbasani, Logan, Severin & Freeman of New York.

title: A Switch to Mystery
description: WHY would a television writer, a veteran of Sid Caesar's classic. Your Show of Shows comedy series, take the plunge into the chilling world of murder mysteries? I wanted to write something but felt I had no public, said Lucille Callen, who is the author of a new mystery, Introducing C. B. Greenfield, about the sleuthing skills of Maggie Rome,a reporter for a suburban newspaper, and her editor, the acerbic C. B. Greenfield.

title: LIBERMAN: STAYING IN VOGUE
description: It's a mistake to consider fashion journalism an art. True art doesn't belong in this medium anymore. I say this to my friends, to writers and photographers: Do what I do in my life! Do what is necessary. Take the pictures, write the articles I need for my magazine, and then use the money you make for your private, creative purposes. Don't put your deepest soul into this kind work!

title: $40 Billion Is Needed For City Restoration, Goldin Says in Report
description: New York City will have to spend $40 billion in the coming decade if it is to rehabilitate its physical plant  roads, bridges, sewers, water mains, schools and other municipal structures  and to make modest capital improvements, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Alvy Singer, the fellow played by Woody Allen in Annie Hall, is depressed by live lobsters and almost everything else you can think of, including the concept of the expanding universe. Alvy is the sort of fellow who dwells on the knowledge that if he just sticks around long enough, Coney Island will be five billion light years from Brighton Beach.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: What started as a little rishin contest of the local Rod and Gun Club a quarter of a century ago attracted 70,000 people from all over the country last year. No longer solely a fishing expedition, the threeweek Windsor Shad Derby now features a float parade, taking off from the Deerfield section of town at 2 P.M. Saturday (Shad Derby Day) and winding up on the green, where arts and crafts, antiques, and more ways to cook shad than you will ever want to know are available.

title: Two Boys, Hidden After Death of Mother, Are Turned Over to Their Divorced Father
description: Two children placed in hiding by members of Brooklyn's Polish community to fulfill the dying wish of their Polishimmigrant mother were found in Flatbush Friday night and returned to their EgyptianAmerican father after a confrontation in a Brooklyn police station. But the case is not closed.

title: Steelworkers Shift Site Of 80 Talk for E.R.A.
description: PITTSBURGH, May 12The United Steelworkers of America has changed the site of its 1980 convention from Las Vegas to Los Angeles because Nevada has not ratified the proposed equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution, the union's president, Lloyd McBride, announced yesterday.

title: Local Governments Cutting Gasoline Use
description: HACKENSACK

title: A Few Nearly Perfect Perennials
description: For me. certain perennials seem indispensable. Six of them particularly form the backbone of my spring garden. They are air hardy. selfsufficient. adaptable and most of all interesting.

title: The Great Race for Olympics Tickets Begins Now
description: Americans who hope to see the summer Olympic Games in Moscow next year are going to have to make tracks to insure themselves a place in the grandstands. Although the games are still more than 14 months away, more than half of the 24,000 places alio: cated for American spectators have already been reserved.

title: Carey Selects Commerce Chief
description: ALBANY, May 12 (UPI)  William D. Bassett Jr., a Republican from Buffalo, was nominated yesterday by Governor Carey as State Commerce Commissioner to replace John S. Dyson if the Senate confirms Mr. Dyson as head of the State Power Authority. The appointment had been expected. Mr. Bassett would remain chairman of the Urban Development Corporation and the Battery Park City Authority. Senate confirmation is required.

title: Homosexual Receives Approval To Take a Male Friend to Prom
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., May 12 (AP) School officials have approved a high school senior's request to take his male friend to a prom this month.

title: Around the N
description: GALVESTON, Tex., May 12 (AP) collapsed oildrilling rig sank below the surface of the Gulf of Mexico, and officials said today that little hope remained for eight missing workmen. ..

title: Rock: Graham Parker at Palladium
description: Graham Parker and the Rumour have had an uneven recording career since they made their first two albums in 1976. In his recent song Mercury Poisoning Mr. Parker blames Mercury, his former record label, for making him the best kept secret in the West, but his third and fourth albums weren't very consistent and his fifth, the recently released Squeezing Out Sparks, also has its ups and downs. But Mr. Parker and his band are enormously talented and invest their music with a withering intensity; they're the sort of artists whose failings one tends to forgive. And at the Palladium on Friday night, they succeeded brilliantly. The show was the sort on which reputations are made.

title: For an Evening, the Victorian Era Reighed
description: As two men in gym shorts and Tshirts jogged toward Central Park along East 91st Street the other evening, they skillfully skirted a trio of women in long gowns and garden hats emerging from a taxi in front of number 7, a Renaissance palazzo known as the Burden Mansion.

title: SADAT SAYS SAUDIS ARE UNLIKELY TO BUY U.S JETS FOR EGYPT
description: MIT ABUL KOM, Egypt, May 12 President Anwar elSadat said today that he no longer expected Saudi Arabia to finance the purchase of 50 American jet fighters for Egypt, and would ask the American people to raise the money for them by public subscription.

title: Roderick P. Thaler And Jane Driscoll Set June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Driscoll Jr. of East Williston, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Driscoll, to Roderick Phillips Thaler. He is a son of Mrs. Vincent O'Gorman of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Dr. Richard Winston Thaler.

title: GARDENING
description: Time was when a typical rooftop garden consisted of a scattering of potted plants. Today, however, plantings on high are apt to be as elaborate as anything earthbound. These bowers in the sky look so enticing one would think it's easy being green up there. Actually it's not, but careful planning, installation and maintenance can work horticultural wonders.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: It is occasionally nice to have a numismatic auction in this city that someone can attend with only a $20 bill in theirwallet and still have hopes of being to buy something that is offered. The Johnson & Jensen medal sale at the Sheraton next Sunday is just such an event. A cursory survey of the 610 lots in the catalog, going by the estimates. disclosed more than 200 pieces that might run under $20 each and still leave enough change to take of the carfare home.

title: States to Get $253 Million
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  A record $253 million is expected to be allocated to 43 states and Puerto Rico as their estimated share of Federal collections from timber sales and other fees charged users of national forests, according to the Agriculture Department. The estimate is for the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30.

title: Crash and Rain Delay Indy 500 Time Trials
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 12  A 5 hour rain delay and Danny Ongais's crash in the fourth turn during a practice session today wiped out the first day of time trials for the Indianapolis 500. Since no cars were able to make a qualifying attempt, the pole position will be decided tomorrow during six hours of time trials.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Plenty of hardnosed cold warriors have been moaning about the nation's failure of will in permitting the fall of Saigon and the ouster of the Shah. Tightfisted capitalists like to consider it another failure of will that the Federal budget has not been balanced and their taxes reduced.

title: A Critical Congressional Study
description: The Arts Endowment was strongly criticized in a House of Representatives investigative report released at appropriation hearings earlier this month. The report attacked the endowment as so deficient in its management policy and practices that it fails to meet its legislative mandate.

title: Mental Checkups By Family
description: FAMILY mentalhealth checkups may become as common as medical health checkups if an unusual experiment in community education at New Rochelle's Center for Family Learning gains acceptance..

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: I'd never even read a book before this one, said Sparky Lyle, in a fairly serious (for him) tone, stroking his blond gunslinger mustache, and I probably never will again. I just can't sit still that long.

title: 2 Nonpresciption Aids For Dieting Approved By Government Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  A panel of experts retained by the Government has concluded that two ingredients used in several commonly available nonprescription diet aids actually do help people lose weight.

title: Ice Dance of the Dinosaurs
description: MONTREAL, May 12  They're not as tall as most guards in the National Basketball Association but in hockey, they're huge. And for goaltenders, they're dinosaurs, as Ken Dryden of the Montreal Canadiens described himself and John Davidson of the New York Rangers while awaitine tomorrow's opener of the

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: One of the characteristics of these troubled times is a widespread distrust of Government officials. I'm not thinking so much of the fact that public opinion polls show Congressmen to be at about the bottom of the list when it comes to peoples feelings of trust.

title: Jeffrey Walkowiak Weds Virginia Burnham
description: Virginia Livingston Burnham, daughter of Virginia Schroeder Burnham of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Douglass Oswald Burnham of Southbury, Conn., was married in Greenwich yesterday to Jeffrey Louis Walkowiak, son of Mrs. Robert P. Kollman of Sherman, Conn., and Louis C. Walkowiak of North Grosvenordale, Conn.

title: A Novel of Gnostic Doctrine
description: HAROLD BLOOM is the William C. DeVane Professor of the Humanities at Yale. He is also one of the most controversial literary critics, the proponent of a literary theory that, if it were established, would enforce an entirely new concept of literary history. Author of several mutually sustaining books in the theory and practice of criticism, he has now written a work of fiction, a Gnostic fantasy.

title: THE KIDNAPPING OF CHRISTINA LATTIMORE
description: It was inevitable that the Patricia Hearst story would find fictional form. The Kidnapping of Christina Lattimore is an early example. The scene is shifted to Texas, but the trap

title: Spurs and Suns on Verge of Making Title Playoffs AllSouthwest
description: Several years ago, basketball was something the people in the Southwest tolerated while waiting for the college football season to start. But now, while it may not thrill those National Basketball Association people who worry about television ratings, the San Antonio Spurs and the Phoenix Suns are a step away from meeting for the league championship.

title: Cassidy Wins in Return
description: COMMACK, L.I., May 12  Bobby Cassidy, 176, of Levittown made a successful comeback after a 14month layoff, winning a unanimous 10round decision Friday night from John Capobianco, 1751/2, of Huntington in the feature lightheavyweight bout at Long Island Arena before a crowd of 2,276.

title: Accomplished New Versions of Webern
description: Columbia Records survey of the complete works of Anton Webern under Pierre Boulez's direction has been a long time aborning. The project began over a decade ago in London and was first announced for release some five years back. but only this month have the disks found their way into the shops.
