Like Columbia's previous allWebern set. recorded in Los Angeles between 1954 and 1956 by Robert Craft. the canonical 31 works with opus numbers are arranged in chronological sequence: the eighth side is filled out by the composer's orchestral version of the Op. 5 pieces for string quartet. his instrumentation of Bach's Ricercare from The Musical Offering and several Schubert dances, the latter conducted by Webern himself in a 1932 recording with the Frankfurt Radio Orchestra. Since the album is labeled Volume 1. clearly a second set is planned to include his youthful preOpus 1 music and various items discovered over the past 25 years.

title: ART
description: GARDEN CITY THERE are artists who will travel great distances to find a subject matter that will satisfy their artistic visions. There are those who will painfully probe the outer reaches of their minds, seeking imagery for their expressions. And then there are those who are simply content to paint whatever is near them  their surroundings, whether they be a neighboring landscape, familiar faces or familiar rooms.

title: IMPROVISING ON THE ROOF
description: A penthouse garden is a luxury only a few can enjoy. However, every building, rich or poor, has a roof and many are suitable for gardening. With a little ingenuity, an intrepid rooftop gardener can improvise such amenities as paving, parapets, a water source and drains.

title: DINING OUT
description: FIVE miles south of the Westchester border sits Amerigo's, one of the finest Italian restaurant in the metropolitan area. Begun as a pizzeria 90 years ago, it evolved into a fullscale restaurant and today stands as a testament to high quality and culinary consistency offered up by Amerigo and Millie Coppola.

title: End of the Old South
description: SHE claimed to have won all the admiration, felt all the glorified sensations, of a South belle, while working with the poor of R mond and becoming a Fabian Socialist. Ellen G gow, daughter of a genteel mother and a dour Sco Presbyterian ironworks official, embodied the cl of types. Her heritage made it perhaps inevitable she would experience the pulls of tradition and inn tion as pervasive personal ambivalences.

title: Westchester Communities Want a Better Tax and Aid Break
description: WHITE PLAINS  A secessionist movement afoot in Westchester County. The war is civil, far, but state and Federal officials fear that it could have widespread fiscal and political repercussions.

title: A Ranger Fan's Nightmare Is Also His Dream Come True
description: THERE is this memory that haunts me. I see the Rangers in the old Madison Square Garden playing the Canadiens in the 1967 Stanley Cup playoffs. The home team has rallied to send the game into overtime.

title: Vasquez Outpoints Pena In Bout at Felt Forum
description: Davey Vasquez scored a unanimous decision over Jose Pena Friday night in the featured 10rounder of a Felt Forum boxing card.

title: Many Hispanic Leaders, Disillusioned With Koch Policies, Seek New Paths to Progress
description: Shortly after the election of Mayor Koch, a group of Puerto Ricans  businessmen, community activists and political infighters  came together in a committee formed with the blessing and supnort of Deoutv Mayor Herman Bodin.

title: Retired Priest Sues Firefighters For Failing to Respond to Blaze
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio, May 12 (AP) $600,000 lawsuit has been filed agaMst the city of Mansfield and local firefighters by a retired Roman Catholic priest whose home was destroyed in a firefighters' strike last year.

title: South Africa Measure To Curb Press Reports Of Alleged Corruption
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 12  The South African Government is preparing legislation that would make it an offense for newspapers to publish allegations of corruption or other irregularities in government activities before the allegations have been officially investigated and reported to Parliament.

title: SPORTS
description: DARIEN SPRING has come late to Connecticut. The dogwoods are behind schedule. Only recently have trees sprouted their normal clusters of leaves. The nights are too cool yet for beach parties. The water in the swimming pools is icecold. Most bikinis remain in the dresser drawer.

title: Here At Last: New Help With Old Problems
description: Now, every Thursday, The New York Times gives you help with most of life's little problems and a lot of the big ones, too, in The Home Section, a special pullout section added to your copy of Thursday's Times.

title: ANTIQUES
description: WOODBRIDGE FOR more than 15 years, John and Elizabeth Harrington have collected furniture and household accessories of the American Federal period, furnishing their large early 19thcentury house on Amity Road with tables, chairs, case pieces and paintings dating from the 1790's through the 1820's. This weekend, however, the Harringtons will begin to sell off that carefully accumulated collection, taking the second important step toward making a dramatic change in the style of house in which they will live and the kind of antiques with which their new home will be furnished.

title: Shell Juggles Molecules At Its Louisiana Plant
description: NORCO, La.  There's a certain misleading predictability about much of what goes on at the Shell Oil Company's sprawling Norco Refinery here in the swampandbayou country 25 miles west of New Orleans, a prime gasolineproducing facility for the nation's No. 1 gasoline retailer.

title: Skull Dug Up at Alamo Is Linked to 1836 Battle
description: SAN ANTONIO, May 12 (UPI)  Archeologists say that skull bones dug up near the Alamo apparently belonged to a man who died in the famous battle between the mission's defenders and Santa Anna's Mexican Army in 1836.

title: Tragic Life, Majestic Art
description: The story of the short, tragic life and majestic accomplishment of Vincent van Gogh has been told many times and Is told once again by the Dutch art historian Evert van Uitert in his introduction to VAN GOGH DRAWINGS (Overlook Press, $12.95), which reproduces 100 drawings  from a stiff imitation of Millet at the start, through the vigorous Winter Garden of 1884 and such masterpieces as The Potato Eaters a year later, to the startling swirls and whorls the final work. The price of this six-by-eight-inch book is low, perhaps because it was printed in Yugoslavia; but some of the images are quite muddy.

title: Alternatives Eyed if Gas Takes a Holiday
description: JOHN V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, says he plans to be on hand tomorrow morning when the first sale of gasohol is made on the Island. Like other motorists, he says he would like to try some out in his car.

title: Mary Loeb Is Married to Michael C. Ludlum
description: Mary Melissa Loeb, daughter of Lillian Slocum Whitman of Holmes Beach, Fla., and C. Edward Loeb of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Carland Ludlum, son of Mrs. Herbert B. Ludlum Jr. of Fitzwilliam, N.H., and the late Mr. Ludlum. The Rev. Oscar A. Mockridge 3d perforind the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Montclair, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev. Herbert A. Donovan Jr.

title: On Language Salutations
description: Today is the last day you can get away with To Whom It May Concern. In a recent piece grumbling about whom, I asked readers (who may have been concerned) to suggest alternatives to that stilted salutation, and present herewith a bunch.

title: Opera: Abduction by Bronx Troupe
description: Mozart's The Abduction From the Seraglio is one of those paradoxical operas that requires the vocal resources of a major opera company to meet the work's technical requirements, but for dramatic and esthetic reasons looks a lot better on a small stage. A minuscule comic opera plot is swathed, not to say smothered, in gorgeous music that is usually horrendously difficult. Perhaps that is the reason more performances of it turn up at the hands of enterprising small companies than in the big houses.

title: Poll Indicates Americans Oppose Pretoria's Policy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 12 Most Americans condemn South Africa's racial system but would oppose any United States military involvement there, according to an opinion poll prepared by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and conducted by the Response Analysis Corporation of Princeton, N.J.

title: Clues in Westchester Slayings Are Hunted in Brooklyn
description: New York State and City police, in a steppedup joint effort aimed at solving four murders last week in Bedford Hills, yesterday scoured a Brooklyn neighbor hood where a car abandoned apparently by suspects in the case was recovered Thursday morning.

title: The Long, Rocky Journey From Marsh to Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Pegasus  the posh, new restaurant and betting palace atop the grandstand at the Meadowlands Race Track a world of marble, oak and brass ; of potted palms, $15 steaks, and parimutuel clerks in white shirts and ties; of the distant lights of Manhattan's skyline and the George Washington Bridge.

title: NEW LANDSC IN ART
description: In the darkness on top of the volcano, wrapped in a sleeping bag against the desert cold, I am watching the oncoming night draw in around me. The stars seem to bend down from the zenith and tuck themselves in behind the crater's lip. Beyond its black silhouette, I can hear mountain lions coughing on their hunting rounds. The nearest human being is a ranch hand who lives in a shack on the desert floor 1,000 feet below me, just at the limits of the blast of an automobile horn. My own voice,it seems to me, would probably float in the air like the lions coughs, soft and scarcely audible. I turn a shoulder to the wind and wait for dawn.

title: Deaths
description: FRANKELCharles and Helen. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, May 15, at 4:33 PM, at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. A reception for family and friends will follow the service. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Columbia University. The National Humanities Center, or the International Council on the Future of the University.

title: Thrillers and Killers
description: Reflecting on these three freshly minted volumes, it struck me that for all us addicts of the Novel of International Intrigue, Aug. 22, 1485, is a date to remember.

title: Carter Becomes an Issue In the Kentucky Primary
description: MADISONVILLE, Ky., May 12 President Carter's Administration has suddenly become a major issue in a bitterly contested sixway Democratic prim Governor.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, MAY 13, 1979

title: In Logical Next Step, '83 Class at Haverford Will Be Partly Female
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., May 12  Haverford College ended years of internal debate today over the admission of women by announcing that next fall the freshman class would be open to women for the first time.

title: Sylvan Armonk Troubled Over Contaminated Wells
description: ARMONK PEOPLE in this little hamlet refer to it as a community of quality. It is a neat little shopping village with historic buildings and churches and a park with resident geese and an attractive gazebo, and it is set in a hilly countryside sprinkled with expensive singlefamily homes.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: Today and every day through May 24, the ReevesReed Arboretum, 165 Hobart Avenue, Summit, has a host of things going on as part of its annual fundraising benefit. Utilizing the combined funds of residents and the city of Summit, the 12acre, 19thcentury estate was acquired in 1974 as a nonprofit center for varied garden, lecture and educational projects.

title: FOOD
description: EAST MORICHES MOTORISTS on the Montauk Highway in East Moriches may notice a white frame house with a large green sign on the lawn that announces: Danish Pastry Shop. If a smaller sign near the door says Open, it pays to stop in. Otherwise, make a note to return. near the door says Open, it pays to stop in. Otherwise, make a note to return.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: First, the nice news. Lanford Wilson's Talley's Folly is a lovely play, and one of the things it does most tellingly as it begins its intermissionless performance at the Circle Repertory's home in Sheridan Square is to mock the stage  that home of easy illusion  on which it is being performed. Judd Hirsch. the bearded, challenging, wry and wise man of the piece, saunters into view from backstage while the house lights are still full up. Grinning at us conspiratorially, he lounges against the stage apron and begins to expose, one by one, all the pretty scenic appurtenances that are supposed to make us believe in a starcrossed but nonetheless moonstruck romance. The piece is to be a sort of waltz, he explains, a series of halfevasive, halfclinging movements between two people trying to find each other, and. all of the louvers and the latticework and the gewgaws that make silver streaks of the eaves overhead have been planned to give the dance an aura of cheery plausibility. He goes on. That rotating gizmo beneath the pier at upstage center is the device that makes the water sparkle. The sunset glow in which the troubled, yearning meeting begins comes from the lightboard, of course. And if nightfall is to have its proper faraway sounds, then a soundeffects man  such a handy chap  will provide barking dogs in the background, on cue.

title: City Ballet: New Odette In 'swan
description: As every loyal dance fan knows every spring, the only way to keep up with developments is to zoom from theater to theater. It is not a practice to be recommended  except to joggers  but Friday night it was possible in this way to catch up with some of busy season's highlights.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Labor Election Loss Looking Bigger
description: LONDON, May 12  Sir Harold Wilson used to say that he wanted to do for the Labor Party what Franklin Roosevelt did for the Democratic Party. He wanted to make it the natural party of government.

title: Music Notes: A New ThreeAct Opera By P.D.Q. Bach?
description: Things are getting worse. First there was The Stoned Guest' (a halfact opera). Then came Hansel & Gretel & Ted & Alice (an opera in one unnatural act). Now we are told that there is a threeact opera by the same composer, the infamous P.D.Q. Bach, waiting to be found, and that it will be staged by no less an organization than the Opera Company of Philadelphia in the fall of 1981.

title: The Exotic Beauty Of Summer Bulbs
description: NO MATTER what your garden scheme is, you can count on tender, summerblooming bulbs to provide additional beauty and interest.

title: Realty News Deal Honored as Most Ingenious
description: For negotiating the sale of the building at 1166 Avenue of the Americas, four brokers have won an award for the most ingenious realestate deal of 1978 in the annual competition sponsored by the Real Estate Board of New York.

title: San Marino Aide Coming to U.S.
description: SAN MARINO, May 12 (AP)  The Foreign Secretary of the Republic of San Marino, Giordano Bruno Reffi, begins an official visit to the United States today, officials said. He is scheduled to meet with American officials and plans to visit the United Nations. San Marino, which has 19,000 inhabitants, is in central Italy.

title: Talcott Parsons: Nobody's Theories Were Bigger
description: Talcott Parsons, who died last week in Munich at age 76, was the dominant figure in American sociology  if not worldwide  from the mid1940's to the mid1970's, when he retired from Harvard, where he had taught throughout his academic career.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THIS is the time of year when many homeowners tackle such jobs as painting the outside of their homes, repairing gutters or doing similar outdoor chores that call for the use of a tall extension lad der.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The controversy over nuclear energy plants has not touched on one important question: labor disputes. Our social development has reached the point where the manufacturing of anything which is dangerous or potentially dangerous is prohibited by law. Products ranging from automobiles to baby's nightwear are subject to thorough examination and possible recall. In addition to these safeguards, monopolistic practices are subject to heavy fines and sometimes prison sentences.

title: Foster Mother's Day
description: For many women, the second Sunday in May is inescapably sad. These are the millions of mothers whose lives have been touched by the nation's system of foster care. Some are parents with serious personal problems whose children have been placed in other homes or foster care institutions. Some love their children but are too poor to care for them. Some are foster parents who want permanently to adopt children already in their homes temporarily but cannot afford to lose the benefits available only for foster care.

title: Konrad Michelsen Weds Ann Fairlie
description: The marriage of Ann Gelston Fairlie, promotion art director for The New Yorker magazine, to Konrad M. Michelsen, a lawyer with the New York firm of Crowell, Rouse & Varian, took place in Montclair, N.J., yesterday. The Rev. Herbert H. Thompson, rector of Grace Episcopal Church in Jamaica, Queens, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Fairlie, parents of the bride. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rolf T. Michelsen of Heliport, L.I.

title: Martha R. Vianney Wed To Gary Robert Beale
description: Martha Rich Vianney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmond Rich Vianney of Milford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Gary Robert Beale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sumner Beale of. Stratford, Conn.

title: Air Force Reviving Tunnel Plan for the MX Missile
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  The Defense Department, under pressure to come up with a workable plan for basing a new mobile intercontinental missile, has revived the idea of deploying the weapons in tunnels, officials say.

title: Wine
description: Having a bad case of the sniffles is not unusual for J. Michael Broadbent. As one of 60 Masters of Wine  a title awarded very sparingly by the British wine trade  he needs his nose in good working condition. Mr. Broadbent is probably the world's foremost discoverer of fine old wines.

title: Legerdemain Time
description: HARTFORD IT is budget surplus time again, that season at the end of the fiscal year and the legislative session when the state, like a family trying to reconcile the checkbook, figures out whether it has any money left, and if so, where to spend it. Legislators and lobbyists are playing the game intensely again this year, knowing that the tight spending plan just passed by the General Assembly may mean that this may be the last round of such activity for several years to come.

title: Deaths
description: TEITELBAUM  Lottie, devoted mother of Judith Butler, and Mitchell. loving grandmother d Scott and Melissa. Services today. 10:45 AM. at The Colonial Chapels of I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich St.. Hemostead, L.I.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: Three of Thornton Wilder's early short plays in which the seeds of Skin of Our Teeth and Our Town germinated are to be presented this week by the theater department of the State University College at Purchase. Often read but seldom performed, The Happy Journey to Trenton and Camden, The Long Christmas Dinner and Pullman Car Hiawatha, first published in 1931, may be seen today at 3 P.M. and Tuesday through Saturday at 8 in the chamber theater setting of the Lab Theater, Room 0013, Library. Admission is $3.

title: State Begins Spraying Trees on Long Island in an Attack on the Pesky, LeafChewing Tent Caterpillars
description: For the last few years, one of the few unpleasant aspects of spring's arrival on Long Island has been the encroachment of a persistent pest known as the tent caterpillar.

title: DINING OUT
description: MYSTIC PRIME tourist attractions are not often gourmet gathering grounds. Mystic Seaport is no exception. But if you are not too exacting, you can dine conveniently and in pleasant period surroundings at the Seamen's Inne, right next to the entrance to Mystic Seaport.

title: LETTERS
description: The Dollar

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: DR. T. ALEXANDER POND, who will be leaving the office of acting president of the State University at Stony brook on June 30 to return to his duties as professor of physics  a post he has held for the last 17 years  says he also looks forward to the chance of serving as a commissioner on the Tristate Regional Planning Commission.

title: David Ferguson Fianc of Nancy Ferguson
description: The engagement of Nancy Hopkins Ferguson to David William Ferguson, son of Dr. and Mrs. George W. Ferguson of Middletown, R.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Ferguson of Winnetka, Ill. A July 28 wedding is planned. The families are not related.

title: Taking a Tax by the Horns
description: HARTFORD NOT many officeholders in Connecticut have built a successful political career by advocating a state income tax, but several evenings ago a Republican Representative from an affluent town in Fairfield County stood in the House and proposed a state income tax to pay forthe new schoolfinancing legislation.

title: Rangers Believe Defense Will Be the Key
description: MONTREAL, May 12  The secret is out: the Montreal Canadiens fear the Rangers. Another secret: the defending Stanley Cup hockey champions would have rather faced the Islanders in the fourofsevengame final round, which opens at 4 P.M. tomorrow at the Forum.

title: Big Auction To Measure Art Market
description: The strongest test of the contempomry att market in five years will take place, in an auction Friday night at Christie's, Manson & Woods, Park Avenue at 59th Street. The sale of 67 selections of postWorld War II art works is expected to bring up to $2.4 million and may well upstage the Robert C. Scull sale of October 1973 that totaled $2.1 million, the world record for contemporary art.

title: Vassar in 20th Edition Of Its Book Fair
description: TWENTY years ago, members of the Westchester Vassar Club became dissatisfied with sell ing maple syrup to raise scholarship funds and decided that books would be a more appropriate commodity for an institution of higher learning. Today, they're about to celebrate two decades in the book business at the 20th annual Vassar Scholarship Book Fair.

description: ROME, May 12  Leading rightwing Christian Democrats have started a political offensive to move the governing party further to the right and impose a hardline antiCommunist policy on reluctant party leaders regardless of the outcome of the June 3 election for Parliament.

title: Look Is Stoned
description: You might get the idea something was wrong at both Look and Rolling Stone magazines.

description: FORKED RIVER

title: Meeting V. S. Naipaul
description: ON our way to Brazil in 1962, we stopped for some time In Trinidad. We did not meet V.S. Naipaul until a few years later, but we were led to his brilliant early novel, A House for Mr. Biswas. So, from the first his genius was clear. It is now 22 years and 14 books since he began, and Naipaul is still in his 40's.

title: Educating the Disabled Is Something Really Special
description: Three years ago, the Stamford, Conn., board of education, along with school districts across the country, began a systematic effort to locate handicapped children who were not being adequately, taught. Among those they turned up were several dropouts with severe social and emotional problems. They ended up in residential placements at a cost of about $10,000 a year, said Edward Friedlander, director of pupil personnel services for the district.

description: The Yankees and California Angels performed at Yankee Stadium yesterday in a constant drizzle that made the footing unsure for the outfielders. The batters took advantage, whacking 27 hits, 12 for extra bases, as the Yankees scored a soggy 65 triumph before a cold and damp crowd of 28,783.

Seldovia, Alaska, has been awarded $500,000 for a water improvement project to help stimulate the expanslop of the fishprocessing industry. In Maine, the city of Rockland will receive $245,000 to help expand an industrial park.

The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas Davis of the Roman Catholic Church of the Ascension in New Milford, N. J., who also married the bride's parents 28 years ago.

description: Cyrus S. Eaton Sr. was an early advocate of a kind of detente, so early in fact that he was widely regarded as hopeless maverick.

Trains also leave Athens three times a day but they take eight or nine hours. Second class on the train costs the same as the bus; first class isabout $13. If you want to drive the 180 Miles to Olympia, a small rental Car will cost from $9 a day. Most rental agencies also offer special weekly rates. Unless you qualify for tourist coupons by bringing your own car into the country, gas is expensiveabout $3.40 a gallon.

title: NATO Views on Arms Pact: Wary Praise to Hostility
description: CASTEAU, Belgium, May 12 Reaction to the strategicarms agreement at gathering of highranking officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization ranged from sharp attack to cautious welcome here this week.

description: RAHWAY MENTION this industrial city of 30,000 people, and one immediately associates it with Rahway State Prison, which is actually in adjoining Woodbridge.

title: E.P.A. Warns of Radiation Peril to 2,000 in Florida
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  More than 2,000 people in central Florida are exposed to potentially hazardous levels of radiation because they live in houses that were built on reclaimed phosphate mines or land where radium from phosphate is close to the surface, according to calculations of the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Some Plusses in Inflation for Westchester Residents
description: DOES it make cents to live or work in Westchester? In the current atmosphere of rising inflation, the answer is a qualified yes. Qualified because the economic benefits during an inflationary period accrue to those who own homes or apartments. According to the most recent census, 52 percent of the dousing units in Westchester were owneroccupied while 48 percent were renteroccupied.

description: MIAMI, May 12  Betty Cook of Newport Beach, Calif., found a stretch of smooth water to her liking in a sea of sixfoot swells today and went on to win the Bacardi Trophy race for powerboats.

title: Italian Theater Is Molto Vivace
description: ROME Despite strikes, terrorism and political instability, the theater in Italy is not only thriving, it is exhibiting exceptional vigor. In the competition for performing space, garages and warehouses have been converted, cellars cleared, apartments restructured, deconsecrated churches and unused convents occupied, palaces and prisons, museums and markets preempted, even circus tents set up.

description: Fritz Mueller, the United States recordholder for men over 40 years old, and Nina Kuscsik, a veteran of 50 marathons, head a field of more than 800 runners in the 43d Yonkers Marathon today.

title: What They're Saying
description: John Davidson, after the Rangers defeated the Islanders in a Stanley Cup semifinal playoff: This is just an orange soda. But wouldn't it be nice if we could sip a little bit of champagne out of the Stanley Cup?

title: Highways Will Be Noisier in 2000 Without New Rules, Expert Says
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  Highways in the United States will be 50 percent noisier in the year 2000 unless action is taken to curb the racket from cars, trucks and motorcycles, a Government expert says.

title: A NonFord Takes the Wheel
description: The longawaited passage of power has finally begun at the Ford Motor Company.

title: Oliver! Gets Winning Twist
description: GLEN COVE MOST Broadway musical hits become London musical hits. The English theater's native musical successes  those it has  do not as a rule travel well, or at all. They remain fogbound, or an ocean apart.

title: Garden Hits Webgter Ruling
description: The Madison Square Garden Corporation, which owns the Knicks, joined the National Basketball Players' Association yesterday in attacking Telford Taylor's refusal to overturn the compensaton award for Marvin Webster. Larry O'Brien, the National Basketball Associciation commissioner, had awarded the Seattle SuperSonics Lonnie Shelton, $450,000 and the Knicks' firstround draft choice. The players' group and the Knicks had appealed the award.

title: A TankSized Pain
description: WITH the price and shortage of gas seemingly destined to impose a steadily increasing limitation on highway travel, consider the plight of Stephen J. Negri. When he wants to fill er up, he needs more than 200,000 gallons.

title: Hlne Martin Wed in Bermuda
description: The marriage of Helene Martin, a student at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, to Seth McCormick Lynn Jr., a vice president in the employeebenefit investment division of the Bankers Trust Company, took place yesterday at the Anglican Cathedral in Hamilton, Bermuda. Bishop Anselm Genders of Bermuda performed the ceremony.

title: Lyle, Surviving Knockdown, Beats LeDoux in 10 Rounds
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 12 (AP)Ron Lyle kept his boxing career alive as he survived a knockdown and won a split decision from Scott LeDoux in a 10round heavyweight bout today.

title: NEW ORLEANS MAYOR IN ANTICRIME DRIVE
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 12  After months of mounting fear over an increasing number of crime reports, Mayor Ernest N. Morial has declared open season on criminal activity in the city and appointed a citizens committee to study the problem and recommend solutions.

title: Film: 'Cage aux Folles,' Farce in a French Club:The Cast
description: "La Cage aux Folles," the French farce that opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse, is the name of a nightclub in St. Tropez, in the south of France. According to the film, the club is both hugely popular and wildly notorious, though to the rest of us it seems the sort of place that could give St. Tropez a horrid reputation for being square. The Cage aux Folles puts on drag shows that feature thickly set, middle-aged men who, dressed like the chorus of the Princeton Triangle, sing and dance, and then, while taking their bows, flip off their wigs to astound the audience.The movie is based on a play by Jean Poiret that has, I'm told, been very successful in France, but exactly when it was successful is difficult to guess. The nearest Broadway equivalent to the foolish, mechanical sentiment of this farce might be something on the order of "Never too Late," which goes back almost 20 years. "La Cage aux Folles" is naughty in the way of comedies that pretend to be sophisticated but actually serve to reinforce the most popular conventions and most witless stereotypes.It's the story of Renato (Ugo Tognazzi) and Zaza (Michel Serrault), who have been lovers for 20 years and who run the Cage, Renato as the manager and Zaza, whose real name is Albin, as the star of the show. Though Renato is supposed to be the masculine member of the couple, his wrist is only slightly less limp than Zaza's. The difference between them is that Zaza wears more makeup, cries more easily and complains about her lover's indifference.The would-be farcical complications revolve around the announcement of Renato's son, Laurent, that he is getting married and, to make things worse, that his fiance is the daughter of a cabinet minister known for his rectitude, a man who is, among other things, secretary-general of the Union of Moral Order. When Laurent's fiance and her parents arrive in St. Tropez to visit, you pretty well know what the second-act curtain will be, what with Laurent's real mother arriving on the scene unexpectedly, thus exposing one of Zaza's most heartfelt if worst performances.There might well be a real movie here, but it is not the one directed by Edouard Molinaro and written for the screen by Francis Veber, Mr. Molinaro, Marcello Danon and Mr. Poiret. It's not only that they go for gags at the expense of character  and humor  but also that they go for such cheap gags, such as Renato's attempting to show Zaza how to walk like John Wayne. Even worse, though, is the awful sentimentality.The leading performances are very much of the style of the film itself  energetic, broad, much too knowing and superficial. Mr. Tognazzi is a fine actor, but here he looks as ridiculous as his role. Mr. Serrault, who won the French equivalent to our Oscar for his performance, is all too convincing as the hammy, temperamental transvestite. He minces more grossly than ever did Billy De Wolfe, and he lunges at pathos like someone playing right guard for the Rams.

title: Ade1phi Gains in Lacrosse
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 12  Ed Hughes scored four times to lead Adelphi University to a 159 victory over Cortland State in the quarterfinal round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II lacrosse playoffs. Hughes added two assists while a teammate, Rob Engelke, scored twice and had four assists.

title: Elyse F. Klein, a Lawyer, Fiancee of Robert Targ
description: The engagement of Elyse F. Klein to Robert I. Targ has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gustav L. Klein of North Bellmore, L.I. Mr. Targ is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Targ of North Lauderdale, Fla., formerly of White Plains.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE are not too many restaurants where you can heaveto by land or by sea and still be within sight of the Empire State Building. The Chart House, which is situated at a marina on Sandy Hook Bay, is ideal for the landlubber who wants to mingle with the ChrisCrafts or for the yachtsman who wants to step from boat to bar. The restaurant's owner, Mario Stacchini, plans shorten that step soon by expanding onto a dockside terrace, which will double his present seating capacity of 110 and help to accommodate the seasonal influx.

title: Orphanage in Sri Lanka Helps Protect Elephants
description: PINNAWELA, Sri Lanka  Sixmonthold Saman, a favorite of visitors because he is only 3 feet tall, weighs a mere 400 pounds and is playful, came here to the only elephant orphanage in the world because of an accident that not uncommon among his kind.

title: JOURNALS OF CZECHS IN U.S. ARE LAGGING
description: WEST, Tex., May 12  The magazine Hospodar has tried adding a fivepage section in English and introducing Czech language lessons.

title: Miss Davis Plans Wedding in August
description: Announcement has been made by Mr.and Mrs. Edgar Glenn Davis of Indianapolis of the engagement of their daughter, AnneElizabeth Davis, to Marino Rocco Polestra, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francesco Marino Polestra of Lexington, Mass. The wedding is planned for Aug. 18.

title: Robert F. Hill, Miss Schwenk Will Be Wed
description: Kathryn Robertson Schwenk, circulation manager of the North American Precis Syndicate Inc., a publicrelations concern, and Robert Foote Hill, vice president of James C. Edwards & Company, investment counselors, plan to be married June 30.

title: On the Job, Myths Are Reality and Damaging
description: WASHINGTON  Rami Rabby was a good student. When he received his master's degree from the University of Chicago School of Business nine years ago, he graduated high in the upper half of his class. But unlike many of his classmates, including those with poorer grades, Mr. Rabby was not sought out by corporate recruiters. On the contrary, he had to endure 130 interviews over a sixmonth period before he was offered a job; The difficulty was that Mr. Rabby was blind.

title: Elizabeth P. Barringer Married
description: Christ Episcopal Church in Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Elizabeth Pratt Barringer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Minor Barringer of Chadds Ford, Pa., to John Alexander Clark of Cambridge, Mass., son of Alexander Clark of Rockport, Me., and the late Mrs. Clark. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John L. O'Hear.

title: Blumenthal's Higher. Inflation Forecast: Trouble for Guidelines
description: When Robert S. Strauss was the Administration's inflation fighter, he was always careful to caution that results would take time. The same warnings came when Alfred E.Kahn took over. It would be this spring, he said, before wage and price guidelines showed any effect. Last week, Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal pushed the timetable once more into the hazy future: He raised the forecast for inflation this year to at least 8 percent and said it would be summer or early fall before any improvement was seen.

title: Brookhaven Lab: Experts at the Ready
description: UPTON BY 1 P.M. of the day that the name Three Mile Island began to become synonymous with a nuclear accident, a team of health physicists from the Brookhaven National Laboratory here were on the scene in Pennsylvania beginning to determine how much radioactive iodine had leaked out into the air.

title: Amy V. Stancs Married To Daniel R. Brooks Jr.
description: Amy Virginia Stancs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Downey Stancs of Litchfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Daniel Richard Brooks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brooks of Denville, N. J.

title: Paige's 3:56.3 Takes Mile; Maree in Event
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 12  Don Paige is for real in the mile. The latest Villanova middledistance star proved that tonight by winning the Dream Mile in 3 minutes 56.3 seconds, finishing ahead of such worldclass performers as Eamonn Coghlan, Suleiman Nyambul and Sydney Maree.

title: Old Home Day for the Supervisors
description: IF I may have the last word, Edwin Michaelian began, and as was usually the case 10 years ago when he was County Executive. he did. And so ended Monday's 10year reunion of the last Westchester County Board of Supervisors, which was the legislative body of the county from 1703 to 1969.

title: CRIME
description: Noah Gordon's THE JERU- SALEM DIAMOND (Random House, $9.95) has so much going for it that one hates to see the book get weaker and weaker as it goes on. The basic conception is exciting: a famous diamond comes to light. Originally, it had been one of the jewels in the Hebrew Temple of biblical times. It had passed into the hands of a great Saracen. From there it went to the Vatican, only to be stolen. Now it surfaces in Jerusalem, and a New York diamond merchant  a Jew  is. asked by the Vatican to recover it.

title: Spring Festival of All the Arts
description: MADISON S. PECTRUM '79, New Jersey's most ambitious showcase of the arts  it involves more than 1,000 of the state's artists and performers  will be held at Fairleigh Dickinson University here next Saturday and Sunday.

title: 381 Shot Wins at Pimlico
description: BALTIMORE, May 12 (AP)  More Pleasure, the longest shot in a field of seven 3yearolds at 381, posted a threequarterlength victory over Thrice Worthy today in the $25,000 Preakness Prep at Pimlico Race Course.

title: The Nation
description: Turning liabilities into assets is the stuff of which clever accounting is made. As last week's economic events made plain, it can also be the making of good politics.

title: Congress Siphons Gas Rationing Plan
description: For those who believe that the future of America previews in California, the lines of cars waiting for gasoline in Los Angeles seemed a good omen for President Carter's standby rationing plan. Realizing that it could happen out there it might soon happen elsewhere, Congress would give Mr. Carter the authority he wanted.

title: Ribicoff Has Built A Human Legacy
description: SENATOR Abraham A. Ribicoff may be retiring at the end of next year, but he is leaving a legacy that stretches from the Federal judiciary, to Congress, to Federal departments in Washington, to the State Capitol here in Hartford and to the worlds of business and academia.

title: Business Could Try a Touch of Candor
description: Business is spending too much of its time talking about business, with business to business, collectively shaking heads over the growth of Government, the impact of regulations, the scarcity of resources, the stifling affect of Government on our economy, the failures of regulatory agencies, Congress, even the courts. What business must start doing is spend more of its time talking and working with consumers and Government to solve these problems.

title: More From Patti Smith and Lou Reed
description: Thirteer months ago Patti Smith and Lou Reed released albums at the same time on the same label. As a result, they frequently were discussed together. Since then, Mr. Reed has released a new twodisk set. But ever prolific. he has now come ow. with another LP. at precisely the same time as Miss Smith has come forth with her latest album.

title: A Correction
description: Because of editing errors the class membership given for a number of students in last week's article on sex education in the Westport schools was out of date, and one individual identified as a member of the school board is no longer serving in that capacity.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: THE specifics of General Motors new Xbody cars  the Chevy Citation, Pontiac Phoenix, Oldsmobile Omega and Buick Skylark  are available almost everywhere these days, thanks to G.M.'s $100 million advertising campaign. But there is one thing that you can't get from the ads, and that is the feel of these family cars of the 1980's.

title: Cicada on Toast? A Matter of Taste
description: MURRAY HILL NATURE is providing New Jersey with a new food for beefless Wednesday: cicadas. Although not overly attractive to look at, they should be not be overlooked.

title: Handicapped Are Feeling New Strength In Congress
description: The handicapped movement has come of age as political force. Like so many groups that see themselves as disadvantaged minorities, the disabled are demanding larger share in the American dream  more jobs, better education, easier access to a good life.

title: Highway Agency Says Minorities In Jobs Are Up Slightly Over 1977
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  The Federal Highway Administration has reported that 23.3 percent of the jobs in federally aided highway projects last year were held by members of minority races, an increase of less than 1 percent over 1977.

title: Amtrak Offers Riders a Last Chance on Some Trains
description: Since there is a strong possibility that portions the passenger rail network in the United States will be cut back in the fall, Amtrak is calling the forthcoming summer the last chance to see certain parts of America by train. The lastchance stance is based on Secretary of Transportation Brock Adams's plan to discontinue 15 name trains and otherwise reduce the present 28,000 miles of routings to 15,700 miles. Congressional action is expected to salvage some of the proposed cuts, but until Congress acts, a cloud exists over a number of trains.

title: Rightists Demonstrate in Spain
description: MADRID, May 12 (AP)  An estimated 200,000 rightists demonstrated here yesterday calling for Spanish unity. The demonstration against political terrorism was organized by the rightist New Force Party. Basque separatists and a Maoist terrorist group have said they carried out nearly 50 political assassinations in Spain so far this year.

title: Sally Norton Bride Of Howard Turner
description: The marriage of Sally Norton to Howard Ross Turner took place yesterday in Seattle. The Rev. Peter Raible of the University Unitarian Church performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Poth Jr., friends of the couple.

title: King, Head of U.S.A.C., Given Vote of Confidence
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 12 (AP) The United States Auto Club board of directors gave the group's embattled president, Dick King, an overwhelming vote of confidence Friday and then appointed him board chairman. It refused to accept his offer to resign.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: EVANSTON, III.  At noon, W. Michael Kailing usually walks a block along Sherman Avenue to the Smithfield Foods grocery where he buys a sandwich to take back to his desk at the State National Sank of Evanston. Sometimes he walks across Davis Street to Peacock's Dairy Bar or up to Yesterdays, a restaurant near the Northwestern campus.

title: Tree Spraying Begins in Caterpillar Fight
description: FOR the last few years, one of the few unpleasant aspects of spring's arrival on the Island has been the encroachment of a persistent pest known as the tent caterpillar. The insect. which attacks the leaves of cherry trees and other fruit trees, has been most persistent in the groves that line the Island's state parkways, particularly trees in the area of the parkway near Westbury.

title: GARDENING It's Maytime and the Dogwoods Rejoice
description: MAY belongs to the dogwoods. The beautiful display of this splendid native tree will be with us everywhere for the next few weeks. It graces lawns, woodlands, even highways  especially the Merritt and Taconic Parkways.

title: Umpires Closer to Pact
description: The umpires' dispute with major league baseball is creeping closer to a settlement. Negotiators for the two sides met for about four hours yesterday in Princeton, N.J., after having had an amicable daylong session in New York Friday. They plan to meet again tomorrow.

title: Virginia Neaher Bride of Stephen Gardner
description: Virginia Ann Neaher, a daughter of United States District Court Judge and Mrs. Edward R. Neaher of Garden City, L.I., was married in Washington yesterday to Stephen Kahn Gardner, son of Mrs. Irvin B. Gardner of Hillsborough, Calif., and the late Dr. Gardner. The Rev. John C. Harper performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square.

title: Coal Industry Urges U.S. Courts To Ease New StripMining Rules
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  The coal industry is continuing its broad court attack against new Federal regulation of the environmental effects of strip mining by filing lawsuits against the Department of the Interior that bear the names of more than 100 corporate and state plaintiffs.

title: Fireman Held in Colombia Says He May Have Unwittingly Been Part of Smuggling Plot
description: RIOHACHA, Colombia, May 12 William A. Spradley, the Houston fireman who has spent the last 13 days under armed guard in a hospital here, acknowledged for the first time yesterday that he might have been an unwitting participant in a smuggling operation.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40.000 outlets across the United States.

title: Notes: The Continuing Expansion of Amusement Parks
description: As the weather warms up and travelers feel the urge to get out and let go, America's amusement parks, already numbering more than 500, show few signs of losing favor as a travel destination. To the contrary, they are continucing to grow and expand to meet what appears to be an unquenchable desire for thrill rides, nostalgia exhibits, circus acts, freeroaming animali and carnival midways.

title: Poems of Caribbean Wounds
description: DEREK WALCOTT'S superb new collection is described by its publishers as an odyssey, and justly. The book opens with a long narrative about a poor mulatto sailor in flight northward from Trinidad, closes with the title poem, which dramatizes revolutionary movements of mind and feeling in Jamaica, and includes several shorter pieces set in island villages in St. Croix and elsewhere. The only items remote from the Caribbean circuit are a salute to Joseph Brodsky and a memorial to Robert Lowell.

title: CHESS
description: There is a saying that goes. Don't try to win the same game twice to which should be added: Don't even try to draw the same same twice.

title: An Eventful, Even Harrowing, Ocean Voyage in 1862
description: The 747 was not crowded, so I had three seats to myself. And yet, I was annoyed  annoyed that I did not have a proper bed to sleep in, annoyed that the plane had been delayed two hours in leaving London's Heathrow for Washington's Dulles, annoyed that there had been a problem with food services and we had only cold food aboard.

title: The Birth of Lloyd's of New York
description: It was just a year ago that two American insurance brokers tried to win access to the hallowed trading room of Lloyd's of London by buying British brokerages. But Lloyd's, that venerable marketplace begun in 1688 to apportion insurance risks, said no.

title: ART VIEW
description: WASHINGTON Among the painters who played a decisive role shaping the course of French art in the 19th century, Adolphe Monticelli (182486) is today one the least known. In this fact alone there is a large and illuminating irony. For Monticelli was not only a marvelous painter, but was once widely recognized as a figure of considerable distinction. Van Gogh adored his work, and was indeed obsessed with it; it was one of the subjects he quarreled about with Gauguin. Ryder, though he never openly acknowledged it, was likewise deeply indebted to it. And these are not isolated examples of the esteem which Monticelli was held by artists on both sides of the Atlantic. Though caring little for worldly success, he wielded large influence.

title: Carter to Back Bond Curb but Seeks Change Beneficial to New York
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  President Carter has decided to support controversial legislation that would prevent states and cities from issuing taxexempt bonds to raise money for mortgages on singlefamily homes, senior Administration officials say.

title: Fun in FundRaising
description: PRINCETON WHERE else but at an auction could anyone buy in one evening such incongruities as a Boehm sacred cow (in porcelain) recreated from the Tutankhamun treasures, a truckload of wellrotted sheep manure for one's garden, a baseball autographed by Ted Williams, six running feet of new Bantam paperback books or a cake month for six months?

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Exactly how, when, and with what children should be introduced to art is a matter on which no two people agree. Efforts in that direction vary, moreover, from one generation to another. Sometimes the guided tour is all the rage, sometimes the discreet suggestion, sometimes a total liberty. Sometimes (as at the Frick Collection) children are not allowed in museums at all. Sometimes (as in the new museum complex in Paris, called Beaubourg) they are wooed and courted and made to feel important. There's just no telling what may come of this tactic or that; and if someone in the class turns out to be the major painter or the outstanding art historian of the next 50 years, luck has much to do with it.

title: ABomb Tests: Cold War Fears Stifled Doubts
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  When the ranchers of the rugged Nevada mesas and the residents of southern Utah's quiet hamlets first gathered in the predawn darkness to watch man's early experiments with the atom bomb light up the sky, they were not thinking of cancer or birth defects or death.

title: Enduring Party Being Stressed By Caramanlis
description: CHALKIDIKI. Greece, May 7  Political parties in Greece are built around a personality and tend to have a life span equal to the political careers of their founders. But the ruling New Democracy Party moved to break that precedent last weekend at the urging of its creator, Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis.

title: ART
description: PORT WASHINGTON

title: Barbara Hutton Dies on Coast at 66
description: Barbara Hutton, the highly publicized, oftmarried Woolworth heir who spent much of her life searching for a happiness that apparently eluded her, died in Los Angeles Friday of a heart attack. She was 66 years old.

title: Czaravich Captures Withers at Aqueduct
description: That's the wrong cap, said William L. Reynolds, the owner of Czaravich to Jean Cruguet before the Withers Mile at Aqueduct yesterday. It's supposed to be more orange than red.

title: MOTHERS AND DAUGHTERS Taking a New Look at Mom
description: Love alone, or reasonable guilt, might explain our devotion to the ritual of Mother's Day. At the heart of the devotion is the yearning, sentimentality and nostalgia for the oldfashioned and certainly deeply loved Mamma that celebrations of the holiday evoke. But the importance of the day to the national psyche  today is the 65th anniversary  and the idealized image it represents are hard to reconcile with its acutely negative counterpart, first venomously articulated by Philip Wylie 36 years ago in Generation of Vipers. Mom, he wrote, was a middleaged puffin with an eye like a hawk that has just seen a rabbit twitch far below. She is about 25 pounds overweight. ... In a thousand of her, there is not sex appeal enough to budge a hermit 10 paces off a rock ledge. Wylie's book went through 20 editions in its first dozen years. Later, Philip Roth named the culprit Mrs. Portnoy, and many psychoanalysts corroborated the indictments against her. Depending on her misdeed, she could cause threemonth colic, infantile rocking behavior or coprophagia in her child. Later, she might let go too perilously early or hold on too suffocatingly long . Wylie and Roth were far from the first, of course, to dwell on mothers. Men have been writing on the subject for centuries Sophocles, Shakespeare, Freud, Lawrence, among others, adoring or exploring dark facets.

title: ANTIQUES Nyack Street Fair Lures Jerseyans
description: NYACK, N.Y. ON A normal spring Sunday, Nyack, with its picturesque Victorian houses and treelined streets running down to the Hudson, can be a sleepy place. But next Sunday, it will become a bustling market town, with more than 250 merchants lining the streets with outdoor stalls filled with antiques, collectibles and examples of old and new arts and crafts.

title: June Wedding Set By Chase Rodgers
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Eugene Rodgers of Bowmansdale, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Chase Rodgers, to Anthony Hart Harrigan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrigan of Charleston, S.C. A June 16 wedding is planned.

title: Liberal Party Threatening to Censure Moynihan for Supporting Tax Credits for Private School Tuitions
description: In an unusual break between party and public officials, Liberal Party leaders threatened yesterday to censure Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan publicly and deny him endorsement because he again sponsored a tuition taxcredit bill for parents of private school students.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: THE specifics of General Motors new Xbody cars  the Chevy Citation, Pontiac Phoenix, Oldsmobile Omega and Buick Skylark  are available almost everywhere these days, thanks to the General's $100million advertising campaign. But there is one thing that you can't get from the ads, and that is the feel of these family cars of the 1980's.

title: TV VIEW
description: ?? more though artistic recyclings of recent year. Murie?? Spark's The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie has been brought to television Miss Spark's novella first appeared in this country in 1961. Before being published in handcover form it was published in The New Yorker Magazine in 1966. I saw a London West End stage adaptation of the book starring Vanessa Redgrave Miss Brodie arri??d ?? Broadway shortly therafter with Zoe Caldwell in the title role. And in 1968. the movie version won an Oscar for Maggie Smith. For this television production. made last fall. Miss Spark's heroine is being portrayed by Geraldine McEwan and. once again. the character of Jean Brodie provides the opportunity for a memorable performance.

title: The Tumbling Tumbleweed Is One Target
description: LOS ANGELES  Any day now a plane will wing its way from the Soviet Union with a load of odd passengers bound for California: gall flies. California's Department of Transportation has contracted for the insects as mercenaries to do battle with that entity beloved by Western singers, tumbleweed. Tumbleweed, alias Russian thistle, forms itself into big balls that go rolling across the landscape in high winds, disrupting highway traffic and piling up in roadside drifts that cost a lot to remove. A natural enemy of the Russian thistle, a European white moth, has done a lot to quell the weed in warm Southern California but hasn't taken to the cooler Northern California climate. The more adaptable gall fly is believed to be the answer.

title: If Westway Is Dead, It Sure Shows Moveffient
description: It sometimes seems that Westway has been in the works longer than the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, and never more so than now, when New York City's controversial West Side Highway project could be only months away from the end of seven years of planning and in the throes of a critical squaringoff between proponents and opponents.

title: Mailbox: Sports Is Different
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Fund for the HaveNots
description: WASHINGTON  The poor countries who have been demanding their share of the world's wealth are finally getting a Common Fund to help stabilize the commodity prices most of them live by.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Antony Tudor has never been a choreographer to repeat himself. In the distinguished body of works he has created since the 1930's, each ballet (very few persons have seen all simply because they have been performed over the decades on a variety of continents) seems to have had a different structure and approach specifically suited to its subject.

title: Political Action Groups Set '78 Spending Pace
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI)  Committees financed by big business, labor, professionals and conservatives outspent political parties by almost 3 to 1 in the 1978 Congressional elections, the Federal Election Commission says.

title: A Dark Vision
description: FOR sheer abundance of talent there can hardly be a writer alive who surpasses V.S. Naipaul. Whatever we may want in novelist is to be found in his books: an almost Conradian gift for tensing a story, a serious involvement with human issues, a supple English prose, a hardedged wit, a personal vision of things. Best of all, he is a novelist unafraid of using his brains  ne wouold surety jeer at the common American notion that the exercise of mind saps a writer's vital juices. His novels are packed with thought, not as lumps of abstraction but as one fictional element among others, fluid in the stream of narrative.

title: Rally Hails a Ukrainian Dissident
description: Although he is now known as one of the five ,recently freed Soviet dissidents, Valefityn Moroz is, above all, a Ukrainian nationalist. And yesterday, he kissed and shook the hands of scores of UkrainianAmerican men, women and children at rainy rally in his honor in Bryant Park, thanked them for their efforts to free him and urged them not to be afraid of calling yourselves nationalists.

title: If You Go ...
description: ... looking for a working farm to visit, you may obtain a free list of 22 Department of Agriculture offices that supply information on farms in their areas. The list is available by writing to Special Reports Division, Office of Governmental and Public Affairs, Room 460A, United States Department of Agriculture, Washington, D.C. 20250 (2024472505).

title: Exotic Summer Bulbs Add a Touch of Class
description: Instead of filling in voids in the perennial flower border with annuals, why not try the more esoteric tender bulbs for a touch of class? These treasures are not widely planted in American gardens and they should be.

title: Headliners
description: How people dance through the wonderful, blooming springtime world of magazines! Only a week or two ago, some new people took over Esquire and said they would turn it from fortnightly back to a monthly. Now look! Jann Wenner, founder, editor and publisher of Rolling Stone, said last week that he will take over as editor and president of Look and change from a biweekly to a monthly. Robert Gutwillig, who had performed many staff changes during his tenure as editor Look's first eight issues, has himself been performed out position. And the beat goes on ...

title: Salvador's Revolutionary Bloc Growing in Strength
description: SAN SALVADOR, May 12  El Salvador's Popular Revolutionary Bloc, which is occupying the cathedrals and the French and Venezuelan embassies here, seems to be growing in strength as much as a result of Government repression as of the country's widespread poverty and unemployment.

title: The Crown Jewels From the Kremlin
description: When Americans speak of the Kremlin, images of Soviet political power are called to mind. But for over 500 years the Moscow Kremlin  the word means fortress in Russian  served not only as Russia's governmental center but as repository for the czars massive wealth. Now for the first time an exhibition of 100 of the Kremlin museums most precious objects  the Crown jewels  has come to the West and will open Saturday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 12 (AP) Vietnam agreed today to China's call for an exchange of prisoners captured during their frontier war earlier this year.

title: Margery S. Cuyler To Wed on Aug. 23
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis B. Cuyler of Princeton, N.J., and Stockbridge, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Margery Stuyvesant Cuyler, to John Newman Hewson Perkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Newman Perkins of South Bend, Ind. The wedding is planned for Aug. 23.

title: A Big Spender From Frankfurt Named Hoechst (Herkst)
description: It is the world's biggest chemical company, bigger even than Du Pont. Its headquarters are overseas, but it employs 9,000 Americans in 19 states and registers 5900 million in sales here. Despite all that, the company has an identity ptoblem. Few Americans have ever heard of it, and of those who have, many can't pronounce its name.

title: Engagements
description: JACOBSSWART Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Kende announce the engagement of her daughter Judith Lynn Jacobs to Mr. James Melvin Swart of Hadley, N.Y.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Canada's Most Populous Province Is the Key to the May 22 Election
description: TORONTO Out there, said the banker waving his arm across the Ontario skyline, That's where it'll all be decided.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: I favor a policy of zerobased regulation, Charles D. Ferris said last year shortly after becoming chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. Before we continue regulating any service, we must take a hard look at whether market forces can more effectively serve the public interest. The commissioners have now taken that hard look, and last week they seemed ready to recommend that radio stations be freed of most Government controls. A final commission vote is scheduled for later this month.

title: Armonk AT A GLANCE
description: According to the North Castle Town Historian, Richard N. Lander, Armonk was settled in 1722 by a group of Englishmen from Rye. Many early settlers were Quakers from Long Island. A farming community, it was originally called Mile Square, but the name was changed in 1851 to Armonck, a loose derivation of the Algonquin word for the fishing place between the hills. Later it was shortened to Armonk. The hamlet became a center for shoe manufacturing from about 1850 to the 1870'x. Armonk remained a small country village until the postwar suburban expansion brought an influx of population.

title: Where We Stand
description: Two weeks ago thousands of Americans welcomed a number of prominent Soviet dissidents when they arrived here after years of imprisonment and confinement in Russian psychiatric hospitals. To gain the release these dissidents, whose crimes were either that they wanted to leave the U.S.S.R. to go to Israel or that they demanded that their country abide by the Helsinki Agreements, the United States had to exchange two convicted Soviet spies.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: When we read Lucy Dawidowicz's review of The Warsaw Diary of Adam Czerniakow (Feb. 25), we asked ourselves whether she wanted to cast this firsthand account of a catastrophe into instant oblivion. To her, Czerniakow is but a man of modest talentg, an assimilated Jew who played only a minor role in prewar Jewish life, and his diary is neither history nor literature  its meager text is hardly even readable. What a cavalier dismissal of the most important diary of the holocaust! What a paltry appraisal of its invaluable contents!

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE Banking Homogenization
description: WASHINGTON  When Sears, Roebuck & Company, the world's largest retailer, announced in February a plan to offer its 26million credit card holders, through direct mail, up to $500 million of 2to10year notes in $1,000denominations, banks and thrift institutions shuddered. Would other giant corporations decide to enter the financial services arena? Sears's move was yet another stage in the metamorphosis of consumer banking, a phenomenon some Government and industry officials have dubbed homogenization.

title: Jacob's Pillow Opens July 2 With Benefit
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Lee, Mass., will open its 47th summer season July 2 with a benefit performance by 12 soloists from the Royal Danish Ballet. The festival, which will take place in the dance compound founded by Ted Shawn, the moderndance pioneer will begin its eightweek run the next day with performances by Lotte Goslar's Pantomime Circus, July 37.

title: Definition of Terms Used for Radiation
description: Following are some terms used in measuring radiation doses:

title: SPORTS A Road RacePlus On Tap in Far Hills
description: FAR HILLS ROAD racing has arrived as a major participant sport in New Jersey. But the Midland Run has evolved into more than just 20kilometer and threemile events.

title: GRIGORENKO GETS A SECOND OPINION
description: Meeting in Honolulu in late August 1977, the Sixth World Congress of Psychiatry passed resolution that added fuel to one of the profession's most fiery controversies. By a narrow margin, the congress condemned the abuse of psychiatry in Soviet political cases  the misdiagnosis of dissidents as mentally ill and their incarceration in institutions for the criminally insane.

title: What's Doing in GENEVA
description: MUSEUM OF IDEAS  Emotion recollected in tranquillity was Wordsworth's definition of poetry. It is a good description of Geneva, too.

title: Kennedy Center Sets Summer Opera
description: WASHINGTON, May 12  The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has announced it would open its first Summer opera season July 10 in its new 475seat roof Terrace Theater.

title: HOME CLINIC Important Steps for Ladder Safety
description: THIS is the time of year when many homeowners tackle such jobs as painting the outside of their homes, repairing gutters or doing similar outdoor chores that call for the use of a tall extension ladder.

title: Autopsy Shows Internal Bleeding Killed Man a Cab Driver Punched
description: An autopsy on a man fatally struck in the neck by a cab driver during a dispute over a fare in the East 51st Street station house Friday night showed the victim had died of internal bleeding, the New York City Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday.

title: New Quake Off Yugoslav Coast
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 12 (AP)  A strong tremor was registered today off Yugoslavia's southern Adriatic coast, the site of a destructive earthquake four weeks ago, the Tanyug press agency reported. The tremor measured 5 on the Richter scale, an intensity able to cause property damage. There was some damage in the town of Kotor in Montenegro Province, Tanyug said, but no injuries were reported.

title: Family Lives on Philosophy and the Land
description: PENNSBURG, Pa., May 10  Not in this town, nor in the next, but on the rim of one of many valleys around here lives a young woman with an odd approach to life: quoting Nietzsche, she makes moonshine; reading Stendhal, she roasts dog; the message, says Dolly Freed, is people hardly need to work at all.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: BRIDGE
description: The oldest bridge club in the world, and in many ways the most remarkable, is the Portland in London. It was founded as a whist club during the Napoleonic Wars, under another name, and was reconstituted in 1825 as the Portland for the sole purpose of removing one highly unpopular member. In 1895 the club produced the first code of laws for bridge and has aided in revising them ever since.

title: Questions/Answers
description: We movea into on old twos( this spring where the chrubben overgrown. particularly pieris. Itinipers and yew in the front of the house. When can we Safely hack them hack' F T. 0.. Scarsdale. N.Y.

title: J.T. Steen Jr., Ida L. Clement Wed in Texas
description: Ida Louise Clement and John Thomas Steen Jr. were married yesterday at the Epiphany Episcopal Church in Kingsville. Tex. The . Rev. James Krammer Alcorn, rector, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Louis Henderson Zbinden of the First Presbyterian Church of San Antonio.

title: Rhodesia Sanctions  The Arguments For and Against
description: A Senate amendment to lift sanctions against Rhodesia will be called up on Tuesday to try to preempt President Carter's decision on the issue. He has promised to rule by June 25 on the legitimacy of the newly elected Rhodesian Government. led for the first time by a black Prime Minister.

title: Tourist Industry Maps Fuel Strategy
description: THE ISLAND may be less than a tankful away from New York City, but if one cannot get gasoline this summer it can be a long way to go.

title: MURRAY POLLACK
description: LOS ANGELES, May 12 (UN)Murray Pollack, president of the Screen Extras Guild, died of cancer Thursday in Midway Hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: Boating Deaths Rise Slightly
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP)  A total of 1,321 people were killed in boating accidents in 1978, but the death rate, 9.4 for every 100,000 boats, was a record low, the Coast Guard has reported. The number of deaths, however, increased by nine over the 1977 figure. There were 450,000 more boats on on American waterways in 1978, bringing the estimated number to 14 million. Of these, 8,576 were involved in accidents, causing 1,761 injuries and property damage of $12.3 million, the Coast Guard said Friday.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WE are almost bored by the sight of apartmenthouse fires on television. It is cheap thrill, an easy score for freelance camera crews who sell their footage of misery. And then we never see the people again.

title: Letters: Perils of Passports for Two
description: To the Editor:

title: Other World Events
description: In South Africa, where black detainees frequently die in detention and black nationalist leaders have been jailed for life, terms of two and four years are relatively light. Such were the sentences meted out last week to of 11 black students convicted of sedition for organizing protests against unequal education that erupted into the Soweto riots of 1976 and 1977. The judge said he had taken into account the defendants youth and their long detention since arrest. The daughter of a jailed black nationalist suggested another reason: They want to improve their impression abroad.

title: Topics Verbal Gymnastics
description: The Russians are getting nervous about the Olympic Games they yearned to stage next year. They sense a threat not to their athletes but to the rest of the population.

title: A HalfCentury of Memories From the Fresh Air Fund
description: With a son and five grandchildren, to celebrate Mother's Day. But today will also bring her memories of thousands of other children  New York City youngsters who have spent summer vacations in the country thanks to Mrs. Anderson's halfcentury of work with the Fresh Air Fund.

title: Belle Blanchard Bride of Blake Newton 3d
description: Belle Carter Blanchard, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mercer Carter Blanchard of Columbus, Ga., was married last evening to Blake Tyler Newton 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Newton Jr. of Washington, formerly of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Norman Seifferman, who performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Columbus, was as sisted by the Rev. Treadwell Davison, an uncle of the bridegroom, and the Rev. Henry Lee Atkins Jr., a cousin of the bridegroom.

title: SHOP TALK
description: BAY SHORE BOTH ends of Bay Shore's long Main Street, also known as the Montauk Highway, are interesting shopping areas, although vastly different. On East Main Street you'll find a heavy concentration of funky, unbelievably cluttered antiques shops and Chinese restaurants, while on West Main you'll encounter more staid, traditional array of shoe and clothing shops and bargain hunters havens.

title: THE MARKETS A Surfeit of Worries
description: There was a shortage of gasoline supplies last week in California and a shortage of stock buyers Wall Street. What the financial district had, instead, was a surfeit of worries. Worries over rising interest rates, diminishing crudeoil supplies, rising crudeoil prices and the whenandif recession.

title: Music: Marriner Leads Philharmonic in Mozart
description: Neville Marriner was in charge of the New York Philharmonic's second Music in May concert Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall, and Mozart dominated the proceedings. This seemed like a good idea  Mozart's music is just as suitable for the sort of lighter fare being offered at this series as it on a serious symphonic program, and Mr. Marriner has long been admired as one of the best Mozart stylists around today.

title: Proposition 13 Fever Cools
description: DESPITE its initial glitter and glamour, Proposition 13 seems to be fading faster than most fads, at least on the Island.

title: City Tentatively Rejects A Power Plant for Bronx
description: ALBANY, May 9  New York City has tentatively rejected a proposal under which the State Power Authority would construct a $1 billion power plant in the South Bronx.

title: Canadiens: A Standard of Excellence
description: MONTREAL May 12  As they have since 1924, when the Forum was built, children pressed their noses today against the glass door that led to the rink, praying for. a glimpse of their. heroes wearing the bleu, blanc et rouge of that special team: the Canadiens.

title: Sidney Green to Play
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 12 (AP)  Three of the nation's top high school basketball players  Clark Kellogg, Sidney Green and Anne Donovan have accepted invitations to play in the Seamco tournament here May 27. Kellogg, from St. Joseph's High in Cleveland and Green, from Thomas Jefferson in Brooklyn, will compete in a NorthSouth male matchup. Miss Donovan, 6 feet 8 inches, from Paramus (N.J.) Catholic High, will play in the opening game, a female NorthSouth matchup, of the doubleheader at Kutsher's Country Club.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: It's midMay, and, according to the folks at the Planting Fields Arboretum, the perfect time to see what spring has sprung. They tell us azaleas are in peak bloom, with the Azalea Walk and its collection of Oriental and hybrid plants literally bursting with colors ranging from white to red to purple. Thousands of daffodils cover the ground, while visitors looking upward can catch the pink and white blossoms of the flowering crab apple, cherry and magnolia trees. On Planting Fields Road in Oyster Bay, the arboretum is open from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Until Saturday, $1.50 admission is charged only on weekends; after that it's the regular 9229200.

title: IRAN PAPER IS SHUT AFTER SHARP ATTACK
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 12  Iran's most independent newspaper. Ayandegan, stopped publication today after Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini attacked its reporting as depraved.

title: South Korea Frees 16 In a Gesture on Rights Before Visit by Carter
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 12  Sixteen students and opposition figures were abruptly freed by the South Korean Government today, a move apparently designed to improve its human rights image before President Carter's visit next month.

title: A Humane and Adventurous Art
description: IT may be that the function of mediocre books is titillate or, worse, to comfort; and the function good books is to disturb. If so, this slender collection of essays on the art of biography is a very good book indeed. So compact are the pieces by Edel, Kaplan, Kazin, Tuchman and one or two others, so crammed with ideas and insights and nuances, that each could very well be expanded to several times its length. Leon Edel's essay, in particular, The Figure in the Carpet, throws out provocative  and provoking  statements with dizzying speed, and though the piece is only about 13 pages long, it will surely be cited for years to come as a classic statement of the new biography. Justin Kaplan's graceful essay on the naked self gives us more insight into Walt Whitman in 14 pages than we might expect in a booklength study by a less gifted writer; and Barbara Tuchman's Biography as a Prism of History which, quite properly, concludes the volume, is at once a statement on the manifold uses of biography (in the service of historical study) and a critique of contemporary biographical method.

title: LETTER FROM CHINA
description: FIVE centuries before Johann Gutenberg, the people of China were using movable type to print and disseminate their traditional fiction, poetry and art. Today, the intellectuals of that vast land are struggling to recover from a decade in which they were obliged to labor on farm communes and the printing presses stopped running for anything except slogans and blatant propaganda. During a recent visit to five representative cities of the People's Republic of China  Canton, Shanghai, Suzhou, Nanjing and Peking  we discussed the current state of literature and publishing with writers, editors, university professors, librarians and publishers. What follows is a digest of our impressions, as precise as is possible in a country whose government is not certain whether its population is now 800 million, 900 million or 1 billion.

title: Smithtown Vote Due on a Halfway House
description: SMITHTOWN ALCOHOLISM does not just live on Skid Row, it lives on Main Street, said Joseph A. Califano Jr.. Secretary of Health. Education and Welfare, just two weeks ago while announcing a new Federal antialcoholism drive. The Nesconset Taxpayers Association wants no part of alcoholism on any street  Main or otherwise  here in Smithtown.

title: Living With Atomic Reactors Is Not So Peaceful After Three Mile Island
description: WASHINGTON  While perhaps 100,000 people assembled here to protest nuclear power last week, one conspicuous by his absence was Dr. Arthur R. Tamplin, a biophysicist who has spent more than a decade fighting the nuclear power industry and warning about the risks of radiation.

title: Sunday Observer How's Business?
description: If the state withers away it is more likely to be succeeded by the multinational corporation than the institutions of communal brotherhood foreseen by Karl Marx.

title: Joseph Shields, Broker Since '43 With New York Stock Exchange
description: Joseph V. Shields, a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1943, died Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital. Mr. Shields, who lived in Manhattan and Old Westbury, L.I., was 64 years old.
