description: NEITHER rain, snow nor sleet  or for that matter, public office and the press of years  has stayed Edward Cornell from his selfappointed undergraduate rounds. For. after 30 years of intermittent but unremitting study, Mr. Cornell is scheduled to receive a bachelor's degree from Rutgers.

description: ADLERMilton, beloved husband of Mildred (Mimi), devoted brother of Joseph and the late Louis. loving uncle and greatuncle. Services Monday, May 14, 2PM at The Riverside. Ocean Parkway at Prospect Park.

title: GARDENING A Lot From a Little
description: IN the good old days, the average suburban home was a house at the edge of a village with at least an acre of land. It probably had a horse, a cow, a pig or two, some chickens and a large vegetable garden.

The Detroit Tigers are at the Stadium for 8 P.M. games tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday.The Mets have a threegame series with the St. Louis Cardinals in Shea Stadium at 8 on Friday night and at 2 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday.

title: Barbato To Relinquish His Suffolk G.O.P. Post
description: At an emotional meeting of the Smithtown, L.I., Republican Committee, Nicholas Barbato announced that he was resigning as town leader because, he said, my presence may hurt my party's chances for victory in November.

title: Two Days Under Sail, when Time Is Too Short for More
description: The early morning sun woke me with a shaft of light through the twofootsquare hatch over the double bunk was sharing with my wife, Julie. Looking hazily through the opening I noticed a sail furled on a boom the size of a telephone pole.

title: Stage: A Fresh Virginia Woolf
description: MONTCLAIR REVIVAL of Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?, one in which the director, Arnold Mittelman, has found fresh and absorbing ways to interpret Edcate, Marshall Spiller's lighting seems too unvaried in its harsh brilliance, but Sigrid Insull's costumes have delightfully flashy pinks and purples for Martha's wardrobe and properly scaled grays and browns for the less flamboyant characters of George. Nick and Honey. ward Albee's battle of the sexes, is being staged by the Whole Theater Company here until June 17.

title: Bid Trainer Sees A Livelier Preakness
description: The way Bud Delp sees it, next Saturday's 104th Preakness Stakes will be much livelier horse race than the 105th Kentucky Derby.

title: Washington the Scene and Backdrop

Washington is the scene of John Ehrlichinan's The Whole Truth and Gwen Davis's Ladies in Waiting, and the backdrop of Leslie Wailer's The Brave and the Free. And all three purport to be stories about bow America works.

title: English Cup Final Won by Arsenal
description: WEMBLEY, England, May 12 (AP)  Liam Brady, the Irish soccer star, set up three goals today as Arsenal edged Manchester United, 32, in the English Cup final at Wembley Stadium before a crowd of nearly 100,000.

title: Some College Taverns With a Passing Grade
description: FEW things in life resist change as well as a good college bar. Taverns come and go, bars become discos, faithful clientele move away from a favorite haunt: But college bars stay the same, generation after generation. Legends and traditions grow up around them. College bars are history and graffiti, and family might trace its roots in the dark, varnished woods where an ancestor inscribed the name of a girl he loved.

title: Peyser Throws In A Monkey Wrench
description: WASHINGTON AS Representative Peter A. Peyser figures it, more than 34,000 small businesses have terminated their pension plans for employees because of the huge costs of complying with a multitude of Federal regulations.

title: Elizabeth C. Miles Wed in Stockbridge
description: Elizabeth Clark Miles of New York, daughter of William S. Miles of Stockbridge, Mass., and the late Mrs. Miles, was married yesterday to Robert Michael Montgomery of Kempsford, Engiana, son of LaeUt. Col. Robert Kerr Montgomery, Royal Engineers, retired, and Mrs. Montgomery of London.

title: Retooling The Libido
description: O say that Kingsley Amis's new novel concerns a tetchy professor who tries sex therapy for his wonky libido is also to suggest that this is a chestnut which Peter De Vries has already given a thorough roasting. As for the raveling marriage, I had the salutary experience of reading Too Far to Go, John Updike's bumper collection of Maples stories, an hour after finishing Jake's Thing  there is no bookworm like an airline passenger  and I could not help but notice that the mess we make of our lives, and the marital mess in particular, varies according to nationality. Perhaps you have to be a Yugoslav to talk about President Tito's latest marriage without collapsing into laughter, and I think you have to be an American for the Maples stories to scorch your conscience and worry you terribly; certainly, anyone who is unfamiliar with the splendors and miseries of living in Britain would be fairly baffled by Jake's Thing and find it funnypeculiar rather than funnyhaha.

Now they have, in a graphically detailed 20pave wall poster a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times last week. Its author, Wei Jingsheng, was arrested a few weeks after the poster appeared on March 3, reportedly charged with counterrevolution, a capital offense. copy of which was obtained by The New York Times last week. Its author, Wei Jingsheng, was arrested a few weeks after the poster appeared on March 3, reportedly charged with counterrevolution, a capital offense.

Nevertheless, there are those who have been able to overdome formidable obstacles of this kind, and thus enjoy photography as a hobby.

The fuel rods are temporarily stored in underground, concretelined pools precisely because nobody knows what to do with them.

O'HERN, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, is said to be in line to succeed Stewart Pollock as counsel to Governor Byrne when Mr. Pollock moves up to the State Supreme Court later this summer. Biddle Jr. as his counterpart at the National Endowment for the Arts, the Administration has been accused of shaping the two organizations  which together dispense the lion's share of what might be called Federal cultural subsidies  to its own political ends. The two appointments, said critics, presaged the beginning of a calculated shift of vital funding away from socalled elitist institutions such as New York's Metropolitan Opera and toward organizations at the grassroots level.

title: ANTIQUES
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, never timid about pioneering in its collecting efforts, has done it again. It has acquired two extraordinary designs, a bathroom sink and an elevator cab  selections most museums and collectors have scorned until now in their pursuit of significant 20thcentury decorative arts. Chances are, they will no longer.

The small box is six inches wide, seven inches long and six inches high. Made of goldplated bronze (there is also a silver version), the box and its contents weigh 27 pounds.

He believed that the drugtreatment programs he had once strongly supported had not worked, so he moved to the other extreme, putting his faith in a News Analysis law that was the toughest in the country. He predicted it would quickly clear the streets of pushers.

Forest at a bend in the river, a meeting place, an Arab settlement, a European outpost, a European suburb, a ruin like the ruin of a dead civilization, the glittering domain of New Africa, and now this.

title: Remembering Mother on Her Day
description: Ed Daniels escorting his mother, Odaline, on the Promenade at Rockefeller Center yesterday after taking her to dinner. Mr. Daniels is carrying a potted plant he bought for her. At right, telephone operators were called in on overtime to handle heavy volume of Mother's Day calls. The mothers among the operators were given corsages.

title: Body Is Found in Gulf on Oil Rig
description: GALVESTON, Tex., May 13 (AP) Divers completed their search of a sunken oil drilling rig today and found the body of one of the eight men missing since the rig collapsed in the Gulf of Mexico on Thursday.

title: Philadelphia Primary Tuesday
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (AP)  Fifteen candidates will vie for their parties nominations Tuesday in bids to succeed Mayor Frank Rizzo, who is barred by law from seeking a third consecutive term.

title: Question Box

Asarco Inc. announced a twocent decrease in its domestic spot selling price of electrolytic copper to 88 cents a pound, effective immediately, for cathodes on a delivered basis. The company said current premiums for special shapes would remain unchanged.

title: GOING OUT
description: KEYS TO THE KINGDOM Last week various concerts celebrated the 150th anniversary of the birth of Louis Moreau Gottschalk, one of America's first classical composers and an international piano virtuoso whose personal life was equally colorful. Gottschalk kept extensive journals and diaries and wrote prolific letters about his travels and life. The music of the New Orleans native also contained elements of black, Creole and West Indian cultures that led to the emergence of ragtime and jazz.

title: KHOMEINI RESTRICTS SENTENCE OF DEATH TO CRIME OF MURDER
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 13  Irans revolutionary leader decreed today that only those people proved guilty of offenses involving the killing of others could be sentenced to death by the revolutionary courts.

title: The City

description: SAN DIEGO, May 13  Gene Richards ended the New York Mets disastrous stay on the West Coast today by lining a twoout single to right in the 10th inning to score Dan Briggs and give the San Diego Padres a 54 victory.

title: BrazilAngola Oil Pact
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 12 (Reuters)  Angola will provide Brazil with 15,000 barrels of oil a day starting next year under an agreement signed here, according to sources at Petrobras, tne Brazilian state oil company. The price will be at the level then in effect in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting. Countries. The accord also provides for the Brazilian company to drill in Angola and to train Angolans in the industry.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the SportsMonday section on April 30, the manufacturer of the AquaScooter water vehicle was incorrectly identified. The manufacturer is AquaScooter Inc of Springfield. N.J.

title: Paris-Bonn Quarrel Over Plutonium Threatens to Split West Europe
description: CAHORS, France, May 13A quarrel between France and Wert Germany over plutonium, the principal explosive in nuclear weapons, is threatening to divide West European nations on the question of nuclear security and to complicate further President Carter's campaign for stricter controls on nuclear technology..

title: Tens of Thousands in Poland Mark 900th Anniversary of Patron Saint
description: CRACOW, Poland, May 13  Tens of thousands of Polish Roman Catholics marked the 900th anniversary today of the martyrdom of St. Stanislaus, Poland's patron saint, marching through the streets of Cracow to the small stone Church on the Rock where he was killed.

title: U.S. and China Reach 6 Cooperative Accords On Eve of Trade Pact
description: CANTON, China, May 13  Juanita M. Kreps, United States Secretary of Commerce, today outlined six agreements on scientific, technological and business affairs reached with Peking on her trip to China. She also confirmed that it is quite likely that we will be able to initial an aereement on trade tomorrow.

title: A HelterSkelter Shelter Mess
description: You would think a city that built the world's best water system and runs the longest subway would be able to arrange for the construction of a few thousand small, identical glass sheds to shelter people waiting for a bus. We find ourselves thinking longer and harder about the shockingand perhaps scandalriddenincapacity of New York's government in this matter.

title: Sonics On Top, 106105
description: PHOENIX. May 13 (AP)  Gus Williams connected on a 16foot shot with 52 seconds remaining to put Seattle in front, and the Sonia went on to beat the Phoenix Suns today, 106.105.

title: Blair's Homer Helps Reds Win
description: PITTSBURGH, May 13 (AP)  Paul Blair's first National League hit, a tworun homer, snapped a sixthinning tie and helped the Cincinnati Reds to a 73 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.

title: Lock Haven Women Gain Lacrosse Title
description: HOLLINS, Va., May 13 (AP) Diane Minshall's goal with 12 minutes left gave secondseeded Lock Haven State a 54 victory today over topranked Hollins in the title game of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association Division II tournament.

title: Ballet New: Casts in Nutcracker
description: NEW casts filled up American Ballet Theater's production of The Nutcracker on Saturday, topped with very fine and different debuts in the title rote. Danilo Radojevic stressed the nutcracker in the prince at the matinee at the Metropolitan Opera House, while Anthony Dowell brought out the prince inside the nutcracker in the evening's performance.

title: HARTE M. JUDDSON
description: Harte M. Juddson, who served in the United States Foreign Service for many years, died Saturday at his home in the Bronx after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

title: Two Men Seize Keys and Codes, Then Loot Bank Cash Machines
description: Two men armed with revolvers invaded Citibank's Brooklyn regional office early yesterday, seized keys and combinations for the readymoney machines at all the bank's Brooklyn and Staten Island branches and took nearly $100,000 at three of the outlets before bank security agents changed the combinations, the police reported.

title: Yale's Women Row to Crown
description: LAKE WARAMAUG, Conn., May 13  Yale University's varsity women's eight won the major race today in the Eastern Women's Intercollegiate rowing championships.

title: Tokyo Students Hurt in Blast
description: TOKYO, May 13 (AP)  Explosives in a model volcano being prepared for school exhibit blew up today, injuring 17 high school students, the police reported. All the students were hospitalized and some may lose their eyesight, authorities said.

title: U.S. Women's Five Takes Title
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 13 (AP)  Carol Blazejowski scored 25 points and Nancy Lieberman got 13 as the United States won its first world women's basketball championship since 1957 by defeating previously unbeaten Canada, 7761, today in the final game.

title: Lor Gail Browner Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Lor Gail Browner to Ben James Kaplan took place yesterday at the Rye Town Hilton Inn in Port Chester, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin M. Browner of Purchase, N.Y. Mr. Kaplan is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Kaplan of Pittsfield, Mass.

title: U.S. Laboratory Reactor Passes an Accident Test
description: IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, May 13 (AP) The first fullscale test of a nuclear reactor's ability to recover from a sudden loss of cooling water was a complete success, the Department of Energy said today.

title: Reprieve for Some Amtrak Routes Possible as a Budget Rise Is Sought
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  Amtrak, which has been facing an Administrationordered slash of 12,000 miles from its 27,500mile national rail passenger system as of Oct. 1, may be able to retain five or more of its 16 threatened services after all at least for two years.

title: Topics
description: After hearing that radar once recorded a tree traveling at 84 miles an hour, and other absurdities, a Florida judge has dismissed 80 speeding cases and vowed never to trust the technology again. He leaves 9,000 Dade County cases in limbo and surely invites similar rulings elsewhere.

title: Parole of a Kidnapper Angers Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, May 13  It's a long way from Georgia's Reidsville State Prison, a steamy hellhole where racial murders and homosexual assaults are commonplace, to the pellucid, fishteeming waters of Alaska's Alexander Archipelago. Tomorrow, Gary Steven Krist is scheduled to take that journey homeward because the Georgia Board of Pardons and Paroles has declared him a rehabilitated citizen.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Whitman Bassow, Executive, Marries Mimi Clifford, Editor
description: Mary Elizabeth Clifford, an assistant managing editor of Facts on File, a reference publication, and Whitman Bassow, executive director of the Center for International Environment Information, were married yesterday at their home in New York. Cantor Alex Zimmer performed the ceremony.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 33, 28, 19, 36, 29 and 27. The supplementary number was 11.

title: Dr. Morton Hoberman, A Rehabilitation Expert
description: Dr. Morton Hoberman, an authority on physical medicine and rehabilitation, died Thursday in Southampton Hospital on Long Island. Dr. Hoberman, who lived at 30 Nautilus Drive, Hampton Bays, L.I., was 68 years old.

title: New Postmaster Primed to Meet Challenge
description: George F. Shuman, who has just been appointed postmaster of New York, comes to.the job with two fearlessly frank monitors of the Postal Service he dare not ignore. His daughter, Colleen, lets him know if it takes more than three days for his letter to travel from New York to Hawaii, where she lives, and another daughter, Maureen, is a parttime mail clerk in the post office at Manchester. N.H.

title: Coast Motorists Traveling Less, Worrying More
description: LOS ANGELES, May 13California is throttling back its freewheeling, motorized style of living under the pressures of its second gasoline crisis in five years.

title: Sheba Strunsky Goodman Dies; A Founder of Rescue Committee
description: Sheba Strunsky Goodman, a founder of the International Rescue Committee, a humanitarian organization, died Saturday in Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. She was 76 years old.

title: Washington Watch
description: WHITE HOUSE economists have their eyes on new regulations coming this year. Last week,

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, MAY 14, 1979

title: Panamanian President Discreetly Pushes Canal Issue in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  While on an official visit to Spain last month, President Aristides Royo of Panama became sufficiently alarmed about aspects of pending American legislation to carry out the Panama Canal treaties to dispatch a message to President Carter.

title: Space Shuttle Engine Is Tested
description: BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., May 13 (UPI)  Space agency officials said yesterday they had successfully fired the first of three main rocket engines for the space shuttle Columbia in a flight certification test at the National Space Technology Laboratories. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration plan to launch the space shuttle Nov. 9.

title: The Case of the Returned Marine: Accusations Mix With Sympathy
description: If the charges of collaborating with the Vietcong ever lead to a courtmartial, Pfc. Robert R. Garwood of the Marines will certainly not lack for accusers with incriminating memories.

title: At CBS, Neither the Best Nor the Worst of Times
description: It was neither the best of seasons nor the worst of seasons for CBSTV. Although the network that had once been the leader in television programming and the focus of the industry's glamour had lost those glittering prizes to ABCTV, it has been spared the trials of NBCTV, the network that has fallen into third place.

title: Arabs on West Bank Reject Gesture by Israeli Liberals
description: JERUSALEM, May 13  A few hundred vines and olive saplings, plants of ageold Mediterranean civilization, have become symbols during the last few days of the conflicts between Arabs and Jews in the Israelioccupied West Bank and of the frustrations that await anyone seekine to ease the strains.

title: TV: 'sonRise, About Autistic Child
description: SONRISE, on NBCTV at 9 tonight, is the story of a family's efforts to save a son who has been diagnosed as unreachable by medical experts. It is based on a book of the same name written by Barry Neil Kaufman, the boy's father.

title: Former DivinitySchool Head and Peddie Headmaster Was 84
description: The. Rev. Dr. Wilbour Eddy Saunders, president emeritus of the ColgateRochester Divinity School and former headmaster of the Peddie School of Hightstown, N.J., died Saturday at his home in Webster, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Just Another Came To Confident Victors
description: MONTREAL, May 13  We never looked at them, said Carol Vadnais. We played them like they were just any good hockey team.

title: The Region
description: ELIZABETH, N.J.  John F. McGaugh, publisher of The Daily Journal here, is scheduled to appear in Municipal Court today on charges brought by striking employees that the company violated a local ordinance by bringing in nonunion personnel to publish the newspaper.

title: The Spaceman Lives
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Listening to the Radio Market
description: Having begun to deregulate cable television, the Federal Communications Commission now wants to set radio free. It is considering staff proposals to repeal rules fixing the maximum broadcast time that may be filled with commercials and the minimum that must be devoted to news and other nonentertainment programs. Meanwhile, members of the House Commerce Communications subcommittee want Congress to go further, abolishing the fairness and equal time doctrines, granting permanent licenses and exacting a spectrum fee from broadcasters in exchange for their new freedom.

title: Chess:
description: Mikhail Tal of Latvia, who won the world championship from Mikhail Botvinnik in 1960 and lost the return match the following year, has never challenged for the title since, but he has steadily added first prizes to his illustrious tournament career.

title: Survey Shows Campus Drug Use Down Slightly but Still Prevalent
description: Drug use on college campuses continues to flourish but may be declining, especially among freshmen, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Kennedy Views Youth Jobs As a Key to City Upgrading
description: At just the time that urban causes seemed to be taking the severest pounding on Capitol Hill, Senator Edward M. Kennedy and three colleagues announced their intention to introduce a measure that because of its timine its objective and particularly its sponsorship, is bound to keep before the public in the coming election year at least part of the debate about how best to help cities and their people.

title: Zukerman, Perlman in May Music
description: THE first of the New York Philharmonic's Music in May Concerts last week at Avery Fisher Hall was reportedly only half full, but Saturday evening's installment was packed. The cause for all the excitement was Pinchas Zukerman and Itzhak Perlman. Mr. Perlman was just playing the violin. Mr. Zukerman was doing that plus playing the viola plus conducting.

title: Rangers Surprise Canadiens in Cup Opener, 41
description: MONTREAL

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Suits Draw Attention to Unorthodox Education Combine
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  One of the nation's highestpaid educational officials and the unusual amalgam of institutions that he has developed are drswing public attention because of court battles here and elsewhere.

title: Beaumont Moves Toward a Dream
description: Efforts to reopen the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center are moving along step by step, with something of the deliberate pace of a play in progress. But Richmond Crinkley, the man in charge of putting this complicated production together, already has a clear view of the final scene  the opening season itself. My dream scenario, he said recently, would be to open with new plays by Woody Allen and Edward Albee, plus a classic.

title: Bullets Triumph, Trail in Series, 32
description: LANDOVER, Md., May 13  Tom Henderson is a New York basketball product, but he is not a shooter. His role with the Washington Bullets is to get the ball to Elvin Hayes, Bob Dandridge and Kevin Grevey the scorers.

title: Hardships for Small Business Cited In New York Area Economic Study
description: Small businesses bore nearly all of the economic decline in the New York metropolitan region during the 197475 recession, according to a study by the Regional Plan Association, and economists fear that the economic downturn forecast for the next year could affect small businesses similarly.

title: Pipeline Buying More of Husky
description: The Alberta Gas Trunk Line Company announced over the weekend that it would buy 2.2 million shares, or 20 percent, of Husky Oil Ltd. from the Glenn E. Nielson family at $48 a share. Alberta Gas already controls 49 percent of the roughly 11 million Husky Oil shares outstanding.

title: Son Is Born to Swedish Queen
description: STOCKHOLM, May 13 (Reuters) Queen Silvia of Sweden gave birth prematurely to a son today and mother and child were reported to be well. A court announcement said the baby, so far unnamed, was born in Stockholm's Royal Castle a few weeks earlier than expected. It was the 35yearold Queen's second child. Her first, Princess Victoria, was born two years ago.

title: U.S. Seeks Partners Trade Help
description: PARIS, May 13  The Carter Administration, switching tactics, is urging its major trading partners to adopt farreaching changes in the way they run their economies as part of an effort to control the persistent American deficits in the international balance of payments, according to diplomatic sources and officials here.

title: Alternatives to Plastic Credit
description: BONN, May 13 In West Germany, the slow metamorphosis toward a cashless society has not been based on plastic.

title: D. Parke Gibson; Published Guide On the Black Consumer Market
description: D. Parke Gibson, president of D. Parke Gibson International of 475 Fifth Avenue, died of a heart attack Saturday in New York Hospital. He was 49 years old.

title: Paige Joins WorldClass Mile Club
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 13  Two signifcant facts emerged from last night's Dream Mile at Franklin Field: Don Paige has arrived as a worldclass miler and the position of South Africa in international sports is more muddled than ever.

title: Tennis: Final to Tracy Austin
description: ROME, May 13 (AP)  Tracy Austin overcame a cold, her fatigue and a string of errors to defeat Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, 64, 16, 63, today and win the women's Colgate Italian open tennis tournament.

title: TV: Television Annual, Highlights of the Season
description: JUST think of the countless hours that might have been saved if viewers had been aware that The Television Annual: 19781979 was coming. The program, the first of what is planned as an annual event, presents highlights of the season as seen on the networks, public broadcasting, local and syndicated shows. It will be shown on ABCTV from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight.

title: Letter Asking for Help Is Received From a Texan Missing in Colombia
description: BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, May 13  A letter asking for help and bearing the signature of Roy McLemore, missing since the airplane in which he was flying landed illegally two weeks ago on the rugged Colombian coast, was delivered to the Houston fire chief, V.E. Rogers, at his hotel here last night.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company recently reorganized its staff along market lines rather than functional lines. Now Bell Laboratories, the research arm of the Bell System, is apparently playing catch up.

title: Commodities
description: Adfutures contract prices in the nation's biggest commodities markets, corn and wheat, continued to respond to the daily weather ana export reports last week, many traders for the first time began to watch another set of figures  the Federal crop loan release numbers.

title: Credit Cards Fight for Europe's Buyers
description: BONN, May 13  The American creditcard war, the cutthroat competition for more customers, is showing siens of erupting in Europe.

title: If You're Heading for the Delaware
description: Angling for shad usually involves an 8 or 10poundtest spinning outfit, but the fish will strike flies also. In deeper water a fastsinking fly line is needed, or, as Dr. John Hampsey noted at the recent shad festival in Bethlehem, Pa., one can tie a short length of lead core wire to the leader in order to get the fly down.

title: Aspen Series, Renamed, To Be Repeated on NBC
description: Aspen, a short series broadcast in November of 1977 on NBCTV, will be repeated on the network in a few weeks but with a different title.

title: Don Zimmer's Nightmare
description: DON ZIMMER, the manager of the Boston Red Sox, has not yet forgotten it and says he believes he never will. He has replayed Bucky Dent's playoff home run over and over again in his mind, and he has had nightmares about it ever since that afternoon last October.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: For the last two years Richard B. Hoey, economist at Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., has been pessimistic on longterm bonds. Last week he chanced his mind.

title: U.S. Lifters Seek Identity
description: TOTOWA, N.J., May 13  When I introduce the athletes, the announcer at Ice World said today, I expect to hear a big round of applause.

title: Pressure on Bond Prices Expected
description: After meandering through an indecisive week, the credit markets are faced with several difficult hurdles over the next few days. So it would not be surprising to see interest rates head upward once again, some fixedincome analysts said last Friday.

title: Congress Gets Even With the Taxpayer
description: Taxpayers and state legislators who have been clamoring for Washington to balance the Federal budget may be getting more austerity than they bargained for. The House of Representatives recently voted to eliminate the states $2.3billion share of general revenuesharing and the Senate wants to scuttle President Carter's $250million supplementary aid bill for distressed cities. Both houses seem intent on outsaving the White House and on getting even with the local politicians who have glibly made Congress the spending scapegoat.

title: Yale Is Victor in Eastern Sprints
description: WORCESTER, Mass., May 13 Yale's musclemen swept Harvard aside today to win the Eastern sprint championships on Lake Quinsigamond in an impressive display of rowing prowess.

title: Guidry to Start; Yanks Win, 1210
description: Ron Guidry is back in the starting rotation and Bob Lemon and his coaches should be back in George Steinbrenner's good graces.

title: Plot to Kidnap 2 Envoys In Istanbul Is Reported
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 13 (UPI) The Turkish police said today that they had uncovered a plot to kidnap the American and Israeli consuls in Istanbul by an ultraleftist group that said it was responsible for killing an American serviceman two days ago.

title: Cubans Seek Asylum in Caracas
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 13 (AP) Twelve Cubans seeking political asylum drove a bus through a fence surrounding the grounds of the Venezuelan Embassy in Havana last night and succeeded in gaining entry to the building, President Luis Herrera Campins announced today.

title: Western Influence Growing in East Europe
description: WARSAW  Across Eastern Europe, throughout the six Communist countries that have served as a buffer Tor the Soviet Union since the end of World War II, powerful currents of Western infuence are running beneath the surface of Soviet domination.

title: The Philadeiphia Primary: Is Rizzo Right?
description: JENKINTOWN, Pa.Last tall, Frank L. Rizzo, the eightyear Mayor of Philadelphia, suggested that if blacks could vote black then whites would just as easily vote white. This assertion was de cried by both blacks and whites as racist and divisive, yet the 1979 Democratic mayoral primary tomorrow seems to be following this very scenario.

title: Assembly Unit Is Formed To Study Nuclear Safety
description: A newly formed committee of the State Assembly will visit the Indian Point nuclear power complex in Westchester County today in its first step in an effort to study the safety of such generating plants and to consider alternative energy sources.

title: THE SEARCH FOR GAS FOLLOWS A PATTERN
description: About half the service stations in the New York metropolitan area were closed yesterday, and many others were limiting sales to stretch gasoline supplies cut back by the major oil companies, but motorists out on an overcast Mother's Day were only moderately inconvenienced by queues at the pumps and longer rides to open stations.

title: Arson Suspected at Jobs Office
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 13 (AP) Arson may have been the cause of a fire that destroyed personnel records of workers scheduled to lose their jobs with Federal employment program, according to fire officials. The fire occurred Saturday at the headquarters of Total Community Action, which is financed under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act. Under new Federal guidelines, workers who have been in the program for more than 18 months must be replaced.

title: Single Mothers Sharing a Difficult Time
description: Not long ago, Patricia Polhill, a 25yearold flight attendant, invited Jacqueline Whitehead, who is 18 years old, to her home to demonstrate how she juggles her job, her responsibilities to her 5yearold daughter and her domestic life.

title: Sources of Donations Obscured in Albany By Legislative Funds
description: ALBANY, May 13  I've got a problem in Syracuse, a top legislative aide said. He was talking to a labor lobbyist, as he would talk later to business lobbyists, about a New York State legislator who was having trouble financing his reelection campaign.

title: Fairchild Splits Stock
description: GERMANTOWN, Md., May 11 (Reuters)  Fairchild Industries declared a fiveforfour stock split and a dividend of 25 cents apiece on the postsplit shares. The split is payable June 22 and the dividend June 29, both to holders of record May 31. The company, which makes aircraft and aircraft components, will pay cash in lieu of fractional shares.

title: Children, Instead Of Ships
description: WASHINGTON  Congress has the opportunity this year to pass two costcontainment measures for children that it failed to take final action on in the 95th Congress. One is a bill to pre vent the unnecessary removal, ana discourage the longterm placement, of children outside of their homes; the other would provide doctors and dentists for about two million poor children who now lack such regular basic health care.

title: Sports Briefs
description: ZOLDER, Belgium, May 13 (UPI) Jody Scheckter of South Africa, driving his Ferrari at a steady pace while biding his time, won the Belgian Formula One Grand Prix today with a 15second cushion over Jacques Laffite of France in a Ligier.

title: Waldheim Visits Refugee Camps In Thailand Hours After Shelling
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, May 13 (AP)  Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations visited two refugee camps outside this border town today, hours after artillery and mortar fire from Cambodia damaged houses south of here, local officials said. There was no firing during Mr. Waldheim's tour of the refugee centers, which were not hit during the shelling..

title: Advertising
description: RHEINGOLD, once New York's favorite beer but now in sixth place, tonight begins to take on Schaefer, the current No. 1, with corn. oarative advertising. With the blessing of the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, which regulates alcoholic beverage advertising, Rheingold will name the competition.

title: The Stage: Devour The Snow
description: THE story of the Donner Party is one of an elemental quest for survival against seemingly insurmountable obstacles. In 184687, emigrants to California from the Middle West, snowbound in the Sierra Nevada, were driven to cannibalism. That historical event is the source for Abe Polsky's Devour the Snow, which opened last night at the Hudson Guild Theater.

title: New York Sets Furious Pace
description: MONTREAL, May 13  The New York Rangers, who have been underdogs in virtually every game of the Stanley Cup playoffs, roared through the opener of the finals today with a 41 trouncing of the defending champions, the Montreal Canadiens, at the Forum.

title: Outdoors
description: BETHLEHEM, PA. S certain as the northward flight of waterfowl Or the blooming of mayflowers, the American shad comes in from the sea in spring and ascends rivers to spawn.

title: Music: Ax Gives Recital at the Y
description: EMANUEL AX, who won the Avery Fisher Prize last week, is wellestablished as a pianist with spectacular fingers and a distinct poetic gift. Such a reputation is, of course, a tribute to Mr. Ax's artistry, but it can also seem a liability of sorts. Mr. Ax's recital Saturday night at the 92d Street Y was a case in point. It was very good, but one expected something more.

title: '55 Atomic Bomb Tests in Nevada Are Recalled by a Former Soldier
description: WASHINGTON. May 13  They were bored and they were lonely and but for the marathon blackjack game there was little to do except sit and read and wait for the next atomic bomb to be tested.

title: No Title
description: Martha Johnson, Writer, Wed

title: In Riverside Park: Seeing the Forest for the Trees
description: Dr. Catherine Hazen and her daughter, Elizabeth, 3, drawing a chalk circle a tree in Riverside Park as they helped to count the park's sylvan population. About 175 volunteers, working in sectors, came up with an estimate of over 12,000 trees. The Friends of Riverside Park, a recently formed community ganization, directed the census of the trees as part of its project to seek public and private funds for the restoration and preservation of the park.

title: Vance Warns That Senate Changes Could Doom ArmsLimitation Pact
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance warned today that Senate amendments to the new SovietAmerican treaty limiting strategic arms could doom the accord.

title: Sporting Gear
description: A Young Pitcher's Baseball

title: Archbishop in San Salvador Urges Regime to Release 3 Labor Leaders
description: SAN SALVADOR, May 13  Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero urged El Salvador's armybacked Government today to release three missing labor leaders whose freedom is being demanded by a militant organization that is occupying the French and Venezuelan Embassies.

title: Cape Town Squatters Are Facing a Brighter Future
description: CAPE TOWN, May 9  The bulldozer that amves at dawn to smash black people's shanties at the Crossroads squatter camp is now no more than a monster in teacher's collection of drawings by the squatters children.

title: ExConvict Held In Queens Death Of Police Officer
description: Queens detectives early yesterday charged a 35yearold former convict with last Thursday's barroom killing of Police Officer Robert Soldo. They said they believed the shotgun blast that killed the officer had been intended for someone else, whom the gunman had been hired to slay.

title: Kings Point Wins
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., May 13  Alex Simgelski won four races in Division A, finished second once and third twice to lead Kings Point to the team title today in the America Trophy sailing regatta.

title: City to Convert Piers Into Parks In Each Borough
description: New York City will finance the transformation of seven aging piers and waterfront lots into thriving public parks by this summer, under a plan announced yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Loews Reported to Oust Top Bulova Executives
description: The Loews Corporation, which completed a $35 million takeover of the Bulova Watch Corporation in March, has drastically revamped the management of the nation's oldest watch company, unseating the chief executive officer and four other top executives, according to reliable industry sources.

title: Greta Zuckerkandel Bride of John Borie
description: Greta Zuckerkandel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Zuckerkandel of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to John Stewart Borie, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Boyd Borie of Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed at the Hotel du Pont by the Rev. Stanley E. Johnson, an Episcopal priest and chaplain at the University of Pennsylvania, from which the couple graduated last year.

title: At Rites for 2 Bedford Hills Victims Compassion Is Asked for the Killers
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 13  At memorial services today for Christopher Richard Sperry, who would have been 22 years old next week, and his family's 84yearold former governess, Nellie McCormack, forgiveness was asked for the killers of the two laughing and joyous friends.

title: Notes on People
description: Cliff Robertson Wins a Point and an Ample Sum

title: Bank Takeover Bill Set for Assembly
description: A bill is to be introduced in the state legislature tomorrow that would prohibit foreign takeovers of large banks in New York State, it has been learned.

title: Dr. Robert Howard Ozer Marries Lisa H. Goldberg
description: Lisa Helene Goldberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Goldberg of Oradell, N.J., was married yesterday. to Dr. Robert Howard Ozer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Ozer of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed at the Tam crest Country Club in Alpine, N.J., by Rabbi Andre Ungar of Temple Emanuel in Westwood, N.J.

title: Dance: City Ballet Salutes the French
description: THE New York City Ballet's Saturday evening performance at the New York State Theater could have been called French composers night, for it offered works of two kinds to Ravel, Debussy and Bizet. There were two dramatic fantasies and two abstractions.

title: Behind the Usual davits Guesses
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  As many politicians play the annual Jacob K. Javits Guessing Game  will he or will he not run for reelection?  Mr. Javits will tell you that he has something much more important on his mind.

title: Fight Over Rhodesia Sanctions Reflects Carter Bid to Save Africa Policy
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  The Carter Administration is trying to find ways to buy time to save its policy on southern Africa, which is threatened by the recent Rhodesian elections, the Conservative victory in Britain, South Africa's rejection of a plan for SouthWest African independence and opposition in Congress.

title: U.S. Plan for Fall of Skylab Craft Includes Medical Aid
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  While its experts continue to insist that the chances of damage from the reentry into the atmosphere of the Skylab space station are small, the National . Aeronautics and Space Administration has prepared elaborate contingency plans to provide medical, engineering and legal assistance anywhere that pieces of the massive spacecraft might fall.

title: De Gustibus
description: Garlic, we stated recently, has long been thought of as a miracle worker. It is said to cure warts, hay fever and all sorts of irritations that plague mankind. To the list of garlic's fine proper ties, Maurice B. llexter of Manhattan adds a postscript: When the sculptors on carrara marble find a weak spot in the stone, they rub a piece of garlic on it. It hardens it enough so that they can continue their operations.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Christine Young Bride of Kevin McKenna
description: At Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, in Greenville, Del., yesterday, Christine Dorothea Young, a freelance medical illustrator and painter, was married to Kevin Erard McKenna, a doctoral candidate in the department of biomedical engineering at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. The Rev. Dr. John L. O'Hear performed the ceremony.

title: Supplementary OvertheCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Surgery for Boxer
description: LAKE CHARLES La., May 13 (UPI)  Ronnie Newton of Fort Smith, Ark., who collapsed in his locker room after being knocked out in the national Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships, today underwent surgery and was listed in serious condition. Newton, a welterweight, was knocked unconscious by Donald Curry of Fort Worth with 22 seconds remaining in the final round of their bout last night.

title: Clippers Get Walton For Record Salary
description: SAN DIEGO, May 13  The San Diego Clippers ended a yearlong quest for Bill Walton, the coveted 6foot11inch center, by announcing today they had signed him to a sevenyear contract at more than $800.000 a season.

title: The Prime Time Of Muriel Spark
description: Vanessa Redgrave played her in London. Zo Caldwell played her on Broadway. Maggie Smith played her in the film adapted from the novel, winning more friends and an Oscar for her role as the unforgettable Scottish schoolmarm.

title: Around the Nation
description: Damages Over $ I Million In West Virginia Floods

title: Murray Captures Yonkers Marathon
description: YONKERS, May 13  Back in the early 1960's, when he was a student at Villanova University, Dan Murray hoped to be a mainstay of Coach Jumbo Jim Elliott's powerful track teams.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  SALT is a MEGO: when confronted with the complexities of strategic arms limitation talks, many Americans respond with My Eyes Glaze Over.

title: S.E.C. Chief a Policy Enigma
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  For months, Harold M. Williams, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been a bit of an enigma to those who follow the S.E.C. A lion on the speaking dais, preaching jarring notions about how corporations should be run, he has been more of a lamb at the commission table, leading the way in softening agency rule proposals and scaling down new disclosure requirements.

title: Linda McVay Wed To Bruce Hillowe
description: Linda Marie McVay and Bruce Victor Hillowe were married yesterday in the Duke University Chapel in Durham, N.C., by the Rev. Michael Reid of St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenport, L.I.

title: Events
description: Music

title: World News Briefs
description: China Says That Vietnam Is Trying to Alter Border

title: Mears Captures Pole For Indy 500 Race
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 13  Rick Mears of Bakersfield, Calif., the last driver in the lineup at the time trials today, wrested the Indianapolis 500 pole position from a former teammate today as favored A.J. Foyt managed only the sixth fastest qualifying speed.

title: Jazz: Rickie Lee Jones Makes New York Debut
description: THERE'S been a lot of talk of late about Rickie Lee Jones, the jazzrock singer who made her New York debut (unless you count Saturday Night Live a few weeks ago) this last weekend at the Village Gate. This writer has had his reservations heretofore, and he has some of them still. But there can be no doubt that Miss Jones is a considerable talent, and that in live performance she makes an even stronger impact than she does on records or than she did in the rather artificial context of the Saturday Night Live show.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Canadiens Lament 3 Assists
description: MONTREAL, May 13  In the Forum, where the Canadiens occasionally lose but others hardly win, the Canadiens admitted that they lost today.

title: Rumania Increasing Food Prices
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, May 13 (AP)  Many food prices in Rumania will increase by about onethird tomorrow in the second such price rise in one year. The Government said today that the higher prices were part of the current fiveyear economic plan. The list of items affected by the 32.8 percent increase includes canned fruit and vegetables and canned fish and fish products. A decree signed by President Nicolae Ceausescu said the increases were expected to produce stimulation of economic enterprises.

title: Stage: The Utter Glory Of Morrissey Hall
description: THE Utter Glory of Morrissey Hall, a comic musical about chaus at an English girls school, moves by fits and starts. It takes off at times in a chain of delightful absurdities; the chain breaks frequently, leaving a great many limp and uncertain intervals.

title: POLLUTION ISSUE KEY IN DENVER PRIMARY
description: DENVER, May 13  Denver, still thought of as the milehigh city with pristine air and mountain spring water, is sitting through a nonpartisan mayoral race that is largely focused on its brown cloud and its water supply, along with transportation and housing problems.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON, May 13  One of the great legal victories for freedom of the press in our time was won the other day by The Sunday Times of London. The European Court of Human Rights decided that the paper had been wrongfully restrained by the British courts from publishing the results of an investigation into the thalidomide drug disaster.

title: MAYOR IS REPORTED PLANNING TO UNIFY AMBULANCE SYSTEMS
description: Mayor Koch has Liken steps to unify New York City's fragmented and competing emergency ambulance systems through the creation of a new uniformed service in the city, according to top city health officials.

title: TaxFree Mortgage Bond Fight
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  Brokers packed Away their hotpink resort wear and golf clubs on Friday in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., and prepared to don the usual pinstriped suits and briefcases for hearings in Washington on legislation that would prohibit the financing of housing mortgages through taxexempt municipal securities.

title: State Halts Bid For Interway
description: The Interway Corporation, a large transport equipment leasing company, said yesterday that the New York State Attorney General had issued a temporary prohibition last Friday against takeover bid by a major competitor, the Gelco Corporation.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TODAY

title: Argentina's Terror
description: BUENOS AIRES  Lieut. Gen. Jorge Rafael Videla, President of Argentina and head of the military junta that ousted the disintegrating Peron regime in 1976, speaks with pride as he recounts the junta's accomplishments during the past three years.

title: Thomas Kielty Scherman Dies; Founded Little Orchestra Society
description: Thomas Kielty Scherman, the founder, mainstay and conductor of The Little Orchestra Society through 27 seasons, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital of apparent heart failure. He was 61 years old and a resident of Central Park West.

title: TV: 'sacketts, 3 Western Brothers
description: THE Sacketts, on NBCTV tonight and tomorrow at o'clock, is based on two novels by Louis L'Amour. NBC advises that Mr. L'Amour's 74 western novels, 11 of them about the Sackett family, have sold more than 70 million copies, more than can be claimed by any other author of westerns.

title: Touring Soviet Five Loses
description: BOSTON, May 14 (AP)  Pat Ewing of Cambridge scored 19 points to lead a Bostonarea high school allstar basketball team to an 8579 victory over a touring Soviet junior squad Sunday. Zurab Grdzelidze, a 6foot9inch Soviet forward, scored a gamehigh 20 points. It was the fifth defeat for the Russians in seven games. They end the tour tomorrow in a game at St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens.

title: High Court Upholds Outside Directors
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that outside directors of mutual funds had the power under certain circumstances to seek to have a shareholders suit against the fund's management and its investment adviser dismissed.

title: Books of The Times
description: LET's see now: they squeezed some 800 pages out of the 30year life of the poet Hart Crane and two thick volumes out of William Faulkner's career. At that rate a biography of biography itself ought to be worth at least 2,500 pages in three volumes, shouldn'tlt? Yet Telling Lives: The Biographer's Art is only 151 pages long. And i; still manages to cover every major aspect of the art that I.ould thinkof Offhand  the problem of length andselectivity; the goals that biographers should strive for; the distinction between major and minor lives and how each should be approached; the question of the involyment of the biographer in his subject's life, and the attendant threat of oversubjectivity; the`role of autobiography and the relationship of biography to history. All in 151 pages.

title: Heads Down on a Rainy Monday
description: Huddled under umbrella, a man hurried past potted trees outside CBS Building on Avenue of the Americas yesterday as rain fell for the third straight day  a boon to trees but an annoyance to people. Forecast is for clearing skies.

title: California's Lieutenant Governor: An Adversary in Brown's Shadow
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., May 11 You might think of Jerry Brown and Mike Curb as the odd couple.

title: Fusion: The Answer to Fission?
description: NEVER before has the derivation of energy through the splitting of atoms been in greater disrepute. The accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania has been followed by reports suggesting that even lowlevel radiation from such plants can be hazardous.

title: Chelsea Persists as Ethnic Family Patterns Fade
description: Chelsea is not for families anymore, it's for individuals, said Helen Gilson, whose steelblue Irish eyes reflect anger as well as resignation over the changes she has seen in 60 years.

title: Sales Rise 39% For Small Cars
description: WASHINGTON, May 14, (AP) Spurred by inflation and fuel shortages, sales of small cars have increased 39 percent in the first four months of this year over the same period of 1978, the Department of Transportation said today.

title: Sale of Gasohol Begins in Suffolk Amid Questions by Wary Drivers
description: SHIRLEY, L.I., May 14  O.K., fill it up with gasohol, said Penny Flanagan, a highschool English teacher in this South Shore village on the suburban fringes of eastern Long Island.

title: Hugh N. Boyd, 67, ExPublisher Of New Brunswick Home News
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 14 (AP) Hugh N. Boyd, chairman of the board of directors and editorial chairman of The Home News of New Brunswick, died yesterday in Princeton Medical Center where he had been hospitalized since May 4 after he fell down a flight of steps at a Princeton restaurant and suffered a hemorrhage. He was 67 years old.

title: U.S. Navy Ships Continue to Call at Taiwan's Ports
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, May 11Despite the United States break in diplomatic relations, its naval vessels continue to make unpublicized calls at Taiwan's ports, and Chinese Nationalist military are still being trained in the United States In the use of Americansupplied weapons.

title: About Education
description: OUR generation, the generation of survivors, will never permit that lesson to be forgotten. said President Carter during the recent memorial services for the six million victims of the Holocaust. But many educators and historians are not convinced that the implications of even such unimaginable horrors will be fully understood and remembered unless the lessons of what happened, and why and how it could happen, are taught from generation to generation.

title: Stevens Assures Puerto Rico
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)  Ted Stevens, the Senate Republican whip, said today that Puerto Rico would be virtually guaranteed statehood if residents of the commonwealth wanted it. Puerto Ricans will vote on the issue in a plebiscite next year. Should they ask for it, Congress could not refuse it, the Alaska Republican said.

title: Federal Center Inmate Slashes Arms and Dies
description: A 33yearold inmate at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on Foley Square slashed his arms with a doubleedged razor blade in his cell early Sunday and, despite efforts by guards, paramedics and inmates, died later at BeekmanDowntown Hospital, a spokesman for the detention facility reported yesterday.

title: Carter's Clash With Congress on Gas Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  While Jimmy Carter was truing in choppy waters off Virginia Beach today, the reverberations of his collision with Congress last week over a standby gasoline rationing plan were still being heard on

title: The Road to Tyre Displays Lebanon's Scars of War
description: TYRE, Lebanon, May 11  The narrow road to this tiny port city parallels the Mediterranean and follows a rail track that once went all the way to Haifa in Palestine. Now Haifa is in Israel and no trains have gone there since l948. The tracks are brown with rust and covered in many places with vines and bright marigolds.

title: Notes on People
description: Little has been heard in recent years from Bernadette Devlin, a tempestuous representative of Northern Ireland's Roman Catholics. Ten years ago, at the age of 22, she became the youngest woman ever to sit in the Btish Parliament, and for the next few years she was an international symbol of militance. Then in 1974 she lost her seat in Parliament and dropped out of politics after marrying a schoolteacher, Michael McAllskey.

title: Around the Nation
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 14 (AP)  Medical investigators said today that they had asked each of 12,000 high school students to donate a small amount of blood to help find the cause of a serious outbreak of a flulike illness here.

title: Suspect Seized in 1977 Slaying Of Underworld Figure in Queens
description: A 30yearold Manhattan man, Francis T. Featherstme, was arrested yesterday in the 1977 shooting death of Michael J. Spillane, a reputed gang figure, authorities said.

title: Neve Survival Plan for Olympia Beer
description: TUMWATER, Wash.  The Olympia Brewing Company survived Prohibition by producing jams, jellies and a fruit drink called Applju. It survived World War II and packagingmaterial shortages by collecting, washing, sorting and reshaping thousands of metal caps used to seal its beer bottles.

title: Treasury Paying Accounts on Time
description: WASHINGTON, May 19  The backoffice squeeze at the United States Treasury is past, a senior official said today.

title: HoffmanLaRoche to Pay Million To 400 Women in JobBias Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)  HoffmanLaRoche Inc., a major drug manufacturer, has agreed to pay 400 women employees $1 million in back pay to correct alleged job discrimination patterns, the Labor Deoartment said today.

title: Joan Chandler Dead: Played on Broadway In My Three Angels
description: miss cnancier macle her Broadway debut in 1944 in The Late George Apley, the dramatization by John P. Marquand and George S. Kaufman of Mr. Marquand's novel, starring Leo G. Carroll and Janet Beecher. Miss Chandler played one of the two Apley children.

title: Theater: Prisoners of Quai Dong, a War Drama
description: ALTHOUGH there is only one guerrilla prisoner in Harold Willis's The Prisoners of Quai Dong, the plural in the title is there deliberately. For it is the author's argument that in Vietnam everyone  natives. Americans soldiers, civilians  were all locked in the same .suffocating prison. It is a point that has been made before by many others. Indeed, if the ingredients in Mr. Willis's play, which he has fashioned from a novel by Victur Kolpacoff, seem familiar, it is because they have turned up innumerable times in the many books, plays and motion pictures tha; have intervened since The Prisoner: of Quai Dong was written more than a decade ago.

title: High Court to Consider InsiderCase Conviction
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)  The Supreme Court agreed today to consider whether a New York financial district printer who used information from his job to purchase stock in companies scheduled for takeover attempts was wrongfully convicted.

title: Symbol of Mets' Woes: Montanez Is Batting .155
description: PITTSBURGH, May 14  Willie Montanez, who usually bats in the cleanup position, has not been hitting and the Mets have not been winning. Is there a connection?

title: Studies Suggest A Harmful Shift In Today's Menu
description: RECENT investigations into the dietary habits of prehistoric peoples and their primate predecessors suggest that heavy meateating by modern affluent societies may be exceeding the biological capacities evolution built into the human body. The result may be a host of dietrelated health problems, such as diabetes, obesity, high blood pressure, coronary heart disease and some cancers.

title: Big Board Election Change
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that members had approved an amendment to permit the election on May 24 of two or more vice chairmen of the exchange. The move was viewed by some members as an effort to convince John J. Phelan Jr., the exchange's only vice chairman, to remain in office amid suggestions that the workload had grown too heavy. Mr. Phelan, an exchange specialist, recently said that after four years in office he did not intend to run again.

title: Doled, Bakered and Bushed in New Hampshire
description: MANCHESTER, N.H.  In the Granite State of New Hampshire, where the first Presidential primary in the nation is held every four years, the hotel and motel owners, the restaurant proprietors, and the carrental agencies all have big, happy smiles on their faces. Never before has the courting of New Hampshire voters started so early for a Presidential campaign.

title: Bridge:
description: A big lead almost went to waste in the Cavendish Club Invitational Pair Championships, which ended here Sunday night. Kit Woolsey and Ed Manfield, both of Arlington, Va., were far ahead of their nearest pursuers after the first day's play, and they still led by 737 international match points going into the final session, but then they hit trouble.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, known as MONY, one of the nation's largest life insurers, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a subsidiary, the North American Life and Casualty Company, Minneapolis, to the West German insurance cornpany Allianz Versicherungs A.G. for $138.3 million.

title: After Harsh Debate, Canadian Candidates Focus on Undecided Vote
description: OTTAWA, May 14  The three major party leaders battered one another in a twohour television debate last night as they began the final days of campaigning for the election a week from tomorrow.

title: Storm Kills 52 in India
description: NEW DELHI, May 14 (Reuters)  The death toll from the hurricane and floods on the southeast Indian coast over the weekend rose to at least 52 today. Local officials said about 160,000 dwellings had been destroyed or damaged in Andhra Pradesh State.

title: Texan Held by Colombian Indians Admits Plan to Smuggle Marijuana
description: BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, May 14  A Texas pilot who says he is being held for ransom by Indians in a remote part of Colombia said last night that he had been trying to pick up a load of marijuana for delivery in the United States when he and a Houston fireman landed a plane on the Colombian coast two weeks ago.

title: Death Threats Cited By Refugee Informer In Paraguayan Case
description: A Paraguayan refugee said here yesterday that he had received death threats because of his role in tracking down  in Brooklyn a former Paraguayan police official who has been accused by international groups of being a member of a political death squad.

title: Companies List Their Sales and Earnings Reports for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) irldi cafes stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 14 Mickey Steurer, the cocaptain of Princeton's National Invitation Tournament championship basketball team in 1975, was named the university's assistant basketball coach today, replacing Bob Dukiet, now the head coach at St. Peter's.

title: Tennis
description: AT VIENNA

title: CAR WORKERS SHOW SWING TO TORY SIDE
description: OXFORD, England, May 10  When John Patten began to run for Parliament here a few years ago, his 6 A.M. visits to British Leyland's sprawling Cowley works east of town brought nothing but grief. The workers tossed his leaflets back at him, unleashed a stream of abuse and sometimes gave the Oxford geography teacher, who was on the Conservative ticket, concern for his safety.

title: Silkwood Radiation Case Is Ready for Jurors Today
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, May 14  Was a 28yearold laboratory technician named Karen G. Silkwood contaminated by radioactivity because of negligence on the part of one of the country's major nuclearenergy companies? Or did she, as a union activist, accidentally contaminate herself while trying to manufacture evidence against the company?

title: HomeBond Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  Members of the House Ways and Means Committee expressed deep reservations today over a bill to curb the use of state and local taxexempt securities to finance housing, and the bill's sponsors held out the prospect that their sweeping proposal would be modified.

title: Highs/Lows
description: New York Stock Exchange Listed Issues

title: Use of Challenged Tests Is Barred by Macchiarola
description: New York City's School Chancellor, Frank J. Macchiarola, citing an erratic scoring pattern in the annual citywide reading test taken by 460,000 elementary and junior high school students in March, ordered principals throughout the city yesterday not to use the tests to determine ounil promotion or a school's rank.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: IN THE NATION
description: Senator Howard Baker, the minority leader, is crying foul because President Carter recently argued that Senate rejection of SALT II would give the United States the image of a warmonger. But Mr. Carter was right; and

title: TV: Drama of Hodgkin's Disease
description: HODGKIN'S disease is the pits, the heroine of Walking Through the Fire is told by her roommate soon after being admitted to the hospital for an examination that will show that she, too, is afflicted.

title: Hopkins Is Team To Beat
description: Johns Hopkins begins the final round in defense of its national lacrosse championship tomorrow.

title: Deaths
description: CLAYMANEdna. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Dr. Mordecai L. Gabriel, President

title: Indian Ocean Called Vienna Topic.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 14 The Soviet Union and the United States intend to discuss their longstalled talks on limiting military forces in the Indian Ocean when President Carter meets next month with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader.

title: Lambert M. Huppeler, 71, Dies; ExHead of Consulting Concern
description: Lambert M. Huppeler, founder of the Lambert M. Huppeler Company of Manhattan, died Saturday at a nursing home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 71 years old and had also lived in Naples, Fla.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Mack Trucks Sells 10% of Its Shares
description: Mack Trucks Inc., one of the nation's largest truck makers, said that It had completed sale of 10 percent of its common stock and $85 million in convertible debentures, which can be con

title: Big Drop Seen in U.S. Payments Gap
description: PARIS, May 14  Anthony M. Solomon. Under Secretary of the Treasury, today predicted a further substantial reduction in the country's balanceofpayments deficit next year, but at the cost of a pronounced economic slowdown.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Koch Asked by China To Postpone Fall Trip
description: After months of anticipating cultural exchange, new business ties and authentic Chinese cuisine, Mayor Koch has been informed by government officials that his trip to China, scheduled for this fall, must be postponed until next year because of overcrowding.

title: Screwdrivers For Gump
description: MONTREAL, May 14  When the bar waiter aproached, Gump Worsley looked up and asked, You have nygrapefruit juice?

title: TokyoMoscow Talks Begin
description: TOKYO, May 14 (AP)  The deputy foreign ministers of Japan and the Soviet Union opened two days of talks today aimed at improving relations. between the countries.

title: A. I. Makarevsky, 75, of Soviet
description: MOSCOW, May 14 (UPI)  Aleksandr I. Makarevsky, a Soviet aviation engineer, died Friday at the age of 75, the newspaper Sotsialisticheskaya Industriya said today. A graduate of the Bauman Technical College, Mr. Makarevsky served from 1950 to 1960 as director of the Central Aerodynamics Institute, a major research and development center in aviation engineering, at the town of Zhukovsky, 20 miles southeast of Moscow.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Canada Life Assurance Company has elected to its board of directors Richard L. Terrell, recently retired vice chairman of the General Motors Corp ration.

title: Police in North Bergen Seek to Check Papers Outgoing Mayor Took
description: NORTH BERGEN, N.J., May 14Hudson County detectives are trying to determine what documents may be missing from the town hall here after outgoing Mayor Peter M. Mocco was seen loading boxes into a car.

title: Senator Dole Joins G.O.P. Race For 80 Presidential Nomination
description: RUSSELL, Kan., May 14  Senator Robert Dole announced today to a hometown audience of friends, school bands and fellow veterans that he was running for President, committed to getting the American people to believe in themselves again instead of relying on Washington.

title: Boy to Press Effort to Play On Girls Volleyball Team
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 14 (AP) Donald Gomes will take his case to the Supreme Court of the United States in a final effort to play on the girls volleyball team at his high school, his lawyer said today.

title: Mickey Sheds Light On Human Behavior
description: MICKEY MOUSE has passed his 50th birthday, but he appears much younger today than when he was born of Walt Disney's pen in 1928.

title: A Portrait on Tape
description: Jacob Goodwin is 29 years old and Daniel Lieberstein is 30, but they spend their days strolling down memory lane with people who are old enough to be their grandparents.

title: TURKEY WOULD BAR U2 USE OF AIRSPACE IF SOVIET OBJECTED
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  Turkey has told the United States that only if Moscow does not object will it allow the American U2 reconnaissance planes to fly over its territory to check on Soviet compliance with the arms limitation treaty.

title: Pianist: David Hollander
description: SCHUMANN and Schubert comprised the bill of fare for David Hollander's piano recital Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall  Schumann's Kinderscenen (of which this writer missed the first half) and Kreisleriana, separated before the intermission by Schubert's four Impromptus (Op. 142.).

title: Rangers Swamp TV Opposition
description: The first game of the Stanley Cup final between the Rangers and Montreal Canadiens overwhelmed all its television opposition in the metropolitan area Sunday, according to the Nielsen ratings.

title: EDUCATION
description: MORE than a century ago, Harvard Law School Dean Christopher Columbus Langdell revolutionized the study of law by introducing the case method, through which students learned by reading and analyzing the decisions of appellate courts. Opposition to the innovation among faculty members and the practicing bar led to the creation of a new law schodl at Boston University to provide what was then termed an antidote to the theoretical tendencies alarmingly displayed at Harvard.

title: Gov. Brown to Order More Filling Stations To Open on Weekends
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 14 (AP) Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., in a move to cut long lines of motorists in search of gasoline, said today that he would sign orders implementing several new energy proposals, including one that will require more California gasoline stations to remain open on weekends.

title: Deaths
description: BLAUAbram, M.D. On May 14, 1979. Husband of the late Anna Blau. Father of Meryl B. Menon, brother of Samuel Blau of Montreal, Canada. Interment private.

title: Zambia Leader Survives Mishap
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, May 14 (AP) Prime Minister Daniel Lisulo of Zambia nearly suffocated today when he was trapped for 30 minutes in an elevator, officials said. Mr. Lisulo, who reportedly was visibly shaken when rescued, was trapped when electricity failed after he boarded the elevator to reach his office.

title: The City
description: More than 13,000 city workers would be eliminated through attrition during a threeyear period as part of a financial plan to balance the city's budget.

title: Top Court Backs Curb on Inmates At Foley Sq. Jail
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  The Supreme Court, reversing two lower Federal courts, ruled today that conditions at the new Federal jail on Foley Square in New York City did not violate the constitutional rights of inmates awaiting trial.

title: Palestinian Rule Splits the Israelis
description: JERUSALEM, May 14  Israeli officials met for three hours today to coordinate various recommendations for Arab selfrule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, and wide differences were reported between the Government majority and the military.

title: COURT, 63, TIGHTENS BAN ON SEX BARRIER IN EDUCATION LAW
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  The Supreme Court significantly strengthened the Federal law that bars sex discrimination in education today by ruling that the law gives individuals the right to bring sex discrimination suits against schools and colleges.

title: First City Ethics Review To Begin for Councilman
description: When the City Council Ethics Committee closets itself in a meeting room tomorrow in the matter of Eugene F. Mastropieri, it will be making history.

title: CHILE JUDGE REFUSES TO YIELD 3 TO U.S.
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 14  Chile's Chief Justice today rejected a United States request for the extradition of three Chilean Army officers indicted in Washington for the murder of a Chilean exile there in 1976.

title: House Votes to Trim $2.5 Billion From Its Own 80 Budget Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  An economyminded House slashed an additional $2.5 billion in spending from its own version of the 1980 budget and then voted to accept the financial package by a surprisingly large margin, 220 to 184.

title: Lave to Curb Cable TV Competition Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  Executives in the television industry and in professional sports called on Congress today to enact a law to give them a stake in the growth of cable television systems and to provide some protection against competition from cable systems.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, May 14,1979

title: Debut: Ann Greenfield, Mezzo
description: ANN GREENFIELD, whose New York debut took place Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a young mezzosoprano who graduated from the Oberlin Conservatory and now studies in New York. Miss Greenfield made a positive impression. Though she does not sing with all the freedom and authority of a seasoned recitalist, her interpretations are conscientious and on track, and her ample, warmly cushioned voice is very pleasing to listen to.

title: I.M.F. Reduces the Gold Sold at Monthly Auctions
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)  The amount of gold sold by the International Monetary Fund at monthly auctions will be reduced to 444,000 ounces from 470,000 ounces, starting with next month's sale, the I.M.F. announced today.

title: Science Watch
description: Last week, atop Arizona's Mount Hopkins, a telescope was dedicated that ranks third in the world in lightgathering power and may serve as the prototype for an instrument far more powerful than any yet built.

title: Move Would Form Wall St.'s No. 2 Firm
description: Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. and Loeb Rhoades. Hornblower & Company announced plans yesterday to merge in a consolidation that would be the largest in Wall Street history.

title: Jets Top Draft Picks Get Their Feet Wet
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 14  Marty Lyons, the New York Jets No. 1 draft pick, was convinced that he had brought today's rain cloud with him all the way from Alabama. Mark Gastineau, the No. 2 pick, was telling anybody who would listen about the harrowing experience of being drafted twice.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TELLS ITS TERMS FOR PEACE
description: CAPE TOWN May 14  Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said today that South Africa would risk international economic sanctions rather than accept existing proposals for Westernbacked peace settlements in Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa.

title: Diagnostic Data Asks Trading Delay
description: Diagnostic Data Inc., a pharmaceutical research company based in Mountain View, Calif., announced it had asked the National Association of Securities Dealers to delay trading in its common stock until the company had a chance to explain publicly the reasons for a delay in the Federal Drug Administration's approval of its new drug, Ontosein.

title: The Region
description: Tug Crewman Killed After Going Berserk

title: William Backer Leaves McCann
description: William M. Backer, 52yearold vice chairman and creative director of McCannErickson, resigned yesterday because of philosophical differences with the Interpublic Group of Companies, the parent company.

title: City Raiders Bar 18 Cabs as Unsafe, Cite 25 Others
description: Five inspectors from New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission staged a dawn raid yesterday, removing medallions from 18 cabs for unsafe and dangerous conditions and serving 61 summonses for mechanical violations on 25 to 30 other cabs, according to Jay L. Turnft, the commission chairman.

title: G.M., to End Suit, Agrees To Optional Car Radios
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  The General Motors Corporation has settled an antitrust suit by agreeing to restore car radios to the status of optional rather than standard equipment on 13 models, including the company's new Xbody cars, the new generation of small cars intended to meet the Government's fuelefficiency standards.

title: A Better Break for Rangers: Nilsson Is Back for hup Finals After Injury
description: MONTREAL, May 14  Just in case the pain in Ulf Nilsson's right ankle stops reminding him of that night more than 11 weeks ago, the pictures are still in mind. The Garden. The Islanders. The twoonone with Anders Hedberg, his closest friend on the Rangers. The miss. The loose puck in the corner. The defenseman  Denis Potvin  coming from behind. The boards. The ice, where his foot was caught. The check.

title: Assemblymen Tour Nuclear Plant
description: BUCHANAN, N.Y., May 14  After touring a Consolidated Edison Company nuclear power plant here this morning, a group of Assemblymen said they were still unconvinced about the safety of such generating facilities.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Adams, Stanley

title: Central African Empire Accused of Killing Students
description: PARIS, May 14 (AP) Amnesty International charged today that about 100 students were killed by soldiers in the Central African Empire last month because they objected to wearing uniforms to class.
