title: A Broadway Gala for Lerner and Loewe
description: Julie Andrews, Rex Harrison, Herrnione Gingold, Louis Jaurdan and other big names of the musical theater paid tribute last night to two men who probably did as much as anyone else to make them stars  Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe.

title: Search Narrows In Four Murders In Bedford Hills
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., May 14 The investigation of four executionstyle murders in this affluent Westchester County community entered a new phase today, according to the county prosecutor, with detectives narrowing their search and eliminating theories about the crimes that he said still appear to have been motivated by burglary.

title: Consolidation Trend Still Active on Wall Street as Firms Struggle for Survival
description: The merger trend that has haunted Wall Street for a decade refuses to go away.

title: TAX UNION PLAYING CHIEF ROLE IN DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  At the headquarters of the National Taxpayers Union, in a row house on Capitol Hill, they call it our constitutional convention. They deny that the opponents or proponents of abortion or busing or free speech or firearms could take control and extensively rewrite the United States Constitution.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, MAY 15, 1979

title: The Doctor's World
description: HOUSE CALLS are one of medicine's most restricted services, sought for their convenience by many more people than there are doctors willing to make them. Once standard part of medical practice, house calls now are a romantic fantasy of the horse-and-buggy era to younger Americans who have never had a physician treat them at home.

title: Lester Flatt Is Buried in Tennessee's Hills
description: SPARTA, Tenn., May 14  Lester Flatt returned today to the hard, unyielding, Tennessee hill country whence he and his music came.

title: EARNINGS
description: The J.C. Penney Company reported yesterday a 6.1 percent increase in profits for its first fiscal quarter, ended April 28, on a sales gain of 6.9 percent. Net income for the nation's thirdlargest retailer was 335 million, or 51 cents a share, up from $33 million, or 50 cents a share, on 2.5 million more shares out standing this year. The report is the first to be issued by a retail chain for the April quarter, an accounting period general in the industry.

title: About New York
description: It was the last rehearsal, with only two hours until the concert, and some of the old people were swaying with pleasure up on the stage as they sang Israeli Lullaby.

title: Gasoline Problems Weaken Market
description: Investors continuing concern over gasoline supply problems sent the stock market down moderately yesterday in sluggish trading. Gambling issues, which were hard hit Thursday, were the best performers.

title: Adoptive Families: Reunion Picnic in the Suburbs
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 12 What with the rain and a toytractor traffic jam on the lawn, the picnic had all the trappings of any children's party. The children scampered around, and their parents talked about what they would tell the youngsters when they were old enough to ask where they came from.

title: Teeth Show Fruit Was The Staple
description: PRELIMINARY studies of fossil teeth have led an anthropologist to the startling suggestion that early human ancestors were not predominantly meat eaters or even eaters of seeds, shoots, leaves or grasses. Nor were they omnivorous. Instead, they appear to have subsisted chiefly on a diet of fruit.

title: Bus Strike Over For First Group Of the Disabled
description: A yellow school van pulled up at Public School 182 in the Bronx at 8:15 yesterday morning, and Dewitt, Maribel and seven other children, some in wheelchairs, others on crutches, made their way to the schoolhouse door.

title: Taiwan RaisesTrade Surplus
description: TAIPEI, May 14 (AP) Taiwan's trade surplus widened in April to $150 million from $89 million in the yearearlier month, an economic official said today.

title: B Lorry's Stores Agree to Correct Ads On Liquidation Sale
description: B & B Lorry's, a chain of bankrupt men'swear shops in the New York area that has been advertising what it said was a courtordered liquidation sale for more than half a year agreed yesterday in Federal Court to run corrective advertising.

title: Letters
description: Pollution Control's Unduly High Price Tag

title: Concert: Isaac Stern at Y
description: THERE were ups and there were downs at last night's gala benefit concert at the 92d Street Y for that organization's performing arts fund. But the ups were sufficiently high that the evening could be counted a memorable one. (Interested music lovers can try to obtain seats for tomorrow night's repeat, which replaces the cancelled Rudolf Serkin recital at the Y.)

title: John Swope, Noted Photographer
description: John Swope, a photographer who had a long association with Hollywood and the theater and who was also a theatrical producer, died Friday at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 70 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Pop: Buffy SainteMarie Sings
description: BUFFY SAINTEMARIE, who was at the Bottom Line On Sunday night, provides potent ammunition for opponents of musical labeling. At various points in her early show one legitimately could have said she was playing and singing traditional tolk ballads, middleoftheroad pop, protest songs, progressive rock, soft rock, and American Indian chants. Yet she did not have to work hard at surmounting any barriers between the supposedly diverse idioms; everything she did came out sounding like Buffy SainteMarie.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of precious metals futures surged yesterday on late buying, much of it from overseas, where inflation fears have been growing recently. The buying was provoked by a surprising rebound in Comex silver futures early in the session as traders braced for carryover selline that beean last Friday.

title: Vandals Ravage Brooklyn Public School
description: Vandals, apparently working throughout the weekend, systematically ravaged Public School 159 in Brooklyn. They slashed stage curtains, smashed doors, overturned furniture, shredded records and destroyed musical instruments.

title: Paper in English for Latin Region Begins Publication in So Paulo.
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 14(Reuters)  A new Englishlanguage newspaper began publication here and in other major cities of Latin America today.

title: Saudis Scuttle a BillionDollar Arms Consortium With Factories in Egypt
description: CAIRO, May 14  A billiondollar consortium founded four years ago to try to make the Arabs more selfreliant in armaments today became the latest casualty of the Arab reaction against Egypt's peace settlement with Israel.

title: East Europeans Show Disdain For Soviet Life
description: BUDAPEST  After 34 years of Communist rule, much of Eastern Europe wears the Soviet brand of MarxismLeninism like an illfitting mask, covering a broad distaste for the Soviet system.

title: Kennedy Offers Broad Health Plan And challenges Carter to Support It
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  Challenging President Carter to join him in an effort to make quality health care a right for all our people, Senator Edward M. Kennedy introduced his longgestating national health insurance legislation today.

title: 69 Endowed Scholarships Cut Duke's Athletic Costs
description: DURHAM, N.C.  While intercollegiate athletics have become so expensive that many major college administrators find it virtually impossible to solve their fiscal difficulties. Duke University has a surprisingly optimistic attitude toward the future of bigtime varsity snorts.

title: Tigers Beat Yanks On Wilcox 4Hitter
description: Milt Wilcox, a native Hawaiian, who calls his slow curve ball a yackadoo, used that pitch plus an assortment of others to stop the Yankees and Reggie Jackson last night in a 31 Detroit victory.

title: Events
description: Theater

title: A Pump Too Far
description: A clever Southern California commuter beat the gas lines last week by taking a plane from one Los Angeles airport to another. That way of coping with the gasoline shortage won't work for everybody, however, and it is obviously time to start thinking about more practical remedies.

title: Concert: Sir Georg Leads Chicagoans
description: FOR several seasons now rumblings of discontent have been heard from a faction of New York concertgoers over the continued popularity of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and its conductor, Sir Georg Solti. This sort of backlash invariably develops whenever any reign has gone on for an unusual stretch of time. Stokowski and the Philadelphia felt it in the 1930's. And in their own times, so did Toscanini and George Szell. Solti/Chicago, you might say, are overdue to be pulled down from their pedestal.

title: Carey Proposes $797 Million Plan For Transit, Including City Subway
description: ALBANY, May 14  Governor Carey proposed a plan today to spend $797 million to upgrade New York City subways and improve commuter and freight rail lines around the state. The proposal includes a new $350 million state bond issue that could be put before the voters in the fall.

title: ExNavy Man Wants Nautilus Preserved at Groton
description: WASHINGTON, May 19  Frank Scheetz, a former Navy quartermaster who lives in Groton, Conn., offered a pro posal today that would save taxpayers. $19 million and preserve the Nautilus, the world's first nuclearpowered submarine, as a public memorial at her birthplace in Connecticut.

title: Figures in Carey's Plan On Rail Transportation
description: ALBANY, May 14  The following is the breakdown of Governor Carey's $797 million railtransportation proposal. The figures under the State column refer to funds that would be obtained from a $350 million bond issue, which would need voter approval.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Manila Bishop Assails Regime for Quashing Protest of U.N. Parley
description: MANILA, May 14  A prominent Roman Catholic bishop denounced the martiallaw Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos today for sending not policemen against several hundred dissidents who gathered yesterday to discuss the irrelevance for poor people of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development under way here.

title: Australia Defeats Italy For Nations Cup Title, 21
description: DUESSELDORF, West Germany, May 14 (AP)  John Alexander and Phil Dent defeated Adriano Panatta and Paolo Bertolucci in the doubles today to give Australia a 21 victory over Italy in the Ambre Solaire Nations Cup tennis final.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Because of the Doppler effect, will the pitch of a train whistle become higher and higher as the train moves with a constant speed toward a stationary listener?

title: Enemy Dept. Is Studying Changes in Gas Pricing
description: The Lnergy Department is considering a ceiling on the price spread at the pump between leaded and unleaded gasoline that could cost motorists several hundred million dollars a year, a petroleum newsletter reported yesterday. The gap is now 4.8 cents a gallon. Average.price changes likely to result would be small, the Lundberg Letter said, but because of the huge gallonage involved, the aggregate cost would be significant.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: Beaths

title: Floating Point Plans To Oppose Lawsuit
description: Floating Point Systems Inc., Portland, Ore., said it planned to oppose a lawsuit filed by the Enterprise Wallpaper Manufacturing Company on behalf of itself and other stock purchasers, charging violations of securities laws regarding Floating's public offering of stock last year.

title: Bail on the Back Burner
description: Mayor Koch's study bill on bail marks his overdue entry into the serious discussion of pretrial detention in criminal cases. The bill, though flawed, reflects months of research and thought. It is a welcome contrast to the Mayor's repeated, thoughtless denunciations of Judge Bruce Wright's recent release of a defendant without bail.

title: Deaths
description: FRANKELCharles and Helen. The staff, trustees and Fellows of the National Humanities Center deeply mourn the deaths of this sensitive and compassionate couple. As President of the National Humanities Center, Charles Frankel inspired us all. Charles and Helen were our friends and they will be deeply missed.

title: Yields on Bills Off at Treasury
description: Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and the 182day maturities.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WHAT PRICE LIFE? Robert Cormier, author of After the First Death, will discuss the new novel tomorrow at a seminar to be presented from 12:30 to 2  P.M. at B. Dalton's Book Store, on the lower level of the Author's Plaza, Fifth Avenue and 52d Street. Admission is free.

title: Californians, Fearing Gas Lines, Rediscover LoneDistance Bus
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., May 11 With service stations as dry as this desert retreat, many Californians have rediscovered the longdistance bus.

title: NBC Struts Its Peacock for Affiliates
description: LOS ANGELES, May 14  With little to boast about in the present, after a seasa tin which its audiencepopularity ratings bad slipped in most parts of the day, NBCTV is putting the accent an the past and the future in its annual meeting here this week with representatives of the 215 television stations that make up the network  the past to evoke the glory that once had been NBC's, the future to signify that the network is on the road to recovery.

title: Indy 500 Officials Decide Not to Use Pacer Lights
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 14 (AP) United States Auto Club officials announced today that pacer lights, which have been a subject of criticism at the Indianapolis 500, would not be used at the Mav 27 race.

title: Stage: 'second Thoughts, a Musical
description: SECOND Thoughts is a frail musical about a young black who grows up in Alabama and comes to New York where he writes a Broadway play.

title: Doctor Practices From a Gas Line
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 (UPI) The obligations of medical practice are one thing, but California's gasoline shortage is another and yesterday, Dr. Myles Lippe found the two on a collision course.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Taxes
description: CONGRESS, upset over oil profits, is growling anew at one of the oil companies favorite ways to cut their taxes. By an overwhelming vote, the House of Representatives last week took an unexpected swipe at the oil companies foreign tax credits.

title: Bertrand N. Honea Is Dead at 92; ExBoard Head of Paper in Texas
description: FORT WORTH, May 19 (AP)  Bertrand Needham Honea, former board chairman of The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, died yesterday. He was 92 years old.

title: BISINESS Digest
description: In what would be the biggest merger in Wall Street history, Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. and Loeb Rhoades Hombiower & Company announced plans to create a giant brokerage and investment firm with total capital of about $250 million. The new name of the firm would be Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., and it would rank second in size only to Merrill Lynch & Company, which has a capital base of $720 million. [Page D1.]

title: A Good Season for Caterpillars
description: NEW HAVEN, May 14 (AP)  Dry weather is being blamed for an unusually bad infestations of Eastern tent caterpillars in Connecticut this spring. The caterpillar's white, webby tents are being reported in trees across the state in greater quantities than usual, according to Kenneth Welch, assistant entomologist at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station here. Defoliation at Roaring Brook Nature Center in Canton Is the worst in four or five years, according Jay Kaplan, director of the center. The caterpillars do not fare well in damp weather,, Mr. Kaplan said.

title: World News Briefs
description: JERUSALEM, May 14  Two American students who were under deportation orders from the Israeli Government left the country today. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said they had departed of their own free will but did not say where they went.

title: ALGERIA TO DEMAND 20% OIL PRICE RISE
description: ALGIERS, May 14  At next month's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Geneva, Algeria will demand a 20 percent rise in oil prices, according to its new Energy Minister, Belkacem Nabi. Thus, postBoumedienne Algeria, with one or the most amDlttous industrialization plans in the third world and running a heavy foreign debt, shows no signs of easing its militancy within OPEC.

title: Concert: Bellini's Version of Romeo and Juliet
description: CONSIDERING opera's fascination with thwarted love, vendettas and death, it is odd that the Romeo and Juliet tale has not attracted more of the genre's important composers. After you have mentioned Gounod, Bellini and Delius, the list dries up quickly. Why, for instance, did Verdi and Boito, with their Shakespearean leanings, pass up a chance to end an opera with a marvelous double suicide? Too easy, perhaps. Whatever the reasons, they did not faze Bellini, whose greatly underesteemed I Capuleti e i Montecchi was given powerful performance by the Opera Orchestra of New York on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Rangers Carefree, Foe Grim
description: MONTREAL, May 14  The Rangers, did not leave New York behind. They took it with them and, after their 41 victory in yesterday's opener of the Stanley Cup. hockey finals, transformed the staid Forum into a noisy offBroadway theater.

title: Javelin Settlement With S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that Canadian Javelin Ltd. had settled charges filed in 1976 against the company and its officers, directors and controlling shareholders. The litigation, the latest in the Canatian mining and exploration company's long history of troubles with the United States regulatory agency, involved the commission's allegations that the company had made false and misleading disclosures in reports to the agency. In particular, the agency alleged that the company could not account for a $700,000 payment in 1972 to Owl Investments Ltd., a Grand Cayman corporation.

title: Georgian Enters NoContest Plea To Charge by Jury in Lance Case
description: ATLANTA, May 14 (AP)  A former Georgia banker, indicted in March by Federal grand jury investigating former Budget Director Bert Lance, appeared before a Federal District judge today to change his plea from innocent to no contest on one of the counts against him.

title: Chemical Sues Andersen Over Frigitemp Reports
description: The Chemical Bank filed a $6.6 million damage suit against Arthur Andersen & Company in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday, accusing the giant accounting and auditing firm of issuing false and fraudulant financial reports on the condition of the Frigitemp Corporation.

title: Newly Resurgent Klan in Alabama Is Closely Watched by U.S. Agents
description: DECATUR, Ala., May 12  After four years of no more than routine interest in a seemingly moribund Ku Klux Klan, the Federal authorities in Alabama are now once again paying close attention to the newly resurgent and sometimes violent racist organization.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Detroit Tigers, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. ( TelevisionChannel 11, S P.M. RadioWINS, 8 P.M.)

title: 2 Texans Killed in Plane Crash
description: Al. BUQUERQUE, N.M., May 14 (AP)  Two Leytelland, Tex., men were killed when a light plane crashed just after takeoff from Albuquerque International Airport. The Police said Michael Wayne Boyd, 28 years old, died yesterday at the scene and Jerry Roberts, 28, died at local hospital.

title: Market Place
description: FOR thousands of investors who purchased shares in the AutoTrain Corporation at the initial offering price of $8.90 a share in 1971, the current trading rage may be the best thing to happen since the soaring prices of the early 1970's.

title: Advertising.
description: I THINK we have another Smokey Bear, said Stuart B. Upson, chairman and chief executive of DancerFitzgeraldSample, the nation's 13thlargest ad agency, as he and a number of his associates gazed lovingly at a sketch of a bloodhoundlike dog wearing a trenchcoat.

title: Topics Alarms and Incursions
description: Summary executions by the komitehs, the Islamic managers of the Iranian revolution, have now climbed to more than 200. The vigilantelike killings have caused international concern, and Prime Minister Bazargan not long ago admitted embarrassment that his provisional Government could not control the situation.

title: Medical College To Oppose Pact To Do Abortions
description: The director of health and hospitals for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York said yesterday that he would seek to nullify a proposed agreement under which New York Mdical College would be expected by the city to provide abortion services at Lincoln and Metropolitan municipal hospitals.

title: U.S.China Trade Pact Is Initialed
description: CANTON, May 14  The United States and China initialed a longsought trade agreement today, paving the way for greater American access to the vast Chinese market and for expanded Chinese exports to the United States.

title: Pauline Kael Out of Movie Project With Beatty
description: LOS ANGELES, May 14  Pauline Kael, the film critic who left The New Yorker a few months ago to become production executive with the actor Warren Beatty, is now  in a game of musical chairs  a consultant and scout at Paramount.

title: Steel Haulers Lose Rate Plea
description: WASHINGTON May 14 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission temporarily denied today a 5 percent rate increase requested by the nation's steel haulers.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Harold Tanner; an executive vice president of Blyth Eastman Dillon & Company, has been named chairman of its operating committee, a position that places him in the top echelon of the brokerage and investment banking firm. As Wall Street sources size up the promotion, Mr. Tanner will likely serve as righthand man to Alvin V. Shoemaker, Blyth's president and chief executive officer. For its part, the securities firm was vague about Mr. Tanner's exact position in the pecking order. A spokesman simply noted that Blyth has a president and chief executive officer, a chairman, two vice chairmen and many executive vice presidents. (Blyth is controlled by the INA Corporation, which owns the Insurance Company of North America.)

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: A highgrade utility bond issue was priced yesterday to yield 9.82 percent, and investors showed no inclination to rush to buy the securities, even though a good case could be made that the rate of return was the highest for such securities since late 1975.

title: Dressed to Kill In Nomad's Land
description: The following is excerpted from the contents of a small brown folder distributed to store buyers, the press, private customers and admirers who attended the recent opening showing of the Mary McFadden FallWinter 79 fashion collection at the Circle in the Square Theatre.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: BLAST DAMAGES JAIL IN ROME: Explosion from a bomb in a car parked outside the Queen of Heaven jail in Rome damaged nearby vehicles and a water main, causing local flooding. A gate to the jail was blown apart. The Popular Revolutionary Movement, a leftist organization, took responsibility.

title: $2.4 Billion Home Loan Issue Is Set
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks announced yesterday that they would sell $2.4 billion of bonds this week to refinance $2.18 billion of maturing securities and to raise about $200 million of additional money to aid the housing industry.

title: OBSERVER
description: When Nikita Khrushchev visited the United States in 1959, President Eisenhower sent him on a helicopter tour of Washington and suburbs during the rush hour. Khrushchev came back apalled by the spectacle of machinery and exhaust fumes spread out beneath him. Such a thing, he said, must never be permitted to develop in the Soviet Union.

title: PARKING RULES
description: Alternate side parking regulations wilf be in effect in Brooklyn today so that trash accumulated during the tugboat strike can be removed. The rules, which will be suspended in all other parts of the city, will later be applied in the other boroughs, in rotation.

title: Talmadge's Accountant Questioned on Payments
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI) Senator Herman E. Talmadge's accountant said today that he did not learn of excess expense reimbursements paid to the Georgia Democrat until June 1978, even though the issue was raised in nine months earlier, during the Senator's divorce proceedings.

title: Allstate Cuts Rates On G.M. XBody
description: NORTHBROOK, Ill., May 14 (AP)  The Allstate Insurance Company, one of the nation's largest auto insurers, announced today that its collision and comprehen. sive rates on the General Motors Corporation's new Xbody series of autos would be reduced immediately.

title: 2 Houston ExOfficers Sentenced
description: HOUSTON, May 14  Two former Houston policemen were given fiveyear suspended sentences in Federal District Court today for conspiring to fabricate evidence and lying to a grand jury in the case of a Louisiana youth shot to death by one of the officers in a chase.

title: Deutsche Bank Opens U.S. Drive
description: The Deutsche Bank, the largest nonAmerican bank in the world, has opened its doors on West 57th Street and, armed with some distinct advantages, it is expected to be a formidable competitor for its American counterparts.

title: Democrats Plan Direct Primary Ballot
description: Continuing a democratization process that began eight years ago, top New York Democrats have agreed that next year, for the first time, Democratic voters will be :able to choose directly among Presidential candidates listed on the primary ballot.

title: Polaroid, Citing Slowing In Market, to Lay Off 800
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 15 (AP)  Citing excess inventories and a softening in the instant photography market, officials of the Polaroid Corporation, today announced the company's first productionline layoffs since the 1940's.

title: Carey Pushes Hongkong's Midland Bid
description: ALBANY, May 15  Governor Carey today stepped up his effort to obtain approval for the Hongkong & Shanghai Banking Corporation to take over Marine Midland Banks Inc. of Buffalo and said he would press for legislation to overcome some of the objections of Muriel F. Siebert, the State Banking Sunerintendent.

title: Plate Cracks Discovered In Nuclear Plant in Jersey
description: SALEM, N.J., May 15  Dents and cracks in some metal plates holding nuclear fuel rods in place at the Salem One generating plant have been discovered, prompting an examination of all such plates in the reactor by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.

title: Umpires Dispute Near Settlement
description: Baseball's regular umpires apparently are near a settlement with the American and National Leagues that could end a labor dispute that has lasted since before spring training.

title: De Lorean Chief Named
description: Eugene A. Cafiero, who resigned in March as vice chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, yesterday was named president and chief executive officer of the De Lorean Motor Company. Mr. Cafiero, 52 years old, had been president of Chrysler from 1975 until November 1978. De Lorean is constructing a pl4nt near Belfast, Northern Ireland, to produce a stainless steel sports car.

title: Westinghouse Suit By T.V.A. Settled
description: RICHMOND; May 15 (AP)  The Westinghouse Corporation and the Tennessee Valley Authority today reached a tentative courtapproved settlement of the T.V.A.'s uraniumsupply suit against the company.

title: Key Rule On Coal Modified
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  An important Department of Energy rule on coal conversion has been modified after White House officials ordered an earlier version withdrawn because of complaints by economists that the rule could have led to unnecessary costs.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Legislation Advancing To Save Striped Bass
description: Even as the first large striped bass of the year are caught in the surf off Martha's Vineyard Island, Mass. and not to forget the small stripers taken in the ocean off Long Island nearly two weeks ago  legislation intended to improve the lot of this highlyregarded food and game fish is advancing steadily through Congress.

title: Lamed G. Bradford, Chief Editor At Little, Brown From 55 to 68
description: MILTON, Mass., May 14 (AP)Lamed G. Bradford, an editor for such writers as Ngaio Marsh, J.D. Salinger, Norman Mailer and Henry A. Kissinger, died Saturday at his borne here. He was 68 years old.

title: Private Lives
description: THERE are women in the garden with hammers and saws. They are dismantling the rotten sun deck. They are turning the planks of the sun deck into firewood. They are creating a hole in the garden, which they will fill, with brave new sun deck, on a foundation of cement, to endure unto the second or third millennium of mortgages, a sort of space station with splinters. One day the brave new sun deck will be old and weathered, and so will we, and we will sit on it in our electric gocarts, waiting for a crocus, and Erik von Daniken or Immanuel Velikowsky will fall out of the Bermuda Triangle into our lap of repose, and it will be closing time in the gardens of the East.

title: Citicorp Note Rate Up
description: Citicorp reported yesterday that the average rate in its weekly sale of 91day notes rose to 10.211 percent from 10.180 percent last week. The new rate was the highest for the bank holding company's weekly sales since Feb. 27. Bids accepted ranged from 10.140 to 10.220 percent, including 42.3 percent of the bids at the high; a total of $671.3 million was submitted for the $100 million issue.

title: 2 City Hospitals to Do Abortions Despite Archdiocese
description: The president of the New York Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that abortions would be performed at Lincoln and Metropolitan municipal hospitals despite the opposition of New York Medical College, the Roman Catholicaffiliated medical school that will begin providing regionalized medical services at both institutions on July 1.

title: National Parks Expecting a Record For Visitors Despite Tight Gasoline
description: Despite gasoline shortages and inflation, the national parks are looking forward to more visitors this summer than ever before  a total, in terms of visitor days, considerably larger than the nation's population  and the National Park Service is planning a third try at setting up an advance reservation system for overnight stays.

title: Italian Civil Servants Out for Day
description: ROME, May 15 (AP)  About 2 million Italian civil servants staged a oneday strike today that closed airports, schools, courts and most government offices. Unions called the walkout to urge the Government to approve legislation to provide higher pay and improved benefits for 1979. Contracts expired at the end of last year.

title: TV: CBS Revives 36 You Can't Take It With You
description: YOU Can't Take It With You is the kind of play television has swiped completely from the stage. It is a situation comedy, the staple of television that, except for an occasional revival, is rarely seen on Broadway anymore.

title: Evidence Rights For Defendants Gain in Albany
description: ALBANY, May 15  Legislators and Governor Carey have reached agreement on a bill that would permit defendants in criminal cases to find out most of the evidence the state has against them befor2 their trials. negotiators disclosed today The bill calling for the pretrial discovery process, which would put New York in line with most other states, follows five years of discussions among legislators, court administrators, lawyers and district attorneys.

title: O'Hare Revises Taxiway Control
description: CHICAGO, May 15 (UPI)  Stricter controls on taxiways at O'Hare International Airport, the world's busiest, have been imposed because of a nearcollision on Feb. 15 between a passenger airliner and a landing cargo jet. The new procedures announced yesterday by the Federal Aviation Administration require air traffic controllers in charge of takeoffs and landings to permit taxiing aircraft to cross runways. Controllers in charge of ground traffic formerly handled the task.

title: Televised Queries for Anderson
description: ALBANY, May 15  The majority. leader of the State Senate, Warren M. Anderson, will take questions from the public on a televised callin show tomorrow night. The show will be televised from 10 to 11 P.M. over public television stations around the state. People with questions for Senator Anderson, a Binghamton Republican, can call (900) 8201911 beginning at 8 P.M. The questions will be screened by a panel of news people chosen by WMHT, the public television station in Schenectady.

title: Harvard Tightens Graduation Rule And Deemphasizes Survey Courses
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 15  Harvard University unveiled its longawaited core curriculum today. The new curriculum is a radical departure from established methods of) undergraduate education and the first major change in Harvard's course of study in 30 years.

title: News Summary
description: Lifting sanctions against Rhodesia within 14 days after the installation of a blackmajority Government in Salisbury was requested by the Senate in an unexpected rebuff to President Carter's southern Africa policy. The request was made in a sense of Congress resolution that will not be binding on the President even if it is also approved by the House. The appeal was adopted by a vote of 75 to 19 in an amendment to an authorization bill. [Page Al, Column 6.].

title: Election. Panel Planning Public Campaign Audits
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)  The Federal Election Commission announced today that it was reversing its policy and would begin discussing some campaign audits in nubile sessions.

title: Richard Altick Book Wins Freedley Prize
description: The 1978 George Freedley award for books about the theater has been awarded to Richard D. Altick for The Shows of London: A Panorama History. 16001862.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: He's one of the few salesmen in the industry who really know what's inside an engine.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: MOST people have a special liking for foods that are stuffed. It might be roast turkey, a breast of veal, peppers, onions, zucchini, clams, mussels, lobsters or oysters. After all, oysters Rockefeller are in a sense stuffed with a spinach filling. The reasons are as numerous as they are obvious. A filling, stuffing, dressing, or farce, call it what you will, offers an appealing contrast both in flavors and textures. And almost anything within reason can go into a wellmade filling, from ground or chopped leftover meats and vegetables to whole sausages (one of the most interesting stuffed foods I've ever sampled was cooked by a Cuban acquaintance, a roast loin of pork stuffed with chorizos, a fleshy garlic sausage).

title: Wine Talk
description: EVERY year around this time, Peter Allan Sichel puts out. his annual report on the previous year's vintage. Actually,:it is far more than a summary of weather conditions and grape sugar content; it is an eiceptionally lucid and thonaugh acount :of: what is happening in the French wine world, from a Bordeaux wine merchint's point of view. Mr.. Sichel is president of the French arnfof the Sichel familyip wine business. He is a cousin of Peter, M.F. Sichel.of New York, who head.of the German, or,.Blue Nun, end of the business.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Higher; investors Are Hesitant
description: Interest rates climbed higher in the credit markets yesterday as new issues of corporate and taxexempt bonds failed to attract investors.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: NOBODY ever went broke by underestimating the public's taste, said H.L. Mencken, to whom Jessica Mitford has been compared. Miss Mitford, however, occasionally goes for broke in her enthusiasm for exposing organizations that take advantage of individuals. At such times, it seems she does overestimate the public's taste. It is possible that some of these victims ask for these organizations and invite their abuses.

title: As Parliament Opens, Queen Reads Tory Plan
description: Queen Elizabeth II, in the House of Lords with Prince Philip at her side, presented the Conservative program as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and advisers listened. The program is considered one of Britain's most ambitious since the end of War World II. Page A3.

title: Ghana Says an Uprising Fails
description: LONDON, May 15 (Reuters)  The Accra radio said today that an air force officer and a handful of airmen made brief and unsuccessful attempt to stage an uprising in Ghana this morning. The broadcast, monitored here, said the rebels had been overpowered and were in military custody. One airman was killed, the statement.

title: The City
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office has indicted Fred Williams on the charge of firstdegree murder, making a death sentence for him mandatory if he is convicted of the charge.

title: Staley to Increase CornSyrup Output
description: Responding to increased demand,the A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company said that it planned to increase production of its highfructose corn syrup by about 55 percent at its Lafayette, Ind., plant. With the expansion, which will be completed early next year, the plant's capacity for producing the syrup will total more than 800 million pounds yearly. A spokesman said that further expansion of output was planned for the sweetener, which is widely used in soft drinks.

title: Jury to Get Case of San Francisco Mayor's Murder
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 15  With testimony and argument ended in Dan White's murder trial, a jury of seven women and five men is to begin deliberation tomorrow on the Crucial question that remains: Was the 32year old former Supervisor of sound mind about 11 A.M. On Nov. 27 when he shot to death Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk within the space of a few minutes?

title: Gary, Ind., Bus Strike Ends
description: GARY, Ind., May 15 (UPI)  Bus drivers ended a twoweek strike against the Gary Public Transportation Corporation and returned to work today.

title: A President for PennDixie
description: William J. Scharffenberger will become president and chief executive officer, of PennDixie Industries, the company said yesterday, subsequent to the preparation of a mutually acceptable employment agreement. If it is prepared, he will begin on June 25.

title: Theater Movies by ABC
description: The chairman of the American Broadcasting Companies told stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting that the company was planning to produce and distribute motion pictures for theaters.

title: COMMODITIES Silver Futures Decline; Gold Up $4.50 an Ounce
description: The increasingly volatile silver futures market closed down 3.80 to 2 cents an ounce yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange (Comex), largely because of a relatively rare and brief vacuum in buy orders about 1:15 P.M., according to brokers.

title: A Japanese Aircraft Scandal Seems Ended
description: TOKYO, May 15  An aircraft bribery scandal that provided rich insights into corruption in Japanese politics ended here today with an announcement by Tokyo prosecutors that they had completed a fourmonth inveAtivatinn.

title: Carey Asks Motorists to Save 7 Gallons by End of May
description: ALBANY, May 15  Governor Carey asked today that each New York State motorist conserve seven gallons of gasoline between now and the end of May to deal with what he said would be a 7 to 10 percent shortage in the amount of gasoline normally available in the state this month.

title: Julian H. Lines, a Rail Executive And Leader in Episcopal Church
description: Julian Hudson Lines, an industrial developer and railroad executive, died Monday of a heart attack in his Manhattan apartment. He was 66 years old.

title: Concert: An AllAmerican Program
description: THE American Composers Orchestra, which fortunately looks like it will endure  for a while at least  is not really out to win a popularity contest. Its aim is to, give an overview of American music, particularly that of the present time, without restrictions in matter of style. In the past, this has often resulted in austere, not to say puritanical, programs on the part of similar new organizations. Yet this ensemble's Monday night concert in Alice Tully Hall could have gone down easily with almost any audience because of its range, variety and general accessibility.

title: Home Mortgages At Record Rates
description: Yields on home mortgages rose to record levels yesterday in the Federal National Mortgage Association's latest agreement to purchase Governmentbacked and conventionally financed housing loans over the next four months.

title: Abram Blau, Psychiatrist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Abram Blau, chief psychiatrist of the childadolescent psychiatry unit at the Mount Sinai Hospital from 1947 to 1971, died Monday at his home in New York. He was 72 years old.

title: Koch Favors Increases For Elected Officials; Hearing Due May 2,5
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he believed the city's elected officials deserved salary increases.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The small hiuns called calls are ideal for my family. I am curious, about two things: What joint are they made from and where did the name originate?

title: Supermarkets In an Ethnic Mood
description: DALLAS

title: Topics
description: The ranks of murderous governments have been thinned, mercifully, in recent months with the overthrow of Uganda's Idi Amin and Cambodia's Poi Pot. Now comes a gruesome report from Amnesty International concerning Emperor Bokassa I and schoolchildren in his Central African Empire.

title: HELP THE FRESH AIR FUND
description: HELP THE FRESH AIR FUND

title: Music: Marriner's Adieu
description: NEVILLE MARR1NER'S second and final Music in May series concert with the New York Philharmonic on Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall may have been slightly eccentric in its programming, but it added up to a crisp, polished and generally delightful evening of music. A pity, then, that there weren't more people there: on Saturday the crowd had overflowed on to the stage, whereas on Sunday the house was half empty. One could attribute the previous day's turnout to the presence of Pinchas Zukerrnan and Itzhak Perlman. But one would also think Mr. Marriner would have an audience, and besides he had the winner of the Gold Medal at the 1978 Tchaikovsky Competition, Nathaniel Rosen, as his cello soloist.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: At this time of year, our fancy turns to flowers. Not only would we like masses of real ones, but we love the idea flower themes all around us. Therefore, we were pleased find a new shop called La Fleuressence, where Penny Burns and Zina Colovic have gathered together all sorts of flowery things in a shop like a bower. The first sight that catches one's eye is a large arrangement of silk flowers placed in an antique basket; it's tagged at $295, but there are smaller ones starting at $15. There are handpainted silk scarfs by an artist named Leslie, which repeat the flowers and are lovely enough to frame ($75 to $95). Other crafts people have done interesting flower jewelry, crocheted pillows and potpourris. Check out the antique bags, particularly the Victorian reticule solidly beaded in a flowerpattern and hung on a silver chain for $285, plus more recent ones at lower prices. La Fleuressence is at 1240 Madison Avenue (89th Street).

title: Threat of Job Action Brings Halt In Admission to Health Facilities
description: HARTFORD, May 15 (AP)  Connecticut officials halted admissions to state health facilities late today in reaction to a threatened job action by state health care workers.

title: Trigger Prices On Steel Cut
description: The Treasury Department said yes. terday that it would reduce trigger prices on imported steel during the the third quarter by an average of 1.4 percent.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 15  Lebanon's two major Christian rightwing parties, in an attempt to stop fierce fighting between their militias, announced today that they are to merge into one organization with a single leadership.

title: Careers
description: FRANCHELLIE (FRANKIE) CADWELL believes that one reason too many ads do not pull the way they should is that the advertising field is not attracting enough bright young M.B.A.'s or others with strong business training. So her agency, Cadwell Davis Savage, a subsidiary of Compton International, one of the nation's largest agencies, announced a program of $500 prizes each year to outstanding tudents majoring in marketing at each of three noted business schools  the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, Harvard University's Graduate School of Business Administration and the Columbia University Graduate School of _Business. Her aim: to encourage more graduates with master of business administration degrees to think of advertising as a career.

title: Spanish Brigadier Is Shot
description: LEON, Spain, May 15 (AP)  An unidentified gunman shot Brig. Emeterio Puente Aller, a former official of Parliament's guard, today, seriously wounding him, the police in Leon in northern Spain said. They blamed the First of October Antifascist Revolutionary Groups, a Maoist organization, for, the shooting.

title: John Wins 8th as Yanks Beat Tigers, 113
description: Tommy John, the man with the surgically rebuilt left elbow and the best pitching record in baseball, made it eight straight last night as the New York Yankees overpowered the Detroit Tigers. 113. Since joining millionaire's alley as a free agent from the Los Angeles Dodgers, the 36yearold sinkerball dealer has been almost letter perfect. And, he kept the streak alive last night with a sevenhitter and with extravagant support from his teammates, notably a pair of home runs by Chris Chambliss, four hits and four runs by Willie Randolph and four runs batted home by Graig Nettles.

title: Products From the North:
description: TORONTO, May 15  Most Americans know, or think they know, that Canada exports many natural resources and is populated by Mounties and Eskimos. But other products of Canada have had tar more impact though much less fame as Canadianmade.

title: SENATORS DECLARE RHODESIA SANCTIONS SHOULD END QUICKLY
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  President Carter's southern African policy sustained an unexpected rebuff today when the Senate adopted an amendment asking him to lift sanctions. against Rhodesia within 14 days of the installation of a blackmaioritv Government.

title: Assixiated Press and United Press International
description: David W. Marston, Republican, left, and William J. Green, Democrat, while speaking to supporters last night in Philadelphia after each won nomination In primary election for Mayor. They will compete in general election in November.

title: Connally Reports More Than $1 Million in Personal Income in 16 Months
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 John B. Connally filed a personal financial disclosure report with the Federal Election Commission today showing that he had more than $1 million in gross income over the last 16 months.

title: Soviet Supplies Reach Space Lab
description: MOSCOW. May 15 (UPI)  The unmanned Soviet. Progress 6 cargo capsule successfully docked with the Salyut 6 space laboratory today, delivering a vital cargo of fuel and supplies to two astronauts who have been in orbit for 79 days.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARYA SARA (Arya National Shipping Norton, USly). Khorramshahr July Bandar Shatwour 4 and Bandar Abbas 6; sails f rom Port Newark, N.J.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday. May 7, to Sunday. May 13). listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United S:ltes households with television Bets.

title: Stage: Getting Out By Marsha Norman
description: THE emotional impact of Getting Out is so honest and direct and the performances are so incandescent that it all seems very simple: just a blaze of theatrical energy that lights up the Off Broadway scene as nothing else has dine this season.

title: Applied Devices Sale To China Appfoved
description: The Applied Devices Corporation of Kissimmee, Fla., said that a subsidiary, the Digital Resources CorPoranon, Houston, had received approval to sell a $5.5 million computer to China.

title: Companies List Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter

title: Litchfield Murder Trial Set for Medical Student
description: A fourthyear medical student at Columbia University is scheduled to go on trial in Litchfield, Conn., on May 29 for the murder of a fellow student who was found stabbed to death on a wooded estate in New Hartford, a small town in northern Connecticut. on July 31.

title: Scientology Suit Backed By U.S. Appeals Court
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI)  A Federal appeals court reversed today a Federal judge's decision to throw out the Church of Scientology's request for records on the church held by the National Security Agency.

title: China Sets $10 Billion Japan Loan
description: TOKYO, May 15  China is concluding a series of bank loan agreements to borrow more than $10 billion from Japan, including a $2 billion agreement with the official ExportImport Bank of Japan signed here today.

title: Japan May Ease Currency Flow
description: TOKYO, May 15 (UPI)  The Japanese Government has decided on a package of measures to liberalize foreign exchange trading that has been basically banned, Government officials said today.

title: Group of 10 To Renew Loan Fund
description: PARIS, May 15  The industrialized world's 10 richest nations agreed today to renew for five years the special $7 billion credit line they set up to help one another in 1962. The decision to extend the General Arrangements to Borrow means that the United States and major industrial nations will continue to have relatively little need to borrow from the International Monetary Fund if they get into financial difficulties.

title: Venezuela Says OPEC Is Studying Prices Tied to Exchange, Inflation
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 15 (Reuters)  The oilproducing countries are studying a new method of oil pricing to take into account inflation and variation in exchange rates, the Venezuelan Mines Ministry said today.

title: EARNINGS Resorts International Up
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 15 (AP) Resorts International Inc., operator of the only gambling casino in Atlantic City, announced today that its earnings for the first three months of 1979 totaled almost $19 million, against $1.8 million in the like 1978 quarter. Net sales and revenues totaled $84.3 million, against $26.2 million the previous year.

title: Tatiana McKenna, 66, Ex Food Editor at Vogue
description: Tatiana McKenna, a former contributing food editor to Vogue Magazine, died last Wednesday in Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore. She was 66 years old and lived in Owings Mills, Md.

title: JUDGES GET REPRIEVE ON FINANCE REPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  A Federal judge in New Orleans today blocked implementation of a new law that requires Federal judges to disclose information about their personal finances. The temporary restraining order, sought by six Federal District judges in the South, did not cover similar disclosure requirements for members of Congress and the executive branch.

title: TV's Effects on Children To Be Discussed by Panel
description: A panel discussion on What TV Is Doing to. for, With Children will be held May 30 at the Sheraton Center hotel under the sponsorship of the New York chapter of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.

title: From a 4.-by6 Kitchen, Dinner for 40
description: LANDLORDS and architects think that people who live in small apartments hate cooking. This is why the typical New York kitchen is an airless hole where the cook must work alone.

title: Reputed Leader in Crime Family Seized in 1974 Slaying of Bookie
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 15  Aniello Dellacroce, allegedly an overseer of the Carlo Gambino crime family, was arrested today on charges involving the 1974 murder of a Yonkers bookmaker suspected of being an informer, the New Rochelle office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

title: Columbia Service Eulogizes Frankel as Activist Thinker
description: Dr. Charles Frankel, who was murdered with his wife, Helen, last week in their Bedford Hills home during a series of still unsolved burglarymurders, was remembered yesterday at Columbia University. He was recalled as almost a luminous figure, intellectually and physically gifted, totally articulate and shining with integrity.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Disarmament Commission  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Navy Ships on Training Missions Collide in Pacific Fog, Injuring
description: SAN DIEGO, May 15 (UPI)  Two Navy ships on training missions collided in a Pacific fog bank yesterday, injuring seven crewmen.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: GRATING and shredding are often such small jobs  a couple of teaspoons of parmesan, a dusting of nutmeg, a hint of lemon rind  that the bestequipped cook would feel foolish hauling out food processor every time. So it's good that the oldfashioned, nonmechanical graters haven't been relegated to places in museum cases yet.

title: Results of Aetna Offer
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, a large insurance company with headquarters in Hartford, said yesterday that it had acquired about 96 percent of the shares of the American Reinsurance Company. The tender offer for the shares, priced at $62 each, expired Monday.

title: Rejoin the Union on Memorial Day
description: New York State observes Memorial Day on May 30; the rest of the country celebrates it on the last Monday in May, whatever the date. This year, May 30 falls on a Wednesday so while other Americans are enjoying a threeday weekend. New Yorkers will be stuck with two fractured celebrations, separated families and economic loss. The way to repair the damage is for the state to conform to the national pattern. It is too late to do anything about the absurdity for this year, but the time to prod the Legislature to act for future years is now, as everyone starts to think about it.

title: Backers Use New Tactic to Rebuff Foes of House Campaign Subsidy
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  Supporters of Federal subsidies for House election campaigns unveiled a new defensive strategy today and won the first test of its effectiveness.

title: Dome Petroleum Offering
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., a large Canadian oil producer, has announced plans fora preferred share offering involving two types of shares, one calling for payment of a cash dividend and one providing for stock dividends in preferred shares. The total offering will have a face value of about $100 million and be offered publicly through a group managed by Wood Gundy Ltd.

title: It was rough going on Centre Street yesterday for John Gibson, who tried to mix a business call with babysitting for son, Jeremy, 2.
description: Finally, catching the little fellow at his own game, Mr. Gibson caged Jeremy between his legs as he took notes and finished his call.

title: Death
description: ADAMSMary S. On May 15, wife of the late George B., mother of George B., Jr., grandmother of Lisa, Marea, Get) and Alison. Funeral mass at Church of St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89 St. Thurs. May 17 at 10AM.

title: McEnroe Heading Forest Hills Field
description: John McEnroe heads the list of players named for the second annual Forest Hills invitation tournament at the West Side Tennis Club starting July 9.

title: Sunshine Now Brings Hot Showers As City Gets a Solar Energy System
description: The first solar energy system operating in a public building in New York City is providing hot showers for tennis players and other athletes using the Morty Arkin Memorial Field in Astoria Park, hard by the Triborough Bridge in Oueens.

title: Events
description: Theater

title: Around the Nation
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 15 (AP)  Violent crime has become so common in New Orleans that Gov. Edwin W. Edwards ofLouisiana says he wants to create a force of about 50 state supercops to help city policemen deal with it.

title: Stage: Little Elephant Is Dead, Japanese Play
description: KOBO ABE, the celebiated Japanese novelist and playwright, believes in a theater of action and imagery. As he says. Within the words themselves there must be action. An Abe play. such as The Little Elephant Is Dead, which began a week's run Monday La Mama Annex, has a script  one that is poetically descriptive, but not fully suggestive of the sweep of the experience. In the case of Mr. Abe, the play is the performance.

title: The Region
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.  Anthony J. Statile, chairman of the badly divided Bergen County Republican Party since June 1977, is stepping down at the end of his current term for health reasons. The 63yearold former, tnailorder executive, who suffered,a heart attack in February 1976, told a news conference here that he was resigning because the latest report from my doctor leaves no doubt that I have to slow down.

title: Siberian City Builds Flood Dams
description: MOSCOW, May 15 (Reuters)  Thousands of people using bulldozers, trucks, barrows and sandbags have built 24 miles of temporary dams to defend the west Siberian city of Tyumen from record floods caused by the spring thaw, the newspaper Trud reported today. Three thousand of the city's 335,000 people have been evacuatexl from lowlying areas, where the water has reached rooftop level, the report said.

title: Television
description: 5:55(4)Running

title: Father and Son Killed in Fall
description: NEW HAVEN, W. Va., May 15 (UPI) A man and. his son plunged 112 feet to their deaths today when a scaffold broke on the outside of a boiler room at an Appalachian Power Company plant under construction. About 800 workmen walked off the job out of respect for the victims, who were identified as Jimmie S. Pauley, 43 years old, and Jimmie S. Pauley Jr., 20.

title: Personal Health
description: MARIA was 9 months old but the size of an infant half her age. She rarely smiled, paid little attention to her surroundings, slept a lot and ate poorly. When approached by a stranger, she lowered her face. covered her eyes with her hands and tightened her lips.The masks of childhood depression are varied and often misleading.

title: Secrets of a Chocoholic
description: CANDY consumption in this country has been dwindling for years. As a health hazard, nutritionists rank sugarladen candy somewhere between unfiltered cigarettes and cobra venom, and the candy bar  more specifically the chocolate bar  is the only thing that shrinks faster than the dollar. Is it any wonder that Hershey's is getting more and more into the spaghetti business?

title: U.S. Recalling Envoy Over Chile's Refusal to Extradite
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  The State Department said today that the American Ambassador to Chile was being recalled as a result of the decision by Chile's Chief Justice to reject the United States request for the extradition of three Chilean Army officers indicted here in the murder of a prominent Chilean exile.

title: Vermont Workers Strike At Nuclear Power Plant
description: VERNON, Vt., May 15 (AP)  Sixtysix union workers at the Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant.walked off their jobs today, leaving a skeleton crew of supervisors to run the 540megawatt reactor.

title: Israel Reports Snag in the Talks On Transfer of El Arish to Egypt
description: TEL AVIV, May 15  The Israeli Foreign Ministry warned today that a snag had developed in the civilian arrangements for the transfer of the northern Sindi town of El Arish to Egyptian sovereignty under the peace treaty.

title: U.S. Olympic Effort Gets $2 Million Grant
description: The largest private contribution to the United States Olympic movement, $2 million by Burger King, was announced yesterday. Col. F. Don Miller, executive director of the United States Olympic Committee, said the money would be used to support the two national training centers in California and Colorado.

title: Mets Blank Pirates As Swan Excels, 30
description: PITTSBURGH, May 15Before last night's series opener with the Mets, Manager Chuck Tanner of Pittsburgh lamented the fact that this season had been one in which his team was finding it difficult to put things together.

title: Chess:
description: It has already been noted that since he became world champion in 1975, Matoly Karpov has expanded his methods of winning. This is not without precedent: After Alexander Alekhine won the world title from Jos Raul Capablanca in Buenos Aires in 1927, he blossomed into a positional player and a connoisseur of end games, whereas he had earlier concentrated heavily on combinations and attacking play.

title: Vote on Schweiker's Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)  Following is the roll call by which the Senate today approved a nonbinding resolution introduced/by Senator Richard S. Schweitzer urging President Carter to lift trade sanctions against Rhodesia:

title: Bonwit Fifth Ave. To Close Saturday
description: Bonwit Teller's Fifth Avenue store in New York will close this Saturday, several weeks earlier than had been expected.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: It seems to me that the time has come to nationalize energy  production and distribution. Such a move forward would be in the interests of all parties (with the exception perhaps of energy company managements).

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Britain's National Retainers
description: LONDON  The speed of a change of Gcniernment in Britain still comes as an excitement, each time it happens. One day James Callaghan is at 10 Downing Street; the next, Mrs. Thatcher comes in with the suddeness of a coup d'etat. The voters are very reassured by these quick results: Look, we did it! And many Americans have envied the efficiency of the British turnaround, with such a quick election campaign compared to the Presidential election and no lameduck interim afterwards. It is like the turning of a revolving stage, with no interval, no stagehands in sight, and bright new scenery with a new cast of characters, while the old scene disappears into the darkness backstage.

title: Ballet: School Workshop Peformance
description: THE School of American Ballet is celebrating its 45th anniversary this year, but the kind of Workshop Performance presented twice Monday at the JuIlHard Theater has been an annual event for 14 years.

title: Oil Union Asks Federal Inquiry Into Rival Unit
description: The Petroleum Trades Employees Union, which is scheduled to resume contract negotiations with Getty Oil today, said yesterday that it had asked Federal anticrime officials to investigate the background of a rival union. The members of that union are apparently destined to get the work formerly done in New York by members of the Petroleum Trades Employees Union.

title: CARTER DROPS PLAN FOR RESOURCES DEPT.
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  President Carter today abandoned his plan to create a new department of natural resources, scuttling this year's only major proposal for Government reorganization.

title: SAUDIS AND U.S. ACT TO KEEP CLOSE TIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  Administration officials said today that despite recent strains, the United States and Saudi Arabia had agreed to try to keep their sharp differences over the EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty from interfering with their close relations in other fields.

title: Letting Banks Into the Underwriting Act
description: State and local governments and public authorities depend on private underwriters to raise billions each year by selling their bonds. But an old Federal law prohibits commercial banks from competing for much of this business. The result is not just unfair treatment for the banks but higher interest costs for the public.

title: 12 Are Arrested in Sale Of Angel Dust in City
description: The arrest of 12 persons and the issuance of arrest warrants for nine others on charges of selling the drug phencyclidine, better known as an2e1 dust. were announced yesterday by United States Attorney Robert B. Fiske Jr.

title: Carter Proposes Legislation on Mental Health Care
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)  President Carter, saying that 10 to 15 percent of Americans had an emotional problem of some kind. today sent Congress legislation to revamp mental health care in the United States.

title: Options Suit Filed in Dallas
description: DALLAS, May 15 (UPI)  The federal Government has accused a Dallasbased company and 27 other corporate and individual defendants of selling fraudulent eold and silver options.

title: Bids on Bulletproof Vests In P.B.A. Project Studied
description: The New York City Department of Investigation is looking into the bidding and purchasing practices used by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in its publicly supported campaign to provide bullet proof vests for police officers. lte police union, with the help of other organizations and many prominent individuals, has so far raised more than $900,000 in contributions and pledges toward its $1.5 million goal of outfitting every New York City police officer on street duty, as well as every housing and transit officer, with a protective vest.

title: Begin Says He Is Concerned Over Sadat's Isolation
description: JERUSALEM, May 15  Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that he and his Govehiment were concerned about the isolation of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt in the Arab world and about the economic and political pressures on Cairo from Arab countries.

title: Blue Fin Is Best Children's Film
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15  Blue Fin, an Australian film, was awarded a Ruby Slipper as the best feature film at the eighth Los Angeles International Children's Film Festival by both the children's jury and the grand (adult) jury. Blue Fin, which has a background of tuna fishing, explores the relationship of a boy and his martinet father.

title: Bank of New York To Purchase Empire
description: The Bank of New York Company said it planned to acquire the Empire National Bank at a price of $22 a share. Empire National, which operates 40 offices in Orange, Rockland and Dutchess Counties, developed partly through mergers with smaller banks that once flourished in the middle Hudson River area.

title: New York Airways Acts To File for Bankruptcy
description: New York Airways, which halted helicopter service here after an accident April 18 in which three persons. were killed and 12 injured, said yesterday it would seek court protection from its creditors under the Federal Bankruptcy Act to give it time to work out a plan that it hoped would eventually lead to a resumption of flights.

title: Oil Shortages: Then and Now
description: The long lines at California's gas stations have awakened annoying memories of the Arab oil embargo five years ago, provoking a herewegoagain mood among the nation's motorists. But, as energy specialists have come to see it, the situation today is considerably different. Even though oil analysts say the shortages this time should not be nearly so painful, in another sense the experts are far more troubled now than they were in 1974.

title: Stage: An AllBlack I Love My Wife
description: HEADED by LawrenceHilton Jacobs of television's Welcome Back, Kotler series, new team, all black, as happens,jtepped into the four leading roles of I Love My Wife last night, ano so smooth was the transition that the Michael StewartCy Coleman musical never missed a beat. The performances by Mr. Jacobs and his colleagues were high spirited, rather broad and more than a little robust. But I Love My Wife, now in its third year on Broadway, is no polite British drawingroom comedy, and their style fitted the material neatly..

title: Silverman Maps Road Back for NBC
description: LOS ANGELES; May 15  Fred Silverman, president of the National Broadcasting Company, said today that news would take on greater importance in the network's broadcast service and suggested that in the next few years the primetime entertainment schedule might have to be reduced by 30 minutes to permit expansion of the national newscast.

title: Jersey Trooper Guilty In Manslaughter Case
description: BRIDGETON, N.J., May 15 (UPI) A New Jersey state trooper was convicted of manslaughter today in the shooting death of a Vietnamese refugee during an automobile chase.

title: Embattled Dryden Returns in Triumph
description: MONTREAL, May 15  The pose has always been the same. Ken Dryden leans forward on his goaltender's stick, his forearms parallel to the ice, his left arm resting on the blocking glove on his right hand. The pose is the same when the red goal light is on behind him; when everyone is wondering how he just made that last save, and even when an emergency has thrown him into a Stanley Cup final.

title: GOING OUTGuide
description: TONES AND TREES Dance Performance on. Mondaya and musiCiand theatiftin'Wednesclays are planned for thWstfason's Sweet 14 FestiVal el free Oniertain Union Square, starting this Mdraintand continuing through Mid049berjltis is the park's tiiiidannuil CultUratelebration,organiZed bYcOm mdnliyand civic interests to better the area bordering on West 14th Street.

title: TV: Muppets Plug a Movie They've Made
description: THE Muppets have a movie coming out, and that's the very slender pretext for The Muppets Go Hollywood, an hourlong special to be shown tonight on CBS  TV at 8 o'clock. A large, splashy party has been staged at the Coconut Grove, so that the Muppets can mingle with television and film stars. The stars show themselves to be good sports and the Muppets come across as ingenious, but not particularly charming scenestealers. Only a few of the stars have any talent for ad libbing with a bundle of fur.

title: Consolidated's New. Chief
description: G.J. (Jack) Tankersley, 58 years old, was elected chairman and chief executive officer yesterday of the Consolidated Natural Gas Company at a board meeting after the corporation's annual meeting. He succeeds Robert E. Seymour, 63, who will become chairman of the executive committee of the Pittsburghbased public utility holding company.

title: Union Action Delays The Post
description: The printing of the early edition of The New York Post was delayed for about one hour yesterday when pressmen refused to cross an informational picket line set up Monday by Teamsters Local 531. The dispute involved publisher resistance to an attempt by home deliverers in Queens to raise their charge to The Post.

title: Professor Joins Inquiry Into APlant Accident
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) President Carter announced today the appointment of Carolyn Lewis, a Journalist who is now a profetsor, to be the 12th member of his special commission to investigate the nuclear accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant.

title: Cigarette Maker Pays Up
description: A check for $135,797.60 was sent to New York City by the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company after officials in the city's Finance Department demanded that the nation's largest cigarette manufacturer pay city taxes on cigarettes that were distributed free as part of a promotional campaign.

title: SEARS LOSES ITS SUIT OVER JOBBIAS RULES
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  A Federal judge today dismissed a sweeping suit challenging Federal equalemployment programs that was filed by Sears, Roebuck & Company, the largest retailer in the United States.

title: Toyota's Output Rose 4.9% in April
description: The Toyota Motor Company announced in Tokyo that its April  motor vehicle production rose 4.9 percent from April of last year to record 251.140 units. However, exports in the month, the company said, fell 17.1 percent to 100,882 units.

title: PARLEY ON REFUGEES OPENS IN INDONESIA
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia; May IS With the number of Indochinese refugees in transit camps throughout Southeast Asia climbing toward 300M00, representatives of 24 nations. including Vietnam, met here today to distuss the problem.

title: Canadians, Deeply Divided and Troubled Face a Crucial Election
description: OTTAWA  In an election campaign, every little bit helps: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau is often introduced at rallies as a man with international prestige who deals with world leaders and who keeps Canada on the map.

title: Mexico's 'special Days: Hoopla and Profits
description: MEXICO CITY

title: The New York Times/Neal Boenzi
description: PEACE OFFICERS MEMORIAL DAY OBSERVED: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire and Mayor Koch joined Mrs. David Guttenberg, left, and Mrs. Horace L. Ford, widows of two police officers slain during 1978, at memorial service at Police Headquarters yesterday. Four city police officers were slain during the year. Service was part of a nationwide observance for all police officers killed in the line of duty and who have died during the year. The memorial day was established in 1962 by President John F. Kennedy.

title: Chrysler: Rough Road Ahead
description: SYRACUSE, May 15  Lee A. Iacocca warned shareholders of the Chrysler Corporation today that no one can promise any easy answers or quick turnaround in our company's fortimes.

title: The New York Times/ Neel Bowok
description: The cables of the Brooklyn Bridge, silvergray with fresh paint, are also a web to entice two adventurers on a day when sunshine was just triumphing over hazy fog. Setting off from Brooklyn Heights into the steel and stone of down town Manhattan, the youngsters, safe from traffic on the roadway below, are too young to know that around the world there are people who tell themselves, If I ever get to New York, I'd like to walk across the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Canada, a Vast, Divided Nation, Gets Ready for a Crucial Election
description: TORONTO, May 15  Almost unnoticed by the world, Canada, that vast, rich and littleunderstood nation, approaches its crucial national elections next week a divided and deeply troubled land.

title: California: Don Juan's Out of Gas
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.  Just at the moment there.isn't any gasoline in this part of the world, for all practical purposes. Some people are getting it, by waiting five hours or more it line. One lady, I understand, ran over somebody who tried to cut in ahead of her and put him in the hospital. I haven't tried this yet, because I'm afraid of violence, especially when inflicted by women. Still it's a problem for me, because I'm particularly attached to the three cars I own.

title: Rangers: No One Expected 4 Straight
description: MONTREAL, May 15  The clichs were on the other foot tonight. All the we couldn't get goings and we were just standing arounds emanated from the Rangers dressing room following their onesided 62 defeat at the hands of the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Dr. Bernard Cinberi, 74, Obstetrician and Author
description: Dr. Bernard Cinberg, an obstetrician, gynecologist, author and conservationist, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and lived in Waterside Plaza.

title: Lockheed Reports Further Jet Orders
description: The Lockheed Corporation announced the purchase of two longrange L1011500 jet transports by the privately owned West German tour airline Lufttransport Unternehmen. The order follows one last week by Air Canada for six of the planes plus an option for nine more.

title: Country Music Honor for Carter
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)  President Carter received an award today from the Country Music Association. Willie Nelson and Charlie Pride, the entertainers, presented the award at an Oval Office ceremony recognizing Mr. Carter's enthusiasm for country music.

title: On an English Estate, Czarist Connections
description: TEYNHAM, ENGLAND

title: Days of 100Acre Preserve On L.I. Appear to Be Over
description: DIX HILLS, L.I., May 15  As a few people walked along a path overgrown with underbrush, a chipmunk scampered to cover in this 100acre natural preserve amid the suburban parkways and housing developments of Long Island. But its home in the preserve, one of the last undeveloped tracts of land in the town of Huntington, may soon give way to a housing development.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter scolded, the American people for what he called their refusal to recognize that the nation was confronted with an energy crisis. Speaking to a gathering of business leaders in the White House, he said that Americans are looking for scapegoats, in believing that the Federal Government has been in collusion with oil companies to create shortages. He also said they refuse to face the inevitable prospect of fuel shortages. [Page A1.]

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AT0 Inc., Willoughby, Ohio, a diversified manufacturer, has named Richard W. Patterson to the newly created position of senior vice presidentservices.

title: Saudis Ban Egyptian Papers
description: CAIRO, May 15 (AP)  Saudi Arabia has banned Egyptian newspapers and magazines, the Middle East News Agency reported today. The ban is part of the Arab boycott of Egypt in retaliation for its peace treaty with Israel.

title: Business Records
description: EVELYN BRUTON, 186 Grand Concourse, the Bronx. Liabilities, 55,854; assets, 5108.

title: Edward J. Benesch, an Engineer; Had Role in Many Major Projects
description: Edward J. Benesch, retired vice president and chief engineer for Syska &; Hennessy Inc., Engineers of New York, died Saturday at his home in Littleton, Colo. He was 75 years old.

title: Father of 2 Agrees to Pay His Dead ExWife's Bills
description: Membert of Brooklyn's Polish community who had supported the late Cecilia Bogdaniuk El Gamal before she was accepted for welfare  and who were attentotinz to raise funds for her remaining hospital and funeral bills  received as surances yesterday that reimbursement would be made by her former husband, Mohammed El Garnal, an assistant secretaryof Chemical Bank.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Alternateside parking regulations are suspended throughout New York City today. Tomorrow, Friday and Saturday, the regulations will go back into effect only in Brooklyn as part of a boroughbyborough rotation plan to clean up refuse during the tugboat strike. Next week, the regulations will go back into effect in the Bronx and be suspended in the other boroughs.

title: Bill to Speed Antitrust Trials Gains
description: WASHINGTON, May 15.  A bill to speed up antitrust litigation by discouraging stalling by defendants before and during trial was approved today by the Judiciary Committee of the Senate in 14to1 vote.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M.; WNCN. La Campanella, Paganini; Concerto a Quattro No. 2, Galuppi; Captaine Piper's Pavan and, Galliard, Dowland; Etudes Tableaux excerpts.

title: Charter Completes Carey Acquisition
