title: CARTER IS OPTIMISTIC ON JUNE GAS SUPPLY
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  President Carter expressed the belief today that the worst of the current gasoline shortage would be over by next month.

title: 4 TaxFree Bond Issues Sell Quickly
description: Aided by the general advance in the credit markets yesterday, four large issues of taxexempt bonds totaling more than $200 million were offered for sale, many at yields of 7 percent or more. Investors quickly bought most of the securities.

title: Jurors End 2d Day of Deliberation In Silkwood Contamination Case
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, May 16 (AP) Jurors in the Karen Silkwood plutonium contamination trial deliberated again today without reaching a verdict on whether to award the young woman's estate millions of dollars.

title: Koch Assails 4iberal Party Chiefs Over Their Criticism of _Moynihan
description: Mayor Koch yesterday accused Liberal Party leaders of an undercurrent of bigotry in their criticism of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan for sponsoring a tuition taxcredit bill for the parents of orivateschool Children.

title: Home Beat
description: HER work used to be overscale - wall tapestries done on commission for such companies as Knoll International or the Bank of Hong Kong at the World Trade Center. But Leora Klaymer Stewart, a fiber artist who studied at the Art Institute of Chicago and has been making fiber structures for more than 10 years, is now working on a smaller, more personal scale and is concerned with offloom techniques, rather than weaving. When I first came to New York five years ago, Miss Stewart said, I was making huge, environmental works what I call my exhibition pieces. But I was not really thinking about where they could possibly be used. She calls her newest pieces, each from 12 to 24 inches square, composite structures. They include individually wrapped, looped and braided elements, but are small in scale and manageable in size. I see them as fragments of a larger piece, Miss Stewart explained. It's as if one looked under a microscope at the blowup of a weave detail. The pieces are all made from natural fibers in white, sand, rust and brown colors, and are encased in wooden, glasstopped boxes. A show of Miss Stewart's work, along with that of another fiber artist, Deborah Warner, opens tomorrow and continues through June 16 at the Hadler/ Rodriguez Galleries, 35 East 20th Street. Miss Stewart's pieces range in price from $1,000 to $1,800.

title: Adelphi Triumphs, 1613, In Lacrosse Semifinal
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 16 Robb Engelke scored two goals and had seven assists, while Dave Leistman added four goals to lead Ade1phi University to a 16.13 victory over St. Lawrence in a semifinal game of the National Collegiate Division IIIII lacrosse chamoionshin.

title: COLOMBIANS ARREST PILOT AFTER ESCAPE
description: MAICAO, Colombia, May 16  Roy isteLemore, the'American pilot held forransom by Indians for 17days neai. this remote jungle. village, broke away last night at what his captors had been led to believe was a rendezvous set up ter trade him for $100,000 ransoin.

title: Around the Nation
description: ROCKLEDGE, Fla., May 16 (AP) Judges in Florida's Brevard County have told law enforcement agencies that radar alone will no longer be enough evidence to convict a driver of speeding.

title: Rizzo Spurns Both Mayoral Nominees
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 16  The Democratic and Republican nominees to succeed Mayor Frank L. Rizzo were on the streets campaigning this morning, only hours after winning their primaries, while the Mayor suggested he might support an independent candidate in the fall.

title: American Air Sees Big Profit
description: FORT WORTH, May 16 (UPI)  Albert V. Casey, chairman and president of American Airlines, said today that his company's secondquarter profit would set a record, following a firstquarter loss.

title: A Happy Hunt Returns as a Foe of Cosmos
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 16 - Steve Hunt, who helped the Cosmos capture North American Soccer League championships the last two seasons, returned to Giants Stadium tonight to play against the Cosmos.

title: Backgammon:
description: In backgammon a player strives with each roll to improve his position. What constitutes improvement, however, often depends on the overall board uosition. As a result, plays that appear constructive may have little value or may actually be detrimental. For example, a basic goal is to construct new points. Generally, each new point restricts the opponent's movement while facilitating the safe movement of one's own men. Because building points is such a natural objective, many players will do so automatically. without stopping to consider if they serve a useful function.

title: President of Mexico Shuffles His Cabinet On Eve of Castro Visit
description: COZUMEL, Mexico, May 16 On the eve of a state visit to Mexico by President Fidel Castro of Cuba, President Jos Lopez Portillo tonight unexpectedly reshuffled his Cabinet, replacing Foreign Secretary Santiago Roel Garcia and two other ministers.

title: Taxis Block Traffic in Demonstrations Against New Regulations
description: Traffic was slowed for 20 blocks on Second Avenue yesterday as taxis moved at snail's pace, five abreast. Jay L. Turoff, head of Taxi and Limousine Commission, said drivers were from Last Minifleet Association, protesting rules forcing them to doubleshift cars. Largest group, with 200 cabs, was on Grand Central Parkway. Page B13.

title: Typographers Reelect Poweis
description: Bertram A. Powers was reelected yesterday as president of New York Typographical Union No. 6, defeating two opponents. He received 4,816 votes; James J. Duffy received 1,161, and Gabriel Falsetta, 362. David W. Crockett was reelected vice president with 3,791 votes, while Al PaoRini received 1,771, and Seymour Gritz, 787. Mac Engler was unopposed for reelection as secretarytreasurer.

title: We Are the Advance Guard
description: As a young man, he urged blacks not to fight in World War I and President Wilson called him the most dangerous man in America. He later organized the railroad porters into the first black trade union in America, which eventually earned him a seat on the executive council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. Inside the civil rights movement he was known as a superior strategist who encouraged debate among leaders. Throughout a long and energetic life, people knew when A. Philip Randolph disagreed.

title: Inquiry on 3 Mile Island Is Held Up As Dispute Blocks Subpoena Power
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., May 17  The Presidential commission that is looking into the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant halted the main part of its investigation this morning, charging that a dispute between Congress and the executive branch had held up legislation empowering it to subpoena witnesses and, question them under oath.

title: UConn Struck By a Rampage
description: STORRS, Conn., May 17 (AP)  The University of Connecticut campus has been left strewn with burned books, broken glass, smashed furniture, rotting garbage and other debris after students went on an endofsemester rampage, officials reported.

title: British Envoy Confers With New Rhodesian Leader
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 17  A special representative of Britain's new Conservative GoVernment conferred today with Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa, whO will soon become Rhodesia's first black prime minister.

title: City Is Studying Why Lintel Fell, Killing Student
description: New York City officials started an investigation yesterday into the death of a Barnard College freshman who was struck Wednesday night by a window lintel that fell from the eighth floor of a building on Broadway owned by Columbia University.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation is seeking to sell its Los Angelesbased refining and marketing operations for about $275 million.

title: Ciulla's Charges Assailed
description: BOSTON, May 17  Anthony P. (Big Tony) Ciulla hunched over a sizetoosmall witness box today and told a jury in United States District Court here today that besides being a fixer of horse races he had also been a frequent lawbreaker and jail inmate.

title: Jazz: Jarrett on Piano
description: THERE has been something of backlash against Keith Jarrett of late, but his appearances this week at the Village Vanguard, where he is ensconced through tomorrow, should help correct that.

title: Coast Gasoline Shortage Hurts eater Box Offices
description: LOS ANGELES, May 17  Among the victims of the current Southern Califoinia shortage are Deathtrap, Pygmalion and Annie. Since the gas crisis began two weeks ago, ticket. Sales and revenues are down for shows at: nearly every major,Los Angeles theater.

title: Title Insurance Challenges Old British Land System
description: LONDON, May 17  When someone buys property in certain parts of Gloucestershire, one of the first things he does is to mark the boundaries by planting a bramblebush hedge around the perimeter. Over the years he makes sure to trim the hedge from the inside while watching Mother Nature enlarge his holdings.

title: COMMODITIES
description: The price of gold on the futures market continued its slow but steady climb in quiet trading yesterday while wheat and coffee futures declined.

title: VoteSeekers Court Alienated Western Provinces
description: OTTAWA  Politicians, their aides and political reporters have done little in this capital for nearly two months other than sleep here on weekends. It is to the West they head at the start of each new week, M a search for votes in the election of a new House of Commons next week.

title: Maritime Provinces: Poor, Proud And Reminiscent of Appalachia
description: SYDNEY, Nova Scotia  In 1886, sime 90 years before Quebec voters elected a provincial gove.inment committed to some form of. separatism from Canada, the Nova Scotia legislature passed its VV/13 resolution on secession.

title: ExAmbassador to Iran To Head Study Group.
description: WASHINGTON. May 17 William H. Sullivan, who resigned last month from the Foreign Service after serving as Ambassador to Iran, has been named president of the American Assembly, a nongovernmental study group.

title: Hoover to Oppose Fuqua Control Bid
description: NORTH CANTON, Ohio, May 17 (UPI) The Hoover Company indicated today that it would oppose an attempt by Fuqua Industries to gain control of Hoover through a cash purchase of $18 a share.

title: Jazz: Taylor And Laskin
description: BILLY TAYLOR, who is playing piano at the Knickerbocker Saloon, University Place at Ninth Street, for the next two weeks, is giving his bassist, Victor Gaskin, a stronger, more prominent role than is customary in pianobass duos.

title: Once More for the Money
description: BALTIMORE, May 17  Flying Paiter lost 50 or 100 pounds in the Kentucky Derby and Luis Barrera lost $500, but neither Ben Ridder's horse nor Screen King's trainer is throwing in the towel. Two weeks after. Spectacular Bid whipped them in the first race of the Triple Crown series. Flying Paster, Screen King, General Assembly and Golden Act were here at Pimlico ready to take one more shot at the gray colt in the 104th Preakness Stakes, the second part of the classic troika. General Assembly finished second at

title: Governor Carey Rides the Rails
description: There is no question, especially with gasoline short, that New York's rail system can use the $797 million in improvements Governor Carey has now proposed. The question is, can the state afford them?

title: Amex Expands OddLot Trade
description: The American Stock Exchange plans to expand its oddlot Government securities market by adding Government National Mortgage Association certificates to the Treasury and Federal agency issues now traded, Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman, announced yesterday.

title: United Press International
description: POLISH PRIMATE VISITS THE POPE: Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski kissing the hand of Pope John Paul II on arrival at the Vatican. Cardinal Wyszynski will accompany the Pope to the sixthcentury abbey at Monte Cassino today to honor Polish soldiers killed helping to liberate the town in World War II.

title: Italy Building Its Case Againsts Marxist Professor Tied to Terrorists
description: FLORENCE, May 17  GovernMent investigators are pressing their case against Prof, Antonio Negri, the Marxist philosopher whose arrest on suspicion of having taken part in terrorist activities startled the Italian political establishment a month ago.

title: The New York Times /Carl T. Gossett
description: TRIPLEDIGIT GASOLINE: Sign at a Second Avenue service station displays what is believed to be the highest price for the fuel in the metropolitan area. Page B6.

title: Iran Paper Offers Prize For the Slaying of Shah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 17 (Reuters) An advertisement in an Iranian newspaper today offered anyone who murders the Shah an expensespaid pilgrimage to the holy city of Mecca, Saudi Arabia.

title: Penn State Will Leave Circuit, Go Independent
description: SHAWNEEONDELAWARE, Pa., May 17 (UPI)  Penn State University sad today it planned to withdraw from the Eastern 8 Basketball League and become an independent, effective at the end of the 198081 season.

title: Worker Dies in Chemical Vat
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif., May 17 (AP) An employee at the OwensCorning Fiberglas plant died yesterday when he fell into a chemical mixing vat during cleaning, the Santa Clara County corner said. The victim, Manuel Bello, 35 years old, of San Jose, died of chest injuries.

title: F.B.I. Is Duped By Own Ruse; U.S. Faces Suits
description: Operation Frontload looked to the Federal Bureau of Investigation like the perfect undercover plan for penetrating organized crime in the construction industry in New York and elsewhere.

description: There was no countdown or deafening, roar of rocket engines, but the conditions were perfect as thiS young girl found as she sent scores of wobbling soap bubbles into the lower atmosphere along Nidth Avenue yseterday, a perfect day for so important an event.

title: Castro Is Warmly Welcomed by Mexican President
description: COZUMEL, Mexico, May 17  Describing President Fidel Castro of Cuba as one of the personalities of this century, President Jose Lopez Portillo welcomed him today on his first visit to Mexico in more than 20 years.

title: School Cuts in City's 80 Budget Fought
description: Restoration of some of the cuts proposed for the city school system in Mayor Koch's budget for the fiscal year 1980 emerged as the most urgent priority during two weeks of public hearings by the Board of Estimate and the City Council's Finance Committee. The hearings ended yesterday.

title: Games Are Fare on 83d St.
description: Amateur athletes and fans of street fairs will find their interests combined tomorrow from 11 A.M. to6 P.M. at the Biggest Game in Town on 83d Street, between East End and First Avenues. Games of basketball, hockey, darts, golf, backgammon and more will be played at the fair, sponsored by the 83d Street Block Association. In addition, there will be entertainment by clowns, puppeteers, mimes, magicians and musicians. The rain date is Sunday. In. formation: 7346977.

title: Tributes to Randolph Led by Carter and Mondale.
description: President Carter and Vice President Mondale led tributes yesterday from political, religious anti civic leaders to A. Philip Randolph, the longtime labor leader and civil rights activist, who died Wednesday afternoon.

title: Breaking in the Uniform as 124 New Firemen Graduate
description: Jason Fairservices, 2 years old, had some difficulty keeping his fireman's cap on as he was treated to an inspection of apparatus at the Fire Department's Training Center on Randalls Island. His uncle, Keith Monzillo, was one of the 124 firemen who graduated from the department's sixweek training course in ceremony there yesterday.

title: Carter to Speak in Indiana
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (Ap)  President Carter will travel to Indianapolis Jai* 2 to address the Jefferson,JacksonDay Dinner of the Indiana. Democratic Party, the White House press secretary. Jody Powell, announced today.

title: The Pop Life
description: DONNA SUMMER'S twodisk album, Bad Girls, is an exhilarating set, her best yet, and the first single from it, Hot Stuff, is the best commercial single of the year so far. The disk represents a new triumph for the production team of Giorgio Moroder and Pete Bellotte, and in its own way, it's as much a fusion record as the SummerMoroderBellotte I Feel Love single was. But most of all, Bad Girls represents a breakthrough for Miss Summer as a singer.

title: Restaurants
description: OLDFASHIONED Cantonese dishes, now unfortunately out of fashion, are very much evidence at the Mon Hueng Seafood House, a typically large, sprawling Chinatovm restaurant, with plastictop tables, a notable absence of conscious decor and a loyal clientele that jams the place, especially on weekends. The menu features a good number of expertly prepared seafood specialties, but.there are also meat dishes worth trying.

title: Ford and A.M.C. Set Plant Closings
description: The Ford Motor Company and the American Motors Corporation announced in Detroit yesterday that they would temporarily close some assembly plants because of the lagging sales of fullsized cars.

title: Fur Shows Open With Focus on the New Silhouette
description: The fashion spotlight turned on the furriers this week, and a very pleased lot they were. After all, they have had three frigid winters in a row, sending shivering customers into their showrooms. In addition, there is the change of silhouette in all aspects of fashion, and even the wellfurred woman can be lured into considering a new style.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets, responding first to news of lower production and housing and later to a largerthanexpected increase in the money supply, advanced early in the day and fell back later, closing with small net changes.

title: What's Happening at the Festival
description: What's Happening at the Festival

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television  Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio  WMCA, 8 P.M.)

title: George Crumb Music and Talk in Queens
description: Two works by George Crumb and two other contemporary composers, Tobias Picker and Michael Cherry, will be performed by the New Music Consort, a chamber group, Sunday at 3 P.M. at York College's Hillside Center. Auditorium, 150111 87th Road, Queens.

title: The New York Times/Fred R. Conrad
description: AFTER MONTHS OF RESTORATION the Shubert Theater, on 44th Street,boasted a new copper roof, a cleansed terior and improvements to the interior. Scaffolding was removed yesterday.

title: Film: 'Battlestar Galactica,' a Sci-Fi Child of TV:Space Operetta
description: HERE is a problem in deduction: Once upon a time, in the far-away galaxy called California, there was a television series called "Battlestar Galactica." It was a very expensive series, and it was a flop. So the series was canceled. Then Universal took the three-hour debut episode of the show and decided to release it in movie theaters to those same people who hadn't even liked the program for free. A little Sensurround was added. The commercials were removed. Someone thought the whole thing was a good idea.Here are some questions you won't even need your Intergalactic Gyromodular Datamatron to answer: Has Hollywood finally come up with something even less imaginative than the common sequel? If so, then why? Can a lavish but mediocre television program be improved by the absence of commercials that do, after all, wake an audience up? In all fairness, it should be pointed out that part of the principal audience for "Battlestar Galactica"  small children already hooked on "Star Wars"  was asleep by the time the original three-hour episode concluded on television, inasmuch as a long Presidential press conference gummed up that evening's schedule. But who's to say that it wasn't the program itself, and not the lateness of the hour, that made them drowsy?Certainly "Battlestar Galactica" has that effect in its current form, notwithstanding the ferocious rumbling noises that have been added to its soundtrack. Everyone involved seems to have worked so carefully and expensively at aping "Star Wars" that the humor has been lost, and so has the sense of fun. The only real additions to the "Star Wars" format, in fact, are a couple of ill-advised romantic subplots and a little boy with a fuzzy robot that has taken the place of his lost dog."Battlestar Galactica" was produced by John Dykstra, who was responsible for a lot of the special effects in "Star Wars," and the technical aspects of the program are accordingly impressive. There's even one new gimmick, a woman character with two mouths and four eyes. But the other effects, no matter how well executed, simply don't have the impact they did when they were new. If you've seen one ship chase another around the block in outer space, you've seen 'em all."Bttlestar Galactica" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It takes a generally smirky tone toward its female characters, one of whom is supposed to be the sci-fi equivalent of a prostitute.

title: Sidewalks of New York Are One Big Street Fair This Weekend
description: InBrooklyn, Park Slope is turning is inside out for its fourth annual Seienth Heaven Fair on Seventh Avenue, and in Bay Ridge, NOrWegianAmericans will march in celebration of their heritage. In Greenwich Village; the attraction will be Ye Olde Village Fair on Bedford, Barrow and Commerce streets Gramercy Park is checking in with Edwardians and Cockneys; there will be a Sephardic Fair on West 70th Street off Central Park West; and, on the Lower East Side, Little Ukraine will present its culture, food and neighborhood pride.

title: Montreal's Defense Never Rests
description: Looking back on their 41 loss to the Montreal Canadiens last night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers arrived at a common conclusion: It was defense that did it  the Canadiens defense.

description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overtheCounter.

title: Economic Scene
description: How Japan Sees Chinese MarketJAPAN looks across the sea to China as the last big remaining market in the world. A common view in Japan is that the Japanese and Chinese economies are complementary, with China abundant in minerals, oil and coal (which Japan lacks) and with Japan rich in capital and technology (which China needs).

title: Books of TheTirnes
description: N what Jefferson called the splendid misery of being President of the United States, here is what Gerald R. Ford has to say: I never felt better physically. I never had a clearer mind. I never enjoyed an experience more.

title: Dionisije Milivojevich; Serbian Church Bishop
description: LIBERTYVILLE, III., May 17 (UPI) Memorial services for Bishop Dionisije Milivojevich, the spiritual leader of thousands of members of a sect of the Serbian Orthodox Church in the United States,and Canada, were scheduled for today through Saturday.

title: Canadiens Defeat Rangers, Take 21 Lead in Cup Final
description: As if inspired by a deafening noise from a feverish crowd rooting against them, the Montreal Canadiens kept their poise, scored after the Rangers crept within a goal in the final period and won Game 3 of the Stanley Cup final series by 41 last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Egypt Tells. Soviet Ambassador It Would Like to Better Relations
description: CAIRO, May 17 (AP)  Boutros Ghali, Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, and Vladimir P. Polyakov, the Soviet Ambassador, met today to discuss strained relations between the two countries and also the Middle East situation in general.

title: Hanes. Makeup Venture: Another Golden Egg?
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C. The name sounds vaguelyFrench, but the marketing is verfAmerican, masterminded by the Hanes Corporation, once known mostly for departmentstore hosiery and men's and boy's underwear.

title: The City
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that 16 of 21 shortterm goals of a plan announced last September to clean up the Times Square area had been accomplished as promised in the first third of the 18month program.

title: LOUIS SCATURRO
description: Dr. Louis Scaturro, an assistant professor of nuclear engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home in North Andover, Mass. He was 28 years old.

title: Chile Court Orders Freeing of 39
description: SANTIAGO. Chile, May 17 A Chilean court today freed 39 people arrested on orders of Ministry of the Interior for demonstrating against a Government ban on may Day celebrations.

title: AUGIE RATNER
description: EL CAJON, Calif. May 17  August (Augie) Ratner, a middleweight boxer in the 1910's and 1920's, died last Monday in a hospital.He was 84 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on April 24 incorrectly equated 170 with the number I followed by 20 zeroes. The value of 120 is 1.

title: Why Jason Robards was fated to play Howard Hughes.
description: THEY couldn't have cast anyone else as Howard Hughes, Jason Robards was saying. Robards was his middle name, and he had cousins named Loomis, which was the maiden name of one of my grandmothers. I figured I didn't have to do any preparation for the part. It's all built in genetically. Maybe I should have written a will myself.

title: World News Brsiefs
description: MANILA, May 17 (UPI)  The Soviet bloc and its atlies staged a walkout at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development here today when a representadve of the ousted Cambodian ernment of Prime Minister Poi Pot was given the right to speak.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Concern over rising oil prices helped push gold to a record high for the third consecutive session on European bullion marketg yesterday while the dollar, in demand to pay for oil, rose in New York and abroad.

title: Rebuked Aide to Head Federal Election Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) Former Representative Robert Tiernan, publically rebuked for making 12,000 in personal calls on Government telephones and sued for not paying his campaign bills, was elected chairman of the Federal Election Commission today.

title: Nathaniel Rafael Jones
description: When Nathaniel Jones received a call from the White House Wednesday night inviting him to yesterday's commemoration of the 25th anniversary of the Brown v. Board of Education decision, he thought it was because he was the general counsel to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. He had no idea that the ceremony would also become an occasion fora personal celebration.

title: Nevada Reporter Loses Appeal On Ruling in Shield Law Dispute
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., May 17 (AP) The State Supreme Court has upheld the contemptofcourt judgment against a Las Vegas Sun reporter, Dan Newburn, for refusing to answer questions about the will of the late Howard R. Hughes.

title: Play: Murder at Howard Johnson's
description: MURDER at the Howard Johnson's comes in only three flavors; all of them vanilla.

title: Cosmos to Hire Coach for Goalies
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 17  The signing of a Brazilian specialist, Miguel de Lima, to coach the goalkeepers will be announced by the Cosmos next week.

title: Begin and Weizman Clash on Plan For West Bank and Gaza SelfRule
description: JERUSALEM, May 17  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman clashed today with Prime Minister Menachem Begin over the Israeli Government's plan on selfrule for Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza territories. Mr. Weizman said he would probably refuse to represent Israel at negotiations with ERVIA next week on the selfrule issue.

title: 9th Ave. Festival Blends Flavors Of Many Nations
description: PAUL PALMA hopes that it will be warm tomorrow and Sunday. for the sixth annual.Ninth Avenue. International PestiVal, not uncomfortably warm, but Warm enough forthe avenue's merchants to keep him busy. It is Mr, Palma who will supply just abciut all the ice that keeps the Taiwanese pineapple, Long Island clams, Massachusetts oysters, Philippine beer, Pellegrinomineral water, pickled Korean kimche, Turkish boorek (a drink nuts and honey), Barbadian sugar cane and Cuban flan cold on hundreds of sidewalkfood stands along the avenue.

title: Yiddish Theater May Get New House
description: A new Yiddish National Theater that would serve as a permanent home for Yiddishlanguage stagecraft in all of its aspects is in the cards for the theater row that has come about on West 42d Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues.

title: Eastern L.I. Gasoline Dealers Fear Empty Pumps for Memorial Day
description: Village officials and gasoline retailers on eastern Long Island  largely dependent on summer tourists, who triple the population of its seaside villages warned yesterday that there may be no gasoline in the area's 154 service stations on Memorial Day weekend, when the season begins.

title: Scene of an Early Victory: Schools Are Still Segregated
description: SUMMERTON, S.C.  The public schools in this little rural town in the South Carolina outback are a curious legacy to the memory of the Rev. Joseph Albert Delaine, the slight, stiffbacked black preacher who fought so hard and hurt so much to make the schools of Summerton neither white nor black but, as the Supreme Court finally put it, just schools.

title: $350,000 in Diamonds Stolen
description: Two men, one armed with a handgun, robbed the sixthfloor offices of of the Baron Diamond Company at 580 Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon of more than $350,000 in diamonds. The police said the robbers handcuffed two salesmen, then rifled two desks and the company's safe.

title: Strong Opposition Delays Bill on Panama Canal Pact
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Opponents of a House bill to put the Panama Canal Treaty into effect came close today to sending it back to committee. As a result, Democratic leaders decided to delay final floor action on the bill indefmitely.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSOscar. Guiding Light Lodge. 1151 F.& A.M. sorrowfully announces the passing of their brother Oscar Abrams and extends to his bereaved fanny their sincere sympathies.

title: F.C.C. Meets on Telecommunications
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The Federal Communications Commission talked of fields of flowers, canaries and gorillas today in a broad public discussion of ways to lift regulations from the telecommunications industry. In the end, after the public meeting, the commissioners put off action on regulatory changes until the staff sorts out varying needs of  and threats from  the big and small companies in the industry.

title: King Trackmen Capture Manhattan P.S.A.L. Title
description: Mark Preston, Mitchell Harris and Jim Destin were double winners and Martin Luther King High School took the team title yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League Manhattan track and field championships at Downing Stadium.

description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)  The Department of Health, Education And Welfare is losing several of its top, officials in a series of resignations speeded up by a tough new Government ethics act that takes effect July 1.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 17 (UPI)  Roy Smalley singled and doubled to highlight a 14hit attack by Minnesota that carried the Twins to a 76 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight and gave Jerry Koosman his seventh triumph without a loss.

description: FRANKFURT, May 17 (AP)  West German production of passenger cars and station wagons totaled 342,300 units in April, down 12.5 percent from 391,331 units in March but up 9.1 percent from 313,530 units in April 1978, the automobile industry association reported today.

title: Concert: A Premiere
description: THE urge to draw a likeness of their native land comes over most composers at one time or another in their careers. Sometimes a Ma Viast or a Boris Godunov is the result, but more often we get the orotundities of A Lincoln Portrait or similarly wellmeant flights of patriotism. Donald Erb, whose New England's Prospect was given its New York premiere at Carnegie Hall last night by the Oratorio Society of New York, plainly was aware of how difficult it is to convey the flavor of a nation in music without sliding into clich. As a consequence, perhaps, his ambitious sevensection work for narrator, choruses and orchestra struggled so hard to avoid the obvious that it ended up being vague and unsatisfying both as rhetoric and as music.

title: Price Violations At Woolworth's Charged By City
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs charged yesterday that F. W. Woolworth & Company nickels and dimes its customers with mispriced sale items and unavailable advertised specials.

The first discovery was made May 8 in the luggage of a Tel Aviv man traveling with an Iranian passport. Three arrests followed.

Besides the usual madness and merriment involving King Oberon and Puck, theproduction will include a new noteoriginal incidental music by Richard White. May 17 From the point of  view of members of the American Association of Advertising Agencies meeting at the Greenbrier Hotel here, probably the nicest thing that happens each day off the links and courts is the prediction that the future holds the need for even more advertising.

On Sunday two starfilled movies open at the Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street, but they won't be premieres; one was made in 1937, the other five years later. And the attendent trumpets, drum rolls and roving searchlights won't be outside the theater, they'll be flashing across the silver screen inside, as part of the opening credit announcing a 20th CenturyFox film.

title: 2 Territories Wait to Be Provinces
description: WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, May 17  Separating Canada from, the Soviet Union, its other superpower neighbor, are two vast territories that are waiting to become Canadian provinces.are still ruled by a commissioner appointed by the Prime Minister. Provincial status is probably still some time away, but would come sooner under government led by the Progressive Conservative Party.

title: Stage: Musical Festival Tells Story of Carnival

Certainly, it has energy and good humor, and the kind of innocent vulgarity that would not be inimical to a child's birthday party. In fact, Festival would be a smash at child's birthday party. It is a ceremony for innocents.

title: Tough Choices for Afghanistan's Regime and Its Opponents.

title: 1982 World Cup Soccer Will Go Up to 24 Teams

title: In T.V.A. Country, Contentment Is a Nuclear Plant

title: Two Get Draws As Karpou Plays 20 in New York
description: Last night, the first time in 50 years that a reigning world chess champion has Karpov met 20 challengers simulta neously at the Game Room on Manhatcrushed 18 of the egos, but most unpredictably, he inflated two others by giving drows  to an unrated Manhattan woman and to a 14yearold boy from Brookly.

title: Monthly Orders Rise 5% for U.S. Home
description: The U.S. Home Corporation, one of the country's largest onsite manufacturers of singlefamily homes, said that its April new orders totaled 1,567 units, about 5 percent more than were ordered in the same month last year. It put the orders value at current prices at about $91 million.

title: Continental Oil Earnings
description: The Continental Oil Company expects this year's earnings to be substantially better than last year, Ralph E. Bailey, company chairman, told a group of security analysts meeting yesterday in Stamford, Conn. He also predicted exceptional earnings growth through the mid1980's.

title: Jury Acquits Judge Groh In $7,000 Extortion Case
description: A Queens jury acquitted Judge Robert T. Groh of Civil Court yesterday of charges that he had extorted $7,000 in political payoffs for Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President. The jury deliberated for four hours.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Judge Leon Jaworski's compelling plea (OpEd May 7) for the rights of the unpopular accused isproperly focused on the responsibility of lawyers to do their very best to establish innocence. But his preoccupation with assuring a fair trial puts too much emphasis on the judicial processes and too little on the aim of a just society a fair outcome for the accused.

title: Ecuador General Accused of Role in Killing
description: QUITO, Ecuador  A series of legalbbfuscations apparently designed to protect a general from charges of complicity in the assassination of a onetime presidential candidae appears to have shakenthe faith of Ecuadoretinsin their judicial system.

title: Screen: 'Death of a Bureaucrat, 'Gutierrez Alea's Cuban Comedy:The Tape Is Red
description: RED tape can strangle a society more efficiently than even the wiliest revolutionaries or, as the case may be, the wiliest counter-revolutionaries. Forced to deal with the pomp, ceremony, protocol, forms, fine print and contradictory instructions of their bureaucracy, citizens first seethe with anger and then they may simply give up in frustration. There are times when a lost rubber stamp is mightier than the sword.This is the underlying theme of Tomas Gutierrez Alea's quirky, high-spirited Cuban comedy. "Death of a Bureaucrat," which opens today at the Cinema Studio. The film, made in 1966, two years before his extraordinary "Memories of Underdevelopment," is as much a movie maker's movie as it is a social satire. Mr. Gutierrez Alea happily helps himself (and us) to the styles of all sorts of film comedians, including those of Chaplin, the Keystone Kops and Laurel and Hardy, as he tells the tale of the good-natured, none-too-bright young man who attempts to come to the aid of his recently bereaved aunt.The woman's husband, having been an "exemplary worker," was buried with all sorts of honors and tributes. Among his achievements he invented a Rube Goldberg type of machine to mass-produce busts of the hero, Jos Martin, but he was accidently caught in the machine's gears, This "poor man's Michelangelo" (as he's called) was also buried with his union card, which the widow needs if she is to obtain the pension that is due her.The nephew's problem is that be cannot obtain an exhumation permit for two years and then, after he has stolen the body from the cemetery, he can't obtain a permit to rebury the corpse until he obtains the exhumation permit. As the poor man goes from office to office, meeting with every conceivable type of indifference, sloppiness and self-importance, his adventures lead to a final, fatal but highly satisfying confrontation.Slapstick comedy is not the form that Mr. Gutierrez Alea is most at home in. Indeed, with the exception of Jacques Tati and Blake Edwards, there are few directors who understand the graceful mechanics by which slapstick comedy operates. Yet Mr. Gutierrez Alea has managed with remarkable skill to concoct a comedy whose lunatic fun absorbs the outrage.At one point there is a superbly wild custard pie-and-flowers battle at the cemetery, which begins when the irate cemetery officials start to dismantle (Laurel and Hardy style, or is it Edgar Kennedy?) the hearse of the undertaker who wants to rebury the corpse without the proper forms. How the custard pies find their way into the fracas I'm not sure, but they are beautifully splattered over landscape and people. Harold Lloyd is recalled when the nephew finds himself locked into a government office after closing time and, to escape, must climb out a window onto a narrow ledge in front of a large clock high above the street.The pace of the comedy is erratic. Like the uncle's bust-manufacturing machine, it moves in fits and starts, but at its best it is most satisfying. Salvador Wood is very funny and straight as the nephew and Silvia Planas is a model of patient grief as the widow who becomes resigned to keeping the corpse at home, preserved as best it can be with ice borrowed from the neighbors.Even when the comedy is strained, "Death of a Bureaucrat" should work on the gut responses of anyone who has ever stood in lines at bureaus dealing in driver's licenses, rent control, gas, water, electricity or  perish the thought  complaints. I also find irresistible any movie that contains a banana peel that gets stepped on.

title: Key Figure in Schools Case. Decries Rights Lag in North
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  There is no gray in 'enneth Clark's hair now, 25: years after his research on the effect of; segregated education on black and white children was immortalized in the Supreme Court's opinion in Brown v. Board of Education by one of the most famous footnotes in Judicial history. But there was weariness in his face and his Voice as he spoke at the commemoration of the Court's decision about his views on the state of racial affairs and education in America today.

title: NASA Awaits China Decision on Space Flights in 82
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, in anticipation of a contract to put into orbit a Chinese civil satellite communications network, has tentatively scheduled cargo space on two space shuttle flights in 1982.

title: Exxon Head Sees Oil Demand Exceeding Supplies for Decade
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 17  World oil demand should exceed supplies for the next decade, the president of the Exxon Corporation, Howard C. Kauffman, said here today.

title: U.S. SEEKING PLEDGE SOVIET WON'T CURB RATE OF EMIGRATION
description: WASHINGTON, May 17The United States has asked the Soviet Union for some kind of assurance that emigration, involving mainly Jews, will continue to be liberalized so that Moscow can become eligible for trade benefits.

title: Ontario Worthy of Superlatives: Big Best, Richest, Most Important
description: TORONTO, May 17  If Ontario was anywhere except the middle of Canada, it would be a major independent nation and an economic power in its own right.

title: Easum, Ambassador to Nigeria, May Become U.S. Deputy at U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Administration officials said today that Donald B. Easum, Ambassador to Nigeria, was expected to be named United States deputy chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: Big Spending Vs. Austerity
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  In the often impromptu scenario of politics, entirely uncoordinated events will occasionally achieve, nearly simultaneously, a sort of sharpfocus, splitscreen presentation of a major national issue. It happened on Capitol Hill this week.

title: Art: Double Salute To Mexico's Tamayo
description: FOR quite some years now, Rtifino Tzuniyo has been the best painter in Mexico. Next Aug 26, he will be 80 years old.

title: IN THE NATION An Unwanted Bedfellow
description: John F. Burns of The New York Times has reported from South Africa that officials there hailed the Senate's resolution calling on President Carter to lift economic sanctions against Rhodesia. That ought to tell supporters of this resolution something, unless they think the United States should be in bed with South Africa on Rhodesian policy.

title: Foreign Debt Up 20% in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, May 17 (AP)  Israel's foreign debt rose by 20 percent in 1978 to $16.5 billion, according to figures released by the Central Bureau of Statistics.

title: Billy Carter Not a Tenet Of Inquiry, Lawyer Says

title: Three in Key Army Jobs Reshuffled by Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI)  The Pentagon today announced a reshuffle of three top Army men that is a consequence of President Carter's promotion of a threestar general to be the new Chief of Staff.

title: McEnroe Out With Injury; Miss Austin Is Winner
description: TOKYO, May 17 (AP)  John McEnroe suffered an ankle injury and had to quit in his firstround match at a $175,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament today. The 20yearold New Yorker was trailing Pat DuPre, another American, 76, 32, when he retired.

title: Unhappy Jersey Commuter Finds a Forum
description: On the way home from work yesterday evening, Arnold Decof finally found someone to listen to his complaints about commuter bus service to New Jersey.

title: Met Head Summons A Meeting on Slump
description: Lorinda de Roulet, board chairman of the Mets, has scheduled a highlevel dialogue with management when the bedraggled team returns today from its coasttocoast losing roadtrin.

title: A Survey Shows Alienation Grips Two Poor Areas
description: Residents of two of the city's poorest neighborhoods feel alienated from City Hall, an attitude hardened by their perception that services in their communities have deteriorated over the last few years, according to the results of a new poll released yesterday.

title: Army to Make Entry Requirements For Women Same as Those for Men
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The Army, in a major policy shift, is scheduled to announce tomorrow that women seeking to join the service will have the same entry requirements as men. Previously, women needed a high school diploma and higher test scores to join the Army.

title: Miss Stoll Scores Upset AfterHer Purse Is Stolen
description: VIENNA, May 17 (AP)  Unseeded Caroline Stoll of the United States momentarily was left penniless today after a pickpocket stole her purse at the courts, but then she scored the biggest win of my life in the $75,000 women's Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Opera: Gimpel, the Fool in Yiddish
description: There is a long tradition of Yiddish operetta, but serious opera in Yiddish is something else again. What may be the first example of this form here or probably anywhere for that matter will happen on Sunday night at 8, when David Schiff's Gimpel, the Fool is staged at the 92d Street Y. The piece is also the first in a series called Jewish Opera at the Y, which will include works based on Jewish subjects and using Jewish thematic material. And, to conclude the list of firsts, it is the initial opera to be written by the composer, a pupil of Elliott Carter's.

title: U.S. Finds OilReserve Cost Rising
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI) The fuel reserve program intended to protect the United States in case of oil embargoes has had multimilliondollar cost overruns, an Energy Department report said today.

title: Labor Dept. Creates a New Post To Oversee CETA Job Program
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  In his latest effort to get a grip on the Government's sprawling employment and training pro. grams. Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall announced today the creation of a new highlevel post to oversee the multibilliondollar jobs effort.

title: U.S. Is Studying Charges Linked To Mastropieri
description: Eugene T. Mastropieri, whose expulsion from the City Council was unanimously recommended by the Council's Ethics. Coinmittee on Wednesday, is under jnyestigation by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of having as. sisted organized crime figures, to evade Federal income taxes, sources close to the inquiry said last night:

title: Film: 'Hanover Street,' a Love Story:Romantic Mixed Nuts
description: EVERY now and then a film comes along of such painstaking, overripe foolishness that it breaks through the garbage barrier to become one of those rare movies you rush to see for laughs. What Peter Hyams has achieved with "Hanover Street," his new film about a wartime romance set in the London of 1943, is a movie that is almost as funny as Woody Allen's "What's Up, Tiger Lily?" which, if you remember, was a straight-faced Japanese spy picture that Woody took over and dubbed with a hilariously knuckle-brained English-language soundtrack. The clichs were everywhere, but always just slightly out of place and inappropriate.This pretty much describes the unfortunate method of "Hanover Street," which looks as if Mr. Hyams had studied every popular romantic drama, from "A Farewell to Arms" to "Love Affair" and "Love Story," and then, when he left the screening room, had been hit on the head with a brick. When he woke up he remembered bits and pieces of things he'd seen but his judgment had fled."Hanover Street," which opens today at the Loew's State 2 and Tower East Theaters, starts being funny with the opening credits, which are set against a vista of fleecy white clouds and a soundtrack full of John Barry's music so heavenly we suspect we might be dead. But no. As the camera pans down we realize that we've been suspended over London's Hanover Street, an elaborate studio set full of carefully simulated Georgian buildings, a lovely Wren-ish church at the far end, and lots of extras looking like a wartime populace.It's here, late one afternoon, that handsome, debonaire David Halloran (Harrison Ford), an American bomber pilot on his day off from bombing Germans, and classy Margaret Sellinger (Lesley-Anne Down), a young woman of exquisite beauty dressed in a Red Cross uniform, meet when they both run for the same bus. Before you know it, they're having tea in a nearby tea-shop and he's saying such things as, "Who are you and what are you?" and she's being mysterious.David: "Tell me your name."Margaret: "I can't."David: "Please."Margaret: "No."David: "I'll call you Fred."Whatever he calls her, it's love, love, love. Does Margaret have a fatal disease? A police record? Amnesia? We soon learn the truth. She's married, and not only married but happily married, to upright, honoborable Paul Sellinger (Christopher Plummer), a British intelligence officer. She's also a mummy to Sarah Sellinger (Patsy Kensit), an eight-year-old of such sweet precocity we want to ship her off to the coal mines for a vacation."Hanover Street" is the hysterically unconvincing story of the clandestine affair of David and Margaret who, once a week, make love in quaint little country inns in scenes of lap-dissolve close-ups shot so near to the flesh that we might well be back watching Streisand and Kristofferson in "A Star is Born." Only the music is different (it's worse).A program note, contained in the movie's publicity kit, solemnly declares that "cameras played an important part in the filming of 'Hanover Street.'" Like many other directors Mr. Hyams believes (mistakenly, I think) that the closer the camera gets to a subject, the more important the subject becomes. Close-ups, though, are to movies what too many adjectives and adverbs are to prose. Instead of clarifying meaning, they soften it with fancy pretentions.Not that there's much meaning to soften in "Hanover Street." The middle of the movie sort of vamps for time as if waiting for the next page of the script to arrive. It cross-cuts among montages that show (1) David and Margaret driving through the countryside en route to their rendezvous, (2) David flying through flak over occupied France, and (3) upright, honorable Paul Sellinger confronting a knotty intelligence problem that eventually results in his and David's going off on a mission into occupied France.Two men, each of a different backgrounds and outlook but each in his way true to his code, facing death together and not knowing they love the same woman! I would love to read the minutes of the story conference that accepted that one. They might even be funnier than the movie.It's going to be interesting to see how the public responds to "Hanover Street." To me it looks like a movie that underestimates its public and spares no expense doing it. Such nonsense, spread on so thickly, seems essentially cynical. I can't believe that anyone connected with the picture, from Mr. Hyams, who wrote as well as directed it, to the actors, didn't know they were involved in a con job.I've no idea whether the film will do anything for Mr. Ford's screen popularity. He's more of a comic-strip character here than he was in "Star Wars," which was a live-action cartoon. Miss Down is sublimely scenic. Alec McCowen, one of the better actors in the English theater, spends what time he has on the screen fiddling with a pipe.In his last movie, "Capricorn One," which was about a faked space mission, Mr. Hyams was exposing fraud. In "Hanover Street," he's practicing it."Hanover Street," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested"), contains the aforementioned love scenes and some rude language.

title: New York County Lawyers Group Elects Baer as Its New President
description: Harold Baer Jr., a partner in the law firm of Guggenheimer & Untennyer, was elected president of the New York County Lawyers Association last night, succeeding Lawrence X. Cusack.

title: New Evidence in Officer's Slaying
description: Detectives investigating last Thursday's fatal shooting of an offduty police officer in an Astoria, Queens, bar now believe that the officer might have been mistaken by the gunman for a lone shark who had been marked for death in retaliation for a murder 10 years ago, sources close to the investigation said last night.

title: The Charm and Showmanship of Fred Silverman: Affiliates Get His Message
description: LOS ANGELES, May 17  Fred Silverman, president of the National Broadcasting Company, put his flair for showmanship on display in a threeday meeting with NBCTV affiliates here and won what he had sought  a vote of confidenCe and their implicit pledge of support for his efforts to reverse the network's fouryear decline in popularity.

title: The Outlook for Gasoline Supplies in May
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)  Will drivers soon face long lines at gasoline stations? The question cannot be answered precisely. Long lines traditionally develop at the end of the month when gasoline supplies become scarce.

title: British Delegate, Wittyas Ever,_ Is Leaving After 5 Years at U.N.
description: UNITED'NATIONS, N.Y.. May 17 Even if the British election had not swept the Labor Government from power, Ivor Richard would have been heading home, he says, because it was time after hire years as chief delegate to move along.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Swiss Vote Due on Nuclear Curbs
description: GENEVA, May 17  A confusing campaign is being waged in Switzerland for a referendum this weekend on the development of nuclear energy.

title: Bache Group Net Up Sharply
description: The Bache Group, the parent company of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, a leading stock brokerage house, yesterday reported a sharp advance in net income for its third fiscal quarter ended April 30 to $1.9 million, or 24 cents a share, more than triple the $501,000, or 7 cents a share, reported in the comparable quarter of last year.

title: Typewriter Import Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI)  The Treasury today opened an antidumping investigation of imports of portable electric typewriters from Japan.

title: Heart of Canadian Election Debate Is Just What to Do About Quebec
description: MONTREAL, May 17  Quebec, the problem child in the Canadian federation, is once again at the heart of a confused political debate that has marked the long national campaign for the election of new House of Commons next Tuesday.

title: 5 Catholic Parishes Work To Get Absentees Home
description: For years, Ann Sharp, has been a sometime Catholic, going to church, she says, only a few days a year.

title: About Real Estate
description: BEDFORD, N.Y.  It will be recalleil that the spacious, horsy town of Bedfbrd was one of nine in Westchester County where the state's Urban Development Corporation proposed a modest touch of suburban lowincome housing seven years ago.

title: Nippon Steel In China Talks
description: TOKYO. May 17 (AP)  The Nippon Steel Corporation, the largest steelmaker in Japan, said today that it would send five officials to Peking tomorrow to reopen negotiations on construction near Shanghai of what will be one of the world's largest steel mills.

title: Metal Anchor Blamed For Fall of Slab on L.I.
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 17 (AP) An engineering report says that an anchor made of gray cast iron that fails suddenly without warning if subjected to too much stress caused the fall of a fourandahalfton concrete slab from the facade of Nassau Community College's physicaleducation center last March.

title: Expert Traces More Money to Talmadge's Accuser
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)  Senator Herman E. Talmadge's thief accuser probably took about $13,000 from a secret bank account for his personal use, a Government financial expert said today.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission praised 11 companies today for taking steps to recall or repair 90 percent of the estimated 12 million electric hair dryers that contain potentially dangerous asbestos heat shields. They agency's fourc.ommissioners approved the programs unanimously.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Alternatesideofthestreet parking regulations are in effect today and tomorrow only in Brooklyn as part of a boroughbyborough rotation plan to clean up refuse built up during the tugboat strike. Next week, the regulations will be in effect in the Bronx and suspended in the other boroughs.

title: Choice of Ambassadors a Constant Point of Dispute Between Professional and Politician
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  Sally Shelton, a 34yearold political protegee of a Texas Senator, shifted uneasily in the witness chair in the cavernous chamber of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday during a 15minute hearing on her nomination to be Ambassador to Barbados.

title: Catching a Brisk Harbor Wind Past a Clear City Skyline
description: It was a clear day with a good wind as the schooner Pioneer sailed through the harbor yesterday past the skyline of lower Manhattan and made her way back to berth at the South Street Seaport. The ship, which trains students in the art of sailing, plies the waters of New York harbor during warmweather months with cargoes of passengers seeking a respite from a fastpaced urban life or trying to get a glimpse of what the bygone era of sailing ships was like.

title: Pentagon Chief Briefs Spaniards On NATO's Plans and Arms Pact
description: MADRID, May 17 (Reuters)  Defense Secretary Harold Brown briefed Spain's military today on NATO's defense plans and the projected SovietAmerican treaty to limit strategic arms, Spanish sources said.

title: Kremlin. Art Dazzles: the Eye In Show at Met
description: ONE of the don'tmiss sights of the Western world is the Kremlin in MitscoW and its complex of churches and museums, each groaning with accumulated treasures that reflect  in such surfeit as to glaze the eye of the most appetitive art traveler  the power of the Russian throne and church before the revolution of 1917.

title: U.S. Hunting for Copies of Classified Data on Bomb
description: The Department of Energy is trying to round up copies of a classified document that reportedly gives the precise details of the trigger mechanism of hydrogen bombs and that has been available to the public at the Loi Alamos (N.M.) Scientific Laboratory since 1975.

title: News Summary
description: Continued liberal Soviet emigration is being sought by the United States. Until at least oral assurances are received, American officials said, Washington cannot make Moscow eligible for trade concessions. The United States wants to grant nondiscriminatory tariffs and Governmentbacked credits to Moscow and Peking at about the same time. [Page A1, Column 3.]

title: New York Folklore Conference at Hunter
description: A free, fourday conference on the folklore of New York City, sponsored by organizations in,the city, will begin today at the Hunter College School of Social Work, 129 East 79th Street, between Lexington and Park Avenues.

title: U.S. Commercial Fishermen Set Mark in Seafood Catch Last Year
description: WAS1(INGTON, May 17 (AP)  The Government reported today that United States commercial fishermen set records last year for the amount of seafood caught and the value of the catch.

title: Bridge:
description: There are several oddities about a Chinese finesse. It is not a finesse, it is not Chinese and Deng Xiaoping, Peking's senior Deputy Prime Minister and the only known Chinese bridge player, has probably never heard of it.

title: Dow Gain Of 14.47 Best In 7 Weeks
description: Prices on the New York Stock Exchange jumped sharply yesterday as the trading pace picked up, with bluechip and oil issues making the best gains.

title: Business and the Law
description: IF the Supreme Court decision had not become known by the catchy term Illinois Brick, if Senator Edward M. Kennedy had not put his prestige on the line in efforts to overturn it, if fundamental questions of law and economics were not involved, and if both large corporations and consumers were not opposing the legislation on the ground that it would harm the interests of consumers, then the antitrust enforcement bill of 1979 probably would not have captured the wide attention it has.

title: Ballet: The Dancer Who Isn't There
description: THE trouble with announcing ballet casts is that audiences are unreasonable enough to expect to see dancers for whom they have paid good money. Lately however, the American Ballet Theater has made so many substitutions that even this department has received a number of complaints from enraged ticketbuyers.

title: Auctions
description: AN auction that is both the largest sale of ancient Egyptian art in decades and the most important public sale of GrecoRoman antiquities since 1972 takes place tomorrow at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, with sessions at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: A band of clouds stretches alpng the Eastern Seaboard, dissipating as it extends southward to the Florida coast. Clouds are also visible in the Texas Panhandle, and over the Northern Plains States. Clear skies are apparent elsewhere.

title: Books: Editor as Sleuth.
description: LUCILLE KALLEN'S Introducing C.B. Greenfield does just that. It gives us a chance to meet Charlie Greenfield, a curmudgeon of an editor who runs a weekly newspaper in Westchester County in way that does not endear him to the vested interests or to narrowminded politicos. Charlie has a deliberate and somnolent manner behind which hides a steeltrap mind that is working in high gear all the time. The book introduces us, too, to Maggie Rome, a star member of his staff, a sharpeyed matron, a devoted wife and mother of two, who is an able reporter and even more able in carrying out her editor's commands  weird, or at least puzzling, as some of them are.

title: Judge Releases Hanna In Korean Bribe Case
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI)  A Federal district judge has freed from prison former Representative Richard T. Hanna, Democrat of California, the only Congressman convicted in the socalled Korean influencebuying scandal. His sentence was reduced to time served.

title: Umpires Settle Money Issues
description: Major league baseball umpires met with Lee MacPhail, president of the American League, and Chub Feeney, president of the National League, yesterday in an effort to end the strike that has been under way since the start of 'spring training. It appeared that the money issues, at least, had been resolved.

Now it is time for the Actors Theater of Louisville, Ky. Last season, it gave us The Gin Game on Broadway, and last Tuesday night it gave us Getting Out at the Thealer de Lys. Soon it will give us Lone Star and Pvt. Wars at the Century Theater. These two short plays by James McClure will go into previews May, 31, open June 7, and be produced by Michael Harvey and. Peter A. Bobley, in association with, as they say, Columbia Pictures. Movie companies have invested in any number of shows, but this may be the first time they have gone Off Broadway for a nonmusical.

title: Moon's Church Rebuts Testimony on Income
description: Officials of the Unification Church led by the Korean evangelist Sun Myung Moon denied an assertion by former member of the church that the organization had raised between $109 and $219 million nationally last year through street solicitation. They said the figure was close to $20 million, an increase of about $12 Million since 1975.

title: Kathryn Pittman
description: Kathryn Pittman, an artist and educator, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital of cancer. Mrs. Pittman, who lived in Manhattan, was 64 years old.

title: Sonics Beat Suns, Gain N.B.A. Final
description: SEATTLE, May 17 (UPI)  The Seattle Supersonics got a careerhigh 33 points from Jack Sikma and: survived a lastminute scare tonight to defeat the Phoenix Suns, 114110, and win their secbnd consecutive National Basketball Association Western Conference. chpionship. The Sonia will face the winner of tomorrow night's game between the Washington Bullets and the San Antonio Spurs in N.B.A. championship series.

title: Phils Win 50Hit Slugfest, 2322
description: CHICAGO. May (UPI)  Aided by an 18mileperhour wind blowing out to left field, Philadelphia and Chicago belted a recordtying 11 home runs today, including three by Dave Kingman of the Cubs, as the PhiIlies squeezed out a 2322 victory on Mike Schmidt's 10thinning homer.

title: The Region
description: WASHINGTON  An abrupt reversal of position by the Carter Administration has failed to break a deadlock over how to. rescue the deficitridden 1980 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, N.Y. The Administration's reversal came in the form of an announcement that it was lifting certain conditions it had imposed on the $11 million it had agreed to contribute to close an $18 million deficit for the Olympic Games.

title: Mets Lose, 65; Stargell Hits 2
description: PITTSBURGH, May 17  Two home runs by Willie Stargell powered the Pirates to a 6to5 victory over the Mets tonight as the New York team headed home after a 14game trip that brought only three victories.

title: City Acts to Halt illegal Dumping; Company Cited
description: Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel, who has been facing a growing problem of illegal dumping on streets and lots by private carters, said yesterday he was cracking down, and he named one company as probably the worst offender.

title: TransAtlantic Cable
description: The American TelephOne and Telegraph Company filed plans with the Federal Communications Commission for a seventh transAtlantiC telephone cable between America and Britain, to be laid by A.T.&T. and five other unnamed American companies. It would be in place by mid1983, the filing said.

title: Port Authority Is Putting Pressure On. Both Sides to Settle Tug Strike.
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which is increasingly concerned about the diversion of cargo to other ports during the 47dayold tugboat strike, moved yesterday to put pressure on both sides to settle the dispute.

title: ExPoliceman Put on Probation For a False Arrest and Assault
description: A former police officer who had beaten and falsely arrested another man was put on five years probation yesterday by judge who noted his impeccable police record and service to the community.

title: Koch and Stein Spar Over the Cleaning Up Of New York's Streets
description: Dirty streets are the No. 1 issue in Manhattan and garbage collection by private companies should be tested in four of the borough's 12 sanitation districts, Borough President Andrew J. Stein said yesterday.

title: For Children
description: SHEEPTOSHAWL DAY, with demonstrations throughout the day, including one by Roland Wickson. a Trumbull, Conn., shepherd, who will shear sheep, and others by members of the New Canaan Weavers Guild. who will card wool, and members the Handweavers Guild of Connecticut, who will weave on looms, Sunday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Heckscher Farm. Stamford Museum and Nature Center. 39 Scofieldtown Road, Stamford. Conn. Admission: s2oer cer. (203)3221646.

title: Judge Upholds Owner of Yacht Over Insurance
description: Gene DeMatteo, the 46yearold owner of a large construction company in New Haven, is a man who recognizes the truth in J. P. Morgan's reply when asked how much it cost to own a yacht; Any man who has to ask about the annual upkeep of a yacht can't afford one.

title: Women's Softball Team Set to Compete in China
description: PEKING, May 17 (UPI)  A United States women's professional softball team, the Connecticut Falcons, arrived in Peking today to compete against Chinese teams.

title: Publishing: Young Adolf Author on Hitler's England
description: BERYL BAINBRIDGE has never been a.journalist. But as a writer, she acts like one in an important regard: she needs a deadline.

title: Israel the Dream At Bloomingdale's
description: Thanks to Israel, Bloomingdale's is a nonshopper's paradise this weekend, which is good news for the half of the family that would rather improve its mind while the acquisitive partner loses his or hers and runs through the savings.

title: An Endless Winter for the Fans
description: Outside on Seventh Avenue the sun had not gone down and it was too warm to wear a hockey sweater comfortably. With the spring evening and the scalp. ers and the young vendors hustling Tshirts and hats, you would have thought there was a Beach Boys concert inside. The Endless Summer. For these people, it was a wonderful night fora hockey game. Any night this late in the spring is a wonderful night for a hockey game.

title: Seven Students Slain in Ankara As LettRight Warfare Continues
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 17 (AP) Three masked men with machine guns killed Seven leftist students and wounded two in an Ankara cafe last night, apparently in retaliation for the killing of two rightist youths on Tuesday; the police reported.

title: Prof. Longhair Is Swinging at the Gate
description: Professor Longhair, whose distinctive rhumbablues recordings from the late 1940's and early 50's are the foundations of New Orleans rhythm and blueS and rockandroll, embarked last week on hisfirst national tour. He has successfully toured Europe and played engagements in New York and other major United States cities, but this is the first time he has put a band, together and hit the American road for an extended period. With a recent appearance on the Today show, under his belt and an album available on a massdistributed record label for the first time in some years., the Professor seems to be winning some of the recognition he has long deserved.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON. May 17 Before he goes to Vienna next month for hiS summit meeting with the Soviet leaders on a second strategic arms limitation treaty, President Carter is clearly going to have to come to some sort of understanding with the Congressional leaders of both parties at the summit of Capitol Hill.

description: 5:55(9)Running

title: The Editorial Notebook Out of the Tax Mess, Into the VAT
description: On the I'mMadAsHell Scale, the property tax is a 9, the payroll tax is a 6, but the sales tax rates only a yawn.

title: Silkwood Jury Asks AboutInjury
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, May 17 (AP) Jurors deliberating the alleged responsibility of the KerrMcGee Corporation in the plutonium contamination of the late Karen G. Silkwood asked the trial judge today to define physical injury.

title: Law on Foreign Service Lists the Qualifications
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  The Foreign Service Act, Section 500, says: It is the policy of the Congress that chiefs of mission and Foreign Service officers appointed or assigned to serve the United States in foreign countries shall have, to the maximum practicable extent, among their qualifications a useful knowledge of the principal language or dialect of the country in which they are to serve, and knowledge and understanding of the history, the culture, the economic and political institutions and the interests of such country and its people.

title: Nevada, Seeking Tourists, Debates Buying Gas oqUnregulatedMctrket
description: The Nevada Legislature will hold a joint hearing today on an emergency bill that would allow the state to purchase gasoline on the socalled spot market.

title: Movie: 'Winter Kills,' a Serio-Comedy:Spring Fever Time
description: "WINTER Kills," which opens today at Cinema 2 and a number of other theaters, has been advertised with the slogan "Something funny is happening in 'Winter Kills.' Take it seriously!" You don't see desperation like this every day, nor do you happen upon movies this likable, this ridiculous, or this impossible to describe. "Winter Kills" isn't exactly a comedy, but it's funny. And it isn't exactly serious, but it takes on the serious business of the Kennedy assassination. That's why other ads for the film have been comparing it to "Dr. Strange-love" and "M*A*S*H." They don't do the trick, either.This isn't a social satireit's more like a movie with spring fever. It doesn't make a bit of sense, but it's fast and handsome and entertaining, bursting with a crazy vitality all its own. Sitting back and watching it doesn't seem the proper response, somehow. Chasing it with a butterfly net might be closer to the mark.The ideahold onto your hat, please  is that Jeff Bridges is the half-brother of a young President who was assassinated 19 years ago, and that their father, played by John Huston, is the richest, most powerful, and most merrily depraved man in America. Suddenly, new evidence about an extra marksman, a previously unknown assassin, falls into the half-brother's hands. He decides to conduct his own investigation. The first stop is a wig factory.He meets mobsters. He wonders about the Central Intelligence Agency. He follows the trail of a Jack Ruby type (Eli Wallach) with connections in Cuba. He falls in love with a gorgeous young magazine editor (Belinda Bauer), who is of course not a magazine editor but a gorgeous spy, and who is said to have been a former mistress of his late brother's. She would have been about three years old at the time. However, "Winter Kills" has so many other screws loose that by the time this curious fact comes to light, it's small potatoes.William Richert, who makes his directorial debut and also adapted the screenplay from Richard Condon's novel, flirts with the notion that the way to hold power in America is to master the art of giving others the runaround. In line with this, Mr. Bridges is indeed run ragged before winding up right back where he started.This point has been both examined and illustrated more effectively in other American movies  "All the President's Men" and "The Parallax View," both by Alan Pakula, come to mind. But that hardly matters, because Mr. Richert seems to care very little about narrative strength or clarity. Instead, he writes crisp, brittle dialogue that packs a lot of information into clipped sentences and also packs quite a wallop. His direction, equally economical in its way, is riveting even when it concentrates on the irrelevant. One sequence, for instance, has Mr. Bridges leaping onto a horse and galloping to the top of a mountain just so he can shout to the heavens "You stink, Daddy," or words to that effect. But what a mountain! And what a breathless race! And what a memorable moment, even if the thing it does most successfully is to recall "Lawrence of Arabia" (Maurice Jarre wrote the music for both films). That's no minor accomplishment.In addition to being a shining example of the cinematography of Vilmos Zsigmond, "Winter Kills" is a lavish, globe-trotting movie with a large and distinguished cast. (It has to be a large cast, since people Mr. Bridges meets have a way of being bumped off soon thereafter.) Sterling Hayden plays a zillionaire rancher who chases Mr. Bridges off his territory in a tank. Dorothy Malone is Mr. Bridges's nutty mother, who weeps about the ill health of her little dog and then smothers the creature in his sleep. Anthony Perkins is about as eerie as he's ever been; he and Richard Boone are particularly delightful. Toshiro Mifune has about three lines, not enough to establish whether he's supposed to be Mr. Huston's business associate or valet or houseboy.Mr. Bridges and Mr. Huston have roles that are just about unplayable, since you have to believe the screenplay's nonsense in its entirety in order to accept their characters at all. Still, Mr. Huston is commendably jolly, and Mr. Bridges is so amiable he can make an audience follow him anywhere, even to the end of the world's woolliest shaggy-dog story. I'm still not exactly sure who did what to whom, but it all has something to do with Elizabeth Taylor. Who makes an uncredited, non-speaking cameo appearance. And mouths only one word, not a very nice one. And plays the President's procuress. And is by no means the most farfetched creature this movie has to offer. Really.

title: Hammermill Cleared of Price Charge
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The Council on Wage and Price Stability cleared the Hammermill Paper Company today of an earlier charge that it had violated the Government's voluntary guidelines for price restraint.

title: PriceSignal France Urges Controls Report Gets On Spot. Market for Oil
description: Producers of antiknock additives for gasoline responded cautiously yesterday to a recommendation by the Federal Trade Commission staff that the commission issue an administrative complaint charging them with unfair methods of competition.
