description: There's Talent Aplentysin Arthur Rubinstein's Family

title: Income Up 0.3% in April
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)  The personal income of Americans rose threetenths of 1 percent in April, not enough to keep pace with the current inflation rate of 1 percent a month, the Commerce Department said today.

title: What Needs Recognition in Rhodesia
description: The Senate has now shown that it knows how to turn the Rhodesia dilemma into a disaster, but not much else. While professing concern about Western interests and Soviet inroads in Africa, it rushed through a gratuitous resolution urging a quick end of sanctions against Rhodesia, thus undercutting the President's effort to win more genuine power for Rhodesia'S blacks and foolishly alienating most of black Africa. Who would have thought that our worldlywise Congress needs lessons in statecraft from Mrs. Thatcher?

title: Market Place
description: SEARS ROEBUCK, once a blue chip name found in scores of institutional portfolios, has been sold heavily of late as the chain attempts to regain a preeminent position among the nation's retailers.

title: Protests in Nepal Pointing Toward Liberalized Monarchy
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Violent student demonstrations that have taken a number of lives in recent weeks appear to be the leading edge of a drive to liberalize the monarchy that governs this Himalayan kingdom.

title: What Is God to Do  Discuss His Obit With Every Reader?
description: Following are excerpts from a recent address on A Personal Concept of Religion that Isaac Bashevis Singer delivered M a lecture series on The Writer at Work sponsored by the Gallatin Division of New York University. Mr. Singer, whose most recent novel is Shosha, won the Nobel Prize in Literature last year.

title: Rohatyn Asked by Carey to Return To Head M.A.C. as Gould Resigns
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, whose colorful reign as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation ended in January, was asked by Governor Carey yesterday to take the lob back.

title: Coty Panel Cites 1979 Fashion Leaders
description: Four American fashion designers re. ceived special honors at the 37th annual meeting of the Coty American Fashion Critics nominating committee yesterday. They are Geoffrey Beene, Ralston, Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren, all members of fashion's Hall of Fame.

title: Abu Dhabi Oil Rise Of 80 Cents Seen
description: Abu Dhabi, following the lead of several important suppliers to the United States, raised the price of its crude oil by 80 cents a barrel yesterday, according to an authoritative industry source.

title: Doubled Green Yields Greenery
description: A fledgling Carolina silver bell glistened in a shaft of sunlight as it was planted yesterday morning in Central Park. The budding tree will share a section of the park stretching from 67th to 69th Street along Central Park West that will soon be alive with thousands of groundcover plants, forsythia and rhOdodendron bushes and styrax trees.

title: 2 Oilmen Split on End To Controls
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  In testimony in the House of Representatives today, top executives of two of the nation's largest oil companies differed on President Carter's decision to remove price controls from crude oil but agreed in opposing his proposed windfall profits tax.

title: Music: Marseillaise Proves a Surprise Berlioz
description: WASHINGTON, May 17One of the works that has been attracting delighted attention from audiences at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts has been the French National Anthem. Daniel Barenboim has been opening each concert of the Orchestre de Paris with The Star Spangled Banner and a Marseillaise. What with the lusty 250voice Chorus of the Orchestre de Paris and what appeared to be a soupedup orchestration of the Marseillaise, the Concert Hall of Kennedy Center has been resounding to volley after volley of uninhibited sound. There were those, on opening night last Tuesday, who had some derogatory remarks to make about this vulgar arrangement of the great tune. Then the arranger turned out to be none less than Hector Berlioz, and there were some red faces.

title: $90,000 Cash Taken on East Side From Apartrbent of ExPhysician
description: A retired physician told the police last night that burglars had entered her apartment at the Pavilion, 500 East 77th Street, at York Avenue, yesterday and stolen $90,000 in cash from a dresser. The victim, Dr. Armida Zepeda, said she had intended to use the money for a trip next week to her native Chile.

title: DrivelessDay Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) Americans ought to leave their cars home one day a week to help ease gasoline shortages that will last at least through the summer of 1980, Mr. Bardin told Congress today.

title: Teacher Awarded $580,000; Talk to CIA. Barred Tenure
description: A 38yearold former Brooklyn College faculty member was awarded $580,000 in damages yesterday by a Federal District Court jury in Brooklyn that found he had been wrongfully denied tenure and promotion because he had allowed himself to be debriefed by the Central Intelligence Agency after a sixweek trip to Europe in the summer of 1976.

title: Environmental Group Files Suit Against U.S. on Asbestos Rules
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (Reuters) The Environmental, Defense Fund sued the Government today in an effort to force it to require removal or repair of asbestos materials in public schools.

title: Events Today
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, MUSIC IN MAY. Avery Fisher Hall, 8.

title: Begin Proposes Meeting With Hussein on a Pact
description: JERUSALEM, May 18  Prime Minister Menachem Begin offered today to meet with King Hussein of Jordan to negotiate a peace treaty.

title: Books of The Times Thinking a Novel in Venice
description: TERRITORIAL RIGHTS. By Muriel Spark. 240 pages. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $9.95.

title: Daniel L. Muss, 53, a Professor Of. Engineering at City College
description: Daniel L. Muss, a professor of engineering at City College, died Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital in Newark after brief illness. He was 53 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: A Reward of $25,000 Considered for Leads To the Bedford Killers
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., May 18 group of prominent Bedford residents are considering offering a $25,000 reward for information that would lead to the arrest and conviction of the killers of four residents of this northern Westchester County town whose bodies were discovered a week ago yesterday.

title: Paul Southwell, Age 66, St. KittsNevis Premier
description: Prime Minister Paul Southwell of St. KittsNevis died yesterday at Victoria Hospital in St. Lucia while attending a conference of the West Indies Associated States Council of Ministers. He was 66 years old.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Clouds cover coastal areas of the Northern and Middle Atlantic States. A thin band frontal clouds stretches from the upper lake region to the central Plains States. Behind the front, an area of layered clouds covers the Northern Plains States and western sections of the Central Plains States.

title: Puerto Rican Theater To Present El Macho
description: El Macho, a play by Joseph Lizardi, will be presented for a month, starting next Wednesday, by the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater. It will be done in English and in Spanish on different nights. This play will be the last production at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater's stage in a former firehouse at 304 West 47th Street, just west of Eighth Avenue, before the building is renovated and reconstructed as a 199seat theater.

title: Supreme Court Curbs Reporters Access to Building
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI)  The Supreme Court announced today a series of restrictions.on reporters access to the Court building in an effort to stem preliminary news leaks about the Justices deliberations.

title: Death in the Morning (Firing Squad, Spain, 38): A Family's Night Watch in Prison
description: The room looked as though it were a visiting place for prisoners to receive their families on Sundays or something like that. It had high windows, some benches and chairs. There was a statue of Liberty that looked like the one in New York, but perhaps it was the figure of justice carrying scales in her outstretched arms. There were some armed warders in the room. As we came into the prison there were shouts from the guards: Centinela, alerta! Alerta esta! I remember all this as vividly as though it were now, although I thought for a long time that I didn't remember, that it was stories my mother and aunt told me. But it isn't so. I've proved my memories correct since then, though I was only five at the time.

title: Music: Orchestre de Paris's Romeo et Juliette in Concert
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  Hector Berlioz was always experimenting with novel musical forms, and he called his Romen.et Juliette, scored for large orchestra, chorus and three vocal solo. ists, a dramatic symphony. It is a long work  over an nour and a nail and is very seldom heard in its entirety. Sections of it, true, are sometimes played. Arturo Toscanini, for one, used to make a great thing out of the Queen Mab scherzo; and other conductors once in awhile have turned their attention to someof the other orchestral sections, such.ns Romeo Alone or the Festival music describing the Capulet ball.

title: Britain Is Said to Plan For a Rhodesia Envoy
description: LONDON, May 18  Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has decided to send a fulltime envoy to Rhodesia, authoritative Government sources disclosed today.

title: Israeli Seaborne Troops Assault Guerrilla Base in South Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 18  Israel resumed attacks on Palestinian guerrilla sites in southern Lebanon today, carrying out a seaborne raid on a base of a Syrianbacked faction.

title: Talk Deadlock Reported By China and Vietnam
description: TOKYO, May 18 (AP)  China and Vietnam blamed each other today for lack of any progress in their peace talks. But the two sides left the way open for another round, to be held in Peking.

title: Expos 5, Phillies 3
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP) Andre Dawson's 10th homer of the season, a tworun shot, capped a threerun seventh inning that helped the Montreal Expos score a raindelayed 53 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.

title: Model Tells Court About Relationship With Thorpe
description: LONDON, May 18  Norman Scott, the man who claims to have had a homosexual relationship with Jeremy Thorpe in the early 1960's, took the witness stand today and described it in explicit detail.

title: The City
description: New York City bus riders will be getting more than 700 buses with special seats that apparently provide greater passenger comfort, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 21.

title: Yankees, Beattie Rout Red Sox
description: BOSTON, May 18  Cedric TalHs, the Yankee general manager, stuck his head into the mob surrounding Jim Beattie and said, It's Columbus this time instead of Tacoma. Then he laughed and added, Congratulations.

title: Billy Carter Says Peaniit Money Wasn't Diverted to 76 Campaign
description: ATLANTA, May 18  Billy Carter said today that he had told a Federal grand jury here under oath that he knew of no money being diverted from his family's peanut business or its bank loans to his brother's 1976 Presidential campaign.

title: PARADES TODAY
description: A parade entitled Bronx 79: A Salute to Our Children will take place today beginning at 11 A.M. The route is on the Grand Concourse, beginning at Mount Eden Avenue and ending at 161st Street.

title: Lid on Spot Oil Price Rejected
description: BRUSSELS, May 18 (AP)  The energy ministers of the European Economic Community have rejected French proposal to limit oil prices on the Rotterdam spot market where prices are about double the contract rate charged by the oil exporting nations.

title: Exxon Says It Has Major EnergySaving Invention
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, said yesterday that it was almost ready to market an invention that, in little more than a decade, could save the energy equivalent of one million barrels of oil a day in the United States alone.

title: Ballet: Bostonians Present A Bournonville Premiere
description: BOSTON, May 18  November will mark the_ anniversary of the death of oe of ballet's greatest choreographers, Denmark's August Bournonvilje. And last night here at the Music Hall, the Boston Ballet presented the American premiere of a raeatricauzea isournonvine technique class entitled Wednesday's Class in celebration of Bournonville'S 100th anniversary.

title: A Book Attacks Nuclear Power
description: Today, new reactors are put into operation in densely populated areas without experimental knowledge about the unpredictable interplay between thousands of components that make up these complex gigantic systems.

title: Washington Star Unit Sold
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 18 (UPI)  The Universal Press Syndicate has acquired the Washington Star Syndicate from the Washington Star Company, a subsidiary of Time Inc., officials at Universal announced today. Under the agreement approved yesterday by Time's board, Time will assume a significant minority stock interest in Universal in exchange for the assets of the Washington Star Syndicate, an undisclosed amount of cash and other considerations. Universal is the nation's largest independent feature service.

title: Fellini Rehearsal Screened at Cannes
description: CANNES, France, May 18  Using an orchestra as the microcosm of modem society, Federico FeRini, the Italian director, has created a troubling, turbulent film, Orchestra Rehearsal, that was shown here today out of competition at the 32d Cannes Film Festival.

description: Cable television subscribers in four cities  Moline, Ill.; Jackson, Miss??? Boise, Idaho, and one other not yet chosen  will function as a test market for Playcable, a system that will allow television receivers to be used for video games.

description: TOKYO, May 18 (AP)  Iran has notified Japan of a further 15 percent oil supply cut starting July 1, officials of the Trade and Industry Ministry said today.

title: OBSERVER Galloping Off In All Directions
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  Appropriately, the California gasoline search expedition arrived at the White House in a small fleet of automobiles, some of them large.

title: Dent Becomes Least Of Torrez's Problems
description: BOSTON, May 18  They had come to see the Yankees play the Boston Red Sox., 33,699 of them. The fire laws at Fenway Park permit no more. They had come to see a rivalry that was only postponed fora while after the Yankees had defeated the Red Sox in a playoff game last October to win the American League pennant.

title: U.N.Agency Accused of Hiding Data on Hazards in Nuclear Energy
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 18  An environmental watchdog organization has accused the United Nations Environment Program of suppressing its own report on possible health hazards in nuclear energy and the dangers of accident at nuclearpower installations.

title: U.S. Reports Offer on Medicine
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (A)  State Department sources, commenting today on President Castro's remarks, confirmed that the embargo included medicines and said that an offer to exempt certain rare medicines had elicited no response.

title: Tactics in Murder Case Criticized
description: SMITHTOWN, L.I., May 18  The police investigation into the April 20 slaying of a 13yearold boy here has focused on four local teenagers, but lawyers for some of the youths say the police have so violated the teenagers constitutional rights that any., cdnviction that might be obtained would be overturned on appeal.

title: Umpires Dispute Is Settled, With Return Slated Today
description: Most of baseball's regular 52 major league umpires will be back on the job today, assured of pay increases and summer vacations. The end of their threemonth labor dispute was announced in Manhattan yesterday by the presidents of the American and National Leagues.

title: U.S. Rum Makers Spirits Flag on Trade Accord
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Rum producers in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, giddy from the splurge of rum consumption by Americans in recent years, are now worried that the Carter Administration is making it easier for foreign competitors to crash the party.

title: As Western Ships of State Sail On, in Convoy
description: WASHINGTONThe United States and its allies quietly observed the 30th anniversary of the Atlantic alliance recently. The anniversary was more important than the absence of celebration suggests.

title: Drivers May Find Gas Is Scarce on Weekend
description: A survey by the Automobile Club of New York has found that motorists in the metropolitan area will have problems getting gasoline this weekerid. Most service stations will ration their fuel supplies and shorten their hours or close altogether, according to the survey.

title: Exxon Synthesizer Designed To Recapture Energy Waste
description: The Exxon project is intended to accomplish two things: to reduce the waste of electricity by inadvertent conversion to unwanted heat, and to match exactly the power coming from a given line with the power needs of the motor that it is feeding. The goal is to save energy, possibly in large amounts.

title: 2 FLORIDA CONVICTS FACE ELECTROCUTION
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 18 (AP) Gov. Bob Graham signed death warrants today for two convicted murderers, John A. Spenlcelink and Willie Jasper Darden, and a prison official scheduled their electrocutions for net Wednesday at 7 A.M.

title: President Is Disturbed About Narrow Margin Of Vote on Canal Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  President Carter acknowledged today that his Administration had suffered a setback on legislation to transfer control of the Panama Canal to Panama, and said it was disturbing that the House of Representatives came within two votes yesterday of shelving the bill putting the canal treaty into effect.

title: Davona Dale, Star Filly, Wins BlackEyed Susan
description: BALTIMORE, May 18  Calumet Farm's Davona Dale, the Spectacular Bid of this season's 3yearold fillies, continued to dominate her division today by scoring a 4length victory in the $111,800 BlackEyed Susan Stakes at Pimlico.

title: Karen Silkwood: From Activist to Protest Symbol
description: In the summer of 1972 a slight, darkhaired woman named Karen Silkwood from Nederland, Tex., who had dreamed of becoming a scientist, left her husband and children, moved to Oklahoma City and took a job as a laboratory technician at the KerrMcGee Corporation's nuclear processing plant in nearby Cimarron.

title: Lingerie: Wit, Whimsy and Practicality
description: Clothes to be worn in public generally receive a lot more attention than clothes for private life, but a number of designers are trying to narrow the gap. They are turning out styles that are seductive or practical, or both.

title: Basque Bar Owner Is Shot Dead; 49th Spanish Political Killing
description: MADRID, May 18 (AP)  Two masked gunmen killed a Basque bar owner in Lemona last night in Spain's 49th political killing of the year, the police reported today.

title: ROBERT S. BENEPE
description: Robert S. Benepe, retired chairman of the board of Leacock & Company, table linen manufacturers of New York, died Monday at a highway service station in Florida while going by car from his winter home in Delray Beach, Fla., to his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 83 years old.

title: Castro, Citing Blockade, Lays Poor Relations to U.S.
description: COZUMEL, Mexico, May 18  President Fidel Castro said last night that his Government's relations with Washington remained perfectly bad because the United States was persisting in its economic blockade of Cuba.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON A N officer of the RCA Corporation in New York has invented an optical device to correct the semiblackness that afflicts many people who have suffered strokes or other brain injuries. Jerold J. Benavie, a staff vice president, will be granted patent 4,155,633 next week for the device, which can restore the lost half of patient's field of vision.

description: By The Associated Press

title: Corporate Net Lagged In Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  The pace of growth in corporate profits slowed markedly in the first quarter, increasing by less than 1 percent from the fourth quarter of 1978, mainly because of a sharp reduction in the overall expansion of the economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Mike Thomas Is Traded
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)  The Washington Redskins, capping a housecleaning that saw the release of such experienced players as Bill Kilmer, Chris Hamburger and Jake Scott, announced today that they had traded Mike Thomas, a running back, to the San Diego Chargers. for an undisclosed mediumhigh 1980 draft choice.

title: Bomb Threat Empties School
description: PRESTONSBURG.Ky., May 18 (AP)  A bomb threat emptied Prestonsburg High School today, the students first day back since classes were canceled when 27 sticks of dynamite were found on the school grounds two days ago.

title: Slain Man Tied To Big Robbery At Air Terminal
description: One of two Queens men slain ganglandstyle in Brooklyn Thursday was identified by authorities yesterday aS a suspect in the $6 million Lufthansa robbery at Kennedy International Airport  the sixth murder believed to have been connected to the holdup since a group of masked gunmen escaped with their loot from the cargo terminal last Dec. 11.

title: Tokyo Documents of 30's Relate Plans for Resetthng Jews in Asia
description: Newly translated secret documents of the Japanese Foreign Ministry and interviews with former high Tokyo officials disclose that a plan existed, in the years before the 1941 attack on Pearl Harbor, to enlist skills and financial resources of persecuted Jews in Europe, to rescue them from the Nazis and to establish an Israel in Japan's conquered territory of Manchuria, in northern China.

title: Signs of Gas Off Jersey
description: A ray of hope emerged yesterday from the faltering drilling effort in the Baltimore Canyon area off the New Jersey coast.

title: CHILEANS ABSORBED BY SOCCER LOTTERY
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, May 18  The cultural novelty under the military regime is a game of chance that centers national expectations each week on the dream of a quick fortune for a bet of less than a dollar.

title: About New York
description: There were years Antoinette Concello spun high up and looped through the air, graceful and strong as any male flier. But these days she roams out more judiciously from her West Side compartment in the circus train, uuying Mtn new ouaiis  two trom Lord & Taylor, two from Saksfor her granddaughter, Michelle, who is back in Florida.

title: Disease Agency Says Just One Million Used Flu Vaccine Program
description: ATLANTA. May 18 (UPI)  The American public took little interest in the most recent Federal effort to provide free influenza vaccine, possibly as a reaction to the disastrous swine flu immunization program of 1976:

title: African Emperor Denies Slayings
description: PARIS, May 18 (AP) The. ruler of the Central African Empire called in a group of diplomats yesterday and told them that Amnesty International had falsely accused his troops of having killed about 100 students after riots last month.

title: Climber Killed in Yosemite
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., May 18 (UPI)  An experienced mountain climber fell more than 160 feet to his death yesterday when his rope snapped as he scaled the sheer granite wall of El Capitan, park officials reported. A park spokesman said that Christopher Robbins, 24 years old, of Riverside, Calif., was climbing the 3,400foot wall of rock, using the popular Tangerine Route, when his fixed rope abraded on a sharp rock and snapped, sending him plunging to the valley floor.

title: Your Money
description: REFLECTING the current ease with which credit can be obtained, together with high interest rates, many individuals are finding that the costs are a growing burden on income, especially when they include a substantial amount for what is known as credit insurance.

title: Oilers Trounce Jets, 102, In Game 5 of W.H.A. Final
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, May 18 (UPI)  The Edmonton Oilers, led by Ron Chipperfield's five goals, a playoff record, trounced the Winnipeg Jets, 102, tonight and avoided elimination in Game 5 of the World Hockey Association championship series.

title: Gasohol: The Issue Is Practicality
description: If gasohol, the mix of alcohol and gasoline, is really the answer to America's fuel problems, then twothirds of the land area of the United States would have to be given over to growing corn.

title: Fairchild, Ramo Link
description: Fairchild Industries Inc., which already has a 20.6 percent interest in the Bunker Ramo Corporation, announced yesterday that it had made an offer to increase its stake in the electronic components and equipment manufacturer and eventually to acquire the entire company.

title: West German Alarm on Terrorism Fading
description: BONN, May 20  The wanted posters are still up in public buildings, but no one seems to bother any more to cross out the faces of those shot or arrested. West German terrorists, most of whom look like rock band's sidemen or harassed students, are still out there, but both the obsession with them and their roots in West German society have almost disappeared.

title: Gasoline: No Accord On Problem
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  Members of Congress and Administration officials continued to grapple today with the causes and potential cures of the nation's gasoline shortfall, apparently without matting a consensus on a resolution.

title: Concert: Zukerman Leads, Plays
description: Pinchas Zukerrnan is one of the fairhaired boys as far as the public is concerned. Appearing again as conductor and violin soloist Thursday night with the New York Philharmonic in its Music in May series in Avery Fisher Hall, he drew another capacity audience. Presumably it was the prospect of hearing him in his dual roles in Vivaldi's The Four Seasons that drew so many listeners.

title: China Gets Canada Credit
description: OTTAWA. May 18 (Reuters) Canada is granting China a $1.72 billion line of credit to buy Canadian goods and services, according to a statement by the Canadian Embassy in Peking issued here today.

title: Arbour: Rangers Seem to Be Tight
description: Al Arbour of the Islanders was named National Hockey League coach of the year yesterday at the annual Stanley Cup luncheon at the Plaza Hotel, so naturally everyone wanted to hear his views on tonight'srourght game of the cup finals between the Rangers and Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden. The game starts at 9:05 P.M. (Channel 9 TV).

In earlier trading, gold peaked at at $257.875. In London, gold closed at $256.375, down from Thursday's record closing high of $256.90.

description: Sara Jeannette Fredericksen and Leland Davis Breckenridge Jr. were married yesterday evening in the Brick Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson.

description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)  Members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters have voted nearly 3 to 1 to ratify a new national freight contract that stretches President Carter's antiinflation wage guidelines, the union announced today.

Exxon said it would spend well over $100 million to develop the device, which, it said, could save the country the equivalent of a million barrels of oil a day. Acquisition talks have begun with the Reliance Electric Company. [Page 1.]

description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell listed his net worth today as from $253,000 to $630,000.

title: Auto Smashes Into Living Room, Killing Woman
description: WESTLAND, Mich., May 18 (AP)  A 53yearold suburban Detroit woman watching televisfon in her living room was killed last night when a car smashed through her home and landed on top of her, the police said. She was identified as Marjorie Aho.

title: Met Chief Repeats Her Faith
description: The Mets, who returned to town yesterday from a disheartening coasttocoast trip in which they won only three of 14 games, received a day of rest before being forced to resume their National League battles at Shea Stadium. Their scheduled game against the St. Louis Cardinals last night was postponed because of rain and wet grounds. The game has not been rescheduled yet.

title: The Simplism of Testing Teachers
description: The competency testing movement, whose main target so far has been schoolchildren, is now turning on teachers, too. Concerned with the rising cost and declining performance of public education, state legislatures and school boards are starting to require teachers to be tested as well as certified. Poor teaching undoubtedly is much to blame for the sorry state of public schools. But standardized competency tests are hardly the way to tell who is fit to teach.

title: Drug Unit Denies It Is Investigating Houston Firemen
description: HOUSTON, May 18  The Drug Enforcement Administration denied today that it was looking into the possibility that several members of the Houston Fire Department were involved in narcotics trafficking tetween the United States and Colombia.

title: Lawyer Wins Zoning Battle To Add Solar Heating Unit
description: A Westchester County lawyer who spent seven months and $10,000 worth of legal time fighting his local zoning board for the right to install a solar heating unit 1 on the roof of his home was upheld yester. day in State Supreme Court in White Plains.

title: Carter Confusion on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  For a Government that moved quickly two years ago to declare the moral equivalent of war on the nation's energy problems and fought a tough skirmish last week over gasoline rationing, the Carter Administration has sounded a confusing and contradictory trumpet these last few days.

title: 3 Graduations Increase Amherst's Fuel Supply
description: AMHERST, Mass., May 18 (AP) Gasoline stations in this college town will get an extra 30,000 gallons of gasoline for the Memorial Day weekend because three commencements are scheduled for May 26 and 27, Police Chief Donald Maia said today.

title: Association Mixes Judaism and Karate.
description: The four students stood motionless, their gazes distant, as the grand master knotted black cloth belts around their waists.

title: Magazine Loses Appeal to Speed Review of Curb on Bomb Article
description: CHICAGO. May 18 (AP)  A request by The Progressive magazine for faster review of a Federal court order barring its publication of an article about the workings of a hydrogen bomb has been denied in a ruling made public today.

title: Miss Wright Shares Golf Lead With a 70
description: CLIFTON. N.J., May 18  Many observers believe that the Ladies Professional Golf Association is currently going through the Nancy Lopez Era.' but Most of the women on the tour agree that Mickey Wright was the best female golfer in history when she was playing the tour regularly, from1957 to 1969.

title: CAB. Urges Nero Rules For Sinokers on Planes
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)  The Civil. Aeronautics Board proposed new smoking rules for airlines today; including one that would separate pipe and cigar smokers from nonsmokers by at least seven rows of seats.

title: Motorists Across Europe Starting to Feel the Pinch
description: LONDON, May 18  Greece has ordered half its motorists off the highways each weekend, West Germany plans autobahn speed limits on certain vehicles, Italy may stop selling reducedprice gasoline to foreign visitors and Ireland insists on an $8 minimum purchase to discourage tanktopping. These are some of the signs that the oil shortage noose has begun to tighten noticeably on consumers throughout the world.

Margaret Thatcher made the decision, which is seen as an important step toward recognizing the legitimacy of the internal settlement in Rhodesia. [Page I, Column 3.]

title: United Press internations
description: TWO KILLED, 26 INJURED IN LOS ANGELES HOTEL FIRE: Rescue workers lifting an injured woman onto a stretcher early yesterday morning, as the 65room Oxford Hotel in downtown Los Angeles burned. Many were lured when they jumped from second and thirdfloor windows to escape. Arson was suspected in the blaze, which was fought by 100 firemen.

title: Vietnamese Will Join A Soviet Space Flight
description: MOSCOW, May 18 (Reuters)  Astronaut trainees from Vietnam are preparing to take part in a flight under the Soviet bloc Intercosmos space project, Tass, the official press agency, reported today.

title: Bridge:
description: The success or failure of a deceptive play may depend on nontechnical factors. If the move comes quickly, an opponent is less likely to be suspicious than if the card hits the table after much thought.

title: Silkwood Heirs Win $10.5 Million In Setback to the Nuclear Industsy
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, May 18  A Federal jury today awarded $10.5 million in damages to the estate of Karen Silkwood, a 28yearold laboratory technician contaminated by radiation in 1974 while employed at a KerrMcGee Corporation plutonium plant near here.

title: Braves Win As Murphy Clouts 3
description: ATLANTA, May 18 (AP)  Dale Murphy drove in five runs with three homers tonight, leading the Atlanta Braves to a 64 victory over the San Francisco Giants. The triumph was Atlanta's third straight.

title: City Ballet: Baryshnikov In Orpheus
description: Over the 31 years since it was created, George Balandline's Orpheus has become a signature work. In its deceptive simplicity and its limpid score by Igor Stravinsky, this retelling of the OrpheusEurydice myth has become freighted with history. A revival last February was received with some disappointment, with balletomanes renaming it Morpheus and cooler heads worrying about datedness. On Thursday, it was performed again by the New Wit City Ballet at the New York State Theater and, though it has not returned to its former exalted state, there were hints of greatness.

title: Bullets Beat Spurs, Reach Final
description: LANDOVER, Md., May 18  A 15foot corner jump shot by Bobby Dandridge with eight seconds remaining tonight gave the Washington Bullets a dramatic 107105 triumph over the San Antonio Spurs and the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference championship.

description: BALTIMORE, May 18  A few days before Spectacular Bid won the Kentucky Derby two weeks ago, his trainer said the 3yearold colt knew something was cookine.

description: Don King, the promoter, officially confirmed yesterday that a Larry HolmesMike Weaver heavyweight championship fight would be held on June 22 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Israeli Foresees 58,000 Families Settling in Arab Areas in 5 Years
description: JERUSALEM, May 18 (Reuters)  An Israeli settlement official disclosed today plans for 20 new Jewish outposts on occupied Arab land in the coming year and estimated that 58,000 Jewish families would move to the lands in the next five years.

title: COMMODITIES

title: Boris Chaliapin, Artist Who Drew 400 Time Magazine Covers, Dies.
description: Boris Chaliapin, an artist who specialized in portraits and is perhaps best known for the more than 400 covers he drew for Time magazine from the early 1940's through the 60's, died of cancer yesterday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 72 years old, lived in Easton, Conn., and for many years maintained a studio in New York City.

title: Where Do You Get Intensity?
description: Intensity is the end word in sports. Once upon a time it was muscle, then it was desire. They all mean the same thing  working harder than the other team. But the jargon changes. Intensity is the word now. It is also the mason why the Montreal Canadiens hold a 2.1 lead over the New York Rangers in the Stanley Cup finals that resume at Madison Square Garden tonight. They're outworking us, says Phil Esposito, the Ranger warhorse. It's as simple as that  they're outworking us. In hockey, that is almost always the difference. In game often decided by ad libs rather than a script, the puck seems to bounce for the team that works the hardest, the team with intensity. That's how the Rangers reached the finals  by outworking the New York Islanders, as Al Arbour, the Islander coach, acknowledged. But in the cup finals against the Canadiens, the Rangers seem to have misplaced their intensity. Not that they're loafing. They're working. But the Canadiens are working harder. The scoreboard testifies to that. Ever since the Rangers took a 20 lead early in the second game, the Canadiens have outscored them, 101.

title: SAMUEL ARUM

Nothing short of the personal intervention of the President himself is likely to save his already battered guideposts.

title: Chile's Intolerable Answer

As the United States prosecutor in the case has said, this ruling is a disgrace. It may still be reversible, but only if the Carter Administration makes unambiguously clear its own determination to serve justice and to deter political terrorism.

title: Ballet: Tudor's Undertow

As revived by the American Ballet Theater on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, this work to a somber score by William Saaim= no ionger seemed shocking, despite its sordid theme. Yet it does remain stimulating and it is far from obscure. Very clearly, in Undertow Mr. Tudor attempts to show what forces might cause someone to commit a sex crime.

title: All Players Aim to Star In the Bud et Act
description: WASHINGTON  For the past five years, dedicated members of the Senate and the House have laboriously drafted a joint fiscal plan, complete with revenue estimates and spending ceilings that are initially voluntary guidelines but later become enforceable limits. This year - in large part because of Goverment austerity, or at least the appearance of it  the Congressional attempt to take effective control of the Federal budget away from the White House is threatening to become a victim of its own success.

title: Plays That Probe the Roots Of Faith
description: Four recent Broadway offerings prove once again that John Donne was right: No man is an island not even a priestphilosopher. As priest I worship a secular society many of whose members find worship at best irrelevant and at worst dehumanizing; as philosopher I wonder at mysterious metaphysical meanings which often don't seem negotiable even as nostalgia among active pragmatic moderns. The plays - Meeting by the River, Faith Healer, Whose Life Is It Anyway? and The Elephant Man are filled with the kind of questions and meanings that preoccupy priests and plague philosphers - belief, unbelief, freedom, death, resurrection, salvation, hope, despair.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: In the long gone days of the original Life and Look magazines, people in the world of photography did not care much as they do today what the Museum of Modern Art thought of them. Photographers became famous not by showing in museums but by appearing in the big picture magazines, and when they got angry with people in authority, their rage was usually directed not against museum curators but against magazine editors. However, now that photography has been recognized as art, museums and galleries have become an important alternate route to photographic fame, and museum curators are coming under attack.

title: Recreation Fees Also on the Rise
description: THOSE who play will be paying more for their fun this summer. Most towns on the Island are beginning t.:.) charge for recreational programs that were once free, and where 01( fees already exist, they are being increased.

title: Realty News Pahlavi Building 80 Percent Rented
description: The pink granite skyscraper at 650 Fifth Avenue - owned by the Pahlavi Foundation, which represents the in terests of the deposed royal family of Iran - has rented about 80 percent of its office space, and it has been named the Piaget Building after the watch that is imported by one of its major tenants.

title: A Local Rocky
description: Cassidy, at left, slugging it out with John Capobianco, 25, of Huntington, at Suffolk Forum in Commack. After a slow start, Cassidy came on in the final rounds of a mauling, bruising fight to take a unanimous 10round decision.

title: Changing Western Winds Raise Rhodesian Hopes
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia = In Rhodesia, as in Vietnam and other guerrilla wart, spokesmen on the Government side have a habit of seeing corners that have been turned. Usually, as when the Government launched an amnesty program for black nationalist insurgents last year, the hopes have proved illusory. At every turn, the war has grown worse, the economy has shrunk another notch and whites have increased their flight to South Africa and Britain.

title: 49 Years of Elegance Ends At Bonwit's 5th Ave. Store
description: Bonwit Teller dosed its Fifth Avenue retail operation for the last time yesterday, passing the way of the Savoy Plaza Hotel as an enduring standard of elegance on the avenue.

title: County Exceeds State In Cancer Death Rate
description: CANCER deaths have risen faster in Westchester Coun than in the region or the state as a whole in the last several years, according to figures released recently by the New York State Department of Health. Between 1975 and 1977 cancer deaths increased by 7 percent in the county, as against a 3.5 percent statewide increase. At the same time, cancer mortality rates for Nassau and Suffolk Counties  suburbs with similar style of living and urbanization patterns  increased by 5 and 4 percent, respectively.

title: Returnees to Englewood Find There's No Place Like Home
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J. - Tina Oberbeck came back. John Glidden came back. Karen Lane came back. So did Allan Silverstein, Edith and Jerry Escala and Charles Osgood.

title: Old Eli Shows New Face as 278th Commencement Nears
description: NEW HAVEN, May 17  A. Bartlett Giamatti propped his feet on a coffee table in his modest office in Woodbridge Hall the other day, studied the smoke from his cigarette and talked of one of the themes he planned to use in his baccalaureate address Sunday as part of Yale University's 278th commencement.

title: Japan Readies for Skylab Debris
description: TOKYO, May 19 (AP)  A panel Of Japanese officials is planning what the Government will do if the American Skylab space vehicle falls toward Japan when it reenters earth's atmosphere between June 20 and July 4. The 85ton spaceship is expected to scatter 500 pieces, weighing a total of 25 tons, over path 4,000 miles long and 100 miles wide.

title: NUMISMATICS

In it one can read about the gold 8escudo pieces, coined in 1713, that were salvaged from a shipwreck in the Spanish Main off Florida; the five Liberty Head nickles made via hankypanky just two centuries later; and the California territorial golds and the 1894S dime that launched a career.

title: Horse Killed in Car Crash
description: CLOVER, S.C., May 18 (AP)  Two stray horses collided with two police cars here this morning, killing one horse and damaging both vehicles. Lieut. William Justice was driving down North Main Street when a horse.ran in front of his patrol car. The horse was killed and damage to the police car was estimated at $1,000. Lieutenant Justice radioed for assistance. As the second patrol car headed for the scene, another horse ran into the street. This time there was only minor damage to the car and the horse was not seriously hurt.

title: Trial Reveals Teamsters
description: WNETTV /Channel 13 and Citicorp were pressured by a teamsters union official into taking business away from moving companies represented by a nonteamsters union, accordin2 to evidence introduced at a trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The teamsters official and an accomplice were convicted last week of bribetaking and attempted grand larceny in the case.

title: Rangers Defeated by Savard's Goal
description: The Montreal Canadiens won twice by 43 at Madison Square Garden at 12:30 this morning, getting an overtime goal from Serge Savard a minute after Larry Robinson's apparent score was never registered by the goal judge. Thus, the Canadiens took a 31 lead in The Stanley Cup final series.

description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 19, (AP) Twelve state senators who went underground to boycott a legislative session today eluded the Texas Rangers and state police who have been ordered to arrest them.

title: Homosexual Jews Find Rebirth In Their Own New Synagogues
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 19  Every Friday night, about 75 members of Congregation Sha'ar Zahav here celebrate the Sabbath, the traditional Jewish day of rest. But their service, unlike those conducted by most Jews, includes a prayer that asks for rest not only from breadwinning, but also from the, effort of appearing straight in a straight world.

description: MEDFORD, Mass., May 19 (AP) Tufts University's trustees voted today for partial divestment of school holdings in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: What's a Driver to Do?
description: The principal energy problem this weekend is not too little gasoline but too much confusion. The American driver was skeptical about the reality of the energy crisis to begin with; public good will has now been shaken still more by contradictions. The President de- nounces Congress for rejecting standby gasoline rationing; Congress assails him as being un-Presidentially harsh. The President says there'll be more gas by June. The oil industry says not so. Is the country in fact using less gasolineor is that only a matter of statistical appearances? Is there a genuine gasoline shortage or is it all a conspiracy to jack up the price? Increasingly, the public climate is soured by such distractions when the need is to fasten attentionon the main event:

description: STORRS, Conn., May 18  The presi dent of the University of Connecticut told the school's trustees today that the students involved in rampages this week that damaged the university grounds would be subject to the strongest possible disciplinary action.

And for the less obvious reason that more than any other, it celebrates freeenterprise capitalism, relatively unfettered by government, as the golden key to eeneral prosperity.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 19 (AP) Spitting or throwing a cigarette butt on the street may bring offenders a jail term of up to 29 days. Home Ministry officials said South Korean streets were clean by Asian standards, but that a nationwide cleanup campaign was under way.

And the arts in turn inspired the creation of many Harlem showplaces of the past the theaters, nightclubs and dance halls with worldwide reputations, places that now exist only as fading memories.

title: Flying Ants Are LowDown Critters
description: ARE you ready for something new to worry about, fellow homeowners? Just because spring has finally made it and you've survived frozen pipes, flooded basements and barren fuel tanks, don't think for one instant that you're home free. At this very moment carpenter ants could be marshalling their forces.

title: Notebook: Skaters In Role of Writers
description: Rod Gilbert, the columnist, had a problem. He became the greatest scorer in the history of the New York Rangers in his career from 1960 until last season, but now he was just another writer. He sat in the Montreal Forum last Tuesday, with all the other writers, watching the Rangers go through their pregame drill. His new role may not seem as painful as getting clobbered by a John Ferguson check, but wait until the editors get through with him.

title: Hooker Pledges Cooperation in Inquiry on Hicksville Waste Disposal
description: The Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corporation, which last week refused to supply a House subcommittee with records of a study on the contamination of ground water and drinking wells from itochemi- cal dump in Michigan, has agreed to assist New York State in whatever efforts may undertake in an inquiry into possible health hazards at its wastedisposal site in Hicksville, L.I.

title: TV Takes Another Look at Watergate In Blind Ambition
description: HOLLYWOOD, Blind Ambition, John Dean's account of his White House career and of events leading to the Watergate scandal, will come to television when CBS presents an eighthour dramatization, featuring Martin Sheen as Mr. Dean and Rip Torn as Richard Nixon, beginning tonight at 8. (The subsequent installments will be telecast tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday evenings at 9.)

description: BOSTON, May 19 (AP)  A United States Supreme Court Justice has cleared the way for a econd challenge in the Court to a Massachusetts law curbing abortions paid for with welfare funds.

title: MiddleClass Hispanics Heading for Greener Pastures
description: Daisy BarretoHess, who hplds a master's degree in counseling psychology, has just been hired by a New Jersey state agency. One ister, Ana, is in her first year of college; a brother, Felix Jr., is working toward a master's degree in urban planning, and another sister, Iris, the only one without a college background, manages abusy hamburger palace. They all grew up in a suburban New Jersey community and would seem to be typical daughters and sons of the restless, ambitious middle class. And they are except in one respect: They are Hispanics.

title: 'sweeney Todd
description: The controversy that has surz. rounded Stephen Sondheim's Sweeney Todd since its Broadway opening will be compounded by the release on RCA of the twodisk cast album. There are those who think this the most progressive musical of recent years, and perhaps the closest we've yet come to a genuine popular American opera. There are others who think it pretentiously, selfconsciously arty. This writer inclines to the former persuasion.

title: Amherst Chancellor Designated
description: BOSTON, May 19 (AP)  David Knapp, president of the University of Massachusetts, has chosen the University of Minnesota's administrator, Henry Koffler, to succeed Randolph Bromery as chancellor at the school's 29,000student campus at Amherst. The appointment of Mr. Koffler, the 57yearzold vice president for academic affairs at the Minneapolis campus, must be confirmed by University of Massachussetts trustees, who are to meet in Boston on Wednesday.

title: From Alixandre: Big Names, Sleek Shapes
description: As the fur showings continued last week, the leading designers fixed the trends for next fall's nippy days. If there is a fur in your future this year, it will probably be narrow (except for shoulders), sleek and not so sporty. And it's likely to be mink, Persian lamb, silky gray squirrel or sheared furs with interesting surfaces, ridged or knitted. Forget about chubbies or Girl of the Golden West ragged furs. Since prices will be higher than those of last fall (even curly lamb, which used to be a fun fur, can set you back $4,500), you might as well get your money's worth in elegance.

title: Mrs. Thatcher's RightWing Guru
description: LONDON - British politicians, by and large, do not employ imagebuilders to aid them in their electoral campaigns, and even if they did, it is doubtful that Sir Keith Joseph would use one. Thus it was, in political speech five years ago, that Sir Keith offered the opinion that women from the lowest social classes, many of them unmarried or teenagers unable to care for their children, were producing a third of all British babies. In the uproar that followed, Sir Keith contended that he was guilty of clumsy phraseology. A fellow Tory's assessment is harsher. His problem is that he has a very fine mind, he says, but no judgment.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The Joffrey Ballet and Rudolf Nureyev will repeat their Homage to Diaghilev program from July 17 to July 28 at the New York State Theater. On March 10, 1980, the company is scheduled to return to its home at the City Center 55th Street Theater tor three weeks in a new and fullevening production of Cinderella by Robert Joffrey. And on Nov. 3, 1980, the Joffrey Ballet expects to begin a sixweek full repertory season with several New York premieres.

title: PapuaNew Guinea: One of the Last Places on Earth
description: Most people think of New Guinea as remote and forbidding. But my friend Len and I had been there during World War II and could not shake the romantic notion of someday returning. Finally, this year, Zola and Gerrie, our wives, Lola US to stop MIMI% ana GO something about it. The four of us settled down to bone up on geography and anthropology, then got in touch with travel agent. On her advice, we decided to concentrate on two areas, the milehigh central highlands and, since we were all interested in New Guinea aft, the Sepik River basin, where much of it is produced.

title: Lincoln Center The First 20 Years
description: They will be celebrating the 20th birthday of Lincoln Center tomorrow night and there will be a big party surging around the plaza and several of its six cultural edifices, too sparkling a bash to let one cogitate on the place's growth as a performing arts center in the same sense New York logic that makes West 38th Street a garment center and Mott Street a Chinese restaurant center. A score of years and here we are, 31,000 performances and 52 million ticketbuyers later, kconvenient milepost in history where we can pause, between the acts and before the party, to see where things have been, where they are at and where they are going.

title: You're Buying a School System, Too
description: WHEN you buy a house, you're buying a school system, said Maureen McGrath, a mother of two who checked out several Westchester districts before buying a house in Rye. Mrs. McGrath and her husband, Jim, were indifferent to scnoois wnen they lived in apartments and their children were toddlers, but when their daughter, Jennifer, was old enough for kindergarten and they were thinking about a house, they began comparing test ratings and asking friends in other towns about the schools.

title: It's Been Fun But California Suspects the Party Is Over
description: LOS ANGELES  Like thousands of other Californians, Philip Reid, a salesman who lives in the San Fernando Valley, was trapped in a long line waiting for gasoline last week. Look at all those cars, he said, looking up from a book he had brought to while away the time. You know what's happening? We're witnessing the demise of the Americanwav of life. The future is here.

title: Dissident's Progress
description: HISTORY'S CARNIVAL A Dissident's Autobiography. By Leonid Plyushch. With a contribution by Tatyana Plyushch. Edited and translated by Marco Carynnyk. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. 429 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: What's Doing in INDIANAPOLIS
description: MOTORRACING CAPITAL - When Ray Harroun won the first Indianapolis 500 auto race in 1911, going a hot 74 miles an hour, the event's host city had but 230,000 residents. Today, the city has a population of more than 750,000. But even now, Indianapolis is best known for the annual race where some 300,000 spectators watch cars go faster than 200 mileg an hour.

title: Sorry, No Teaching of Values Allowed
description: BETHESDA, Md.  The Carnegie Council on Policy Studies in Higher Education has confirmed that a general decline in moral standards is evi. dent on campus. Students cheat readily; professors cooperate in debasement of standards. The proposed cure is predictable: Require standards and teach ethics. That proposal would be the crucial constitutional watershed in our history. There is no way that ethics can be taught in statesupported schools and universities without violating the First Amendment prohibi- tion against establishment of religion. But, you will say, we are not talking about God; we are concerned only about values. Precisely. There is no way, to decide upon values except in relation to a theory of ultimate reality by definition, a religion.

title: Lynnette Buchanan To Be Wed July 14 To James Bennett

title: ANTIQUES

And the Park Avenue Antiques Show opening Thursday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, will be no exception. The fair, on view from 1 to 10 P.M. daily and until 7 P.M. on Sunday when it closes, will offer selections from about 125 dealers. Admission is $4.

title: Notes: Cubans Holding Festival
description: Americans are discovering that they can once again visit Cuba; and they are doing so most frequently in group tours. And now they may fly directly to Havana from Tampa. Fla.

title: At Kennedy, It Looks Like Another Frustrating Summer
description: Sunbronzed and still radiant with memories of clacking palms and glycerine Caribbean surf, the returning vacationers alighted from their jet at Kennedy International Airport and made their way to Immigration. They shrugged off a long wait at the baggage return and the snaking lines at the Customs counters. Their cheer withstood push through the mob of welcomers and another lineup outside for a taxi. They could still smile as the cab inched through the airport traffic. But idling on the highway in a maddening crawl of congestion, they felt euphoria give way to irritation. Their tempers frayed and snapped. By the time the travelers reached home, the enchantment of the trip had been all but erased - another casualty of the airport traffic mess.

title: Talk With Muriel Spark
description: Muriel Spark is like a small bird: light, slight, ageless, alert, with tiny wrists and a pretty profile, and a suggestion of plumage about the hair and dress. Her life is divided between a flat in Rome, a small holiday place at Nemi, and her friend Penelope Jardine's home in Tuscany - a ruinous paradise that incorporates a 13thcentury church. Success has not, for Muriel Spark, meant the acquisition of possessions. She doesn't like ownership, preferring to be on the move, a cuckoo in other people's nests. She is happy staying in friends houses, and seems to have no need of the familiar domestic routines that spell security for most of us. Eternally inquiring and curious about places and people, I draw the line at for

title: Pursuing the Silkwood Case Became a Cottage Industry

Today Karen Silkwood's death has been elevated far beyond that of a statistical blur. Her name-now evokes an image of martyrdom ; according to some 'she was the first person to die through the carelessness of the nuclear power industry.

They watched as he effortlessly ran through a repertoire of jumpers and dunks.

From him I learned that it is not just a concept, but the way that concept is executed that is important. His is the architecture of ideas, and I worry that ideas and professional practice do not intersect enough. He pauses, then adds: Maybe my early training set me back. title: A 20Year Talk With Saroyan
description: FOR 20 years now, I have been conducting a continuous conversation with William Saroyan the form of short, widely spaced paragraphs. We first met at the San Francisco Museum of Art when took notice of a burly, blackmustached Armenian gentleman doing the divorcedfather dance with one son, one daughter, explaining the sense and nonsense of maze construction. The picture I had in mind was the handsome, exotic boy writer of The Daring Young Man on the Flying Trapeze, My Name Aram, My Heart's in the Highlands, the early stories, novels and plays of great success - the careless gambler from Fresno who bragged and laughed his way to New York. This was not the man I saw, this shy and hopeful swain wooing his own children. But recognized him anyway: from the deep rise and resonance of voice, and from an aura of personage that was unmistakable.

title: CAMERA

title: Outpatient Life Stressed in L.I. MentalHealth Plan

Busing has been used as a tool to deal with the problem of school segregation, and now it is being proposed as a tool to help alleviate the problem of mentally ill persons here. title: U.S. to Issue Prison Standards
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell says the Justice Department will issue Federal standards for prisons by the end of this summer. The standards would require ac- tions in more areas than the Constitution mandates and could be a guide for state and local prison officials, he said recently. The Government would use the standards to determine awards from the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, a division of the Justice Department that disburses Federal funds for crime-fighting programs, and in auditing state and local correctional systems.

title: RENE LEVESQUE AND THE DIVIDED HOUSE OF CANADA
description: Rene Levesque is a poker player - an excellent poker player by most accounts. The Premier of Quebec, who would break the province away from Canada and split the nation, learned to play poker from his grandmother. She must have been about 70 and I was 6, Levesque remembers. She and her old lady friends were damned good. They taught me a lot. Few people are more devious than a group of old ladies playing poker. Rene Levesque the poker player is the key figure in the saga of Canada's troublesome province of Quebec, where 80 percent of the six million Quebecers are French speaking and trace their roots to the first French colonists who sailed up the St. Lawrence River 400 years ago. They are fundamentally different from the rest of Canada, whose heritage is British. And Rene Levesque is the loudest, strongest, most convincing and inherently trustworthy voice they have ever heard telling them that they can be themselves, that they share a common destiny, that that destiny is within reach and to hell with anyone who says otherwise. In less than 10 years, Levesque, a former journalist and French

title: Zoo Worker Mauled by 2 Bears
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, May 19 (AP) A worker at the Cheyenne Mountain Zoo was mauled by two polar bears for more than 30 minutes yesterday before zoo officials shot and killed one of the animals and rescued the man. title: MAILBAG
description: To the Editor: As director of Black Theater Festival U.S.A. at Lincoln Center, I was surprised that Bernard Carragher, in his introductory review of the history of black theater ['Black Theater Has Moved Beyond Revolution, April 29], appeared to dismiss Lorraine Hansberry's A Raisin in the Sun as a conventional play which, specifically, was not a harbinger of the revolutionary things to come. This is the more ironic since it is almost directly contrary to the viewpoint of the festival committee, which set aside a special evening to celebrate the seminal im. portance of Lorraine Hansberry in the emergence of black drama. As James Baldwin summarized: Never before in the entire history of the American theater had so much of the truth of black peoplets, lives been seen on the stage.

Miss Stoll toppled Dianne Fromholtz of Australia yesterday in another upset.

title: ART VIEW
description: It is now just 20 years since the American painter Sonia Gechtoff, then resident in San Francisco and an established abstract painter in West Coast art circles, had her first solo exhibition in New York. A reviewer at the time found her work mournful, introverted and disturbing. It certainly looked angry. The painted surface was thick, wet, dark and restless, and it made few concessions the bright decorative quality that was just then reconciling public taste to the Abstract Expressionist style. Hers was essentially an outsider's art. Whereas other West Coast painters focused on light, her subject - perhaps one should say her obsessionseemed to be shadow.

The retrospective, which will be at the Whitney until Sept. was first presented at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

title: Toxicity Study Due for Plant In Hicksville
description: THE Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corporation, which last week refused to supply a House subcommittee with records of a study on the contamination of ground water and drinking wells from its chemical dump in Michigan, has agreed to assist New York State in whatever efforts it may undertake in an inquiry into possible health hazards at its wastedisposal site in Hicksville.

title: Gas. Shortages Changing Driving Habits of Nation
description: WOODBRIDGE, N. J., May 16 - .At first glance, cars were thronging the New Jersey Turnpike with as much determination as ever. Cynthia Butler, the hostess at the Marriott Restaurant, hadn't seen much change in business. not vet anyway. For Doug Gregg of Southold, L.I., who was driving to North Carolina, there wasn't any other way.

title: ART A Warm, Humorous View of the City
description: SUMMIT

title: Layoffs at Polaroid: What Went Wrong?
description: Something did seem amiss at the Polaroid Corporation. The stock of inventorentrepreneur Edwin Land's instant camera colossus had been behaving erratically lately. As is usually the case at Polaroid, Dr. Land wasn't talking, but his actions last week said enough. For the first time since the late 1950's, Polaroid ordered a major productionline lay off - 800 workers, most of them from its camera division plant in Norwood, Mass.

title: Bail Is Different for Rich and Poor
description: In New York City, there are several criminal justice systems. One operates in theory, another in practice. One applies to the rich, a second to the poor. People accused of Federal crimes are treated differently from those accused of violating state law.

title: MIDEAST SITUATION PROMPTING STRAUSS TO BEGIN JOB EARLY
description: WASHINGTON, May 19  President Carter's newly appointed Middle East negotiator says that because of the worsening situation in the region he has decided to take control of American involvement in the next round of EgyptianIsmeli talks earlier than planned.

title: TV VIEW
description: In the matter of the communications revolution, the old Bob Dylan lyric might seem especially apt: Something is happening, but you don't know what it is, do you, Mr. Jones? Presenting an award at the recent Oscar ceremonies in Hollywood, Francis Ford Coppola, the film di- rector, rambled on disconcertingly about the ways technology will rapidly alter the future distribution of entertainment and the popular arts. Much of his mass television audience may have been mystified by his remarks, but, in fact, Mr. Coppola was only recognizing the inevitable. More and more people do know what is happening, and, as far as television and independent producers are concerned, they do know what it is in terms of crucial power plays.

title: MUSIC A Harvest of Musical Treasures
description: IN New York the concert season is rapidly winding down, but Connecticut continues to offer an abundance of musical riches this week, including solo recitals, orchestral programs, opera, chamber music and even proof that you do not have to be religious to enjoy your churchgoing this afternoon.

title: Dedicated to Peace of Mind
description: PINELAWN, N.Y., MAY 20  Is there anything more precious than inner peace? Tranquility and a sense of security are among our most cherished blessings. But all too often they prove to be elusive. Perhaps because they are compounded of so many ingredients, big and small, that give us a sense of wellbeing  like money in the bank, a happy and healthy family, a good job, insurance policies  and, for more and more people, a family site at Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: U.S. EMBASSY CURBS ACCESS FOR RUSSIANS

title: Maryland, Johns Hopkins Gain Finals in Lacrosse
description: COLLEGE PARK. Md.. May 19 (AP) - Maryland's Terry Kimball and Barry Mitchell scored three goals apiece today as the Terrapins defeated Navy, 1510, and earned the right to play Johns Hopkins in the finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I lacrosse championships.

title: Getting to Atlantic City to Lose Money Is Easier Now
description: The Memorial Day Weekend - next weekend - marks the first anniversary of Atlantic City as a casino gambling spa, and this summer it is being made easier for you to get there by car, bus or plane to part with your money.

The Rev. Louis Bentivoglio performed the ceremony in St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Siesta Key.

title: City Rated Better Than Rest of New York on Toxic Waste Dumping
description: The regional director of New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation said last week that New York City had fared somewhat better than other parts of the state in the dumping of toxic wastes, but she named several sites of spills in the city.

title: Shoumatoff (Alex) Peels the County's Layers
description: AS a writer, I study places, and what makes a place  the physical environment and the human milieu, says Alex Shoumatoff. His interest in the relationship of man and nature, or increasingly, the lack of relationship has produced three books. 1 he latest, to be released June 7, is Westchester Portrait of a County (Coward, McCann and Geoghegan, $9.95).

title: Cost of Capital Parking to Rise
description: >WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)  The cost of using the city's parking meters is going up. Beginning Monday, the District of Columbia will begin converting meters from a 40-cent-an-hour rate to 50 cents an hour. The increase represents a 500 percent rise over the hourlong parking rate of the 1960's.

title: Ada D. Miller Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leslie P. Miller of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ada Diane Miller, to Dr. Richard R. Ress, son of Warren Ress of Hackensack, N.J., and Shirley Ress of Teaneck, N.J. An Oct. 28 wedding in Rye is planned.

Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington this summer have been postponed for year. But Mr. Wilson has not given up on the project and, in the meantime, is mounting a new, three-hour-plus production that may receive its first performances in New York in late June.

title: Zukerman Named to Lead St. Paul Chamber Group
description: Pinchas Zukerman will succeed Dennis Russell Davies as music director of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra beginning with the 198081 season. It is the first such DOSt that Mr. Zukerman will have in this country; he is music director of the South Bank Festival in London. Starting out as a violin and viola soloist, he has been conducting with increasing frequency, and he has been guest conductor with many leading American orchestras.

title: Draft of Charter For F.B.I. Limits Inquiry Methods
description: WASHINGTON, May 19  The Carter Administration will soon send to Congress the first governing charter for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The proposed charter imposes extensive but not absolute restrictions on the bureau's employment of controversial investigative techniques, .including the use of informers, undercover agents and covert criminal activity.

title: There's Still No Sign of Light In Lebanon's Bloody Tunnel
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  It was quite a week for Lebanon. A conference between the Lebanese and Syrian Presidents was followed by the resignation of Lebanon's Prime Minister, Selim alHoss, who said he wanted to make way for a national reconciliation cabinet of politicians to replace his cabinet of technocrats. In East Beirut, battles between

title: Irene Schall, Boston Lawyer, Is Married to Roger Stanford
description: Irene B. Schall, a Boston lawyer, and Roger Stanford, who has a law practice in New Bedford, Mass., were married yesterday in Fall River, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Kaszynski in the St. Stanislaus Roman Catholic Church.

title: Deaths
description: RANDOLPHA. Philip. The National Council of Jewish Women mourns the death of a magnificent civil rights leader whose struggle for racial Justice. equal opportunity and human dignity, helped democracy work for all Americans.

title: The Seaway, 20 Years Later
description: WELLAND, Ont. - There was Queen Elizabeth II of England and President Eisenhower of the United States amid colorful bands of sailors, trumpeters and bagpipers, backed up by choirs, pennants and the red coats of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. Ships of the world lined the waters nearby as the leaders of the two great nations met to officially open the St. Lawrence Seaway, an unprecedented joint fiveyear, billiondollar navigation and hydroelectric project designed to harness one of the world's major rivers and for the first time to open the North American heartland to direct international maritime commerce.

title: At Home: A Move Against Taking Things Lying Down
description: CARRYIN a large plastic garbage can, I was cleaning up that part of my property that is on the other side of the stone wall. Legally, this does not belong to me, it's town property, but I regard it as mine because it surrounds my house and I take care of it. I make this trip with the garbage can several times year.

title: A.C.L.U. Issues Guide for Elderly
description: A new guide for the elderly by the American Civil Liberties Union says the Social Security Administration often makes mistakes in deciding applications for Social Security benefits. The guide offers advice on appeals, ing a success rate of nearly 50 percent in appeals of initial denials for disability benefits. About 40 percent of Social Security rulings brought into the courts are overturned, it says.

title: Uranium Mines In West Leave Deadly Legacy
description: RED ROCK, Ariz.  The Great Galleon Rock, after which Shiprock, N.M., is named, floats against the sky just a few miles from here, like a fantastic cathedral, a dream of grace and hope.

title: Transit Aides Say Design Study is Needed for Proposed New Bus
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)  Efforts to develop a new federally mandated bus, with lifts for wheelchairs, must undergo a thorough design review after the refusal by bus manufacturers to build the vehicle, according to transit officials from Los Angeles, Miami and Philadelphia.

title: Lynn Curtis, Kevin Crowe Are Married

Thompson & Company, a mortgage brokerage concern, was married yesterday to Kevin Edward Crowe, president of Payroll Equity Plans Inc. in New York. The cere- mony was performed in Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., by the Rev. Dr. Wendel W. Phillips, rector emeritus.

title: DINING OUT
description: DAVID JONES, an informal, woodpaneled place on the water in Island Park, is a difficult call. How does one evaluate a restaurant that offers splendors and disasters? Where some dishes are prepared and seasoned with great skill, while others merely go from freezer fryer or languish, forgotten, under the broiler?

title: FILM VIEW
description: My heart leaps not up but sideways when I read reports from the current Cannes film festival. officially launches this year's film festival season, which will end here in late September with the New York film festival. There are other film festivals before Cannes and after New York but these two, more than any of the others, define the season and set its tone. Of the two, the one at Cannes is the more mysterious, the more demanding, the more exhausting, the more crassly commercial and the one more full of promises that, very frequently, go unhonored.

description: In Summary

title: Sharing a Vision Of Wild Flowers
description: SPRING in Westchester County often conjures up images of lush lawns, opulent shade trees and impeccable flower beds, but beyond the careful suburban landscape, hundreds of wild flowers bloom in secretive bursts of color, amid the weeds of Westchester's wild places. Trillium, lady's slipper, jack-in-thepulpit  the names are almost as magical as the vision they produce when discovered casually by a hiker or a jogger. And it's this vision that Paul Frese, director emeritus of the Meyer Arboretum at the Ward Pound Ridge Reservation, will share with audiences in a talk on wild flowers at the county park today.

title: Collaborating on Children's Books: Adult Teamwork in Scarsdale
description: Inever set out to write children's books; I don't read children's books; I read Updike, said Harriet Langsam Sobol of Scarsdale, the author of five books for children.

In a letter to each House member, James L. Robinson, director of the conference's Office of Government Liaison, reiterated the church's previously stated view that such a department would further increase Federal interference in both public and private edutation.

title: Feldstein: The Bull in a Data Shop
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. - When the witness before the Senate Finance Committee last fall was introduced as the president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, one of the Senators promptly asked, What's the Na- tional Bureau? With that, the Senator from New York, Daniel P. Moynihan, jumped up and delivered a ringing endorsement of the economic research organization and the man who has headed it for two years, a bespectacled Harvard economics professor named Martin S. Feldstein.

title: Nadia Kahan Is Fiancee Of Robert Jay Ableman
description: The engagement of Nadia Ruth Kahan to Robert Jay Ableman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Ableman of New London, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Kahan of Brookline, Mass.

title: IN THE NATION Politics Without Parties
description: Senator Lowell Weicker of Connecticut set what must have been a record this week - fastest withdrawal from one of the earliest Presidential campaigns yet waged. He announced for the Republican nomination on March 12 and withdrew on May 16, 14 months before the party convention and 18 months before the national election.

title: When Man Got Off the Ground

title: Annapolis:
description: Beautifully situated, steeped in history and so well preserved that it is reputed to have more Georgian houses than London, Annapolis is one of the most attractive towns in America. Although best known as the home of the United States Naval Academy, the old community, its brick houses radiating out from the harbor, may so captivate the visitor that the Naval Academy becomes dessert, not the main course.

title: Outgoing Environmental Official Sees Need for a Global Approach
description: LOS ANGELES, May 19  The focus of environmental concern needs to be broadened from domestic to global problems, in the opinion of Charles Warren, the retiring chairman of the Federal Council on Environmental Quality.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: FOR LOVE ALONE and LETTY FOX: HER LUCK. By Christina Stead. (HBJ / Harvest, $5.95 each.) When these two novels, the work of an Australian who spent considerable time in Britain and the United States, were first published in the mid1940's, they raised many critics eyebrows. ('Shades of D. H. Lawrence!') Now returned to print, they are fascinating as precursors of contemporary styles. For Love Alone (1944) tells of a young girl's abandoned pursuit of romance in London. Lefty Fox: Her Luck (1946) satirizes the sexual promiscuity of Manhattan's smart set. In both, the plot is scanty but the writing is sometimes lilting, sometimes biting.

description: A flotilla of 180 small sailboats will gather three miles off Newport in Rhode Island Sound Friday for the ,start of the sixrace series serving as the Olympic pretrials regatta:
