title: GTARDENING Strategy and Tactics in the War on Pests
description: THIS springtime must surely go down in the record books as one of the most splendid ever. From the time the first crocus appeared, and on to the forsythia and daffodils, the highest expectations were fulfilled. Then came the dog- woods, crabapples, lilacs, cherries; and, as they are now fading, the first iris and early peonies are coming along. Soon, roses.

title: Briton Is Expected to Warn Vance hat Policy on Africa May Change
description: LONDON, May 19 - Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary, is expected to tell Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance on Monday that the new Conservative Government hopes to maintain solid front with the United States on southern Africa but may be unable to do so.

title: Cards Beat Mets on SIX in 12th
description: HOUSTON, May 19 (UPI)  Barry Evans and Gene Tenace belted consecutive home runs with one out in the 11th today, enabling the San Diego Padres to score a 42 triumph over the Houston Astros.

title: John F. Hoban, Railroad Director For Port Authority For Last Year
description: John F. Hoban, director of rail transportation for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey since May 1978, died Friday in New York University Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: A New Group Of Handel Disks
description: Not so long ago, Handel was standard fare on symphony orchestra programs, and few thought to question the propriety of 100 players saw- ing away at his music in a fullblooded Romantic fashion. Those days appear to be over. In fact, we now more often than not listen to the instrumental music of Bach, Handel, Vivaldi and their contemporaries played on authentic instruments and directed by speialists with sophisticated knowledge of Baroque performance practices.

title: Beauty Timing The Sun
description: The cosmetics industry seems regularly to fall in love with certain ingredients, words or concepts. A few years ago, protein was a pet. Then came pH, then collagen. This summer, SPF (sunprotection factor) appears to be the favorite.

description: As 125th Street goes, the planners say, so goes Harlem. If redevelopment throughout the Harlem community is to succeed, it must succeed first on 125th Street - the 12block commercial and cultural center that was once called the uptown Broadway but has long since lost its luster.

description: It's beginning to look like summer. Gard& centers, supermarkets, florists and every kind of plant shop are burgeoning with flats of flower seedlings for sale. Soon you'll be piciung out your favorites and adding some new ones to try this year. Most of the young plants display their first blossoms with promise of spectacular full bloom to come.

title: Body of Boy, 2, Found in Trash
description: VILLE PLATTE, La., May 19 (AP) The body of a crippled 2-year-old boy has been found in a trash bag and his mother and her friend have been charged with murder. the Evatuteline Parish sheriff's office said. Detectiie Dan Marcantel said the body of Michael Mayer was found yesterday on the ground beside a highway near here. Sandra Mayer and Charles LaFleur were arrested and chaiged with firstdegree murder, he said.

title: Testing of Teachers Considered
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)  Members of the District of- Columbia school board, voicing concern about declining student achievement in the city's public schools, are considering requiring teachers to submit to competency tests. If the move gains momentum, there could be further labor discord in the school system, which was shut down for nearly three weeks earlier this year by a teachers strike.

description: Renaldo Nehemiah of Scotch Plains, N.J.. and 16-year-old Candy Young of Beaver Falls, Fa., both record-breaking hurdlers, have been voted by the New York Track Writers Association as the outstanding athletes of the indoor track season.

title: Black Life Expectancy Moves Up to 68 Years
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)  The gap in life expectancy between whites and blacks has narrowed from seven years to five years in the last decade, the National Center for Health Statistics says.

title: It's Often a Court Of Last Resorts
description: WHITE PLAINS T T 9:30 Tuesday morning, Vin- cent Gurahian, deputy admin- istrative judge for Westches- ter's Family Court, was in his chambers conferring with two lawyers about the possibility of settling a case out of court. Down the hall, to the left of the judge's chambers, the small, windowless waiting room on the sixth floor of Family Court was crowded with people, mostly women, who passed the time nervously staring at their hands or at passersby.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: At what point do you lose faith in a play? Normally, audiences suspend judgment for quite a long time, I think. In the old days, by which I mean the days when plays were written in three acts rather than in two (or in one), I developed a casual rule of f numb: the audience, I told myself, will always give playwright his first act. That's to say, the first act might not he great, it might even be a bit on the wobbly side; but the playgoers who'd come in hopes of being entertained would Olidg to their hopes right through the first intermission, al1pf.ving for the possibility that things might pick up in Act Two. In fact, Arthur Hopkins once wrote a book called Your Second Act?, the title of which indicates pretty clearly that that's where the audience's vital decilions were made, their anathemas formed, their hearts ong last turned to stone. But that, you see, could be a good 40 qr. 50 minutes after the enterprise had begun.

title: Haiti Eases Entry for Americans
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 19 (AP) -- The Haitian Government, pressed by tourism interests, has rescinded a law requiring Canadians and Americans to have passports to get into the country. A spokesman said the regulation was requested by the security forces. He said Canadians and Americans now need only proof of citizenship.

title: Miss Anderson, After Fall, Takes 2 Gymnastic Titles

Carey of Rockville Centre, to David Phillip Lavins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence J. Lavins of Villanova, Pa. Msgr. Edward L. Melton performed the ceremony.

title: Cordero is Accused Of Devilish Riding

title: Karl Lagerfeld. The Designer Setting Fashion's Tempo
description: In the past, there were designers like Dior, Chanel and flalenciaga, important not only for the clothes they made themselves but for the fact that they seemed to be influencing everybody else who made clothes. Today there is Karl Lagerfeld. The padded shoulders, belted waistlines and narrow skirts he introduced a year ago have their counterparts in styles presented all over the world. What do you think of Karl's clothes? is the question fashion people ask each other in Paris, Milan, London and New York.

description: TWO quite different notions are hitched together uncertainly in Just a Little Bit Less Than Normal, a wispy British play that opened last night at the Manhattan Theater Club's upstairs stage.

description: LONDON, May 20 Already surfeited with politics, the British will vote again on June 7, only five weeks after the general election, to choose members of the European Parliament.

title: The City

A different performer or group will be heard nightly, and the traditional and folk sounds will range from vintage swing to Jewish music of Eastern Europe and that of black and white Africa, the Balkans and South America.

title: Clarence Lewis Jr., 67; Former Aide at Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, May 20  Clarence McKenzie Lewis Jr., a lawyer and cornmunity development activist, died yesterday at his home here. The New York native had been suffering from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, known as Lou Gehrig's disease. He was 67 years old.

description: MADRID, May 20  With delegates openly weeping and shouting his name, Felipe Gonzalez, the 37-year-old leader of the Spanish Socialist Workers Party, announced dramatically today that he would not be a candidate for reelection after radicals at the party's congress defeated his centrist ideological anoroach.

If Henry Kissinger opposes the arms control treaty, or supports crippling amendments, its demise is virtually certain. But to do that, the former Secretary of State would have to repudiate his own works in two Republican Administrations.

title: A Normal but Modest China Trade
description: After some very hard bargaining, China and the United States have agreed on the terms of normal trade. Their pact is the right, almost inevitable result of the decision to normalize diplomatic relations. The danger is that both countries expect too much and face disappointment.

title: De Gustibus The Jicama: A Snack With a Latin Flavor
description: One of the most delectable of snacks in Mexican, South and Central American homes, is a juicy, crisp root vegetable called a jicatna. When peeled, cut into strips and bitten into, it has the texture of a chilled new radish or sweetflavored, crunchy raw white potato. It is vaguely like a rutabaga in shape.

description: LONDON, May 20  The United States has quietly interceded in the dispute between Egypt and Saudi Arabia in an effort to reduce the polemics caused by the signing of the peace treaty between Egypt and Israel.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: There are men on second and third with one out. The batter hits long drive that is caught by the center fielder. Both runners, who started to advance at the crack of the bat, attempt to return to their bases. The runner from thikd makes it back, tags up and again dashes for home. He crosses the plate before the throw to second, which arrives ahead of that runner, results in the third out. Does the run count?

The first one was given on Tuesday as part of Kennedy Center's festival, Paris: The Romantic Epoch. Since that day Daniel Barenboim and his orchestra have presented a complete Damnation de Faust and Romeo et Juliette, as. well as the seldomheard Tristia for chorus and orchestra and the Symphonie Fantastique.

title: Caution Flag Aids Bonnett's Victory

title: Polaroid's Future Out of Focus
description: What lies ahead for a company that revolutionized the camera industry in one generation? It introduced instant photography and, more recently, instant movies. The company sold more than 20 million cameras in the last seven years, including 9.3 million in 1978.

title: How to Strengthen the Drug Law
description: The fallingout between Governor Carey and his party's Senate leadership over how to amend New York's socalled Rockefeller drug law is an unfortunate and we hope brief digression in the drive to reform that benighted statute. All knowledgeable students of the law agree it must be changed.

title: BankCard Protection
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)  The Federal Reserve Board has proposed tighteninn Protection for consumers who have cards that allow them to use 24hour bank teller machines. Under the proposed change, a consumer whose card is lost or stolen would have two days to mail a notice to his bank during which he would be liable for a maximum of $50 in unauthorized use.

title: Beth Ann Gerchick Is Married
description: Beth Ann Gerchick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney D. Gerchick of Jericho, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Jeffrey M. Green, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mort Green of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Her husband is a graduate student at the Wharton School.

title: John Takes 9th on 2Hitter, 20

At that particular time. General Manager Haywood Sullivan said today, I was afraid of the medical condition of his arm, and I also had some concern about his pitching in this ballpark.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Frederic C. Dumaine, chairman of the Amoskeag Company and head of its Bangor & Aroostook Railroad, has been named temporary chief executive officer of the Fanny Farmer Candy Shops. Amoskeag, a Bostonbased holding company, owns 41 percent of Fanny Farmer.

As president, he succeeds John C. Savage, 47, who has been moved to executive vice president of the NCK Organization Ltd., the agency's corporate parent. Graham Lockey remains chairman of N.C.&K.

title: Envoy of Venezuela And 4 Others Escape Salvadoran Militants
description: SAN SALVADOR, May 20 (AP)Venezuela's Ambassador and four other hostages escaped from the Venezuelan Embassy tonight, fleeing nine anti-Government militants who occupied the building May 11.

Endicott of Washington, Conn., and the late Robert Rantoul Endicott, to Peter John Ames of Boston, son of Jasna PerVan Heurtley of New York. The Rev. Lee A. Neuhaus officiated.

title: Nkomo Is Given Degree At a College in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, May 20 (AP)  Joshua Nkomo, one of two leaders of the Rhodesian guerrilla alliance known as the Patriotic Front, predicted today that the government elected in Rhodesia last month would collapse this year.

This is a dump train, he said loudly, glaring angrily at the other passengers. Mama, why are we riding in a dump train?

description: Dwight Stones may pay a lot of money so he can highjump again, just fon the fun of it. The quiet amateur highjumping scene may be enlivened it Stones goes through with his plan to apply for reinstatement with the Amateur Athletic Union.

title: Consumer Group Says Shortage Caused by Oil Industry and U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 20  A consumer group critical of the oil industry asserted today that deliberate actions by the oil industry and the Federal Government had induced a shortage that it described as artificial underdeliverability.

description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 20  In a pro; test against what it called clear interference in Iranian affairs, the Government told the United States tonight to delay sending a new Ambassador to Teheran.

title: Balloonists Race on the Wind for Charity
description: Rising high over rolling hills and green farmland, a bouquet of multicolored hotair balloons  21 in all  raced into the sunset yesterday from Mullencrest Balloonport in Whitehouse Station, N.J. Backed by corporate spon- sors, the balloonists raised more than $3,000 for the Matheny School of Gladstone, N.J., for students with cerebral palsy. Tom Baldwin of Stockton, N.J., with Margo Eld, floated .to victory in his Barnes balloon.

title: Reservation Town Is Tense but Quiet After Disturbances That Killed Two
description: RED LAKE, Minn., May 20  A tense truce gripped this Chippewa Indian reservation town tonight after weekend disturbances in which two youths died, three men were wounded and a number of homes, stores, tribal buildings and vehicles were burned.

title: Apocalypse Now
description: CANNES, France, May 20  Tension mounted last week for what was surely the. main event of the 32d Festival International du Film: the first public showing of Francis Coppola's eagerly awaited blockbuster, Apocalypse Now. Thousands of onlookers jammed the street in front of the Palais du Film last night when the picture was shown to an audience of showbusiness personalities and executives, many of whom were more interested in making the scene than in watching the screen.

title: 2,000 Protest APower At Pennsylvania Rally
description: READING, Pa., May 20 (AP) About 2,000 people shouting, First you try to kill us, then you want to bill us, demonstrated today at the headquarters of the Metropolitan Edison Company, operator of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant.

description: IN his new Plains Daybreak, Erick Havikins has created one of his finest dance works  a luminous evocation of a peaceable kingdom that is also a complete theatrical experience. ,

title: Alice Eve Sardell, Lawyer, Is Bride of Dr. Albert Harary

The Municipal Assistance Corporation plans to sell longterm taxexempt bonds that likely will yield about 8 percent.

title: Direct Primary in New York Gives Kennedy a Time Edge
description: New York Democratic leaders have agreed on a primary date that would give Senator Edward M. Kennedy time to assess President Carter's performance in four early primaries next year before deciding whether to challenge the President in the New York primary.

description: MUNICH, West Germany, May 20For a man who has been called monster, racist and reactionary with numbing frequency during the last month, Otto von Hapsburg is a mildlooking ogre.

title: Rotterdam Oil Brokers Defend Volatile Market
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands From the window of his office here, where the Rhine River flows into the North Sea, Hans Gruen watches the oil barges plying between West Germany and the Dutch coast. Look at them, he tells a visitor, They're only half full. That's why prices are high. There isn't any oil. It's not our fault.

title: Cities
description: The traffic situation in many of the nation's biggest cities is more of a mess than ever, despite a decade of official campaigns intended to streamline traffic and to persuade drivers to switch to public transportation in downtown areas.

title: Jersey Life Merger Gains
description: The New Jersey Life Insurance Company said that the New Jersey Commissioner of Insurance had approved a proposed merger between it and the NJL Corporation, owned by Paul R. Cory, president of New Jersey Life. The plan, which provides for the payment of $2.45 a share to all shareholders of the company except Mr. Cory and NJL, remains subject to approval of shareholders of New Jersey Life.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Wearing a weight while practicing a sport not only strengthens specific muscles, but also makes the activity seem easier when the weight is moved. A new training aid called the Band, which is made in different sizes to fit around the wrist, ankle, head or waist, is both comfortable and unobtrusive. Made of lead encased in a foam pad and covered with vinyl, the flexible weight is worn doughnut style and runs from 8'/2 ounces to 5 pounds, depending on its use. There are seven models ranging in price from $14  $35, which can be purchased from J. A. Preston, 33 West 13th Street, and, starting in June, from Paragon and Herman's.

description: ALBANY, May 20  The Legislature appears ready to extend the controversial heart bill, which lets New York City policemen and firemen retire at threequarters pay if, they develop any heart ailment during their term of employment.

title: Flying Paster, Assembly Drop Out of Belmont Field
description: BALTIMORE, May 20  Spectacular Bid rested today for his final assault on the'Triple Crown of racing while most of his rivals scattered, soundly beaten and no longer willing to test him in the Belmont Stakes.

title: 8 Cars Bumped As Indy Trials End
description: INDIANAPOLIS. May 20 (UPI) Time trials for the Indianapolis 500 wound up today with eight cars bumped by faster machines and four test runs disallowed for violating the rules.

title: The Region
description: Federal investigators, in an effort to determine what caused a small plane to crash early Saturday into a house in Massapequa, L.I., killing six persons, yesterday reassembled its remnants.

title: Tennis: Chris Lloyd Trounces Miss Stoll
description: VIENNA, May 20 (AP) Topseeded Chris Evert Lloyd turned back Caroline Stoll, 61, 61, today in the final of 375.000 Colgate Series tournament.

title: Hans F. Fischer, 60; ExIndustrialist Found Guilty on Tax Chargei
description: Hans Ferdinand Fischer, a retired industrialist, died Saturday at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla., from a self-inflicted gunshot wound, according to the police. He was 60 years old. The police said that his body was discovered by a maid.

title: Austin Senators Still in Hiding, Embarrassing the Texas Rangers
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 20  The Texas Rangers and the state police thought for ,while today that they had one of their men.

title: The Monopoly's Challengers
description: Theodore Vail worked it out in the early 1900's. The Government could regulate the phone company (which he headed) and put a ceiling on its profits. In exchange, he would get a monopoly. Nobody else could put as much as a toe on the phone company's mountain. And so was born one of the most successful business philosophies in the world.

title: Zumwalt Says Joint Chiefs Have Deep Reservations
description: WASHINGTON, May 20  Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the retired Chief of Naval Operations, said today that the Joint Chiefs of Staff had deep reservations that have not been made public about the new SovietAmerican treaty limiting strategic arms.

title: Levi Strauss to Add Koracorp Industries
description: Levi Strauss & Company, the apparel maker, announced Friday that it had signed an agreement to acquire Koracorp Industries, also a maker of apparel, which last year had sales of about $185 million and earnings of S7.8 million

title: Costs at Some Universities Will Rise Above $9,000 This Year, Survey Finds
description: The total cost for a year at the most expensive and prestigious colleges and universities will surpass $9,000 for the first time next fall, according to the college scholarship service of the College Entrance Examination Board.

title: Seaboard Complaint Over Bid Dismissed
description: The United States Court of Appeals in New York has dismissed Seaboard World Airlines complaint that Tiger International Inc. made false and misleading statements in its Jan. 18 tender offer to purchase 638,000 shares of Seaboard common stock.

title: U.S. Motorists Crossing Borders To Get Gasoline
description: BUFFALO, May 20  American visitors to Canada are finding gasoline supplies abundant at Ontario's Lake Erie resorts this spring  often at bargain prices  and large numbers of American tourists. are expected to cross the border this summer to escape the gas crunch at home.

title: Washington Watch
description: Gasoline Defeat:. Whose Fault?

title: John Livingston Picard Weds Meryl Dale Marger, Therapist
description: Meryl Dale Marger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Marger of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to John Livingston Picard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Picard of New York. Rabbi Charles Kroloff of Temple Emanuel in Westfield, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Marger home.

title: NATO Leaders Say the French Have Key Role
description: BRUSSELS, May 18  France and Spain were absent from this week's meeting here of NATO'S Defense Planning Committee, but military and political leaders of the alliance argue that without the active .participation of the two coun-

title: ERNEST EMERLING
description: Ernest Emerling, a former vice president of Loews Theaters, died Friday evening at his home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 74 years old.

title: Events Today
description: ORCHESTRE DE PARIS, Carnegie Hall

title: Jury on Coast Without a Verdict In Murder Trial of ExSupervisor
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 20 (AP)Jurors in the murder trial of former Supervisor Dan White retired for the night after an unusual Sunday session today to try to decide the fate of the man who has admitted killing Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Fed Rate Increase Considered Unlikely
description: The Federal Reserve's. Open Market Committee will meet tomorrow to debate the course of monetary policy over the weeks ahead, and there is widespread belief among bond dealers and moneymarket analysts that the authorities will not vote any increase in shortterm interest rates.

title: Wayne Frederick Yourstone Marries Gail Barbara Behrens
description: The marriage of Gail Barbara Behrens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram S. Behrens of Briarcliff Manor. N.Y., to Wayne Frederick Yourstone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Yourstone of New Brunswick, N.J., took place yesterday at the Westchester Inn in Ossining, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Michael Robinson and the Rev. Joseph Bodner, a Presbyterian minister.

title: The Sweetener in Our Future
description: The saccharin problem is back. When the Food and Drug Administration tried to ban this popular but cancercausing sweetener two years ago, public and industry protests forced Congress to impose a moratorium for further study. That grace period expires Wednesday, raising again the perplexing issue of how to regulate the substance. Is there no way to protect the public health and yet allow millions of Americans to choose their own foods- and poisons?

title: T.R. Berner Weds Nancy B. Meiselas
description: Nancy Banks Meiselas, an editor at Farrar, Straus & Giroux, New York publishers, and Thomas Roland Berner, an associate with the New York law firm of Debevoise, Plimpton, Lyons & Gates, were married yesterday in Cold Spring, N.Y. Surrogate Millard L. Midonick of New York performed the ceremony, at the bridegroom's home.

title: Chevron Is Charged
description: SAN FRANCISCO. May 20 (AP) The Department of Energy has charged Chevron U.S.A., a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California, with a $62.9 million violation of petroleum pricing regulations.

title: PRESIDENT CRITICIZES nes WHO NEGLECT TO USE VOTING RIGHT
description: CHEYNEY, Pa., May 20  President Carter chided black Americans today for failing to exercise their voting rights to help conquer the cancer of racial injustice thathe said has always been near the heart of America.

title: Polish Primate, on Visit to Rome, Celebrates Mass With John Paul
description: ROME, May 20 (Reuters)  The Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, celebrated mass with Pope John Paul II today in his first public engagement since canceling two trips in Italy because of a lingering cold.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times yesterday incorrectly reported that the Time Moving and Storage Company of Brooklyn was suing two tenants of the Citicorp Center- the accounting firm of Price, Waterhouse & Company and the law firm of Winkle Farr & Gallagher  for canceling moving contracts because of pressure from a teamster union official. Time Moving is actually suing Citicorp and Local 814 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Helping Troubled Women in an Era of Change
description: The big black and white banner proclaimed Women in Crisis Conference. It prompted a few quips from the men across the hall at a legal semi, nar, but it was anything but a joke to the 1,500 women (and a few men) from 47 states who gathered in New York City for three days last week to tackle women's problems.

title: Architecture: Lincoln Center and Changes Wrought by 20 Years
description: TONIGHT Lincoln Center Plaza will be filled by a gala party celebrating the 20 years since President Eisenhower broke ground for the huge cultural complex's first structure. It was the first step toward changing a slum neighborhood into a sea of travertine palaces.

title: Rhodesians Stepping Up Their campaign to Encourage Defections by Guerrilla Forces
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 20With political developments in Britain and the United States apparently moving in its favor, the Rhodesian Government is concentrating at home on a steppedup campaign to lure defections among the estimated 13,000 black nationalist guerrillas ensconced in tribal areas around the country.

title: Symposium Assesses the Impact Of Italian Culture on Life in U.S.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20 Scholars from Italy and the United States gathered at Harvard University this weekend to assess the influence of Italian culture in American life.

title: Stage: God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater
description: GOD Bless You, Mr. Rosewater, based on Kurt Vonnegut's 1965 novel, is a jauntily misanthropic musical about philanthropy and hypocrisy in everyday life. Opening last night at the WPA Theater, this is a show with a satiric bite and a devious mind  gifts from the original author.

title: Beauty and Solitude in a Canoe
description: BANTAM, CONN.

title: West Haven Loses
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., May 20 (AP) Dave Righetti walked Larry Rush to force in Mike Henderson with the winning run in the ninth inning today as the Holyoke Millers downed the  West Haven Yankees, 32, in Eastern League baseball.

title: Geiberger Captures Colonial by a Stroke
description: FORT WORTH, May 20 (UPI)  Al Geiberger let a fourshot lead slide away but rallied with a near hole-in-one on the 16th today and won the Colonial National Invitation golf tournament by one stroke.

title: TV: 'The Body Human
description: ALTHOUGH subtitled The Sexes, tonight's production of The Body Human, on CBSTV at 8, is about sex, in rigorously clinical manner, of course. This is part of the informational series produced by Tomorrow Entertainment and Medcon, a supplier of special materials to themedical profession. The programs are part celebration of modern . medicine, part humaninterest vignettes that could have been plucked intact from the soap opera General Hospital.

title: 50 Gather for Ceremony At Silkwood Crash Site
description: CRESCENT, Okla., May 20 (UPI) About 50 persons gathered yesterday at the roadside culvert where Karen Silkwood's life ended in a car crash and put up a sign reading: Born 2-19-1946. Died 11-13-1974. Vindicated 5-18-1979.

title: Equipment Orders Stir Concern
description: WASHINGTON, May 20  Business outlays on capital goods have suddenly replaced consumer spending as the most dynamic sector of the economy.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Bridge:
description: The annual World Championship book is a little different this year. In 1975, for the first time in a quarter of century, there was no world team championship. The Olympiad in New Orleans last June included: the World Open Pair Championship, the World Women's Pair Championship,  the World MixedPair Championship, the Venice Trophy for women's teams representing continental zones and the Open Team Championship.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Alternate-side-of-the-street parking regulations will be in effect today only in the Bronx, in the boroughrotation effort to clean up refuse that has accumulated during the tugboat strike

title: Joanne Blum Is Married To Randy N. Eisenpress
description: Joanne Blum, daughter of Is.r. and Mrs. Walter H. Blum of White Plains, was married yesterday at the home of her parents to Randy N. Eisenpress, an associate with the New York law firm of Butler; Jablow & Geller. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony.

title: The Canadiens: A Dynasty Bound For More Glory
description: HE was a young man and he had just suffered a defeat in the Stanley Cup playoffs. It was after midnight and he still was drenched in perspiration as he described what it's like to play the Montreal Canadiens in the playoffs.

title: Jazz: Elgart Orchestra
description: THE bigband era was virtually gone in 1952 when the Les Elgart Orchestra (later known as the Les and Larry Elgart Orchestra and sometimes the Larry El- gart Orchestrathe two are brothers) was formed. It was the last of the major stylized bands  primarily sweet, with a touch of jazz  and, although it has not played a public engagement in New York since it opened a bigband series at the Riverboat 13 years ago, the band has been working steadily at private functions, on cruises and out of town.

title: Rep. Moffett Presses Energy Issues in Campaign Trip
description: PLAINVILLE, Conn., May 20  Representative Toby Moffett is known in Washington as an angry critic of the oil industry and a leader of a dissident Democratic movement in the House to overturn President Carter's plan for gradually abolishing price controls on crude oil.

title: SENEGAL PRESS LAW UPSETS JOURNALISTS
description: DAKAR, Senegal, May 20  Sooner or later, political discussions here turn to the subject of relativity. Senegal is relatively democratic and the Government is relatively enlightened, says a Western diplomat.

title: Market Place
description: What Defines A Tender Offer?

title: Affirmed, 15, Wins Easily
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif.. May 20 (AP)  Affirmed, the 1978 Triple Crown winner, easily captured the 8272,400 Californian at Hollywood Park by five lengths today.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: Brat/Is

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: STANLEY MARVIN JORDAN

title: U.S. Budget Cuts Posing A Dilemma for Liberals
description: WASHINGTON, May 20  In classic fashion, the fierce debate over Federal spending has handed liberal Democrats some tough choices this year. Depending on their priorities and sense of strategy, the liberals adopted different

title: Fishermen to Protest Again Over Navy Puerto Rico Curb
description: VIEQUES, P.R., May 20  The Vieques Fishermens Association, which has been fighting the Navy's use of its island off Puerto Rico for amphibious assault operations, announced plans to stage an even larger protest tomorrow than the one yesterday in which 21 persons were arrested.

title: Brehm
description: DUCHESSI--WIlialm M. The Ohlcers, General Executive Board and Members of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union record with deep sadness The death of our colleague and friend, Executive Vice President William M. OvC.hessi. He was a founding member of the Textile Workers Union of America, and became an Organize soon after the founding convention In 1939. He was fond of telling how his first deeck from the uniannottfled him that the entire staff had been placed on half Pan ,Think cared? I was too busy working on the Mohawk campaign. That symbolized Bill DuChessrs life. Ife served the Textile Workers and the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union with a rare devotion and dedication that made np tasks too demanding and no sacrifice too taxing. He welcomed responsibility and noted

title: Exotic Fare Tempts FestivalGoers
description: Thousands of New Yorkers turned out under overcast skies to tickle their taste buds with tempting offerings at the sixth annual Ninth Avenue International Festival. Ethnic foods and music from many cultures were featured.

title: ABROAD AT HOME The Savor of SALT
description: WASHINGTON  The instinctive American skepticism toward absolute claims should serve the country well as it debates the second strategic arms limitation agreement in the months ahead. For what is at issue is not perfection but the balance of advantage: whether ratification of the treaty would on balance make us more or less secure.

title: Jersey Steel Mill, Reopening After 4 Years, Is to Hire 500
description: ROEBLING, N.J., May 18  The John A. Roebling's Sons steel mill here, shut, down for four years, has been bought by a new company that plans to reopen it this fall

title: Erica Ward, Lawyer, Bride
description: Erica Anne Ward and Ralph Joseph Gerson, who graduated with the class of 75 from the University of Michigan Law School, were married in Washington yesterday. Rabbis Irwin Groner and Stanley Rabinowitz officiated at the Madison Hotel.

title: Estonian Is Reported Executed
description: MOSCOW, May 20 (Reuters)  A 38yearold Estonian chef has been executed for killing a man and a teenage girl while under the influence of alcohol, the newspaper Sovietskava Estonia reported in an edition reaching Moscow today.

title: Big Day for Chinaglia, cosmos
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 20  It was Giorgio Chinaglia Day at Giants Stadium this afternoon and the big centerforward responded accordingly, scoring two goals and leading the Cosmos to a 3.1 victory over the Tulsa Roughnecks.

title: World News Briefs
description: Nepal Reopening Colleges After Violent Clashes

title: United Press International
description: ATTEMPT TO DISRUPT AIR TRAFFIC: Japanese demonstrators releasing balloons trailing strips of aluminum foil to jam radar yesterday as they tried to interfere with flights at Tokyo's new international airport at Narita. The protest by 5,000 marked the first anniversary of the opening of the airport.

title: Stricter Motorcycle Laws Urged
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI)  The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety wants the Government to require headlights and running lights on motorcycles to come on automatically when the i2ni- tion is turned on and to stay on until the engine is shut off. The request, to the Na tional Highway Traffic Safety Administration, comes at a time when motorcycle deaths have increased by 24 percent from 1976 to 1977. It also follows the repeal of helmet laws in 29 states.

title: Bill for Death Penalty Passes Albany Senate By Margin of 41 to 17
description: ALBANY, May 21  The State Senate approved tonight a bill to restore the death penalty in some cases of murder, gaining for the first time the twothirds margin that would be needed to override a veto by Governor Carey.

title: Beefing
description: It costs a lot more to do things these days. Sleeping, eating, working, playing and even dying all cost more than just a few years  or even weeks ago. It would appear that in the minds of many all we have to do is keep the price of meat down and everything will be OK. A recent story in one regional newspaper is typical. The headline read: Record cattle prices won't help housewife. The first paragraph said, in part: This story is good news if you're in the cattle business and bad news if you're a housewife trying to stay within a food budget. Cattle prices hit record levels at the Omaha stockyards.

title: U.S. IS HOPEFUL IRAN ACCEPTS ENVOY SOON
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  The United States, holding to a conciliatory attitude toward Iran, said today that it hoped to be able to send Walter L. Cutler to his new ambassadorial post in Teheran soon.

title: Audubon Group Plans Science Effort
description: THE National Audubon Society, long known for its activities and research in the conservation of bird life, is about to change its feathered image to one that relates more directly to the major scientific, social and environmental Problems that plague the world today.

title: Botha Pushes Easing of Apartheid But Doubts Remain Among Blacks
description: CAPE TOWN, May 16  In a flurry of moves in recent weeks the South African Government has announced plans to change fundamental aspects of apartheid, the system permanently separating whites and blacks and entrenching white control in the richest parts of the country.

title: Notes on People
description: The consumeraffairs subcommittee of the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee had no trouble yesterday getting an audience and television coverage of hearings on whether Congress should authorize a special gold medal in honor of John Wayne. A key witness was Maureen O'Hara, often Mr. Wayne's costar, who tearfuly told the subcommittee: John Wayne is not just an actor. John Wayne is the United States of America.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: With the credit markets sliding lower in price yesterday, Treasury securities dealers estimated that the Government's twoyear notes that are scheduled for sale this afternoon would yield 9.80 percent or a little more.

title: Letters
description: To SCIENCE TIMES:

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: A Visit to Cabinet Meeting: Carter Sets the Pace and Tone
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  At 8:55 this morning, the men and women who run the executive branch of the United States Government began strolling into the Cabinet room in two's and three's. W. Michael Blumenthal, the Treasury Secretary, had a kiss for Juanita M. Kreps, the Secretary of Commerce, who has just returned from China; Patricia Roberts Harris, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, was chatting with Bob Bergland of the Agriculture Department.

title: CALIFORNIANS FIND CAS IS EASIER TO BUY
description: LOS ANGELES, May 21 (AP)  The long lines at gas stations that clogged California streets and frustrated drivers over the past three weeks were reduced dramatically today. In some areas there was no waiting at all.

title: Easen Best First Novel
description: Reuben Bercovitch is a West Coast movie and television script writer. He is also a translator from the Yiddish, fact that has been reasonably important in his career. For among his trans- lations were some he did for Irving Howe, author of World of Our Fathers. After a while he confided to Mr. Howe that he had written a novel  his first. Mr. Howe read it and loved it and asked his agent, Bernice Hoffman, to read it. She did and loved it, too. So did Knopf, which published it last year as Hasen.

title: Jack Pulman, 51, Dramatized I, Claudius, Other BBC Shows
description: LONDON, May 21 (AP)  Jack Pulman, who dramatized Robert Graves's I, Claudius for television, died of a heart attack yesterday in the Royal Free Hospital. He was 51 years old.

title: Perry Signs Padre Pact
description: SAN DIEGO, May 21 (UPI)  Gaylord Perry, the only pitcher to win the Cy Young Award in both the American and National Leagues, signed a oneyear contract with the San Diego Padres today.

title: Scot Contends Victoria Had a Secret Marriage
description: LONDON, May 22 (AP)  Michael MacDonald, curator of the Museum of Scottish Tartans at Comrie in Perthshire, says Queen Victoria May have secretly married John Brown, a Scot selected by Prince Albert many years before his death to be her gamekeeper, and borne him a son.

title: Legislators Accept Key Trade Wording
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  Influential senators and representatives, bowing to European demands, agreed today that new trade legislation should require domestic companies to show material injury before they can get relief through countervailing duties against imports that are subsidized by foreign governments.

title: Deaths
description: ANDERSONAnna, on May 20, 1979, widow of Andrew J. Anderson. Survived by sister Emily Schaffner and brother Aloysius Schaeffner. Reposing at the Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home. 6020 Roosevelt Ave., Jackson Heights. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 9:30 AM. Blessed Sacrament Church. Visiting hours 25, 74:30 PM.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS  Accord on a compromise plan for improving Westchester County's parkways has been reached by Westchester legislators. State Transportation Commissioner William C. Hennessy and members of Governor Carey's staff, according to Assemblythan John M. Perone, a Mamaroneck Republican.

title: IN THE NATION
description: A trial going forward in Ulster Coun ty, N.Y. shows once again how hard it is for prison inmates to get consideration of their grievances without resort to methods more likely to bring prosecution than redress  a sort of Catch22 behind bars.

title: NELLIE POSNANSKY
description: Nellie Posnansky, music teacher, pianist and therapist, died Sunday in Bronx Lebanon Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: G.P.U. Gets Financing to Help Jersey Subsidiary
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation, in financial difficulties because of the recent Three Mile Island nuclear accident, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with a bank group that would provide $8 million of 60day secured shortterm financing so that its New Jersey subsidiary, Jersey Central Power and Light, would have no trouble meeting its $16 million purchasedpower bill for April.

title: Advertising
description: YOUNG & RUBICAM resigned some $25 million in billings from the BristolMyers Company yesterday because it could not make reasonable profit, according to house memo distributed yesterday by Alexander Kroll, president of the agency's domestic operation. It marked the end of a 44wear relationship.

title: Sears Net Off 3.4%, but Progress Is Cited
description: ALHAMBRA Calif., May 21  Addressing a disgruntled, standingroomonly meeting of Sears Roebuck & Company shareholders, Edward R. Telling, chairman of the world's largest retail- er, reported that net income had dropped 3.4 percent on a 10.9 percent sales decline for the three months ended April 30. Nevertheless, be said, the company is making good progress in its fiveyear plan to reestablish itself as an aggressive merchandiser for middleclass America.

title: Klein Claims Full Responsibility For Difficulties of Sewer District
description: HAUPPAUGE. L.I., May 21  The Suffolk County Executive, John V. N. Klein. today took responsibility for the soaring costs and alleged mismanagement of the county's controversial Southwest Sewer District, which is under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Suffolk County District Attorney and a committee of the County Legislature.

title: 2,997 WinDegrees in 278th Yale Ceremony
description: NEW HAVEN, May 21  Yale University awarded a record 2,997 degrees at its 278th commencement today, including 13 honorary degrees, which went to an opera singer, an expatriate Russian dancer and the Mayor of Los Angeles, among others.

title: Thinking Computer Is Out to Get Paranoia
description: RESEARCHERS in California have produced a computer whose responses are so paranoid that psychiatrists interviewing it with a teletype machine cannot distinguish it from a mental patient.

title: ISRAELIS IN ACCORD ON PEACETALK PLAN
description: JERUSALEM, May 21  The Israeli Government approved proposals today for limited Arab selfrule in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip in preparation for talks with Egypt and the United States.

title: U.S. Finances News Guild's Latin Unionizing Drive
description: The 35,000member Newspaper Guild has ,embarked on a Latin American unionization program with United States Government funds.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: INVENTORY American Psychiatry in Crisis is the subject of public forum tonight at 7:45 sponsored by the BrandeisKallen Chapter of the American Jewish Congress at 15 East 84th Street.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: West German Woman, 64, Given 12 Years in East Berlin Spy Case
description: EAST BERLIN, May 21 (Reuters) An East Berlin military court sentenced a 64yearold West German woman to 12 years in prison today on charges of military espionage.

title: Cannes Sees Syndrome
description: CANNES, France, May 21 (AP) The China Syndrome, the American film about an accident at a nuclearpower plant, had its European premiere yesterday as an entry in the 32d Cannes Film Festival.

title: World News Briefs
description: GENEVA, May 21  A resolution adopted today by the assembly of the World Health Organization called on the agency's director to refuse all cooperation with the new biracial Government of Rhodesia.

title: Last Ranger Defeat Was Primarily Mental
description: MONTREAL, May 21  You did not need a psychologist to tell you the Rangers were a beaten team before they even took the Forum ice for the final Stanley Cup game. They had mouthed the kind of words that proud men choose when facing death.

title: Wright Perfects Reserve Role
description: Charley (C.J.) Johnson watched the mob scene Sunday as Larry Wright, a substitute guard, was besieged in the Washington Bullets dressing room. Wright had just scored 26 points, including the two free throws that gave the Bullets a 999; victory and a 10 advantage in the National Basketball Association finals against the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: TV: Mumford Views Architecture and Civilization
description: IN Lewis Mumford: Toward Human Architecture, on WNETTV at 9 o'clock this evening, Mr. Mumford is the focus, not the subject, of a 90minute essay. The architectural and social critic, now in his mid80's, is interviewed in his Amenia, N.Y., home. Excerpts are combined with comments from a national sampling of architects. historians and critics who, in varying degrees, have been influenced by Mr. Mumford's ideas. The result is a neatly compact and generally sound elementary course in architecture and civilization.

title: Supreme Court Reverses A StockFraud Decision
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  Stock fraud is illegal even if brokers, not their customers, are the victims, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

title: Hempstead Recyclers Find Coins in Realm of Garbage
description: WESTBURY, L.I., May 21  What's in a ton of trash? Since January, the Town of Hempstead's new $73 million garbagerecycling plant here has been producing a windfall of energy, reusable metals and discarded exotica ranging from bowling balls and wooden legs to soupstained neckties and small amounts of sootstreaked coinage.

title: Church's Project For the Elderly Stirs Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn., May 21  For the Rev. Martin B. Hitchcock, pastor of Saint Mary's Roman Catholic Church, the elderly have the right to live out their lives in the communities where they were born and raised.

title: Reliance Wary About an Exxon Bid
description: Shares of the Reliance Electric Company soared 10 points yesterday, to 47, as its management reacted cautiously to the possibility of a takeover bid by the Exxon Corporation.

title: Lacrosse: A Clash Of Styles
description: Maryland and Johns Hopkins will meet Saturday on the lacrosse field at Byrd Stadium in College Park, Md., in what could be a classic battle of a fiery offense (Maryland) against a stubborn defense (Hopkins).

title: About Education
description: ACORDING to a recent poll by The Daily Princetonian, more than onethird of the university's undergraduates say they have cheated on an examination at least once during college. By coincidence, the Carnegie Council on Policy Studies in Higher Education has issued a report accusing some colleges and universities of ethically shady behavior. While the council did not ignore cheating by students, it directed most of its criticism at institutions that cheat by misrepresenting themselves to prospective students and the world. It also said that professors are often less than truthful when they give students undeservedly high grades in an effort to protect their own popularity and budget or those of their departments.

title: Theater World Cites 12 New Performers
description: Twelve performers from Broadway and Off Broadway productions during the 197879 season will receive the 35th Annual Theater World Awards Thursday at the Gotham Hotel, Fifth Avenue and 55th Street.

title: Ballet: Sylphide Saved
description: Asylph flew down from Canada on Saturday to help the American Ballet Theater. The company. which has been plagued with injuries, found it lacked a ballerina for the evening's La Sylphide at the Metropolitan Opera House. And so, on short notice, it imported Veronica Tennant of the National Ballet of Canada for a single appearance in August Bournonville's great Danish ballet.

title: GAF Sells Unit to Uforma
description: The GAF Corporation said yesterday that it had sold its business forms operation in Shelby, Ohio, to Uforma Inc., a privately owned company. The $12 million deal is part of a company redeployment program, GAF added, that would enable it to concentrate on its major businesses of chemicals, building materials and photographic products.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Record prices were posted yesterday for all precious metals futures on both sides of the Atlantic as dealers scrambled for stocks of gold, silver and platinum to meet investor and speculator demand.

title: DONYALE LUNA
description: ROME, May 21 (AP)  Donyale Luna, an American actress and model who in the 60's became one of the first black women to succeed as a highfashion model, died Thursday in a clinic here. She was 33 years old.

title: Continental Plans to Buy Florida Gas
description: The Continental Group Inc., formerly the Continental Can Company, has reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Florida Gas Company for about $340 million in cash and stock, both concerns announced yesterday.

title: Concert: A Phantom Instrument
description: BACH wrote two concertos for three harpsichords and orchestra, and both works turned up at Sunday night's Music in May concert at Avery Fisher Hall. Strangely  one might almost say perversely  not one of the six solo instruments was a harpsichord. Alexander Schneider, who conducted chamber orchestra drawn from the New York Philharmonic's ranks, took a remarkably blithe attitude toward scholarly strictures, in the tradition of his mentor, Pablo Casals, and the British provocateur Sir Thomas Beecham.

title: Lawyer for Cruise Line Says Safes Were Looted on Ship That Burned
description: A lawyer for the Italian cruise liner that burned and sank at its St. Thomas. V.I., pier March 30 has suggested that the safe and deposit boxes were forced open and ransacked during or after the fire.

title: American Can Pact On Texaco Patents
description: The American Can Company has signed an agreement that will give it an exclusive license covering Texaco Inc. patents on use of lignin chemicals to increase oil recovery. The process helps increase the amount of oil that can be extracted from underground oilbearing reservoirs.

title: 18 U.S. Artists Featured in Caracas
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 21 Five prominent American painters are visiting Venezuela to participate in the opening of an exhibition of contempo- rary work by 18 artists from the United States. Richard Anuszkiewicz, Richard Diebenkorn, Ellsworth Kelly, Robert Motherwell and Frank Stella, plus group of American gallery directors, attended yesterday's opening of the display.

title: Occidental Pact On China Coal
description: LOS ANGELES, May 21 (AP)  The Occidental Petroleum Corporation has signed an agreement with Peking to develop some of China's coal reserves, Armand Hammer, chairman, told the company's shareholders today.

title: Egypt, Cut Off Fiom Saudi Funds, Is Likely to Seek Increase in U.S. Arms Aid ArmsAid
description: CAIRO, May 21  With customary financing from Saudi Arabia cut off, Egypt is expected to look for American military assistance beyond the $1.5 billion in credits approved by Congress.

title: Indy Race Protests Are Rejected
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 21 (AP) Seven protests involving qualification procedures for next Sunday's Indianapolis 500 auto race have been denied by race officials, Tom Binford, chief steward at Indianapolis Motor Speedway, said today.

title: Taiwan Radio in English Beams Assurances on U.S. Ties
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  ICRT, Taiwan's new Englishlanguage radio station, is broadcasting a 24houraday message of reassurance to both Chinese and foreign businessmen here that the decision of the United States to break relations with Taiwan has not really changed anything.

title: BRITON TELLS VANCE SHIFT WILL BE SLOW ON RHODESIA POLICY
description: LONDON, May 21  Lord Carrington, Britain's new Foreign Secretary, reassured Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today that the Conservative Government intends to move slowly before making decision on ending sanctions against Rhodesia or recognizing the black majority government that will soon take office there.

title: McGeorge Bundy: A Finish and a Start
description: McGeorge Bundy has been an aide to an admiral, a coauthor with a statesman, a dean of a college, adviser to Presidents and leader of a foundation. Few men have had their services so highly solicited and their efforts so infrequently praised. Now nearing 60 years to age and about to leave the presidency of the Ford Foundation for the life of gentleman historian at New York University, Mr. Bundy departs to compliments, arrives to criticism and remains characteristically unstirred by either one.

title: Foes of Nuclear Energy Attend Con Ed Meeting
description: Antinuclear demonstrators used proxy votes to infiltrate Consolidated Edison's annual stockholders meeting yesterday to complain about alleged safety deficiencies at the utility's Indian Point nuclear power plant.

title: Thomas Edison Retains Queens Crown in Track
description: Thomas Edison High, winner of the indoor title, retained its outdoor crown yesterday in the Public Schools Ath- letic League Queens track and field championships at Randalls Island. Coach Dave Cohen's squad tallied 52 points to edge Bayside, which had 50.

title: HalfGallon Gas Sales Suggested in New York
description: ALBANY, May 21 (AP)  Some New York State motorists may soon be buying the more expensive grades of gasoline by the half gallon.

title: ExOfficial Guilty of Manslaughter In Slayings on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 21  Dan White, a former San Francisco Supervisor, was found guilty of voluntary manslaughter today in the shooting deaths of Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk, and the verdict touched off a confrontation between the police and demonstrators at City Hall.

title: The City
description: Felix G. Rohatyn agreed yesterday to take back his old job as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and said that his company, Lazard Freres & Company, would serve as the M.A.C.'s unpaid investment adviser.

title: Theater: Dialogue and Dreams Atop a Mountain
description: IN On Mount Chimborazo, a new play by the West German playwright Tankred Dorst, a quintet of hikers reaches the top of a towering mountain. This is not Mount Chimborazo, an Ecuadorian peak remembered by two of the characters from a dream of youthful adventure, but an unnamed mountain facing the border of East Germany. On Mr. Dorst's mountain, there is no dramatic excitement, only a dry, rarefied atmosphere.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Commission on transnational corporations  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Japan Limits GasStation Hours
description: TOKYO, May 21 (Reuters)  Most gasoline stations in Japan will be closed on Sundays and national holidays after this Sunday, a spokesman for the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The stations agreed to a Government request to close on holidays in order to carry out a 5 percent energy conservation program adopted last month.

title: Dismissal Denied in Photo Bribe
description: A judge in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn denied a motion yesterday to dismiss bribery charges against James Mitteager, a freelance writer accused of bribing a correction officer to get pictures of David Berkowitz, the imprisoned so-called Son of Sam killer.

title: Volunteering as Paramedics For the City's Wounded Trees
description: Sometime this week or next, 30 men and women will receive certificates from the New York City Department of Parks proclaiming them, in effect, paramedics for the city's trees.

title: Dr. Giorgio Lolli, 70, Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Giorgio Lolli, a psychiatrist and former medical director of the Yale Plan Clinic for Alcoholics, died May 14 at the age of 70 in Rome after a brief illness. He had offices in Rome and New York and had divided his time between the two cities..

title: By the Light of the Ayatollah's Oil
description: Now that the Senate has deplored the execution 250 persons by its kangaroo komitehs, the new Iran wants to clarify relations with the United States before it will receive the next American ambassador.

title: MEXICO PRESSES U.S. TO END SOMOZA AID
description: MEXICO CITY, May 21  Within hours of breaking diplomatic relations with Nicaragua, Mexico urged the United States today to disband all remaining assistance programs to the regime of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: Time Spent on Housework Declines
description: Women are spending less time on housework. Men are spending more. And the chief beneficiary seems to be the television set.

title: Algerian Oil Is World's Costliest
description: Algeria notified oil companies yesterday that it had raised the price of its oil by more than 13 percent. At $21 a barrel, up $2.45, Algeria's best crude becomes by far the most expensive oil in the world.

title: $5,000 Tip Is Won By Bartender in Suit
description: MINEOLA, L.I., May 21  A bartender from Manhasset today received the equivalent of a $5,000 tip in an out-of-court settlement for drinks he had served to a customer a year ago.

title: How Cable Goes to Market
description: Just as they are finally winning rescission of rules that unfairly shielded broadcast television against their competition, cable television companies are grasping to hold on to some unfair protection for themselves. They are to be free at last to carry programs from any part of the country, but they do not want pay the market price for such shows. They want to attract customers with highquality entertainment but without paying a fair royalty. That is not our idea fair competition.

title: Japan Business Loan Rate
description: TOKYO, May 21 (AP)  The interest rates for business loans charged by 13 major Japanese commercial banks rose for the first time in about four years, a preliminary report by the Bank of Japan said today. The average rate went up 0.027 percentage points from March's level to 5.479 percent a year in response to the increase in the Japanese official discount rate from 3.5 percent to 4.25 percent last month.

title: Gold Soars To $263.88 On Oil Fear
description: LONDON. May 21  The price of gold rocketed ahead by $7 an ounce and closed at a record 5263.88 an ounce here today in another session dominated by worsening fears about oil.

title: Pirates Win on Homers
description: MONTREAL, May 21 (UPI)  Willie Stargell broke a 22 tie in the fifth inning with his ninth home run of the season and Ed Ott added his third homer in the eighth inning today as the Pittsburgh Pirates ended Montreal's threegame winning streak with a 42 victory over the Expos.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Why do some substances glow after being subjected to light?

title: Japanese Carrier Orders Airbuses
description: TOKYO, May 21 (UPI)  Toa Domestic Airlines said today that it had contracted to purchase six Europeandeveloped Airbus jetliners and taken options on three others. Toa, one of the leading Japanese domestic carriers, said the initial six jets, worth $225 million, would be delivered between October 1980 and May 1982. The remaining three will be purchased in 1983, it said.

title: EDUCATION
description: THERE is no mistaking the gift in a child who can do calculus and higher forms of mathematics while he is still in junior high school. But being gifted is far less apparent when a youngster of the same age shows it through his ability to handle language rather than numbers.

title: Bridge:
description: The quartet that will represent New England in the Grand National zonal playoffs in White Plains June 9 and 10 could fly under other flags. Bob Becker of Boston, Lew Finkel of Providence, R.I., and Art Moore of Framingham, and Eric Robinson of Cambridge, both Massachusetts, could call themselves Harvard, since Robinson is about to graduate from that institution and the others are all graduates of Harvard Law School.

title: Jets Win Final W.H.A. Series
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 21 (AP)  The Winnipeg Jets were in their glory last night after defeating the Edmonton Oilers, 73, in the sixth game of the World Hockey Association championship series.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: CHICAGO, May 21 (AP)  Gould Inc., a manufacturer of industrial and electrical products, today withdrew its $70ashare offer to buy the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation after Fairchild said it would merge with Schlumberger Ltd.

title: Michael McClure's Josephine Wins Obie for U.S. Play
description: Michael McClure won an Obie award last night for his play Josephine, named best new American play of the year by the Obie committee. This was one of 27 awards made at the 24th annual Village Voice Obie ceremony honoring achievement in the Off Broadway and the Off Off Broadway theater.

title: High Court Rejects Boy's Plea
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 21 (AP)  The Supreme Court in Washington rejected without comment today a request that it allow Donald Gomes to rejoin the girls' volleyball team at Rogers High School in Newport.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: The average discount rate on threemonth Treasury bills climbed yesterday to 9.744 percent, the secondhighest rate on record for these shortterm Government securities, topped only by the 9.908 percent rate reached on Aug. 6, 1974. Last week, the rate was 9.506 percent.

title: Italy's Own Elections
description: ROME  In Naples there are  or were until a short time ago  monks who danno i numeri  give the numbers. Theirs is the rare supernatural, unconscious gift of revealing what numbers or combination of numbers will win the lottery the following Saturday. The messages are not clear. They must be deduced by experts from a casual gesture. an incident, a stray remark, or a street encounter, according to arcane rules. True, most things have their corresponding numbers. which can be looked up in a book called La Smorfia (The Grimace), but the numbers are few  from one to 90, confusions inevitable, and success ultimately depends on the choice of the incident and its precise definition. The art of monkwatching is not easy.

title: Nkomo Sees Continued Sanctions
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 21 Joshua Nkomo, the Rhodesian guerrilla leader, expressed confidence today that President Carter would oppose lifting economic sanctions against the new government in Salisbury, which he predicted would fall within months.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, May 20  Question: Dr. Dementia, you are the world's foremost authority, I believe.

title: High Court in Florida Rejects Pleas to Delay Executions of 2 Killers
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 21 (AP) The Florida Supreme Court refused today to delay the executions of convicted murderers John A. Spenkelink and Willie Jasper Darden Jr.

title: Stress Factor Linked to Test For Diabetes
description: SCIENTISTS have found that the activity of insulin the human body is exquisitely sensitive to small amounts of the stress hormone adrenalin; a discovery they believe has important implications for the widespread use of early diabetes testing and perhaps for better understanding of the nature of this common and serious illness.

title: Fitch Bows Out As Cays' Coach
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, May 21 (UPI) Bill Fitch, the only coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers in their nine years of operation, resigned today.

title: Former Aide Says He and Talmadge Laundered Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  Daniel Minchew, the key witness in the Congressional investigation of Senator Herman E. Talmadge's financial affairs, said today that he and the Georgia Democrat had conspired to launder campaign and office funds through a secret bank account.

title: Takeover Stocks Score Gains; Dow Up 0.52, Closing at 842.43
description: Takeover stocks scored impressive gains yesterday as the market in general made a small advance in moderate trading.

title: Fink Pulls Back His TaxCut Bill To Block G.O.P.
description: ALBANY, May 21  The Assembly Speaker, Stanley Fink, blocked his chamber today from considering his own bill to cut taxes by $200 million. He did so to stop Republicans from gaining any political advantage by trying to amend the bill to make it more generous.

title: Short Interest on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 3.7 million shares in the month ended May 15 to 39.5 million shares. The short interest for the yearearlier level totaled 42.9 million shares.

title: Gala Marks 20 Years Of Lincoln Center
description: LINCOLN CENTER, looking every bit like a travertine and glass birthday cake, with festive dollops of light, water and people, famous and not so famous, observed the 20th anniversary of its start as a shovelful of earth at its groundbreaking in May, 1959.

title: Gordon Smith, Aft Expert, Dies; Built AlbrightKnox's Collection
description: Gordon M. Smith, director of the AlbrightKnox Art Gallery in Buffalo from 1955 to 1973 and one of the outstanding American museum men of his generation, died Sunday of a heart attack at his home in Buffalo. He was 72 years old.

title: Varsity School Buses Back in Service After Walkout
description: Vartity Transit Inc., whose operations had been shut down for more than three months by a wildcat walkout by schoolbus drivers, resumed transporting 107,000 children to public schools in New York City yesterday.

title: A Maimed Terrorist Flees Cell at Bellevue
description: William Morales, who lost most of both hands in an explosion and is suspected of being a member of F.A.L.N., the terrorist group seeking independence for Puerto Rico, escaped from a prison ward at Bellevue Hospital yesterday, apparently by using an elastic bandage as a makeshift rope to climb down from a 40foothigh window.

title: Jeep Sales Feel Gas Shortage
description: DETROIT, May 21  The gasoline shortgage has once again impelled American car buyers to look for lighter, more fuelefficient models and brought about a pronounced drop in sales of larger cars, recreational vehicles and utility vehicles.

title: Tuck School Prize For Times Writer
description: N.R. Kleinfield, a reporter for. The New York Times, has been named a firstprize winner in the 1978 Media Awards for Economic Understanding. The awards, given to print and broadcast journalists in markets of various sizes, are spon sored by the Amos Tuck School of Dartmouth College and the Champion International Corporation. Mr. Kleinfield will receive $5,000 for a series of articles on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Walton Has Operation For Bone Spurs on Ankles
description: SAN DIEGO, May 21 (UPI)  Bill Walton, who signed a sevenyear contract with the San Diego Clippers, reportedly for $1 million a season, underwent ankle surgery today, a club spokesman announced.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Frank A. Grisanti, a management consultant in the computer field, has been elected president and chief executive officer of General Automation Inc. At the same time, John B. Conlan Jr., a 48yearold Phoenix lawyer who is a former member of the House of Representatives and has been a General Automation director since 1975, was named to the parttime post of chairman.

title: Opera: Tippett's Ice Break in Boston
description: BOSTON, May 20  The Ice Break, being performed for the first time in the United States by Sarah Caldwell's Opera Company of Boston, is characteristic of Sir Michael Tippetts music in two essential respects. The first is that the new opera, completes 1977 and first given at Covent Garden the same year, is the offspring of a vital, questing intelligence, fortified by moral courage and unquenchable hopes. The second is that, notwithstanding various oddities and ambiguities along the way, its boldness and breadth of vision ultimately prove inspiring, and very moving.

title: EARNINGS
description: Genesco Inc., which has been discontinuing some operations in an effort to achieve profitability, reported a $6.4 million deficit yesterday for the third fiscal quarter ended April 30, substantially above the $323,000 loss a year ago. About twothirds of the loss was attributed to closings or disposal of various operations. The company sold its Bonwit Teller speciality stores to the Allied Stores Corporation.

title: Turkey Needs a Hand, Not a Rod
description: When Congress decided last fall to lift the arms embargo on Turkey, it confessed a failure. It acknowledged that the threeyear ban had estranged a strategic ally and injured NATO without promoting, as intended, a Cyprus settlement. Lifting the embargo made it politically possible for Turkey to reopen American military bases, including intelligence monitors on the Soviet Union. It also let the United States lead an effort to rescue Turkey from economic crisis, political instability and military decline. No doubt also contributed to last weeks resumption, after a twoyear break, of formal talks between Greek and Turkish Cypriots.

title: U.S., IN SHIFT, URGES REFINERS TO STEP UP OUTPUT OF GASOLINE
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  In an apparent shift of emphasis, the Administration urged the nation's oil refiners today to step up the production of gasoline and to tap existing stocks of gasoline more quickly than expected to help ease the immediate shortage.

title: FlexiVan Seeking To Acquire Seaboard
description: The struggle for control of Seaboard World Airlines took a new turn yesterday when the FlexiVan Corporation, which does a global business in cargocontainer leasing, announced it in- tended to buy the cargo airline for $18.25 a share.

title: Kennedy Joins President in Urging Overhaul of Regulatory Procedures
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  Senator Edward M. Kennedy joined President Carter today in calling for an overhaul of Federal regulatory procedures and unveiled legislation to complement and strengthen the Administration's efforts.

title: India Seeking to End Disunity in Third World Bloc
description: NEW DELHI, May 21  India is playing a key role in efforts to patch up the shattered unity of the socalled nonaligned group of nations, whose solidarity has been breached by differing views on conflicts in Asia, Africa and the Middle East.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: West German Government Bars Display of Some ProNazi Books
description: BONN, May 21 (AP)  A West German Government agency today banned from public display eight books and records on the ground that they glorified the Nazi regime. West German law bans the display of Nazi symbols.

title: An Aristocrat Who Believes in Noblesse Oblige
description: LONDON, May 21  Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary, was called upon to perform a peculiar duty last week during the ceremonial opening of Parliament. He stood at the right hand of Queen Elizabeth II as she read the speech from the throne, holding aloft a red velvet hat called the cap of maintenance.

title: Alcohol: The Fuel of the Future?
description: WITH gas lines in California and spot shortages and everhigher prices at pumps across the country, the gasoline shortage is generating some energy of its own  primarily in new research on gasohol, alcohol and other alternative fuels for the nation's 100 million automobiles.

title: Oliver Miles, ExOfficial At Goodyear, Dies at 72
description: Oliver E. Miles, a former executive vice president and member of the board of directors of Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, died Thursday at his retirement home in Litchfield Park, Ariz. He was 72 years old.

title: First Great Weakfish Contest Is a Big Hit
description: SLAUGHTER BEACH, Del., May 20  In the fall the deer come out to feed in the flat fields around here, and many are taken by hunters. Late in the year, when the wind comes hard off Delaware Bay, flattening the marsh grass, Canada geese frequently drop within shotgun range. Midspring is the time of the weakfish, or sea trout, as it is called here, and everywhere there are the signs of the bait sellers: Squid. Worms. No checks.

title: Court to Review Quotas for Contractors
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  In a case, that could become the next major challenge to a program designed to help blacks, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether it is legal or constitutional for Congress to set aside a fixed percentage of Government construction funds to be awarded to minorityowned construction companies.

title: News Summary
description: Reassurance on Rhodesian policy was given to Washington by London, which said in effect that the first major shift, if any, was up to President Carter. Lord Carrington, the Foreign Secretary, also told Secretary of State Vance that Britain's new Conservative Government would move slowly before making a decision to recognize Rhodesia or lift sanctions against Salisbury. [Page A1. Column 4.]

title: O.E.C.D. Warns on Oil; 2 Nations Ask Rationing
description: PARIS, May 21  Amid calls for global oil rationing, the United States and other industrial nations were warned today that the present world oil shortage might already have condemned them to a prolonged economic downturn, with rising unemployment and high inflation that would last until the middle of the next decade.

title: E.P.A. Reported Near an Accord With U.S. Steel
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  The United States Steel Corporation and the Environmental Protection Agency are on the verge of a landmark agreement that would require the company to clean up pollution from some of its older and dirtier plants, Government officials said today.

title: New Cabs Arrive to Do Battle With City Streets
Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Clerks Near Agreement With Atlantic City Track
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., May 21 Local 137, Sports Arena Employees, which represents New Jersey's racetrack parimutuel clerks, is expected to vote ratification tomorrow night on a year's contract with Atlantic City Race Course, which opens its meeting Thursday.

title: Iranian Criticism Softened
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 21  Foreign Minister Ibrahim Yazdi said today that, while the Senate resolution was a very obvious interference in Iranian affairs, the Iranian Government still hoped there would be friendly relations between the people of the two countries.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 21 (UPI)  For Affirmed it was just another workout, but for his trainer and jockey it was another chance to sing the praises of the 1978 Horse of the Year and Triple Crown winner.

title: Clothes From a Petticoat Past
description: It's a summer day in turn-of-the-century America. A couple in a newfangled motor car are facing the future. She's wearing a serviceable blue denim sailor dress, he's in a duster. They pass a more elaborately dressed family in a surrey, going in the opposite direction.

title: Paid Education Leave Is Sought In New Auto Workers Contract
description: DETROIT, May 21 (UPI)  The United Automobile Workers union wants a common European custom included in its contract package with the big three auto makers, paid education leave.

title: Senate Committee Gets Information on Abortion
description: ALBANY, May 21  The state's Department of Social Services tonight delivered the first round of information that state Senator John J. Marchi, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, had requested for an investigation he is conducting into the way the state administers the money it spends for abortions under Medicaid.

title: Rene Longy, Pianist, Music Theoretician, Bernstein's Teacher
description: Renee Longy, pianist and music theoretician whose teaching career spanned 65 years, died of cancer Sunday at the home of friends in Bronxville, N.Y. She was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Centralizing Education Is No Reform
description: Any day now, it will be up to the House to stop President Carter's proposal for a separate Department of Education. The measure squeaked through the House Government Operations Committee by a margin of one vote after the Senate had approved the measure by a big margin. But the idea remains as unwise as when it was first broached in a Carter campaign promise to the National Education Association.

title: Hyman Barshay, 77; Former Justice Served 30 Years on the Bench
description: Hyman Barsnay, a retired New York State Supreme Court justice, died of heart attack yesterday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 77 years old.

title: Canadiens Beat Rangers, 41, for 4th Stanley Cup in Row
description: MONTREAL, May 21  For the fourth straight year the Montreal Canadiens captured the Stanley Cup.

title: Leisure Dynamics On the Move Again
description: Avrett, Free & Fischer has become the agency for Leisure Dynamics of Waneapolis, which has Lakeside Games in that city and Cox Hobbies in Santa Ana, Calif. The agency says that billings are estimated to be in the $5 million range.

title: Money Rise Laid to Tax Payments
