description: WASHINGTON, May 21  The sharp rise in individual tax payments is creating problems for the nation's money managers and is largely responsible for an AprilMay bulge in the money supply, according to a number of private and Federal Reserve economists.

title: DieselCar Sales Picking Up Speed
description: DETROIT, May 21 (UPI) American motorists bought a record 22,552 diesel cars last month, or nearly three times as many as a year ago. And thousands of persons were turned away as waiting lists grew  up to a year for some cars.

title: 8.18% Yield On M.A.C. Issue Likely
description: The $125 million issue of Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds scheduled for sale this week is expected to yield 8.18 percent  the highest rate of return on new investmentgrade taxexempt bonds now on the market.

title: Fast Fiction for Hungry Readers
description: CANAAN, N.Y.  A hotel, a couple of restaurants, a scattering of dairy farms and 1,472 people are in this rustic hamlet set hard by the foothills of the Berkshires. There is also a man responsible for 300 million books.

title: Zack, 11 Others, Advance In U.S. Open Qualifying
description: SUMMIT, N.J., May 21  Mike Zack, a touring pro from Union, N.J., fired a 72, 70142 at the Canoe Brook Country Club today and led 11 pros and one amateur into the United States Open regional qualifying round. The 12 New Jersey golfers will travel to the Stanwich Club in Greenwich, Conn., for the regional qualifying on June 5. The Open is scheduled June 1417 at Inverness in Toledo. Ohio.

title: 5 CONGRESSMEN JOIN TO DUMP PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  Five Democratic Congressmen are organizing a campaign to dump President Carter from the Democratic ticket next year and draft Senator Edward M. Kennedy as his replacement.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, May 21 (UPI)  A Federal grand jury investigating the banking activities of Bert Lance, the former budget director, reconvened today for what is expected to be the final week of hearings in the controversy that drove him from President Carter's Cabinet.

title: Study Alters View Of Gene Structure
description: THE structure of animal genes, including those of humans, is far different from what had been believed for at least 20 years, new discoveries have revealed. Furthermore, scientists have found previously unimagined complexities in the way the code messages of the genes are translated and processed by living cells.

title: U.S. Aides Preserve Shaky Truce Among Chippewas in Minnesota
description: RED LAKE, Minn., May 21  The fragile truce that has maintained an uneasy calm at the Chippewa Indian Reservation here since last night threatened to come apart today, but some fast behindthescenes conciliation efforts by Federal officials appeared by late afternoon to have glued it back together.

title: Science Watch
description: Persons with obstructive lung diseases that often leave them frighteningly short of breath can learn improved breathing patterns through computerized biofeedback training, a Boston University nurse reported last week.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: DAVID I. SHAPIRO

title: TV: The Helen Reddy Special
description: NOW that it is finally going to be shown, from 10 to 11 o'clock tonight on ABCTV The Helen Reddy Special turns out to have at least as much to do with salesmanship as it does with entertainment.

title: Taxes
description: TAXES  who should pay them and how much have rarely been the object of so much heated debate as they are today. In the United States, efforts to lower property and capital gains taxes are at the center of the political stage and in Britain a new conservative Government owes its election in part to the widespread desire to lower levies on individual income and wealth.

title: St. John's Nine Sets Back Seton Hall in Final, 30
description: Chris Rich scattered three hits and ran his undefeated streak to six in pitching St. John's University to a 30 victory over Sewn Hall in the championship game of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's New YorkNew Jersey playoffs yesterday afternoon at the Redman's field in Jamaica, Queens.

title: A Guilty Plea In Land Fraud
description: Arnold Aronoff, 47 years old. former vice president of the Edward C Levy Company, Detroit. pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to charges that he used the mail to defraud Penn Dixie industries of more than $3 million in a Florida land swindle.

title: Jazz: Mary Lou Williams
description: A JAZZ legend that is in a constant process of selfrenewal, Mary Lou Williams, the pianist, and a jazz legend that has been going through some difficult throes of renewal, the Duke Ellington orchestra, shared a concert late Sunday afternoon in the Main Gallery of the Library & Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center as part of the fiveweek Black Theater Festival U.S.A.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Texas Demands That Preacher Shut Girlss Home Linked to Abuse
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex.,  After a sixyear battle with Brother Lester Roloff over the way the popular radio preacher runs his home for wayward girls, a battle that has become deeply intertwined with the state's tangled politics, Texas has filed court papers demanding that the home be closed.

title: Canadians Vote Today, With Cliffhanger Likely
description: OTTAWA, May 21 (Reuters)  Canadians vote tomorrow in general elections that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, his grip on power shaky after 11 years in office, says could make or break national unity in the face of Quebec's push for independence.

title: N.R.C. Reactor Licensing Will Be Delayed 3 Months
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  Nuclear Regulatory Commission officials said today that there would be a delay of at least three months in issuing licenses and permits for new nuclear power plants until safety lessons learned in the March 28 accident at Three Mile Island could be incorporated into the new reactors.

title: Guidry Bows, 31, To Tigers
description: DETROIT, May 21  With utter disregard for his imposing credentials, the Detroit Tigers battered Ron Guidry and the Yankees into submission, 31, under a 13hit barrage tonight before 26.153 chilled fans.

title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices Rule Age Bias Cases Must First Go to States
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  The Supreme Court ruled today that a worker who believes he has been discriminated against because of his age cannot sue his employer in Federal court unless he has first brought his complaint to the appropriate state agency.

title: Victor Denny, 77, Former Leader Of U.S.T.A. and Seattle Financier
description: BELLEVUE, Wash., May 21 (UPI) Victor Denny. former president of the United States Tennis Association and a descendant of one of Seattle's first families, died yesterday at his home here. He was 77 years old.

title: City Council Questions Koch Aide Sharply Over 1980 Budget Figures
description: Why does the Koch administration expect to collect less in parking fines in the next fiscal year than this year?

title: Players and Fans Try to Charm Cup Triumph From Lady Luck
description: MONTREAL, May 21  Desperate times call for desperate measures. A hockey puck, traveling over a frozen surface at 100 miles an hour, can turn a champagne celebration into a sad summer by a change in its direction of fraction of a inch.

title: Socialist Party Split in Spain Threatens to Disrupt Nation's Politics
description: MADRID, May 21  A dangerous breach has opened in Spain's second largest party, the Spanish Socialist Workers Party, that could have an important impact on all the political parties, which are continuing to evolve three and a half years after the death of Francisco Franco.

title: Holiday Inns Plans Growth in Europe
description: More than $200 million will be spent by Holiday Inns Inc. to develop and refurbish hotels in Britain and in Continental Europe, the company announced at a London news conference.

title: $3 Million Logicon Orders
description: Logicon Inc. announced yesterday that it had received orders totaling $3 million to provide newspaper textprocessing systems for The Washington Star and the Easton Publishing Company, publisher of The Easton (Pa.) Express.

title: Soviet Letting Jews Emigrate, but Not Many Others Who Want to Leave
description: MOSCOW, May 21  Although emigration by Jews has risen sharply in recent months, sharply enough for the Carter Administration to consider granting trade benefits to Moscow, the situation for other Soviet ethnic and religious groups, including ethnic Russians, shows no sign of easing.

title: Truckers Strike Getty In New York and LI; Gasoline Is Promised
description: Fiftyfive truck drivers who deliver gasoline and diesel fuel to service stations and wholesalers in New York City and on Long Island struck the Getty Refining and Marketing Company yesterday after contract talks broke down.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Carter Administration urged oil refiners to raise gasoline production and to tap existing stocks of gasoline more quickly than expected to help ease the immediate shortage. The move represented an apparent shift in strategy for the Administration. Until recently, top priority had been given to rebuilding depleted stocks of heating oil by early fall, even at the expense of inconveniencing motorists this summer. Meanwhile, the White House said the gasoline supply situation would be better if Congress had passed the Administration's energy proposals sent up in 1977. [Page A1]

title: Egyptians Reject the Israeli View That El Arish Will Face Hardship
description: CAIRO, May 21  Egyptian officials today rejected Israeli contentions that the Arabs in El Arish will face hardships when the Sinai town is returned to Egyptian control Friday.

title: Market Place
description: IF you own New York City Housing Authority bonds and plan to sell, you may wish to delay the decision.

title: NEW BRITISH ENVOY TO U.S. IS APPOINTED
description: LONDON, Tuesday, May 22  Sir Nicholas Henderson, a recently retired career diplomat, was named late last night as Britain's new Ambassador to the United States.

title: William M. DuChessi; Led the Textile Union In Legislative Actions
description: William M. DuChessi, executive vice president of the 510,000member Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, died in Washington. D.C., Saturday after a long illness. He was 64 years old and a resident of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Missing Texas Senators Still Eluding Police Hunt
description: AUSTIN, Texas, May 21 (UPI) There were indications tonight that the 12 Texas state senators who have been in hiding for four days were winning their fight to block a presidential primary bill that they say would favor former Governor John Connally, who is a contender for the Republican nomination.

title: U.S. Backs One Of Ironton Bids
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  The antitrust division of the Justice Department announced today its opposition to bids by the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad and the Norfolk & Western Railway to purchase the small but valuable Detroit, Toledo and Ironton Railroad.

title: Falcons Again Top China In Women's Softball, 82
description: TOKYO. May 21 (AP)  The Connecticut Falcons women's softball team beat the Tianjin team, 82, in Peking today for its third straight victory in its current China tour, the New China News Agency reported.

title: Travels With Lord Stanley
description: MONTREAL, May 21  During the day Maurice (Lefty) Reid, the curator of the Hockey Hall of Fame, drove over from Toronto in his station wagon with a very important passenger  Lord Stanley, as Lefty always identifies his companion. But this Lord Stanley is a trophy, not a person. And the trophy, of course, is the Stanley Cup, the huge silver chalice that was locked in its wooden crate in a guarded room not far from the ice at the Forum tonight. The Montreal Canadiens needed a victory over the New York Rangers to win the cup for the fourth consecutive year, for the fifth time in the last seven years, for the eighth time in the last 12 years, for the 16th time in the last 27 years and for a record 22d time in this National Hockey League club's glorious history. But the wooden crate with

title: Translator Adds Speech
description: Texas Instruments Inc. has developed a handheld language translator that not only displays foreign vocabulary words, but also uses electronic speech synthesis to pronounce them, industry sources have disclosed.

title: About New York
description: Frank Davis had been stabbed in the heart last winter outside the Cafe de la Paix. So it was a pleasure to buy him a beer at one of the cafe's sidewalk tables on a grand spring afternoon last week.

title: Entertainment Events
description: PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA, Carnegie Hall. 8.

title: Books of The Times
description: IT is, perhaps, a measure of John B. Connally that he could, in the 1960's, call Billy Graham the conscience of America, while at the same time reviling the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. If Mr. Graham was indeed our conscience, we had some moral blind spots. According to

title: G.O.P. Accused of McCarthyism at Hongisto Hearing
description: ALBANY, May 21  A Senate committee hearing that focused on Richard D. Hongisto's brief and controversial tenure as Cleveland's Chief of Police dissolved into partisan wrangling this morning. The committee is looking into Mr. Hongisto's nomination as Correction Commissioner.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: CARTER WEIGHS CUTS IN EMBASSY STAFFS
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  President Carter said today that he had directed study of United States embassy staffing, with a view to reductions in personnel based upon the recommendations of two retiring Ambassadors.

title: StockCar Driver, 33, Dies Of Injuries in April Race
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., May 21 (AP) Larry Brandon, a racecar driver, died today of injuries received in a racing accident on April 21. Brandon's stock car was one of four that collided during the Western World Championships at Manzanita Speedway.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHEKHOV WITH PALMS It's not often you can see a Caribbean version of Chekhov's play The Marriage Proposal, but that's today's presentation in the Sweet 14 festival of music, dance and theater held on Mondays and Wednesdays at the north end of Union Square Park, above East 14th Street. The new adaptation of the Chekhov comedy is being performed by the young theater troupe, the Family, and the starting time moves up to noon from the series's regularly scheduled hour of 12:30 P.M.

title: Legislator Questions the Legality Of Giving CETA Funds to a Lifer
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)  A legislator is questioning the legality of paying $10,540 a year in Federal job training funds to a prison inmate serving a life term for murder and armed robbery.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am a beginner in the kitchen with a basic problem: I recently made a white sauce or cream sauce that was too thin. I simply added too much liquid for the amount of butter and flour used. I tried to cook it down but it wouldn't get thicker. Why not?

title: EARNINGS
description: R.H. Macy & Company reported 47.2 percent jump in profits yesterday for its third fiscal quarter on a 12.2 percent sales gain. Directors responded with an increase in the quarterly dividend to 46 cents from 41 cents. It is payable July 2 on 10.3 million outstanding shares to holders of record June 8.

title: Letter: On Presidential Tenure
description: To the Editor:

title: 6 Accused of Conspiring to Smuggle Birds Into U.S.
description: SYRACUSE, May 22  The director of the Oklahoma City Zoo, a New Jersey canary breeder and four other persons have been charged by Federal officials here with complicity in an international conspiracy to smuggle exotic birds into the United States.

title: Rangers Keep Up Spirits
description: I can't believe it's over.

title: Dow Rises 2.94 in Expanded Trading
description: The stock market registered a moderate advance yesterday in accelerated trading. One of the bigger declinem was a highflying gambling issue, Caesars World, in response to an adverse news development.

title: Islip Is Expected to Adopt Ordinance Banning Fire Island Nudity
description: KISMET, Fire Island, May 22 Long a bastion of liberalism and anythinggoes, Fire Island is about to lose one of its freedoms: nude sun bathing. Not to mention nude swimming, nude Frisbeeing and the practice, at certain beaches, of doing just about everything in the buff that people elsewhere do with their clothes on.

title: Advertising
description: AMERICA'S magazine publishers, no strangers to crisis situations, are facing still another one, really big one. The already tight paper situation is on the verge of getting terrible.

title: Sohio Head Still Says No Pipeline
description: CLEVELAND, May 21  The chairman of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said today that he saw no reason to change his company's decision not to build a CaliforniatoTexas pipeline to carry surplus Alaskan oil, a decision he said he planned to make final within about a month.

title: `Gasoline Alley Fans Told Alley Lacks Gas
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (UPI) Race fans headed for Gasoline Alley at Indianapolis were advised today to make their pit stops for fuel before they get close to the site of the Memorial Day weekend racing classic.

title: Dane's Are Warned on Gasoline
description: COPENHAGEN, May 22 (AP)  The people of Denmark have been warned that they are not being frugal enough with gasoline and will have to be stricter if they want to avoid a grave energy shortage. Prime Minister Anker Joergensen has said that consumption must be cut as much as 15 percent in the next few years to keep pace with a diminishing supply.

title: City Ferryboat Crews Are Put Aboard Tugs To Transport Garbage
description: The city succeeded yesterday in getting crews aboard three chartered tugs that it hoped to begin using in the next day or two to move garbage from Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx to a Staten Island landfill.

title: Witness Against Talmadge
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Daniel Minchew always wanted to be in the limelight in Washington. This week he made it.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: NEVER mind ships and shoes and sealing wax, and cabbages and kings, the time has come to speak of vacations or, more accurately, the days leading up to vacations. Almost no one takes off for a week or two or four on the spur of the moment. At least not in my circle. The time away is planned and replanned and scheduled and blocked off, and it would seem as though any situations requiring action would be well in hand when the date on the calendar finally coincided with the departure date.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, MAY 22, 1979

title: Bombs Believed Planted by I.R.A. Destroy Ulster Real Estate Office
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 22 (UPI)  Four firebombs exploded in the offices of one of Belfast's biggest real estate agents today, starting a fire that destroyed the building.

title: Folk: Odetta Opens Series at Atrium
description: THE Atrium of the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue at 53d Street, which has been the setting during the last year for three concert series devoted to American songwriters, collegiate singing groups and street musicians as well as other musical categories, began a sixweek series devoted to folk music on Monday evening with Odetta, the singer and guitarist, as the initial performer.

title: 3 Guilty of Racketeering in Westchester Theater Case
description: Eliot H. Weisman, the 41yearold former president of the bankrupt Westchester Premier Theater in Tarrytown, N.Y., was convicted with two other men in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday of racketeering, stock and bankruptcy fraud and obstructing justice.

title: City's Sunshine Brings New Yorkers Outdoors
Opting for Charcoal
description: Every year, at the beginning of the barbecue season, the question arises as to which is preferable charcoal, charcoal briquettes, gasfired stones, such as lava stones, or electric grills.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: An unintended achievement of the Iranian revolution is that finally minute attention is being given to infractions of human rights in Iran. Other thirdworld countries, especially those favored by the United States Government and corporations, escape such attention.

title: Juvenile Justice Agency Approved
description: The City Council voted yesterday to create a Department of Juvenile Justice. The work of the new agency, sought by Mayor Koch to consolidate programs for young people accused of crimes, is now handled by several city agencies.

title: Sadowsky Seeks $203 Million Cut In Revenues From Koch's Budget
description: The City Council's Finance Committee will try to reduce Mayor Koch's 1980 budget by $203 million in oneshot revenues that may never materialize, the committee's chairman said yesterday.

title: Small AWar Is Called Survivable
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  A new Congressional study says that while a largescale nuclear war would be a catastrophe for the United States and the Soviet Union the two nations could probably recover from a limited nuclear conflict in which each side sought to destroy the other's military forces.

title: Music Hall Rehearsing for Rebirth in June
description: ROBERT F. JANI, producer and chief executive officer of Radio City Music Hall productions, sat in his aerie up against the ceiling of the Music Hall. looking down toward the rehearsal on the immense stage with its 100foot Wide proscenium. Mr. Jani, surrounded by script notes, two phones, a microphone and a wicker basket full of appointment reminders, was leaning out into space, calling to his production Manager, Jay Moore.

title: CasaIs Festival Canceled Over Dispute
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., May 22  Puerto Rico's most famous cultural asttraction, the Casals Festival, has been canceled this year as a result of a dispute between the organizers and local musicians.

title: COAST GAS SCARCITY HURTS LEISURE SPOTS
description: LOS ANGELES, May 22  California's popular amusement and tourism spots, early victims of tight gasoline supplies, are trying to hold onto business by luring the onetank travelers  people who live within close proximity.

title: Bridge:
description: Before the start of an event it often happens that directors or officials area looking for a few more players, either to produce a convenient number or simply to enlarge the participation. Everybody knows that such lastminute, haphazard entries have no chance to win, but everybody is sometimes wrong.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ROME, May 22 (AP)  Unheralded Dominique Bedel of France, ranked only No. 211 in the world, toppled sixthseeded Brian Gottfried of the United States, 62, 64, in the first round of the $200,000 Italian open tennis championships today. Illie Nastase of Rumania and Raul Ramirez of Mexico also lost.

title: Letters
description: To THE LIVING SECTION:

title: CARTER BIDS TO LIFT BANKINTEREST CURB
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  President Carter today endorsed fundamental changes in the rules governing the nation's financial institutions by asking Congress to phase out interestrate ceilings on all consumer deposits.

title: Bonn, at 30, Strives to Stay Fit
description: BONN, May 22  The Federal Republic of Germany will be 30 years old tomorrow. Like some people of that age, the West German economy is slowing down, showing signs of fat around its waistline and finding it something of a strain to get back in shape.

title: Entertainment Events
description: PETER ALLEN  UP IN ONE, conceived by Peter Allen and Craig Zadan; directed by Mr. Zadan, Biltmore Theater, 261 West 47th Street, 6:30.

title: San Francisco Tense as Violence Follows Murder Trial
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 22  Mayor Dianne Feinstein invoked a mutual aid pact and put policemen from San Francisco and neighboring towns on alert tonight in case of more violence by residents protesting the manslaughter verdict in the slayings last November of Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk.

title: Panic Before a Dinner Party: All the Men Sent Regrets
description: MAYBE it happens to everyone, but never before had it happened to me. A week earlier I had mailed out 18 dinner invitations. Now, on the day of the fateful night, yet another person had telephoned, to cancel his previous acceptance. He had sprained his thigh playing softball.

title: EVIDENCE RULE HELD TO HAVE LOW IMPACT
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  The widespread impressien that guilty defendants frequently go Afree because of the exclusionary rule, which bars the admission of illegally seized evidence at the trial, has been rebutted by a study of the impact the rule has on Federal criminal procedures.

title: `Killer Bees Follow Texas Tradition of Legislative Antics
description: To those unfamiliar with the Texas Legislature, the fact that 12 Senators were on the lam from the Texas Rangers in recent days may seem a trifle peculiar. But the escapades of the Killer Bees are easily Understood in the context of what may be the most remar1able legislative body in the coun

title: Whistle Heralds. CriminalJustice Drive
description: That staid and often aloof institution, the City Bar Association, has gone Madison Avenue with a campaign to blow the whistle on crime:

title: Ornate Cakes
description: THE cakes are so ornate  with their clusters of icing bouquets and their swirls of shaded pastel  and the workmanship so subtle that the ordinary decorated cakes sold in bakeries look barren by comparison.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Daniel P. Davison, one of the brightest stars at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, has left that bluechip bank to become president and chief operating officer of the United States Trust Company of New York. He succeeds Tom Killefer, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the bank, one of the nation's largest trust and investment managers, with $11.5 million in assets under supervision.

title: Deaths
description: ANDERSONDavid John, 61 of Lawrenceville. NJ. on May 21, 1979. son of the late Richard T. and Madeline L Anderson. brother of Mrs Robert C. Brady, Greenwich, CT. Funeral Services will be held Thurs. May 24. at 10:30AM in the MArgrand Transept of the Princeton University Chapel. Princeton, NJ. Interment Princeton Cemetery. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the School of Architecture at the Princeton University.

title: Wine Talk
description: WHAT with skyrocketing prices and some wellpublicized new wine fraud charges, the news from Burgundy has not been good recently for American wine enthusiasts. This week, however, there are a couple of mildly heartening items. The first is the arrival of the 1978 Beaujolais. The second is the report of the Bordeaux wine shipper, Peter A. Sichel, on the Burgundy market.

title: Light Industry Backed in China
description: TOKYO, May 22 (AP)  Du Ziduan, Deputy Minister of Light Industry, has urged priority steps to increase the output of sewing machines, bicycles, wines and liquor, the New China News Agency reported today. The agency said the minister had stressed that development of light industry would expand employment and foreign trade.

title: Belmont Bettors Get Free Ride (for Day)
description: Horseplayers clustered in front of closedcircuit television screens at Belmont. Park yesterday began shouting when the No. 7 horse in the first race sprinted away to a big early lead.

title: Panel in Senate Rejects Bid to Break up Action
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (UPI)  The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee today voted, 9 to 1, against breaking up Action, the umbrella Federal agency for domestic volunteer programs for the poor and for the Peace Corns.

title: Cruyff Gets Aztec Pact In N.A.S.L.
description: Johan Cruyff, the brilliant striker from the Netherlands, signed a multiyear contract last night with the Los Angeles Aztecs of the North American Soccer League.

title: Joseph Ratner, 78, Dies; Philosopher and Author
description: Joseph Ratner, a philosopher, writer and teacher, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in New York City. He was 78 years old.

title: Bench Duty Painful To an Eager Doyle
description: DETROIT, May 22  Brian Doyle, a World Series hero at age 23 and a utility infielder at 24, knows that time is on his side. But he's impatient. He sits quietly on the Yankee bench yearning to play, knowing that he will be around after most of the New York superstars on the field now have opened a bar in Hackensack or joined some Wall Street brokerage house.

title: Beckenbauer Faces Surgery; Out 10 Weeks
description: Franz Beckenbauer of the Cosmos will be operated on by Dr. James Nicholas today at Lenox Hill Hospital for removal of the medial cartilage of his right knee.

title: 19 Food Concerns Cited Under City Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health released the names of 19 food establishments Monday that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also named five restaurants that had corrected earlier violations and two that had been closed for failing to do so.

title: World News Briefs
description: THE HAGUE, May 22 (AP)  Peter Menten, a millionaire art dealer accused of murdering 20 to 30 Jews in Nazioccupied Poland in 1941, must stand trial a second time, the Dutch Supreme Court ruled today.TOKYO, May 22  Japan has sent construction team to build a heliport on the disputed Senkaku islands, situated halfway between Okinawa and Taiwan

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: MY FAVORITE New York story happened to me on a business trip to Rochester, New York, writes Eileen Coester Giuliani. I arrived at my hotel about 6 o'clock in the evening after a busy day, most of which was spent indoors. in cars and in airplanes.

title: 14 Are Killed in Salvador Protest
description: SAN SALVADOR, May 22 (AP)  The police opened fire on leftist demonstrators here tonight, killing at least 14 people and wounding an undetermined number of others.

title: New Bond Issues
description: TUESDAY, MAY 22, 1979

title: Books of The Times
description: WHEN the gods clash, the earth shakes; and few bystanders on the literary scene of the 1960's failed to feel the tremors when Edmund Wilson and Vladimir Nabokov collided in the pages of The New York Review of Books and Encounter magazine over

title: Col. Alhur Simons; Led an Abortive Raid On Vietnamese Camp
description: Col. Arthur D. Simon!, the Green Beret commander who led an abortive raid on a prisoner of war camp deep in North Vietman in 1970 and helped free two American engineers imprisoned in Iran earlier this year, died Monday at Baylor Medical Center in Dallas.

title: Stride Rite Faces Suit in Uniroyal Bid
description: BOSTON, May 22 (AP)  The Stride Rite Corporation faces a potential court fight in its efforts to acquire Uniroyal Inc.'s footwear business.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Generalizations are dangerous, but the taking of several 8to10pound bluefish from the surf at Wasque Point off Martha's Vineyard Island, Mass., six days ago may presage another remarkably productive year of angling for the species along the East Coast.

title: Toyota Exports
description: TOKYO, May 22 (AP)  The Toyota Motor Company has exported 10 million vehicles since July 1936. officials said today. Toyota's exports reached one million in 1969 and five million in May 1975, they said.

title: Albany Accord on DrugLaw Changes
description: ALBANY, May 22  Formal agreement was reached today on legislation to alter the socalled Rockefeller Drug Law. The accord, reached by key members of both houses of the Legislature; would soften sentences for first offenders and stiffen them for subsequent offenders.

title: News Summary
description: The Canadian people, divided along linguistic and regional lines, gave the Progressive Conservative Party a substantial lead in the House of Commons. But the conservatives fell five seats short of a majority. Prime Minister Pierre Eiliott Trudeau said he would ask the Governor General to ask Joe Clark, the conservative leader, to form a government, The Conservatives appeared to have won 135 seats to 114 for the Liberals. [Page A1, Columns 46.]

title: Georges Garin, 66, a Famed Chef Who Pioneered Nouvelle Cuisine
description: PARIS, May 22  Georges Garin, one of France's foremost cooks and a pioneer of the socalled nouvelle cuisine, died in Toulon last week, it was learned here today. He was 66 years old.

title: Roger Bower, 75 Dead; Broadcaster, NBC Aide
description: Roger Bower, a pioneer in international broadcasting, died last Thursday in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 75 yearS old and lived in Lakeville, Conn.

title: East German Escapes on a Raft
description: RONNE, Denmark, May 22 (AP) defector from East Germany has reached this Danish island in the Baltic after four days aboard a small rubber raft, the police reported today. The 22yearold man was not identified to avert possible retaliation against relatives.

title: Philip Johnson Awarded $100,000 Pritzker Prize
description: Philip Johnson, the 72yearold architect whose recent skyscraper designs for New York. Pittsburgh and other cities have been among the most controversial new buildings of the decade, has won the first Pritzker Architecture Prize, a new $100,000 award established by the Hyatt Foundation.

title: Franklin Beats Horse, Fined
description: Ronnie Franklin, the 19yearold jockey who rode Spectacular Bid victories in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, was fined $100 yesterday at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore for whipping a horse he rode Monday on the head and kicking him in the stomach following a rough ride.

title: Citicorp Note Rate Down
description: The average rate on Citicorp's 91day notes declined slightly yesterday to an, average of 10.208 percent from 10.211 percent last week, the bankholding company reported. Accepted bids ranged from 10.180 percent to 10.220 percent, and Citicorp said 80 percent of the bids at the high rate were accepted. A total of $786.25 million in bids was submitted. An additional $100 million of Citicorp paper will be auctioned next Tuesday, but the notes will mature in 90 days, not 91 days.

title: Economic Scene
description: FOR the financial markets the good news, to rewrite Herbert Hoover, is that recession is just around the corner. The markets are counting on recession to bring lower interest rates and a lower rate of inflation. Consumers, having tried to keep borrowing and buying ahead of soaring prices, are starting to give up. The spring rebound at retail counters has been disappointing.

title: Money
description: TUESDAY, MAY 22, 1979

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: George G. Bashian, 73, Is Dead; An Importer of Rugs From Orient
description: George G. Bashian, an importer of Oriental rugs, died Monday at his home in Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Lee Huebner Is Named Publisher Of International Herald Tribune
description: The International Herald Tribune has changed publishers, with the appointment of Lee W. Huebner, who is replacing Robert R. Eckert.

title: Plowing Farmers Under
description: DETROIT  Mechanization was coming like fire, the eminent farm and land historian, Paul S. Taylor, wrote in 1942  highpowered. tractors, corn pickers, pickup hay balers, assemblyline layouts of buildings and feed barns.

title: Despite Wine Lobbying, Man Must Live by Bread Alone in FoOd Stores
description: ALBANY, May 22  A loaf of bread, a jug of wine  should thou find them beside each other in a supermarket?

title: New Peas Unlike Peas in a Pod
description: As a rule, we are far more likely to praise our Escoffiers than our Luther Burbanks, but one plant breeder who has earned nationwide attention is Dr. Calvin Lamborn, research director for the Gallatin Valley Seed Company in Twin Falls, Idaho, and father of the brandnew sugar snap pea.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Gigue for Harpsichord in D minor, Rutini; Sonata for Flute in G, Handel; Concerto for Strings and Continuo No. 7, Albinoni; Etude in C minor, Chopin; The Ruins' of Athens: Turkish March, Beethoven; Sonata for Flute and Guitar in F, Marcello.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: House Democrats disagreed with President Carter's decision to remove price controls from crude oil produced in the United States  the centerpiece of his latest energy program. The Democratic Party caucus voted 153 to 82 to reject the decontrol plan, but the vote did not bind party members to support legislation retaining price controls when it reaches the House floor. [Page A1.]

title: Word Guild Opens Hub For Editorial Freelances
description: There will be an allday event tomorrow at B. Dalton, 666 Fifth Avenue, to celebrate the opening of the New York branch of the Word Guild, a group better known in the trade than outside. This is the organization of freelancers who are not only writers, but also copy editors, copy writers, proofreaders, layout people, graphic artists and the like.

title: Campaiign Scenes, Wisecracks and a Dog
description: TORONTO, May 22  Item: In the early days of the Canadian election campaign that ended today, the candidate spoke into an auditorium microphone, and found it dead. What the hell! he shouted, You can't even make the mikes work here.

title: Durables Orders Slid 8.7% in April
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Orders for durable goods took their steepest plunge in 11 years last month, down 8.7 percent from March, giving the strongest evidence to date that an economic slowdown may have begun.

title: Advice to Girls, Then and Now
description: THE faded little book caught her eye one day in the biology classroom, where it was wedged among others on a shelf. Curious, she started leafing through it. Soon she and her fellow 14yearolds were hooting with laughter. First published in 1959, it was called On Becoming a Woman, and to them it read like a relic of another civilization.

title: Food and the Working Wife
description: The urban working woman is not only bolstering the budget of the American family but is also doing much to upset that family's traditional foodbuying and eating habits. That was the finding of a recent nationwide survey that reported that the working woman's family was likely to eat beef more often, drink beer and wine with dinner, shop for food less frequently and spend less time preparing meals than families in which the woman is not employed.

title: Leningrad's Young People Mob Elton John
description: LENINGRAD, May 22  The first concert in the Soviet Union by the British rock star Elton John erupted into a frenzy last night, with nearly 4,000 Russian fans dancing on their seats and in the aisles.

title: The City
description: A petition asking that lowincome or lowusage customers of electricity be exempted from summer surcharges by the Consolidated Edison Company has been filed with the State Public Service Commission by Bruce C. Ratner, the City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs.

title: Best Buys
description: MORE variety in meat cuts and sizes, new packaging methods for both poultry and fish and a definite trend toward boneless cuts of beef and pork will be changing the look of supermarket meat counters in the coming years. Consumers in search of flavorful beef bones for stocks or the family dog will indeed be left out, although those looking for greater selection, convenience and longer shelf life will soon have it their way.

title: Private Lives
description: HE is somewhere between Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, on Memorial Drive, in a place called the Regency Hyatt, surrounded by dentists hundreds of dentists, who drill him with their eyes, who wear Audiacs in their shoulder holsters. His room isn't ready, and neither is he. The difference between him and his room is that his room will be ready in three hours. He is not so sure about himself. He is having reentry problems.

title: Ullman Says He Favors Cutback In Social Security Tax Increases
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Representative Al Ullman, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that he favored scaling back the big increase in Social Security taxes that is scheduled to take effect in 1981 unless Congress changed the current law.

title: 42 NUCLEAR PAPERS ARE CITED BY A.C.L.U.
description: The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday publicly identified 42 documents relating to nuclear weapons that are available to the public at the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M.

title: Squatter Bees Get the Brush From Upper West Side Home
description: At first, there were only a few bees. But by late afternoon yesterday thousands had nested in the pedestrian signal light at 88th Street and West End Avenue. James Groome, a beekeeper, arrived wearing a black suit, elbowlength gauntlets and a pith helmet with protective netting. As neighborhood people watched, Mr. Groome climbed a ladder, swept the bees into a cardboard box, placed the box in the trunk of his Cadillac and drove off.

title: TV Official Backs U.S. Controls
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  A Mississippi television broadcaster asked House subcommittee today to maintain regulatory control over his industry, a position sharply opposed by most other broadcast executives.

title: Mets Top Cubs, 42, On 6Hitter
description: The team that Casey Stengel used to call my amazing Mets hasn't been amazing for a long time.

title: Chess:
description: The ultimate test of a strategist is the positional pawn sacrifice. To give up something tangible, in this case a pawn, requires complete confidence in one's grasp of the intangible factors of piece mobility and pawn structure.

title: Koosman Loses First
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 22 (UPI) A homer by Buddy Bell in the eighth for his third run batted in of the game carried the Texas Rangers to a 43 victory over Minnesota tonight, sending the Twins' pitcher, Jerry Koosman, to his first loss after seven victories.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Silver futures prices closed up the daily permissible limit of 20 cents an ounce again yesterday on the Comex in New York, except for the expiring spot May delivery, which advanced 16 cents.

title: Britain Says Its Aim in Rhodesia Is Regime the World Can Accept
description: LONDON, May 22  The British Government said today that its goal was legal independence for Rhodesia, with the widest possible international recognition. But at the same time, London confirmed that it was sending a senior diplomat to Rhodesia to maintain close contact with the new Government there, although it is regarded by many countries as illegally elected.

title: Steel Officials Foresee Shortage in Mid1980's
description: A world steel shortage beginning in the mid1980's, portending sharply higher prices for steel, was predicted here yesterday by steel executives attending the annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute, a trade group.

title: Dr. Benjamin P. Sandler, Nutritionist, 77, Is Dead
description: Dr. Benjamin P. Sandler, who specialized in preventive nutrition, died Friday in Asheville, N.C., after a long illness. He was 77 years old and a resident of Asheville.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Brown & Williamson Industries, a diversified company, has appointed Charles R. Hinckle, Leonard Katz, A.C. MacLennan, Emil Moos, Joel H. Newman and Angelo Rosato as vice presidents of the BWI Retail Group.

title: Yanks Halt Rally, Down Tigers, 128
description: DETROIT, May 22  When Luis Tiant is good, he is very, very good.

title: Utility Regulation Said to Risk Credit
description: HARRISBURG. Pa., May 22 (UPI)  Two New York city bankers told Pennsylvania's Public Utility Commission today that the regulatory risk represented by the commission makes banks unwilling to lend utilities associated with Three Mile. Island the funds they need. Stewart B. Clifford, senior vice president of Citibank and one of two top fiscal advisers to the troubled General Public Utilities Corporation, said the commission held the key to the fate of the Metropolitan Edison Company and the Pennsylvania Electric Company.

title: 20 Nations Vow to Use More Coal
description: PARIS, May 22  Major industrial nations pledged themselves today to burn more coal as they pursue what appears to be an increasingly desperate search for ways to curb their heavy dependence on oil.

title: A Teheran Ayatollah Insists He Is Head of Courts
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 22  Ayatollah Sadegh Khalkhali asserted again today, in the face of contradictory remarks, that. he was a leading authority of the Islamic revolutionary courts in Iran, and he reiterated a call that someone should assassinate the deposed Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: Swami in Switzerland Sentenced to 14 Years
description: GENEVA, May 22  The Divine Light of Swami Omkarananda, as the sect leader terms his power, failed him today and a Swiss court sentenced the 49year old Indian to 14 years in prison on charges ranging from breach of the peace to attempted murder.

title: Wife of Morales Sought by Police For Questioning
description: The wife of William Morales, the Puerto Rican terrorist who escaped from a prison ward at Bellevue Hospital Monday, has apparently disappeared from her East Harlem home. She is being sought along with her husband, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Look who's back. Now that Hollywood is planning to refilm Little Miss Marker, there just might be a revival of Shirley Temple's curly hairdo. And not on tapdancing moppets, either. JeanLouis David, the French hair stylist whose New York branch is at Bendel's, is doing sausage curls for big girls. Shirley's dimples aren't required, but a sense of humor is, plus a knack for winding up the curls in rags and infinite patience to brush them carefully around a finger.

title: Companies List Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American E xchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Senate Votes to Make $50 Million for Turkey a Grant
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  The Senate sustained President Carter and decisively overrode its own Foreign Relations Committee today in approving a grant rather than a loan of $50 million to Turkey for arms and military equipment.

title: HighYield Florida Bonds Sold
description: Florida sold $125 million of highgrade taxexempt bonds yesterday that carried the highest yields for such securities in the current upswing in interest rates, and investors, reacting to more signs of a slowdown in the economy, moved swiftly to buy them.

title: Man Indicted in '78 Blaze That Killed Six Firemen
description: A 22yearold man serving a sentence for burglary was indicted yesterday on charges that he set fire last summer to a Brooklyn supermarket in which six firemen died. They fell to their deaths as a blazing roof collapsed while some of their relatives watched in horror.

title: PANEL TO REGULATE NUCLEAR SHIPMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today adopted a new regulation to curb transportation of spent but still, radioactive fuel through densely populated urban areas and to require precautions against hijackings or sabotage.

title: Flamboyant, Vulnerable Star Was in Eclipse Last 2 Years
description: The irony of Elton John's triumphant reception in Leningrad is that it comes after two years of artistic and commercial eclipse in the West. But he is still the bestknown rock star ever to be allowed to perform in the Soviet Union. Thus the fanatic enthusiasm of the Russians may be as much an attestation of his symbolic status and a sign of their longing for Western popular music as it is a response to his considerable performing talents.

title: A New Agency On Gaming Due For Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, May 22  A bill calling for a complete restructuring of the way Connecticut regulates its $7millionayear legalized gambling industry was given final approval in the House of Representatives today.

title: OnePiece Swimsuits Lead Buoyant Market
description: When the bikini sauntered onto American shores from Europe about 15 years ago, sun worshipers eagerly adopted the twopiece look, considered quite daring at that time. For years, it remained the highwater mark of beach fashion.

title: Commitment and Other Orthodontic Woes
description: LEGEND has it that commitment was invented by a crazed orthodontist attempting to halt the decay of society's oral fiber. In the beginning, I think I had a thing going for my daughter's orthodontist  you know, one of those sweet, quiet, fromadistance, marriedlady crushes on a charming and attractive younger professional man.

title: General Smith to Head SHAPE
description: CASTEAU, Belgium, May 22, (Reuter)  Gen. W. Y. Smith of the United States Air Force has been appointed chief of staff of Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers (Europe), effective July 1, SHAPE announced today. General Smith will succeed Gen. James Allen, who will become commanderinchief of the United States European Command.

title: United Airlines Plans $108 Fare To Coast as End of Strike Nears
description: United Airlines said yesterday that was asking Government approval of a nostrings $108 oneway fare between New York and Los Angeles.

title: Theater: Warriors, 4 Bound in Isolation
description: AS the culmination of its Women's Project, under the direction of Julia Miles, the American Place Theater is presenting a festival of three plays by women from 20 that were given staged readings earlier this season. The first of the series, Lavonne Mueller's Warriors From a Long Childhood, is playing through Sunday in the theater's basement space. Although Miss Mueller's drama has crucial shortcomings, it is a striking debut.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IN THE scheme of things, it doesn't seem in the least surprising that of the various meats discussed in this column  veal, beef, pork and chicken  there are more than twice as many chicken recipes as there are in any other category. To my mind as a chef (and parttime home cook), chicken is probably the most versatile of all foods. It also the most economical of meats. Long before Henry IV declared a de sire that every peasant have a chicken in every pot (and long before they named the poule au pot after him) chicken was known as the food of both the poor and nobility alike. Chickens are among the easiest of all edible creatures to feed and allow to propagate.

title: A 100, DayCare Center Is Still Needed.
description: In 1879, when the Virginia Day Nursery opened its doors on the Lower East Side, the names on its roster of children reflected family origin's in. Italy or Enstern Europe. Now the children are predominantly of black or Hispanic heritage.

title: 12 Texas State Senators, Claiming Political Victory, Come Out of Hiding
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 22  Twelve state Senators dubbed the Killer Bees returned to the Texas Senate chamber today after a fiveday absence, contending that the Presidential primary legislation they sought to block was dead.

title: Remnants of Early Virginia Colony Found
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)  The complete outline of a 17th century plantation town, the earliest extensive trace of British colonization in America, has been unearthed in excavations on the banks of the James River near Williamsburg, Va.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) Coast Guard board of investigation has concluded that the skipper of the cutter Cuyahoga was primarily to blame for Chesapeake Bay collision that killed 11 of the 29 men aboard his ship.

title: TV: Music Covers Scale From Manilow to Heifetz
description: IN tonight's television melting pot of music, there is Barry Manilow at 9 on ABC and Jascha Heifetz at 10 do WNET. The Manilow, new, is The 3d Barry Manilow Special. The Heifetz, old, is a rerun of an hour that was first shown on NBC in 1971.

title: Careers
description: NAUTICAL archeology deep in the heart of Texas? Unlikely as that may sound, George F.Bass  who was a pioneer in the field at the University of Pennsylvania, which is famed for its classical archeology pro. gram  is now teaching nautical archeology at Texas A &M University. Its anthropology department offers a master's degree with a specialty in nautical archeology.

title: Rockets' Malone M.V.P. Winner
description: Moses Malone of he Houston Rockets has been named the National Basketball Association's mostvaluable player in balloting by the league's 223 players. The 24yearold center received 112 votes.

title: Hoise Votes Disaster Loans Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)  The House approved legislation today offering homeowners loans of up to $55,000 at 3 pert interest for victims of disasters like the flbods that ravaged Mississippi last month. The action came as the House, voted, 395 to 5, in favor of legislation authorizing $6.9 billion for Small Business Administration programs through the fiscal year 1982. The Senate passed a similar Ulf last week, and a HouseSenate conferees committee will be appointed to work out differences between the two measures.

title: West German Woman Enters Presidency Race
description: BONN, May 22 (Reuters)  The governing Social Democratic Party named woman today as its candidate for President of West Germany but she appeared to have little chance of winning tomorrow's election.

title: Bid for Stokely Stock Blocked by Indiana
description: INDIANAPOLIS. May 22 (UPI)  Indiana has obtained a court order barring two New York concerns from increasing their holdings in StokelyVan Camp Inc.

title: Bonds Rally As Durable Orders Sag
description: With the news of an unexpectedly steep drop in orders for durable goods, the credit markets rallied strongly yesterday afternoon, and new issues of notes and bonds sold swiftly.

title: Murder Charge Is Dismissed In Queens Slaying of Officer
description: Murder charges in the May 10slaying of an offduty police officer in an Astoria tavern were dismissed yesterday for lack of evidence at the request of the Queens District Attorney.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ROBERT B. ERHARDT

title: COurts Postpone Executions of 2 In Florida Cases
description: STARKE, Fla., May 22  Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall tonight delayed for 36 hours the execution order that was to have placed the condemned murderer John A. Spenkelink in Flordia's electric chair early tomorrow morning. Willie Jasper Darden, the death row inmate whose execution was to have followed Mr. Spenkelink's, also received reprieve, his from a Federal district judge.

title: Martin Reported Settling Suit
description: RENO, Nev., May 22 (AP) Ray Hagar, a Reno sportswriter. has dropped a criminal complaint of battery against Billy Martin, Bob Ritter, executive editor of the Nevada State Jour. nal, said today.

title: Soviet and China Seem to Move Toward New Talks
description: HONG KONG, May 22  China and the Soviet Union appear to be moving cautiously toward new talks to try to improve their strained relations, but analysts here doubt that the negotiations will lead to maior breakthrough.

title: Closed End Bond Funds
description: TUESDAY, MAY 22, 1979

title: The Thorpe Trial: From Hoopla to SoulSearching
description: LONDON, May 22  The chief prosecution witness startled everyone at the Jeremy Thorpe murder conspiracy trial the other day by alleging that he and Mr. Thorpe had plotted to murder not only the male model who is a central figure in the case, but also an otherwise unidentified man named Mr. Hetherington.

title: Two Boys Critically Hurt on L.I. As Fire Breaks Out in Bedroom
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I., May 22 (AP) Two young boys were critically burned and three other persons, including a Central Islip fireman, were injured in a house fire last night, the Suffolk County police reported.

title: Limit Sought On Oil Mergers
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Two Democratic Senators, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio, said today that they would introduce legislation to prohibit the country's 16 largest crude oil producing companies from acquiring any other company. in the energy field or elsewhere, with assets of $100 million or more.

title: Clemente's Mother Dies
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., May 72 (AP)  Mrs. Luisa Walker, the mother of Roberto Clemente, the late baseball star, died at her home last night. She was 91 years old. Mr. Clemente, who excelled with the Pittsburgh Pirates, died in an air crash on Dec. 31, 1972, as he was ferrying food and clothing to earthquake victims in Nicaragua.

title: Stephen C. Vladeck, 59, Is Dead; A Civil Rights and Labor Lawyer
description: Stephen C. Vladeck, a labor and civil liberties lawyer, who was chairman of Group Health Inc. from 1967 until last summer, when he became general counsel, died Monday night at his home on Central Park West. He was 59 years old and had been ill for several months.

title: NewsroomSearch Bill Passed
description: LINCOLN, Neb., May 22 (UPI)  The Nebraska Legislature today passed and sent to Gov. Charles none a bill to curb the issuance of warrants to search newsrooms. The bill would allow such warrants to be issued only when there was probable cause to believe that a news person or organization had committed or was committing a crime.

title: Moynihan Feels Kennedy Moves Make Carter Act
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan declared today that unless President Carter acted, he would soon find that he's governing by the sufferance of Senator Edward M. Kennedy. But Senator Moynihan added that he had no idea of what Mr. Carter should do to increase his popularity.

title: 2 Houston Men Held in Colombia Are Fined $20,000 on Air Charge
description: RIOHACHA, Colombia, May 22  The Guajira State Governor's office said today that two Texans had been fined $20,000 each for illegally entering Colombia's air space. One of the men said they had borrowed enough money to square accounts and get home.

title: U.S. Steel Will Spend $400 Million In 3 Years on Pollution Cleanup
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  The United States Steel Corporation, in what was described as the largest environmental control agreement in the history of the steel industry, agreed today to spend $400 million over the next three and a half years to clean up air and water pollution.

title: News of the Theater
description: WITH the return to fashion of padded shoulders, slim skirts and the bigband sound, it was inevitable that these trends would soon turn up on Broadway. They will appear next fall in The 1940's Radio Hour, a new musical dreamed up by Walton Jones that is to open at the St. James on Oct. 9.

title: Furs: From Dior And Saint Laurent
description: THE Christian Dior fur showing on Monday night was an embarrassment of riches that made even the most jaded furwatcher sit up and take notice. Twelve silver foxes on stage an once, an absolute avalanche of sables, a Russian lynx cape with a price tag of $100,000. All told, 146 furs  worth $2 million at retail, according to Laurence Kaye, who has the rights to Dior furs in this country  marched down the runway.

title: Bob Hope to Do a Special From China on NBCTV
description: Bob Hope, whose television shows are often on the road at some farflung locale, will be the host next season on NBCTV of a variety special that will be filmed next month in China.

title: Staff Urges F.T.C. to Curb Claims Made in NonprescriptionDrug Ads
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)  Many assertions frequently made in advertising for nonprescription drugs, such as that they are effective against colds, arthritis or indigestion, could be banned under a Federal recommendation made today.

title: Bank Study In Germany
description: BONN. May 22  A Governmentappointed commission, winding up a fouryear investigation of the dominant role of banks in the West German economy, called today for retaining the country's banking system while acknowledging certain potentialities for abuse.

title: About Real Estate
description: The chemistry is just right on Park Avenue. the Chemical Bank has decided, so it will be moving its corporate headquarters there as part of a longterm expansion.

title: Fitch Offered Job As Coach of Celtics
description: Bill Fitch said yesterday he was 99 percent certain he would accept and offer to coach the Boston Celtics. Fitch, who reisgned as the general manager and coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers Monday with two years remaining on

title: CANADA'S CONSERVATIVES WIN LARGE PLURALITY IN COMMONS; TRUDEAU CONCEDES TO CLARK
description: OTTAWA, Wednesday, May 23 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau conceded defeat early this morning for his Liberal Party in a general election that gave his principal opponent, Joe Clark of the Progressive Conservative Party, a substantial lead but no majority in the next House of Commons.

title: The Furtive Hunt for an Elusive Fungus
description: The 17 people who Were waiting at the edge of a wooded area somewhere in Westchester County on Sunday morning, armed with insect spray, baskets and paper bags, and with tiny magnifying glasses dangling from their necks, won't tell anyone where in Westchester they were. They will tell who they are and what they were doing (indeed, it's sometimes difficult to silence them) but they won't tell where.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: I KNOW that there are cooks who use their pans interchangeably sauting in their omelet pan. making crepes in their saut pan  and do so with some success. But don't see any reason to handicap yourself that way. Not only is it risky (the shape of a pan does, in fact, have a functional purpose), but you miss out on that sense of harmony a cook feels when the welldesigned utensil meets the perfected technique.

title: WASHINGTON
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  When you come back to your native state, old friends ask iii wonder and even in exasperation what's going on in Washington. They seem particularly curious about Jimmy Carter. He puzzles them. They sense his personal integri ty. and want to believe in him, but can't quite make it. He seems to think, they suggest, that because he is righteous, he is right. But why, they ask, are so many.things going wrong?

title: German Burden of Wealth: A Hunt for Status Symbols
description: BONN, May 22  It is not always simple to be rich. It is not simple, especially, for Germans.

title: Times Writer Shares Gerald Loeb Award
description: N. R. Kleinfield, a business and financial reporter for The New York Times, has tied for first place with two reporters from The Chicago Tribune in the largedailies category of the 1979 Gerald Loeb Awards for distinguished business and financial journalism.

title: ExTalmadge Aide Tells of Devising Scheme on Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  With his voice choking, his lawyers grimacing and his former boss smiling, Daniel Minchew tried to explain today to the Senate Select Committee on Ethics why he had become entangled in a scheme that allegedly funneled campaign funds and Senate expense money to his and Senator Herman E. Talmadge's pockets.

title: Clark Center Getting Own Home
description: The Clark Center for the Performing Arts, noted for its teaching of dance techniques, will move next year from Eighth Avenue. where it has been for all of its 20 years, into its own studiotheater facility a few blocks away on Theater Row, the string of theaterrelated buildings on the south side of West 42d Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

title: CableTV News Network Set Up
description: LAS VEGAS, May 22  The creation of a 24houraday national news network exclusively for cable television and the presentation of a series of Broadway and Off Broadway productions for pay cable highlighted a number of program announcements at the National Cable Television Association Convention here.

title: Qaddafi Asserts Amin Is in Uganda Again And Girding for Fight
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, May 22 (Reuters) The Libyan leader, Muammar elQaddafi, said today that Idi Amin, the deposed President of Uganda, was in northern Uganda preparing to mount a guerrilla campaign against the Tanzanianled invaders who overthrew him.

title: MCNAMARA ASSAILS WEAPONS SPENDING
description: CHICAGO, May 22  Robert S. McNamara, former Secretary of Defense, sharply criticized increased military spending in a speech tonight before a Unversity of Chicago audience, but his appearance touched off a protest that resulted in more than 25 arrests.

title: HALFGALLON PUMPS FOR GAS PERMITTED
description: ALBANY, May 22  Fearing widespread closings of gasoline stations during the upcoming Memorial Day. weekend, New York State today gave dealers emergency permission to meter gas by the halfgallon. The change is designed to let more of them charge more than $1 a gallon and thus encourage them to stay open.

title: Million in Art Stolen in Italy
description: SABBIONETA, Italy, May 22 (AP) Paintings, statues and relics from a touring exhibit were stolen early today from the gardens of the Renaissance villa of the Gonzaga princely family in this north Italian town, the police reported. The value of the stolen items was estimated at $1.2 million.

title: Firestone, After 78 Loss, Lists $32.6 Million Profit
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 22 (AP)  The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company today reported earnings of $32.6 million, or 57 cents a share, on sales of $1.35 billion for the quarter ended April 30, in contrast to a loss of $44.4 million, including a $73 million aftertax writeoff for plant shutdowns at home and abroad, on sales of $1.23 billion, in the comparable 1978 period.

title: Delay by H.E.W. in Issuing Report on Desegregation Is Questioned
description: A controversy has arisen over the reasons for tbe:delay by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare in issuing a report on school desegregation that includes the comments of scholars who are critical of compulsory busing.

title: Seoul to Store Oil in Tankers
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 22  The South Korean Government is hastening its plan to use tankers to store crude oil.

title: Begin Is Confident Sadat Will Normalize Ties Soon
description: TEL AVIV, May 22  Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Egypt and Israel would begin normalizing relations on Sunday, when he and President Anwar elSadat meet in the Sinai town of El Arish and proclaim open borders.

title: Must a Mayor Talk to Himself?
description: Not many people were listening, alas, as Mayor Koch performed exceptionally well in one of his characteristic dialogues with himself:

title: Telephone Contract
description: Western Electric International, the manufacturing subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has won a $25 million contract to supply an electronic telephone switching system for the Taiwanese capital city of Taipei. The system, developed by Bell Laboratories, the research arm of A:T.&T., will be ready for service by mid1981.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, May 24

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Deere & Company
description: MOLINE, III., May 22 (UPI)  Deere & Company, the maker of farm and industrial machinery, reported today that secondquarter earnings had risen 22.2 percent to a record $108.4 mil lion, or $1.79 a share, from $88.7 million, or $1.46 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 20.5 percent to $1.35 billion from $1.12 billion.

title: Personal Health
description: There are things you can do to limit the severity of hay fever.

title: Utility Issue Sells Out At 10.50%
description: A mediumgrade utility bond issue was offered to investors yesterday at yield of 10.50 percent, the highest such return since 1975, and it sold out the first day on the market  an underwriting rarity this year. Buoyed by the bond market's afternoon rally, the issue jumped to a premium.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, May 22, 1979

title: Franklin Mint Plans Gold Bullion Coins
description: The Franklin Mint Corporation, mail order private mint and collectibles producer, said that next month it would start minting and selling gold bullion coins and would open two or three test retail stores to sell jewelry and home furnishings.

title: Democrats' Committee Sees the Sights and Sites
description: The members of the Democratic National Convention site selection committee started a threeday visit to New York yesterday by breakfasting with Mayor Koch at Grade Mansion, seeing the sights and checking some of the hotels that would welcome the delegates if the panel chose the city for the party's 1980 convention.

title: Market Place
description: THE New York Stock Exchange, which has been criticized for the markets it has made in some stocks, has opened the door to new competition, and its private club image is crumbling to a degree.

title: BOKASSA ENVOY SAYS KILLINGS DID OCCUR
description: PARIS, May 22  The Ambassador of the Central African Empire said today that Amnesty International, the human rights organization, was correct last week in accusing his country of having murdered students. He announced that he had resigned and formed an opposition group.

title: Strain and Rivalry Plague senate Foreign Relations Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, soon to play a crucial role in the debate over the new strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union, has become troubled by internal strains and rivalries under its new chairman, Frank Church.

title: Putting Gas Guzzlers in Their Place
description: In 1975, when new American cars were getting an average of 14 miles a gallon, Congress ordered the auto companies to improve fuel efficiency to 27.5 by 1985. But how quickly they had to move toward that goal was left to the Department of Transportation. Secretary Brock Adams decided to increase mileage requirements rapidly in the early 1980's, and then ease on to 27.5 by 1985: The average now stands at 19 miles a gal lon. But Detroit is asking for a break  appealing directly to the President last week for a slower, steadier climb to 1985. Such a pace, the manufacturers assert, would save billions in development costs and, for ailing Chrysler, might even make the difference between survival and financial collapse.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a chart accompanying an article on the KerrMcGee Corporation in Business Day on Saturday, some earnings were listed incorrectly. Net income for the quarter that ended March 31, 1979, was $33,442,000, compared with $17,711,000 for the corresponding period a year earlier. Also, earnings per share for the first quarter of 1979 were $1.29, compared with 63 cents a year earlier.

title: The Region
description: ALBANY (AP)  Bowing to the wishes of Governor Carey, a state board has scrapped plans for further hearings on the Long Island Lighting Company's plans for two nuclearpower plants at Jamesport. L.I., and has voted on an expedited process that could mean a decision as early as this fall.

title: Chemical Warfare In Canada
description: SUSSEX, New Brunswick  Sometime during the last two weeks of May, World War II Grumman Avenger airplanes will again roar into the air from small airstrips throughout the Canadian province of New Brunswick. Their targets will not be Japanese ships or airfields in the South Pacific but the Spruce Budworm, a small caterkillar whose favorite food is the foliage of balsam fir trees. Each plane will carry nearly 7,000 pounds of Matacil, an insecticide that is mixed with a poisonous solvent in diesel oil. The planes will cusscross vast areas of forest land, releasing about a million gallons of these highly toxic chemicals on the enemy. They will attack just after dawn to minimize drift but at best only half the spray will land on the target area  even the slightest wind tends to blow the remainder aver farms, towns and people many miles away.

title: Notes on People
description: As Stefan Harris, an 11yearold pianist, played Bach and Beethoven on a small Steinway grand yesterday, a tiny Cairn terrier wriggled sociably around his feet.

title: CableTV Operators Upset by Restrictive Bill
description: LAS VEGAS, May 22  Just when all signs appear favorable for the further expansion of cable television into the major cities, the cable industry finds itself confronted with a new legislative proposal that most cable operators believe will vitiate some of the legal and regulatory victories that the industry has won during the last year.

title: Who Gets the Chair?
description: There will be less brutality in our society if it is made clear we value human life. So said Governor Graham of Florida as he decreed that John Spenkelink, a drifter who murdered a fellow drifter, and Willie Jasper Darden Jr., who killed a merchant during a holdup, should be executed this morning.

title: Rangers Need Maturity and Muscle
description: If one moment from the Stanley Cup finals were to be put in a time capsule, it was the one that occurred early in the third period of Saturday night's fourth game. Two minutes earlier, Phil Esposito's goal gave the Rangers a 32 lead. If they could hold it, the fourofsevengame series would be tied at 22. But now the mo ment occurred. Digging for the puck, Bob Gainey of the Montreal Canadiens crashed into Dave Maloney, the Ranger defenseman, along the boards in the corner to the left of the Ranger net. Leaving the Ranger captain for dead on the ice, Bob Gainey emerged with the puck, skated out unchecked to within about 20 feet of John Davidson and lifted it past the goaltender for the tying goal. Eventually the Canadiens won in overtime, 43, for a 31 lead in the series, and Monday night they celebrated their fourth consecutive Stanley Cup championship with a 41 victory that their Forum parishoners had demanded. But the Stanley Cup final had turned on Bob Gainey's timecapsule goal that somehow symbolized why the Rangers were wiped out in four straight after having won the opener: Their defensemen were too young and too light.

title: 3 Killed as Camper Overturns
description: WESTPORT, Wash., May 22 (AP)  A camper truck carrying a party of eight on a beach outing was struck by a wave and overturned, fatally crushing three persons, the authorities said today. The other occupants of the camper, including two children, were reported in good condition in a hospital. One of the dead was identified as James Dereus, 42 years old, of Ames, Iowa. The others were not immediately identified.

title: Harrison Police Seek Burglar
description: HARRISON, N.Y., May 22 (AP)  The police are looking for a thief who has been nicknamed the bathroom burglar beCause of his way of breaking into house. The police noted that in two burglaries last weekend the invader got into homes by climbing through bathroom windows. He took an undetermined amount of jewelry, including a ring valued at about $60,000. the police said.

title: Crown Central Plans Link With Insurer
description: BALTIMORE, May 22 (AP)  The Continental American Life Insurance Company, a Delaware insurer, has entered into an agreement to affiliate with the Crown Central Petroleum Corporation of Baltimore.

title: DEMOCRATS IN HOUSE SPLIT WITH CARTER AND BACK OIL CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Democrats in the House of Representatives disagreed today with the centerpiece of President Carter's latest energy program his decision to remove price controls from crude oil produced in the United States.

title: PPG Plans Spending Of $300 Million
description: Although it considers a recession as still a possibility for late this year, PPG Industries is planning heavy capital spending, the company's top officers said.

title: Soviet U.N. Delegate in Hospital
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May. 22 Oleg A. Troyanovsky, the Soviet Union's chief delegate to the United Nations, is undergoing tests for a stomach ailment at New York Hospital but said today that he expected to be home by the weekend.

title: French Thoughts On U.S. Barbecue
description: I HAVE never believed that old canard about no accounting for taste. A preponderant liking for one food or another is almost invariably traceable to childhood patterns or the learned taste of adulthood. What has long fascinated me, however, are the marked differences in taste at the international level.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, May 14, to Sunday, May 20), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: 33 Senators Urge Panel to Vote A BudgetBalancing Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)  A bipartisan group of 33 Senators urged the Senate Subcommittee on the Constitution today to send to the Senate floor a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget.

title: Dissident Words at Russian Bookstore
description: What means more to a Soviet diplomat: prose or the proletariat?

title: Bomb Kills 3 Near Jerusalem and Israeli Jets Retaliate
description: JERUSALEM, May 23  A bomb exploded at a crowded bus stop in a town near here today, killing 3 persons and wounding 13. Israeli planes swept over Lebanon within hours in reprisal action against Palestinians.

title: Market Place
description: Convertible Funds Gains

title: Notes on People
description: F.B.I. Agent Honored for Work on Letelier Slaying

title: Money
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY23, 1979

title: Arabs in World Health Group Lose Bid for Suspension of Israel
description: GENEVA, May 23  Arab countries today conceded defeat of their demand for suspension of Israel's rights as a member of the World Health Organization by agreeing to the shelving of a resolution involving the issue.

title: Foreign Assets In U.S. Decline
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) Foreign official assets invested in the United States fell during the first three months of 1979, reflecting intervention sales of dollars in foreignexchange markets by several major industrial countries to support their currencies, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company has announced the resignation of Karl H. Rudolph, chairman and chief executive officer. Robert M. Ginn, president, will become chief executive officer. The post of chairman will remain vacant.

title: Moe's Remarks Cost Him $3,000
description: Doug Moe's disparaging remarks about the officiating in the closing minutes of the seventh game of the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference championship round have cost him $3,000.

title: Indians Garland Wins, 43
description: BALTIMORE, May 23 (AP)  Pat Kelly hit a threerun pinch homer in the last half of the 10th inning, giving the Baltimore Orioles a 52 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Energy

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: A Zoning Law in Need of Reform
description: It is easy to see what is happening on New York City's streets as big building begins again; it is far from easy to understand the zoning regulations that are shaping the new skyscrapers.
