description: Arthur Miller wears a toga over his gray flannel suit, a sly reference to his commercial success as a playwright; Inga Morath, his photographerwife, is shooting with her camera. Arthur C. Clarke, the sciencefiction writer, is in a space suit; Sophia Delza, in black tights, demonstrates her Chinese dance and t'ai chi; Virgil Thomson, the composer, conducts with raised baton and Peter Brook swings from a trapeze reminiscent of his production of A Midsummer Night's Dream.

title: Helen Caldicotes Many Lives: Pediatrician, Mother, Activist
description: BOSTON  She has long been regarded as the other pediatrician in the antinuclear movement. With her famous colleague, Dr. Benjamin Spock, she marched in the recent Washington rally against nuclear power carrying a black coffin that was decked with papiermache forms of infants and a sign saving: Babies Die First

title: State Weighs Purchase, Leasing of 3 Race Tracks
description: ALBANY, May 24 (AP)  Governor Carey's staff is drafting a $70 million plan for purchase of the state's three major thoroughbred tracks.

title: Very Wet Situation Is Likely to Continue Into Beginning of Holiday
description: The National Weather Service described yesterday's weather conditions in the metropolitan area as only a Government agency can.

title: Sonics Tie Series, Top Bullets, 9282
description: LANDOVER, Md., May 24  The quick and aggressive Seattle SuperSonics, doubleteaming, trapping and overplaying Bobby Dandridge and Elvin Hayes, disrupted the Washington Bullets' offense in the second half tonight and rallied for a 9282 victory at the Capital Centre. It tied their National Basketball Association championship series at 11.

title: 8 Indicted as Members of National Mob
description: TRENTON, May 24 (AP)  Eight reputed New Jersey mobsters have been named in a 29count indictment alleging the existence of a nationwide organization established to commit crimes and maintain power over its rivals and victims, Attorney General John J. Degnan said today.

title: A Narrow Option
description: What's a necktie wearer to do? First, there were narrow ties  Slim Jims they were called. Then ties got wider and many men threw out their collection for the new, wider, smarter ones.

title: House Votes to Ease Restrictions On Former Government Workers
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  In a move that reflects a growing backlash against the ethics changes of the postWatergate era, the House of Representatives today approved a bill that would weaken the restrictions on Government officials when they return to private life.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, MAY 24, 1979

title: French Strike Truncates Telecast to U.S.
description: A taped. twohour telecast of the 1979 Cannes Film Festival Awards being beamed by Satellite to a United States network of 83 stations and an estimated 20 million to 30 million viewers was truncated by 43 minutes last night by wildcat walkout of French television engineers in Paris.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The political tension between President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy is now drawn too fine for the comfort or safety of the Democratic Party, the Administration, perhaps even the country. Who's the legitimate ruler here? Senator Pat Moynihan asked the other day, no doubt expressing the quandary Of a good many Americans.

title: Art People
description: CONTROVERSY still simmers over Our Tree of Life, a sculpture by the late Jacques Lipchitz, now standing before the Hadassah University Hospital in Jerusalem The work, 20 feet high. evolved from a fivefoot plaster model left by the sculptor, who never saw the finished piece. It was pushed to completion by his widow, Yulla, who works in sculpture herself.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Congress approved a tentative Federal budget for the next fiscal year, with a projected deficit of $23 billion. Approval came nine days after the statutory deadline, but the lapse had no practical effect. Fights over spending were expected to continue. [Page A1.]

title: Abortion, the City and the Church
description: New York City now faces what looks like a particularly acute dilemma over abortion. The city plans to sign a $24million contract between New York Medical College and two city hospitals that would be served by the college. The problem, in brief, is that the college is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church, which opposes abortion, but city hospitals must, as a matter of public policy, provide abortion services. However, the dilemma may not be as difficult as it looks.

title: District Discloses Subway Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May, 24 (AP)  More than three years after opening the first segment of Washington's subway, the Metro board of directors agreed today to begin operating the system seven days a week, starting this fall. The directors approved a series of new bus and rail fare increases to support the 1980 budget, which includes Sunday rail service beginning Sept. 2.

title: Reporter Receives Apology
description: Billy Martin apologized publicly to Ray Hagar yesterday and told the Reno, Nev., sportswriter he was sorry for having punched him last Nov. 10 during an interview in a bar.

title: Israel Barricades Beersheba Area For Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM, May 24  Israeli security forces set up barricades today on the approaches to Beersheba, where talks are to open tomorrow between Israel, Egypt and the United States on selfrule for the Israelioccupied West Bank and Gaza territories.

title: Khomeini Terms Secular Critics Enemies of Islam
description: TEHERAN; Iran, May 24  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini castigated his secular critics today, telling his followers they should struggle with them even worse than you did with the Shah.

title: A Blues Singer Looks Back
description: Joya Sherrill, a tall woman with warm, luminous eyes who says she loves to talk, was talking the other afternoon at Michael's Pub, where, at night, she sings. She was talking about Duke Ellington, television and Iran, all of which have played important roles in her life.

title: South Africa, Back in U.N. a Day, Is Barred From Debate on Namibia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 24 The General Assembly voted 96 to 16 today to prevent South Africa from participating in its current debate on SouthWest Africa. The South African delegation immediately walked Out.

title: MEMORIAL DAY
description: Memorial Day is being Observed nationally on Monday and in New York State on Wednesday. Holiday schedules will vary. An article is on page A12.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Broadway
description: WHERE are the roles for women? They are here. Wine Untouched, a new play by Bjorg Vik, will open at the Harold Clurman Theater on June 18, and in its cast will be Glenn Close, Patricia Elliott, Donna McKechnie, Swoosie Kurtz and Susan Slavin. These

title: Economic Officials See No Recession
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and top Administration economic advisers express optimism about the economy today.

title: Screen: 'Alien 'Brings Chills From the Far Galaxy:A Gothic Set in Space
description: A GIGANTIC construction moves serenely through space where, though the night never ends, there's always enough light to see strange objects. This one looks like the main set of D.W. Griffith's "Intolerance." It's as if Babylon had been cut loose from earth to sail back through space to its own time. In actual fact, it's the cargo-ship Nostromo on its return to earth at the end of an extended voyage to the far end of the galaxy.When we go inside, the ship appears to have been as suddenly deserted as the Marie Celeste. We wander down empty corridors into abandoned living quarters, into engine rooms and, finally, into the command room where the computers are the only signs of life. The interior of the ship is vast. It contains the kind of waste space one seldom sees anymore except in some rare old Manhattan pile like the Dakota. Something decidedly eerie is going on.Thus  familiarly but with immense promise  begins "Alien," Ridley Scott's new, elaborately produced science-fiction film that opens today at the Criterion and other theaters. However, as this voyage continues, familiarity consumes the promise and leaves as residue the memory of some shrieks from shocks of a most mundane kind.The crew of the Nostromo has not vanished. They are merely sleeping the time away and, shortly after the opening credits, they come forth from their sleep-pods to prepare for their re-entry into the earth's orbit. It's then that they encounter peculiar signals from the wreck of another space ship, one from another galaxy and one which has crashed onto an uncharted planetoid. The Nostromo stops to investigate, locates the craft and, when it takes off again for earth, it carries aboard a specimen of alien life, a small, octopus-like blob that won't stop growing and  possibly worse  is "unclouded by conscience or delusions of morality."That's about all one should or can say about the story originally conceived by Dan O'Bannon and turned into a screenplay by him and Ronald Shusett."Alien" is an extremely small, rather decent movie of its modest kind, set inside a large, extremely fancy physical production. Don't race to it expecting the wit of "Star Wars" or the metaphysical pretentions of "2001" and "Close Encounters of the Third Kind." At its best it recalls "The Thing," though the Howard Hawks film was both more imaginatively and more economically dramatized.It's an old-fashioned scare movie about something that is not only implacably evil but prone to jumping out at you when (the movie hopes) you least expect it. There was once a time when this sort of thing was set in an old dark house, on a moor, in a thunderstorm. Being trendy, Mr. Scott and his associates have sent it up in space.As he demonstrated with "The Duellists," his first feature, Mr. Scott is a very stylish director. Though "Alien" is not the seminal science-fiction film one wants from him, it's executed with a good deal of no-nonsense verve. The members of the small cast are uniformly good though, with two exception, the roles might have been written by a computor.Sigourney Weaver is impressive and funny as the Nostromo's executive officer, the second in command, a young woman who manages to act tough, efficient and sexy all at the same time. Ian Holm is also excellent as the ship's science officer, a man with a secret that will set him apart from everyone else forever.Other members of the crew are played by Tom Skerritt, Harry Dean Stanton, Yaphet Kotto and Veronica Cartwright, the actress who was so good in "Invasion of the Body Snatchers." She plays a somewhat similar role here, one that requires her to weep a lot and leaves her so red-eyed and red-nosed that she may be in danger of becoming the Isable Jewell of the living-color space-age."Alien's" sets and special effects are well done, but these things no longer surprise or tantalize us as they once did. In a very short time, science-fiction films have developed their own jargon that's now become a part of the grammar of film. You know the sort of stuff I mean  the shots of blinking instrument panels, of wildly bleeping computers, of cryptic messages clattering in square type-faces across televisio screens. There's also the obligatory shot of that huge space vehicle early on in every film. It appears from over our right shoulder, passes over our head and then proceeds slowly and majestically toward the far distance at screen-left. When I first saw it in "2001," it was awesome. Now it makes me feel like a turtle on a busy though unnaturally quiet highway.

title: Radio
description: 7Noon, WNYCFM. Overture No. 5, J. C. Bach; Flute Sonata in F, Handel; The Frog Galliard, Morley; Now, oh now, I needs must pert, Dowland; Brandenburg Concerto No. 1, Bach; Sonata No. 3 for Violin and Piano, Beethoven.

title: Union Suitors Seek Brooks Bros. Redress
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Bluecollar makers of Brooks Brothers whitecollar shirts argued today at the company's annual shareholders meeting that they were being treated unfairly.

title: Merry Isle Triumphs In $108,000 Holmes Pace
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 24  The favored Merry Isle closed powerfully down the middle of the track to score a onelength victory tonight in the $108,000 Oliver Wendell Holines Pace at the Meadowlands. He returned $5.20 for $2.

title: Restaurants
description: WHEN waiters ask if guests want their Indian food flavored hot and spicy at Sahib on 86th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, they really mean what they are saying. So if that is your preference, know that you will be taken at your word. On the other hand, dishes at Sahib also are mild or medium spiced when so ordered. But it is the essential hotness of Indian food, combined with soothing rice pullao, cool, cucumberflecked yogurt, the gentle brown lentil stew known as kali dal, and mint chutney that really makes for the seductive contrast of flavors and textures that distinguishes this cuisine.

title: Report of Ruling on Extradition Of 2 Scientologists Is Corrected
description: LONDON, May 24 (AP)  The Associated Press erroneously reported yesterday that a magistrate had ruled that two leaders of the Church of Scientology should be extradited to the United States.

title: Advertising
description: THE One Show awards program last night at the Pierre Hotel was a triumph for Ally & Gargano, two of its creative people and its client, Federal Express. Together they all but swept the field for the best television commercials. Of the nine television categories the team took four gold awards and a silver.

title: Shortage: The Hows and Whys
description: Memorial Day weekend is the start of the summer driving season, when gasoline consumption reaches a peak, and the season begins this year with both uncertainty and suspicion. Ameri- cans do not know whether they will be able to get gasoline, most suspect that the shortages to date have been contrived and many simply do not understand how the nation got itself into this predicament. The questions and answers that follow are intended to put the current gasoline problem in perspective:

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 8 P.M. (Television  Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio  WMCA, P.M.)

title: 4 Sought for Questioning In Bedford Hills Murders
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 24  Descriptions of two men and two women wanted for questioning in the murder of four Bedford Hills residents the night of May 9 were released today by the Westchester County District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari.

title: Shrinking From Politics
description: When Jimmy Carter came out of nowhere to win the Presidency, it was conventional wisdom to regard him as a brilliant politician, but lacking substantive knowledge. That view has surfaced again. Consider, for example, this muchquoted passage from the kissandtell revelations of a former White House speechwriter: Shortly before I left, I heard one of the Georgians say to several others, You know, there really ought to be a place for people like us between the elections, someplace we could rest up and get ready for the next one. As for the next tier of staffers, obsessed by substance rather than politics, Carter didn't mistreat these troops so much as he ignored them.

title: Lance and Three Associates Plead Not Guilty to Conspiracy Charges
description: ATLANTA, May 24  Bert Lance, the former director of the Office of Management and Budget, and three business associates entered pleas of not guilty today to charges that they had violated Federal banking and conspiracy laws to obtain $20 million in loans for their own use from 1970 to 1978.

title: A Flourish as Tate Wing Opens
description: LONDON, May 24  With a flourish of flags, the Band of the Blues and Royals playing Handel's Water Music and a spectacular 16minute fireworks display over the Thames, the Tate Gallery, the museum of predominantly modern art, opened its new extension tonight to the pop of champagne corks at a gathering for a thousand people.

title: Deaths
description: VLADECKStephen C. The Faculty & Staff of N.Y. University. Libraries is deeply saddened at the lass of our highly valued and good friend. His sincere dedication, personal and professional commitment to the traditions of social justice and democracy will ever be admired and remembered by us. Our deepest sympathy to his wife, Judith; and his family.

title: Art: Diebenkom Refines His Vision
description: NINE canvases at Knoedler (19 East 70th Street) show that Richard Diebenkorn continues to be in the top rank of painters working in this or any other country. The exhibition, which also contains some 30 works in mixed media on paper, discloses no greatchanges in the motifs that have occupied this California artist for a decade  the numbers in his Ocean Park series are now more than 100. The differences are merely those of quality and vision.

title: New Faces: Susan Kingsley and Pamela Reed
description: THE two actresses are a study in contrasts. Susan Kingsley, tall and thin, Southern in speech and countryplain in her responses, is Kentucky born and bred. Pamela Reed, compact and feline, watchful and intense, is a New Yorker by way of Washington State and points in between. In short, they could hardly De more unlike, and yet they have teamed up to create one of the more memorable stage portraits of the season in Marsha Norman's Off Broadway success, Getting Out, at the Theater de Lys.

title: Nuclear Experts Reportedly Knew Of Flaw in Some Reactors in 1977
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Nuclear safety experts in the Government knew that Babcock & Wilcox reactors had an important engineering flaw more than a year before that flaw played a critical part in the March 28 accident at Three Mile Island, according to a report obtained by the House Interior Committee.

title: Firestone Accused of Laxity in Recalling Radial Tires
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Joan Claybrook, the Federal automobile safety thief, criticized the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company today as being slow to fulfill its commitment to recall more than eight million faulty radial tires.

title: Companies List Their Earnings Reports for Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Disabled Women: A Conference on Discrimination
description: Marilyn Saviola, a quadraplegic polio victim, told a conference here yesterday that disabled women who are striving to be independent are caught in a double bind of discrimination.

title: Don Regan of Merrill: Bullish on His Computer
description: Merrill Lynch's Donald T. Regan uses one. Frank Cary of the International Business Machines Corporation and Citibank's Wafter Wriston don't. Nor do most high executives in business today. If the computer age is well upon us, then most chief executives are doing their best to keep it at a distance.

title: Mose Allison Sings and Plays His Special Brand of Blues at New jazz Club
description: My philosophy, say Mose Allison, who is at Fat Tuesday's tonight and tomorrow night, is that you have to get a style and then you have to transcend it. You have to work on trying to rise above your style instead of getting trapped in it; you have to be able to take off from that style and get into other things. That's where I am now.

title: Loomis of S.E.C. Owns Stock in 50 Companies
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  Philip A. Loomis Jr., a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission since 1971, owns stock in almost 50 corporations, according to financial disclosure records made public this week.

title: Eastern Air Lines Issue
description: Eastern Air Lines said yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $50 million in 20year convertible subordinated debentumc. to be offered by an underwriting group headed by Lazard, Frres & Company and Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith Inc. Proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, including acquisition of aircraft, the company said.

title: Economic Scene
description: PRESIDENT CARTER'S latest effort to resolve the nation's oil problem  by phasing out controls on domestic oil starting June 1 has met bitter opposition within his own party. The roots of the opposition, however, lie deeper.

title: EARNINGS
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company, the giant retail chain battling to prevent a takeover by Brascan Ltd., yesterday reported a 19.3 percent decline in earnings for its fiscal first quarter. The de- cline reflected a currency loss kin contrast to a profit the year before) and drop in income from its British subsidiary because of currency translations.

title: Proposed: A Work Credit
description: Whenever the subject of youth unemployment is resurrected for frontpage treatment, the question of the minimum wage rises for debate.

title: VANCE MEETS BEGIN, THEN GOES TO SADAT
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, May 24  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance met in London today with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and then flew here to confer with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt. The talks were aimed at improving the atmosphere for the next round of EgyptianIsraeli negotiations, which start tomorrow with the return of the town of El Arish to Egypt.

title: Film: 'Poseidon' Returns:Inside a Floating Hulk
description: IF ever a ship deserved to sink, it was the S. S. Poseidon for sure. But no. At the beginning of "Beyond the Poseidon Adventure," which is about as far "beyond" the original as a snail can skip, we see the hull of the capsized ocean liner as a tugboat approaches, hoping to salvage whatever loot was on board. There is also a medical vessel, commanded by Telly Savalas, who is pretending to offer first aid but is in fact an archcrook. Are there any survivors of the wreck? If so, they've either been rescued already or they're sleeping with the fishes. Nobody cares.Almost all of the action in "Beyond the Poseidon Adventure," which opens today at the Cinerama I and neighborhood theaters, takes place inside the dark, unsightly remains of the damaged vessel. This is almost as disastrous as whatever first hit the "Poseidon," or ignited that skyscraper in Irwin Allen's "The Towering Inferno," or made the bees lose their little winged tempers in Mr. Allen's "The Swarm."Mr. Allen, who directed "Beyond the Poseidon Adventure" and produced it too, is so obviously ill-equipped to stage action scenes in cramped quarters that his audience winds up wishing as fervently as his characters for a chance to see the light of day.It turns out there are survivors. A blind man (Jack Warden). His kindly wife (Shirley Knight). A nurse (Shirley Jones). A father in a pink ruffled shirt (Peter Boyle) and his daughter in a yellow ruffled dress (Angela Cartwright). A phony Texan (the late Chill Wills). Plus a couple of others, all of whom make silly, romantic plans about what they will do if they ever get out, and all of whom are discovered by the tugboat crew. This consists of Karl Malden, Michael Caine and Sally Field.Mr. Allen's one undeniable talent is for attracting actors you'd love to see doing just about anything else. Mr. Boyle fares better than the others, perhaps because he hollers loudest, but no one really survives the indignities of Nelson Gidding's screenplay. Some day, perhaps Mr. Caine  blandly heroic here, but interesting anyway  and the indomitable Miss Field will have a chance to make a real movie together. But for the meanwhile, it's sink rather than swim.When last seen, the "Poseidon" had been blown into small pieces. With any luck, this means Mr. Allen can't possibly make a threequel."Beyond the Poseidon Adventure" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It includes a few brief, violent confrontations.

title: A RoadShow Trouper Plays a Bit Part Effectively
description: WESTPORT, CONN., May 24 Sharpeyed motorists who think they see a dummy at the wheel when they pass a stationary police car equipped with a radar gun may be right. The Connecticut state police have been using a borrowed mannequin on radar duty along the Merritt Parkway in Fairfield.

title: World News Briefs
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 24 (UPI) King Birendra Bir Bikram, responding to nearly two months of student rioting, today ordered that a referendum be held in Nepal so that the people could decide' whether a new form of government should be adopted. No date was set for the referendum.

title: Reported Felonies Show Drop, and Rise, in New York
description: The crime rate declined sharply in most of New York City's poorer neighborhoods between 1975 and 1978, but continued to rise in the more affluent areas, according to a study based on Police Department statistics.

title: A Regional Guide to Holiday Fun
description: New Jersey

title: State Removes Board of Mannes College
description: ALBANY, May 24  The State Board of Regents voted today to remove the ninemember board of trustees from the Marines College of Music.

title: Alternate Plan Is Offered To Comply With Title IX
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)  coalition of some 300 universities and colleges has submitted an alternate plan to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare for compliance with the Federal law banning sex discrimination in intercollegiate athletics.

title: Publishing: Goodman Leaving Harvard Press
description: WILLIAM B. GOODMAN will be leaving the Harvard University Press and joining David R. Godine, Publisher, in July as editorial director. Before Harvard, Mr. Goodwin was executive editor at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title: Mayors to Meet in Pittsburgh
description: WASHINGTON, May 24(AP)  The United States Conference of Mayors will hold its 47th annual meeting June 913 in Pittsburgh, it has announced. The sessions will be held at the Pittsburgh Hilton. At the conference, the mayors will adopt a series of resolutions that will set their nationwide policy for the coming year.

title: The Region
description: TEANECK, N.J.  Three high school students returning from their junior prom were killed early yesterday when their 1970 Volvo station wagon struck a bridge abutment on a rainslicked overpass on Route 4 here and broke apart on impact. A fourth teenager was critically hurt.

title: 2 Courts Lift Stays, Clearing Way For Execution of Florida Murderer
description: STARKE, Fla., Friday, May 25  A three judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit late last night vacated a stay of execution for John A. Spenkelink, the condemned Florida murderer, and state officials set Mr. Spenkelinh's execution for 10 A.M. today.

title: Museum Drops 19 Aronson Paintings. From Show Over Christian Themes
description: Because of their Christian symbolism, 19 early paintings by a Jewish artist have been deleted from a forthcoming retrospective of his work at the Jewish Museum,. Fifth Avenue at 92d Street. They will hang instead at the National Academy of Design, three blocks away, with the museum exhibiting more than 100 later paintings that comprise the bulk of the show.

title: Spring Cleaning at the Duck Pond
description: Work began yesterday on Central Park duck pond, park's southea'st corner, which will be drained, dredged and landscaped, at an cost of $800,000 to $1 million. It is first of five park ponds to be restored. The others are Prospect in Brooklyn, Seton Falls in the Bronx, Cpl. Lawrence Thompson on Staten Island and Baisley in Queens.

title: Rhodesian Outlook Lifts Price of Defaulted Bonds
description: As Britain and the United States grapple with the question of reestablishing relations with Rhodesia, prices of defaulted Rhodesian bonds have risen briskly.

title: Sohio Board Votes No On Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  The board of directors of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) today unanimously reaffirmed the company's decision to abandon its plan for a CaliforniatoTexas pipeline to carry surplus Alaskan oil.

title: Daily News to Get New Publisher
description: W. H. James will retire June 1 as president and publisher of The Daily News in New York. He will be succeeded by Robert M. Hunt, president and chief executive officer of the Chicago Tribune Company.

title: Closings on Memorial Days
description: Under a 1967 Federal law creating a series of threeday holiday weekends, the last Monday in May was established as the official Memorial Day holiday, a practice followed by Connecticut, New Jersey and most other states, where the holiday will be observed this Monday.

title: Cautious Holiday Travel Begins As Gasoline Shortage Threatens
description: Overshadowed by forecasts of a gasoline drought and rain, millions of wary vacationers began streaming out of New York City and Its suburbs today for traditional Memorial Day weekend trips, tailored In many cases to the new realities of an oilscarce age.

title: Auctions
description: OLD masters sales these days are filled with art works as provocative to scholars as they are to buyers. Brenda Auslander, the specialist in this field at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th. Street, believes that ideas about them have changed in the decades since these paintings were acquired or studied by the academic community. The paintings by two artists in Sotheby's sale Wednesday at 10:15 and 2 P.M. are cases in point.

title: Arms Bill Gets Rhodesia Clause
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)  The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today a $40 billion weapons bill but added an amendment that would force President Carter to lift United States trade sanctions against Rhodesia. The amendment would lift the sanctions the minute the President signed the bill into law. The elections did not include the Patriotic Front guerrilla groups that the United States has said must be involved in any settlement for black majority rule.

title: UConn Beats Navy, 54
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29  The University of Connecticut defeated Navy, 54, today in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball playoffs.

title: Andrew Ziegler Is Dead; Merchants Bank's Head
description: Andrew Ziegler, president and chief executive officer of the Merchants Bank of New York, died Friday at Elmhurst General Hospital in Queens. Mr. Ziegler was stricken while on vacation in the Caribbean and flown home by air ambulance. He was 65 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Chinese Women's Delegation Visits Barnard
description: A delegation described as the first group of leading Chinese women to visit the United States since the two countries established relations toured the facilites of Barnard College's Women's Center yesterday. The 11member group included a hospital director, political leaders, an engineer and a reporter from The People's Daily.

title: The Pop Life
description: BLACK music in general and disco music in particular are worlds in which the flamboyant seems commonplace, but even by those standards, Sylvester is, something special. An unabashed homosexual and often exotically costumed as a transvestite, Sylvester  he insists on no last name  gives a show that makes most performers look positively dowdy.

title: Books of The Times
description: ELLERBEE, according Stanley Elkin's new novel, The Living End, is having a bad time of it. . . . He had many financial reversals.... His

title: Americans Take Top Prizes at Cannes
description: CANNES, France, May 24 (AP) The Cannes Film Festival, the mecca of European film makers who once scorned Hollywood as the home of rich moguls who make lowgrade movies, awarded all of its top honors to American films today.

title: Housepainter Goes on Trial in Murders of 2 Women
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 24  The murder trial of a 38-year-old housepainter accused of strangling two Bergen County women nearly four years ago began here today with opening statements by the prosecutor and the defense attorney

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: When the New York Stock Exchange was reorganized in 1972, the chairman became chief executive officer as well, and the expanded post was filled by a fulltime, salaried employee. Previously the top executive job had been the president's, and the chairman had been the senior representative on the board of the exchange's membership. In the new order, that function fell to the vice chairman, a parttime position for an active member.

title: At the Movies
description: HAVING just completed Resurrection, a film about a woman who has healing powers, Ellyn Burstyn said she was feeling under the weather: I don't think any kind of healing can cure the common cold. Anyhow, I always give myself an excuse to take to my bed whenever I finish a movie. I am languishing at home among the dogwood and lilac blossoms.

title: Joseph Scribner Is Dead; An Investment Banker
description: Joseph M. Scribner, an investment banker who served two terms as a governor of the New York Stock Exchange, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Anne Arundel General Hospital in Annapolis, Md., where he lived. He was 81 years old.

title: Mondale Says President Orders Review of Job Program on Youth
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)  Vice President Mondale said today that Federal jobtraining programs for youths had proved less than totally effective and announced a major policy review to decide how to change them.

title: Southern Yemen AT A GLANCE
description: Southern Yemen, officially the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen, is a coastal country of 62,000 square miles and a population of perhaps two million along the southwestern edge of the Arabian Peninsula. It is bordered by Oman, Saudi Arabia and, to the northwest, Yemen, offix0020;cially the Yemen Arab Republic

title: New Phone Directory To Let Customers List Incomplete Addresses
description: For years your name could be listed or unlisted in New York State telephone directories. Now, if you like, you can be partly listed.

title: Billy Puts It Up to George
description: Billy Martin, the once and future manager, squared the Reno rap yesterday and put the next move up to George M. Steinbrenner 3d. The proprietor of the Yankees must now keep his promise to reappoint Martin manager for the 1980 baseball season or prove himself less magnanimous than Ray Hagar, Bowie Kuhn and the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio.

title: Walter Kerr
description: Well, everything's been pecullar all season long, I said to myself as the attractive young lady tried to claim my seat for The Elephant Wax Bernard Pomerance's engrossplay about a hideously malformed circus freak restored to bunstattY by a compassionate doctor and a cunning, courageous actress, had began its career in this country in a tiny workshop playhouse. Because it almost instantly began Selling out, and turning far too many people away, some thought was given to moving it to midtown. Caution seemed the byword, based On the old notion that Broadway is less than hospitable to plays not written by Neil Simon, and the production bided its time in its limited quarters until a suitably modest Broadway house could be found. In time the Booth, one of midtown's smaller and more attractive theaters, Warne available, and The Elephant Man had just made the transfer. I'd gone back to see how Broadway was treating and taking it (splendidly, with ardor) on the evening The young lady seemed bent or joining tee in F-114.

title: Return of Marine Buoying Hopes On the Missing in Southeast Asia
description: The unexpected return of Pfc. Robert R. Garwood of the Marines this spring after 16 years in Vietnam has touched off hopes among the families of some other men still unaccounted for in Southeast Asia that their husbands and sons may still be alive.

title: Deaths
description: ACKERWilliam L. Jr. The Mole: announce with deep sorrow the passing of their beloved member or May 23, 1979. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to the family.

title: Deaths
description: HODESLeonard. After a long bout with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis. Beloved husband of Esther, devoted father of Andrew and Lisa, dear brother of Martin, fatherinlaw of Shelley. Services and interment were held Thursday, May 23, 1979. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Muscular Distroshy Rockville Centre, New York.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  More offidals these days are making more speeches In this country than ever before, most of them manufactured by people who don't deliver them. But occasionally somebody cries out from the heart on a subject of world significance.

title: A New Subway Map That Goes Back to Basics
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has scheduled for late next month distribution of a new subway map, three years in the making. New map, a detail of which is shown above, will replace schematic model introduced in 1972. It returns to relatively undistorted geographical layout, with a new system contrasting colors to differentiate subway lines. The location of the system's 458 stations is shown in relation to major streets, neighborhoods and tourist attractions. The map is now still in the proofreading stage.

title: Movie: French 'Toy':Human Plaything
description: On the top of the second (and last) page of notes I kept while watching Francis Veber's French comedy, "The Toy." I find that I wrote, "This is the WORST movie of ALL TIME perhaps." At the bottom of the page I added a postcript, "NO perhaps."When I'm making notes in the dark I occasionally use capital letters, as much to plant an idea firmly in my memory as to facilitate the later reading of the notes. This time I needn't have been so fastidious. There's no easy way to forget a comedy as glumly coy and out-of-touch with everything as "The Toy." It may not be the worst movie of all time, but when you watch it, it seems that way, which is the same thing.The movie, which opens today at the Paris Theater, stars Pierre Richard ("The Tall Blond Man With One Black Shoe"), who looks like a sort of straightened-out Harpo Marx, as a magazine reporter who works for a tight-lipped, tyrannical publishing tycoon played by Michel Bouquet. One day the tycoon's small, bratty son, who's been told he can have any toy in a large department store (also owned by his father), sees Mr. Richard and demands to have the fellow wrapped up and sent home as his playmate.The rest of the movie alternates between a series of uninspired slapstick gags, in which "the toy" attempts to obtain his freedom, and a series of supposedly serious scenes in which Mr. Richard teaches the child some respect for life, limb and other people's feelings.Mr. Richard mugs unfunnily from beginning to end and Fabrice Greco plays the overbearing child with awful convinction. Mr. Bouquet, one of the most urbane and witty of French character actors ("La Femme Infidele," "Mississippi Mermaid," among others), suggests a degree of furious monomania that is supported by nothing else is this flimsiest of pictures.Mr. Veber, credited as one of the authors of the current "La Cage aux Folles," both wrote and directed "The Toy."

title: Deaths
description: GOLDMANEmanuel. Congregation Bnal Jeshurun deeply mourns the Passing of Its distinguished Honorery Trustee, Emanuel Goldman. For more then half a century his gentle demeanor and outstanding good works made of him a beloved figure. His exemplary sense of dedication to human betterment and Jewish continuity inspired all. As loyal brother, cherished brother-inlaw, devoted uncle or thoughtful friend, his singular love for family and friendship endeared him and knew no bounds. Everyone who knew him sensed that this was the parted Jewish gentleman, who taught all to express their Ideals more in deed than declaration. To his family and friends our deepest sympathy. May God shelter him within the abiding love of His Pre-

title: About Real Estate
description: The tax incentive known as J51 has had a farreaching impact on housing production and neighborhood revitalization in the city, especially in Manhattan, since 1976. That was the year the incentive formula was extended to encompass the conversion of hotels, factories, office buildings and other large properties into apartments. Previously the incentive had been used only to encourage improvement of buildings already residential.

title: Deaths
description: COLEMANJacques G., beloved husband of Mildred, devoted father of Ann B. Roll and Jacques G. Coleman, Jr. Friends may call Saturday 7.9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, Medison Ave. at 81st St., with service Sunday 1 PM.

title: Clark Meets Aides as Trudeau Confers With Cabinet
description: TORONTO, May 24  On opposite sides of Canada, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Prime Ministerelect Joe Clark conferred with aides all day today, planning the first changeover of Canadian governments in 16 years.

title: Israeli Planes Again Strike at Palestinians in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 24  Israeli jets struck again today at Palestinian areas in Lebanon, and the Government here condemned the attacks as arrogant defiance of international conscience.

title: COMPROMISE BUDGET APPROVED BY HOUSE AS LIBERALS SWITCH
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  The House of Representatives narrowly gave final Congressional approval today to a tentative Federal budget for the next fiscal year when a group of liberal Democrats accepted a compromise offered by the Senate. The vote was 202 to 196.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW May, 26

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY, MAY 24, 1979

title: Business Borrowings Continue Down
description: A second consecutive weekly decline in business borrowings at the leading New York City banks was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and seemed to provide additional evidence of a slowdown in economic activity.

title: Music: Philharmonic
description: THIS year, economics have forced the New York Philharmonic to abandon its longpopular Promenades concerts format, which involved decoration of Avery Fisher Hall and the re- placement or many seats with cafe tables and chairs, but Andre Kostelanetz is back again as usual at this season to conduct concerts of easytotake, tuneful music.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MAY 25, 1979

title: Chauffeur Is Guilty in Murder of Singer in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 24  A Westchester County jury today found Michael D. Spearman, a 21-year-old man from Kansas City, Kan., guilty of second-degree murder in the slaying last November of Linda Scott, a 28-year-old country and western singer

title: Sadat Is Said to Offer Asylum to Shah of Iran
description: LONDON, May 24  President Anwar elSadat of Egypt has said he will offer asylum to the deposed Shah of Iran, a weekly London newspaper reported tonight.

title: Antiques Show Luring Buffs To the Armory
description: THE Park Avenue Antiques Show, that popular annual springtime event that offers a wide selection period wares, has arrived with a new name, a new management but an old address  the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street.

title: Ralph Mendelson, 52, A Philharmonic Violist
description: Ralph Mendelson, a violist with the New York Philharmonic orchestra for 26 years and a member of various chamber groups, including the New York Chamber Quintet and the Musical Arts Trio, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He had been operated on for a brain tumor about a year ago, and fatal complications developed. He was 52 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Wadkins Leader With a 69
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, May 24  I'd much rather have it 80 degrees with no wind, Lanny Wadkins said today after he had shot a three-under-par 69 for a onestroke lead in the Memorial Tour.: nament at Jack Nicklauss Muirfield Village Golf Club. But that was a very solid round, and its hard to fuss when you play like that in this horrible weather.

title: Extra Indy Qualifying Rejected
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 24  The United States Auto Club, after three postponements of a deadline, announced today that there would be no extra qualifying for six cars that had been bumped last Sunday in the final time trials for the Indianapolis 500.

title: ZZZZzzzzzMMMMMmmmmmmm
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  One pound of cloverhoney results from 10 years of labor by one bee, and the visitation and pollination of about 10 million flowers. Bees use fascinating strategies to harvest honey  the basis of their energy economy. Can we learn useful lessons from their example?

title: Turkey's Hopes for Ecevit Meld to Disappointment
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 24  Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit of Turkey came to power a year and a half ago buoyed by a great wave of public optimism that he would overcome the political and economic dangers facing the country.

title: A Holiday Guide to Where the Fun Is in the Region
description: There are all sorts of special ways to experience summer this weekend in the city  including biking, laughing, floating, strolling, tasting and flopping down on the city's beaches, which open officially tomorrow.

title: Business and the Law
description: BACK in 1969, when some newspapers were not quite so sensitive to conflicts of interest and when the Federal securities laws were not quite so sweeping, Alex N. Campbell purchased 5,000 shares of stock in a small company called American Systems Inc. Shortly thereafter, Mr. Campbell, who

title: Cherry Released By Bruins
description: BOSTON, May 24 (AP)  The Boston Bruins released Coach Don Cherry today from his National Hockey League contract, which runs through July, and announced a parting with the volatile coach after his bitter feud with the front office.

title: United's $108 Ticket Approved
description: The Government gave its approval yesterday to United Airlines, which resumes service Monday after a 55day strike, for a norestrictions $108 oneway fare on all nonstop flights between New York and Los Angeles.

title: Thinking Twice About Mergers
description: The best action on Wall Street these days is the merger game. Dozens of major firms, including McGrawHill, Fairchild Instruments, Reliance Electric and Fiiestone, have been targeted for acquisition by other companies intent on growth through product diversification.

title: Surgery Is Scheduled For Murphy of Braves
description: ATLANTA, May 24 (AP)  Dale Murphy, a catcherfirst baseman for the Atlanta Braves who is among the National League leaders in home runs with 13 and runs batted in with 37, will undergo surgery for a torn cartilage in his left knee.

title: 6 Awards by Press Club For Jonestown Coverage
description: The Overseas Press Club yesterday announced six awards for coverage of the Jonestown massacre in Guyana, including two posthumous awards to an NBC news correspondent and an NBC cameraman slain along with Representative Leo J. Ryan. Democrat of California, during the Congressman's investigatory trip to Jonestown.

title: Ballet: Bujones in 'swan
description: SWAN Lake is a traditional test of technique, artistry and even mettle for the ballerina dancing the double role of the Swan Princess Odette and Odile, her evil counterpart. On Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House, however, the American Ballet Theater's production of the classic belonged to its Prince Siegfried, Fernando Bujones.

title: Israeli Settlers Battle Army Over Land Loss To Egypt, Then Leave
description: EL ARISH, IsraeliOccupied Sinai, May 24 (Reuters)  Israeli settlers opposing the loss of farmland to Egypt fought off eviction for a time today by pelting Israeli soldiers with melons, tomatoes and stones, spraying them with insecticide and rolling barrels downhill at them. but the settlers withdrew several hours later after Deputy Prime Minister Yigael Yadin, hastily summoned from his office, in Jerusalem, told them that Prime Minister Menachem Begin had promised to take up the matter of continued access to the fields when he meets with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt in El Arish Sunday. Mr. Yadin obtained the promise by telephone from Mr. Begin, who is on a visit to London.

title: Rutgers Hopes jolted In 11Inning, 32 Loss
description: The Rutgers University women's softball team entered the National Collegiate championships as the only unbeaten team, with a pitcher whose earnedrun average was almost perfect. The skeptics were out in force last night in Omaha and watched Rutgers, in its first tournament appearance, lose its perfect record, 32, in 11 innings to Northern Colorado.

title: Esmark Profits Advance 11.3%
description: Despite a $10.5 million plunge in earnings of Swift meatpacking operations, Esmark Inc., the parent holding company, reported yesterday an 11.3 percent rise in net income to $23.6 million, or $1.13 a share, for the second fiscal quarter ended April 28, up from a restated net of $21.2 million, or $1.02 share, for the 1978 quarter to reflect last September's acquisition of Pemcor Inc. Revenues were $1.7 billion.

title: Dance: 2 by Balanchine
description: TWO of George Balanchine's most unusual works for the New York City Ballet turned up on the same program Wednesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: DIESEL FUEL SUPPLY IS CRITICALLY LOW; PRICES UP SHARPLY
description: The supply of diesel fuel, which powers much of the surface transportation equipment used in the United States, has fallen sharply. And prices, like those of gasoline, are skyrocketing.

title: Six Arrested in Soviet Spy Plot
description: CAIRO, May 24 (AP)  Documents found in a raid on the Bulgarian Embassy last December have led to the arrest of six Egyptians, including two former members of Parliament, on espionage charges, Interior Minister Nabawy Ismail announced today. Mr. Ismail, describing the plot as an attempt to impose Soviet influence on Egypt, said the spies acted on Kremlin orders to try to penetrate the Egyptian presidency, Foreign Ministry, the military and other organizations.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, May 24 (UPI)  A Federal court jury convicted four Serbian nationalists late today on charges of plotting to kill Yugoslav diplomats in Chicago.

title: Was New Investigation Chief Given Signal?
description: Was Governor Carey sending out a signal when he summarily dismissed Eric A Selff, the chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, without any explanation? That is the critical question facing the new chairman, Adam Walinsky.

title: Irving N. Fisher, 78, Drama Critic And ExCurator of Yale's Library
description: Irving Norton Fisher, retired curator of the Yale University Library, died yesterday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 78 years old and had been retired for almost 10 years.

title: Deaths
description: DRACHSamuel. The HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Centre records with sorrow the passing of the father of its member Stanley Drake and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family.

title: Screen: Sellers in New 'Zenda':A Comic Version
description: PETER SELLERS is the only real reason to see "The Prisoner of Zenda," which opens today in a new, comic version at the Ziegfeld Theater. But as reasons go, Peter Sellers is an awfully good one. The film that has been constructed around him has its share of dead air, and every time the emphasis turns to derring-do, the director, Richard Quine, seems well over his head. But when Mr. Sellers appears, playing either one of the two characters he tackles here, the film really does come to life, and not simply for its humor. Here, as in "Dr. Strangelove," Mr. Sellers is dividing his energies between a serious character and a funny one. And the serious performance is, in many ways, the more remarkable of the two.Actually, "two" isn't accurate  for a few brief moments at the film's opening, Mr. Sellers plays a third fellow who dies after uncorking a bottle of champagne while riding in a hot air balloon. (The cork punctures the fabric, of course.) Then he becomes both the King of Ruritania, who behaves like a marvelously effete English playboy with yet another of Mr. Sellers's superb speech defects, and a Cockney cab-driver who is absolutely deadpan.For anyone unfamiliar with the first several-screen versions of "The Prisoner of Zenda," or even with the book, these two lookalikes are forced by considerations of Ruritanian politics to chance places. The Cockney falls in love with the real King's fiance (Lynne Frederick), who hates the real King but must marry him. (Her country's economy depends on the Ruritanian potato supply.) Complications ensue, and so do some intermittent but genuinely funny gags. There is a hackneyed jealous-husband routine that works better than it ought to, and one swashbuckler's entire speaking part seems to consists of hearty ha-ha-ha's. In one sequence, Mr. Sellers and Catherine Schell wind up trading chicken calls with several sets of villains and one authentic owl.Mr. Sellers is onscreen with himself surprisingly often, and the effect never looks trumped-up. He performs a perfect balancing act, orchestrated so well that the funny character makes the serious one even more effective, and vice versa."The Prisoner of Zenda" doesn't have the kind of finesse that Blake Edwards's direction has given the "Pink Panther" series. But the slack moments are painless enough, and they come as a fair exchange for the pleasure of Mr. Seller's artfully schhizoid company."The Prisoner of Zenda" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It contains minimal violence and a subplot that involves marital infidelity.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 25 (Reuters)  President Tito, apparently in excellent physical and mental condition, celebrated his 87th birthday toclay.

title: Gasoline Costs Spur 1.1% Rise in Prices
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 Higher costs for gasoline, housing and food pushed inflation well into the doubledigit zone again last month and brought the largest decline in worker purchasing power in 16 months, the Government reported today.

title: Col. Stedman S. Hanks, Airport Engineer, Writer
description: Col. Stedman Shumway Hanks, U.S.A.F., retired, an airport engineer and writer, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: Two Police Officers Hurt Slightly In Bronx by Man With a Shotgun
description: A Bronx man has been charged with attempted murder after firing a shotgun and slightly wounding two police officers last night. the notice said

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American E xchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Green Thumbs Sprouting in the Suburbs
description: WESTBURY, L.I., May 25  Ever since he moved to Rockland County three years ago, William Beharnna has puttered around in his backyard garden because, he said, it makes him feel like a country squire. Pat Marx, who gardens on Long Island, says that she will invest the time needed to tend the little plot of vegetables in her backyard so that, come August, she will spend as little time as possible in the produce section of her supermarket.

title: Radiation Hangover at Test Area Leads to Evacuation in Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 25 (AP) About a dozen families left their homes today after state officials confirmed that highlevel radioactivity had been found in animal life near a former underground nuclear test site.

title: The Wrong Symbol in Germany
description: The one thing the German people didn't need at this stage of their development was to have the foreign press carry headlines like ExNazi Voted West German President. The choice of Karl Carstens for that symbolic post would be jarring any time; it was especially so on a day that should have been an occasion for Western celebration: the 30th anniversary of the Bonn Republic.

title: State Opens Bids for the Sale of Love Canal Houses
description: BUFFALO, May 25 (AP)  Men and women on opposing sides of the controversy over, the Love Canal toxicchemical dump in Niagara Falls taunted one another yesterday at an emotionally charged meeting as state officials opened bids for the sale of abandoned homes along the old dump site.

title: NO SURVIVORS FOUND
description: CHICAGO, May 25  An American Airlines jetliner lost an engine and crashed shortly after takeoff from O'Hare International Airport this afternoon, killing all 272 persons aboard. It was the worst disaster in United States aviation history.

title: Housen, Vanderbush Take Wilson Cup Golf Tourney
description: HARTSDALE, N.Y., May 25  Bob Housen, the New Jersey state amateur champion, and Warren Vanderbush of Woodlake captured the eighth annual Charles E. Wilson Cup invitation golf tournament, combining to shoot 103 in heavy rain that caused the event to be reduced from 36 to 27 holes.

title: Navy Troubled by Career Force Losses
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. ,INDEPEND  ENCE, off Puerto Rico, May 18  Juan Ortega, a 22yearold hull technician, is going back to his family's farm in New Mexico after his fouryear Navy stint ends next year.

title: Harrelson Is Back With the Phillies
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (UPI)  Bud Harrelson, 34 years old, came out of retirement today to sign with the Philadelphia Phi!lies following an injury to Larry Bova, their regular shortstop, who was placed on the 15day disabled list with a broken thumb.

title: President, Angered Over Setbacks, Urges Leadership From Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  President Carter, stung by a series of defeats on Capitol Hill, lashed out today at the demagoguery and politrcal timidity that he said had made the American people doubt the courage and effectiveness of their political leaders.

title: Abrams Acts to Avert Walkout Threatened By 800 Court Officers
description: The New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, obtained a temporary restraining order yesterday in an effort to head off a strike threatened for early next week by 800 State Supreme Court officers in New York City.

title: Nigerian Oil Up $2.45 A Barrel
description: Nigeria has raised the price of its oil by about $2.45 a barrel, bringing its top grade of crude to almost $21 a barrel, according to oil company sources in New York. The move, retroactive to May 16, mirrors a similar increase by Algeria earlier this week and puts new pressure on Libya, whose oil now sells for about 8 percent less than its African competitors, to join the move to higher prices.

title: CONTROVERSY RAISED BY DC10 ACCIDENTS
description: The DC10, manufactured by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, had had only three fatal accidents before yesterday. But it nevertheless has been one of the most controversial planes ever to fly the airways.

title: CurrentEvents TV Piograms Designed for Youth
description: Plans have been formulated for a daily, live, halfhour currentevents television program produced for distribution to high schools throughout the country by PBS satellite. All that is lacking is the money  an estimated $3 million to $5 million for a year's operation.

title: The City
description: The body of a man tentatively identified as Martin Paretzky, a 71yearold diamond dealer who disappeared nearly four months ago when he was believed to have been carrying as much as $500,000 in diamonds, was found floating in the Hudson River yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 25 Delaware University blasted four home runs as it defeated .Seton Hall University, 101, today in the opening game of, the National Collegiate Eastern Regional baseball tournament. The victory avenged a defeat suffered earlier this month.

title: Keys
description: CANAL FULTON, Ohio  Because there were tuition bills to pay and boring books to buy, I took the job: one of those 20houraweekandalldaySaturday deals that nobody ever wants except college students, retirees and divorcees. America at the time was corning out of the moonshot recession on the verge of a postVietnam slowdown  and since all the hippies everywhere were cutting their hair, I decided to go to work.

title: Fog Halts Olympic Sailing
description: NEWPORT, R.I., May 25 (AP) The first race in the preliminary Olympic sailing trials was canceled today because of fog. More than 300 yachtsmen aboard 188 boats had registered for the opening. Two races were scheduled for tomorrow, weather permitting

title: Geneva, Bastion of the Bankers, Chooses First Communist Mayor
description: GENEVA, May 25 (UPI)  Geneva, bastion of the Swiss banking establishment, will have its first Communist Mayor.

title: Jeanne Calderon Wed To Gary M. Friedland
description: Jeanne April Calderon and Gary Mitchell Friedland, 1978 alumni of the Georgetown University Law Center, were married yesterday. Rabbi Sally Priesand performed the ceremony in her study at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue. The bride had been associated with the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy. Her husband is with the law firm of Tucker, Flyer, Sanger, Reider & Lewis in Washington, where the couple will live.

title: BMT Token Clerk Slain
description: A token clerk was shot and killed early yesterday in his booth at a deserted BMT subway station in the East New York section of Brooklyn. He was murdered just a month after he had been robbed at gunpoint in the same booth.

title: Bridge:
description: Whether any particular business activity tends to be associated with bridge expertise is an interesting question. Discounting the computer specialists, who nowadays are spread evenly throughout the business world, the answer appears to be insurance.

title: District Attorney's Clerk Uncovers Theft of Check
description: A New York City computer analyst accused of stealing $5,600 from the city was caught because he allegedly altered payment voucher submitted by the Manhattan District Attorney's office, according to an indictment filed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Mariners 3, Rangers 2
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 25 (AP) Bruce Bochte and Julio Cruz delivered runscoring singles and Shane Rawley squelched a Texas rally in the ninth inning tonight to lead the Seattle Mariners to a 32 victory over the Rangers in the first game of a doubleheader.

title: Marxist Regime in South Yemen Showing Improvement in Quality of Life in Villages
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, May 20  Once a major port and naval base on the route from the Arabian Sea to Europe, this steamy capital is shabby and listless, with many shops closed and its markets nearly bare. However, villages in the interior, neglected for centuries, are described by Government officials as prospering, with schools, clinics and farm cooperatives in place for the first time.

title: Egypt and Israel Open Negotiations At Beersheba on Palestinian Areas
description: BEERSHEBA, Israel, May 25  Two months after they signed a peace treaty. Egypt and Israel formally opened negotiations today to try to find a solution to the contentious Palestinian issue.

title: 2 Terrorists in Madrid Assassinate General and 2 Colonels in Ambush
description: MADRID, May 25 (AP)  Two terrorists disguised as laborers killed a general, two colonels and their chauffeur in machinegun and grenade attack today in Madrid in one of the country's worst urban guerrilla attacks in recent years.

title: Costs of Fuel and Housing Lead Rise in New YorkArea Price Index
description: Rising costs of fuel, transportation and housing in the New York area sent the Consumer Price Index soaring nearly 1 percent last month, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Honda's Profit Plunges
description: The Honda Motor Company yesterday reported a 48.9 percent drop in profits for the fiscal year ended Feb. 28. The plunge was attributed to the appredation of the yen against foreign currencies in most of the company's foreign markets, which reduced profit margins on overseas sales of Honda Products.

title: Markets Schedule
description: The schedule for Greenmarkets in the city are as follows, with most markets open from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. The World Trade Center market will be open from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: W.A. Darlington, ExStage Critic For London's Daily Telegraph, 89
description: W.A. Darlington, dean of London's theater critics, author of the World War 1 comedy Alf's Button and a regular contributor to The New York Times between 1929 and 1960, died yesterday in a Seaford, England, nursing home. Ile was R9 years old.

title: ADELBERT CAMERON
description: Adelbert (Del) Cameron, a member of harness racing's Hall of Fame, died early yesterday at Delaware Valley Hospital in Wilmington, Del. He was 58 years old.

title: Roth Undergoes Surgery, Will Be Out Indefinitely
description: Werner Roth, the captain of the Cosmos, underwent surgery for removal of the medial cartilege in his right knee yesterday and will be lost to the team indefinitely. Dr. James Nicholas performed the operation at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TEAM TONES A gala spring concert benefiting the Greenwich House Music School is scheduled for 3 P.M. tomorrow, with a taxdeductibleadmission of $10 and a varied lineup of entertainers. The place is New York University's School of Education Auditorium, 35 West Fourth Street, and a reception will follow in the garden of the music school at 46 Barrow Street.

title: U.S. Loses in Volleyball
description: TOKYO May 25 (AP)  The United States national men's volleyball team lost to China's national team today, 158, 615, 1511, 1510 . The matches were part of an annual invitation tournament, which this year features China Japan and the United States.

description: Because of a typographical error, the assets under supervision of the United States Trust Company of New York were incorrectly stated in Business Day on Wednesday. The correct figure is $11.5 billion.

description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, MUSIC IN MAY. Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center. 8.

title: Provenzano and Associates Found Guilty of Extortion
description: NEWARK, May 25  A Federal jury today found a former teamsters official, Anthony (Tony Pro) Provenzano, and three codefendants, guilty of conspiring to extort thousands of dollars from Seatrain Lines, one of the nation's largest containerizedcargo shippers, in return for labor peace.

title: About New York A Quiet Pleasure in the Silence of the Grave
description: After Rosemary Cashman, mother of nine (including a fine Flatbush balance of a nurse, an F.B.I. agent and a seminarian), warns about her husband setting up his slide projector, she quietly leaves the room.

title: Exxon Bids $1 Billion for Reliance
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, has made a $1.17 billion tender offer for the Reliance Electric Company. If the transaction goes through, it would be one of the biggest cash takeovers in corporate history.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Hoover Company announced yesterday that Judge Leroy J. Contie Jr. of United States District Court in Akron, Ohio, had ordered Fuqua Industries not to acquire or offer to acquire any additional shares of Hoover's common stock.

title: Irma Louis Worrell Married To Dr. Robert Leon Fisher
description: The marriage of Irma Louis Worrell, manager of business affairs for Young & Rubicam, an advertising agency, to Dr. Robert Leon Fisher, an orthodontist, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Shames. Justice Theodore R. Kupferman of the Appellate Division, State Supreme Court, performed the ceremony.

title: Making Job Agencies Earn Their Keep
description: There is at least one thing on which Senator Kennedy and the White House agree these days  the need for better results from Federal teenage job programs.

title: Rock: Cheap Trick Displays Original Visual Style
description: Cheap Trick is charging full tilt into the upper echelons of rock stardom mostly on the strength of its funny and original visual style. Most new rock bands look and act as if they have taken a correspondence course in grooming, costuming, and stage moves  the same course all the other bands took. The Cheap Trick's lead guitarist, Rick, Nielsen, seems to have learned from Buster Keaton, and the drummer, Bun E. Carlos, could have been shanghaied from a Phillip Marlowe mystery. Robin Vander, the lead vocalist, and Tom Petersson, the bassist, look and act more like conventional rock stars; if they didn't, the group's shows would be more like circuses than like rock n roll.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 47.

title: Canadian Election: A Tonic for Separatists
description: MONTREAL, May 25  Nationalist forces in Quebec have apparently been revitalized by a federal election Tuesday that divided the country ethnically and sustained their contend/in that Canada is really two nations.

title: The Stage: Lone Canoe, Allegory by David Mamet
description: CHICAGO, May 25  It is possible to find an intention in David Mamet's new musical play, Lone Canoe. But like cook asleep in the back room of a restaurant, it has to be sought out, and even then it has nothing to serve us.

title: Davona Dale: Bring On Colts
description: Outside the barn at Belmont Park where Davona Dale and Alydar reside rain continued dripping off the slanted green roof. But the mood inside,. along a comfortably .dry shedrow, was one of cheerful anticipation. Davona Dale and AJydar both will be going to the post this weekend. As usual, the Calumet Farm barn looked like an orphanage for cats.

title: OBSERVER Pillovved As In Araby
description: Apartment hunters in New York quickly learn about the Arabs. Agents show two bedrooms and rusty plumbing and say, This one's only $250,000. Isn't that a little steep? It's the Arabs, is the reply.

description: The French Boot is coming to New York City.

title: Northrop Finds Profit In FullService Pacts
description: ENID, Okla.  What keeps the airplanes flying at Vance Air Force Base here is a corps of 1,200 civilians: former wheat farmers turned groundskeepers, former homemakers applying their skills in the mess hall, former service station mechanics finetuning broken training aircraft.

title: Levy's Bakers to Close, Selling Name to Arnold
description: Henry S. Levy & Son, the baker of Levy's Bread (You don't have to be Jewish to love Levy's real Jewish rye), has sold its name to Arnold Bakers, of Greenwich, Conn., and will soon close its Brooklyn bakery and end nearly 100 years of operations in the New York City area, Samuel C. Rubin, Levy's president, said last night.

title: Ballet: The Four Temperaments
description: Every so often, the difference between the New York City Ballet and every other ballet company in the world flashes out with blinding light. And nowhere is it more obvious than in a work such as The Four Temperaments, which had its first performance of the season Thursday night at the State Theater.

title: Notes on People
description: A Gold Medal to Cheer John Wayne on His 72d Birthday

title: The City's Greenmarkets: Fresh Produce and Controversy
description: It sounds so easy: Get a few farmers to cart their corn and tomatoes, apples and quince to the city a few days each week, and turn drab vacant lots into booming outdoor markets. Neighborhoods will be transformed, struggling farmers will flourish and all will be right with the world.

title: Morales Fled From U.S., Phone Caller Tells F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that it had received an anonymous telephone call from a man who said William Morales had fled the United States.

title: Utility Allowed Securities Sale
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 25 (AP)  The Metropolitan Edison Company, the financially troubled operator of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, has received authorization to sell $250 million in securities.

title: Burris Is Resigned To Role as Reliever
description: CLEVELAND, May 25 With hopes higher than his earnedrun average, Ray Burris, the newest Yankee, was forced to temper his enthusiasm somewhat today when the night game against the Cleveland Indians was postponed by rain. It will be made up during the Yankees visit here in September.

title: No Shift In Fed Rate Policy Seen
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  Contrary to a widespread belief in the money markets, the Federal Reserve System's top policymaking body did not authorize a shift toward higher interest rates when it conferred on April 27, according to a Federal Reserve report published today.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Economy

title: Board of Regents Lifts Probation For a BedfordStuyvesant School
description: The New York State Board of Regents has voted unanimously to lift the probationary status it imposed a year ago on Boys and Girls High School in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn. The school had been plagued in recent years by violence and low academic performance.

title: Piano Recital: Shehori Plays Three Sonatas
description: Since his debut in New York five years ago, Mordecai Shehori has apparently developed quite a following. On Thursday night, a virtually capacity crowd filled the Kaufman Auditorium of the 92d Street Y for his latest recital, and it listened with the closest attention to his planing. The Israeli pianist repeated two works he had performed in New York before, the Liszt B minor Sonata and Beethoven's 32 Variations in C minor on an Original Theme. Besides these, the program included a Scarlatti Sonata in E (L. 23), Mozart's Sonata in A minor (K. 310), the BachBusoni Chaconne and Moriz Rosenthal's Carnival of Vienna on Themes by Johann Strauss.

title: Mets, Pirates Tied in 11 th, Fog Halts Game
description: Fog dense enough to make the figures on the scoreboard barely visible forced the game between the New York Mets and the Pittsburgh Pirates to be called in the 11th inning last night with the score tied, 33, before a paid crowd of 6,611.

title: Karen McMennamin Is Wed to Jochen Bene
description: Karen Foster McMennamin, a former marketing representative with the International Business Machines Corporation in New York, and Jochen Cristoph Bene, a director of the GermanAfrica Lines in Hamburg, Germany, were married yesterday in St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan. Conn. The Rev. Alfred H. Whisler, the rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Alexander Says Army Counseled Keeping Ft. Dix
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  The Secre tary of the Army disclosed today that the Defense Department, in deciding to close Fort Dix, N.J., in.March, had rejected an Army recommendation to keep the base open and to close basictraining activities in other parts of the country.

title: Polish Dissident Quickly Freed
description: WARSAW, May 25 (UPI)  The police released a leading dissident, Jacek Kuron, today after detaining him for nearly 48 hours. The action was viewed as a warning that critics of the Communist Government would not be allowed to exploit the visit by Pope John Paul II early next month. Mr. Kuron, a sociologist, was held in Cracow, where he went Tuesday for a meeting with other members of the Dissident Committee for Social SelfDefense.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: ExBudget Manager Is Accused Of Taking $148,000at WCBSTV
description: A former televisionnetwork accounting executive was indicted yesterday on charges of defrauding WCBSTV of more than $148,000 by creating a fictitious production company and employees.

title: Vilas Gains Semifinal in Italian Net
description: ROME, May 25 (AP)  Starting and finishing strongly, topseeded Guillermo Vitas of Argentina advanced today to the semifinals of the $200,000 Italian open tennis championships. Vilas survived two match points before he subdued Adriano Panatta of Italy, 61. 67. 75.

title: Brewers 3, A's 2
description: MILWAUKEE, May 25 (AP)  Gorman Thomas singled home the winning run with two out in the eighth inning and Sixto Lezcano hit two basesempty home runs to lead the Milwaukee Brewers to a 32 victory over the Oakland A's tonight.

title: Students Learn to Relax and Expel the Exam Jitters
description: During the next three weeks, students in about half of the country's colleges and universities and in most high schools will still be cramming for final exams 6and some will be torturing themselves with so much anxiety that their fears may become selffulfilling prophesies: Fear of failing blocks other thoughts and You're waiting for the final exam to begin. The professor is taking forever to sort out the exam booklets and your hands feel clammy. You don't know what kind of a test it's going to be and all the material you studied is flashing back and forth inside your head, which begins to throb. Important names and dates blur and slip away.

title: Textile Talks With China Stall
description: PEKING, May 25 (AP)  ChineseAmerican textile negotiations ended today without an agreement, raising some doubts that Congress will approve a trade accord initialed by the two sides when Commerce Secretary Juanita M. Kreps was in China earlier this month.

title: FLORIDA EXECUTES KILLER AS PLEA FAILS
description: STARKE, Fla., May 25  The state of Florida trussed. John Arthur Spenkelink immobile in the electric chair this Morning, dropped a black leather mask over his face and electrocuted him.

title: Yields on Bills Off at Treasury
description: Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and the 182day maturities.

title: News Summary
description: The Sinai capital was returned to Egypt after a dozen years of Israeli military occupation. Egyptians cheered, prayed and wept as the Israeli flag flying over El Arish was lowered and the Egyptian flag raised. There was scuffling between some Egyptian youths and the Israeli soldiers, but violence was averted. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock exchanges, commodities markets, most businesses and most banks throughout the United States will be closed Monday because of the Federal observance of Memorial Day.
