title: Presuming Too Much
description: The presumption of innocence  that a person innocent until proved guilty  isn't in the written Constitution, but it is basic. The Supreme Court 84 years ago called it the undoubted law, axiomatic and elementary, and its enforcement lies at the foundation of the administration of our criminal law. But the current Court majority seems bent on reading it out of the unwritten law.

title: Plays About Vietnam War Scheduled for Highlighting
description: Plays dealing with the Vietnam War will be highlighted in a special performance at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater/Cabaret on Monday at 8 P.M.

title: Steinbrenner: Martin Back in 80
description: CLEVELAND, May 25 (AP) George Steinbrenner, making his strongest statement of support on the subject, said on a radio talk show today, Billy Martin is my manager in 1980.

title: Stronger Dollar Irks Europe and Japanese
description: PARIS, May 25  Western Europe and Japan have a new complaint about the dollar it is getting too strong, and mat means higher prices for all the goods priced in dollars, most notably, oil produced by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Gentlemen And Lady, Start Your Engines
description: RENO, Nev.  I have decided to forego the Indianapolis 500 this year.

title: City Starts Programs To Enable It to Return Housing to Tax Rolls
description: A major effort to return cityowned dwellings to the tax rolls began yesterday with the start of three separate programs that are expected to lead to the sale of more than 150 buildings containing 3,500 apartments.

title: A Curtain of Fog Descends on the City
description: The seeming solitude of a city wrapped in fog complemented that of a lone stroller walking along an abandoned pier in Jersey City. More damp weather is forecast for today, but the National Weather Service gives hope for some sun tomontow and a fair day on Memorial Day  if you celebrate it on Monday

title: NuclearWater Dumping Halted
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 25 (AP)  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today banned the discharge of highly radioactive waste water from the Three Mile Island nuclear generating plant into the Susquehanna River until an environmental study is made.

title: Chronology of Air Disasters
description: The American Airlines crash at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago yesterday in which 272 persons were killed was the nation's worst domestic air crash and the world's third worst civil disaster. Previous major international and domestic air disasters include the following:

title: In Beersheba, Desert May Become a Bridge
description: BEERSHEBA, Israel, May 25  The desert stretching out from the stark concrete buildings of the BenGurion University of the Negev can become a bond, a bridge between Israel and Egypt, said the university's president, Yosef Tekoah. today.

description: Black American groups have mounted one of their largest lobbying efforts on an international issue in an attempt to persuade the Carter Administration not to revoke sanctions against Rhodesia.

description: TOKYO, May 25  Suntory Ltd.. the Japanese producer of one of the world's biggestselling brands of Scotchtype whisky, Suntory Old, will begin selling to China later this month with the export of 500 cases of whisky valued at more than $100,000.

title: Blacks at Southern Parley Debate Whether to Support Carter in 1980
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 25  The first regional black political convention of the year opened here today, dominated by the question of whether blacks should support President Carter's reelection.

description: CORNING, N.Y., May 25 (AP) Judy Rankin sank a birdie putt on the 18th hole today to tie Susan O'Connor for the lead after two rounds of the rainplagued $100,000 Corning Classic.

title: Prominent Aide of Khomeini Is Wounded in Teheran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 25  Ayatollah Hashemi Rafsanjani, believed to be a member of the secret, ruling Revolutionary Council, was shot and wounded near his home here tonight. It was the third recent shooting of an important Iranian revolutionary figure.

title: General Motors Predicts Record Year for Car Sales
description: DETROIT, May 25  The General Motors Corporation, asserting that the nation's economy still has considerable forward momentum, today reaffirmed its belief that 1979 would be another year of strong sales for the American automobile industry.

title: A Partial Listing of the Those Who Died in Jetliner Crash in Chicago
description: Following is a partial list, released by American Airlines, of crew members and passengers that were killed. The list was provided by The Associated Press.

title: The World Invades Booksellers Meeting
description: LOS ANGELES, May 26  This is the year of the internationalization of book publishing in the United States. Last year, the cry could be heard at the American Booksellers Association's annual convention in Atlanta that the British are coming, the British are coming. At this year's gathering of the book community here, where 20,000 publishers, sellers and others who create and market books are present, the British are no longer coming, they are here, and in record numbers.

title: Death Penalty Opponents Embittered by Execution
description: Opponents of capital punishment reacted with anger and bitterness to yesterday's execution of John A. Spenkelink. Several protests were staged around the country, including one outside the Supreme Court in Washington, where 13 demonstrators were arrested.

title: Schlesinger Decries Sohio Pipeline's End
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that the Administration was extremely disappointed by the decision of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) to cancel its plan to build a $1 billion pipeline from California to Texas.

title: Your Money
description: WITH the cost for a year at the nation's most expensive colleges and universities next fall expected to surpass $9,000, students will be searching harder than ever for ways to finance their education

title: Soviet Assails West Berlin Role In Vote for European Parliament
description: MOSCOW, May 25 (AP)  West Berlin's participation in the election of the European Parliament next month is a grave violation of the 1971 fourpower agreement on Berlin, Pravda charged today.

title: Freshman Congressman Learns to Settle for Small Triumphs After Enthusiastic Start
description: WASHINGTON. May 20  Five months ago Michael L. Synar was sworn in as a freshman member of the United States Congress, bursting with wideeyed enthusiasm and the firm conviction that he was the luckiest 28yearold in the country. Today he still relishes the job, but he is a weary man who has learned to settle for small triumphs and small joys.

title: Onetime Polish Capital Wears Clean Facade for First Visit by a Pope
description: GNIEZNO, Poland, May 23This town, the first seat of Poland's rulers a milennium ago, is preparing to receive a Pone for the first time.

title: Flattened Debris and Bodies All Over
description: CHICAGO, May 25 The plane just lost power and slowly rolled over on its side, George Owens, a witness to the worst domestic air crash in history, said today shortly after the fiery disaster at O'Hare International Airport here.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Justice Dept. Discloses Inquiry Into Financing of Carter 76 Ads
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI)  The Justice Department has been conducting a preliminary inquiry into financing by Rafshoon Advertising Inc. of advertising in Jimmy Carter's 1976 campaign for the Presidency, the department disclosed today.

title: OilRig Jobs: Perils and Rewards
description: COGNAC PLATFORM, Gulf of Mexico It rises out of the dull blue waters of the Gulf of Mexico like a giant Erector set, battleship gray broken by bright yellow cranes and guard rails, rows of red valves and machinery cov ered with babyblue shields

title: The Legislator as Educator
description: The modem legislator, with some admirable exceptions, has discarded the role of educator in favor of performing services for his constituents  and not really the constituents as community, but the bestorganized, bestfunded, and most politically active interest groups within the constituency.

title: Thames Stocked With Salmon
description: LONDON, May 25 (AP)  Three thousand salmon fingerlings were released into a tributary of the Thames yesterday. The Thames Water Authority hopes to reestablish the salmon breeding cycle in the nver, which was almost sterile only

title: Books of The Times Glamour Can Kill You
description: What Nancy Cunard most wanted to be, she said in answer to a questionnaire, was impervious, egocentric, concentrated, secret, unquestionable and yet all things to all men. She suc

title: Joan Joyce Hurls China NoHitter
description: PEKING, May 25 (UPI)  The Con necticut Falcons, champions of American women's softball, won the sixth and final game of their China tour today when Joan Joyce pitched a nobitter in a 10 victory over a Chinese allstar team in the city of Lanzhou.

title: Gas Lines Touch Off Arguments; Price Hits a Record in Manhattan
description: Gasoline shortages caused arguments at service stations on Long Island yesterday and forced the posting of police officers to direct a line of waiting motorists in Manhattan. Meanwhile, prices rose to record levels 56.5 cents a halfgallon at a Getty station in lower Manhattan.

title: Answers to Ouiz
description: Questions appear on page 24.

title: Deaths
description: HESSAda(nee Davis), Thursday, May 24, Miami, Fla. Beloved wife Henry Hess of Miami. Fla., mother of Robert L. of Glen Coe. Illinois Judith A. of MiaMI, Fla. Sister Tillie Davis Rene, Miriam Davis Farkas, both of Los Angeles, Jean Davis Fogel of New York, Davis of West Palm Beach, Bernard Davis, Monroe Davis New York. Grandmother of Carl, Laura, Jonathan and Roper of Coe, II. Services from the BloomfieldCooper Funeral Chapel, Highway 35, Ocean Township, Rabbi Murray Ezring officiating. Interment at the Chesed Shel Ernet Cemetery, West Banks Avenue, Neptune. N.J.

title: Chicago Board Plans Addit ion
description: CHICAGO, May 15 (UPI)  The board of directors of the Chicago Board of Trade will hold a special meeting next Thurday to complete plans for an addition of at least 23 stories to its existing exchange structure, the board president. Robert Wilmouth said today.

title: Literary Couple Reported on Jet
description: Sheldon Wax, the managing editor of Playboy magazine, and Judith Wax, a Chicagobased freelance writer and humorist, were among the passengers booked on the American Airlines flight that crashed in Chicago yesterday, the airline said last night.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)  A military judge ordered a further investigation today into an involuntary manslaughter charge leveled against the captain of a Coast Guard cutter that was involved in a fatal collision on Chesapeake Bay. The judge then adjourned the hearing without setting a date for the skipper's courtmartial.

title: Facilities for 'shoppingBag Ladies And Battered Women Are Planned
description: Plans for a new storefront center to help shoppingbag ladies and two shelters for battered women in the Bronx and Queens were announced yesterday by Stanley Brezenoff, head of the city's Human Resources Administration, at a City Council budget hearing.

title: Exiled Brazilian Leader Hopes for Return Home
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  Leonel Brizola, a former Brazilian labor leader, says he hopes to end his I5year exile within weeks and return to Brazil to rebuild his banned Labor Party into a major opposition force.

title: Halston's Collection Adds a Classic Note To Fur Showings Finale
description: The Halston collection brought down the curtain on this year's major fur showings earlier this week. His customer is the sort of woman who thinks of a fur in the same way she might a diamond (it can cost just as much this year) and she doesn't want heretodayandgonetomorrow gimmicks. Since Ben Kahn, the furrier for whom Halston designs, travels the world for top pelts and the designer doesn't gussy them up, the Halston fan has a sense of security in her investment. Halston follows no one else's drummer. There isn't a shoulder pad in the entire collection, nor furs dyed in rainbow colors.

title: Art: The Tate Adds Galleries And Contexts
description: LONDON, May 25  With the opening tomorrow of its new extension, as it is discreetly called, the Tate Gallery  which functions, in effect, as London's Museum of Modern Art has acquired a significant addition to its permanent exhibition space. And in certain rooms of this construction especially the rooms devoted to the work of Alberto Giacometti, Mark Rothko, Naum Gabo and Henry Moore  the Tate has mounted collections that are likely to remain of permanent interest to connoisseurs of modernist art the world over.

title: Afghan Rebel Group Appeals in New York For Aid for Its Forces
description: A group called the Afghan National Liberation Front appealed in New York City yesterday for support for guerrillas attempting to overthrow the Marxist military regime in Afghanistan

title: Watson Leads by 4 at Muirfield
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, May 25  In 42degree weather, Tom Watson was one of only two golfers to break par today, shooting a 69 for a tworound score of 142 and a fourstroke lead in the $300,000 Memorial Tournament.

title: Auto Safety Hearing Postponed
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)  The Government today postponed for six weeks a public hearing on a possible safety defect in the fuel tanks of 197073 Ford Mavericks and 197173 Mercury Comets. The hearing had been set for next Tuesday but was delayed until July 13 at the request of the Ford Motor Company.

title: Short on Horsepower, but Long on Fuel
description: Rebekah Creshkoff and David O'Neil driving through midtown Manhattan yesterday in their fuelsaving Microcars. The 1.5 horsepower vehicle, designed by Stuart Pivar, resembles a threewheeled motorcycle and gets 70 80 miles per gallon of a mixture of gasoline and oil. Its size, however, magnifies the disadvantages shared by most vehicles in the city: cavernous potholes, intimidating trucks and taxis making right turns from left lanes.

title: Arthur Felberbaum, Was Active In Marxist Politics in New York
description: Arthur Felberbaum, who was active in leftwing politics in New York City, died of a heart attack Sunday at the School for Marxist Education, 830 Broadway, where he was attending a meeting. He was 44 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: John Roger Porter, 69, Is Dead; Head of Microbiology Societies
description: JOWA CITY, May 25 (UPI)  Dr. Johr Roger Porter, presidentelect of the Zq ternational Association of Microbiologt cal Societies, died last night at University Hosnital here. He was 69 years old.

title: The Rea L. H. Garner, ExConsultant on Labor
description: The Rev. L. Hamilton Gamer, who was an official of the National Labor Relations Board office in Newark and in the greater metropolitan area, died Thursday after a long illness at the Orange (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. Mr. Garner, who lived in West Orange, was 79 years old.

title: Takeover And Energy Issues Surge
description: Takeover stocks and Canadian oilandgas issues scored impressive gains yesterday as an acquisition frenzy continued to dominate Wall Street.

title: Memorial Day Closings and, Information on Travel and Gas Supplies
description: Under a 1967 Federal law creating a series of threeday holiday weekends, the last Monday in May was established as the official Memorial Day holiday, a practice followed by Connecticut. New Jersey and most other states, where the holiday will be observed tomorrow.

title: A Guide to WarmWeather Dining
description: DURING the warmer weather, dining out in Westchester takes on a very special meaning, for there are many special places where one can enjoy a leisurely meal alfresco, often surrounded by stunning scenery. The following list of such restaurants is meant as a guide not to the quality of the cuisine but to those places whereethe outdoor atmosphere can make for a romantic experience on a warm night.

title: Giving Science a Helping Hand
description: Excavating ruins in Scotland, exploring shipwrecks off Florida, protecting endangered wildlife in Hawaii are among several research expeditions not for scientists only offered by Earthwatch, a nonprofit organization based near Boston. Its programs give the lay person an opportunity to take part in scientific expeditions throughout the world.

title: 3 Slain in 3 Robberies in Brooklyn
description: Groups of robbers killed three men in separate incidents early yesterday in Brooklyn, and the police reported the arrest of a 20-year-old suspect M connection with two of the assaults.

title: From Womb to Tomb on the Chicken Farm
description: HURLOCK, Md.  Chick No. 138,021 flew wideeyed off a conveyor belt here at exactly 10:09 the other morning, one of about 200,000 cuddlycute, downy- yellow birds that are hatched, four days a week, 52 weeks a year, in fluffy freshet of fowl and profits for Bayshore Foods Inc..

title: Police Step Up Patrols At 119 Token Booths After Slaying of Clerk
description: City and Transit Authority police stepped up protection yesterday at 119 subway token booths not equipped with bulletresistant glass as a second teenager was charged with the murder of clerk in an attempted holdup at a station in the East New York section of Brooklyn early Friday.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Summer reading. This is the time of year that paperback people look forward to most eagerly. Between this weekend and Labor Day  traditionally their busiest season  they'll be stuffing the massmarket racks with books they hope buyers will carry away in armsful to read on the beach or at poolside.

title: CARTER DISPATCHING AN AIDE TO MOROCCO
description: WASHINGTON, May 26  President Carter, responding to a request from King Hassan H, is sending a high Defense Department official to Morocco for talks on the political situation in the Middle East and growing strains in MoroccanAmerican relations.

title: Canada Decides It's Time to Change
description: As Prime Minister for 11 years, Pierre Elliott Trudeau tried to become a symbol of unity for the two cultures of Canada. Last week, his Liberal Party was defeated in elections that showed the country more divided than ever. Liberal support came over- whelmingly from Quebec and smaller Frenchspeaking islands in Englishdominated Canada. The rest of Canada elected as Prime Minister a cleancut Albertan named Joe Clark.

title: Poet of Democracy And of Running, Swimming, Sailing
description: THIS Thursday is Walt Whitman's 160th birthday. Born on May 31, 1819, in West Hills, south of Huntington Station, Walt Whitman was a native son of Long Island. He wrote frequently and adoringly of his origins  Starting from fishshape Paumanok where I was born  and turned his great Leaves of Grass into the evangelpoem of comrades and of love.

title: Holiday Gets Off to a Sunny Start, With Road Traffic Reported Light
description: The Memorial Day weekend got off to a brisk start in the New York metropolitan area yesterday, with planes and trains Heavily booked and reservations hard to obtain. But traffic was relatively light on most highways, although gasoline seemed available for those who were will- ing to endure lines and rising prices, and to accept limits on purchases at many filling stations, especially in the suburbs.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Oh my God, whatever did we let ourselves become? is one of the last lines spoken in Abe Polsky's Devour the Snow, which will continue its workshop production at the Hudson Guild Theater for one more week. The answer to that agonized question is so intensely interesting on several counts that I urge you to get down to West 26th Street pronto, provided the intimate playhouse has any seats left.

title: Two Crippled Lives Mirror Disputes on Herbicides
description: Julio Martinez is a former Marine Corps machine gunner in Vietnam; Bob Ralston is a former cattle rancher in the foothills of the Ozarks. The two men live 500 miles from each other. They have never met, never heard of each other, are a generation apart; they come from dif- ferent backgrounds, different worlds. All they have in common, they say, is their poison.

title: Learns to Live With Developers
description: When sod is removed from the fields, he explained, the machine cutters take off less than onequarter inch of topsoil, but leave most of the grass's 24inch organic root mass in the soil to be converted into nutrients.

title: VANCE REPORTS U.S. WILL MAKE OVERTURE TO THE PALESTINIANS
description: Officials traveling with Mr. Vance said today that the Carter Administration, deeply concerned about the opposition in the Arab world to EgyptianIsraeli peace, was determined to make a goodfaith effort to reverse the condemnation of President Anwar elSadat under way in the Arab world.

title: The Doctoring of Mama Is She Now Fit for Broadway?
description: After hitting an iceberg in Philadelphia and enduring one of the most drastic overhauls in theatrical history, the musical version of I Remember Mama will sail into its Broadway opening Thursday night at the Majestic with all flags flying. Liv Ullmann will be singing in her first musical, the orchestra will be playing the latest Richard Rodgers score, and somewhere in the counting houses the people who put up $1,250,000 to launch the show will have their fingers tightly  crossed. The backers will be praying that Mama has been turned around sufficiently since it came under the fire of the Philadelphia critics to withstand the rigors of Broadway, which this sea- son has already seen several likely musicals capsize.

title: ISRAELIS SEEK ENVOY FOR PRIZE CAIRO JOB
description: JERUSALEM, May 25  Although es1 tablishment of full diplomatic relations between Egypt and Israel is still at least nine months off, the Israeli Government is already casting about for its first ambassador to Cairo.

description: LONG DAY'S JOURNEY: Cyclists in 24hour marathon ride in Central Park yesterday. Riders were stamped after each lap to verify distance traveled.

title: Robin Brantley, Writer, Is Married to Keith Love
description: Robin Ann Brantley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell H. Brantley of WinstonSalem, N.C., and Keith Sinclair Love, son of Ruth Sinclair Love and James Lindsay Love, both of Rock Hill. S.C., were married yesterday morning at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Warren Carr of the Wake Forest Baptist Church performed the ceremony.

title: A Talk With William Styron
description: IT was a wet spring day in Western Connecticut. The green hills and wooded valleys that surround William Styron's handsome yellow 19thcentury house were shrouded in fog. Within, it could have been one of those bustling households in the Deep South so lovingly depicted in Styron's novels: there seemed be a small army of children, servants and gardeners about. The busiest room of the house in which Styron, his wife, Rose, and their four children have lived since 1954 is a large, comfortable kitchen where guests are offered Styron's homemade soup and a Virginia ham ordered from a fellow in Surry County, near my hometown.

title: Catskills Hotels Turned to New Uses
description: On the grounds of the former Flagler Hotel in Fallsburg, N.Y., retarded adults till a garden whqe golfers once teed off. Guest rooms are now classrooms. The golf shop is an arts and crafts room and woodworking shop, and one of the bars is a home economics workshop.

title: Films and Plays About Vietnam Treat Everything but the War
description: The Academy Awards clinched it. Suddenly, we are told, the Vietnam War has become accepted as a proper subject for every form of American popu- lar art. The war has come out into the commercial artistic mainstream, ready to take Oscars, National Book Awards for fiction and hours of prime TV playtime. Now, while entertained, we can purge our doubts and guilts and heal the suppressed divisions of the war years. Indeed, the chairman of the department of psychiatry at North- western University, Dr. Harold Visotsky, has gone so far as to inform us that Hollywood is thus providing our own Nuremberg trials.

title: Americas Choose 7 Rights Judges
description: WASHINGTON, May 26  A University ,of Texas law professor who was one of the youngest inmates to survive the German extermination camp at Auschwitz, has been elected a judge on the new InterAmerican Court of Human Rights.

description: WASHINGTON,May 26  Paul J. Curran, the special Government counsel investigating bank loans to President Carter's family peanut business, has personally delivered a subpoena to the White House seeking records for the investigation

title: 2 Dead, 15 Injured in Blast At Coast Chemical Plant
description: PITTSBURG, Calif., May 26- A chemical processor exploded at the Dow Chernical Company plant here at 8:30 A.M. today, killing two workers and injuring about 15 others, four seriously.

title: MEXICO IS FOCUSING ON SEABED WEALTH
description: MEXICO CITY, May 26  Clarinn Island is an 11square.:raile dot in the Pacific covered by flowering cactus, surrounded by sandy beaches, guarded by schools of tuna and whales and, until recently, forgotten by its owner, the Mexican Government.

title: New Killings Last Week Did Not Diminish the Depth of Opposition
description: SAN SALVADOR  After the police killed 14 members of the Popular Revolutionary Bloc holding a peaceful demonstration last week, the antiGovernment coalition responded defiantly, The blood of our brothers has been spilled, but the historic struggle of the people will not stop.

Lee Stanton 3d, who received Master of Architecture degrees from Columbia University last year, were married yester- aay in the St. James Chapel at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, dean of the cathedral, and was followed by a reception at the Colony Club.

title: Two Saudis Each Lose a Hand
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, May 26 (AP) Two men convicted of robbing a bank each had a hand chopped off by order of an Islamic court, a Government announcement said today. The statement said the traditional punishrhent for theft contained in the Koran was carried out in Mecca yesterday.

title: Paperbacks:
description: SHOSHA, by Isaac Bashevis Singer. (Fawcett/ Crest, $2.50.) Aaron Greidinger, writer and rabbi's son, looks back on his life in Warsaw on the brink of World War 11 and his affairs with a variety of women, including sweet, backward Shosha, whom he loved most. This latest novel of the Nobel Prize winner contains  as our reviewer Alan Leichuk observed charming scenes, moving moments, a nice variety characters.

title: Elsie Hilliard Bride Of William Humes
description: The marriage of Elsie Talbott Hilliard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Jones Hilliard Jr. of Pittsburgh, to William McLain Humes took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. John Baiz, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, performed the ceremony.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The commercial cinema has so few truly inventive imaginations we can't afford to overlook any of them, no matter how wild. The ability to create and sustain a not always disciplined fantasy  a tale that effectively bypasses logic with a reality all its own  is a rare talent that distinguishes firstclass storytellers from mere narrators.

title: Rodgers Captures Run In the Rain at Wheeling
description: WHEELING, W.Va., May 26 (AP) Bill Rodgers added another victory to his record yesterday by winning the Wheeling Distance Race after lagging in second place for about twothirds of the 20kilometer run. The race was run in 95degree, drizzling weather.

I did my warmups easily, daydreaming my jogger's dream. Sure will complete the first shipboard marathon on this cruise! Guinness Book of. Records, here I come.

title: Why Do They Still Give Debut Recitals?
description: Most busy New York music lovers rush right by Carnegie Recital Hall on their way to the glamorous events in Carnegie Hall proper. They may notice the hopeful little flyers announcing singers and pianists and clarinetists and guitarists they've never heard of. But to judge from the erratic attendance at most of the concerts that take place there  or the obvious common bonds of family or friendship among those who do attend  it can be safely said that most of New York's tens of thousands of regular concertgoers regularly avoid Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Grieg's Full Version Of Peer Gynt
description: Some of the most popular symphonic music ever written was conceived not for the concert hall, but the theater. One thinks immediately of Men- delssohn's A Midsummer Night's Dream, easily one of his finest scores. Two favorite Beethoven overtures Egmont and Coriolan  were intended as curtainraisers for plays by Goethe and Heinrich Josef von Collin. Schubert's ballets and entr'actes for Rosamunde, a forgotten drama by Helmina von Chezy, include two of his bestknown melodies. If this century has produced nothing comparable plays, it seems, no longer attract the services of major composers  a couple of familiar film scores, Lieutenant Kije and Alexander Nevsky, figure prominently in Prokofiev's symphonic catalogue.

title: Blue Jays Stun Red Sox On 3Run Clout in 9th. 76

title: How to Reform Welfare Reform
description: When Jimmy Carter took office, he vowed to overhaul the entire welfare mess, not merely make incremental improvements. He has become wiser. Congress rejected his proposed structural reform; now he has announced a scaleddown version whose $5.7-billion price tag and compromise approach should finally be acceptable on Capitol Hill. We applaud Mr. Carter's perseverance. His new plan, though more modest, deserves support. Now the friends of welfare recipients need to show that they are also friends of welfare reform.

Conaboy, 53, and a Carlisle, Pa., lawyer, Sylvia H. Rambo, 43, were named to the District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania.

The Stanley Cup once again belongs to Montreal.

title: What's Doing in TORONTO

Although 137 years old, that description of Toionto by a tourist named Charles Dickens holds even more validity today. For decades in more recent times the city wallowed in the depths of AngloSaxon stuffiness. It was reputedly so dull that Torontonians fleeing Jerry Lewis movies went to Buffalo, 70 miles away, for a big time.

title: ART VIEW
description: The Baltimore Museum of Art is in full evolution. Building, rebuilding and remodeling are everywhere evident. Eventually the museum will be the better in every way for this activity. Meanwhile will not at any time shut down entirely. But for those New Yorkers who have always meant to go and see the Matisses from the Cone Collection which are the pride Baltimore the good news is that they will find them on loan at the Guggenheim Museum from Aug. 24 through Oct. But anyone who goes to Baltimore between now and the evening of June 17 will find not only the Cone collection, present and complete, but an exhibition of quite exceptional interest, beauty and provocation: The Complete Drawings Barnett Newman: 19441969.

title: Qatar to Raise Its Oil Price
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 26 (UPI) Qatar announced today that it would raise its oil prices by 80 cents a barrel, according to the official Qatar press agency monitored in Beirut. The price of its best crude, retroactive to May 17, will be $17.84 a barrel. At the end of 1978. its offi- dal price was S13.19. The Persian Gulf sheikdom was the seventh member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase the cost of its crude in two weeks. Qatar is the seventhlargest Arab oil exporter; the United States is its biggest customer.

title: Smokestacks And Tailpipes Still Vexing The Region

In New York, state and Federal officials were negotiating on details of recently submitted pollution con. trol plans, with,the state asking more time to comply. And in New Jersey, officials were considering stiffer antipollution rules for cars, after only minimal success in improving air quality under existing programs. Here is a regional status report on the effort to clean up the air.

title: AkiiBua: Athlete Ensnared In Uganda's Political Strife
description: THE mystery of John AlaiBua is beginning to unfold. Once a glamorous symbol in international sports, the Ugandan, the 1972 Olympic cham- pion and tormer worldrecord holder in the 400meter intermediate hurdles, had not been heard from for almost a year. At one point there was speculation that he had been killed during Uganda's internal strife, but it has been learned that he was jailed last month in Nairobi, Kenya, along with 500 other Ugandan refugees and political prisoners who fled the nowdeposed regime of Idi Amin.

The dozens of executives and local dignitaries gathered at the plant eight days ago were staging their biggest celebration since the ribboncutting that opened the plant in Apri11978.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: A5shilling Puritan coin minted in 1656 under Oliver Cromwell will be one of the high points of the Coin Galleries' mailbid sale that closes Friday afternoon. It is a silver crown of the Commonwealth of England (16491660), a period which was an uneasy interlude between the reigns of Charles I and Charles II. There was no monarch around at the time to be portrayed on the coins, so an armorial shield of St. George (the same dragonslayer to be shown later on the familiar gold sovereigns) was used instead.

title: U.S. Health Officials Recommend Polio Vaccinations for the Amish

title: ANTIQUES
description: Spread out on the worktable was what looked like a jigsaw puzzle of outsized glass pieces. I never did puzzles as a kid, but I do now, said Michael McNicholas, foreman of the glass shop of Rambusch Studios, 40 West 13th Street. He gently lifted off the protective plateglass coverings from the painted segments of a turn-ofthecentury stainedglass window designed by Louis Comfort Tiffany that was about to be cleaned and restored, explaining as he worked just how he goes about it. The leading on this window is in good condition so it will take me only about three weeks to complete, he reported. But the other one from the same client is a basket case and will require four to five weeks to finish.

title: WIZARD OF WALL STREET
description: After he has finished a meeting or a telephone conversation, Henry Kaufman often pauses for a moment and looks from his 91stfloor windows to the skyscraping rectangles of lower Manhattan and beyond to the great blue arc of the southern harbor  a view that reminds him literally of how far he has come. He can see, from his Wall Street office, the precise spot where the boat landed that brought him to this country at the age of 9. His parents, middleclass Jewish merchants, leaving the horror forming in Germany, were greeted here by the economic promise of the Depression's darkest years. They had no work waiting for them, spoke no English.

title: MY PRIESTLY CALLING
description: On March 8. 1964, a little more than two months after his consecration as Archbishop of Cracow, Karol Jozef Wojtyla offered an explanation about why he had entered the church. As far as is known, it was the only time he has bared his soul before others on this subject. He was spending the evening at the Arcebispal Spiritual Seminary in Cracow with a group of friends, mostly priests, and, suddenly, he began talking about himself. One of those present wrote down his words, and that record is one of the most important personal documents that exist concerning the inner thoughts of John Paul II. During a recent visit to Cracow. this writer was given a copy of the transcript by a close friend of the Pope. Here are some excerpts from the unpublished document.  T.S.

title: `Chuck

title: Recordings
description: Charles Mingus, who will be the subject of two memorial concerts Friday and Saturday at Carnegie Hall, was great leader. Great leaders are relatively rare in jazz, as they are in any field of human endeavor, and leadership in general is often misunderstood. Many people assume that leading involves telling subordinates what to do and making it stick, but in jazz a leader can't really do that. He can tell a soloist to improvise with feeling and invention and he can tell a band to swing, but if the musicians do not feel inspired he might as well be telling them to go jump in a lake. Charles Mingus did not exercise leadership so much as he simply exuded it. His soloists played with feeling and invention and his bands achieved a fierce, steamrolling swing, and although his virtuosic bass playing had something to do with it, his presence was enough to get the job done.

A typical set by a typical band might include a Tin Pan Alley pop tune, a hoedown favorite, a jam number to show off the band's improvising soloists, a honkytonk ballad, some ragtime, a boogie and a corny comedy routine.

title: 2 Klansmen and a Black Woman Are Shot in a Street Clash in Alabama

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEWSpectacular Bidding Defeats the MetContinue on Page 26
description: Im dazed, said photography dealer Daniel Wolf after the recordbreaking sale at auction on May 10 of two albums of photographs by the 19thcentury American photographer Carleton W. Watkins at Swann Galleries in New York. And well he might have been. Less than a week before, a single print by Edward Weston had sold Christie's for $9,500, the highest price ever paid for a 20thcentury photograph. On March 15 in London the Victoria and Albert Museum paid $15,500 (7,500) for a print of Robert Howlett's wellknown 1857 portrait of shipbuilder Isambard Kingdom Brunel, considering it a bargain in view of the growing scarcity of quality 19thcentury photographs.

title: Can Audiences Be Sold on Economics?
description: Inflation, a subject that is on everyone's mind, is also one of the most difficult stories to cover in a television documentary. It's too complicated, too abstract: too many ex- perts to disagree about its causes and cures. During the past month, a number of programs have addressed the subject, using a variety of techniques ranging from micro-mini-series on the local newscasts to talking heads on public television. They touched all bases but the dramatic one. Another show is attempting to do that. Inflation: The Fire That Won't Go Out, produced by Gateway Productions, Inc., will be broadcast locally Thursday evening at 8 over WNEW/ Channel 5, part of an adhoc network of more than 170 independent and affiliated stations. Louis Rukeyser of publicTV's Wall Street Week will be host of the onehour

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: The League of Women Voters of Westchester would like to correct misinterpretation concerning the League's position on Playland. The League issued a fact sheet (not a position paper) that included a reference to a sinking fund for major repairs at Playland. In comparing private business with a government facility, we said: All revenues from Playland go into the county general fund as revenue and are not held in a sinking fund for depreciation (as in a private business) to pay for major capital expenditures. Therefore, major capital repairs, such as repairs of the water and electrical systems, have not been made but are needed.

Mr. Hathaway is a son of Patricia Hathaway of Portland, Me., and Maj. Donald F. Hathaway, U.S.A.F., retired, of Bar Harbor, Me. title: Falcons
description: LANCHOW, China, May 26  The crowds in Lanchow were the largest ever to see a women's professional softball game. On the average, more than 40,000 spectators crammed into the Chi Li Ho Stadium each day for the three days the Falcons played here. Thousands more packed the streets leading to the stadium trving to get in.

title: Viking Mint Found in Britain
description: YORK, England, May 26 (Reuters)  Archeologists have found a perfect impression of two 10thcentury coin dies in a Viking workshop here, the first proof of an early Viking mint in Britain. The impression, on a small piece of lead, shows the two sides of an AngloSaxon penny. On one side is a cross and the name, in Latin, of Edwy, England's King from 955 to 959. The other side carries the name of Frothric, the man who minted the dies.

title: Success in Sports Often Breeds Failure
description: OGER ANGELL of The New Yorker once wrote a sad history of an interesting and bewildering psychological phenomenon in his book, Five Sea- sons. Angell described the travail of Pittsburgh Pirates pitcher who, after a brilliant season suddenly became totally wild, but only when a batter was at the plate. As long as no one was in the batter's box, his control was excellent; but as soon as he faced a batter, he was wild. No amount of rest, adjustments in delivery, treatments, or reassurances helped. The pitcher quietly slipped into obscurity.

description: Otto Ehrlich, emeritus professor of economics at the New York Univerity Graduate School of Arts and Science died yesterday. He was 86 years old and was a resident of East Orange, N.J.

title: Hopkins Tops Maryland, Keeps Lacrosse Crown
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., May 26 (AP) - Dave Huntley and Jeff Cook scored three goals each and led Johns Hopkins to a 159 victory over Maryland in the National Collegiate Division I lacrosse final today.It was Hopkins's second title in a row and third since the championship tournament started in 1971.

title: When Maps Listed L.I. as `Matouacs
description: MAP collecting offers a variety- of pleasures ranging from armchair travel to visual understanding of an area's historical development. Recent interest in finding one's roots has led to a popularization of topical map collecting  that is, specializing in maps from a specific geographical area such as the Island.

title: One Foreign Aid Request Got Friendly Treatment Last Week
description: For years, foreign aid has been a favorite target budgetcutters on Capitol Hill, partly because the money doesn't seem to have done much to alleviate global poverty. For years no institutions have felt the heat as much as the international lending agencies responsible for international development efforts since soon after World War II. The world's poor are not notably better off. But for the first time in some years the position of the World Bank, the InterAmerican Development Bank and the Asian and African development banks, appears to be improving.

title: TV VIEW
description: Although it is one of the better documentary series on the entire television spectrum, publicTV's World has developed a disconcerting knack for creating unpleasant vibrations in the producing community. Last year, the project of contention became Blacks Britannica. a film about race and racism in Britain that was made by the husband-and-wife team David Koff and Musindo Mwinyipembe. Before being telecast, the documentary was altered  reorganized, say station executives; censored, say the producers. The production staff removed all their credits from the televised version, and the case is still being thrashed out in legal negotiations. Now, this year, bitter arguments have erupted over the reorganizing of The Shirt Off Your Back, a documentary put into the Public Broadcasting Service pipeline in February. The two cases differ in several key respects, but together they reveal disturbing aspects of the publicTV bureaucracy as it is developing in this country.

title: Regina Keller To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Keller of Roslyn Estates, L.I., and Hutchinson Island, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Regina Frances Keller, to Dr. James Francis Collins, son of Dr. and Mrs. James Collins of Brookfield, Conn.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today- Motoreport Club of North Jong fun rally; start at The Club Haase, Route 46 Westbound, Fairfield. N.J. Regiiitration: 11 A.M.; first caroff noon.

title: Bridgeport: The City Revives
description: RECENTLY on a Saturday walk, we stopped at a tag sale in front of one of the oncefashionable houses in Bridgeport's West End. An old woman had passed away and her home would no doubt soon become a dwelling for two or three families. One of her descendants lugged a box of magazines down from the attic. A faded issue of Harpers caught our attention. What was on the reader's mind in 1919? Bridgeport.

title: Fuel Fears Depress Rentals in Hamptons
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I.  Frances Erskine tapped the steering wheel of her car, then lit a cigarette. The realestate broker had been waiting outside the Colonial house on Hampton Road for a halfhour and the prospective renter had not shown.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: Westchester/This Week

title: V.C. Arguimbau 3d Weds Hilarie Ford
description: Hilarie Burdick Ford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Quintin Urrisari Ford of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Vincent Charles Arguimbau 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Charles Arguimbau, also of Darien. The ceremony was performed in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Noroton, Conn., by the Rev. Douglass Ray. He was assisted by the Rev. Timothy Donovan of St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: MUSIC
description: HOW does it feel to grow up the son of a famous father? asked Eric Shumsky that question last summer at the Aspen Music Festival, and now that the 25-year-old violist is playing in a chamber festival concert Thursday at the HoffBarthelson School in Scarsdale, maybe it's time to print his answer.

title: An Ivoryton Heritage Is Stolen
description: IVORYTON

title: Former Indy Victors Fed Up With Feuds
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 26  The five previous winners who are entered in tomorrow's running of the Indianapolis 500 regard this race as somewhat more difficult to drive than preceding races.

title: U.S. SPENT MILLIONS ON HOME NIXON SOLD
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 26  When Richard M. Nixon was asked in 1973 to explain where he got the money to pay $1.5 million for an oceanside estate of 29 acres at San Clemente, White House sources told The Associated Press that Mr. and Mrs. Nixon planned to bequeath the property to the United States for public use.

title: News Summary
description: Celebrating the peace treaty between their countries, President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel exchanged brief visits, meeting in El Arish, the Sinai capital recently returned to Egypt, then flying over Tel Aviv and Cairo and returning to Beersheba in Israel for more talks. The IsraeltoEgypt flight was to symbolize the opening of a new air corridor that eventually will allow direct routes between the nations. [Page A1, Column 6.].

title: Greenpoint Uneasy Atop 1 7MillionGallon Oil Leak
description: They struck oil in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn last fall  a vast underground reservoir of 17 million gallons spread over nearly 55 acres.

title: Woman and Boy Severely Burned In L.I. Store Fire
description: An 8yearold boy and his 64yearold grandmother were very critically burned and at least 19 firemen were injured yesterday when flames punctuated by a series of explosions raced through and destroyed a large Nassau County store specializing in swimmingpool supplies, sporting goods and toys.

title: Tablets to Holocaust To Stand in Venice
description: A bronze monument of the Holocaust by Arbit Blatas will be dedicated in September in the Campo del Nuovo Ghetto in Venice.

title: Czaravich Doubtful for Belmont
description: Czaravich, one of the main obstacles between Spectacular Bid and his Triple Crown goal, came up ill yesterday and will probably miss his chance to tackle the gallant gray in the Belmont Stakes on June 9.

title: Ballet: Cynthia Harvey In Tetley's Contredanse
description: THE recent works of Glen Tetley are said to be much in favor with their youngest interpretors. Everyone in the cast gets a chance to shine, for one thing, and, motivated by icily voluptuous physicality, the ballets are long on action and short on dramatic or stylistic embellishment. Cynthia Harvey is a promising young dancer, but she is most notable for her sure and gracious sense of classical style.

title: Lebanese Christian Militias Shell P.L.O. Targets in South Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 27 (UPI) Lebanese Christian militiamen shelled Palestine Liberation Organization targets in southern Lebanon today for the second straight day, the P.L.O. press agency Wafa and travelers from the area reported.

title: George Brent, Movie Actor, Dies; Was Leading Man to Many Stars
description: George Brent, one of the prominent screen actors of the 1930's and 40's, was found dead Saturday night at his home in Solana Beach, Calif., a suburb of San Diego.

title: 2,400 Get Degrees at Fordharn University
description: Fordharn University conferred 2,900 graduate and undergraduate degrees yesterday at four ceremonies in the Bronx and Manhattan. If there were themes to the day of happy pomp and circumstance, they were a striving for a higher morality and a hope that it would not rain.

title: Kerry May Grady Is Wed To James Joseph Murphy
description: At Our Lady of the Lake Roman Catholic Church in Sparta, N.J., yesterday, Kerry May Grady, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hazard Grady of Andover. N.J.. was married to James Joseph Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Murphy of Upper Providence, Pa. The Rev. Charles C. Cassidy performed the ceremony.

title: Orioles Shot Down Twice
description: Going into yesterday's doubleheader in Detroit, the Baltimore Orioles were the hottest team in the major leagues. They had won 26 of their last 32 games and enjoyed a 3%game lead over the Boston Red Sox in the American League Eastern Division.

title: Gifford Reaches Top In Bicycle Marathon
description: Henry. Gifford had a feeling he would win this year's PepsiCola Bicycle Marathon in Central Park. I took third place two years ago, and second place last year, so I just had to win this year, he said after pedaling 405 miles in 24 hours to earn the winner's medal from Gordon Davis, the commissioner of parks and recreation.

title: Low Profits Chafe Gas Retailers
description: MEDFORD, L.I:, May 27 Although the price of gasoline has risen sharply in the last three months as supplies dwindled, retailers say that inflation has wiped out nearly half their profit margin and that only a handful of nonbranded, highvolume gasandgo stations are showing a profit.

title: Sverre Kongelbeck, 72, Engineer; Supervised Coast Nuclear Project
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  Sverre Kongelbeck, a scientist and inventor who supervised construction of the giant nuclear accelerator at the University of California, died Friday at the Montgomery (Md.) General Hospital. He was apparently stricken by a heart attack while attending a theater performance. Mr. Konnelbeck was 72 years old.

title: OffRoad Recreational Vehicles Reported Injuring Public Lands
description: According to a vocal advocate of such offmad vehicles as trail bicycles, dune buggies and halftracks, their use revitalizes the intensity and flow of a man's animal spirits.

title: Helpful Reading
description: Some worthwhile texts dealing with the striped bass, the bluefish and surffishing include The Complete Book of the Striped Bass, by Nicholas Karas (Winchester Press), All About Surf Fishing, by Jack Fallon (Winchester Press), and Surf Fishing, by Vlad Evanoff (Harper & Row). If you can find a copy of it, the classic, outofprint Complete Book of Striped Bass Fishing, by Frank Woolner and Hal Lyman (A.S. Barnes), still holds up very well, even though it was published in 1959.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Ever try to keep a logbook dry and unsmudged, boat trip after boat trip? You can with Wet Notes, a nautical notebook with waterproof paper. The satiny surface accepts pencil or pen, and even works underwater if necessary. Wet Notes is bound in leathergrain vinyl and contains a writing pad (refills cost $1.50 each), log sheets and a threeyear calendar. It is made by E.S. Ritchie & Sons of Pembroke, Mass., and it sells for $9.95 at the Manhattan Marine and Electric Company, 116 Chambers Street, and the New York Nautical Instrument and Service Corporation, 190 West Broadway, both in Manhattan, and at other marine stores.

title: Suffolk SewerDistrict TaxCut Bid Seeks to End C.O.P. Split on Klein
description: The Suffolk County Republican leader, Gilbert C. Hanse, is trying to mend the party split over the renomination of County Executive John V. N. Klein by developing a legislative program that would provide tax relief for residents of the county's Southwest Sewer District.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, May 27 (Reuters)  Community leaders pleaded for calm and angry rightists called for a crackdown on urban guerrilla groups today after two days of political violence, the worst in postFranco Spain, left 17 dead and dozens more injured.

title: Sports World Specials
description: Guess who ran second in The recent voting for president of the student body at the University of Minnesota. Would you believe Bombo Rivera?

title: Bangladeshi Home Minister Says 339 Political Prisoners Are Held
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, May 27 (AP)The Government is holding 339 political prisoners, Home Minister Mustafizur Rahman told Parliament yesterday.

title: Washington Watch
description: IT is an idea almost as old as the Republic itself. In a more jingoist age. Henry Clay thought the United States should establish a North American union by military force &necessary. He wanted counterpoise to what he considered to be the wickedness. 01 the Old World.

title: What Are W.H.O.'s Priorities?
description: The World Health Organization has been having trouble deciding whether its mission is health or politics. But at last there are some encouraging signs at its current annual meeting in Geneva.

title: Memorial Day Closings and Other Data
description: tinder a 1967 Federal law creating series of threeday holiday weekends, the last Monday in May was established as the official Memorial Day holiday, a practice followed by Connecticut, New Jersey and most other states, where the holiday will be observed today.

title: Head of Wilson College, Under Fire, Is Quitting
description: CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., May 27 (AP) The resignation of Dr. Margaret Waggoner, president of embattled Wilson College, was announced by the school's board of trustees yesterday, one day after a judge ordered her removed from the board along with another member.

title: Dance: Bill Evans Group Pays Visit From Seattle
description: AS a choreographer, Bill Evans is terribly clever  even dangerously clever  for most of the works that his Bill Evans Dance Company of Seattle presented at the Theater of the Riverside Church on Thursday night were so strenuously inventive that they seemed gimmicky.

title: Select Few Bask in a Nearly Silent City
description: Roseanne Peer stared out a window of the doubledecker bus at a deserted Park Avenue yesterday. Where have all the New Yorkers gone? she asked. Despite the gasoline shortage, New Yorkers had fled the city for the Memorial Day weekend, leaving behind them empty streets and an eerie quiet.

title: Joan Sapinsley Is Married. to Richard Lewis
description: Joan Manfield Sapinsley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Sapinsley of Providence, R.I., and Richard Hendricks Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Lewis of Hartsdale, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Sapinsley home. Rabbi Leslie Y. Gutterman of Temple Beth El in Providence performed the ceremony.

title: Half of Japanese Filling Stations Ignore a Sunday Closing Request
description: TOKYO, May 27 (AP)  Only halt of Japanese gasoline stations complied today with a Government request that they shut down on Sundays and national holidays to conserve fuel, a Government official said.

title: Letter: On New Jersey Bus Subsidies
description: To the Editor: A May 5 editorial endorsed the proposal of the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Transportation (N.J.D.C.T.) which calls for public ownership and operation of New Jersey's bus companies_ Transport of New Jersey, which is a major focus of this proposal, has publicly stated that it will cooperate with any decision reached by the government of New Jersey provided it is assured of fair compensation for its property and full protection for all of its employees. Transport, therefore, is not actively participating in the debate on this issue.

title: U.S., Despite Claims of Veterans, Says None Are Herbicide Victims
description: At various times since 1967, physicians trying to diagnose a single, persistent illness have told Kenneth Pullen that he has possible jungle rot, possible trench foot, possible gangrene, possible vasculitis of the lower extremities, possible vein thrombosis, possible Buerger's disease, possible arthritis, possible thrombophlebitis and probable cutaneous polyarteritis nodosa.

title: Dance: Grethe Holby
description: GRETHE HOLBY has a master's degree in architecture and she has danced with the major experimentalists, Laura Dean and Robert Wilson. It was no surprise. then; that the four abstract dances presented by Miss Holby on Saturday at the Kitchen were intelligently conceived and of some visual interest, despite their nave lighting. They were also strangely listless, the dancers with a few exceptions, most notably Barbara Derecktor  resembling tentative automatons.

title: R. L. LIVINGSTON, 47, OF CITY RIGHTS UNIT
description: Robert Lewis Livingston, a member of New York City's Commission on Human Rights and a special assistant to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, died yesterday at his home at 180 East 79th Street. Mr. Livingston, who had been ill with cancer since last summer, was 47 years old.

title: Associated press
description: INDIANAPOLIS 500 WINNER: Rick Mears was all smiles yesterday after winning Ms first Indianapolis auto race. Article, page C1.

title: Caracas Unveils Economic Plan
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, May 25r The new Government of this South Amen, can oilexporting nation has made public its first overall outline of economic policy, pledging to control runaway public spenamg, reOLICe Ule SIZaDle oatanteofpayments deficit registered last year and maintain the present value of its monetary unit, the bolivar.

title: Volunteers Take Major Role in Search for. Missing 6YearOld SoHo Boy
description: Putting up posters and canvassing the SoHo area of Manhattan doortodoor, the police and scores of concerned volunteers yesterday continued a search for Etan Patz, a 6yearold boy missing since Friday from his home in the district.

title: Seoul Opposition Leader Charges Harassment in Intraparty Struggle,
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 27  South Korea's former opposition leader, Kim Young Sam, says that he has come under increased Government surveillance because he declared his candidacy for the leadership of the New Democratic Party.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ADMIRAL NIGERIA (BFI West Africa LineNorton. Lilly 8 Company). Monrovia June 12 and Lagos 14; sails from Port Elizabeth, N.J. EUROFREIGHTER (Seatrain). LeHavre June 5. Rotterdam 6. Bremerhaven 7 and Greened( 8; salts from PO! i Seatrain, Weehawken, N.J.

title: Tennis: Gerulaitis Scores
description: ROME, May 27 (UPI)  Vitas Gerulaitis wore down topseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina in a record fivehour, 57game match today to win the $200,000 Italian open tennis tournament, 67, 76, 67, 62, 62.

title: Artist Wraps Up His Newest Work
description: Art came to an abandoned fivestory building in the East Village yesterday in the form vf3,500 yards gauze, pouring over the roof, wrapped around the sides, attached to cables at the bottom and billowing forth like party decorations.

title: Texas Leading 10 Major States In Gasoline Use
description: HOUSTON, May 27  Steve Beck, an 18yearold college student, was pulling out of his family's driveway the other night in his blue and white 1978 Ford F150 Ranger Lariat pickup truck with its 400cubicinch V8 engine when a neighbor flagged him down with a question: What kind of gasoline mileage do you get?

title: Memorial Service Held in Florida For Spenkelink, Executed Killer
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 27 (AP) The family of John A. Spenkelink and opponents to the capital punishment system that sent him to his death in the electric chair last week were among those attending a memorial service today for the 30yearold convicted murderer.

title: Carey Watches as Son, Daughter Get Degrees
description: An admittedly very proud Governor Carey watched yesterday as two of his children received university degrees.

title: Recital: Loebei, Pianist
description: LAWRENCE LOEBER, heard Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a 23yearold pianist from Ohio. Mr. Loeber has powerful, welldisciplined fingers, but he is not yet a finished artist. In the course of the evening, he did produce moments of excitement. Too often, however, the music was stiffly phrased and harshly accented, or otherwise unrefined.

title: Notes on People
description: It's no secret that Leonard Bernstein is a conductor who moves like a dynamo, jumping around and flailing his arms while putting an orchestra through its paces. How one orchestra's executive director kept the irrepressible Mr. Bernstein anchored down, at least temporarily, was told by Ernest Fleishmann of the Los Angeles Philharmonic the other day in an interview.

title: Robin Rosen Is Graduated, Then Wed to Dr. Alan Kluger
description: Robin Rosen, who graduated yesterday afternoon from Vassar College, was married last evening to Dr. Alan Jay Kluger. Rabbis Seymour Baumrind and Ephraim Wolf performed the ceremony at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue.

title: TV SPORTS
description: 2:00 (9)Baseball: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The slowdown in this country could become a recession if crude oil prices continue to go up, according to Stuart Eizenstat, President Carter's principal adviser on domestic policy. But he added that an expected decline in food prices should cut inflation below the doubledigit level by the end of the year. [Page D1.].

title: South Yemen Qutiously Easing Restrictions on Women
description: LAREJ. Southern Yemen  The long line of women in black velis some with their arms tattooed like tineblack lace Floveqsat waiting patiettly for the doctor.

title: Jazz: Erwin Plays Gig At Biffs
description: IF Biff's Place were a jazz club in Greenwich Village, the name might sound a little precious. But when it turns out to be a downstairs room reached through the softly carpeted lobby of a midtown hotel the Halloran House, 49th Street and Lexington'Avenue  it is obvious that imagemaking is at work.

title: Sultan of Oman Bids U. S. Warn Moscow on Mideast Adventures
description: MUSCAT, Oman, May 27 Describing the ArabianPeninsula as a.target area for the Soviet Union, the Sultan of Oman, Qabus bin Said, appealed to the United State$ WO, to warn.theRussians against making trouble for its friends in the region. The Russians should be told that they would be playing with fire if they launehedturther adventures in this area, he said in an interview.

title: Beachgoers Will Discover a Changed Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 26  Beachgoers and strollers on the Boardwalk will find this summer that the first year of casino gambling has changed this resort for them as well as for blackjack players and craos shooters.

title: Fund Redemptions Rise
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP)  Net redemptions of mutual funds totaled $174.8 million in April, up from $123.2 million in March, the Investment Company Institute reported.

title: Mailers Ratify Contract
description: Members of the New York Mailers Union No. 6 ratified a threeyear contract with The Daily News and The New York Times yesterday by a vote of 610102. George E. McDonald, president of the union, said the contract was retroactive to March 31, 1978. Mr. McDonald's union has 1,600 members.

title: Doctored Pictures Indicate Race to Succeed Brezhnev
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  It has taken more than three weeks of practicing a neglected art, Kremlinology, but United States Government specialists have concluded from the doctoring of pictures of the Soviet Union's May Day ceremonies by Moscow newspapers that some sort of machinations are under way in a scramble to succeed Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: MAURITANIA PREMIER DIES IN PLANE CRASH
description: DAKAR, Senegal, May 27 (Reuters)The Prime Minister of Mauritania and 11 other persons died today when their plane plunged into the Atlantic off the Senegalese capital of Dakar during a sandstorm.

title: FRANCIS ROBERT GEMME,
description: FrancisRobert Gemme, president of the children's press diviaion  of Regensteiner Publishing Enterprises of Chicago, was among those killed Fiiday in the crash of American Airlines Flight 191 in Chicago. He was 45 years old and lived in Wilmetka, Ill. Mr. Gemme was a former president of Young Readers Press, division of Simon & Schuster in New York.

title: Dance: It's Robbins Day For Lincoln Center Fans
description: DANCEGOERS w#Iing to dash from one Lincoln Center theater to another on Saturday afternoon could have seen three distinctive ballets by Jerome Robbins.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI)  With Vietnam Veterans Week starting on Memorial Day, a drive is under way to raise $1 million for a monument to American servicemen killed in the Vietnam War.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5. 30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 PM ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. REGIONAL OFFICE 9.00 A M. TO 4.30 P.M.MONDAY THROUGH ??? ? ?? ?? ? ? ??? ??? ?? ?

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON .'No victims, no losses, an attorney for Bert Lance confidently told a friend after a Federal grand jury handed up its 1,500word indictment. Bert's defenders are certain that their man can beat the rap.

title: UConn, St. John's In Baseball Final
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 27 The University of Connecticut hammered out 32 hits en route to a 150 victory over Nebraska and a 144 conquest of St. John's today in the National Collegiate Northeast Realanai baseball turnament.

title: Amid Reports of Other Reverses, Carter Did Well in a Budget Test
description: Just after Christmas; a former Congressman ended an informal pe session among friends about the A stmtion's spending proposals for social programs in the fiscal year 1980 by saying: this is only the beginning. Conger has the last word and we'll have a better idea about the budget along toward the middle of May.

title: Sonics Triumph, Lead, 21
description: SEATTLE, May 27The Seattle SuperSonics took a 21 lead in games in the National Basketball Association championship series today by scoring a 10595 victory over the Washington Bullets, but Elvin Hayes, the Bullet forward, was not worried about the deficit.

title: Children Keep Sculpture Alive, And Also in Need of Repairs
description: On the top tier, five small boys dance to an imaginary disco beat, posturing with miniJohn Travolta swagger. From the middle steps, another boy and a bluejeaned girl launch themselves into the air with ecstatic screeches, landing with a sprawl only to clamber back up the steps and leap off again. On the ground, a woman surveys the scene with an indulgent smile, looking pleased with herself.

title: BarnesWebb Link
description: The Barnes Engineering Company of Stamford, Conn., and J. A. Webb Inc. of Buffalo, a distributor of industrial material handling and power transmission components, announced the merger of Webb into a subsidiary of Barnes. Barnes will issue 100,000 shares of common stock for all of the shares of Webb.

title: Piano: Sally Christian
description: THE first impression a recitalist makes comes not from the initial piece, or even the first step onstage, but from the printed program. In this regard, Sally Christian's piano recital Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall bore the stamp of an enterprising, interesting artist. The program listed a Scriabin set including the Sonata No. 7, Book Il of Albeniz's Iberia, and short but substantial works by Tchailrovsky, Faure and Debussy.

title: Ernest Thompson Plins 2 Plays for Next Season
description: Ernest Thompson, whose On Golden Pond successfully reopened the New Apollo Theater on West 43d Street last fall, will have two other plays in production next season.

title: Renault Sets Portugal Expansion
description: The Portuguese Government said that Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, the Preach stateowned auto maker, planned to open three plants and reconvert an existing assembly line in Portugal at a cost of nearly $400 million.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ACCENT ON YOUTH Art collectors of modest means shouldn't overlook a new gallery downtown in the area bordering SoHo and Tribeca, where a photography exhibition by students of the School of Visual Arts is on display tomorrow through Thursday. The gallery, in the American Thread Building at 260 West Broadway, is perhaps the city's only schoolsponsored art showcase not on or near school premises. The gallery was begun year ago to display student works in professional, competitive environment, with all sale proceeds going directly to the young artists.

title: Not Only the Rich Should Run for Office
description: Running for high office in New York State is extremely expensive and, like everything else, becoming more so. It is no accident that the last three elected governors had access to vast private wealth. What should be an incidental attribute in a candidate family money  has become central.

title: Alf Landon in Kansas Hospital
description: TOPEKA, Kan., May 27 (UPI)  Alf Landon, the Republican Presidental candidate in 1936, was hospitalized with chest pains today, but hospital officials would say only that his condition was not believed to be serious or critical. A spokesman said he probably would be hospitalized overnight for observation. His daughter is Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas.

title: Cynthia Ann Gates Is Married
description: Cynthia Ann Gates, daughter of Mr: and Mrs. Edward C. Gates of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Bruce William Baber, son of Dr. and Mrs. Julius J. Baber of Bayonne, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of Princeton University by the Rev. Richard Chrisman of the United Church of Christ, assistant dean of the chapel. He was assisted by the Rev. A. Richard McCabe, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride graduated from Duke University, from which her husband received a law degree.

title: Lightning Kills 3 Japanese
description: TOKYO, May 27 (Reuters)  Three people were killed by lightning in northern Japan today, bringing the total of lightning victims to seven in two days, the police said.

title: Officials Link Alleged Smuggler To Texas Men Held in Colombia
description: MIAMI, May 26  Federal and state investigators here have assembled information that links a Miami man, whom they describe as a principal operator of a major drugsmuggling ring, with William A. Spradley and Roy F. McLemore, the Houston fireman and his flying companion who are charged with landing an airplane in Colombia illegally a month ago.

title: Ina Louise Elfant, Therapist, Is Bride of Steven Alan Asher
description: Ina Louise Elfant, daughter of Martin M. Elfant of Philadelphia and the late Sylvia Slick Elfant, was married yesterday to Steven Alan Asher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Asher of Melrose Park, Pa. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Arthur Ruberg and Marshall Maltzman at Congregation Beth HillelBeth El in Wynnewood, Pa.

title: SPLIT BOLT BLAMED FOR LOSS OF ENGINE IN JETLINER'S CRASH
description: CHICAGO, May 27  The National Transportation Safety Board said today that breakage of a threeinch bolt because of metal fatigue evidently caused an underwing engine and its mounting to fly off an American Airlines jumbo jet just before its crash on takeoff here Friday.DALLAS, May Z7 (AP)  The Airline Passengers Association Inc. has called for a check of DC10 jetliners to determine whether metal fatigue exists on the engine mounts, but it said it did not agree with a suggestion by Ralph Nader to ground the aircraft.

title: Deaths
description: BIE RMANHerbert. Bierman Fem.'. ly Circle mourns with deep sorrow his passing. Beloved husband of Amy. devoted lather of Isabel and the late Cora, an devoted grandfather and brother at Frieda and Bea. Burial Tuesday. May 79 in Los Angeles. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family.

title: Lauren Sari Silbert Is Married to Dr. Franklin C. Lowe
description: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarburst, L.I., yesterday, Lauren Sari Silbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Silbert of Woodbury. L.I.. was married to Dr. Franklin C. Lowe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Lowe of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I. Rabbi Gunther Hirschberg performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Judge Says He Imposed Orders For Secrecy in Carter Loan Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  A Federal district judge in Atlanta said today that he had imposed unusual secrecy orders upon the investigation of President Carter's family peanut business and had specifically instructed White House officials not to make public comment on the inquiry.

title: The HalfUsed Lives
description: Before it was Memorial Day, it was Decoration Day, but remembrance was always at its heart. The nation has had so many to remember since Civil War families laid flowers on the graves of their dead.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock exchange, commodities markets, most businesses and most banks throughout the United States will be closed today in observance of the Memorial Day holiday.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Variations on Theme by Mozart, Glinka; Clair de Lune, Debussy.

title: De Gustibus
description: One of the most heroic, interesting and  curiously  littleknown chefs in history was a Frenchman named Alexis Soyer who was born in 1811 and who, some sources contend, was the greatest chef of his day. He arrived in England when he was 21 years old. I recently received a brief account of his life from Herbert Cahoon of the Pierpont Morgan Library.

title: Tool Orders Down 5% For April

title: Letters

title: W.R. Grace Tackles Retailing Challenge
description: W. R. Grace & Company, the chemicals and natural resources company that wants to become a major factor in retailing, is suffering some of the growing pains that increasingly seem to result from acquisitions in the retail field. The management seems confident, however, that it can overcome them.

description: Worldwide ordeis for new ships at the end of the first quarter were at their lowest level in 14 years, according to a tally by Lloyd's Registerof shipping.

title: Deaths
description: MALLIN  Rage. beloved wife of Henry. Devoted mother of Joel and Barry. Loving grand mother of Jennifer. Adam. Erika, Noah and Molly. Cherished sister of Betty Glasser. Jack and Sam Rubinstein. Service today. 11:45 AM, The Riverside. 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Israeli and Egyptian Aides to Meet on Opening Borders
description: TEL AVIV, May 27  Senior Foreign Ministry officials of Egypt and Israel will meet in Cairo early next month to begin work on activating the agreement to open the border between the two countries.

Jacovides, chief delegate of Cyprus to the United Nations. The Rev. Theophanis Kolyvas performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church in Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: OPEC Seen Imperiling Economy

description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 27Clark Kellogg.did not exhibit the flying 360degree, rimbending jams, or:the 40plus inch vertical leaps, or the.behindtheback passes that high spboal: allstar, basketball games cannot: do without: He;left thatto the others. All he did today was show why. some people are saying that he is the best high school player in the United States.

title: Stage: New Approach to The Tempest on Coast
description: ANTHONY HOPKINS'S owlish and fiercely intellectual Prospero is the risk and the triumph of John Hirsch's extraordinary production of The Tempest at the Mark Taper Forum.

title: Easing Communications Rules
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  Last year it was airline deregulation. This year, the cutting edge of the regulatory innovation promoted by the Carter Administration is in the communications field.

title: Luring Those Stripers and Blues
description: THOSE planning to try surfcasting for striped bass and bluefish will encounter a bewildering array of lures on tackleshop walls, but they need not despair, for with a little knowledge the angler can select a dozen or so good items that will suffice.

title: Vorster Reported About to Resign
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 27 (AP)President John Vorster will resign soon because of new revelations in the multimilliondollar Information Department scandal, two South African newspapers said today.

title: Gasoline Tank Truck Hijacked in California
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., May 27 (UPI) A gasoline tank truck carrying enough fuel to last a service station for four days was hijacked yesterday and its driver held at gunpoint for three hours.

title: Growth Slows In Thrift C.D.'s
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP)  The value of money market certificate accounts at Federally insured savings and loan associations rose by $5.8 billion in April, the smallest monthly increase since September 1978, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported. This followed a $7.9 billion rise in such accounts in March.

title: Diesel Fuel Allocated
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) The Energy Department has announced emergency rules aimed at easing dieselfuel shortages for truckers hauling agricultural goods, surface masstransit systems and companies producing crude oil and natural gas.

title: Polo Postponed
description: BETHPAGE. L.L. May. 27  The opening polo match of the season on Long Island, scheduled for today between Huntington and Brookville at Bethpage State Park; was postponed because of wet grounds.

title: Engineer Sells Model A's To Drive Into the Future
description: DETROIT, May 27  While the Big Three auto makers are busy trying to invent the car of the future, engineers at a small plant in nearby Wixom are reviving the roadster of 1920's  turning out a limitededition Model A Ford, or rather a reproduction of it.

title: State Department Juggling Funds In Effort to Maintain Refugee Aid
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  The State Department is engaged in a desperate financial juggling act to try to maintain its program for transporting and resettling thousands of refugees from Indochina and the Soviet Union while awaiting replenishment of funds for this purpose from Congress.

title: Deaths

title: MOST GAS STATIONS IN CITY ARE CLOSED

title: Murray Beaten On Late Homer
description: The second:and final day of Jacket Weekend brought the biggest crowd of the season out to Shea Stadium yesterday, but the Mets lost a 21 decision to the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: G.O.P. Hoping to See Its Future In Kentucky Primary Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  Tiiesday's Democratic primary in Kentucky is the first major event on a small but significant schedule of offyear elections that Republicans hope will give them a major boost toward the White House in 1980.
