description: PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y.  Exactly 50 years ago, I was a fervently happy schoolboy. Marching down Rochester's Main Street on Memorial Day in 1929, I unsteadily but proudly carried the heavy staff and the American flag. it was a hot, sticky, noisy morning.

title: Donna Joy Reservitz Is Married
description: Donna Joy Reservitz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George B. Reservitz of Lexington, Mass., was married last evening to Steven Michael Shragis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin I. Schraeis of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Cary David Tales performed the ceremony at the Copley Plaza in Boston. The bride, whose father is a urologist, has completed her junior year at Tufts University, from which her husband graduated magna cum laude. Mr. Schragis is entering his second year at the American University School of Law in Washington. His father is executive vice president of the Carol Management Company and vice president of the. Doral Hotels Corporation. At.

title: Site of Mideast Parley May Be Sandy, but It Has Its Pride
description: BEERSHEBA, Israel, May 27  This Cinderella city of the Negev' was not wildly flattered the other day when a cartoonist pictured it as a Sleeping Beauty waiting for the kiss of a Prince Charming to bring her to life.

title: Women's Project Play Staged at American Place
description: Letters Home, a twowomen play by Rose Leiman Goldemberg, isbe the final presentation, in the Women's Project festival of women's plays at the American Place Theater, at 111 West 46th Street, east of Broadway.

title: Officials of E.P.A. Assert Effort Is Being Undercut
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  A growing sense of frustration about carrying out the antipollution laws is permeating the atmosphere at the Environmental Protection Agency, which just a few years ago was riding the crest of the environmental movement.

title: Get Washington's Hand Off the Wheel
description: Any trucker is welcome to go into the business of hauling raisins to market, provided they are unprocessed or coated with cinnamon, honey or sugar. But if the raisins happen to be the chocolatecovered variety, the same trucker has to apply for permission from the Interstate Commerce Commission  and stand a real chance of being turned down. This is the crazy world of truck regulation. The industry is buried under rules and paperwork that cost the public billions in excessive shipping charges. The system has survived since 1935 only because some politically powerful trucking companies and their union drivers benefit more from the restrictions on open competition than they lose on inefficient operations.

title: BONN CONSERVATIVES ARE RISKING A SPLIT
description: BONN, May 28  The leadership of the Christian Democratic Party, risking an open split in the traditional unity of West Germany's principal conservative parties, today proposed Ernst Albrecht, a state premier, as its candidate for Chancellor in national elections next year.

title: Death Called Unrelated To Reservation Violence
description: BEMIDJI, Minn., May 28 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation has concluded that the fatal shooting of a 15yearold boy was not related to the violence that erupted nine days ago on the Red Lake Indian Reservation in northern Minnesota.

title: Topics
description: The first answer, in 1973, came from a spokesman for thenPresident Nixon. How much public money had gone into fixing up La Casa Pacifica, the rundown, 29acre estate he had bought near San Clemente, Calif.? Less than $40,000, the spokesman said. Within days, reporters found evidence that the right answer was more like $100,000, then $200,000, then $400,000  and then the General Services Administration acknowleged it had spent $703,367.

title: Dance: River Repertory Waxes Jolly and Pensive
description: THE River Repertory Company, which appeared Sunday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, proved to be a chipper little group from Millbrook directed by Kathleen M.H. King and Jane McLaughlin, with Miss McLaughlin also providing most of thy choreography. The dancers were bright and the dances were certainly supposed to be bright. Yet, often, those dances were more facile than thoughtful.

title: Strong Quake in Mediterranean
description: ATHENS, May 28 (Reuters)  The Athens Observatory recorded a strong earthquake today in the eastern Mediterranean between northern Cyprus and Turkey. There were no reports of damage or casualties in Greek islands close to the Turkish coast.

title: The Only Active Champion
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y.  Peeking out from inside his leather headgear, Larry Holmes sagged against the ropes behind him. He was accepting punch after punch from Jody Ballard, one of his sparring partners, when he glanced at the spectators hunched nearby on wooden bleachers in Grossinger's ski lodge. I can do anything I want, he said now, suddenly snapping a left jab into Jody Ballard's face. Like that, he said, as he moved easily off the ropes. 'Cause I'm the champ. The only active heavyweight champ anyway. Muhammad Ali, the World Boxing Association champitin, ison a farewell world tour of exhibitions. Larry Holmek the World Boxing Council champion, is training for a June 22 title defense at Madison Square Garden against Mike Weaver, whose Hercules nick

title: Bail Set at $100,000 in S.I. Armored Truck Holdup
description: A 44yearold exconvict was held in lieu of $100,000 bail yesterday following his arraignment in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on charges that he took part in the $2.24 million robbery of a Wells Farm armored truck last Dec. 19.

title: Air Force Man, Home For a Funeral, Is Slain
description: An Air Force sergeant, home on leave to attend his father's funeral, was shot to death yesterday by a gunman firing at someone else as he walked on a Brooklyn street, according to the police.

title: Notes on People
description: After a delay of 12 years, a bust of Richard M. Nixon has been quietly installed on the staircase of the Senate, along with one of Lyndon B. Johnson. The marble busts are there not because the two were Presidents, but because as Vice President each presided over the Senate, and busts of all Vice Presidents since 1886 have eventually wound up on the staircase. The delay in the installation of the two busts is complicated to explain, but here goes.

title: News Summary
description: Ayatollah Khomeini was challenged over his declaration that all Iranians who did not subscribe to Islam and the leadership by the clery were enemies. His position was assailed by the director of Iran's national oil company. Later, Prime Minister Bazargan said on television that the decisionmaking roles are so numerous in our country that they have paralyzed much activity. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Rhodesia's Assembly Elects Black To Ceremonial Office of President
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 28  The two houses of the new blackdominated Parliament today chose Josiah Zion Gumede, a 59yearold black civil servant, to be President of Rhodesia when Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa's coalition government takes power on Friday.

title: New England Survey
description: Higher shortterm interest rates have affected cash flows and profits of New England's small businesses only slightly, if at all, according to nearly threequarters of the executives responding to a survey by The First National Bank of Boston and the Smaller Business Association of New England. However, their study, released yesterday, showed that almost the same number expected that the higher rates would affect cash flows in the next six months, and more than eight out of 10 believed profits would be affected in that period.

title: On Earning City Raises
description: Hardly anyone ever wants to pay elected officials more. Last year, a mayoral advisory committee, chaired by Richard Shinn, the president of Metropolitan Life, suggested raises of as much as $10,000 for members of the New York City Board of Estimate and City Council, but the idea succumbed to general indignation. Mayor Koch urged Mr. Shinn to establish a new committee to take another look and the new committee's hearing last week roused the same old furor.

title: Administration Widening Investigation of Herbicide Effects on Veterans
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  The Carter Administration has ordered the widening of an investigation of the longterm effects of exposure to Agent Orange, a herbicide that was widely applied as a defoliant in Vietnam for nearly a decade, a highranking Government official said today.

title: TV: A Dramatic Study Of 2 Lonely Characters
description: THE collaboration of the Maryland Center for Public BroadCasting and Baltimore's Center Stage, which last year produced a fine version of Melville's Bartleby the Scrivener, has suc- ceeded nicely once again with An Apple, an Orange. Adapted by Diane Johnson from her own prizewinning short story, the compact drama, essentially a twocharacter study, can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on WNETTV.

title: American Judge Frees East German Refugee In West Berlin Court
description: WEST BERLIN, May 28  A special United States court for West Berlin, in jury trial that raised complex constitutional, political and legal issues, today freed a 33yearold East Berliner charged with diverting a Polish airliner here last Year.

title: BusShelter Inquiry Focuses On New Report on Bidding
description: Investigations into the awarding of $100 million busshelter franchise in New York City are concentrating on new testimony and a handwritten memorandum that raise fresh questions about the propriety of the bidding process, according to principals involved in the investigations.

title: At Jordan Bridge, A Tough Check on Arabs
description: ALLENBY BRIDGE, Jordan, May 25  This border crossing point from Jordan into the occupied West Bank is a hot and dusty spot in the Jordan Valley enveloped by endless stretches of desert and an eerie silence.

title: Nuclear Realities
description: BOSTON  About a week after the accidental temporary loss of coolant from the core of the nuclear power plant at Three Mile Island, an electricutility executive told me: We've spent $400 million on a $1 billion new nuclearpower plant. The fate of that investment now appears to depend on the outcome of a semihysterical process. He is by no means the only anxious electricutility executive. The managements of all of the 90 companies that at the time of the accident had already invested a total of nearly $50 billion in partly built reactors are desperately worried.

title: Dietz Qualifies to Row In PanAmerican Games
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 28  Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club qualified for the United States rowing team that will compete in the Pan. American Games by winning the single sculls trials today.

title: Vance Makes It Clear He Won't Stay On After 1980
description: ROME, May 28  Almost imperceptibly, Cyrus R. Vance's time as Secretary of State has begun to run out.

title: Consumption of Candy Declines Again in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI) Americans ate less candy again last year, and the price reached $1 a pound for the first time, the Department of Commerce reported today.

title: T.V.A. Chairman After One Year
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  When S. David Freeman, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, and David E. Lilienthal, its spiritual father and former chairman, visited a nuclear power plant near here last week to mark the authority's 46th anniversary, Mr. Lilienthal was asked how he would handle the problems facing today's utility executives.

title: Jenkins Wins at Devon Despite Broken Thumb
description: DEVON, Pa., May 28  Riding with a broken left thumb, Rodney Jenkins piloted Doctor Smallie to victory in the intermediate jumper class today at the Devon horse show.

title: Edward E Butler, 70, Partner in a Law Firm
description: Edward F. Butler, senior partner in the New York City law firm of Conboy, Hewitt, O'Brien & Boardman, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Andean Nations In Accord
description: CARTAGENA, Colombia, May 28 Participants at the fivenation Andean summit meeting signed documents to set up a Court of Justice and to empower Julio Csar Turbay Ayala, president of Colombia, to represent Andean nations this July in negotiations to improve relations with the Common Market.

title: The City
description: Six people sustained injuries last night as a car swerved out of the path of another vehicle and jumped onto crowded sidewalk in Times. Square. The injuries were believed minor.

title: ExMet Gets 5th Homer
description: TOKYO, May 28 (AP)  Wayne Garrett, formerly of the New York Mets, hit a tyrorun homer in a losing cause today as the Hiroshima Toyo Carp edged the Chunichi Dragons, 54. The home run was Garrett's fifth of the Japanese League season.

title: Disclosures Straining Press Relations at Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  Recent unauthorized disclosures of Supreme Court decisions and the new security restrictions with which the Court responded have further strained an already tense relationship between the Court and the reporters who cover it and have provoked something of a press room debate about how the Court, the least accessible of national institutions, should be covered.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The American people, President Carter said the other day, have absolutely refused to accept a simple fact. We have an energy crisis . . . . We are going to have less oil to burn and we are going to have to pay more for it.

title: Pakula Will Film 'sophie's Choice
description: LOS ANGELES, May 28  Movie rights to Sophie's Choice, William Styron's newly published novel about a woman who has survived a Nazi concentration camp, have been purchased for more than $500,000 by Alan J. Palmla. Mr. Pakula, the director of All the President's Men, Klute and The Parallax View, wheedled a look at the galleys of Sophie's Choice eight weeks ago.

title: As Competency Exam Looms, a LastMinute Tutoring Attempt
description: The tutor took a dollar bill and four quarters from his pocket and asked his student:

title: HERBERT LANDSMAN, STORES OFFICIAL, DIES
description: Herbert S. Landsman, executive vice president and a director of Federated Department Stores Inc., died yesterday in a Cincinnati hospital after a long illness. He was 60 years old.

title: Young Georgians Study Folkways in Foxfire 5
description: Those who over the years have been following the documentation of Appalachian folkways and traditions, as pictured in the Foxfire books, will be happy to learn that Foxfire 5 is due from Doubleday/Anchor next month.

title: Opera: Desperate Husband Opens Spoleto
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., May 28 The third Spoleto Festival U.S.A. got under way here Friday, and will continue through June 10. This year's installment was fraught with some uncertainties, and the openingnight performance fell victim to an amateurish gaffe But where it counted  the quality of the performances and the charm of the city itself  the first weekend of the festival can be counted a huge success.

title: Order Continued Against Strike By State Supreme Court Officers
description: Justice Thomas J. Hughes of State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday continued until Thursday a temporary restraining order obtained by Attorney General Robert Abrams that prohibits 800 State Supreme Court officers in New York City from striking.

title: Adviser to Carter Calls for Defeat Of Rights Amendment Opponents
description: CLINTON, N.Y., May 28 (UPI) Sarah Weddington, President Carter's adviser on women's affairs, says that unseating opponents of the equal rights amendment in the 1980 elections could be the key to the amendment's adoption.

title: Ashe, Gottfried, Mayer Score in French Tennis
description: PARIS, May 28  Three seeded Americans  Arthur Ashe, Brian Gottfried and Tim Gullikson  won today as the $300,000 French open tennis championships began.

title: Joseph G. T. de Berry, Executive At Magazine, a Jet Crash Victim
description: Joseph G. T. de Berry, a magazine executive, was among the 273 persons killed in last Friday's crash of an American Airlines jet in Chicago. He was 47 years old and lived in Portland, Conn.

title: Policemen in Indian Town Clash With Supporters of Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, May 28 (Reuters)  At least 12 people were injured today in clashes between policemen and supporters of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi in the coastal town of Contai, in West Bengal, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: Layoff in Israeli Gem Plants
description: TEL AVIV, May 28 (Reuters)  All 10,000 workers in the Israeli diamondpolishing industry will be laid off during August because of a worldwide sales slump, the Diamond Exchange said today. Union leaders are demanding full pay for the enforced vacation. The industry exported polished stones worth more than $1.3 billion last year, making it Israel's biggest industrial export earner.

title: Long Lines and High Prices Welcome Returning Drivers
description: A steady stream of travelers ending the Memorial Day weekend flowed back into New York City late last evening as motorists contended with long lines, rising prices and limits on purchases at the handful of gasoline stations open in the metropolitan area.

title: Wage and Price Monitoring: A Random, Informal Process
description: WASHINGTON  Christine Kaplan was a program analyst with the Federal Energy Administration and later with the Consumer Products Safety Commission.

title: Nevada Approves Plan To Buy Gas for Tourists
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., May 28 (AP) The state Legislature approved today a $10 million fuelbuying plan aimed at guaranteeing visiting gamblers that they won't run out of gasoline.

title: Panel Backs Glomar Explorer Conversion
description: APANEL convened by the National Science Foundation to assess the feasibility of converting and operating the Glomar Explorer as the first ship capable of drilling into potential deepsea oil fields has decided that the $700 million project is justified.

title: Taxes
description: AFTER After two years of wailing and lobbying, Americans who live and work abroad wrung from Congress in 1978 a tax revision widely regarded as generous. The cost to the Treasury  revenue that would have been collected if Americans abroad had been taxed like Americans at home was estimated at $411 million for 1978. That left in the expatriates' pockets $156 million that would have been collected if Congress had enacted the less generous Administration bill, whose overall price tag was $255 million.

title: Carter's Aides Showing Toll Of Attacks From All Sides
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  Besieged by an unruly Congress, hurt by open defections to Senator Edward M. Kennedy and by the indictment of Bert Lance, bedeviled by national jitters and public suspicions over the politically explosive energy issue, the Carter Administration is suffering its worst malaise since taking office.

title: 6 at Mount Rushmore Rescued
description: KEYSTONE, S.D., May 28 (AP)  Six tourists who were stranded on a tramway to Mount Rushmore yesterday were rescued unharmed, according to the Pennington County Sheriff's office. Rescue teams from nearby Rapid City and Keystone used ropes and ladders to bring the riders to the ground. The passengers were seated for three hours in three tramway cars, hanging 20, 40 and 60 feet above the ground.

title: Brezenoff Supports FosterCare Billl
description: New York City's Human Resources Administrator said yesterday that he supported the general principles of a bill agreed upon last week by state legislators and Governor Carey for a major overhauling of the state's fostercare system. But he also offered some criticisms of the plan.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: LONDON May 28 (AP)  Gold bullion jumped more than $5 an ounce to another record price in Europe today, while the dollar held steady against other major currencies.

title: AkiiBua's Wife Tells of Ordeal
description: Petty personal jealousies and Uganda's partisan politics under Idi Amin took John AkiiBua out of international track and field in recent years at the peak of his running career, Mrs. Joyce AkiiBua said yesterday.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: Accounting for Genocide, by Helen Fein (Macmillan, $15.95). The Holocaust in occupied countries.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock exchanges, commodities markets and most banks throughout the United States were closed yesterday for Memorial Day. Banks in New York and Maryland, however, were open, but will be closed tomorrow for the traditional Memorial Day holiday. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York was also open yesterday and will be closed tomorrow.

title: OBSERVER
description: Aristotle, Sun Yatsen, Elizabeth Barrett Browning and Machiavelli chatted around the table with Steve Allen.

title: London Money Market Analyst Warns U.S. on Monetary Policy
description: Gordon T. Pepper, a slim, grayhaired, 44yearold economist, is London's answer to Wall Street's Henry Kaufman. Mr. Kaufman, a senior partner and chief economist at Salomon Brothers, is regarded as one of the Street's brightest pundits, and his analyses of the credit market and predictions about the economy are followed well beyond the investment world, in Government offices and corporate suites across the country.

title: Yes, Pay $1 Million
description: LOS ANGELES  This year's corporate proxy statements, which shareholders receive before annual meetings, reported for the first time the exact compensation of many of America's top executives. And it is high, indeed. More than a few are making in excess of $1 million a year and at least one executive earns twice that.

title: Hebner Symbolizes Mets' Risks to Obtain a Hitter
description: The key to the Mets new offense, especially last week when he was the hottest batter in town, is a 31-year-old bachelor from Boston who makes $200,000 a summer playing third base and considerably less each winter digging graves in West Roxbury. Mass.

title: Jersey Democratic Chiefs Voicing Doubts on Carter
description: TRENTON, May 28  Democratic party leaders in New Jersey  citing what they call increasing disaffection over President Carter's decision to make urbanaid programs absorb a large share of the budget cuts designed to stem inflation  say they have detected a growing concern about Mr. Carter's ability to win reelection.

title: Curren of Texas Takes N.C.A.A. Tennis Crown
description: ATHENS, Ga., May 28 (AP)  Kevin Curren of Texas captured the National Collegiate tennis singles championship today by beating Erick Iskersky of Trinity, 62, 62, 63, in the final. The topseeded Curren, a South African, did not lose a set in the tournament.

title: Scientists See a Loophole in the Fatal Law of Physics
description: SCIENTISTS in different fields are beginning to see a possible loophole in a fundamental law of physics that has for a century imprinted a profound pessimism upon the attitudes of science toward everything from cancer research to the fate of the universe.

title: Three Climb Third Highest Peak
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 28 (Reuters)  Three members of a British expedition have conquered Kanchenjunga, the third highest peak in the world, the Tourism Ministry said today. The 28,200foot summit has been reached by only two other expeditions.

title: Greece Becomes 10th Member of Common Market
description: ATHENS, May 28  Greece became the 10th member of Western Europe's Common Market today when the official papers were signed by Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis and representatives of the other member countries in a ceremony within sight of the Acropolis.

title: Johnny's Image Sets Mark
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 28 (AP)  Johnny's Image lost the lead in the stretch, then passed Star Spangled and won the $250,000 Invitational Turf. Handicap in the stakes and course record time of 2:25 1/5 for the 1mile event today at Hollywood Park. The winner paid $3.40.

title: Panel Criticizes industry In Grain Elevator Blasts
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  Many of the devastating explosions that ripped through grain elevators in the last two years might have been prevented if the operators had not returned dust to the wheat and corn they were preparing for shipment, according to a special panel in the Agriculture Department.

title: Ernest Doerfler, 72, Labor Expert And Adjunct Professor at Hunter
description: Ernest Doerfler, an adjunct professor of economics at Hunter College, died Sunday at his summer home at Three Arrows in Putnam County, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived in the Parkchester section of the Bronx.

title: Market Place
description: WHAT is a reasonable commission or service charge on an investment? Commission charges on buying or selling securities usually run 1 percent of the purchase price. In some commodities the fees could be higher, but 2 percent would be regarded as extraordinarily high in, for example, a contract for silver coins.

title: U.S. APPEARS TO BEAR OILSHORTAGE BRUNT
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  The United States is now bearing a disproportionate share of the world oil shortage, perhaps twothirds of the estimated shortfall of 1.2 million barrels. a day, according to Government and industry officials. They cite Federal policies and the changing nature of the international oil business as the reasons.

title: Sadat Sees No Early P.L.O. Role
description: CAIRO, May 28  President Anwar elSadat suggested today that he foresaw no role for the Palestine Liberation Organization in negotiations over the West Bank and Gaza Strip until well after selfgovernment had been established in those areas.

title: Science Watch
description: The Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory reported last week that it has developed a new and efficient way of using soot to capture the energy of sunlight in running large electric generators.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHEN all is said and done, William Styron's autobiographical novel, Sophie's Choice, is a stunning achievement. But I must say it had me worried for a while. Apparently, it had Mr. Stvron worried, too. In a survey of SOPHIE'S CHOICE. By William Styron. 515 pages. Random House. $12.95. concentrationcamp literature that he undertakes while preparing to write about his beloved Sophie Zawistowska, Mr. Styron's persona (Call me Stingo) comes across George Steiner's collection of essays, Language and Silence. Brooding over the issues that Steiner raises, Stingo tacitly admits to qualms about the fitness of writing fiction about the Holocaust. Yet finally he disagrees with Steiner. I cannot accept Steiner's suggestion that silence is the answer, that it is best not to add the trivia of literary, sociological debate to the unspeakable. Nor do I agree with the idea that In the presence of certain realities, art is trivial or impertinent. So he goes ahead and writes Sophie's Choice, which is to say he went ahead and wrote the novel we are reading.

title: L. I. Legislators Sue On New Gas Pricing
description: A group of Long Island County Legislators and consumer activists filed a suit in State Supreme Court in Albany yesterday challenging the state's emergency order permitting gasoline dealers to use halfgallon pricing.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurers' Stable Profits Lure Corporate Suitors
description: The Crown Central Petroleum Corporation, in a littlenoticed development, agreed the other day to pay $32 million in stock for the Continental American Life Insurance Company of Delaware.

title: Greece in Common Market: Risky Phase for Europe
description: ATHENS, May 28  When Greece formally signed up as the 10th member of the European Common Market today, it opened a risky new phase in Western Europe's postwar quest for greater unity and influence in world affairs.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Gas Crisis Spurs Layoffs in Auto, Industry
description: DETROIT, May 28  When the ternperature went into the high 80's and 90's inside some of the assembly buildings at Chrysler Corporation's Warren Truck plant, the workers used to take a walk, as a matter of course, until things cooled down.

title: Nina Ricci Sportswear For Autumn in New York
description: Which came first, the perfume or the dress?

title: FixedIncome Schedule Light
description: With much of the credit markets closed both on Monday and Wednesday for holidays, the volume of new fixedincome financing this week will be light. Only $167 million of corporate notes and $320 million of taxexempt notes and bonds are scheduled for sale, a level well below average.

title: Family Violence: Another View
description: Violence in the family is best understood not as the isolated act of a single individual but as an eruption traceable to complex relationships within that family, according to Dr. Rodney J. Shapiro, a University of Rochester psychologist.

title: Art: The Erotica of Picasso Comes Home
description: BARCELONA, Spain, May 28 There is a sense in which the whole immense oeuvre of Pablo Picasso (18811973) one of the most copious artists who ever lived  forms a single, unbroken autobiographical account of his life. He began, as many artists do, by painting his family and friends and the places where he lived, and he never really stopped doing this through all the many changes in style for which he was celebrated.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets strode jauntily ahead last week for four consecutive days, recording their biggest advance since January as bond traders and portfolio managers began to take seriously the possibility that interest rates may have peaked. As the spectacular week ended, however, the dominant view seemed to be that rates were still basically headed upward.

title: Chiasso Bank's ExChief Takes Blame for Scandal
description: GENEVA, May 28  Ernst Kuhrmeier, the former head of the Credit Suisse branch in the southern Swiss city of Chiasso, accepted full responsibility in court today, during opening testimony, for one of the worst scandals in Swiss banking history.

title: Rivers Homer Beats Brewers by 21  Davis Wins First
description: MILWAUKEE, May 28  The last time Reggie Jackson tried to bunt, a series of cataclysmic events ensued. Jackson was suspended for five days, the Yankees began their historic comeback from a 14game deficit and Billy Martin tearfully disappeared and instantly reappeared.

title: About Education
description: FOR years, the sprawling elementary school had been a model of good education and effective integration. A toughminded but compassionate principal inspired confidence among children, parents and faculty members. Student teachers competed for permanent assignments in his school, and he picked his staff with care. When necessary, he shrewdly beat the system to get what he deemed essential.

title: About New York
description: One of the city's overlooked virtues  the quiet strength of the virtue of Queens  will be on display next week when Martin L. Simms steps, forward to receive his diploma at York College.

title: Spain Declares $20 Bed An Artistic Heritage
description: MADRID, May 28 (Reuters)  A bed valued at $20 has been declared part of Spain's national artistic heritage.

title: Q & A
description: Q.  Why doesn't a spider get caught in its own veeb?

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Around the Nation
description: JACKSON, Miss., May 28 (AP)  An evacuation ordered after scientists found an apparently radioactive frog and a deformed lizard near a site of 1960's atomic weapons tests was accidentally triggered by a contaminated laboratory dish, a University of Mississippi spokesman says:

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: MSGR. PATRICK A. O'LEARY

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amax Inc., a natural resources company, has elected Rolf Genssler president of its Amax Nickel division.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: L. Merrill Rasmussen has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the Husky Oil Company, the subsidiary of Husky Oil Ltd. that is responsible for its United States petroleum operations. He succeeds James E. Nielson, who remains president and chief executive officer of the parent corporation, based in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Beaumont and 2 Unions Sign for Reopening in '80
description: The new management of the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center has taken an important step toward its planned reopening of the building in early or mid1980 by signing contracts with two major theatrical unions, Actors Equity and the International Al- liance of Theatrical Employees, Local 1, the stagehands' organization. The final step in the negotiations was the ratification of the agreement late last week by the membership of Local 1.

title: Advertising
description: A PPROFESSOR at the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration would appear to have the answer to a lot of adland prayers. In a time of soaring TV time costs, he is offering a way of condensing commercials without remov- ing any content. And in a time of increasing clutter, the same system, he says, increases the memorability of the message.

title: Joseph PoIlet, Painter, Known for Landscapes,
description: Joseph Pollet, an artist, died Saturday in New York Hospital at the age of 81. He lived at Westbeth, the artists housing complex in west Greenwich Village.

title: Sedate Russians Hear Elton John
description: MOSCOW, May 28  Elton John, billed as singer and pianist, hit Moscow with his rock songs this week after a fourday tour in Leningrad and summed up the experience this way: I think people here are not used to the sort of concert we give them.

title: EDUCATION
description: IN the spring of 1977, Serge Lang, a professor of mathematics at Yale University, received a questionnaire soliciting his views on topics ranging from grade inflation to defense spending.

title: Angus L. Bowrner, 74, Founder Of Oregon Shakespeare Festival
description: Angus L. Bowmer, whose devotion to Shakespeare began in the little town of Bellingham, Wash., where he was born and taught school, and flowered in the formation of the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, died Saturday in Ashland, Ore. He was 74 years old.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The United States appears to be bearing perhaps twothirds of the world oil shortage of 1.2 million barrels a day, Government and industry officials say. As a result, the Department of Energy has quietly changed its policy opposing American purchases on the costly spot market. [Page A1.]

title: Stress Can Cause Work Epidemics
description: CINCINNATI IN a small Midwestern plant, a group of women are assembling aluminum lawn furniture. Suddenly, one of them, then another and another, sees a blue mist hovering over the workers. In ones and twos, then by the score, the women begin to complain of headaches, bad tastes in their mouths, dizziness, lightheadedness and weakness. The symptoms spread like wildfire, the workers head for the exits and the plant is closed for several days while industrial hygienists take air samples and search for toxic chemicals that may have caused the outbreak.

title: '78 Output Off For Aramco
description: BAHRAIN, May 28 (Reuters) Saudi Arabia's ArabianAmerican Oil Company produced an average 8.1 million barrels of crude oil daily last year, compared with 9 million barrels the preceding year, an oil industry journal reported today.

title: U.S. Banks Lift Europe Borrowing
description: For the first time since 1973, American banks have become net borrowers from the Eurocurrency markets, reflecting the recent improvement in the overall balance of payments of the United States, according to banking sources.

title: Russian Hints Soviet Would Favor A Rejection by Turkey of U2 Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  A highranking Soviet official said today that Moscow would welcome a decision by Turkey to turn down an American request to fly reconnaissance planes over Turkish territory as part of an effort to monitor Soviet compliance with the new armslimitation treaty.

title: Chemical Links Found Between Body Functions And Behavior
description: NEW discoveries have revealed surprising links between the chemistry of behavior and that of other body functions in humans and animals. Chemicals of a group called peptides, long known principally for their actions on blood vessels, the kid- neys, temperature regulation or other functions outside the brain, have been found to perform key roles in signaling within the brain and in the control of such perceptions as thirst, pain, emotion and perhaps even memory.

title: More Effective Justice for Juveniles
description: Now that electionyear emotion over teenage crime has subsided, it may be safe politically for the New York Legislature to reconsider its decision to prosecute violent adolescents as adults. We thought the law wrong when it was adopted  hastily conceived and needlessly harsh. In light of actual experience, the case for repeal is even stronger.

title: Carl Lewis Takes Jump, Sprint in Eastern Track
description: Vince Draddy won the 880yard run in 1 minute 51.5 seconds and Greg Herzog was first in the mile in 4:12.9. But it was Carl Lewis of Willingboro (NJ.) High who was the most impressive performer yesterday in the rainsoaked Eastern States schoolboy track and field championships at Downing Stadium on RandalIs Island.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AWAY THEY GO New Yorkers who enjoyed television runoffs of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness in recent weeks now have a bonus  a new photography display on the sport of kings starting tomorrow in midtown. The place is Nikon House, the showroom and demonstration center for camera and optical equipment at 620 Fifth Avenue, overlooking the Rockefeller Center skating rink.

title: COLLEGE IN DISPUTE IS TIED TO NEW YORK
description: Nova University, a Floridabased institution offering doctoral degrees in more than 20 states, conducts one such program in New York and Connecticut without authorization from either state.

title: Mark of Moses At Jones Beach 50 Years Later
description: WANTAGH, L.I., May 28  The 50th season of operations at, Jones Beach State Park began last weekend, and, despite numerous manmade changes and some that nature forced on it, this heath still seems indelibly marked by the mind and character of Robert Moses, Master builder of New York State's parks, bridges and highways.

title: Dallas Story: Fortune Made in a Hurry, Lost in a Hurry, Then Death at 39
description: DALLAS, May 28  Even when things went bad, when the $400,000 yacht, the RollsRoyce and the Playboy Club that he owned were gone and he had a $2.2 million debt to the Internal Revenue Service, Joel H. McQuade maintained a special affection for Dallas.

title: Cosmos Beaten by Sting For Second Setback, 31
description: CHICAGO, May 28  The Cosmos suffered their second loss of the season today, bowing to a superior Chicago Sting squad, 31, before 21,127 fans at Wrigley Field.

title: Soprano: Joung ja Kim
description: THERE were some charming moments during Joung Ja Kim's recital Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, but they occurred in spite of the Korean soprano's technical limitations, rather than through any marked success in surmounting them.

title: U.S. Orders All DC10's Inspected For Bolt Defect Linked to Disaster
description: CHICAGO, May 28  The Government today ordered airlines flying DC10 jumbo jets to immediately inspect or replace enginemounting bolts like the one suspected of having contributed to the crash of an American Airlines DC10 on Friday. The crash took 273 lives, the highest toll of any air disaster in this country.

title: Falcone Loses 5th Straight  Rain Delays Game
description: The Mets, who have demanded a lot of patience from their dwindling band of fans in the last three National League seasons, got down to the hard core yesterday.

title: Israeli Shells Kill 2, Lebanon Says
description: BEIRUT, May 28  Three days of Israeli bombardment of the Lebanese Mediterranean port of Tyre has destroyed several buildings, killed two people and sunk several fishing boats in the harbor, according to a Government announcement here.

title: Strauss Denial Emphatic
description: Mr. Strauss emphatically denied yesterday that he had issued any ultimatum in the textile negotiations in Peking. Reached by telephone there at 5:30 P.M. New York time (5:30 A.M. Peking time today), he said: I told them we leave here around the 31st, and we have issued no ultimatum to anybody.

title: Legislators Want to Be Names
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 28  Westchester County's 17member Board of Legislators, chafing under the impression that County Executive Alfred B. DelBello gets all the publicity, has come up with a solution of sorts. Their names are to appear on county signs whenever his name appears.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)  The United States Ambassador to the Central African Empire is being recalled to Washington following reports that about 100 school children were massacred there last month, the State Department announced today.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: ROBERT J. PLUMB

title: State Senator Who Died in Crash Of Helicopter Is Buried in Idaho
description: KELLOGG, Idaho, May 28 (UPI) State Senator Gerald Blackbird, who flew 1,400 helicopter missions in the Vietnam War and died last Monday when a copter he was piloting crashed in Idaho, was buried today with full military rites.

title: Deaths
description: ANTON  Jennie. Beloved mother of Muriel Anton and Martha and Charles Friedman. Loving grandmother of Alan and Wendy Friedman. Services Tuesday, 1:30 PM, Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapel, Queens Blvd & 76 Rd, Forest Hills.

title: The Doctor's World
description: COMPANY DOCTORS and occupational medicine specialists, who have made major contributions to public health, are in short supply, and their scarcity threatens to curtail further reductions in health hazards in the workplace.

title: State Dinner ($61.40) Scores; Alydar Sixth
description: Calumet Farm switched tactics for Alydar yesterday in the $108,300 Metropolitan Handicap, but the new strategy turned out to be a disaster for chalk players who had sent him to the post at 25.

title: IRAN'S OIL DIRECTOR DISPUTES AYATOLLAH ON PRIMACY OF ISLAM
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 28  The head of Iran's national oil company today criticized Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's declaration that all who did not subscribe to Islam and the leadership of the clergy should be considered enemies.

title: Robots May Soon Do AssemblyLine Jobs
description: WARREN, Mich. ALICE, as the staff in the lab at the General Motors Technical Center here calls its small, gangly robot, picked up seven screws and dropped them quickly and precisely into seven holes in a carburetor part.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Retaining SSC&B
description: The 138yearold Dun & Bradstreet Corporation has just retained SSC&B to do its first corporate campaign, not an imagetype campaign, but, the company explained, businesstobusiness advertising that will emphasize products and markets  an umbrella marketing campaign.

title: Herbicides Pose a Bitter Mystery In U.S. Decades After Discovery
description: Forty years after the concept of plant growth regulators began to appear in scientific journals, herbicide use remains the subject of bitter debate and of lawsuits involving potentially hundreds of millions of dollars, and the center of a great mystery.

title: Black Held in Klansman Shooting
description: DECATUR, Ala., May 28  A black City Hall maintenance worker was arrested today in the shooting of a Ku Klux Klan official who led his followers in a confrontation with black marchers Saturday.

title: Murder Takes the Spotlight In Staid Connecticut Town
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., May 28  In a secondfloor courtroom in the stone courthouse on the green here, jury selection will start tomorrow morning in the trial of Steven M. Asherman, a 29yearold fourthyear medical student at Columbia University. He is accused Of the murder of a classmate, Michael Aranow, whose body was found on the 184acre estate of his uncle, Frank W.

title: Bridge:
description: A unique double became a unique triple at the Statler Hilton Hotel in Manhattan Sunday night in the Eastern Regional Championships. Uniquer would be the appropriate adjective if there were degrees of uniquity.

title: Pakistan Frees Widow And Daughter of Bhutto
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, May 28 (AP) Nusrat Bhutto, widow of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the executed Prime Minister, and their daughter Benazir were released today from detention in the Sehala police camp near Islamabad and were flown here, the Government said.

title: Smarten Victor at Keystone
description: CORNWELLS HEIGHTS, Pa., May 28  Ryehill Farm's Smarten upheld form in the first running of the $114,800 Pennsylvania Derby today at Keystone, winning by three lengths as the 25 favorite in a sixhorse field.

title: Transway's Next Chief Sets Growth as Goal
description: The position of chief executive officer of the Transway International Corporation will pass on July 1 to John W. Wolcott, the 54 yearold president, from G. Russell Moir, the 66yearold chairman. The transition at the company, which began as a freight forwarder but which has since expanded into other fields, had been expected.

title: City's Hospital System To Undergo ShakeUp Cutting Bureaucracy
description: New York City announced yesterday that it would sharply reduce the highly centralized administration of its

title: UConn Ousts St. John's, Gains N.C.A.A. Finals
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 28  The University of Connecticut earned its first college baseball world series invitation since 1972 today when it defeated St. John's of New York, 40, in the final of the National Collegiate Northeast Regional playoffs at Navy's Bishop Stadium.

title: Deadline Set by Strauss On Chinese Textile Pact
description: PEKING, May 28 (AP)  Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special trade representative, said today that he had given China three days to decide whether to accept or reject United States terms for a textile agreement, but he called chances for a settlement iffy.

title: The Region
description: CANTON, Conn. (AP)  A politically outspoken restaurant operator and his wife, both charged last week with illegal gambling, were burned severely yesterday by a fire in their living quarters behind the restaurant. The couple  Domenick Cifarelli, 55 years old, and his wife, Patricia, 46  were taken to the University, of Connecticut Medical Center, in Farmington, then transferred to Hartford Hospital's burn unit.

title: Woman Pitches 3 Shutouts in Day
description: OMAHA, Neb., May 28 (AP)  Kathy Arendsen of Texas Women's University hurled three softball shutout victories yesterday. She gave up only five hits in 21 innings of fastpitch softball and struck out 31 batters as her team won the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women's college world series.

title: Radio
description: 9:0610, WQXR: Piano Personalities. Eugene List. Three Preludes, Gershwin; Bamboo's; The Dying Poet, Gottschalk.

title: Meen Gets $270, 401
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 28 (AP)  Rick Mears earned $270,401 for his threehour winning drive in the annual 500 race yesterday, the Indianapolis Motor Speedway announced tonight.

title: Two House Democrats Underscore Carter's Difficulties in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, May 28  Amid polls showing. President Carter to be in deep political trouble with Connecticut Democrats, two Representatives who are the leading Democratic contenders for the United States Senate nomination next year have widened their distance from the President and his enemy policies.

title: Commodities
description: THE sugar futures market has been both uncommonly frustrating and predictable for traders since 1979. Recently, however, it has become far more nervefraying than predictable, because it is dominated by what Congress may or may not do with two vital pieces of legislation. And Congress shows no sign of acting on either bill.

title: Common Market AT A GLANCE
description: The European Economic Community, or Common Market, is an association of countries seeking a continous and balanced expansion of Europe's economy to foster political stability and, eventually, unity by eliminating customs duties among members and setting up common transport, agricultural and external trade policies. It was established Jan. 1, 1958 based on the Treaty of Rome signed March 25, 1957 by Belgium, France, West Germany, Luxembourg, Italy and the Netherlands. It was preceded by a Coal and Steel Community (1951). An Atomic Energy Community was founded along with the economic community. Great Britain, Denmark and Ireland became members in 1973. An agreement for eventual membership was signed first with Greece in 1962. A similar agreement was signed with Turkey in 1964. Spain and Portugal

title: Israel Frees 16 Arabs in Peace Gesture
description: JERUSALEM, May 28  Israel today freed 16 Arab prisoners in what officials called a goodwill gesture to President Anwar elSadat of Egypt.

title: Entertainment Events
description: DELMIRO COUVEIA, In Portuguese with English subtitles. selected by Geraldo Sarno, Public Theater, 425 Lelavette Street.

title: Senate Confirmation Role Sought On Posts of Brzezinski and Aide
description: WASHINGTON, May 28  Long resentment in Congress over the influence exerted on foreign policy by Presidential advisers such as Zbigniew Brzezinski and Henry A. Kissinger has created an unexpected problem for the Carter Administration on a major piece of legislation.

title: For Felix in the Attic, A Moment in Spotlight
description: For some reason they have locked Felix in the attic ... the children's book begins; on a mysterious but casual note of anxiety. Felix, a little boy of indeterminate age with a nose reminiscent of Pinnochio, proceeds to invent for himself a survival course in selfsufficiency that all but retraces the human experience.

title: Shift of Portrait at City Hall Is a Matter of a President's Pants
description: With little doing in City Hall yesterday, the Federal celebration of Memorial Day, a longstanding question of some Federal and municipal import was finally explained.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8:30 P.M. RadioWMCA, 8:20 P.M.)

title: U.S. Seen Clarifying Bribery Law
description: WASHINGTON, May 27  Overriding the objections of its own enforcement officials, the Carter Administration is preparing to take steps that could undermine a law prohibiting payment of bribes overseas by American corporations, according to highlevel sources in the Justice Department.

title: Suit Against Penney And Officials Fails
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan has dismissed a $10 million damage suit filed last year against the J.C. Penney Company and 12 present or former officials by two of its former auditors.

title: Most Banks Closed Today in New York
description: Most banks in New York State and Maryland will be closed today in observance of the traditional Memorial Day holiday. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York will also be closed today. Stock exchanges and commodities markets will be open.

title: The Supreme but Uneasy Bench
description: The Supreme Court, which often decides whether Government is sufficiently open to the public, sits in an atmosphere of siege these days. A television correspondent breached its vaults and revealed the Court's decisions before they were ready for delivery.

title: Boy Missing From SoHo Was on Own First Time
description: Last Friday was the first day that 6-year-old Etan Patz had ever been allowed to walk alone the two blocks from his home to a school bus. His mother said yesterday that she had yielded to the blond, blueeyed youngster's pleas that he was grown up enough to go out alone.

title: Citicorp Note Rate Down
description: Citicorp sold $100 million of 90-day notes yesterday at an average interest rate of 10.049 percent, down from 10.208 percent last week and the lowest rate in the bank holding company's weekly sales since April 24. A total of $711.3 million of orders was submitted, with those accepted ranging in rate from 10.03 percent to 10.055 percent.

title: Carter Feels Soviet Will Let Kin Of Released Dissidents Emigrate
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  President Carter expressed confidence today that the Soviet Union would soon permit the emigration of the families of five dissidents who arrived in the United States last month under a prisoner exchange agreement.

title: Dr. Marynia Farnham, Author, 79
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., May 29  Dr. Marynia F. Farnham, a psychiatrist and author who practiced for many years in New York City, died in her sleep at nursing home here today. She was 79 years of age.

title: The Tellers Are Small but They Can Tell a Tall Tale
description: A cockroach named .Martina, a mouse called Perez anda cat4namillion that was too lovely to leaVe brought citywide storytelling championships yesterday to 8yearold Chonte Dubose and 10yearold Gregory Hall. Theywere among 10 finalists in a competition that, had involved 8,000 publicschool children since December:

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Another battle may be brewing between Leon J. and Ralph Levitz, the founders of the Levitz Furniture Corporation, and the company's management, headed by Robert M. Elliott. The two Levitz brothers  who, with Ralph's son Phillip A. Levitz, own about 25 percent of the company's stock  are directors but no longer officers of Levitz, a pioneer in pickandpack furniture warehouse showrooms.

title: Council's Panel Expects Ouster For Mastropieri
description: The chairman of the New York City Council Ethics Committee said yesterday that it appeared that Councilman Eugene F. Mastropieri would be dismissed from the Council as the committee had recommended.

title: Carter Aides to Discuss Harlem Trade Center
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  New York City officials will be meeting with White House aides tomorrow to discuss plans for a world trade center in Harlem, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, said today.

title: CocaCola Bottler Is Acquired by KW
description: KW Inc. announced it has purchased all of the stock of the CocaCola Bottling Company of Middletown, Conn. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Deaths
description: PERLEN  Benjamin, The Board of Governors and Members of Pine Hollow Country Club express their feelings of deep loss and sorrow at the passing of a beloved meatier.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: THE instruction may seem unappealing and almost incidental, one little chore in the midst of a flurry of others included in a recipe: It tells you to skim off the fat or the scum on the surface of a soup, gravy or sauce. Trivial though it may seem, the skimming procedure does matter considerably. A taste of grease lingering on the lips can ruin the impression of a soup.

title: Mizzorewa Sworn In as First Black Rhodesian Premier
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 29  In setting redolent of the colonial era, Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa was sworn in today as the first black Prime Minister of Zimbabwe Rhodesia, as the country will be called when his government officially takes office on Friday.

title: WASHINGTON
description: The critical battering of President Carter goes on, but somehow it does not seem to affect his personal serenity. He is clearly disappointed at the opposition within the Congress to his energy and arms limitation policies, and hurt by the opposition to his Presidency within the Democratic Party, but he avoids personal recriminations and retains his usual calm determination.

title: China Approves Peking Bureaus For Four American Newspapers
description: China has granted permission to four American newspapers to open bureaus in Peking, the papers have been informed, but no visas have been issued for correspondents.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Assembly Votes Repeal Of Animal Shelter Law
description: ALBANY, May 29  The State Assembly voted tonight to repeal a controversial law that forces animal shelters to yield dogs and cats to scientific research institutions for experimentation. The vote was 121 to 17.

title: Shirley Hazzard Ends Work on Her Big Novel
description: A major novel by Shirley Hazzard (who wrote Cliffs of Fall and People in Glass Houses), which a spokesperson for her publisher, Viking, described as longer and much more complex than anything this writer has done previously, will be published next suing.

title: Guide to Phone Booths That Merit a Detour
description: CtRISTOPHER REEVE may not have been able to find a phone booth when it was time o switch into his Superman suit, but that's because he didn't know where to look. While the noisy, exposed monstrosities Ma Bell is offering these days do seem to be taking over, there are still a few places left where it's possible to change costumes, rest your feet or just make a phone call unbuffeted by wind, rain or the elbows of fellow phoners. All have seats, some of marble.

title: Barclays Shift in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, May 29, (Reuters)  Barclays Bank International Ltd. is discontinuing personal banking in Chicago but will expand its corporate banking and foreignexchange activities, Raymond Birdseve. senior vice president said today. The Britishbased bank, here since 1973, is closing the retail operation to reduce costs and to concentrate on areas in which we have expertise. he said.

title: Ballet Nacional de Cuba To Open at Met July 10
description: The Ballet Nacional de Cuba will perform at the Metropolitan Opera House in Lincoln Center for three weeks beginning July 10. Under the direction of Alicia Alonso, the prima ballerina who founded the group 30 years ago, the company will perform 23 ballets, including Rare Avis, Night of the Guitar, Remembranza, Time Out of Mind, Giselle, Flower Festival, Song for a Strange Flower, Les Sylphides and a new production of Swan Lake.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities Of ABC News:

title: Critics Question Airlines' Figures On Cargo Thefts
description: Although the nation's largest robbery occurred at Kennedy International Airport last December, when holdup men took $5.8 million in cash and jewels from Lufthansa's cargo building, lawenforcement agencies say that cargo theft at air- ports in the New York City region has been dramatically curtailed in recent years.

title: Political Violence in Spain: Threat to a Young Democracy
description: MADRID, May 29  The most savage outbreak of political violence since the death of Francisco Franco, 17 people killed and 42 wounded in two days last week, has made Madrid fearful, and led some Spaniards to wonder how long their young democracy can absorb the terrorist shocks.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution leaves the states free to administer their parole systems in any way they choose, with no requirement that inmates be allowed to participate in parole board bearings or be informed of the reasons for denial or parole.

title: Price Guide Eased For 7 Companies
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  The Council on Wage and Price Stability today announced that it had approved exceptions to the basic price deceleration formula for seven large companies and had rejected the applications for exception of eight other companies.

title: Events
description: SAINTS ALIVE! comedy by Charles Carmello; directed by Frank Leary, Actors Playhouse, 100 Seventh Avenue South, 7.

title: Barnes Charged in Beating Of His Estranged Wife
description: PROVIDENCE, RI., May 29 (AP) Marvin Barnes, former college and professional basketball star, pleaded not guilty today to a misdemeanor charge of assaulting his estranged wife and was released pending further court action.

title: Rogers of Expos Pitches Second Shutout in a Row
description: MONTREAL, May 29 (UPI)  Ellis Valentine drove in four runs with a homer and a double and Steve Rogers tossed his second consecutive shutout tonight, pacing the Montreal Expos to a 90 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Hottest Hunan Restaurant in
description: If the ultimate perfume for most nostrils is the sweet smell of success, then Diana and Henry Chung, are now inhaling what might be called the sweet and pungent aroma of public esteem on the West Coast. For a couple of years they have been the proprietors of Hunan, the most talked about restaurant in San Francisco, and the history of their flourishing enterprise reads like an O. Henry story.

title: Sonics Defeat Bullets
description: SEATTLE, May 29. Gus Williams scored 36 points and Dennis Johnson had 32 as the Seattle SuperSonics defeated the Washington Bullets in overtime tonight by 119112 in the National Basketball Association final playoffs.

title: Libya Raises Price Of Oil to Record
description: Libya Raises Price Of Oil to Record

title: The Hite Report Author Sues Publisher
description: In what was described as an extraordinary step in the publishing world, Shere Hite, author of The Hite Report, a bestselling study of female sexuality, yesterday sued her publisher, the Macmillan Publishing Company, for allegedly withholding from her about $780,000 in royalties.

title: Wine Talk
description: SAN FRANCISCO MOST of the larger wineries in the country north of here have tasting rooms and guest books for visitors to sign. At one of them last week someone, apparently a teetotaler, scrawled across an entire page: God will get you for this!

title: April Building Awards Up Despite Drop for Housing
description: Although homebuilding slumped sharply last month, contracts for commercial and nonbuilding construction projects (such as generating equipment and highways) raised the total value of new projects 17 percent from April 1978, the F. W. Dodge Division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American MalzeProducts Company, a diversified industrial and consumer products company, has named Edgar D. Gates vice president of personnel and administration.

title: Letters
description: To THE LIVING SECTION:

title: New York Attorney Criticizes Argentina's Lawyers
description: A Manhattan lawyer criticized Argentine lawyers yesterday for doing practically nothing to help maintain a system of justice in Argentina.

title: Mary Pickford Is Dead at 86; America's Sweetheart of Films
description: Mary Pickford, who reigned supreme as America's Sweetheart in the era of silent films, died of a stroke yesterday in Santa Monica (Calif.) Hospital. She was 86 years old.

title: Advertising
description: THE Lorillard folks, who already have 80 percent of their cigarette business in lowtar brands, are going national with still another one Triumph  on the heels of the recent, apparently successful national debut of Kent IN. Both brands have 3 milligrams of tar and 0.4 milligram of nicotine.

title: April Strike Loss Highest in 9 Years
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) The number of working days lost to strikes last month was the highest for the month in nine years, mainly because of a nationwide work stoppage in the trucking industry, the Government reported today.

title: Ensemble Studio Theater Sets OneAct Marathon
description: The Ensemble Studio Theater's annual OneAct Marathon will open June 13 and continue through June 25. The marathon will consist of a series of 13 new oneact plays, each to be performed six times during the 13day period.

title: Troubles Plague Poles Planning Papal Visit
description: WARSAW, May 29  At 10 A.M. Saturday, when John Paul II steps for the first time as Pope onto the soil of his native Poland, every church bell in the nation will toll. They will toll, that is, if the bell ringers know he has arrived.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DETROIT, May 29 (AP)  The Chrysler Corporation will permanently close its Hamtramck, Mich., assembly plant at the end of the 1980 model year, the company said today.

title: ABC of Vitamins Is Far From Simple
description: THROUGHOUT most of evolution, food was our only source of vitamins. Today, however, the oneaday multivitamin pill is a kind of nutri- tional insurance policy for millions of Americans, whether they need it or not. In recent years it's been eclipsed by megadose formulations of individual vitamins supposedly capable of performing health miracles far beyond warding off the wellknown vitamin deficiency diseases.

title: Top Court Bars Deduction For PrivateSchool Cost
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  The Supreme Court ruled today that New Jersey cannot constitutionally provide a special incometax deduction for parents who send their children to nonpublic schools.

title: Phyllis Dove and the Killer Instinct
description: Skipper Lofting, author, artist, steeplechase jockey, coxswain, cowboy, pilot, bareback bronc wrangler, angler and mighty hunter before the Lord, is losing his blood lust. This a graver loss than you might imagine, for Skipper's killer instinct was stronger than you would believe. There is real

title: Interway Accepts New Suitor
description: In a transaction completed by telephone over the weekend, directors of the Transamerica Corporation agreed to pay some $207 million in cash for the Interway Corporation of New York, a major transportation renting and leasing company.

title: New York Police Recruiting Minority Applicants for Test
description: As a youth growing up in East Harlem, Tyrone Woodson said, he was frequently hassled by the police because he was black.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: GABRIEL MASON, 94; BROOKLYN EDUCATOR
description: First Lincoln High School Principal Taught Philosophy in College Dr. Gabriel R. Mason, who was principal of Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn for 25 years, died in New York City Monday following a stroke. He was 94 years old.

title: The Region
description: New York's job count rose by 39,700 to 7,049,600 last month, but the state's Labor Department said the gain was far below the MarchtoApril increases of the last two years.

title: Agency Finds Coaching Can Raise S.A.T. Scores
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  A staff report showing that commercial coaching may help raise the scores of some students on the Scholastic Aptitude Test was released today by the Federal Trade Commission, which immediately cautioned against regarding the findings as an endorsement of coaching.

title: Going out Guide
description: CELLINI'S TRAIL Beauty and imagination invariably mark the yearly arrays of winners in the Sterling Silver Design Competition, and the public is invited to inspect Statements in Sterling/79 tomorrow through June 19 in the lobby of Lever House, Park Avenue and 53d Street. The show Will spotlight 11 winners and 67 additional entries designed and crafted by advanced design students throughout the country. The contest sponsors are the Sterling Silversmiths of America.

title: Gun Used in Bedford Hills Slayings Recovered in Brooklyn, Police Say
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 29  A .32caliber pistol seized by the police in Brooklyn during the arrest of robbery suspects there on Sunday hal been identified by ballistics experts as the weapon used to kill four residents of Bedford Hills in suburban Westchester County earlier this month, according to lawenforcement sources in Westchester and Brooklyn.

title: Scars of Vietnam War Appear to Be Fading
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  A woman in a sky blue dress walked alone among the legions of dead at Arlington after rain chased the midafternoon heat from the national cemetery.

title: McCarter Names Alison Harris
description: Alison Harris has been named to succeed Edward A. Martenson as managing director of the McCarter Theater Company of Princeton, N.J. Miss Harris. whose appointment becomes effec- tive July 1, is administrator and assistant to Arvin Brown, artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. Before joining the Long Wharf, in 1972, she had been associated for three years with the McCarter.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: TWO sisters who had a tiny, elderly grandmother living with them decided to go shopping, writes Sylvia Jaffe. The grandmother, always being left home alone, pleaded with them to take her with them. Knowing she could really not walk or stay on her feet for long, they protested that it would be very difficult for her; but she persisted pathetically until they relented.

title: Fink Tours Power Plant And Talks Some Politics
description: MASSENA, N.Y., May 29  Stanley Fink, the Speaker of the State Assembly, came to this town on the Canadian border today to have a look at alternate energy sources and :o meet people from this area, known locally as the North Country.

title: Amex Index at High Again
description: Some Canadianbased energy issues scored brisk gains yesterday as the marketvalue index of the American Stock Exchange posted another new high. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average eased 3.73 points to 832.55.

title: South Africa Curbs Asked in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 29 Sixtysix countries jointly requested the Security Council today to call for punitive sanctions against South Africa for refusing to carry out the United Nations plan for the independence of SouthWest Africa.

title: OSCAR TRACHTENBERG
description: Oscar Trachtenberg, a retired sales manager with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company of New York, died yesterday in a White Plains nursing home. He was 74 years old and lived in Brooklyn. He is survived by his wife, Shoshana; his son, Stephen, the president of the University of Hartford; two sisters, Frieda Strunin and Dorothy Trachtenberg, and two grandchildren.

title: U.S. GROUNDS DC10'S AFTER CHECK SHOWS GRAVE DEFICIENCIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  The Government, in a dramatic change in policy, ordered the grounding today of all 135 DC10 widebodied airliners owned by American companies because structural problems in their engine mounts appear to be widespread and more serious than was first suspected.

title: TV: Clytemnestra Ends May, We Dance Series
description: BURDENED with the contrived umbrella title of May, We Dance, WNETTV's special monthlong series of dance productions comes to a brilliant conclusion tonight at 9 with Martha Graham's Clytemnestra. It is this season's final production for Dance in America, a public television project that has succeeded splendidly under the sensitive and knowledgeable guidance of the producers, Merrill Brockway and Emile Ardolino.

title: Local Governors Have No Plan to Use Powers
description: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are among the 31 states that have passed laws giving their governors emergency powers to regulate gasoline sales and are thus not affected by President Carter's executive order extending parallel Federal powers to governors of the 19 states without such laws.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Sandwiched between two semiholidays, the credit markets yesterday dawdled through an inconsequential day. Bond prices fell slightly and then recoverea to close with small net dedines, their first in five trading days.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Over the years I have read about one meal or another described as lucullan. I know it means great, but where did the name originate?

title: Judge Bars HalfGallon Gas Sales In Reversal of Albany's Decision
description: A Supreme Court Justice in Albany issued a temporary injunction yesterday restraining all gasoline stations in the state from selling gas by the halfgallon.

title: Gerulaitis In Danger Of Upset
description: PARIS, May 29  Jimmy Connors, Bjorn Borg and Guillermo Vilas won their opening matches, but Butch Waits, playing almost perfect tennis, shocked the crowd at the $525,000 French open tournament tonight by taking a commanding lead over fourthseeded Vitas Geralaitis, 62, 62,36, before darkness suspended play.

title: Behavior of Fish Is Monitored From an Undersea Habitat
description: CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix  At night, the parrotfish swim in to spin their mucous cocoons and sleep in caves in the canyon wall. With the arrival of the day shift, the night shift moves out in a vast exchange of fish. populations in the depths of the Salt River estuary inside the girdling reefs of St. Croix. Everywhere, the shifting carbonate sands wash down the slope of the submarine canyon.

title: Diamond Shamrock Leaving Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, May 29 (AP)  The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said today that it would move its corporate headquarters from Cleveland to Dallas, partly because of what it characterized as Cleveland's deteriorating image.

title: Booksellers Find Variety Spice of Publishing Life

For once, the responses made sense: there is none. No single book among the tens of thousands on display can speak for what the American public will be reading between now and 1980.

description: This is a sleeper neighborhood, said Toby Tobias, proprietor of the Joni Shop, which sells ladies' junior sportswear, sizes 5 to 11. The salesmen don't know about it. They think we're on Steinway Street. When we say Ditmars, they say, Where's that?

title: Film: 'Newsfront, 'Mood of the 50's:Ambitious Australian
description: "NEWSFRONT," which opens at Cinema II today, is a gentle, mannerly Australian film that fully realizes its ambitions, which are intriguing though small. The young director Phillip Noyce has used carefully selected vintage newsreel footage as a way of exploring the personal and professional ethics of a time that is long gone, yet not so far away. One of the minor miracles of "Newsfront" is its synthesis of present and past, its way of introducing modern moral dilemmas without rupturing a perfectly realized mood of the early 1950's. Even when it is most thoroughly immersed in period details, "Newsfront" is too mindful of the present to feel like nostalgia.Artfully integrating old newsreels into a story about a crew of film makers who supposedly shot, edited and took enormous pride in them, Mr. Noyce has structured "Newsfront" like a scrapbook. Key occurrences are represented, both large and small: the events the film crew covered, the changing fortunes of the company that employed them, the different ways one man regards his wife from one year to the next. The transitions are missing, and somehow that makes the material all the more fascinating. In imitation of his characters, Mr. Noyce records things without trying to explain them. The audience is left to contemplate the permanence and elusiveness of change.Although it features a large, fond, boisterous bunch of friends who spend as much time together after hours as on the job, the film focuses sketchily on one man, Len Maguire (Bill Hunter), to whom stability is tremendously important. A fatherly looking figure of indeterminate age, Maguire functions as an anchor to the other, more headstrong members of the group, and yet not even he has much he can truly count on.A devout Catholic and a profoundly decent man, he nevertheless sees his marriage fall upon hard times. He watches the newsreel industry, to which he has devoted his entire professional life, disintegrate with the advent of television. And in one of the film's most touching and beautifully orchestrated sequences, combining new material by Mr. Noyce with the grim newsreel records of a terrible flood, he sees a favored protg die in pursuit of a story. Perhaps inevitably, the news of this young man's death is later emblazoned on posters at the newsreel theater, where a far too stentatious sign invites donations for the widow.The film makers who appear in "Newsfront" aren't much above turning anything into a light-hearted story; that, after all, is the curious trick of their trade. Mr. Noyce has wittily selected footage of Chico Marx singing "Waltzing Matilda" on a visit to Australia, a politician making a speech as flies converge on his face, a dog who croons hideously when his master plays the piano, and many other testimonials to the silliness that newsreels often celebrated. This works as a fine, stark contrast with the characters behind the camera, who manage to be serious, imaginative, and intelligently interested in what they do.A number of love affairs animate "Newsfront," which would be lively and charming even without them. But to the extent that the film is romantic, its passions go beyond the vicissitudes of individual lovers. Bustling with excellent but not conventionally glamorous players (Wendy Hughes and Angela Punch are radiant exceptions), and polished but in no way slick, "Newsfront" embraces the end of an era just as knowingly as it revels in more promising times. There's something attractively rueful about its even-handedness and its scope.

title: Carter Again Affirms Friendship With Lance
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  President Carter reaffirmed today his friendship with Bert Lance but declined to comment on the 33 criminal charges lodged against the former budget director and three business associates last week.

title: LIABILITY OF UNIONS LIMITED BY JUSTICES
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  The Supreme Court today limited the potential liability that a labor union can incur when it fails to represent one of its members adequately in processing a grievance.

description: THE long, hot summer in New York used to be a long, cool spell for the Broadway theater. But not any longer. Summer business at me box office has been rapidly warming up in recent years, and producers are predicting that it will be hotter than ever in the months ahead.

title: The Oil That's Waiting for Congress
description: Sohio made clear last week that it will not build CaliforniatoTexas pipeline to move Alaska's surplus oil to Midwestern refineries. According to Sohio, the pipeline would not pay. According to liberal critics, the big oil company's refusal is part of a plot to increase profits on Alaskan oil.

New ideas are needed to change the system of financing Congressional elections to prevent their becoming noncompetitive, undemocratic and vulnerable to corrupting pressures.

title: Best Buys
description: WE are a nation utterly addicted to convenience. And nowhere is that obsession more evident than in the American supermarket. Monthly, if not weekly, new prepared foods appear on the shelves, ready to tempt shoppers into spending more and more of their food dollar on such items as frozen broccoli in butter sauce, frozen sauted mushrooms, chicken flavored rice and prestuffed chicken breasts.

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS MOBILE MISSILE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  President Carter, evidently leaning toward approving development of a new mobile ballistic missile, said today that the weapon would be consistent With SovietAmerican arms control measures and that its deployment could contribute to world peace.

His comments were viewed by officials as paving the way for a Presidential decision to proceed with the $30billion MX program. [Page Al, Column 2.]

As a result, judging by all accounts, a decent vacation this year is simply out of the question. Decent vacations, of course, begin no closer to home than Cannes or St. Tropez.
