title: After Liberia's Costly Rioting, Great SoulSearching
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, May 26  The event is remembered here simply as April 14. On that day last month, at least 41 demonstrators protesting a proposed increase in the price of rice were shot and killed by army and police forces here, triggering a wave of anarchy that resulted in property damage estimated at $35 million. More than 400 people were injured.

title: Three Mile Utility Rates
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., May 29 (UPI) If the Public Utilities Commission gives its approval, customers of the Metropolitan Edison Company will have to pay about $50 million in extra charges this year, a MetEd official said at commission hearings today. A decision is expected by June 15.

description: Plans by the Navy to slaughter more than 3,000 goats living wild on a Navyowned island off southern California were disrupted yesterday when a consortium of humane groups led by two San Clemente housewives obtained a temporary restraining order barring a helicopter hunt that had been scheduled to begin Friday.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Wednesday, May 30 (AP)  John Y. Brown Jr., a multimillionaire who claimed that it was time for a businessman to run Kentucky, won the Democratic nomination for Governor in yesterday's primary.

description: MOSCOW, May 29 (AP)  The Soviet Union has stopped bombarding the American Embassy with microwaves, an embassy spokesman said today. The move was seen as an attempt by Moscow to improve relations before the meeting in June of President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev. the Soviet leader.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: WE have printed numerous recipes to be cooked in deliberate excess. The point of the exercise is to insure that there will be leftovers that can be put to excellent advantage later; to my mind there are many foods that taste best second time around. The list of good, inspired uses for leftover foods is practically endless, and there is practically no food that can't be put to a second purpose. I feel quite certain it was a thrifty chef who first conceived the idea of what is called consomm Celestine, a chef who probably found himself with an excess of crepes and decided not to throw them out. Consomm Celestine consists of a rich beef broth that is garnished with finely shredded crepes plus a few chopped choice herbs. And there is more than one Scandinavian sandwich or canap that calls for cold (leftover, perhaps) scrambled egg as a topping. One of the choicest is made with cold scrambled eggs and smoked eel with a dill topping.

title: Chief of Inquiry Says Loose Engine Probably Led to Hydraulic Damage
description: CHICAGO, May 29  The head of the team investigating last Friday's, airlirier crash here. said today that the DC10 jumbo jet probably became uncontrollable after the loss of the left engine because of resulting hydraulics damage and consequent retraction of flaps on the leading edge of the left wing.

description: KAMPALA, Uganda, May 29 (Reuters)  Uganda's new rulers have charged four aides of Idi Amin, including Robert Astles, a Briton, with murder, police sources said here today. The four are in custody in Kenya, where they fled when Kampala fell April 11.

Strauss, is unable to reach an agreement in Peking.

description: NAPLES, May 27  If the Communists in Naples are right, the Italian general election Sunday will be close, with only modest gains for the ruling Christian Democrats and no basic setback for the runnerup Communists.

description: SEATTLE, May 29 (UPI)  A morning cup of coffee perks up the minds of coffee drinkers partly because that is what they expect it to do, according to student researcher at the University of Washington.

title: Talks in Rubber Strike Resume Without Optimism
description: FAIRLAWN, Ohio, May 29  Negotiators for Uniroyal Inc. and the striking United Rubber Workers resumed talks today for the first time in 23 days, but at the end of a brief meeting neither party expressed optimism about reaching an agreement soon on a new threeyear contract.

title: Samples of PoliceTest Questions
description: To prepare candidates for the June 30 examination for police officer, the Police Department is sponsoring free tutorial classes in each borough conducted by the Police Tutorial Service.

title: Japan's Unemployment
description: TOKYO. May 29 (AP)  The number of unemployed people in Japan's eligible work force fell to 1.2 million in April from 1.3 million in March, the Govern- ment statistics bureau reported today. The seasonally adjusted jobless rate for April rose to 2.19 percent from the adjusted 2.08 percent figure in March. The number of employed in April reached 54.8 million, up from 53.5 million in March.

title: Boeing May Enlarge Its 747 Jumbo Jet
description: EVERETT, Wash., May 29 (AP)  The Boeing Company says airlines are interested in a larger version of the 747 jumbo jet that would carry more than 450 passengers.

title: Private Lives
description: HE is down to his last committee. What will he do, naked without committees? He has relied on committee meetings to get him out of the house. Otherwise, he would rot among his books  all those old opinions, dead issues, dreamy ruins, beeswax. Instead, he has gone to committee meetings in Savannah and San Antonio and Chicago and Boston and Berkeley and, perhaps, Terre Haute or Columbus  who could be sure?  not to mention Ottawa, for a very good reason. Many sullen motels know his name. He sometimes feels that his credit cards are bigger than he is; that these cards, stood on their ears, wearing rollerbearings, constitute a revolving door by which he is threshed; that, along with information, his chromosomes are being processed.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Do you and your true love like to stroll in the rain together? Then check out the umbrella built for two. Somebody's brainstorm has resulted in joining the sides of two umbrellas and giving them one handle. The double shelter should Keep two people dry without crowding and avoids the dripping down one's back that's inevitable when the pair of you share a normal umbrella. The umbrella is $50 on Barney's main floor.

title: Documents Show Shah Sought U.S. Lobby
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 29  In confidential files of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's deposed Government, Marion Javits's public relations connection with Iran Air was described by the Shah's offi- cials as a cover for efforts to create an Iran lobby that would be influential the United States with Congress and the press.

title: A Vietnam Veteran Stills Audience With a Rebuke
description: As public officials and onlookers stood silent and solemn under the noonday sun, a former marine lieutenant, Robert Muller, opened Vietnam Veterans Week at City Hall yesterday from his wheelchair.

title: President Defends Cost Of Using a Helicopter
description: WASHINGTON, May 29  President Carter has defended his use of a helicopter to go fishing in Pennsylvania last Saturday as much less expensive than going by car.

description: CRISIS bargaining has become the pattern in economic negotiations between the United States and China. Trade talks have gone down to the wire, with the two sides in apparent deadlock, until, on the last day of the visit of highlevel American representatives, the impasse in broken.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTON  For all the appearance of history in the making, this week's meetings and ceremonies marking the border opening between Egypt and Israel do not conceal the vast ambiguity of what is being done in the Middle East.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: HEXTERMarguerite. The Board of Trustees of the JBG Educational Institute deeply mourns the passing of Marguerite Hexter, wife of our distinguished Vice Chairman, Dr. Maurice B. Hexter. Compassionate and concerned, she was deeply committed to the advancement of mental health research and practice, building hope of a better future for the emotionally disturbed. Our warmest sympathy to the entire family.

title: Notes on People
description: Talk about burying the hatchet may be clich, but it's appropriate nonetheless for the scheduled appearance next Monday by Marys Mannes, the writer, at the commencement exercises of the Mannes College of Music. The last time she and other trustees of the college were burying hatchets it was in each other over merger plans with the Manhattan School of Music.

title: A Duke Who's Heir To Europe's Last Private Army
description: BLAIR ATHOLL, SCOTLAND HIS castle, its white stucco turrets rising above the green forests in Perthshire. resembles a gingerbread fortress in the middle of Disneyland. The last time he fired cannons outside the castle's main entrance, the blast did nothing more than shatter 12 panes of glass. Furthermore, he describes himself as a pacifist, and there are rumors that he has never learned to salute properly.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: President Carter signed an executive order giving the nation's governors authority to regulate gasoline sales in their states this summer. The President warned that spot shortages of gasoline and long lines at the pumps might be in prospect unless consumption was reduced significantly. [Page A1.]

title: The United Nations Employs No Historians. It Should, and Here's Why.
description: In a sense, the United Nations is university, where people learn, where people teach, and where people, indeed, come to agreement occasionally, so long as the subject is not too controversial. Thus when I was recently invited as an academic and historian to speak to a distinguished group of diplomats and United Nations officials, I asked myself, Is there an historian employed as an historian on the staff of the United, Nations and all its subsidiary bodies? There is not. The United Nations certainly employs economists, sociologists, and professionals of every other kind, but no historians.

title: Soviet, in Shift, Lets Foreigners Into Festival
description: The Spartakiade, the Soviet Union's quadrennial sports festival and this year a dress rehearsal for the 1980 Olympic Games in Moscow, will have a new look.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The east and west branches of the Delaware River and one of its tributaries, the Neversink, will continue to receive carefully timed and life-sustaining releases of water from three New York City reservoirs.

title: 7 East Colleges Form League
description: BOSTON, May 29 (AP) Seven Eastern basketball powers  Boston College, Connecticut, Georgetown, Providence, Seton Hall, St. John's and Syracuse formed a new conference today for next season.

title: Down on the Farm: A Modern Barn/House
description: IT isn't just an ordinary farmhouse, and it certainly can't be called a converted barn. In the barn/farmhouse that was recently completed Westchester County by Paul Segal Associates, the New York architectural firm, there is more country living than simply being down on the farm.

title: Children Offer Piquant Show On Hometown
description: Attention Mayor Koch, the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and all other political and civic persons and organizations spending huge amounts to promote the virtues and polish the image of a troubled New York City.

title: Assembly Votes to Make Memorial Day a Monday
description: ALBANY, May 30  On the day the Legislature told the rest of New York to celebrate Memorial Day, the State Assembly chose to work  and approved a bill changing the day New York State will celebrate Memorial Day in the future to match that of the Federal Government.

title: Xcor Unit Seeks Bar To Bally Gaming
description: Xcor International Inc. said that its Williams Electronics Inc. unit had filed a suit in New Jersey seeking an order to prevent the Bally Manufacturing Corporation from proceeding with its planned entry into the Atlantic City gamblingcasino business.

title: Outer Critics Honor Marsha Norman
description: Marsha Norman has been voted winner of the John Gassner New Playwrights Medallion by the Outer Critics Circle for her highly lauded play Getting Out. Mr. Gassner was Sterling Professor of Playwriting at Yale and is a former president of the circle. The Outer Critics Circle is an organization of writers on the New York theater for outoftown newspapers and other media.

title: TOP SWISS DIPLOMAT SLAIN IN EL SALVADOR
description: SAN SALVADOR, May 30 (Reuters) The Swiss charg d'affaires here was shot to death today after four youths had tried to kidnap him, the police said.

title: Knicks Join in Fight On O'Brien's Award
description: The Knicks have challenged the National Basketball Association by joining forces with the National Basketball Players' Association in their objections to Commissioner Larry O'Brien's compensation decision in the Marvin Webster case.

title: Stage: Spanish Romeo
description: THE Romeo and Juliet that the Spanish Theater Repertory Company is performing in repertory in Spanish through June 11 in a translation by the late Nobel Laureate Pablo Neruda is thoroughly engrossing even to one who knows no Spanish. It is a version that emphasizes the volatile passions of the principals, conscious of nothing but their own feelings and the gulf that separates the two nations  the young people and their elders.

title: Mets Bow To Cards By 73
description: ST. LOUIS, May 30  In a woolly game marked by a fist fight, 29 hits off seven pitchers and homers by Lou Brock and Ted Simmons, the St. Louis Cardinals overpowered the New York Mets tonight, 73.

title: Deaths
description: HENNEY  Richard B. Of Merrick. on May 30, 1979. Executive Director and Trustee of Duke Endowment. Brother of David F. Brother-in-law of Polly. Uncle of David and Robert. Funeral from. the N.F. Walker Funeral Home; 2039 Merrick Ave., Merrick. Mast of Christian Burial Cure of Ars R. Church. Saturday 9:45AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Family will receive friends Friday 25 and 710PM.

title: Scrutinizing the DC-10
description: The DC10 crash last Friday, in which 273 were killed, jolted the country but perhaps no more so than the events that have followed. Even people who accept the idea of occasional plane crashes with some equanimity as a peril of modern life are left to wonder whether their reasonableness is being abused by regulatory complacency.

title: Carter Vows to Focus on Vietnam Veterans Rights
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  President Carter said today that the nation is ready to change its heart, its mind and its attitude toward Vietnam veterans. He pledged to work to extend their rights and ordered a study of the effects of herbicides used during the war.

title: Approval of Carter Falls To 37% Low, Poll Finds
description: President Carter's approval rating, as measured by the Gallup Poll, has fallen to 37 percent, matching the lowest level since he took office, the polling organization reported yesterday.

title: Transfusion for Sickly Turkish Economy
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 30  There is practically no Turkish coffee available in Turkey any more. Even Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit apologetically offers his visitors only tea.

title: Judith Bennett, a Psychologist; Victim of DC10 Crash in Chicago
description: Judith Bennett, a psychologist and a senior editor of Forum Magazine, was among the 273 persons killed in Friday's crash of an American Airlines DC10 jet airliner in Chicago, it became known yesterday. Mrs. Bennett, of Evanston, Ill., had been on the way to a convention of the American Booksellers Association in Los Angeles.

title: Hordes of Illegals? No.
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Many people believe that the United States is being silently invaded by millions of illegal aliens who take away jobs and burden taxpayers.

title: Bridge:
description: Upsets continued in the Reisinger knockout team championship at the Beverly East Club in Manhattan Tuesday night. The only survivor of the four topranked teams, John Solodar's secondseeded squad, was soundly defeated by the youngest team in the field: Josh Parker, Mike Radin, Jeff Juster, Marty Fleisher, Larry Cohen and Eric Robinson won by 52 international match points. (Their average age is 22.)

title: Letters
description: To THE HOME SECTION:

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HOME TEAM This weekend marks a special celebration at Tramps, the supper club and talent showcase at 125 East 15th Street, between Third Avenue and Irving Place. Tomorrow night and Saturday there will be homecoming performances by Robert Kraft and the Ivory Coast.

title: Mrs. Feinstein Seeks Election
description: SAN FRANCISCO. May 30 (UPI)  Dianne Feinstein, who became Mayor upon the assassination of George R. Moscone, said today that she would seek election to the post in November. Mrs. Feinstein was president of the Board of Supervisors when Mr. Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk were shot to death in November by former Supervisor Dan White. On Dec. 4, she was elected by the board to replace Mr. Moscone.

title: The Region
description: WASHINGTON  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today agreed to allow Jersey Central Power and Light Company to resume operation of its Oyster Creek power plant after the utility agreed to adopt safeguards against recurrence of a May 2 lossofcoolant incident. Shepard Bartnoff, president of Jersey Central, said the plant in Lower Alloways Creek Township might begin startup operations tomorrow.

title: State's Dairymen Get ButterPat Champion
description: ALBANY, May 30 (AP)  Assemblyman Rolland E. Kidder, who last year persuaded the state to make grape juice available in its cafeterias, has begun a campaign in behalf of the New York Stateproduced butter catty.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: If you need furniture legs for building a new piece of furniture or updating an old one, M. Wolchonok at 155 East 52d Street is a store to visit. The sign above the door proclaims, Legs, Legs, Legs, which is indeed the case. Wolchonok carries at least 50 styles of furniture legs: bed legs, bun feet, plated brass or chrome legs and wooden legs, including butcher block and chair and table legs in a great variety styles. Brass legs, especially useful for glasstopped coffee tables, are available in more than 10 sizes and styles. They cost from $15.79 to $140 for a set of four. Wooden legs come finished or unfinished. There are more than 25 styles, ranging in price from $1.25 to $45 a leg and including various cabriole legs, or legs with a ball and claw foot, reeded legs, and rectangular and round ones. A wooden bun foot, for an upholstered chair sofa, costs $6 and comes in one size. Adjustable glides for the bottoms legs are also available, at $1 each. Wolchonok will cut to exact measurement for $1 a leg and will do special orders.

title: TV: Inflation, War Criminals, Laos
description: TONIGHT, while NBC is bringing back the trashy miniseries Aspen under the kickier title of The Innocent and the Damned, the schedule is Suddenly bubbling with documentaries. Two  one on innation, the other on Nazi war criminals  are on the independent Metromedia station WNEW / Channel 5. The third, going inside Laos, is part of the ABC magazine 20/20.

title: Moe to Stay With Spurs
description: SAN ANTONIO, May 30 (UPI)  The San Antonio Spurs announced today that Coach Doug Moe would keep his job for at least another year.

title: Borg Wins, Gerulaitis Survives
description: PARIS, May 30  Bjorn Borg had to struggle for the second day in a row to win in the French open tennis tournament today, while Chris Evert Lloyd coasted to a firstround victory.

title: 7 Are Killed in Maine Plane Crash
description: OWLS HEAD, Me., Thursday, May 31 (AP)  A Downeast Airlines plane crashed while attempting to land at a municipal airport on the Maine coast last night, killing at least seven of the 18 persons aboard.

title: Mortgage Rate Up in Canada
description: MONTREAL, May 30 (UPI)  The Bank of Montreal and the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce today announced an immediate increase of  percent in most morteare rates.

title: Indonesia's Chinese: Real Rulers or a Harried Minority?
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 25  The Chinese minority in Indonesia, about four million strong, is subjected to a broad range of discriminatory measures by the militarydominated Government of President Suharto. At the same time, the Chinese are strongly disliked by the most outspoken opponents of the regime for collaborating with it and profiting from it.

title: Calendar: A Tour of Manhattan Residences
description: Six New York City residences, stretching from Sutton Place to Central Park West, comprise next Wednesday's 10th annual house tour to support the summer camp for blind and multihandicapped children.

title: REGULATORS PERMIT INTEREST RATE RISES IN SAVINGS ACCOUNTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Federal bank regulators approved a series of measures today to let consumers earn more interest on their savings accounts. At the same time, they authorized Feder- ally chartered savings and loan associations around the nation to offer variablerate mortgages, ones with interest rates that would fluctuate in relation to prevailing rates for other kinds of loans.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Umpire DiMuro Hurt in Collision at Plate
description: MILWAUKEE, May 30  Lou DiMuro, the second most senior umpire in the American League, suffered a bruised spine in the Yankees 52 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers tonight when Cliff Johnson, a Yankee baserunner, collided with him while scoring in the 11th inning.

title: Judges Beyond a Law
description: They may be grumbling in private, but most Federal officials are now filing the extensive financial reports required by the 1978 Ethics in Government Act without a fuss. Alas, six Federal judges from Southern states are doing their grumbling in public, in the form of a suit attacking the new law.

title: Food Fair Had Loss In SixMonth Period
description: PHILADELPHIA. May 30 (AP) Food Fair Inc., currently reorganizing under Federal bankruptcy laws, today announced losses of $117 million in the sixmonth period ended Feb. 10.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch from the Cannes Film Festival published in The Times last Thursday reported erroneously that the producer and director Francis Coppola had purchased the Inglenook Winery of Napa Valley, Calif. Since 1969, Inglenook Winery has been owned by a division of Heublein Inc.; in the middle 1970's, Mr. Coppola purchased what had been the Inglenook homestead, as well as some of the vineyards.

title: Market Place
description: WHEN Wall Streeters urged Ted Walkowicz to open the. National Aviation and Technology Corporation fund to new investment, he said that National Aviation had been in business for 50 years and that shareholders had been happy with its performance as a fixedcapital or closedend fund.

title: Zalmon Yavneh Dead; Was a Leading Cantor
description: The Rev. Zalmon Yavneh, for 53 years a cantor and cantor emeritus at the West Side Institutional Synagogue in New York, died Monday at his summer home In South Fallsburg, N.Y. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 300 Police Hunt For Missing Boy As No. 1 Task
description: Three hundred uniformed police officers and detectives canvassed the city yesterday in the search for 6yearold Etan Patz, who was last seen last Friday while on his way to a school bus stop. Detective Ken Baumann of the First Precinct said the police had no leads.

title: Home Beat
description: SHE is Non, he is Nob. He was born in Kyoto, Japan; she was brought up there. They moved to New York in 1970 as Mr. and Mrs. Utsumi. In Japan, both had worked with fabrics in a fashion context but had always wanted to do textiles for interiors. In fashion. Mrs. Utsumi said, fabric design is always under the fashion designer, and one doesn't have enough control. In interiors, it's the final thing. The Utsumis, both in their early 30's, wanted to design a line of textiles for what they call our gen eration. We see life as a total concept, Mr. Utsumi explained. Things you live with, things you eat, things you wear, all show your concept of life. Next week, Nob+Non Collection I will be introduced by Knoll International, the furniture and textile company. The Utsumis are pleased. Seven prints in two weights, one a 100 percent cotton batiste, the other cotton sheeting, include 36 colorways. We tried to change the concept printed fabric, Mrs. Ubsumi said, and give it a new look, which is fresh, subtle, quiet, sensitive and suitable to the urban lifestyle. White and natural are used as basics with grays, beiges, silver and touches of blue or orange. The grid and graphtype designs are hand drawn to soften the industrial look, Mr. Utsumi said. The 48inchwide fabrics are $18 to $30 a yard list, through architects and designers, at Knoll International, 743 Fifth Avenue.

title: Dance: Vienna Waltzes by City Ballet
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S Vienna Waltzes was an immediate and tremendous audience favorite from its first performance in 1977. That it has remained so was clear on Tuesday when it reentered the New York City Ballet repertory at the New York State Theater.

title: 2 Seized in Tin Ingot Theft
description: Federal Bureau of Investigation agents have arrested two men for possession of $600,000 worth of tin ingots that were stolen in a Brooklyn truck hijacking. An F.B.I. spokesman said Edward Cowles, 49 years old of 306 Locust Street South Hempstead, L.I., and Thomas Conzo, 35, of 230 Stratford Avenue, Brooklyn, were taken into custody yesterday and the stolen ingots were recovered at Scott's Smelting Company, 575 Scholes Street, Brooklyn, which Mr. Cowles owns. The ingots were stolen Tuesday afternoon when three gunmen accosted the driver of a tractortrailer, owned by the Standard Motor Freight Company of Secaucus, N.J., as it left Pier 9B in Brooklyn with the shipment of ingots.

title: The 2 Memorial Days: Many Won't Forget
description: The city had its second Memorial Day in three days yesterday and proved it is not an easy thing to do.

title: Medical School Plans China Link
description: WORCESTER, Mass, May 30 (AP) The Medical School of the University of Massachusetts is adopting a Chinese sister school. It plans to organize a faculty exchange program with Shanghai Medical College No. 1 this year. Dr. Philip Caper, vice chancellor for health affairs, said that the arrangement would allow American medical educators to learn about Chinese folk medicine, selfcare programs and acupuncture.

title: Advertising
description: STEPHEN M. BLACKER and Kenneth L. Marks worked together in the advertising sales department of Time magazine. They worked together at New York magazine. They worked together at The Village Voice. And they worked together at The New York Post.Muller Jordan Herrick, with about $22 million in billings, has acquired Edward M. Meyers Associates, with some $2.5 million. Both agencies are 23 years old. Although the Meyers shop will be an autonomous subsidiary, keeping its name and its high command, the parent company, to reflect the new development, has changed its name to Muller Jordan Meyers.

title: KURT JOOSS IS DEAD; CHOREOGRAPHER, 78
description: Kurt Jooss, the German choreographer, died on May 22 in a hospital in Heilbronn, West Germany, as the result of injuries suffered in an automobile accident. He was 78 years old.

title: Trade Deficit Spurs Dow Decline
description: News of a widening trade deficit sent an already jittery stock market into broad retreat yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 10 points to reach its lowest closing level in nearly three months.

title: Those Unreachable White House Stars
description: Good ideas don't always ripen in good season or on the proper limb. So Washington has been surprised and put off by a very good idea that Senator Edward Zorinsky, a maverick freshman from Nebraska, grafted onto the annual State Department authorization bill: a requirement that the Senate confirm future national security advisers to the President.

title: TradeAdjustment Funds Voted
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI)  The House passed legislation today providing $191 million during fiscal 1980 to help workers and companies that lose jobs or business because of competition from imports.

title: 13 American Mayors Plan a Tour Of China in a Reciprocal Program
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP)  Thirteen American Mayors will tour China for 11 days next month in an exchange program, the United States Conference of Mayors announced today.

title: Books: Literary Touring
description: For a walker in London carrying the light luggage of literature, one of the pleasures is to come upon a lovely blue enamel plaque affixed to a house saying that Robert Browning lived here on Welbeck Street; or that Virginia Woolf spent several years in Fitzroy Square; or that George Gissing could be found at home in Oakley Gardens, Chelsea, when not berating publishers dwelling in that center of venality that his novel called New Grub Street.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: PITTSBURGH, May 30  Shareholders of the Pittsburghbased Dravo Corporation and Southern Industries of Mobile, Ala., today approved a merger agreement under which Southern Industries will become a wholly owned subsidiary of Dravo effective June 1.

title: 211 Flee Fire on Train in Canada
description: IROQUOIS, Ontario, May 30 (AP) The engine and three cars of a passenger train caught fire yesterday, forcing the 211 people on board to flee into a mosquitoinfested swamp 84 miles west of Montreal.

title: Backgammon:
description: The Memorial Weekend Tournament last Sunday in Westbury, L.I., was sponsored by two active regional groups: Long Island Backgammon and the New Jersey Backgammon Association. Eighteenyearold Howard Sloan, the youngest player in the field, took first place by defeating Robert Liebowitz. Marc Freeman won the first consolation; Mike Zviti the second consolation; Rena Caverly beat Mary Litrel to take the intermediate division.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The United States dollar was lower in Europe and fell sharply in the United States yesterday before American trade figures, announced at midafternoon, showed the trade deficit had widened to $2.15 billion in April.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, May 21, to Sunday, May 27), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Carey Signs a Bill on Inheritances
description: ALBANY, May 30  Governor Carey has signed a bill intended to make easier for children born out of wedlock to collect inheritances from their fathers, his office announced today.

title: Brezhnev Seems Well on Visit to Hungary
description: BUDAPEST, May 31 (AP)  Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, walked unescorted down the ramp of his Ilyushin62 jetliner today to begin a threeday visit to Hungary aimed in part at dispelling rumors of his declining health.

title: Utah Doctors Separate Siamese Twins Linked at Brain
description: SALT LAKE CITY, May 30 (AP)  Surgeons severed a small connection between the brains of Lisa and Elisa Hansen in a 16hour operation to separate the Siamese twins, their doctor said today.

title: Sound
description: WHETHER the legendary Murphy was an engineer or a theologian has never been reliably established, but it was he who formulated the universal law: If anything can go wrong, it will. Murphys Law operates with a vengeance in the manufacture of phonograph records. To illustrate the point, last weeks column traced the parlous path from the studio tape to the metal stampers that press the actual record, with every step of the way giving ample scope to the aforesaid Murphy. The electroplating methods by which the stampers are formed are simple enough in theory, but often beset by practical foulups.

title: News Summary
description: Arabs fought Iranian troops, leaving at least 21 people dead and 71 wounded. The clashes pitted Arabs of Khuzistan Province, who have been seeking autonomy, against the dominant Persians. Other clashes were reported in nearby Abadan, site of the world's largest oil refinery. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: Technology
description: IT'S big, it's crowded, it's complicated and not entirely pleasant, but there's a lot to learn there. That, in short, is the way a longknowledgeable executive describes the computer industry's annual rite of summer, the National Computer Conference, which opens next week at the New York Coliseum.

title: Home Improvement
description: OWNERS OF homes whose exterior walls are covered with wood shingles or shakes often receive conflicting advice as to whether paint or stain is best for these shingles or even as to whether any finish is required. There is an equal amount of confusion when it comes to selecting a paint or a stain because of the number of different types available in each category: some dealers recommend one type, some another.

title: Grandes Dames
description: ELSIE de WOLFE wasn't the first to suggest that the business of interior decorating belonged women. Catharine Beecher and her sister, Harriet Beecher Stowe, had implied that it was woman's preserve in their works on household management and decorating. The novelist Edith Wharton had

title: U.S. and Dutch Women Are to Be Freed by Israel
description: TEL AVIV, May 30  An American woman and a Dutch woman who were jailed as spies for Arab terrorists are to be released in an Israeli goodwill gesture marking the peace settlement with Egypt.

title: KENTUCKY PRIMARY WON BY LATE ENTRY
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., May 30 (UPI) John Y. Brown Jr., the former Kentucky Fried Chicken executive, celebrated his victory in Tuesday's Democratic primary for governor and accepted President Carter's offer to campaign for him in November.

title: Entertainment Events
description: I REMEMBER MAMA, by Thomas Meehan, lyrics by Martin Charnin, additional lyrics by Raymond Jessel; score by Richard Rodgers, Majestic Theater, 44th Street west of Broadway, 6:45.

title: 3 Top West German Writers Cause a Stir by Rejecting State Award
description: BONN, May 30  West Germany's three bestknown writers have refused to accept their country's Distinguished Service Medal, resulting in a groundswell of scolding and irritation, and the authors rebuttal of the criticism today.

title: Civilians Flee Southern Lebanon As Guerrillas and Rightists Fight
description: TYRE, Lebanon, May 30 (Reuters) Thousands of civilians have fled their homes in southern Lebanon after five days of artillery duels between Israelibacked rightist militias and Palestinian guerrillas, Palestinian sources here said today.

title: Blind Ambition Carries CBS to Top of Ratings
description: On the strength of several specials, including three episodes of an eighthour adaptation of John W. Dean 3d's Blind Ambition, CBSTV led the audiencepopularity ratings last week, breaking ABCTV's winning streak of 19 weeks in a row.

title: Interest Is Reported In Acquiring Heller
description: CHICAGO, May 30 (Reuters)  The Walter E. Heller International torporation, one of the world's biggest commercial financing concerns, today announced that a party it declined to identify had expressed interest in acquiring the company.

title: HealthCode Violations Laid to 21 Food Places
description: The New York City Department, of Health released the names of 21 food Auk tablishments this week that it said bad violated the health code. The department also listed five restaurants that had Corrected earlier violations and one that had been closed for failing to do so.

title: Tiny TugofWarriors on Roosevelt Island
description: More than 300 students from Public School 217 on Roosevelt Island participated yesterday in a Jogathon sponsored by Wheaties cereal. The event included jogging, racing, dodge ball, relay racing and, of course, tug war. The event had originally been scheduled to take place two weeks ago, but was postponed by bad weather.

title: Music: Alliance for American Song
description: THE Alliance for American Song went beyond the intentions of its name in its concert on Tuesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. In addition to songs, it presented two instrumental works. The organization Is only two years old and apparently is not sure which way it is going.

title: Permit for Jersey Casino Is Granted As a CrimeLink Inquiry Continues
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 30  The New Jersey Casino Control Commission granted Caesars World a temporary permit today to open Atlantic City's second casino on the condition that Clifford S. Perlman, Caesars World's principal owner, take an unpaid leave of absence from Caesars World and its New Jersey subsidiaries while the state investigates his associations with persons reputed to be linked to organized crime.

title: Notes on People
description: Blanche Bernstein, who left Mayor Koch's administration last March after being shoved aside as Human Resources Administrator and manager of the largest city agency, will return to the New School for Social Research to head a newly established Social Policy Research Institute.

title: Maheu Settles Defamation Suit Against Hughes
description: LOS ANGELES, May 30 (UPI)  Robert Maheu's multimilliondollar defamation suit against Summa Corporation, the holding company of the late Howard Hughes, was settled out of court today.

title: Drug Trade Nourishes Legion of Airplane Brokers
description: MIAMI  Because of increased risks of capture and ever greater potential profits, those who smuggle narcotics from South America are using more and more

title: 81 Profit Was Forecast for DC10
description: LOS ANGELES, May 30  The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the builder of the DC10, has been struggling for years to make a profit from its commercial aircraft. Last Friday's crash of an American Airlines DC10 in Chicago that killed 273 persons came as the company was expecting to begin earning money on the aircraft by 1981.

title: New Stage Works Displayed in Chicago
description: THE theater, among other things, is part mirage; and it tends to recede when approached with active expectation.

title: Choosing a Guardian For Your Child
description: STEPHANIE is an only child. Her husband, Hal, has an unmarried 25yearold sister who lives several states away and is not fond of childen. Not having a guardian for their 5yearold son troubles them.

title: A Nagrin Dance to a Shepard Libretto
description: WHAT next for this year's Pulitzer Prize winner in drama. Sam Shepard? The adventurous playwright has turned to an entirely new field for him  the dance. He's written the libretto for 'Jacaranda, a 30minute solo that will be given its premiere next Thursday at St. Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street, in a program of two dances choreographed and performed by Daniel Nagrin. The audience will hear Mr. Shepard's text as Mr. Nagrin speaks it both on tape and live  in a kind of conversation with himself.

title: Talking Business with Maxwell of Cyrus J. Lawrence
description: Even before the onset of the Arab embargo in 1973, Charles T. Maxwell, a partner and principal oil analyst at Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc., had warned of shortages to come. Now a senior vice president and director of the institutional research firm, Mr. Maxwell widely regarded as one of the most thoughtful and prophetic observers on the energy scene.

title: New Brazil Devaluation
description: BRASILIA, Brazil, May 30 (AP) Brazil has devalued the cruzelro for the eighth time in 1979, changing the exchange rate from 24.635 to the United States dollar to 25.515.

title: Israeli Urges Intensive Settling in Occupied Lands
description: JERUSALEM, May 30  Agriculture Minister Ariel Sharon in Parliament today called for an intensive Jewish settlement effort in the Israelioccupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip during the next 20 to 30 years.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Further Cutbacks In Shell Deliveries
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  The Shell Oil Company, the nation's largest marketer of gasoline, today announced that it would increase its cutbacks in gasoline supplies for most of its service stations in June.

title: Seventh Victim of Fire Dies
description: NORWOOD, Mass., May 30 (AP) Catherine Harrison, a Westwood woman whose husband and five children perished in a fire at their home Monday, died today at Norwood Hospital. Mrs. Harrison, 33 years old, slipped into a coma yesterday and never regained consciousness, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Working Panel to Spur Harlem Trade Complex
description: The White House established yesterday a working group to assist New York City and New York State officials to develop ways the Federal Government could assist in the construction of a $95 million international trade complex on 125th Street in Harlem.

title: Mrs. Javits 'shocked, She Says, by Accounts Of Her Work for Iran
description: Marion Javits described herself yesterday as shocked by reports that the Shah's Government had regarded her 1973 publicrelations contract with the stateowned Iranian airline as a subterfuge aimed at concealing a broader lobbying effort. She said the contract had been designed only to promote travel by cultural and educational leaders to Iran.

title: Trade Gap Worsens
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Higherpriced oil imports and a surge in Americans' purchases of foreign automobiles contributed to a substantial widening of this nation's trade deficit last month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: World Trade Center Still in Shadow
description: Nearly halfway up one of the World Trade Center's 110story twin towers; Pearl Nathanson sells cigarettes, newspapers and magazines to the building's offiCe workers, and is no longer nervous when she feels the structure sway in high winds. used to it now. she says.

title: Times Declares Dividends
description: Directors of The New York Times Company yesterday declared a regular quarterly dividend of 20 cents a share on its Class A and Class B common stock, payable June 26 to shareholders of record June 8. The board also declared a regular dividend of $1.375 a share on the 5 percent cumulative prior preference stock, payable July 2 to stockholders of record June 8.

title: ExAntiwar Figures Say Vietnam Abuses Rights
description: A group of more than 80 educators, writers, artists, entertainers and leaders in the fields of civil rights and social sciences have raised a protest against what they call the violation of rights of political prisoners by the Communist Government of Vietnam.

title: Belmont's Horses Hit By Ailment
description: The coughing sickness afflicting younger horses at Belmont Park has continued to widen, Dr. Manuel Gilman, the track's examining veterinarian, reported yesterday..

title: Books of The Times
description: YOU mightn't think defining the word decadence was worth all the fuss. After all, you can look it up in the dictionary and discover that it means the state of decaying and comes from the Latin decadere, to fall away. But Richard Gilman  the critic, intellectual historian and once and future professor of drama at Yale  makes a sound case for the word's slipperiness in his challenging new book, Decadence: The Strange Life of an Epithet.

title: Celtics Set to Sign Bird Tomorrow
description: BOSTON, May 30 (AP)  The Boston Celtics backed off from their takeitorleaveit stance in negotiations with Larry Bird's agent and now expect to sign the college basketball star Friday to a multiyear contract worth more than $600,000 a season.

title: Bold Ways to Grab the White House's Ear
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  In recent public appearances around the country, Jimmy Carter has taken to inviting his audiences to make contact with him or his top aides directly with specific examples of onerous and unnecessary

title: Photoengravers Strike Deadline Is Revised as Negotiations Stall
description: Negotiators for Photoengravers Union IP and for The Daily News and The New York Times met yesterday in a new effort to resolve a critical jobsecurity issue and avert a strike, which had been threatened for Monday morning but which has now been rescheduled for 12:01 A.M. Tuesday.

title: Steiner Captures Decathlon At N.C.A.A. Track Meet
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., May 30 (AP) Tito Steiner of Brigham Young University, the American collegiate recordholder, regained the decathlon title at the National Collegiate track and field championships today. He won the 10- event, twoday competition by 182 points, repeating his triumph of 1077. Last year he placed third.

title: Hers
description: I SAY right off  I cannot properly imitate Thackeray. Grazing the sooty bookstalls on Fourth Avenue, I came across his Book Snobs, broad swipes at the uppity English, and thought that it might be sporting to try a contemporary version, take a crack at our fine houses, good food, elegant clothes  the splendid stuff of American life. Alas, in our vigorous democracy we no longer have, nor do we mourn, the sharp distinctions of class that lend themselves to satire. We have emerged as a fairminded, humorless race, given naughty oneliners and the indulgence of a few ethnic and regional slurs on Saturday night television.

title: Garment Union Reaches Accord In the Northeast
description: New agreements providing for wage in creases of 25 percent over three years for 130,000 garment workers in the Northeast were announced yesterday by Sol C. Chaikin, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

title: WildlifePreservation Theory Challenged
description: The longheld theory that very large parks and preserves are the way to conserve the greatest variety of wildlife species and their habitats may not be valid, preliminary ecological studies in the Amazon River basin in Brazil indicate.

title: Benjamin Perlen, an Industrialist And Philanthropist, Is Dead at 67
description: Benjamin Perlen, a steel company executive and a leader in Jewish community and philanthropic activities, died Monday of a heart attack at his home at 10 Surrey Road, Great Neck, L.I. He was 67 years old.

title: Expos Blank Phillies Second Time in Row
description: MONTREAL, May 30 (UPI)  Gary Carter cracked a tworun homer and Bill Lee tossed a sixhitter for his second shutout of the season tonight to lead Montreal to a 20 victory over Philadelphia. The triumph marked the second time in as many nights that the the Expos have blanked the Phillies.

title: Lloyd Ends Slump As Wife Looks On
description: PARIS, May 30  It was a firstround match in the French open tennis tournament, and Chris Evert's husband appeared to be on the verge of continuing a sevenmonth losing streak.

title: Belgian Bank Rate Up
description: BRUSSELS, May 30 (Reuters) Belgium and the Netherlands today raised the rates at which their central banks lend funds to commercial banks. Belgium raised its rate to 8 percent from 7 percent, effective immediately, and the Netherlands raised its rate to 7 percent from 6.5 percent, effective tomorrow.

title: Los Angeles Elects a Foe Of Busing to Schools Post
description: LOS ANGELES. May 30  Howard Miller, the president of the Los Angeles Board of Education, who had pledged to obey the law and comply with a court order to integrate public schools here, was removed from office yesterday by voters in the nation's secondlargest school system.

title: Coaches Are Vocal
description: SEATTLE, May 30  The two head coaches had different reactions to the SuperSonics 114112 overtime victory over the Washington Bullets at the Coliseum last night in the fourth game of the National Basketball Association championship series. Lenny Wilkens. was euphoric, while Dick Motta was plain angry.

title: Marriage Announcement 1 -- No Title
description: Linda Whitmarsh Married to Lawyer

title: Franklin to Sell New Gold Piece
description: The Franklin Mint Corporation said yesterday that its new gold pieces, called the Franklin Mint Gold Piece, would be available beginning in the middle of June and would be based on the market price of bullion plus a premium.

title: Use of a Caricature Is Disputed
description: A caricature of State Senator Roy M. Goodman became a Federal Court case yesterday, but it was the artist and not Mr. Goodman who raised the fuss.

title: Yanks Top Brewers On 3 Runs in 11th, 52
description: MILWAUKEE, May 30  The game began as an interesting pitching matchup between Tommy John of the Yankees and Mike Caldwell of Milwaukee, but it ended with neither in the game, with the Yankees winning. 52, and with the homeplate umpire, Lou DiMuro, suffering a bruised spine after a collision with Cliff Johnson.

title: TV Look at Brooklyn Holdup Gun Led to New Clues on Bedford Hills
description: It had been a spectacular robbery. Fifty men and women at a Brooklyn birthday party that started last Saturday night and continued into Sunday morning had been forced to take off their clothes and hand over their Jewelry and cash, and now the television was showing closeup of the four weapons the police had recovered, one of them, a .32caliber automatic pistol with a long. slender silencer attached.

title: About Englishtown
description: ENGLISHTOWN, N.J., May 29 These are the days of wine and roses, of scabrous Beetles renewed with engine jobs, of customers politely shaking Jim Ayers's greasy hand and getting on the waiting list to buy, sight unseen, one of the old Volkswagens he hunts down and rejuvenates.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN., The. Seasons: Troika (November), Tchaikovsky; Les Belles Americaines, Waltz, Offenbach; Symphony No. 5, Benda; Ricercare a 3 for Lute and Organ, Willaert.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: W. HERBERT HANNA

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 30, 1979

title: Stress in Spain
description: A crisis born of terrorism threatens Spain's fledgling democracy. Bomb blasts and gunfire took nearly 20 lives last weekend and injured dozens more. The fact that Spain has overcome similar crises while moving away from Franco's authoritarianism is no reason for minimizing the present danger; good luck cannot be counted on at every turn. The new democratic structure remains fragile. Its survival should be a central concern of all free societies.

title: Javits, Visiting Sudan, Says It Will Not Break Relations With Egypt
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, May 30  A special mission sent to the Sudan by the Carter Administration left here today, apparently reassured that President Gaafar alNimeiry would resist Arab pressure to break with Egypt over its peace treaty with Israel.

title: Blue Snow Found Escaping from Strange Jovian Moon
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Wisps of glowing blue material, possibly vented gases, have been detected at several places in the south polar region of lo, more evidence that the moon of Jupiter is an active spectacular world apparently unlike any other in the Solar System.

title: 47% in Poll of Environmentalists Rate Carter's Performance Fair
description: Only two months ago, President Carter was presented with a black and whitestatuette of a whooping crane symbolizing his selection as Conservationist of the Year. But the whooping crane has, metaphorically speaking, developed laryngitis.

title: 3 Aides at Black College Indicted in Pension Inquiry
description: DALLAS, May 30 (UPI)  Three top officials of Bishop College, a small black institution that has been unable to account for as much as $2.8 million in Federal student aid, have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of misapplication of more than $400,000 in pension funds.

title: Carter Drops Blind Trust Secrecy And Divulges Finances for 19789
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  President Carter filed his financial disclosure statement today, lifting the lid from his socalled blind trust in an apparent effort to keep Charles H. Kirbo as the manager of his business affairs.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, May 30, 1979

title: Program to Encourage Private Aid for Cities Gains Funds and Foes
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Urban development action grants, the most popular big program to date in the long succession of Federal efforts to save the cities, are corning under criticism from both the left and the right.

title: Hess Said to Violate U.S. Price Guidelines
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  The Council on Wage and Price Stability said today that the Amerada Hess Corporation, a large oil refining and marketing company, had violated the Government's voluntary pricerestraint standard and had indicated that it would not reduce its prices.

title: Proposed Loan to China Is Canceled at Chase
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that a proposed $30 million credit it was to have extended to China had been canceled at the request of Chinese authorities.

title: Pickford Burial Today; Services Will Be Private
description: HOLLYWOOD, May 30 (AP)  Mary Pickford will be buried tomorrow in the same seclusion she sought during the last 13 years of her life.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, May 31

title: Brown Says Soviet Long Sought Way to Knock Out U.S. Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Secretary of Defense Harold Brown said today that the Soviet Union has long been striving to achieve a capability for making a surprise attack against American landbased missiles.

title: A Tokyo Shoplifting Career Ends
description: TOKYO, May 30 (Reuters)  A Tokyo woman has been arrested for shoplifting goods worth about $455,000 over the last 10 years, police said today. They said the 46-year-old woman sold the articles at 60 percent of their value.

title: Cellist. Eugene Moye
description: IF Eugene Moye's recital at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night was typical of his performances in general  and there is no reason to think otherwise  he must be ranked as one of the foremost cellists of his generation. He is only 27 years old, but his interpretation of Brahms Sonata in D, for example, had an eloquence about it that is not customarily associated with one so young, and the suppleness and sensitivity of his phrasing throughout the recital testified to musicality of the highest order.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Monitor Corporation, an Indianapolisbased manufacturer of bloodanalyzing equipment and chemical reagents, has elected to its board of directors John F. McDonnell, executive vice president of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: Brock Going Home 'satisfied
description: ST. LOUIS, May 30  Lou Brock, nearing birthday No. 40 and hit No. 3,000 in the big leagues, said today that he was not obsessed with setting records in his final season  nor with the fact that his name had been left off the ballot for the AllStar Game.

title: Marriage Announcement 2 -- No Title
description: Lesley Calcutt Ordway Bride of Bernard Lasker

title: NEW YORK HOLDS UP $90 MILLION PROJECT
description: A proposed $90 million renovation of an office building on Lexington Avenue, the most costly such project ever planned in the city, was jeopardized yesterday when city officials refused to grant propertytax abatement to a Canadian developer.

title: Muzorewa Names a Cabinet, Reserving Key Roles for Himself and Smith
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 30 Bishop Abel T. Mutorewa, Rhodesia's new Prime Minister, named his Cabinet today and appointed himself to head the twinned Ministries of Combined Operations and Defense, which control the Government's war effort against black nationalist guerrillas.

title: Theater: Black Festival In Bullins's Miss Marie
description: IT has been eight years since Ed Bullins's The Fabulous Miss Marie was first presented at the New Lafayette Theater. In that time, Mr. Bullins has gone on to write many more plays and the black theater movement, in which he is a leader, has become an even more vital element in the American cultural environment.

title: Obituary 5 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3843800 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUN DAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9:00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 32800; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 35300; NASSAU CO. (818) 7470600; SUFFOLX CO. (516) 6691800 CONNECTICUT (203) 3487787

title: APlant Aides Describe Previous Errors at Key Valves
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Valves were mistakenly closed at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant on a number of occasions before such an error finally crippled the big electric facility, some of the plant's control room operators said today.

title: Call to F.B.I. Warns of Execution For a Detective in F.A.L.N. Inquiry
description: A New York City detective who has played a major role in the investigation of the F.A.L.N., a terrorist group that seeks independence for Puerto Rico, has been marked for execution by the group un- less he stops trying to recapture William Morales, according to a telephone call made early yesterday to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Sports Today
description: Mats vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis. (TelevisionCablevision, 1:30 P.M. RadioWMCA, 1:30 P.M.)

title: 2 Routs Help U.S. Gain Lead In Walker Cup
description: MUIRFIELD, Scotland, May 30 (AP)  The United States took a slim 65 lead over Britain at the start of the Walker Cup golf competition today. Doug Clarke, American teenager, stunned the veteran John Davis with an 8and7 rout, a record for the event.

title: Council Extends the Life Of Golan Heights Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 30 The Security Council voted today to extend the life of the United Nations peacekeeping force that separates Syrian and Israeli forces in the Golan Heights area.

title: Congress Reflects Fuel Crisis Confusion
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Tulsa, Okla., is tine of the major oilproducing centers in the country, a city where petroleum runs in the veins of the body politic.

title: Preserving Loans to Students
description: Student loans are strictly in keeping with the American tradition of people paying their own way to the extent possible. Students should bear part of the cost of their educations. Parents should do their part, Government its part, but students should do their part too, mostly by borrowing against future income.

title: MANY DC10'S CLEAR LATEST INSPECTIONS AND RETURN TO AIR
description: Many of the nation's 138 DC10 widebodied airliners began flying again yesterday, and the bulk of those owned by eight domestic carriers will have completed federally ordered inspections today, according to airline spokesmen.

title: Doughboys Make 60th Meeting Their Last
description: CHICAGO, May 30  The Veterans of Ambulance Company 129, 108th Sanitary Train, 33d Division of the American Expeditionary Force packed it in for good today without Taps or tears.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Precious metals futures traders were unusually cautious yesterday as they awaited the national trade figures for last month, which many had been led to believe would show an improvement. Some of the hesitancy was also traced to the fact that many banks were closed in observance of Memorial Day, thus limiting the financing of transactions.

title: Police in Rome Arrest 2 Linked to Moro Case and Attack on Party Office
description: ROME, May 30  Italian policemen arrested a man and a woman today in the kidnapping and murder of Aldo Moro, the former Prime Minister.

title: World News Briefs
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 30 (UPI) Ugandan officials said today that a skeleton found buried at the village of Kivuvu, east of Kampala, was that of Dora Bloch, a 73yearold woman believed killed by Idi Amin's secret police after the 1976 Israeli rescue raid on Entebbe Airport.

title: There's Just No Safe Way Of Hoarding Gasoline
description: On June 30, 1978, a Mister Softee ice cream truck exploded in a ball of flame and black smoke on crowded corner near City Hall, injuring more than 150 people. New York's bomb squad, looking for evidence of dynamite, found nothing resembling bomb. What they did find in the wreckage was a flattened piece of red and yellow metal, the remains of a twoandahalfgallon can of spare gasoline.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN ANTONIO, May 30  Officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said in Washington today that the search for the killer of Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr. had been expanded to include members of a Texas motorcycle group called the Banditos, some of whom had appeared in narcotics cases in the judge's court.

title: Design Notebook
description: MY most favorite house in New York was sold not long ago and now stands empty. What will become of it is not certain; but it seems a safe bet that, like other houses of its kind all over the Western world, it will lose its original status. What was built as a big onefamily town house will end up, in other words, as an interlock of one or twoperson apartments.

title: Another Opportunity for Maree
description: The National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships will begin today at Champaign, Ill. For Sydney Maree, the threeday meet is the equivalent of an Olympics or World Cup.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  For politicians junketing at public expense this summer, the old ThreeI League (Ireland, Italy and Israel) has been replaced by the People's Republic of China. Their constituents must therefore become instant Chinawatchers. Here are a halfdozen pointers from a notsoOld China Hand:

title: Senate Ethics Unit Asks New Rules on Expenses
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP)  The Senate Ethics Committee, prompted by disclosures at its hearings on alleged financial misconduct by Senator Herman E. Talmadge, is moving to require more documentation of expense claims by senators.

title: HarteHanks to Buy Radio and Records
description: HarteHanks Communications Inc. said it had agreed to purchase, for $12.5 million, Radio and Records Inc., Los Angeles, publisher of a weekly trade publication for radio stations.

title: State Permitting Officer Torsney Frequent Leaves
description: Robert Torsney, the white New York City policeman found not guilty by reason of insanity in the 1976 shooting death of a black Brooklyn teenager, has been permitted by officials of a New York State psychiatric hospital to spend most nights and weekends at his home in Queens instead of in custody.

title: Nixon and Ford Meet the Booksellers
description: LOS ANGELES, May 30  Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford, authors, took some time out from other activities to talk about their books and ideas before American booksellers holding a convention here this week.

title: BUSINESS
description: Higher interest rates on small savings accounts won Federal approval, as did variable rate home mortgages. The interest charge on the mortages would fluctuate with moneymarket rates. By charging rates that reflect their costs of funds, savings and loan associations will be able to pay the higher savings rates. f Page Al.]

title: Industrial Allies Offer Turkey $1.45 Billion
description: PARIS, May 30  The United States and 13 other industrial countries pledged more than $1.45 billion in emergency financial assistance to Turkey today in a bid to shore up the tottering economy of this strategically placed member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Chaminade, Holy Trinity Reach Finals in Baseball
description: OLD WESTBURY, LI., May 30 Chaminade High School of Mineola defeated St. Mary's of Manhasset, 70, and Holy Trinity of Hicksville beat St. John the Baptist of West Islip, 32, in eight innings today to gain the finals of the NassauSuffolk Catholic High School Athletic Association baseball championships at the New York Institute of Technology.

title: Dr. Gregory L Kole, 43, Is Dead; Surgeon at Eye and Ear Hospital
description: Dr. Gregory L. Kole, director of interns and residents at the New York Eye and Ear Hospital, died Monday at the hospital infirmary. He was 43 years old and lived in Lyndhurst, N.J.

title: Jones Beach Music Man To Play June 28Sept. 2
description: The Music Man, a prizewinner on Broadway and an Oscar winner on the screen, will be presented at the Jones Beach Theater, in Wantagh, L.I., beginning June 28 and running through Sept. 2. There will be previews on June 26 and 27.

title: First Chicago Has Meeting in Peking
description: PEKING, May 30 (AP)  Directors of the First Chicago Corporation, a bankholding company, held a public meeting here today said to be the first by a major United States company in China since the Communists came to power in 1949.

title: WatsonLopez Reign
description: Seldom, if ever, have two golfers ruled the game so thoroughly as Tom Watson and Nancy Lopez do today as the monarchs of a new era.

title: The City
description: A 150foot, cityowned barge carrying 575 tons of garbage sank yesterday in the Hudson River as it was being pulled to a Staten Island landfill by Coast Guard cutter.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We are having a problem with the cold water spigots in our country house. For no apparent reason when turned on they run cold for about two seconds. Then the water turns warmtohot for about 40 seconds, after which it turns allcold. One plumber has suggested that maybe the hot and cold water pipes are too close together, but why would this happen after all these years? G.H., New York City.

title: EARNINGS
description: Brascan Ltd., the big Canadian holding company that has just dropped a long bitter battle to take over the F. W. Woolworth Company, yesterday reported a huge drop in firstquarter net income compared with the yearearlier period.

title: Schools Expected to Get More Money in Koch Budget
description: The players in the New York City budget game positioned themselves for final maneuvers yesterday amid indications that the school system would get more money than Mayor Koch had proposed.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Corporate and taxexempt bond prices rose slightly yesterday on light volume, while the Government securities market was shut down because New York banks were closed in observance of Memorial Day.

title: Trading in Fieldcrest Fuels Takeover Rumors
description: In the last two weeks, the price of Fieldcrest Mills Inc. stock has climbed sharply in very active trading, raising speculation on Wall Street that the company is an acquisition target.

title: ChickenSuit Wearer Plucked
description: SAN DIEGO, May 30 (AP)  The 5foot4inch defendant sat in the jury box, his head hooded by a brown paper sack with peepholes. A yellow feather affixed to the top of the sack was the only giveaway that Ted Giannoulas. the defrocked KGB Chicken, was inside.

title: Listing of Summonses For Dumping illegally Made Public by Steisel
description: As part of a stepped up drive against illegal dumping, Norman Steisel, New York City's Sanitation Commissioner, issued yesterday the first of what he said would be a regular public listing of those given summonses for dumping illegally,

title: Sales Favoritism At Gas Stations Stirs Complaints.
description: Scrawled signs reading $2 Limit were taped yesterday to the gasoline pumps of the Shell service station at 7401 Grand Avenue in Elmhurst. Oueens. But aftey rebuffing a passing motorist who wanted more, an attendant pumped $9 worth of gas into the tank of another driver  a young woman who bought quart of oil and seemed to be a regular customer. A third motorist who pulled in immediately afterward was held to the $2 limit.

title: Companies List Their Earnings Reports for Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Investment Company Set
description: development.

title: Japan's Output Of Color TV Up
description: TOKYO, May 30 (AP)  Japan's color television output in April totaled 762,000 units, up 7.4 percent from April 1978 and 10 percent higher than in March, the country's Electronics Industries Association said today.

title: Study Finds Corporations in Broader Political Role
description: Major United States corporations are becoming increasingly active politically as they seek to influence Federal decisions bearing on their business interests.

title: Deaths
description: ABRY  Dr. Jacques. Beloved husband Berthe. Loving father of Claudine Belcher. Devoted grandfather of Susan, Nancy and Diane. Dear brother of Yosef Abramovici. Services were held privately. Contributions in his memory to the Mount Sinai Hospital Stroke Unit would be appreciated.

title: FRENCH ACT TO CURB FLOW OF IMMIGRANTS
description: PARIS, May 30  The French Government pushed a series of measures aimed at curbing immigration through the National Assembly today.

title: Saudis Raise Some Oil by 8.5%
description: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, yesterday caved in to the pressure that has been building within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and started informing its customers that it had raised the price of some of its crude oil by $1.40 a barrel, or 8.5 percent.

title: Vance Bids NATO Speed Decision on Defense Policy
description: THE HAGUE, May 30  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance told the Western allies today that a new round of SovietAmerican arms negotiations would probably begin early next year and that it was therefore crucial for the Atlantic alliance to reach a consensus on nuclear modernization and arms control.

title: Where the Horses Live Like People
description: For a $10 fee, which benefits the Trinity Episcopal Church here, visitors from Connecticut, New Jersey, Kentucky and the Washington, D.C., area discovered that in Virginia hunt country  which boasts more hunts per square mite than any other part of the United States  some horses live in better style than many people.

title: IRAN ARABS BATTLE GOVERNMENT TROOPS IN TWO OIL CENTERS
description: KHURRAMSHAHR, Iran, May 30 Arab residents of this Persian Gulf oil center fought Government troops all day today in sporadic and confusing battles that left at least 21 persons dead.

title: Deaths
description: RITTER  Leo. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun records with sorrow the passing, of our esteemed member, and expresses its heartfelt sympathy to his dear wife and all the members of the bereaved family

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: In a major management change at the BankAmerica Corporation  parent of the Bank of America, the nation's largest, with assets of $94.9 billion the responsibility for the world banking division was transferred yesterday from C.J. Medberry, chairman, to Leland S. Prussia, one of the San Franciscobased company's three vice chairmen.

title: Vonnegut's Jailbird to Detail Picaresque, Complex Character
description: After an absence of three years, Kurt Vonnegut will be making his mark on the fall fiction lists when Delacorte / Seymour Lawrence will bring out Jailbird in September.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  President Carter, beset by the politics of energy, complains that Congress and the public hide from reality on the issue. The American people, he says, have absolutely refused to accept a simple fact. We have an energy crisis. We have shortages of oil. The shortages are going to get worse in the future.

title: Dormitory Bond Sale Tomorrow
description: The Dormitory Authority of New York State is selling $22.5 million of revenue bonds this week to build a graduatestudent residence hall and to refurbish some loft buildings as offices and classrooms at New York University. The taxfree bonds, backed by securities from the university's endowment, yield up to 6 percent.

title: China Talks On Textiles Bog Down
description: PEKING, Thursday, May 31 (AP) The United States and China have not been able to make a pivotal deal on limiting imports of Chinese textiles to the United States, President Carter's special trade representative said today.
